The sound can be termed lush and rich compared to the recording by the composer but it is a very persuasive performance.

I have had an interest in conductor Kirill Kondrashin from his old Medlodya recordings but I was unfamiliar with the recordings from his tenure with the Royal Concertgebouw. This disc holds the Third Symphony of Sergei Prokofiev, based on music from his opera The Fiery Angel. I know of only one other recording of this symphony by Maestro Kondrashin, which was with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Like the CSO recording, this one is driven by fast tempi, which some listeners may find unsettling but, for me, is a powerful reading that captures the drama of the opera.  The timings are 11:51, 6:17, 7:24, and 6:03(with applause included). (Neemi Jarvi, by contrast, clocks in at 14:36, 7:06, 8:02, and 6:26).The disc includes Dmitri Shostakovich’s Ninth Symphony, a composer with whom Maestro Kondrashin worked closely with in the 1960’s.  The performance is filled with the sort of wit and humor one associates with the Ninth. The Concertgebouw play the music lovinglyBoth are live recordings (from 1975 and 1980) and have no audience noise except for applause at the conclusion. The recordings are clear and well-balanced.  This year marks the centennial of the birth of Kirill Kondrashin (March 6) and hopefully there will be many reissues of his recordings to mark the occasion.

Jep Gambardella is a successful journalist and novelist whose only book (titled The Human Apparatus), written when he was in his 20s, was wildly successful but he has not found himself able to write another. He is admired and is wealthy, living in an apartment in Rome opposite the Coliseum. Jep is a member of a broad intellectual circle of writers, actors, directors etc who enjoy the good life and party the night away. At the start of the film, Jep is celebrating his 65th birthday, and he begins to take stock of his life. He receives new that his first love, Lorena, has died. He husband has found a diary where Stefania names Jep as the love of her life while her husband was a mere good companion.  The film takes us into Jep’s life and we watch as he spends his days walking the streets of Rome, observing the life around him, and have brief affairs.  Jep’s view of life comes during a voice over, as he is walking, and explains that when he came to Rome at 26, he decided that he wanted to become “the king of the high life.” However, he did not want to be a spectator at these parties but have the power to make them fail. The Great Beauty (La Grande Bellezza) is episodic with one scene flowing into another randomly. Jep’s character is very engrossing and I found his conversations and action interesting. One such scene is where his disparages, in a nice way, a fellow-writer Viola at a dinner party. One feels that his comments are on target, even if his observations are cruel.  The camera is simply an observer and watching the film you might wonder where the film is going.  Simply put, we are just observers of Jep’s life.  He has an affair with Ramona, the daughter of an old friend who owns a strip club.  His daughter Romona is performing while Jep is there and together they spend a few nights together.  He takes Romona on a magical late night visit to the museums and palaces of Rome, courtesy of another friend, Stefano (Giorgio Pasotti).  She has some insight into Jep and says that his writer’s block is due to his life in Rome. But as quickly as Romona enters Jep’s life, she disappears.  There are some comic elements in the film. Jep’s editor is a smart talking woman dwarf who is also a good cook and Jep at one point is set to interview a 104-year old with two cooked teeth.Toni Servillo is fabulous as Jep and Sabrina Ferilli (Romona) crafts a marvelous performance. One wishes she had more screen time.  The biggest star of the film would have to be the city of Rome, which is treated as a place of beauty but also a state of mind. An actor friend of Jep tells him late in the film that he is leaving Rome for his home town because he can’t function any more.  Director Paolo Sorrentino has been likened to Frederico Fellini (my wife agrees) but he uses comedy more in his films than Fellini, and while The Great Beauty can be termed an updated version of La Dolce Vita, Sorrentino has his own style.  I can recall the interest and excitement with a new file by Fellini opened and I felt the same feeling anticipating The Great Beauty. I am looking forward to his films to come.

This set of the orchestral music of Sergei Rachmaninov is an excellent buy with some very fine performances. My first encounter with these recording was the single disc issue of the Second Symphony, a performance that I have always recommended to new listeners of classical music for the mastery of the reading. Ashkenazy at times rushes the music (compare to Andre Previn with the RPO and Valery Gergiev with the LSO) first movement is rushed in places where the music needs to be more expansive but the passionate playing by the Concertgebouw is impressive. The Scherzo is powerfully dramatic but works best when not the tempo is not pushed and Adagio is beautifully soaring and lyrical. The performance of the Symphonic Dances and Isle of the Dead are both superb readings. The Symphonic Dances are colorful and lively but also captures the darkness of the music as few performances succeed in doing.  The Isle of the Death is supremely gloomy and atmospheric, leading to a devastating climax. Vladimir Ashkenazy and the Concertgebouw performThe Third Symphony receives an exciting reading of Rachmaninov’s most nostalgic work.  The Concertgebouw is very responsive to the fast/slow tempi and give an exciting performance.  The best performance of the set is The Bells, which was Rachmaninov’s favorite among all of his works. Ashkenazy’s reading is inspired with fabulous playing from the Concertgebouw. His soloists, Natalia Troitskaya, Ryszard Karczykowski and Tom Krause, perfectly express the mood of the poems.The First Symphony is among my favorites of any composer.  The reading by Ashkenazy is very good for the first three movements, which are beautifully played with passion and power.  However, the Finale is a huge disappointment with plodding tempi. Entirely missing is the drama and sense of doom (the so-called ride to the abyss) that was captured by Evgengy Svetlanov, whose recording with his own USSR Symphony Orchestra is the best performance of this symphony. For me, it seems that Ashkenazy wishes to avoid the forward thrust of the music as it ends in a cataclysmic crash of the gong.Aside from the First Symphony, this is an excellent set with much to like in the performances. There are other recordings of Rachmaninov’s music that have finer performances, Kiril Kondrahin in the Symphonic Dances and Evgengy Svetlanov in The Bells, to name two but the Ashkenazy set is one that needs to be on everyone’s self as well.

My first recording of the Mahler Fourth was the Fritz Reiner/CSO on an RCA Living Stereo LP but I have not heard any recordings of the music in recent years. I tended to think of the Fourth as a charming precursor to Gustav Mahler’s more essential symphonies. It always was the most approachable of Mahler’s symphonies for its short length and lyrical melodies. Most conductors take a sweet approach, particularly with the final movement where the soprano soloist sings about all the delights of heaven. This recording by the Berlin Philharmonic and Claudio Abbado has changed my mind.  This is a bold reading that brings that is always thrusting forward and more than hints at the music to come.I have read a couple of reviews (not at Amazon) that are aghast that Abbado has turned a charming piece of music into something brusque and jarring.  However, it seems to me that it is valid to perform the music with emphasis on the drama.  Renee Fleming sings the Finale with luminous beauty. Her voice was criticized as being too heavy and not the imitation of a child in Heaven; rather this is a straightforward reading of the scoreThe first movement is performed at a brisk tempo, sounding playful at times and mysterious.  The Scherzo is lovingly played giving voice to the humor in the dance melody but also the darker hues of the brass.For me, Maestro Abbado’s reading of the Adagio (especially the way he takes the dramatic crescendo with the trumpets sounding mournful) places the Fourth in context with the Fifth Symphony, and hinting at things to come in the Seventh  It shows that Mahler was exploring new tonalities and textures and that his thoughts were in transition to something new.The inclusion of Alban Berg’s Seven Early Songs provides an opportunity to hear more from Renee Fleming, and the song themselves make a wonderful accompaniment to the symphony.  The Berlin Philharmonic responds beautifully to Abbado’s lead.  The recording is clear and provides wonderful detail of the BPO soloist.

Locating this disc at Amazon was quite a surprise. I enjoy recordings of composers conducting/performing their own music, and I had no idea that Jacques Ibert had recorded any of his music. The opening selection is Ibert’s famous Escales, composed in 1922 and prompted by his own travels. The performance is colorful and atmospheric, beautifully played by the Orchestre duTheatre National de l’Opera de Paris.  The musicians respond to Ibert with enthusiasm making this a performance to match others to. The ballet Les Amours de Jupiter was first performed in 1949 to a scenario by Boris Kochno, based on the loves of the god Jupiter from the Metamorphosis of Ovid. Jupiter has romantic encounters in turn with Europa, Leda, Danae and, finally, Ganymede. The ballet consists of an overture and five tableaux featuring each of Jupiter’s conquests with him returning to Juno in the final tableaux.  The music is Jacques Ibert at his best; a lyrical and engaging score beautifully orchestrated.  Escales and Jupiter were recorded in 1954 while Ibert was Director of the Academie de France. The sound is very good mono. The percussion in Valencia seems placed too close to a microphone but, otherwise, the balance is good and there are no distortions.The Chansons de Don Quichotte was part of a film project directed by G. W. Pabst (famous for Pandora’s Box). Unknown to Ibert, the music for the film was a competition between him, Ravel, Milhaud and Delannoy: Ibert was the winner. However, the film was abandoned when funding ran out. A recording of the songs was made in 1933 with Feodor Chailiapin. The texts for the songs (not included with the CD) are poems by Ronsard and Alexandre Arnoux.  Chailiapin was at the end of his career when the songs were recorded but he is in fine voice and sings with real passion. The sound is clear and free from any distortion.

I have not had a recording of the Rachmaninov Third Symphony for a few years and after reading the reviews at Amazon, decided on the Petrenko.  For me, the attraction is the inclusion of the Caprice bohemien, a colorful early work, (composed during 1892 – 94) based on gypsy themes.  The inspiration for the work was the enchanting Anna Lodyzhenska who was of Gypsy parentage. The Caprice is dedicated to his friend and Anna’s husband Pyotr Lodyzhensky. The young Rachmaninov seems to have been under her spell at the time and would later dedicate his First Symphony to Anna, discreetly using only her initials. The Caprice and First Symphony have in common the heavy use of percussion and orchestral tutti passages. Petrenko and the Royal Liverpool turn is a wonderful performance fully of Gypsy charm.  The orchestral only version of Vocalise comes from Rachmaninov’s middle period and receives a sensitive and lilting performance from the Rpyal Liverpool.Sergei Rachmaninov composed his Third Symphony during 1935-36 at his home in Switzerland and Philadelphia. The symphony has had treated unkindly by some musicologists dismissing it as a failure. Perhaps the reason behind this assessment is that the symphony is a transitional work where the composer continues the sparer style he first adopted in his Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini. The Symphony was received with mixed emotion by the premiere audience which was probably anticipating the lush sound of his Second Symphony and Second and Third Piano Concerti.Vasily Petrenko and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra deliver a straightforward and elegant performance of the symphony with plenty of energy and pathos.  I do find some of Petrenko’s tempi choices a bit rushed in the first movement and some of the passages poorly phrased. This new recording enters a crowded field of fine recordings that include Leopold Stokowski, Vladimir Ashkenazy, Evgeny Svetlanov and Mariss Jansons.  The Royal Liverpool may not be the best orchestral but Petrenko gets some fine playing form them. While this is not my most memorable recording of the Third, I will be listening to this performance again.  The sonic are superb and the orchestra is well balanced..

I went to see Philomena with a bare outline of the story, expecting a story that would be very sad. Surprisingly, there is much humor in the film, anger about what had been done to Philomena with much understanding and forgiveness.(spoils below)The story of Philomena begins in Ireland in 1952 when she becomes pregnant as a teenager.  Although it is not shown in the film, her family puts her in a convent. At no time are we aware of any feelings on the part of her family toward her. Apparently, she was cast out because of her pregnancy. Philomena must work in the convent for four years, performing backbreaking labor in the convent laundry, seven days a week. Philomena has a son, who she names Anthony and the nuns force her to sign a document relinquishing her parental rights and agree to never attempt to contact her son. Anthony is adopted, along with a girl, by an American couple for a ten hefty fee of $1,000.The story of the film is Philomen’s search for her son fifty years later. She is joined by journalist Martin Sixsmith, who has been forced to resign from his job.  Martin is looking for something to do and agrees to write a book about Philomena’s quest to find her son. The humor of the film comes from the relationship between Martin and Philomena. She loved to read romance novels and recount the plots to Martin, who would is more into Shakespeare. For years, Philomena has visited the convent hoping that she could persuade the nuns to allow her to have the location of her son. The adoption records have been destroyed in a fire but as Martin discovers they were burned by the nuns themselves. The search for her son takes Philomena and Martin to Washington D. C. but, unknown to her, Philomena’s son has been searching for her.(end of spoilers)Comedian Steve Coogan is the driving force behind the film, having read the book by Martin Sixsmith and realized the screen possibilities. Coogan co-authored the screen play with Sixsmith, as well as producing the film and is perfect in portraying Sixsmith on screen. Dame Judy Dench is wonderful as Philomena, portraying her as a strong and determined woman who is strong in her Catholic faith, remaining conflicted over being forced to give up her son. She truly becomes and not plays Philomena. The film is beautifully directed by Stephen Frears with some great cinematography.  When I saw the film, the audience was completely in awe of the film, and everyone sat quietly while the ending credits rolled.  Philomena is one of those films that one thinks about for a long time afterwards.

York Bowen was a performing musician as well as a composer and was at professional standards on the piano (he was the first pianist to record Beethoven’s Fourth Piano Concerto), viola and French horn. His First Symphony is a student work from 1902. The music is very assured for an 18-year old with beautiful lyrical melodies. The symphony is in three movements, which was innovative for the time and requires a small orchestra. The symphony was not performed during Bowen’s lifetime and had its first in 2010.The First Symphony is not spectacular and one feels that York Bowen is seeking to imitate the styles of older contemporaries.  The music is well orchestrated, Romantic in style, with an individual voice. There is a lovely clarinet solo that opens the second movement and has some interesting melodic interplay between the soloists. The Finale, much like the prior movements, has colorful melodies, beginning with a slow melody and a brisk second subject to conclude: charming but not especially memorable.The Second Symphony was composed in 1909, reverting to the usual four movements, when Bowen was 25 and was first performed in 1912. The music is more assured and mature than the First; it begins with a dramatic motto that leads into an energetic Allegro.  The music is heroic and beautifully developed, and concluding with a powerful chord.  The Lento second movement is gently lyrical with a passionate melody introduced by a horn solo, rising to a climax and returning to the quiet first melody. The Scherzo is magical with an engaging quick-silver melody. The Finale radiates good humor and energy with a triumphant melody that is developed by the orchestra, concluding with a flourish by the full orchestra.Sir Andrew Davis and the BBC Philharmonic turn in terrific performances.  I was more familiar with York Bowen’s piano works and his piano concertos. The Second Symphony is a fabulous work that needs to be performed more often; the first, while it has some great melodies does not have the engagement of the Second.

I think that Bounty paper towels are the best quality and I especially like the select-a-size, but they are on the expensive side when I buy them in a super market. Ordering in bulk from Amazon is the most economical way I've found to purchase Bounty, although they arrive in a huge carton and you do have to store them. I have a big closet so storage is not a problem, but if you live in a tiny apartment this buying option may not be for you.

I generally dislike air fresheners because their scent is usually overpowering and/or merely covers up odors rather than actually eliminating them. Not so with Fresh Wave. This stuff is excellent. First, it has no noticeable scent of its own, which is a huge plus. Second, there's no mess and no reason for the container to be placed in a visible area. The product uses no fans and thus avoids using electricity, something that appeals to my conservation sensibilities.You just open the seal, place the perforated cover back on the jar and then secrete the container in a corner or the bathroom, cellar or other area that warrants freshening. After about three months, the jar will be empty. The little gel crystals it contained will have done their job and then evaporated. All you do is toss out the jar and replace it with a fresh one.

There are some interesting insights in this book, which I had hoped to use as a text for a graduate course I teach on marketing sustainable behaviors. Since traditional marketing is about encouraging consumption, it seemed to me that theories of consumption would be a good place to begin an analysis of the possible ways one might conduct "anti-marketing" (if you will) campaigns to encourage sustainable consumer behavior. While I believe this idea remains valid, this particular book on consumption is not the best source for such an endeavor.Certainly, author Daniel Miller cannot be held accountable for my failure to accurately assess the contents of his book from the Amazon Vine description. Nor should prospective readers assume, as I did, that the book's content would be presented in the same style as Miller's intriguing website, Stuff. This text does, in fact, provide some useful information about consumption and its drivers, a topic that Miller has researched throughout his career.I found, however, that the format and the organization of the book are wanting in that the chapters appear to be sequenced without much regard to helping readers know where to look for specific topics of interest. One is, apparently, not meant to dip in and out of this volume, but is expected to read it straight through. I find this annoying considering that the book is billed as a presentation of research and should, therefore, have an easy way for readers to isolate particular subjects. In addition, the book opens and closes with an extended, imagined conversation among three characters called Mike, Grace and Chris. I find devices such as this tiresome and wish that Miller had been more straightforward in presenting his theories and laying out his main observations.My final quibble is that Miller uses the consumer culture of Trinidad and shopping patterns in London to illustrate more general points, a technique which seems unnecessarily narrow. He then proceeds to round out his view of consumption by taking just one example of a product -- denim -- and examining why people tend to purchase so much of it. While this is admittedly interesting, it doesn't do much to help readers get a full picture of the drivers of consumption and how our supposed greed for denim translates to our more general greed for everything else.In summary, Consumption and Its Consequences is a good book and worthy of a place on the shelves of academics and serious observers of today's social habits and values. But its title, marketing descriptions and format are unclear and leave something to be desired.

Like author Paul Handstedt, I too found myself living in Hong Kong for an extended period, also in the New Territories working on the campus of the Chinese University of Hong Kong. Unlike Handstedt, however, I went solo, as a faculty member accompanying a small group of graduate students who were doing summer internships in that city. I found Hong Kong to be a cosmopolitan, exciting city with a deeply interesting culture that arose out of its history as a cross-roads of world trade, and therefore of humanity. Thanks to immigration, trade and the Pearl River Delta's new status as the "workshop of the world," Hong Kong has emerged as a prototype of the city of the future. And, its dreadful weather notwithstanding, I loved it.Handstedt's Hong Kong experience was, on the other hand, fraught with worry, nearly all of it caused by the headaches associated with getting his children settled in a foreign environment. Thus, his memoir of Hong Kong felt to me unnecessarily critical of the place and the people. I'm not saying that he was wrong to worry about his kids. If I had children of my own I would probably have worried about mine too. But the constant references to his domestic tragedies -- finding a school, maneuvering a stroller on a city bus -- didn't do much to interest me, nor did I find them particularly humorous.So, I would say that Hong Konged is an OK read, but nothing to go out of one's way for. This is a book that might appeal more to those with children, who can perhaps identify with the author in ways that I could not.

You wouldn't think that a clothes pin bag would be important enough to warrant much thought. However, I have a friend who has a cottage on a lake and always has a dozen or so people hanging out there on weekends in the warm weather. Together, we produce mounds of laundry...everything from bathing suits and towels to sheets, clothing and table cloths. And we're always running out of clothes pins. We either lose them in the grass or stick them in a coffee can and then misplace the can.This clothes pin holder has made life easier. It holds a lot and is made out of a heavy Cordura-like fabric that stands up to rain, dirt and other outdoor offenses. The best thing is that it hangs on the line so you can always find the pin holder when you need to hang something. The only criticism I have is that this holder is not well balanced, so it can flop around a lot when it's hanging on the line. If it's full of pins, some usually fall out because the bag tips in a good wind.

No matter what I do, my dishwasher always seems to smell a bit funky. And I've tried many different products to keep its inside clean and odor free, including expensive products and old-fashioned home solutions such as white vinegar. Another thing that I like about this product is that you get 24 treatments out of a single bottle. It works quite well and doesn't cost a fortune, so it is my current dishwasher cleaner of choice.

The Hydro Silk is a truly great product. I use it most every day and have never had such a close, easy shave. This Schick has four separate blades, which is one more than my former favorite razor, which was also a Schick but only had three blades. And the blades are called "silk" for a reason. There is a little bar of lotion at the top of the blade cartridge that makes the blades slide smoothly over your skin.The cartridge is easy to install and remove and each one seems to last a long time. I only have to change blades a couple of times a month. I highly recommend this product.

The best thing about this muscle wrap is that you can open it up and use it right away. It is already cold, without the necessity of freezing it first. And it wraps easily around arms, legs, etc...wherever you need it.After its coolness wears off, you just put it back into its pouch, add two tablespoons of water and seal it up. In a few hours, it's ready to be used again, all nice and cool without ever having to go into a refrigerator. I take this in my backpack or in the car when going on an extended road trip. Make a great addition to your portable first aid kit.So far, I've used it four or five times and it still works well.

If you don't own any other books on paranormal experiences, including reincarnation, mediumship, apparitions and OBEs, this is a good overview to have on your bookshelf. Author Chris Carter begins this survey in the late 1800s, when the British Society of Physchical Research (and later its spin off the American Society)began to systematically research the claims of spiritualists that they could communicate with the dead. He moves through the 20th century, covering hauntings, dreams, the more recent 'new age' beliefs and figures such as Jane Roberts, who claimed to channel a spirit named Seth who told her what life was like on the other side.Most of the material that Carter includes has been extensively covered elsewhere, but not in a single volume. Some of the paranormal accounts he discusses are quite convincing. One such is the work of a professor at the University of Virginia named Ian Stevenson, whose book "20 Cases Suggestive of Reincarnation" is a classic and whose research methods are rigorous and based on the scientific method.Some of the material in this book gives one pause in terms of its credibility. Although no one can prove that life after death exists, there is definitely a good deal of evidence for something that today's science can't account for. Arthur C. Clarke said, "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic." Perhaps some of the stories that Carter recounts here are just examples of natural phenomena that our technology does not allow us to understand. That does not, however, make these accounts any less intriguing.

This account by a physician of his post-death experience differs from most other accounts in several meaningful ways. First, and most important in my view, is that the author presents detailed medical facts about his condition prior to what he asserts was his physical death. He presents convincing evidence that his brain was completely dead and displayed no electrical activity whatsoever. Second, he is absolutely certain that he was indeed dead and his account of his experience includes a great deal of detail that I have never seen in the memoirs of others -- and I have read scores of books on this topic. Finally, unlike many other people who have undergone post- or near-death experiences, Dr. Alexander's medical training and understanding of the human brain makes him a highly credible judge of what actually happened to him. I am not implying that others are not credible; only that this particular author has a degree of knowledge that most others lack and therefore he has more information on which to base his analysis.Whatever you choose to believe, it is quite clear that this doctor experienced some highly unusual phenomena, not just because he claims to have seen 'heaven' but because he was brain dead and then, rather suddenly, revived *with all of his mental functions intact.* Several physicians who attended him are quoted in the book as saying they have no idea how someone in his condition could regain 100% function, but he definitely did. And he has been subjected to entire batteries of medical tests in an effort to ascertain just how his body was able to do this -- all to no avail. Some might call it a miracle. Overall, Dr. Alexander's story is absorbing and a worthwhile read.One more thing to the credit of this book is that it has an excellent bibliography from which interested readers can identify other books on this and similar topics. For me, the question of life after death was not resolved by reading this book, but it did go a good way toward opening up new avenues of inquiry and presenting some ideas that I had not previously considered.

I love Woodstock chimes.  I have several and honestly will no longer buy any other.  But Saturn was a little bit of a disappointment.  It is not robust like I am used to.  It is long, which I wanted for a corner of the eaves of the house, but the pipes are small in diameter.  I knew there were only four as I read up before I purchased.  But smaller pipes = less dynamic resonating tone.  I will keep as it is probably "good" for one that will be closer to where the neighbors might hear.  And as with all Woodstock, I know the quality will last.

I am 67 so I have used a lot of maskara over the years. I needed to make a change because my eyelashes that have always been long and thick, were thinning. Got this for a small office.  Perfect for a cupboard and for carrying with everything needed.  Women like tools too, but we do not need a rolling tool box or even a big metal one with things you will never use.  Keeping it simple!  Opens wide and has great exterior pockets

Perfect size for deli cut meats and cheeses in your fridge drawer or shelf.A nice flat bottom and top that makes stackable.You can see just what you are looking for.Heavy glass that will suffer through any mistreatment.Food tastes better in glass.My next trick will be to use them to bake mini cakes. Good working cart cart for home or office.  Sturdy metal and heavy plastic, but not too heavy to move around including stairs if necessary.  Put together yourself, but is tight so does not wiggle apart with use. Easy to clean even when used outside.
