This is the one!- One zipper- Unzips down each side to open to accordion, top loading- light - easy to pick up, move, load in car- heavy nylon canvas with leather- heavy duty, well designed wheels- heavy duty handle that will go completely within body- leather carrying handle- detachable, heavy duty comfort over-the-shoulder strap- contoured edges for no snags with suits, chairs- can conveniently sit next to chair at conference- front pocket for pens, cards so no loss or need to carry anything else- ability to lock one zipper and enclose handle for air travelDoes not say and picture makes it hard to tell, but this is black

My 3rd Woodstock Chime and just as beautiful as the other two.  This chimes always come with a story of their creation and the notes used.  And they are perfectly tuned so will always send a pleasant and spiritual melody year-round.  My older two have been outside, in California sun, for over two years and they look like new - even the wood part that is quality finished.  Woodstock creates a robust look and sound that would be welcomed by anyone, male or female......no dainty chime here!

I wanted something comfortable that I could slip into.  This slipper went way beyond my expectations.  The incredible Isotoner insole with a hard outer sole great for quick trips outside.  And the knit sweater fabric is softly lined so it does not stretch out, but hugs like you would expect from a sweater.  The fit is true to size (go down, not up) so you will not slip when wearing.  I love the warm color for winter - just enough brown with a hint of red.  These and a cup of coffee make mornings perfect!

Large, thought provoking inspiration.  Recommended for those couples especially in later years with commitments that are beyond words.....these are the words.  A great size to group with a landscape or family photos.  Probably something you will only buy once for that special person....but be sure and do it!
Very difficult compact to open.  The color is off from other Revlon products of the same name.  It is creamy, but that doesn't help the color.

This is the second ornament I have purchased from The Comfort Company; even more beautiful than the first.  Large, beautifully crafted with exquisite detail.  The birdhouse dangles for a touching movement.  It not only comes is a matching purple organza bag, it contains the story of the company and how it was founded to fulfill a need....sometime they have certainly done.  Heart touching and certainly not just for Christmas....this "ornament" will be cherished in a place of honor for years to come for anyone who receives.  Thank you Comfort Company for helping me with the difficult task of giving a part of my heart.

This is my fourth hat purchased as a gift.  This is perfect for men or women to walk the dog, pick up wood from outside at night, or just walking in the rain.  Lights are perfectly positioned for down (reading) or forward or both.  I use it to shut off my water or feeding the critters at night - hands free.
OK, but not great quality for the money.  Took a long time to get since not Amazon delivery.
If you want a flavorful fiber bar, this is it.  The low calories improves the taste so as not to be too fatty or sugary.  Fiber One has actually lowered their price which has made it even better yet!
A wonderful comprehensive book on all gems and minerals.  Beautiful, complete pictures.  This makes a great gift.
A bargain purchase of one of my favorite snacks.  Veggie are great taste and light on the salt.  A better way to chip it!
Ok but too surgary and grainy for my taste.  If you want a sugar high....this will do it.
Still my favorite filling, low calorie snack.  Good fiber and some nutritional value as well.  Great for the price
Not the best quality, but certainly a good price.  Stick with the more expensive Q tip brand.

Perfect size to use as a foot-wash for tired, rough feet.10-minute soak in 1 cup of Listerine, 1 cup of white vinegar and 2 cups of warm water;  double or triple to allow enough for soak.  This will help soften and feel tingly, but be aware....there may be a little blue left behind on your feet :)
A wonderful, flavorful fruit snack.  Like eating juice.  Convenient for putting in your purse or car and 80 calories is the right portion for me.  Better than sugary stuff with no value.

This is my favorite even for my now gray hair.  I have used Nice & Easy for years - even before the gray and seriously, my hair is better for it.  Still think, full, soft and glossy....especially right after dying.  It is simple and easy to use.  Get a shade lighter than desired if you have no gray.  Stay with the correct color if you are gray, but just dye the gray part first and longer.  You will be happy with the evenness as well as the blend of colors that makes it natural looking.  People still do not guess that I am actually gray!

I hope I'm not giving too much away when I say that "kill" as in "Kill the Boy Band" is used in both senses, and it explores the scenario: What would you do if your friends kidnapped and held the least popular (think Ringo) member of your favorite boy band hostage? This is more original than the popular: "What would you do if two guys were insanely in love with you, and they both had superpowers?" theme in young adult lit, so I was interested in reading this. This book is quite dark, and there are flaws, but at least the premise is one I have not read about before in this genre.The narrator, who I will call N (not to be snarky, but because she is nameless), is a teen fan of a Brit boy band called "The Ruperts," (so called because the four members all share the first name). The Ruperts formed as the result of a reality TV show and has the requisite members: one talented one, one dim but hunky one, etc. N's popular best friend from school, Erin, is also a fan, though she keeps that side of her secret with everyone but N. They have two other friends/fans, with whom they mostly interact online: Apple, a wealthy Third-World orphan with body issues, and Isabel, who lives to post foul-mouthed tweets and update her website with Ruperts' gossip. When the book opens, the girls have managed to get a room at the NY hotel where the band is staying to perform a concert. The hostage situation happens unexpectedly, and by the end of the evening, Twitter has exploded, and the girls have a rather big problem on their hands.As mentioned, this is a dark read, and the ending is less than happy.  N. repeatedly claims that the secret of a boy band's success is that they make fans happy, but these four girls seemed anything but.  I enjoyed the running joke of N. giving fake names from popular eighties' movies whenever she met someone, but I found the lack of character development to be frustrating. Each girl seemed to have an equally valid motive for the crime, but none of them seemed sympathetic enough for me to be on their side throughout the book.  Overall, it was an interesting premise but a disappointing execution.

OK, let me see if I have at least some of the rules straight of "Fae World," or Aurora, from where two teen brothers, Callum and Judah, arrive and promptly form a love triangle with a Californian boarding school girl named Noa (no one in this book has a normal name even the Earthlings) in "Shattered Blue."1. The Fae (fairy folk) are each known by a color (such as Red Son), which corresponds to a superpower. The Clear Fae were long thought to have no powers whatsoever, but this turned out to be false. When they discovered they were being so brainwashed, they unsurprisingly rebel, and currently, there is tension between the groups. The brothers' family is right in the midst of the turmoil.2. There is a Portal between the world of Aurora and our reality. Or maybe several. This book answers the question: What happens when a Gatekeeper is hurled through his own Portal? The Portal has an appetite and needs to be fed on a regular basis with humans (of either world), in order to ensure that the Auroran visitors can keep staying in our world. The Portal is guarded by a man who appears to be the gardener at Noa's school but who is magic.3. There is a character who is actually from Aurora, but for some reason, no one figures this out until the end when they are told directly. This character's life is then put at risk, and this is the cliffhanger the first book ends on.When the first volume of this trilogy) opens, Noa is reeling from the loss of her older sister, Isla, who died in a freak accident saving Noa's life. Her parents, especially her mother, Hannah, a travel writer, are depressed and absorbed in their own issues; it's left to Noa to care for her spunky toddler sister, Sasha. But soon she has more to distract her, when two brothers with Fae powers arrive, and need her help to overcome their feud. There are betrayals, misunderstandings, two evil Fae folk who work as strippers, a homecoming float, and more.Overall: This author certainly has a jaw-dropping imagination - I would need to read "Shattered Blue" twice in order to get every aspect of the world-building straight.  However, I found the main "action" seemed to come out of nowhere, and I wasn't too fond of the insta-love, particularly since we don't learn much about Callum before they're deeply involved.  On the other hand, I would likely have enjoyed all the melodrama if I'd read this book as a teen, so my combined rating is four stars.

After Bella becomes a widow, is laid off from her job as a science teacher, and runs out of other options, she packs her five-year-old son, Max, into their car and prepares to drive to her mother-in-law's home, though she has never been close to her. But when a series of coincidences, including a double spotting of a pregnant cat (who they wind up adopting), plus a billboard that turns out to advertise a place that doesn't exist in reality, the two end up taking a detour to Lily Dale, a town in New York State which is full of psychics and other New Age gurus, in which such things as ghosts are taken seriously. To her surprise, Bella winds up getting a job managing the hotel she first stays at, as its owner has recently passed (but it's believed that she was drowned). The proprietor, Odelia, who gives her the job seems not to believe Bella when she insists she is only staying temporarily, and indeed events seem to be conspiring to keep her in Lily Dale. Soon a whole cast of quirky characters are queuing up to befriend and assist Bella, but when a private investigator arrives and starts digging into the case,, Bella realizes she may be in the midst of a mystery - and in the presence of the perp. Is the killer one of the seemingly friendly souls who live in Lily Dale, or perhaps a tourist? Whoever it is, time is running out.I wasn't familiar with this mystery series, and so I first thought "A Lily Dale Mystery" referred to the main detective.  I liked it much better than the first Wendy Corsi Staub book I read (A Perfect Stranger).  Overall, though the pacing got bogged down in the middle of the book, I enjoyed discovering Lily Dale, its cast of oddballs, and Bella herself, who finds that sensing ghosts just may bring a final connection to her deceased husband.

Eve's son, Tyler, was born with a genetic condition that leaves him hyper-sensitive to light, in which an excess of the wrong kind could leave him disabled or even dead. Since his diagnosis, his mom has devoted her life to trying to make Tyler's life as "ordinary" as possible, even if it means shortchanging her husband, David, and mercurial older daughter, Melissa. (This set-up will be familiar to any fan of Jodi Picoult, but the author does provide some twists of her own.) When "The Deepest Secret" opens, Eve is managing all right, but when their neighbor, Amy, an eleven-year-old, goes missing and later turns up dead, a wide net of suspicion is cast upon the neighborhood residents, many of whom have known each other for years. This affects each of the four family members in different ways: David comes to realize the extent of how Eve has excluded him in caring for their son; Melissa is absorbed with adolescent issues that may or may not be tied to the mystery; Tyler stays busy scouting the neighborhood under the guise of taking photos at night; and Eve herself, is attempting to cover up her role in Amy's disappearance, even if it means lying to her distraught friend. Along with Tyler, we come to realize that just about everyone in this book is hiding something, but whether it's of a nature that the police would be interested in tying to this case is another story."The Deepest Secret," definitely puts a new slant on the standard missing-person-throws-otherwise-placid-neighborhood-in-uproar plot, with its exploration of how Tyler's condition affects the family dynamics. In addition, the author does scatter red herrings liberally about, but because many of the secondary characters are undeveloped (I had difficulty keeping them all straight), it is difficult to care about the more peripheral ones. But as the reader learns who the perp is early on in the story, the tension revolves around whether or not he will willingly come forward and confess. Though the reasons this is delayed are inexcusable, it still makes sense for this character.  Overall, it would have been better if it had been more tightly focused, but it is still an absorbing read.

"A Line of Blood," achieves what all good book titles should aim for: multiple meanings.  "Blood" refers to heritage (one of the main characters, Max, is the only son of Alex Mercer, who's also an only son, etc.), and also to the fact that Alex and Max stumble upon a crime scene in the first pages.  Unfortunately, the rest of the book is mediocre and not framed as a mystery at all.One morning chasing their cat, Alex and Max discover their neighbor, Bryce, at his home in what looks like suicide, but the police decide to probe further.  It turns out that Alex's wife, Millicent, may or may not have been involved with Bryce, and so both adults become suspects.  There aren't many other suspects in the book; the main one being their elderly neighbor, Mr. Ashani, who Alex has never cared for.  As the investigation is carried out, the reader learns of the secrets and past trauma in the Mercer family, which includes infidelity, SID and indiscreet journal writings/drawings.  When the book opens, the couple is managing all right, but the murder begins to bring problems they had suppressed to light again.  They must also deal with the effect on Max, but it may be that getting him professional help is not nearly enough.  Will the Mercer family be able to hold it together during this time, and perhaps even manage to cover up each other's actions.The book does not really focus on whodunit; instead it looks at the various sins of the past for both Alex and Millicent and examines how the present stress has a negative impact on their family.  There is a lot of dialogue that is more like banter, which is not surprising when you learn that the author is also a TV producer.  Just about everyone curses freely, including the child, which is sometimes intended as being "affectionate" and other times hostile. (Multiple times, the child refers to his mother as a term rhyming with "brother-tucker," and he also adds endearments that rhyme with "witch" and "shunt.")  I did not care for any of the main characters (and yes, partly because of their language), and found myself skimming as I progressed through the story.  I also thought one plot point, in which they do something expressly forbidden by the detectives to be unrealistic. By the end, I was thoroughly tired of the characters, their banter and their problems, though how it was resolved was a surprise to me and not a traditional mystery-type ending.

When Eden is assaulted by her older brother's best friend, Kevin, (several hours after playing a game of Monopoly), she's understandably conflicted and unsure of whether to report it, particularly since he has threatened her to keep silent. And although she is angry at her parents for not protecting her and her brother for continuing to (unknowingly) socialize with a rapist, Eden cannot explain the reason for her personality changes in the aftermath to them. Formerly, a good student and member of the school band, Eden, along with her best friend Mara, begins to experiment with boys, alcohol, partying and drugs, which continues up through their senior year (the novel spans Eden's whole high school career). Her reputation at school becomes compromised, thanks in part to Kevin's younger sister, who is inexplicably hostile toward Eden. Feeling she has nothing left to lose, Eden begins a pattern of attracting/confusing/repelling the boys with whom she becomes involved.  But when another girl makes accusations against Kevin, will Eden find the courage to speak out and expose the truth?At first, I was drawn into Eden's story, finding the style of the narrative appropriate to her fragile emotional state in the aftermath of the rape.  I also found her reactions to be realistic, even when she couldn't bring herself to tell anyone close to her.  But I found the story arc to be disjointed - situations were set up, promising further development, then dropped.  Also, an entire book where the main character does nothing but party and have sex (this is a judgment from the viewpoint of a reader, not a moral one), becomes dull, especially since Eden repeats the same pattern over and over.  Characters (of any age) without any kinds of meaningful interests that they care enough about to pursue seriously are boring to me, even if the author provides a reason for why this is so.  Overall, I do think the topic of sexual violence against young women deserves public attention, but this was not an engaging way to go about it.

If you're familiar with the outline of Steve Jobs' life, you already know how this movie will unfold, and if you don't, what you'll mainly take away is that Steve Jobs (Michael Fassbender) was a huge jerk to a lot of people, had a gift for alienating everyone around him, but somehow managed to get it together to pull off several major product launches without a hitch, at which he was treated like dirt by those who knew him (in his view), and like a god by those in the audience. Almost all the confrontations take place backstage in this movie, and it's like "A Christmas Carol,": all the major players in Jobs' life take turns showing him how much better their lives would have been had he been decent to them, but then they also acknowledge that he is right, or at least is the most stubborn guy in the room. Pretty much every scene is a variation on the following:Michael Fassbender: I want a Golden Goose. Get me a Golden Goose!Other person: Michael, you may be a genius, but I've got a high IQ, too, and I'm not going to let you intimidate me.Michael Fassbender: I don't care how, I want it NOW!Other person: Oh, okay, if you really insist.Michael Fassbender: And a cream feast..."Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" jokes aside, I have a feeling the director (Danny Boyle) was quite adamant that the secondary characters not kowtow to Michael's character, but get right in his face and yell/bicker/curse/shoot zingers back. This includes Kate Winslet as Joanna Hoffman, Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak, Jeff Daniels as John Sculley, Michael Stuhlbarg as Andy Hertzfeld, and Katherine Waterston as Chrisanne Brennan, all of whom do an excellent job.  (The three actresses who play Jobs' daughter, Lisa, at various ages, are also impressive.) Most of the dialogue is very clever, which is good, but most is also delivered at a volume more appropriate for an outdoor sporting event, which may trigger a migraine, if you're prone to them.  Several scenes take place concurrently with a flashback scene, so you get two arguments going on at the same time.  The extras in the hallways mostly stand around fidgeting with props and trying not to look like they're eavesdropping, which is pretty much impossible, and the extras in the audience get to drum their feet and pump their fists a lot.  We learn about Jobs' adoption history, too, and how it affects him, but most of the movie is people displaying their gifts for verbal repartee.  If this is the kind of thing you like, you should enjoy the movie, but I do recommend for migraine-prone people bringing their medication of choice with them to the theater.  Just in case.

Scarlett Epstein's life has totally ended: her favorite TV show "Lycanthrope High" has been cancelled, meaning she no longer has a fresh source of inspiration for her fan fiction, though she's a well-regarded writer in that community. Her offline world seems weary, flat, stale and unprofitable: she's forced to attend a mediocre New Jersey public school; her stressed single mom, Dawn, is more like a girlfriend than a mature influence; and her former friend, Gideon, has become part of the popular clique and is dating her worst enemy. She doesn't get much sympathy from her best friend, Avery, either, who encourages her to focus on real people, not TV characters, for a change. Her online fellow writers are also heartbroken, but what can they do, except decide to start writing fics with some original characters but still based on the show. Little does Scarlett suspect that her latest foray into fan fiction will wind up being the catalyst for her to further upset her nemesis, perplex and confuse Gideon, as she tries to figure out her feelings for him, and challenge her to start participating in the offline world, rather than sitting back and caustically judging it.There are occasional hilarious insights in this novel, such as when Scarlett observes that on Halloween her peers act like those idiotic teens the detectives always think did it at the beginning of "Law and Order." However, just as Scarlett's online community calls her to task for inserting a "Mary Sue" character into her stories, several of her own character traits struck me as rather "Sue-ish." She's extremely judgmental and in my opinion, mostly gets away with doing and saying hurtful things to her family, friends and peers. (The way the storyline with her father was resolved struck me as unrealistic.) Also, although she describes herself as poor, unattractive, and frumpy, it turns out that all she has to do is blow out her hair and don a tight red dress to get people to notice her; even the most popular girl in school tells her that she's attractive. So although I gave the book points for not being afraid to feature an average-looking teen heroine without a designer wardrobe, I had to wind up subtracting them.Overall, I thought the story Scarlett wrote online (which is posted in full) was tighter plotted than the actual novel.  Teens in young adult fiction used to actually map out and execute plans in order to snare the attractive remote member of the opposite sex; now, it seems, they just wander from scene to scene before the author finally decides for whatever reasons, to put them together.  But maybe the target audience will enjoy it more than I did.

The Coach: Can he still play?Trainer: He's in a coma!The Coach: Answer the question! - "Not Another Teen Movie"I have never been a football fan (warning: reviewer bias), and I don't know much about physics, anatomy or neuroscience, but the idea that lasting damage to the brain can occur if one person keeps banging his helmeted head against another person's helmet repeatedly has never struck me as implausible: heads tend to be soft and vulnerable, even inside a padded container, and probably not designed to take that kind of punishment with impunity. Males of several species have been known to engage in head butting, but the human race is the only one which actually pays money to watch this spectacle. I don't know about the long-term effects of this practice on other animals, but "Concussion," by Jeanne Marie Laskas, makes it clear that there is a correlation between a professional football career and brain damage/dementia in men.  Thanks to a Nigerian doctor and forensic pathologist, Bennet Omalu, who first pinpointed this condition, and several other people, profiled in "Concussion," this is now starting to be acknowledged, though not without struggle.Dr. Omalu had the opportunity to study former Steelers player, Mike Webster's, brain and perform an autopsy on it.  Because Webster had displayed very public erratic and explosive behavior with his family, friends and associates before his death, Dr. Omalu was curious to see if the slides taken revealed anything similar to the deterioration shown in Alzheimer's patients.  He discovered something called tau tangles on Webster's slides, which had not been spotted before, but which helped explain how a man who had once had a career, eventually became unemployable, broke and alienated from those he knew.  The kind of man who wasn't shy about telling a colleague that his shirt could use more starch (without malice), Dr. Omalu was initially stunned to discover the reaction of the NFL, a ten billion dollar a year, tax-exempt, non-profit organization, which was displeased and took many steps to discredit him.  Eventually, Dr. Omalu was made to testify in a court case against his former boss, concerning an FBI investigation into their lab.  And because of his research, other families of NFL players have come forward to bring lawsuits against the NFL for downplaying, if not denying, the long-term effects of concussion..Clearly, this can be framed as a David vs. Goliath type narrative, but it's also the story of a man whose own struggle with depression led to his interest in studying the brains of those who had committed suicide, and who eventually overcame it to go on to discover something unique, even if he was, at times, sidelined unfairly.  At any rate, let's hope both the upcoming film about this topic and this book (on which the film is based) are a catalyst to more people having, as Laskas puts it, "the conversation America does not want to have."

Parker Grant, the protagonist of "Not If I See You First," is a somewhat cynical, fiercely independent teen who also happens to be blind. In true young adult novel tradition, she's lost both her parents tragically: her mom in the accident that blinded Parker, and her (loving but possibly pill-addicted father) in an accident that might or might not have been suicide. Since her dad died, Parker's aunt and uncle (with her two cousins) have moved into her home, which she resents (they cramp her style by trying to over-protect her), and she has just started a new year of high school with a group of new students unfamiliar with her "Rules." Plus she has to train a new guide, and is dealing with a former boyfriend who hurt her badly, (with the kind of thoughtless prank teen boys are prone to with an added layer of injury because of her disability)  but who seems to want her to give him a second chance. Complicating things further is the guy who helped her in the shoe store, who seems to be interested. And the school coach has spotted Parker's private runs and wants her to go out for track.  Even if she doesn't want to admit it, it will take the help of her friends, both new and old, to help her through this.As I read, I kept jumping the gun, believing I knew where the story was headed.  At first, I thought that Parker's conflict would be figuring out what happened to her father and coming to terms with it, and then I thought it was going to be focusing on Parker running track and dealing with challenges there.  Instead, these two potential storylines are dropped abruptly, in order to focus on Parker's drama with her two love interests.  And there is a lot of drama, and yes, the main character is a young teenage girl, but I would have appreciated not quite so much at so high a pitch.  Still, when the focus is on Parker and her relationships with her friends and cousins, things stay interesting, as well as when the track storyline is re-introduced and resolved.  Sometimes the main character comes across as self-centered and selfish, but again, you can see the reasons for this.  Finally, assuming the author is not visually impaired, this book must have taken a lot of research in order to so accurately portray a character who is blind.

I saw this movie mostly because I was a fan of the original "Vacation" franchise starring Chevy Chase and Beverly D'Angelo, even if some of the humor went over my head as a kid (like Cousin Vicki hauling out her stash of marijuana).  I also figured the critics were being overly harsh by panning it, perhaps applying too high standards to what was intended as simply a fun summer comedy.I was wrong.  Oh well, at least it was two hours in an air-conditioned theater.Ed Helms plays Rusty Griswold, who is now an airline pilot.  He loves his family just like Chevy did in the original but is currently feeling disconnected from them.  His wife, unbeknownst to him is reading sell-help tomes, and the two sons, who can't stand each other, also don't really respect him (and given his response in an opening scene to mediating a spat, it's no wonder).  Rather than return to a summer cabin where they've gone for years, Ed decides to take his family on a cross-country jaunt to Walley World, the destination of the original "Vacation" movie.  Fans of the original know that that trip didn't turn out so well, and the same holds true for the new generation of Griswolds.  All the big screen road trip clichés are on full display here, as the family lurches from one disaster to another.  Will they make it to the amusement park intact and in good enough shape to enjoy the roller-coaster?  You probably already know the answer.This movie is rated "R" and for a good reason.  Most of the cursing is done by the youngest, preteen son (Steele Stebbins).  Other characters don't have quite his affinity for four-letter words, but they are the victims of a number of gross gags featuring, among other things, pubic hair and human waste.  If that sounds like fun, you might be pleased to discover that there's also jokes about rim jobs, a pedophile truck driver and a dead cow.  There are a couple of good performances by supporting actors, including Charlie Day playing a suicidal white water rafting guide and Chris Hemsworth as the adult Audrey's well-endowed husband, as well as cameos by Chevy and Beverly, but overall, unless you're craving some serious vulgar humor, I'd recommend skipping this "Vacation."

"Bradstreet Gate" features three Harvard students who were tangentially involved in a murder case, in which a popular professor was the main suspect, even years later. Georgia is a bohemian type, and the daughter of a photographer who featured her in a risqué exhibit (and subsequently got in trouble).  Alice is of Serbian descent and is a caustic would-be journalist from a troubled home.  Charlie, a working class student with political aspirations, is the third of the trio, who later goes into the cyber-security field post 9-11.  The characters' reactions to the professor in question range from admiration to contempt, which changes over the course of the novel.  "Bradstreet Gate" follows the characters into their post-graduation world, where they deal with personal and professional conflicts. And when a memorial tribute is arranged for the anniversary of the victim's death, more info on the case is discovered, changing their lives yet again.This book turned out to be not what I was expecting.  Each main character has a potentially interesting story and path of character development, but I found the novel's structure made it difficult to keep track of what was going on in the present.  Certain events - like one character finding a serious love interest - are dropped into the narrative casually, which made me wonder if I'd missed something earlier.  It also didn't seem like anything was seriously at stake for any of the three; the troubles in their lives post-college did not seem to be caused by the crime.  Overall, it does a good job of bringing Harvard and its atmosphere to life, but was ultimately disappointing.

When Rebecca, a single mom who's raising the adolescent daughter of her deceased best friend, receives a call from her school claiming that her daughter, Callie, was caught bullying a classmate, her response is that her child would never be capable of such behavior.  As the story develops, the reader learns (to no great surprise) that the reality is more complex than that.  While dealing with this issue, Rebecca is reminded of her own youth and the cruelties, both intentional and otherwise, that she and her friend caused another girl.  Rebecca also remembers a teenage girl whose body was found but the cause of her death left unsolved.  When Callie's behavior starts to turn baffling, Rebecca isn't sure how to proceed, but decides that it's a former friend of Callie's who is causing the problem.  Compounding this is the fact that both Calile's parents died violently, and Callie is beginning to question this.  The reader does ultimately get Callie's firsthand viewpoint, showing that the boundaries between bully and victim are far more fluid than the adults around them realize, and that Callie may well be in more trouble than she can handle.Like Judy Blume's book on middle school bullying, "Blubber," we see the main character morph from a bystander to a bully, encouraged by her two friends, and then ultimately a victim, after she decides to take a stand.  If I remember correctly, Blume even titles a chapter, "I can't believe my class would do such a thing," which is pretty much the same reaction that Callie's school and Rebecca maintains for most of the book.  I felt the story really began to shine once Callie's account began and that it would have been a better book if it was told more from her viewpoint, but obviously that wasn't what the author was trying to do.  "Hyacinth Girls," like many recent novels on bullying does a good job of making it clear that though the means to bully have been greatly updated, some of the same causes (lack of communication, peer pressure) are still very much around and need addressing.

Ever since I first saw him in "October Sky," I would be willing to watch just about any movie starring Jake Gyllenhaal (though I draw the line at "Bubble Boy").  Here he plays the heavily symbolically named Billy Hope, an orphan from Hell's Kitchen who, through the help of his youthful love Rachel McAdams, precocious daughter (Oona Laurence) and sheer grit and determination, becomes a champion (and extremely wealthy) boxer.  The only trouble is his wife wants him to ease up to ensure he'll still be around and functional in the future.  But when he's taunted by a rival, and he ignores (as usual) the advice to "just walk away," tragedy occurs, and in a span of a few weeks - a timeline that would be amusing if it wasn't presented so grimly, Billy loses not only his wife, but his assets, his sponsorship, his daughter (who is taken into Child Protective Services), and hits rock bottom.  Luckily, Forest Whitaker appears as a mentor and owner of a run-down gym, who also coaches disadvantaged youths.  In another implausible timeline, Billy swallows his pride, trains hard and turns his life back around in about a month and a half.  No cliché of sports movies is left unmined here, though the entire cast does a fantastic job, making me feel sorry for everyone involved.The lead actor's performance cannot be faulted, either in the way he's physically transformed himself or the way he manages to convey real emotion even though the plot holds no surprises.  Billy Hope isn't always a likeable character, but I found myself rooting for him anyway, even though I knew exactly how the movie would end.

"Proof of Forever," begins when its four main characters: tomboyish, sci-fi fan Zoe; A-list Tali; straight-A Luce and optimistic Joy of the mysterious secret reunite at a summer camp reunion.  They've long since drifted apart and are more concerned with their own romance and family issues than each other's.  However, when they are all flung back in time two years ago to a particular summer at camp, it seems like their only chance to getting back to the future is to repeat a photo shoot at the end of the week.  Now the girls must deal with such issues as the loss of well-developed breasts (really), the possibility that one of their parent's is having an affair, as well as love interests who may or may not be the ones they remember ending up with in the present.  As their fateful day approaches, each girl must figure out who she is and what kind of person she wants to be with.This book had an interesting premise, and I wanted to like it more than I did.  I really liked Zoe's and Joy's sections, but I couldn't really sympathize with Tali and Luce.  I also felt the pace dragged a bit, and there were many characters mentioned briefly as if the reader was supposed to know who they were but who never appeared again.  Overall, it's a sweet story, but could have used more character and plot development.

Kit Ward, protagonist of "Dear Killer," is a seventeen-year-old seemingly normal high school student who also happens to be a serial killer.  Trained by her mother in the art of assassination since she was little (luckily dear old dad is oblivious), she lives by a philosophy of moral nihilism, which will be gradually challenged over the course of the book.  After receiving a letter (she communicates with those who hire her by snail mail) targeting a classmate, she winds up befriending one and killing another, which helps put the police on the trail of "The Perfect Killer," the moniker she goes by.  Kit also develops feelings for Alec, the detective assigned to solving that case and begins to question everything her mother has instilled in her about their unorthodox lifestyle.  When it looks like the authorities may be closing in on her trail, Kit must decide whether to escape or face the consequences of her actions.The author is a gifted writer, however, there are flaws in this novel which caused my rating to go down.  First, the protagonist does not use typical Brit idioms for things, which is jarring because the setting is London (perhaps to evoke similarities to Jack the Ripper).  For example, she calls her mother "Mom," not "Mum."  (Probably comparing the author to Elizabeth George, an American mystery author whose characters always sound authentically British is unfair, but she's proof that research pays off.)Secondly, as noted by many reviewers, there are too many implausible scenarios.  Plots with more holes than Swiss cheese can still be fun (example: Gone Girl), but too many things required a suspension of disbelief, particularly the fact that a detective in charge of such an important case would spend so much time socializing with a teenager (and a female one) at that.  Not very professional, although he's presented as a sympathetic character.  Overall, I found the book easy to get through, but as mentioned, flaws interfered with my enjoyment.

Warning: This review contains spoilers.When Aspen Matis sent off on the Pacific Crest Trail, which stretches from Mexico to Canada, she hoped to recover from the trauma of being sexually assaulted her first week at college, and also prove to her overprotective parents (and herself) that she could truly be independent. After her college dealt poorly with the aftermath of the rape (though that would not be the end of it), Aspen decided to rekindle a recently discovered love of hiking in the wilderness, and armed with a few items of clothing, a backpack and a GPS navigator (which her parents insisted on), she set forth. On the way, she would face various challenges, including running out of water and food, struggling through snow shod just in running shoes, and catching a nearly fatal disease. She would also deal with sexism from some of her fellow hikers (which make up about eighty-five percent of the thru-hikers). As a child, Aspen had been dressed by her mother and frightened to go places on her own, but by the end, she became a young woman who wasn't afraid to step over rattlesnakes and past nearby bears, make trips solo in harsh conditions, and even find a man who would eventually become her husband.Oh how I wanted to love this book. From the description, I pictured it as a kind of feminist manifesto. However, the reality (and I suppose the author can't be blamed for how it's packaged) was quite different. The author is a gifted writer when it comes to conveying the natural environment of her journey. The setting springs to life through her vivid prose, and if the rest matched that, this would easily be a five star review. However, the personal parts often read like diary entries, the dialogue is littered with four-letter words, and the ending struck me as sugar-coated, especially with what you learn in the acknowledgements. I admired the author for how she donated to RAINN and returned to Colorado College on their invitation to speak about the rape.  I'm glad she went on to have a successful life, both professionally as a writer and personally.  However, as a narrator, I felt that while Aspen was very honest about her relationship with her parents, she often failed to realize just how her behavior impacted her fellow hikers on the trail.  There were a lot of minor things in the book that felt glossed over or omitted in order to make the narrator appear more of a victim (and I'm not talking about the rape).  (Yes, I had tons of questions.  What kind of father just lets this kind of behavior go on with his wife without any intervention?  And even without help from one's parents, kids get a lot of info about such things as "stranger danger" from school, other adults and pop culture.  How is it possible in this day and age to be a vulnerable single woman and willingly get into a car driven by a strange man, especially after having been raped?)  This isn't meant to come off as blaming the victim, but I found the narrator's constant lack of basic common sense made it hard to always sympathize with her.

"Reading the Comments" is a thought-provoking look behind the online reviews, likes, Facebook updates, tweets, etc. that there is controversy over whether or not to read in the first place.  In engaging in what author Joseph M. Reagle Jr. calls, "the users' search for serendipity," the best and worst of human nature is evident. This book examines how online platforms for expression adapt (or fail to) as their popularity grows, and how popularity makes it more likely that they will attract bullies and spammers forcing them to take on new directions if they wish to survive.Among other topics, Reagle examines the intentions and effects of comments, how product reviews are susceptible to manipulation and fakery, how cyber-bullying at places like Goodreads can be addressed, how content and ratings cause us to define ourselves (there's an amusing theory floated that Facebook popularity may be causing an increase in facial surgery), how reviewing causes tension between public input and expert opinion, and just what constitutes "constructive criticism."  He also looks at the role the Internet plays in shaming public figures and the excuses they offer for damage control.  Social networking, as Reagle notes, occurred in the pre-Internet era, and some of the same issues are still relevant now.Overall, this book is not at all dry, and some parts, like the ones on Amazon reviews, are very funny.  (As an Amazon reviewer, I must state that I'm not receiving any bribes to put that in here, nor does my rating mean that I am a family member, friend or the author himself reviewing his book.)  It's likely after reading this book, even the most cynical readers may well look at the "comments" with a more jaded eye.

When we first met the protagonist of "Paperweight," Stephanie "Stevie" Delisle, she has just arrived at an eating disorders treatment center in the middle of nowhere (i.e. near the desert) against her will.  Labeled bulimic, she's annoyed at pretty much everything about the center, including her bubbly roommate Ashley and her therapist, the hippie-ish Anna, whom she refers to as "Shrink."  Her older brother died a year ago, and the reader soon realizes that Stevie plans to join him on what she terms the fast approaching "Anniversary."  We also learn that her mother, a high powered lawyer who always seemed to disapprove of Stevie's weight, moved out several years ago, and Stevie's only friend from home (besides her brother Josh) is the charismatic, college-aged Eden, who Stevie meets in a writing seminar and who introduces Stevie to the joys of alcohol, partying and eventually, sex.  Fortunately, for our protagonist, she has a therapist straight out of a young adult novel, who is willing to go the extra mile with her and help her take the first steps toward recovery - even if it is going to take awhile.Pros: Stevie's voice struck me as authentically teenaged: snarky, yet also yearning for acceptance beneath the tough veneer.  My favorite line was when she describes taking a morning trail ride with her therapist and notes, "We're practically a tampon commercial."Cons: The novel's plot seemed formulaic, and there wasn't much to set it apart from other similar young adult "problem" novels.Overall: A good read if you're interested in how eating disorders affect young women, with some very funny lines along the way.

"The Devil in Jerusalem" can be described as "A Child Called It" by way of "Law and Order."  It begins with two young children admitted to the hospital ER, one unconscious, both obviously the victims of severe abuse.  Their mother, Daniella, refuses to admit this possibility and plays dumb when questioned by the two detectives assigned to investigate this case.  Detective Bina, herself a mother, is disgusted and horrified, a reaction the reader almost certainly will share, as more details emerge, and it appears that Daniella and her husband, after moving to Jerusalem, have gotten involved with a charismatic and amoral (is there any other kind?) cult leader who has primary control over disciplining their children ranging in age from a toddler to teenagers.  Both Daniella and her husband are separated from their families, struggling financially and personally, and thus are easy marks for being seduced by this man.  Much space is also given to the backstory, beginning when Daniella herself is in college but must give up her dreams of being a doctor to have her first child.  Crucial to punishing the leader and his flunkies is testimony from the children themselves, but will they be able to detach themselves from their harsh treatment and tell the truth?The subject matter is undeniably grim, though that is not the main reason for my rating.  It is likely that the reader, upon reaching the part where graphic abuse is described, may share the reaction of one detective and feel nauseous.  The descriptions are brutal to read, as just about form of abuse is perpetrated on these innocent victims without anyone intervening for a long time.  If the author set out to shock, disgust and horrify the reader thoroughly, she has more than achieved her goal.The writing quality itself, however, is uneven.  There is much showing instead of telling, as well as some purple prose.  I was surprised to learn that this wasn't the author's first or second book, as those kinds of mistakes are more common (and forgivable) then.  Overall, it does take an unflinching look at a difficult subject, but flaws in the execution keep it from being as powerful as it could be.

This is my first security/cloud camera. We have an unstable neighbor who occasionally acts up and wanders into other people's yards, so I was in need of something like this.I *thought* setup was going to be pretty easy and I do consider myself tech savvy. I scanned the QR code and downloaded the app from the app store, plugged the camera in to a power source and connected it via ethernet to our router. The app located the camera and registered it. It then asked me if I wanted to use the camera wirelessly, which I did, so I selected that option. It then said I could unplug the ethernet cable and use it wirelessly. However, every time I unplugged the ethernet cable, I could not view the camera at all via the iPhone app.I tried several things including resetting the camera, refreshing our wireless router, refreshing the camera itself and deleting the camera altogether via the mobile app and setting it up again. After a day or so, I could not even get it to connect to our wireless network at all (would say network not available or incorrect password - neither of which were true), so I just left it cabled in, which meant I could not place the camera where I needed it to be.I went to TP Link's website and started reading. I also contacted technical support. There is a support page (here: http://www.tp-link.com/en/download/NC200.html) for this model, the NC200. There are things like firmware updates (though they don't tell you how to install/apply them), manuals (though there are three listed, they don't really tell you the difference between them - the names are ambiguous), a web plugin (that does not work on either browser I have - Chrome and IE) and Management Utility, which, as it turns out, is the desktop/laptop program.The manuals are as follows (found on the NP200's support page):* NC200_Camera_Control_V1_UG This is the user guide for the Camera Control program. The Camera Control program is the desktop program. The TP-LINK Camera Control is a software for you to conveniently view and control multiple TP-LINK IP cameras on a single computer screen.* NC200_V1_UG - This is user guide for the camera itself - the NC200. This covers about everything you need to know about the camera including how to set up, the web management tool, mounting the camera, how to set up motion detection and notification sending. This is a fairly technical user guide, but it's worth reading if you really want to understand how to use all the features of this camera.* NC200_V1_QIG - This is the Quick Installation Guide. Same as the little brochure you get inside the box.Through some sort of magic or wizardry, I *finally* got this thing to connect to my wireless network and when I unplugged the ethernet, IT WORKED. While I was waiting for support to respond, I downloaded and installed the desktop program (found under the Management Utility tab on the NC200's support page) and also logged into the camera's admin program via my browser (by putting the IP address of the camera in the browser). Don't ask me how I found the IP address of the camera (update: it can be found when you run the Setup Wizard), but when you do, and you visit that page, BOOKMARK IT.So, with one of those programs (the Setup Wizard program or the web management page), I finally got it going. What's annoying to me is that the included documentation doesn't really tell you about these two programs. I had to hunt to find them and the less than tech-savvy will be totally lost.There are two ways to setup your camera:* The app for your smartphone - there is both an Android and Apple app which can be found in their respective app stores.* The program called "Setup Wizard" that can be found under the "Setup Wizard" tab on the NC200's support page.There are several programs you can use to view your camera, tweak settings and manage your camera (and out of the box, TP Link does not do a good job of explaining these programs, what they are and where to find them):* The program for your desktop called "Camera Control": The TP-LINK Camera Control is a software for you to conveniently view and control multiple TP-LINK IP cameras on a single computer screen. This can be downloaded via the NC 200's support page under the "Management Utility" tab.* The app for your smartphone - there is both an Android and Apple app which can be found in their respective app stores.* The web management page. You get to this by typing in the IP address of your camera into a web browser.* www.tplinkcloud.com -  In order to use this, you will likely have to download a plugin after signing up for a TP Link cloud account. The web plugin can be found on the NP200's support page under the "Web Plugin" tab. Then, once you have created a cloud account with TP link, you can go to www.tplinkcloud.com, log in and view you camera from anywhere. However, as of this writing, I could not view my camera through either the Chrome, Internet Explorer 11 or Edge. So, the "cloud" part of this cloud camera doesn't really work.Pros:* For most people, I would guess setup is easy. I just experienced issues for whatever reason. Using the camera through the app is pretty easy and intuitive.* Cost - for $30, this is a pretty good deal to get some basic home security.* Smartphone app is great - easy to use and download.* Can take a snapshot or record on the fly. Can also schedule recording for certain times/days of the week through the web management tool.* Motion detection with email alerts.Cons:* The camera is so light that if you are using the ethernet cable for a wired connection, you had better secure that camera somewhere otherwise it will topple over.* Picture isn't the best - 0.3 Megapixel (640*480).* Cannot view the camera from IE or Chrome as of this writing.* Not good in low light.I have not yet opted to use the motion detection feature. It's a little complex.For the price (as of this writing, it's $30), I'd say it's an amazing deal. You get quite a bit of functionality for that $30. Setup *can* be easy, but there's a lot of tech stuff to know if you really want to enjoy all this camera has to offer. The support and documentation take some digging to get to, and if you're not technologically adept, you'll be doing nothing more than just watching your live camera on your phone app.

I just got into using essential oils (for scent, not for their supposed benefits) a few weeks ago. In that time, I've owned four diffusers, two of which I've returned. One thing I noticed right off the bat in my endless reading of reviews on this site, is that a LOT of people got these diffusers for a reduced cost. Check the very end of their review and you'll often see the phrase "I received this item in exchange for my honest, unbiased review" or "I received this item at a discounted price for my honest and unbiased review." I was shocked at just how many reviews a lot of these diffusers had; this one has over 2000 reviews. Most people who received it in exchange for a review or at discounted price left four to five stars. But if you start looking at the reviews of people who purchased it at full price, you'll see a different story. In fact, across the board (brands), there seems to be a fairly high failure rate with these things.The technology is pretty simple, yet these diffusers seem horribly overpriced. It's hardly new technology; a mini "humidifier" and a few LED lights. I've had a $30 diffuser and a $60 one, a free one and a $40 one. To date, none of them are perfect. Between moist countertops, reduced output after only one week, lack of scent and small water capacity, most of these diffusers fall short.This item is indeed cute as hell. It's way smaller than I thought it would be, but it's really cute. You kinda go "awwww" when you see it in the box. Setup is easy (again, we're not talking about cutting-edge technology here) - fill to the fill line, add a few drops of EO and turn it on. The item is pink-ish when the light is off, but looks more red with the LEDs on. I rather like the light it emits.And, though it's a small detail (but one I've come to appreciate after owning a few of these), the fact that the adaptor plugs in the BACK and not the BOTTOM is a welcome change. Being that you have to unplug this for cleaning and/or refilling (this unit does not come with a separate cup you can fill and bring back to the unit so you don't have to unplug it), the adaptor being on the bottom is PAIN. So yay for this one having the plug on the lower back.That's kinda where the good things about this unit end.The reservoir for this unit is the smallest out of all the four that I've owned. I'm getting no more than three hours of run time before it auto shuts off. Sometimes less. The reservoir holds 80ml - that's one third of a cup of liquid. There is no intermittent feature.Also, and I have no idea if this is due to the small reservoir, the scent does not last long. I'd say 30 mins to an hour. All of our rooms are small (less than 150SF) and after an hour or so you can no longer smell any scent coming out of this diffuser. If you walk right up to it and stick your face in it, yes, but even in our small kitchen, the scent does not fill that room. I've experimented with anywhere from 3 to 10 drops and it seems to make no difference.One thing I kept reading when I was researching EOs is that their "benefit" was reduced if they were heated. It's worth noting that the Allay does get a little warm and the mist/vapor that comes out of the top is also sometimes warm, not a "cool mist".So, I'm not blown away. It does not throw a lot of scent and it does not run that long. Should you buy it? If you want 30 mins. of scent in your coat closet, sure. If you want your home to smell like whatever oil you're using, no. Pass on this one.

I like all kinds of chocolate - wrapped in foil, drizzled on ice cream, in a bag of trail mix, cake, hot cocoa... you name it, I like it. Except that really cheap Easter candy chocolate - that stuff is terrible. ;) I would not call myself a chocolate connoisseur by any means, but I do love the stuff. I'm drawn to it and find it hard to resist when it's near me.This chocolate is good. Very good, in fact. The first one I tried was the L'Art Du Brut Milk Chocolate Bar with Whole Almonds/Hazelnuts/Cranberries. It is indeed smooth and the chunks of nuts and cranberries were quite good! They are correct when they say "no two bites are alike". I ate the whole thing in about a day. Oops. :)The 2nd one I tried was the L'Ecorce, Dark Chocolate 84% Cocoa, Floral & Bittersweet. Let's just say I do not have a palette for "floral" chocolate, or one this dark. I *thought* I liked all kinds of chocolate, but this one proved me wrong. I thought, hey, it's fancy, I'll power through it! Nope. I couldn't even eat it. It's definitely DARK chocolate and it definitely has a FLORAL taste. I'm sure if you're into that sort of thing, this is quite good. I could not finish it and passed it off to my SO, who seemed to like it.Overall, this is a great chocolate. I suspect most people will like the more traditional chocolate with the chunks of things they recognize and not the more exotic stuff.The packaging is great, the chocolate was fresh and the ingredients list wasn't scary and loaded with things I didn't recognize.

I've owned several portable Bluetooth speakers during the past several years, and dollar-for-dollar, this one is the best I've seen.  The sound quality is nearly identical to more expensive models, yet the weight and size is actually smaller.  It's a perfect companion on those days I'm on the mountain bike and want to hear my tunes.There's nothing major to complain about here, especially for the price.  I'm not a huge fan of the rubberized clip.  Securing it can be a little awkward, but it's not a deal-killer for me.  This speaker performs exceptionally well, and sounds great...even when I'm racing down a hill on my bike.

Update 11/17/2015: After only one week of use, the output is already reduced. It's not putting out as much mist as it used to. It's not been tipped over, it's not been dropped. I've cleaned it properly and taken care to follow all instructions. I'll monitor it for a few more days (while another diffuser arrives in the mail), but I fear this one is going back.I've been heavily researching essential oil differs on Amazon and settled on this one after I returned my ZAQ one (it left surfaces moist after use). This diffuser is $20 more than that one and no better. Prices for diffusers range from $25 to upwards of $80. They all perform one basic function: vaporize water. Some have color-changing lights, some do not. But the concept is the same - put scent and water vapor into the air. For all these things do, I find most of them to be overpriced.It's a very nice looking diffuser. Stylish, fairly small and blends well with my decor. It starts up right away and you can see the mist coming out the top within 3 seconds.I do like the larger water reservoir and the intermittent feature. The light is nice and can "pulse" or be set to a certain brightness - just tap once to turn on the light and then tap again when the brightness is at the level you want.I don't care for the plug placement - I wish it was on the side, not the bottom of the unit. There is also no included pouring cup, so refilling this usually involves unplugging it and taking it to the sink. The top just sits there and is often holding condensation, so when you take the top off, be prepared to do it over a surface you don't mind getting wet.It does what it's supposed to do, but I feel similar diffusers can be had for much less.

My mother has a pretty intense Tic Tac addiction. In fact, I always say she's got the 'Tac Monkey on her back. So, I've tried several flavors over the years. Liked some more than others.These are decent. They do indeed taste like cherry cola. It's weird, but even the cola taste is pretty spot on. They are somewhat tart, too.However, these are not really mints. They're just straight up candy. So don't assume these will freshen your breath. I ate the entire box in one evening. Oops.There's nothing really natural or recognizable in the ingredient list except sugar.Though they were interesting, I can't say I'd buy them as they don't freshen your breath and they aren't a candy I particularly crave.

I like chicken. I like beef jerky. I am on the fence about chicken jerky.These have a good taste. I *did* find them to be spicy enough for me. The flavor was pretty good. I think the main problem is that chicken is such a lean meat that the lack of oil/fat make for a weird texture of jerky. They are definitely edible, but they were not something I'd pick up on my own and eat.For the price and the odd texture, I'd pass on these. They are not bad, but I just don't think chicken lends itself well to jerky.

I really wanted to like this item. It's a nice small size and fits just about anywhere. The changing colors on the top of the unit are a nice touch and I like that I can pause a certain color, too.My main complaint is that it left whatever surface I set it on damp/moist after a few hours of use. I monitored it closely for three days and after about 1.5 hours, the surface the ZAQ rested on became damp. Most of the surfaces I'll be using this on are wood/particle board, so I can't use this item without worrying about it ruining my furniture.What I did like:* Good scent disbursement. I used about 4 drops of EO each time and it really did fill the room with scent. To be fair, our rooms are small (about 120SF or less.* The color-changing LEDs are nice. They are pleasing without being too bright.* I liked the shape of this device - wide base so it's not easy to tip over.* Functions are easy to use and understand - 1 press ON, 2nd press the pause a color, 3rd press to turn off the light, 4th press to turn the unit off* Quiet.* Puts out a fair amount of mist.What I didn't like:* Condensation on the surface it sits on.* Plug on the bottom is cumbersome to undo, esp when you need to plug it back in after refilling.* Small tank that's a pain to refill.* $40 for this unit seems pricey considering it's just a diffuser with an LED light.

I've always been a fan of beef jerky, but rarely buy it. This brand type was good. There was only once piece that had too much fat on it (made it kinda grisly). The taste is good, albeit a little fragrant. The texture was good, too.I'm a little ashamed to admit that I ate this late at night before bed. In secret.You're supposed to refrigerate it after opening. I forgot. I lived anyway.This is a good, middle-of-the-road beef jerky that anyone would like. Not too spicy, not overly seasoned and just chewy enough to keep your mouth busy for awhile.

I'm an avid crafter and I have been looking for a fun and different winter hobby. I came across one of these boards in Michael's the other day and loved the idea! Within a few minutes, I was making bags! Lots of bags! The board is pretty easy to use, though it doesn't look like it at first. After my first two failed attempts, it finally clicked and I made about 15 bags in an hour or so.The board and instructions are pretty self-explanatory, but my complaints are as follows:* You really almost have to be standing to get the punch part to punch cleanly. I tried several times to punch through pretty thin kraft paper and it wouldn't cut cleanly. So, I'd recommend scoring and punching a bunch while standing and then folding and gluing while sitting.* I knew the bag sizes were limited and small and I was fine with that. However, the length of score lines is only six inches, so for bags taller than that, you'll have to make sure to fold carefully. It would be great if the board itself was about 3" longer to allow for easier scoring of taller bags.* You'll likely need a separate cutting board to cut either the correct width and/or length. My recommendation on the bag length (height) is to just trim to the desired length *after* assembling. However, this will mean you can't use the hold punch for the top.While this is a fun hobby, it's not quick. However, it does allow for an inexpensive way to make personalized and fun bags for gifts.The board appears to be well-built and I've had fun using it! I look forward to trying their other boards!

I have little experience with essential oils and only really buy them for their scent, not their supposed "effects". I am very much in love with YL's "Peace and Calming" so when I saw this one, I jumped on it, esp since it's so much cheaper.The oils in Eden's Garden: Chamomile, Clary Sage, Copaiba, Lavender, Peru Balsam, Sandalwood, Sweet Marjoram and Ylang YlangThe oils in Young Living's Peace and Calming: Tangerine, Orange, Ylang Ylang, Patchouli, and Blue TansySo, as you can see, they have *one* scent in common. How Eden's can say this is similar is beyond me.When I first opened the bottle and took a whiff, I recoiled. It stinks. I put it in my diffuser and while the scent was a little better, it's still an odd combination of smells. It smells nothing like Peace and Calming.

Overall, I like the case. It offers good protection for the phone. I've already dropped my iPhone (as I often do) and it survived just fine. The case has a nice clean look and really shows off my rose gold iPhone.My two issues:* The opening for the mute button makes it pretty hard to toggle it on/off. The case is wider than I'd like, and that width puts the toggle too deep in the case.* The case is extremely hard to remove. I change out cases here and there, and this one is a real pain to remove.I'm definitely keeping it, but those two issues are moderately frustrating.

I've used these for transporting my workday lunch (typically a sandwich and some chips or cookies) over the past month.  The results are mixed, but overall the quality of the product is decent.  It's made of very sturdy plastic which is both a benefit and a drawback.The storage boxes will certainly hold up for a long time, even under rough handling.  Unfortunately, the rigid nature of the plastic makes securing the container difficult in circumstances where your food may rest slightly above the recessed lid.  Sometimes, I had to smash my chips or cookies down just to get the thing closed, and even then it was still not 100% shut.While the sandwich compartment has plenty of space, I find the two smaller bays are inadequate for most of the items I typically pack in my lunch.  I did put cottage cheese in one of the compartments, but there was some leakage into the other two.  This is not recommended for any food that may have liquid properties to it.It works great for carrying a sandwich and a few very small assorted items.  The build quality is sufficient, but I feel this product's compartment set-up really limits what you can place in it.

The Bose Wave IV Music System continues the company's legendary tradition of making top-notch audio products.  Even at very low volumes, the Wave IV achieves incredibly full and crisp playback.  Other speakers have to be cranked way up to appreciate the quality, but not with this Bose system.  If you're an audiophile who wants the absolute best-sounding speakers possible, I don't think there's a product that will surpass this one.My primary use for the Bose is as an auxiliary speaker for my laptop.  The MP3s and video gaming audio is incredibly rich -- significantly better than any speaker system I've owned before this one.  I'll also tune in a few local radio stations on the Bose, and like the auxiliary output, the sound quality exceeds what I can convey with a mere written description.If I have one complaint, it would be the lack of on-console buttons.  You pretty much need the remote control to perform all important functions.  You can power the unit off or on by touching the top portion.  That's about it for controlling the Bose Wave IV without a remote, however.  Don't misplace the remote control, or you'll have very limited ability to operate the console.All in all, it's a magnificent product and I'm enjoying it greatly.  You probably will, too.

For the price, these are great headphones. I like the in-ear ones - they help cancel out surrounding noise. They are comfortable to wear.I'm not an audiophile, but for my needs, the sound is great on these. Very rich.The color is great - a nice pink. The cord is color-matched, too.The built-in mic was a nice feature on these for this price point.I have no complaints - these are perfect for my needs.

I was super excited to find this product! A mold product that can be re-used?! Sweet.I almost bought the larger size (which was super expensive), but I'm glad I didn't.I heated mine in the microwave at 15-20 second intervals, like another user suggested. I never did get the middle liquefied entirely. I poured the ooze over my item (you really do need to glue it down - I didn't and I ended up with a resin piece suspended in the mold). They don't really tell you how long it takes to cure, the label just says "allow to cool". So I let it cool for a few hours. I would say let it cool so that it's not warm to the touch, or tacky.This stuff smells... funny. I'm not sure what the smell is, but it reminds me of the unkempt cages at the local zoo. Seriously, it's a really weird smell. Not toxic smelling, per se, but stanky.After I made my 2nd attempt at making a mold of my pieces, I pulled them out easily (did not use cooking spray). The mold looked pretty good, but I noticed my original resin pieces had a pink cast to them. So keep that in mind if you're casting clear items - they may pick up the red dye from the mold and have a pink cast.Later that night, I poured resin into the mold. Usually, the next day, I can pull the pieces out to fully cure. When I pulled these pieces out the next day, they were tacky. It took them several days to fully cure (normally, it would take less than two). The pieces remained tacky for 4-5 days. This will not work for me, as I need to make pieces quickly to sell. Oddly enough, I cast a few more clear pieces (clear, no glitter or mica powder) and they did not come out tacky. But each time I attempt to cast resin with glitter or mica mixed in, the pieces come out tacky. I use Amazing's mold rubber for all my other molds and have never had this problem.So, overall, I do not care for this product. It's a GREAT idea, but I can't deal with tacky pieces that take 5+ days to fully cure.

I have to admit, I was pretty stoked to try this stuff. I've never bought it due to the high price tag.Upon first opening the box, you could smell the product right away. It's STRONG. The cap had come off mine, so a little had leaked out. No biggie. But this particular sent (Royal Flush) is geared towards men and it smells a little like Axe body spray/someone who's been clubbin' all night. Not a fan of the scent, but not a big deal, let's see if it works!My boyfriend tried it out the first morning on what he calls his "old man, gravely, first-of-the-morning" poo and yeah, it worked. Well. NO scent of poo in our impossibly small (5x8) bathroom. I was impressed. I tried it out the next day (thanks sluggish bowels) and had the same result - no. poo. smell. Amazed.So yes, the product works, well. The only thing I didn't like about this particular scent (Royal Flush) was how strong it was, and how long it lingered in the bathroom. This scent gave me a headache, but I'm very sensitive to scents. Whichever scent you use, it will linger behind after your trip to the toilet. In our small bathroom, this means it will stick around for 20-30 mins.The PooPourri is made with essential oils and no nasty chemicals - that I liked. Also made in the USA! The marketing and the packaging are hilarious!The only downside here is the cost (though I received mine for free). That's the only reason I held off on buying it for all these years. Supposedly, the 4oz. bottle will last for 200 "uses".Edit: I also have the Rose Geranium scent, which is much more pleasing, but also, strong. The 2oz. size is great to carry in your purse.

I've had/used many desktops, laptops and now, and all-in-one. Windows 10 is new to me, but I won't comment on that much and just stick to the Toshiba hardware and software. This is my first Toshiba laptop/computer.The unit is nice and light and slim. Must less so than my last Dell laptop. But, to be fair, that was over three years ago. The laptop doesn't look particularly high end; the design is simple but nice.What I liked:*Keyboard is nice and easy to use. I like the low profile keys.* Display is nice and bright* Design of the laptop is simple, but classy looking. It's all plastic, but it looks pretty nice for a mid-range laptop.What I didn't like:* Seems to be a little laggy with even basic things like opening a browser. Each time I got on this computer, it was slow to boot up, slow to open programs and just slow in general.* Buttons below the touchpad are a little too firm.* Display is sufficient - contrast is good and colors appear rich and vibrant.Problems:* The cursor sometimes gets stuck between pointing mode and text mode. I could not get it unstuck.* The edges of the laptop on the bottom where the keyboard is are really sharp. When your arms/hands are resting on the area before the keyboard, the edges are oftentimes bothersome. A rounded edge would have been a better choice.* The space bar sometimes doesn't register. In fact, this happens a lot. You really have to hit the space bar aggressively to get it to respond sometimes. This will be a real problem for someone who types a lot.For the price, it's an OK computer. Not the best, not the worst. I found that using it usually meant my palms would hurt from the sharp edges and the laggy processor meant frequent frustrations. There's nothing that really stands out about this laptop and of all the laptops and desktops I've owned, this one seems a little slow.

As a Prime member, I was so excited when this app came out - "free" music! However, this is one of the worst interfaces I've seen, and I'm pretty tech savvy. I've seen several updates made to the app, and each time, it doesn't get any better. I can't tell the difference between my music, music I've downloaded (but not paid for) and I have no idea if I'm streaming music or playing it off my phone. There's a cloud library and an offline library, but they seem to contain the same thing.I never really cared too much about this (whether I was streaming or playing my music "offline") until I started using the app again recently and noticed I was using a lot of data on my phone. I started clearing my statistics on my phone to see how much the Amazon Music app was using. On my trip to work, which is about 10 mins, if I listen to Amazon music, it uses about 25 - 45MB. By contrast, I fired up Pandora and for the same 10 mins, it used 2.5MB. That's a HUGE difference!Though the free music is great, and it seems to contain a lot of music I like, it's a data HOG if you're streaming and the interface is poor.

Like the other reviewer said, this lamp does NOT look like the image on the box, color-wise. And one of the images shown here on Amazon shows it going from purple at the top down to pink. In reality, the color starts at pink at the top and ends on purple. Also, the colors are nowhere near as nicely spaced as the images show. I'd say the lamp is about 50% red and pink and then there are very narrow band of yellow, green and blue. I have a *very* hard time believing anything about this globe is "hand painted".Lava Lite has a long history (esp since moving production to China in 2003) of quality issues and product images that are deceptively deceiving. You'll almost never see a real image of the product being used on their packaging. There's a reason for that. Most common issues you'll encounter (so save your receipt) are: cloudy/hazy liquid that never clears, gunk/dark bits in the metal coil at the bottom, wax sticking to the bottom of the globe and poor flow. I can almost guarantee any lamp you buy from Lava Lite post-2003 will have at least one of these issues. How do I know? I've bought over 20 of them (and returned/sold/gave away 75% of them). I'm a collector of lava lamps and if you truly want a beautiful lamp that will last, buy a pre-2003 off eBay.The Rainbow Grande looks better off than it does on. When the lamp is turned on, you can see just how poor the spray job is. Not only is the saturation of the spray lighter than I'd like, but you can see how spotty it is. My globe had several spray smudges/defects towards the bottom of the globe.The lamps takes about 2-3 hours to flow with the provided bulb in a house that's about 78 degrees.The base and cap are nothing exceptional. For a lamp this vibrant, a black or white base would have been nice. My base came with one small ding in it. Otherwise, it's decent.I ran the lamp for a few weeks before I decided to return it. The flow was good, but the main attraction - the rainbow part - wasn't as vibrant as I'd wanted. Every time I turned it on, I noticed the poor spray job and was disappointed. For this cost, it just wasn't as stunning as I'd hoped. The colors are un-evenly spaced and the spotty spray job was hard to ignore. I'd pass on this one.

If you're prone to spills or making a mess while measuring out laundry detergent, this product is just what you need. That seems to be the main selling point of Wisk PowerBlasts from what I can tell.  Everything else is fairly unremarkable. It does a good job of getting clothes clean, and the scent is pleasantly fresh but not overwhelming, which is what I want from a laundry detergent. Most of my clothes consist of darker colors, I really can't attest to how it will handle whites or other lighter shades.  However, all my shirts came out looking clean and weren't discolored at all. The scent does not really carry past the dryer though. When I took my clothes out the dryer, the scent was gone.It's a convenient product because you just throw one of the pods into the bottom of your washer; no  measuring or scooping is required. The cost per load, unfortunately, seems a little higher than conventional detergent.
