You can never have too many charging cables, right? Right. I've had many over the years and my first one (from Apple) is has finally started coming apart. I like the Belkin cables as they're a little sturdier and thicker. I also enjoy the colors, as they stand out more. However, the red one I received is more of a dirty red/dull red and is not as vibrant as the picture. No big deal.It's a great length (not too long or short) and I've had no issues using it. I keep this one at work and use it nearly every day.Compared to the OEM cable, this one's a clear winner - cheaper, sturdier, color.I would not call the cable "flat" though - it's round(ed).

I've burned scented candles for years with my current faves being Yankee and IKEA (yes, scented candles from IKEA). I am somewhat particular about scents, as some can give me a headache. I tend to prefer flora;/plant smells and stay away from the ones that smell like food.This candle has a nice, pleasing scent. It's not so overpowering that it's bothersome, but you can definitely smell it when you walk into the room. I have it in my 10x12 bedroom and it's not overwhelming. The dandle has two wicks and appears to have a thin metal piece in the center of the wick.The glass jar and label are very nice - it seems like a very well-made candle, demanding a slightly higher price. The label and lid appear to be of nice, quality materials and the overall impression of the candle is that it's a higher-end product.Some of the profits from buying this candle will go towards plant research, habitat conservation, horticulture and education. A nice touch.Overall, a wonderful candle that's been a delight to light and use!

I've been casting with epoxy resin for a few months now. After looking for cheaper alternatives to Ice resin, I found Alumilite Amazing Clear Resin. Alumilite resin, while cheaper, does have a very slight yellow-ish cast. You won't even notice it unless you had it next to another identical piece cast in another kind of resin.I came across this seller/brand and figured for the price, I'd give it a try. I only do small castings (1oz. or less at a time), so I needed to make sure this would work. Based on the description here and on their website, it seemed it would work for my projects (which include magnets, ornaments and buttons).Instructions were found on their website, as well as included with the product. It's mixed just like Ice and Alumilite - stir for 2-3 mins. with flat stick, scraping the sides. I don't agree with their instructions to "mix vigorously", as that creates more air bubbles. So, mix slowly. Then, let it sit for 3-5 mins. so some of the air bubbles rise and pop.It pours nicely and can be de-molded in 24 hours. It's rock hard in 48 hours. It's very clear and I prefer it over Alumilite. I will continue to use this brand as it's worked out very well for me! The only downside is that since I do such small pours, I had to put it in a different container that had a small opening for pouring.Cost per oz. (including shipping) as of this writing is $.70/oz. Check out the seller's website for cheaper pricing and larger sizes.

This stuff is pretty easy to use, it's the mold container and mixing ratios that might trip you up. If you're making a whole container of the stuff, great - just pour the liquid into the gooey stuff, mix and pour. But if you're making a smaller batch, it's 10 parts silicone to 1 part liquid. I use a gram scale and it works out just fine.You have a few minutes of mixing before this starts to set up, so mix quickly and pour. I blow out the air bubbles on top of the surface with a straw. The rubber sets up in about four hours.I have made about 6-7 molds with this stuff and it makes a great copy of your original item and my resin pieces have turned out great. It captures detail very well.However, two of my molds are now "done" as they have started to degrade and stick to my resin pieces. I wrote the company today about the shelf life of these molds (I had hoped they'd last longer than 4 months) and the customer service rep informed me that this product will produce molds that are good for about 30 - 50 "pulls" (meaning casts). You can get closer to the 50 pulls number if you use a releasing agent. I really wish this information was included somewhere on the packaging or instructions.So, two of my molds are unusable, with more to join that status as I use them more. The last piece I pulled out of the rubber mold was actually stuck to it, so I had to cut/tear it out. Please see attached photos for the mold that's now unusable.At $15 for a kit, with the molds only lasting for about 30-50 pulls, I'm not sure I'll be using this product again.

This is one of the more unique bluetooth speakers I've seen. We have about four of them in our house. :) Nice to see something different looking and fun.Right off the bat, I noticed the interesting packaging and super neon yellow charging cord. Nice to see something different.I easily paired my iPhone to the speaker and was up and running. I installed the app, which allows you to interact with the speaker by powering it on, adjusting the equalizer, setting an alarm and other features. I use the app primarily to turn on the UE Roll and check the battery life.The first few times I played around with the speaker, I noticed a drop in volume when I would switch songs. I am not sure why that happened. There was one other time where the max volume was severely limited and not very loud. I don't regularly experience that issue, but it was an odd one.The speaker itself feels very sturdy and well-made. I can even feel the + and - stitching in the dark to lower/raise the volume. There's a neat bungee-type cord that wraps around the back that allows you to hand the item or fasten it easy to a bike handle, arm of a chair, etc. I took mine into the kitchen and strapped it to a cupboard handle to listen to music while I cooked.The app and using the speaker in general is very easy. No complaints there.The sound is good, but I am not an audiophile. I was more than pleased with the quality of the sound for my needs. The only time I struggle with the sound is when I have it lying flat - the sound doesn't project well around the sides. Again, not a big deal, just turn it up a little.The back is a heavy rubber and makes holding it easy. I didn't really care for the charging port under the flap (somewhat awkward to open and charge), but it's not a dealbreaker. I'm guessing that flap helps with the water resistant aspect of this speaker.Overall, this is a great speaker and I'd recommend it. I can only hope I don't experience any more of the volume issues however.

This is my first Android phone. I've had an iPhone ever since they came out, so please note that in my review of this phone. What phone you've had before you review a new phone will certainly influence your feel about a different OS/manufacturer. I've played around with Android in general (helping people set up their phones) and both my SO and mom have a Samsung Galaxy S5, so I'm somewhat familiar with Android, mostly Samsung's version of it.I will try and stay away from reviewing Android and keep my review mostly limited to the phone's hardware, Sony's proprietary apps and the overall experience of using the Xperia.I got lucky and my SIM from my iPhone 6 (a nanoSIM) fits the Xperia.The phone came and Android Lollipop. Sony's version of Android (for me) was pretty easy to use and navigate. I'm somewhat techy savvy, so even coming from an iPhone, I didn't struggle in poking my way around the OS. The phone was pretty easy to setup, even for someone who's used to iOS. After my first evening with the phone, I had figured my way around it, installed a few apps, hid an app and customized all of my settings.Right off the bat, I noticed this phone gets pretty warm, even with minimal use. I got several prompts noting that if the phone reaches a certain temperature, the app will close. I turned that notification off, as in less than an hour, I'd seen it three times. I don't believe it *has* overheated, but the constant warnings were annoying.On-board storage is 16GB, some of which Android eats up, so you'll definitely want to get a microSD card immediately. I had about 9GB free as of this writing.The screen is nice, crisp and clear. I initially thought the brightness range was a bit weak, but after I turned off the adaptive brightness, I saw I could make the screen much brighter. The screen, and the back of the phone, are fingerprint magnets (like many phones) and it wasn't long before the phone was covered in smudges and prints. The back of the phone is plastic (not glass). The screen is nice, but not as rich as vibrant as other Android devices I've seen.The phone itself without a case is pretty slippery. Though I only spent one day with it "naked", I lived in constant fear of dropping it. It's a sharp-looking phone - very sleek and minimalist. The power button is oddly-placed in the middle of the right-hand side of the phone. And the charging port is also oddly located at the top left. No biggie though. Just not used to it. The volume +/- button isn't obvious at first, but it's on the right-hand side below the power button, with no indication of +/- near it to tell you what it's for.Battery life: Sony claims this phone will provide two days of battery life with average usage. I did not find that to be the case. I'm a mid-range user, power-wise, and at the end of most days with this phone, I was down to 20-30% battery. There's no way I could get two days out of this phone.Bloatware: There's a decent amount of Sony (and non-Sony) "stuff" on this phone, including AVG Protection, Album (Sony online storage), File Commander, Movies, News from Socialife, Video Unlimited and What's New (to name a few). Most of these I did not find useful, so I un-installed or hid them.Performance: The phone is fairly snappy, processor-wise, but I did find some stops and stutters when browsing the web. And sometimes, I'd have to touch the screen twice to get it to perform the function I was wanting. I did keep in mind that this is a mid-range phone, so for that segment, I'd say it performs as expected. I'm not used to any sort of lagging or stuttering when using a mobile OS, so this was a mild annoyance for me. Startup times for apps and commands was a bit slower than I was used to as well.The camera was probably the most disappointing part of this phone. Despite having a 13MP camera, the photos were not that great in comparison to other mobile phone cameras I've used (Samsung Galaxy and iPhone). Even taking a picture was a cumbersome process due to the slight lag when loading and delay after pressing the shutter button. I messed around with several of the options (Manual, SCN mode, etc.) to try and get a better shot, but none of them wowed me. The photos aren't the worst I've seen, but they were not impressive at all. I posted a few to Facebook and they were pretty horrible.The interface for calls on the phone wasn't very intuitive, but I finally figured out how to get back and forth between the phone and contacts. Calls were fine, although even with the volume all the way up, I struggled to hear some callers. I don't spend a lot of time on the phone, so this was not a deal breaker for me.The more I used the phone, the more I liked it. I got used to Android (at least Sony's version of it) quicker than I thought I would. The biggest letdowns were the camera and the lack-luster battery life.Other than that, it's an all-around good phone.I'd really like to rate this phone as 3.5/5 stars, but I can't, so I'll bump it up to four considering for the price, it's a good phone and does everything you'll need it to do.

I've never used an electric razor before. Mostly due to cost and also because I've never had any complaints about shaving my pits and legs, I was eager to try this out, as the idea of shaving my legs while watching the tube appealed to me. And the fact that I could do it "dry" also seemed like a neat idea.The shaver is really nice looking. Very sleek and smooth and comfortable to hold in your hand.I let it charge and then went to work. The first time I tried it, I did it "dry" sitting in a chair. The manual says to shave in a circular motion. I shaved most of my right leg. I still felt stubble. Like, end-of-the-day-after-you've-shaved-in-the morning stubble. I went over it again, pressing a little harder. Still, stubble. No matter what I did, or how many times I went over it, there was still a rough feeling to my legs. I popped the head off and sure enough there were hairs in there, so it works, but it does not provide a close shave.Next, I tried it in the shower. Lathered up my legs and did the right leg with the Remington and the left with my usual disposable razor. Not only did it take over twice as long to shave the right leg, again, I was left with stubble. You couldn't see it necessarily, but you could definitely feel it. The left leg was smooth and went quickly, the right leg was rough and took forever.If this is as good as it gets with electric razors for women, color me unimpressed. Not only does it take forever to shave your legs with this razor, cheap disposable razors gave me a a much smoother leg.This is a beautiful product that's easy to use, charge and clean, but it's primary function falls way short and for that, I cannot recommend it.

The product itself is very easy to mix and pour. It's not toxic smelling.I poured the silicone over my original piece and let it cure overnight. The next day, I popped out my original with ease and had a very nice mold.The next day I poured epoxy resin (from Specialty Resins) into the mold at a depth of about 1/2" and let it cure 24 hours. I then added a second layer of resin at a depth of about 1/4" and let it cure another 24 hours.When I popped my piece of out the mold, it was tacky. Two days later, it's still tacky and will not fully cure. The part of the piece that faced the open air is totally cured, but all parts of the pieces that touched the mold are sticky to the touch. I've used this brand of resin in several types of molds (silicone, plastic, etc) and never experienced this problem, so the issue is the compatibility with this silicone rubber. Despite the product description saying it's suitable with resin, per my response from OOMOO today, they said they "cannot guarantee compatibility with competitor resins". I can't seem to find much on the internet, but I did find something about "tin-cure" silicone rubber not being compatible with epoxy resins. If that's the case, I can only hope the manufacturer updates the description.Unfortunately, I now have a very expensive bottle of silicone rubber I cannot use for my resin molds.

I am an adult female and am always carrying water with me. This bottle is so cute that it's the one I usually grab.The bottle is well-built, colorful and sturdy. It also does not leak. I like the pop-up button, too. The straw, bottle and top come apart for easy cleaning.My only gripe with the Contigo bottles (I have another, adult-sized one) is the effort in which you have to make to get the liquid out. There's quite a bit of sucking going on and you can't just "pour" water into your mouth. Weird "con", I know, but I often take medication with these bottles and you can't just pour the water into your mouth - you have to suck it through a straw and that makes taking pills a chore. Not Contigo's fault though - that's just the nature of this design.Overall, I love the bottle! It's my 2nd one.

This is probably the prettiest knife I own. It's a gorgeous white and green and comes with a sheath. I hate to admit it, but when I have knives with sheaths, I find myself reaching for them less due to the extra effort of removing them. Lame, I know, but it's true. It does fit very snuggly in the sheath, so no worries about it falling out.This knife is gorgeous and comfy to use. It fits well in your hand.This is my first ceramic knife, so I didn't know what to expect. In cutting cantaloupe with it, I thought it didn't cut as smoothly as my regular serrated knives. It's sharp, sure, but most of my knives are serrated, so I've come to get use to how they cut and this knife didn't seem as smooth when cutting. It gets the job done though.There are some very nice perks to this knife though - it won't rust ('cause it's ceramic), the protective sheath is a nice touch and it's certainly nice to look at. But I'm finding it's not the first knife I grab when I need to cut something as I have knives that are older, steel and cut better.Update: my knife now has two little pieces that have broken off of it - the tip, and a little piece on the cutting side of the blade. While this doesn't impact its use, it's frustrating to know this knife can ship, and even more frustrating when you can't find that little chip and wonder if it ended up in your food.

Before I got my fence around my vegetable garden, I knew my plants were at risk. I liberally sprinkled these around the perimeter of the garden and the plants themselves. Would have been nice to include a little shaker or something for as much as these cost.No plants were chewed in the two weeks before I put the fence up. And despite seeing rabbits in my yard all the time, esp near my garden, I haven't seen one in weeks, so I'm calling this product a success.Yes, the smell is terrible, but once applied, you can't smell them in your yard. You will need to reapply after a few heavy rains.

I'll admit it - we've never had a toaster with a single feature except "toast" - meaning, slide the lever down and wait.We've found setting '4' makes a perfect slide of toast for us. And yes, it does indeed toast faster than our previous model. Do pay attention to the number setting though - the dial notch/stripe is hard to read and it's easy to accidentally rotate it while handling the toaster, resulting is much burnt toast. We only use this for toast and bagels, so I can't comment on much else about it.The slots are nice and wide for toasting bagels and English muffins without doing damage to your breads. There's many a time I've had to pry out a bagel from our toaster since I had to shove it in there in the first place.This is a nice-looking toaster, though it will spent all its time in a drawer. It certainly looks much fancier than my previous model. We like it!

It wasn't until the third of fourth time I kept getting resin on my hands while mixing with these that I noticed many of these cups had gouges in them at the top. Approximately 45% of the 100 cup order had holes/gouges/slits towards the tip of the rim which means that for any sort of liquid measuring (which is what most people use these for), a real problem was present. I took the remaining stock I had and returned them, noting in Sharpie all the ones with holes in them.My particular batch was sold by WelDun Solutions - I would avoid this vendor for this item. The cups were very thin and full of holes.

Once I ordered these, I realized I'd committed to a FIVE POUND bag. I quickly had to make a plan for how I was NOT going to eat the entire bag myself. We took some for home and I took approx. four pounds of them to work and quickly forced them on anyone within a 20-foot range of me.These are delicious. Of course they are. Why wouldn't they be? They *are* indeed creamy, and you can definitely taste the toffee. You can't taste the almonds as much and honestly, they could have left those out. Everyone LOVED them.These would be great for a party or event, but if you're a family of two, unless you've given up all hope on, uh, life, do not buy a five pound bag of these. :D You can't really just eat one and think "well that was delicious" and go about your day. Min. qty consumed at each time: I'm going to say at least four.HELP ME.

As others have said, be careful about using this if your yard has only one or two types of grass and is very uniform. Our yard is a hodge-podge of like 7 different types of grasses and had suffered years of neglect before we bought the house.So I'm using this to patch grass-less areas of the yard and fill in thin areas.It works as it's supposed to - obviously, rake up the soil before putting down the seed and water regularly.It met our needs just fine - no complaints!

I spent four hours power washing my house and deck with this unit last weekend. Setup was easy and I really didn't need to use the instructions until I couldn't find the tips to attach. I like that you attach tips for different purposes instead of a whole separate wand like my other power washer. The tips are neatly snapped into the side of the washer. Green for narrow, more-powerful washing and white for wider, moderately-powerful washing.This is a 1700psi washer and it didn't feel as strong as others I'd used. I power washed some of my cedar fence, vinyl siding on the house and my entire cedar desk. Despite the instructions saying that I should use the white tip for softer woods, I found it wasn't powerful enough to get the grime off the wood. I was worried that it would blow the cedar to bits with the power washer, but it did a great job.I spent four hours power washing the deck and house and the unit performed beautifully. No hiccups or anything. I did notice that I had to be REALLY close to the surface to get it clean. Like, 6 inches or less. I don't remember having to get that close with previous power washers.A few very minor annoyances:* The part where the garden hose connects to the side of the unit leaked a little and I had to re-tighten several times.* The top spindle that winds the wand cord unwinds very easily. There's no locking mechanism to keep it in place.* No handle lock; holding the wand in the on position for four hours can get really tiresome.* The electrical cord doesn't really have a good place to be stored/wound.

I've been casting with epoxy resin for a few months now. After looking for cheaper alternatives to Ice resin, I found Alumilite Amazing Clear Resin. Alumilite resin, while cheaper, does have a very slight yellow-ish cast. You won't even notice it unless you had it next to another identical piece cast in another kind of resin.I came across this seller/brand and figured for the price, I'd give it a try. I only do small castings (1oz. or less at a time), so I needed to make sure this would work. Based on the description here and on their website, it seemed it would work for my projects (which include magnets, ornaments and buttons).Instructions were found on their website, as well as included with the product. It's mixed just like Ice and Alumilite - stir for 2-3 mins. with flat stick, scraping the sides. I don't agree with their instructions to "mix vigorously", as that creates more air bubbles. So, mix slowly. Then, let it sit for 3-5 mins. so some of the air bubbles rise and pop.It pours nicely and can be de-molded in 24 hours. It's rock hard in 48 hours. It's very clear and I prefer it over Alumilite. I will continue to use this brand as it's worked out very well for me! The only downside is that since I do such small pours, I had to put it in a different container that had a small opening for pouring.Cost per oz. (including shipping) as of this writing is $1.12/oz. Check out the seller's website for cheaper pricing and larger sizes.

This is a neat concept, and something I've never had before. I *do* love Philips' products and have been happily using their GoLITE BLU all winter for mood and energy.This is a cool-looking device, but right out of the box, I thought it felt kinda cheap. The plastic on the front feels very cheap and flimsy and the way the clock radio sits on your table or nightstand seems to indicate it would tip over pretty easy. I worried that each time I tapped the top of the unit to "snooze" it, it would tip over. Luckily, it doesn't. But the design of the clock radio is an odd one - it's a pretty big disc and then a little leg on the back. There are two very small nubs (size of a pin head) towards the front to assist in stability, but it does always look quite precariously-placed.Setup was pretty easy via the included directions, but I found it was not intuitive enough to set up the device without them. I do like that there are four different brightness levels for the clock. My last clock radio had two settings - bright and brighter. LOL. As someone who has about 12 LEDs in her room at night, I don't need another bright clock staring at me as I sleep.There are three options to wake up - birds, other birds and the radio. I didn't think the birds would wake me up (didn't think I'd be able to hear them), but they did. I actually LOVE birds and own six pet birds, so I wondered if I'd just sleep right through them. Luckily, I did not. The wake-up light comes on gradually 30 mins before the alarm goes off and stays on even during snooze. For me, that meant nearly one hour of the light being on while i tapped the top of the device every 9 minutes. When you're ready to get up, touch the alarm button to shut off the alarm and then tap again to set for tomorrow.There are different light brightness and alarm volume settings that can be tweaked, which is pretty cool. I'm still figuring out which are the best for me.The radio is rather sub-par. The sound is not good, but passable. The little FM antenna wire does help pull in my local talk radio station, but looks pretty awkward snaking out of the back of the device. I've never been a fan of these kinds of antennas, as I'm not sure what you're supposed to do with them exactly; wrap them around the nearest tall object? Let them hang over the side of the table? Bend into neat shapes?Pros:* Cool-looking design* Orange LED clock is pleasant and has an adjustable brightness (something a lot of reviewers missed - the clock brightness *is* adjustable)* When you get your hand next to the front of the device, the "buttons" light up* Gentle way to wake up each morningThe cons are as follows:* No battery backup* Pretty crummy radio* FM antenna is clumsy and takes away from the design of the unit* Cheap-feeling plastic used on front* Awkward stature; looks and feels like it could topple over at any moment (though it doesn't)Overall, I like it. I'm not real keen about the snooze mechanism and the wake-up light hasn't proven to make me feel any more refreshed (yet), but it's replaced my previous clock radio and done a decent job.

These are perfect - they are just as pretty as you see in the photo. They are tiny. Very tiny. Many sure you know just how small 4mm is before you order. I did know they'd be small (I wanted very small), so they are perfect.I did not find the backs to be loose at all. I wear my earrings 24/7 (these included) and have yet to experience any problems.The quality seems to be pretty great - no glue or anything where the gem was attached to the post.For the price, I'm impressed!

I don't mind slugs, but I love my hostas more. This solution is pretty easy to use: shake, water and enjoy hole-free hostas. I shake this around each and every hosta and water with a watering can and it takes care of about 95% of the problem. Don't forget to re-apply after three weeks though - that part really is key. I have a fair amount of hostas, so this product is a life-saver for me! I look forward to trying it around my veggies this year, too.I've had products like this before and the shaker canister is a little easier to use then the shaker bag. No biggie though.Happy to see this can be used around pets and wildlife, too - I wouldn't want this to harm the birds I feed at our feeder.

I had several AeroGardens many years ago, long before Miracle Grow co-opted them. I had two of the smaller 3-pod ones and two of the larger ones (including the pricey Veggie Pro). I eventually sold them all, as they became more hassle than they were worth. My biggest complaint back then was proprietary bulbs and overall business plan; their website, their marketing and their support was spotty, at best, and it was just a VERY expensive way to grow vegetables, flowers and herbs.I recently acquired a 7-pod model for free and luckily, found bulb adapters so I wasn't locked into their pricey $10 CFLs. My interest became renewed. These are a really cool thing to have indoors during cold Midwestern winters, so when I had the opportunity to grab one on Amazon Vine, I jumped. I'm an outdoor gardener, so I'm always happy to see green things growing in winter.This little 3-pod model is cute as heck. The design is quite nice, actually. The concept was still entirely the same - pop in the pods, add some nutrients, fill with water and you're on your way. However, it wasn't long before I ran into problems. After the first day, the "bubbler", or pump, or whatever it's called, quit working. I saw it bubble on day one (a little) and then it was no more. I know these units have been prone to this issue over the years, but I'd personally never had a pump go bad in one of mine. I can hear the motor run, but no air comes out (or so I thought). Also worth noting: the pump doesn't run when the lights are off. So, I now have stagnant water. I wrote customer service on March 2nd - and received a replacement part that fixed the issue. The "aerator" had gummy stuff in there, so before you think it might be the pump, check the plastic thing inside the grow box that goes over the pump - it might be clogged. The part unscrews. Might benefit by having larger holes in it, too. So, it wasn't the pump - it was the aerator. Simple enough fix that I could have likely fixed on my own.On the 2nd day, I noticed the timer was off, too. I plugged it in at 4:30pm so it's "on" time would be while I was away from work. After the first day, it came back on at 3:45 and then at 3:00pm the day after that. So, that will be an annoying issue to contend with. Each day, it continues to come on earlier and earlier.Though some of the newer AeroGardens use LED technology, this unit does not. So sadly, you're locked into those stupid proprietary $10 bulbs.The basil bloomed first (it's usually the first to make its appearance), followed by the dill and then the parsley. You'll want to watch for white fuzz (mold) during the first few days and if you see it, just pick (or tweeze) it off. You can also remove one of the plastic domes and that should inhibit further mold growth as well.So far, everything is growing well. The basil is, of course, growing like crazy (as basil does) and the dill is pretty spindly, as only one seed germinated. Parsley is new to me, I'm interested to see how much that produces. I've already had to raise the light a few times;  make sure you prune back your basil so it gets more bushy rather than tall.This is an expensive, albeit fun, way to grow herbs for your kitchen. The unit is pretty small and I suspect all my plants are going to be pretty cramped in a matter of weeks. The proprietary bulbs are going to be your biggest cost at $10 a piece but everything can else can be had for cheap (seeds, pods - you can re-use the cages and plastic domes). The timer issue is definitely annoying, too. The unit does work and work well, though you might be better off going with one of the larger models with LEDs if you really want to produce more than a few leaves of basil here and there.

This is AWESOME-smelling shampoo. Really nice. I don't often get that jazzed about a certain scent, but this stuff smells really good. Unfortunately, (or maybe fortunately, since I'm sometimes scent sensitive), the smell doesn't really stay much with you after your hair dries.My hair does feel very clean and fresh after using it. I don't feel any sort of build-up or waxy feel to my hair at all. It lathers really really, too. I would say this shampoo is at least the same, if not better than most I use. My hair feels really great and soft after using this.I have no idea what cassia seeds are. Many shampoos use a lot of great-sounding phrases and buzz words to get you buy their product. "Hand-harvested" cassia seeds did make me take note, but it would not influence me buying a product or not. I pretty much go by how my hair and scalp feel after use of a product. I can tell you my hair feels wonderful, it smells great (though subtle) and I have thoroughly enjoyed using this shampoo. I would definitely add this to my regular rotation.

I have to admit, I'm a sucker for colored electronics.Setup was pretty easy and within the hour, I had all my files backed up. Just did what I always did: created a folder and then dragged/dropped my files.I then downloaded the app from iTunes. Setup wasn't totally intuitive via their provided instructions, but I got it done. The how-to is just pictures and wasn't overly easily to figure out, and I'm someone who's pretty tech savvy.I was able to access the content on my iPhone and iPad, which was pretty cool! I've never been able to do that with a hard drive before. I will likely just use this as a regular hard drive and not for streaming media, but it's a really neat feature once you get it set up.

I've had two other George Foreman grills in the past - a little blue one from college (for one person) and a GR2080B 5-Serving Classic Plate Grill. Both always did a GREAT job of cooking meat and draining the fat. Neither had any bells or whistles, but I always like them for their simplicity; they did what I needed them to do and did it well.My only complaint with the grills was the difficulty in cleaning them. Neither had removable plates, so cleaning them was an awkward hassle. Some of the coating would wear off over time, but it wasn't that big of a deal since it was only usually the little nubs that lost their coating.This grill is a nice upgrade from my GR2080B, though all of the improvements weren't necessary for my needs. My favorite part, obviously, is the removable plates. It's SO much easier to clean now! The plates remove and re-attach pretty easily. The ceramic coating seems to be of better quality than the coating on my GR2080B - it's slicker and cleans even easier than the other non-stick coating. Based on the lighter coating of the grill, it's easier to see when you've missed a spot cleaning it, too.The temp and timer I have mixed feelings about. I'm used to NOT having these options and since I'm not well-versed on what temp to cook what meats, I just always set it to 425 and grill whatever I'm going to grill. None of my previous George Foreman's had this option and my meat always grilled just fine. So now, I just set it to 425 and grill everything that way. My previous grills didn't have timers, either, so I got used to not using them - I tend to just take a peek every few mins. The same v and ^ buttons adjust the timer and the temp and I've found that I just don't bother messing with it - I set the grill to 425 and just grill my meat. The temp and timer options seem to be an added hassle that I didn't need.The grill seems to take a little longer to get to temp than my previous grills. Not a deal-breaker, but I know I'm waiting longer to start grilling than I did with my previous models.The cord is stupidly short.The quality, despite the $100 price tag, seems a little cheap. It's not horrible, but for an item of this cost, it feels a little cobbled together. It's heavy enough, but by no means does this feel high-end. The lever on the side to adjust the angle of the grill is oddly-placed and not easy to use.We've made waffles on it, too, and it did a fine job. It says not to use cooking spray and one of the corners of the waffles did stick a little.Overall, I like it. It will replace both my old George Foreman and my cruddy waffle-maker, so that's a plus! For the cost, I'm not sure it's worth the upgrade if you don't need the timer and temp settings though, or the waffle plates. If you just need to grill meat, there are much cheaper options that will suit your needs just fine.

In the search for cheaper alternatives to dye epoxy resin for casting, someone on the internet mentioned this stuff. I have used both these and the Dye-Na-Flow to color my resin for casting. I've experienced no problems so far. The Lumiere stuff is nice and has a shimmery sheen to it. A few drops in my 2TBSP batch of resin, stir and it's ready to pour.For the cost, there's no better way to get this many colors to dye my resin!

I'm fairly new to resin (casting), but have been buying and using Ice resin for a few months now. Ice resin is expensive, so I wanted to see what else was out there, esp since I'm not selling anything I'm making and just messing around. Most of this review will compare this product to Ice resin. At the time of this writing, Ice Resin is about 50% more expensive than Alumilite. Luckily for me, too, you can find this at Michael's and with one of their 50% off coupons, you can get this for about $11 total.I'm only one set of these bottles in, but so far, I'm impressed. I make magnets, charms and general resin pieces from silicone molds, plastic molds and molds I made myself (from that two-part putty stuff). This stuff smells slightly less toxic than Ice, but the smell of both is not overly bothersome to me. I do not work with a mask or ventilation and have not had any issues. The mixing instructions are virtually the same - mix 2 mins. set for 5 mins, then pour. I always pour the thicker stuff first (part B), then part A and mix slowly with a wooden stick, scraping the sides. To get bubbles out, I use my breath and/or a straw. I also set the mix in front of a space heater for half of the 5 min. resting time to get the larger bubbles to rise to the surface. Once the item is poured into my mold, I do check it a few more times over the next 30 mins. and use a straw to blow out any more bubbles I see. I mix 1 - 2 tbsp batches at a time (so pretty small batches).Pouring and working with the Alumilite resin is nearly the same as working with Ice resin. They both are de-moldable in about 24 hours and rock hard in 48 - 72 hours. They are both pretty clear, but the Ice resin is a tad more clear and there is a very (and I say VERY) sight yellow cast to the Alumilite. Unless you were comparing the two side-by-side, you wouldn't even notice it. If looking at the two, the Ice seems to have a cool tone to it and the Alumilite a warm tone - maybe that's a better way of putting it. A lot of what I make has glittery backgrounds, so you can't tell one magnet from the next - they are both clear and shiny.There are oftentimes a lot of very small (nearly microscopic) bubbles in my pieces, but I've been reading that's common with a lot of casting resins and unless you have a de-gasser, this is to be expected. You can't see them unless you're really close to the piece. There's also something to be said for the temp of the room you're pouring in. I mix and pour in my basement, which is at least 10 degrees cooler than my upstairs. I then bring the pieces upstairs to cure for the next 24 hours. I rarely leave them in the basement to cure, but I'm currently experimenting with that process. Warming the resin in a bowl of hot water (in the bottles, of course) and/or putting it in front of space heater makes the resin more runny. It will still cure the same (from what I can tell), but I'm wondering what effect temperature has to do with curing time and bubbles. I'm still learning.So far, this is proving to be a great and much cheaper alternative to Ice resin. For what I'm using it for, it's perfect. Easy to work with, low order, clear and strong. I'll continue to purchase it!

I've had the same scissors for years. I bought them years ago. They're fine. I didn't know there were so many different kinds of scissors out there, to be honest. Sharper scissors, scissors with titanium blades. Non-stick scissors.I do a fair amount of crafting - yarn, resin, cutting photographs, cutting resin, etc, so these are a great pair to have around. They've been a delight to cut with and are quickly becoming my go-to scissors in the craft room. The blades are long, sharp and non-stick - what else could you need? They are comfortable in the hand and easy to locate due to the bright pink color. You can even adjust the blade tension. My other pair of scissors are not bent handle and I didn't know there was a difference, but there is. I prefer the bent handle, but only slightly.These blades cut through duct tape with ease! Neat! I didn't expect that.No complaints. Really. These are great scissors!

A little background. I haven't dyed my hair (all over) in about 15 years. Every few years, I might get red highlights, but that's about it. I don't use product. I don't style my hair. I only blow dry it for work. I have thin, fine dark brown hair. My hair is very healthy, albeit thin. I admittedly was hesitant to try this since I really do love my color, but when I do get highlights, I always got red, so I thought why not...So, this hair dye went on very healthy, un-dyed, un-highlighted 100% natural hair.The process was only slightly different than what I remembered from 15 years ago. There's an extra step here: roots first, save 25% of the mix, add bottle 2, then color the rest. Did it make any difference? Probably not on my hair since I had no previous color on it before.Kit comes with everything you need and some conditioner for the next six washes. The smell of the dye wasn't as toxic as I'd remembered, which was nice. The stuff will stain anything it touches though (duh), so be careful.It took a LOT of washing and shampooing my hair THREE TIMES (in a row) to get this stuff out. I have a bob haircut and used the whole product, so there was a lot of dye in there. I was amazed at how much work it took to rinse the dye out.I was left with an orange blotchy scalp afterwards that I can only hope will clear up soon, as it does not look good.Hair itself feels great. The color is just about exactly what I thought it would be (per the box), so that's good. Despite getting every hair covered, there appear to be two or three spots I missed along my hairline.I'll update in a few days to see how much the color fades and if my orange spotty scalp clears. UPDATE: took about 3 days for the orange scalp spots to clear. Color is holding up well. Many compliments have been received. I'd use this brand and color again.

I do a lot of crafting and never really gave too much thought to the different kinds of scissors that are out there until I had a chance to review some through the Vine program. I cut paper, photo paper, fabric, resin, cardboard, yarn, plastic and other materials regularly. I currently did not a have a pair of scissors like these in my arsenal of supplies. In fact, I only had two kinds of scissors - fabric and what I call "general purpose".These are nice. They are very comfortable to use and feel nice in your hands. The first thing I attempted to cut did inform me that not all scissors are for all things; I tried cutting a piece of paper, and yes, they cut paper, but due to the short blades and the bigger plastic hinge behind them, it was a pain. They are meant for smaller (paper) jobs, like cutting small images out of paper.The blades are sharp. VERY sharp. I liked that. They come with a blade guard and a lanyard. I will not be using the lanyard and since I don't have kids, the blade guard is not needed. I don't use them on my knives, so I won't use it on my scissors.The fine, sharp tips are indeed great for detailed cutting. The only thing I really struggled with was round cuts, or turning. For some reason, due to the short blades, cutting and turning was really difficult with these scissors. Maybe they are just meant for straight cutting and not cutting round edges.The scissors being able to lock closed in a nice touch and the ability to adjust the tension is cool, too. One little odd thing I noticed is that the light pink part of my pair is really muted. It's almost tan or flesh colored. I have another pair of this brand the light pink is very much light pink. Maybe these had been sitting in the sun or on a shelf for a long time. No biggie, but they kinda looked dirty when I got them due to the weird faded pink color.Overall, a great pair of scissors that will be much-needed addition to my crafting projects.

Though these are TOTALLY delicious, they really taste far more like a straight up candy bar. I've tried several protein/energy "healthy" bars, and these do have the best taste. Likely because they're not what I'd call healthy, per se.The taste is excellent. Again, likely due to the sugar/sweet and all the yummy ingredients. The crisp rice is a nice touch. They would make a good breakfast meal replacement, but at 250 cals, they are a little high for a snack.You can definitely taste the chocolate and the crisp rice, but the peanut butter part of the flavor is muted. And they are indeed nutty.These would make a great addition to a breakfast routine or a snack for someone who works out, but for the calorie-conscious, they are a bit high. Same for those who are trying to watch their sugars (14g). No complaints on taste, texture and mouth feel though - they are wonderful!

I even ordered a size up, and it was still insanely small. Quality of the shirt is average, at best. These come from American Apparel, and after doing some reading, I do see that their stuff runs small. I would not order again, knowing the sizing is that far off.

I've been lucky (or unfortunate) to review and own a lot of vacuums in the past couple of years. I've always had Hoovers, but I've tried several others (a high-end Samsung, a Bissell) and what I'm learning is that all vacuums are not created equal. I think people just think, ok, it has great suction, so it's a success.  But, there are so many other details that can make or break using each vacuum a pleasant experience.To date, I've not owned a Dirt Devil... anything. My SO has a very awful handheld vac that he uses on his car and the suction that unit provides is abysmal. That being said, I have no feelings on Dirt Devil one way or the other.We have 720SF of space that's 65% hardwood, 25% vinyl flooring and 10% ceramic tile. We also have some area rugs. The majority of our "dirt" is bird seed (we have six pet birds), dust and dirt. We vacuum once or twice a week.Right off the bat, I noticed the vacuum is lighter and easier to push around than my others. That's a plus. It's overall smaller than my others and has a narrower head, too. No biggie - we have a small house.The wand/crevice tool is what can make or break a vacuum for me. This one has an easy-to-detach wand and it's long enough, too. Suction is great on the vacuum and with the hose - no complaints there. The hose is easy to attach/detach, which if you've ever used a vacuum with a cumbersome hose attachment (I'm lookin' at you Bissel), you'll know that this matters.Suction is good and it picked up all my birdseed and feathers with ease. The brush bar never shuts off and I'm ok with that. Some people think it can damage hardwood floors, but I've not found it to be a problem on mine. I have actual hardwood floors and have yet to see any damage from my vacuums with always-moving brush bars. Note: there is no height adjustment, however. But, that being said, it goes from hardwood to rug with ease - some of my other vacuums have to actually be lifted up to get them onto my rugs.The many ways one can use this vacuum is nice. There's a dusting pad for walls/ceilings and under beds (which I love) and the canister can be left attached to the vacuum or removed. The amount of attachments provided is sufficient - there's nothing else I need.The canister is easy to empty and the re-usable filter is easy to clean. I do prefer canister over bagged vacuums.The cons are as follows:* The CORD. Once you get used to a vacuum with a retractable cord, you've been spoiled and will curse winding the cord yourself. First world problems, I know. The area where the cord is stored on this vacuum is off to the side on the back. When you're winding it, it's obstructed by the hose that connects to the bottom of the vac, so winding the cord up is a pain. You have to hold the hose out of the way so you can squeeze the cord around the tabs. Also, there's a cord holder midway up the vacuum, but not one at the top, so when you're vacuuming, the cord hangs oddly from the middle of the vacuum. I grab the cord and hold it at the top with the handle, but there really should be a cord clip higher up on the vacuum somewhere.* The attachments are attached kind-of precariously to the unit itself. The crevice tool is loosely attached mid-way up the vacuum and I've knocked it off a few times already while just doing normal vacuuming. The other attachment was VERY hard to get attached to the vacuum.* The unit overall feels a little, er, cheap. It feels wobbly and not sturdy. Some pieces aren't snug and tight. This is probably why the unit feels light and easy to move, though.Out of the FOUR vacuums I now own (yes, four in a house as small as ours), this is my favorite one. Overall, it's the easiest to use, has great suction and those hose/wand does a great job. It's the least stressful out of the four to use!

It does what it's supposed to do! After my SO plunged out a huge wad of my hair from the shower plumbing, we knew this was a much-needed accessory.Though this does an excellent job of keeping hair out of the drain, some very odd, and gross "cons" should be noted:* When you first start the shower, the water hits the protector at such an angle that the cold-ish water splashes your feet. I just stand a little farther back. That cold water is a bit of a shock your system first thing in the morning.* It's disgusting as HELL to clean this out. Since all that gunk isn't going in the drain, you'll want to clear this out, regularly, and if you don't:* Since water will pool a little around this (it will restrict water flow a little bit), you see all the hair that is wrapped around it float away from it while you're showering. It's kinda gross. Every time I turn on the shower and the water hits the protector, the hair "detaches" from it and floats around it. It's nasty to look at.The product itself is well-made and sturdy - it won't budge from where you set it. And it does exactly what it sets out to do. However, be aware that all that crap that was previously going into your drain is now going to be wrapped around the protector and will sometimes float away from it while you're showering.So I'm going with four stars since the product itself is stellar, but whether you'll find this to be a beneficial addition to your shower is up to you.

I love all things snack-y. I was excited to try these! When I opened the bag, I though "huh" - sure enough they look like half-popped popcorn. I expected them to taste like it, too (burnt, stale, gross), but happily, they did not. They taste like a cross between a CornNut and a PopCorner/ChipIn, both of which I love. The taste is good - crunchy, a little buttery, salty.140 cals for a one ounce serving is about in-line with the calorie count for most carb-based snacks. There's no too many ingredients in these, which I like. Just simple stuff like popcorn, oil. butter, salt and cream. I was happy to see that there are no artificial flavors, preservatives, hydrogenated oils or corn syrup in these, too. Nice.The only struggle I had was eating them. They are pretty small - about pea-sized. So, you can maybe grab a few of them with your fingers. I almost debated eating them with a spoon. LOLI'd definitely pick these up at the store if I see them - they're tasty!

Despite a note inside the binder saying I was receiving the "My Recipe Starter Kit", no such kit was included.Included was a binder and insert for the cover so you could personalize a 2" x 3" area with your message.The binder seemed a little, er, used, when I got it. The plastic cover on the front and back had some wear on it, almost like someone had been sliding it in and out of a bookshelf for a few months.I normally love Avery products and was actually in the market for a recipe binder at the time. But the quality of this item is average, at best, esp for the cost ($11 at the time of this writing).The design of the binder is cute, and the pockets on the inside display super handy things like a meat temperature chart and measurement equivalents. The binder holds 220 pages, I'm guessing withOUT plastic sheet protectors on them. Binder metal itself seems substantial and snaps closed tightly.For the cost, this should come with some inserts or plastic sheet protectors.Based on cost, lack of anything included and average quality, I'd pass on this one.

When I opened the VERY LARGE box this came it, I had doubts that all my stuff would fit on this. But it did. It's actually quite large, spanning almost the entire width of my shower. I have to admit, it's rather large and unsightly to look at, but I've gotten used to it.Setup was easy - snap the top over shower and suction the cups on the side. The suction cups click to let you know they've adhered and also feature a tab you pull to remove them. You may actually want to do the suction part when you're in the shower so you can get the cups wet. I did this one day without moisture, and the next day, the cups had un-stuck themselves. **Update: the suction cups have now come un-suctioned twie now, averaging about once a week.** I do love the suction cup idea since my previous shelf had to be weighted accordingly so it wouldn't be off-balance. The suction cups on this shelf mean you can stack all your heavy things on one side and not have to worry.The holes for putting your shampoo bottles upside-down to fill is GENIUS. I loved that! And the slotted floor of the shelf is great, too, so you won't get a build up of sludge like I have in my soap holder.The only very slight "cons" are the price ($35 is a lot for a plastic and metal shower rack), the lack of a hook on the bottom (for hanging sponges, etc. - my previous shelf had this) and the sheer size of this thing (it's huge). None of those things are a deal-breaker though. And also, for the love of peter, quit zip-tying things! Those little buggers making getting the product out of its packaging a real chore. They used twist-ties on to secure some of the chipboard to the product, so why use zip ties to secure the rest?Overall, a great product by OXO!

I still get the occasional pimple, even though I'm in my late 30s. I do not regularly use any sort of facial care products or acne treatments. I just wash my face with soap in the shower and very occasionally use astringent when my face is particularly dirty.This is an interesting product. You WANT the two substances to be separated when you use it - the oily stuff on the top part of the bottle and the creamy stuff on the bottom part of the bottle. Why? I don't know. That's just how you're supposed to use it. I mistakenly shook it up and *then* read the instructions. It's actually kind-of fun to apply.So far, on all the pimples I've used it on, they seem to have reduced by the next day. I have a feeling this would not work on that deep, cystic acne I used to have back in high school. But, this does dry out my small pimples and reduce redness/soreness by the next morning. For my needs, it works. I have maybe 1-2 small-ish pimples during "that time of the month" and that's about it. It's not miracle worker, but if your acne is small and not cystic, I can see this working.The only issue I have is that little flakes of it come off when I sleep and I'm getting little chalk-like marks on my dark brown sheets. Not that big of a deal though.

I actually like vacuuming. Well, I like it when it doesn't fight me every step of the way. I bought this vacuum based on its high number of reviews and what looked like POSITIVE reviews.After just having the thing fall over on top of me (again) while using the crevice tool, I thought it was time to write my review.The suction is great. No arguments there. And one might say "isn't that all we need to know?" After having and reviewing several vacuums (including an expensive Samsung), there are many things that can make or break using vacuums and it wasn't until the last two I reviewed that I felt the need to expand on this. Little things (and a few big ones) really make using this vacuum a real pain in the butt.My biggest gripe is the suction tool/crevice tool, or whatever you want to call it. The hose is VERY stiff which means if you pull on it at all, the vacuum topples over. I use the hose/crevice tool A LOT. It's one of the most important parts of a vacuum cleaner for me. The suction on this one is great, but I often have to lie the vacuum on its side when using it so it doesn't fall over. You can hold the vacuum with one hand and hold the crevice tool in another, but often I need that hand for pulling back curtains, etc. when I'm vacuuming up bird seed along my floor trim. Today, as I was on the floor using the crevice tool, I pulled it ever so slightly and the vacuum came toppling over on me, actually breaking the skin on my leg and causing it to bleed. I've sustained bruises from this vacuum falling on me, but this was the first time the stupid thing actually made me bleed!So, even though the hose can expand a few feet, if your hand isn't on the vacuum holding it still, the vacuum will fall over. The only other solution I can find to this is to lie the vacuum down and drag it along the floor while using the crevice tool; at least that way, you don't run the risk of it falling over.Other minor to moderate annoyances include:* The little nub that holds the cord while you are vacuuming (I don't think some people know where this is - it's above the TurboBrush). You really have to shove the cord into this thing to get it to stay. It doesn't snap into it, it just kinda has to be wedged into it.* Since I have hardwood floors and linoleum, I use the 2nd lowest setting on the dial. This means the brush bar noise on the floor is REALLY loud. Louder than any vacuum I've had so far.* Canister has two areas you'll need to take apart to get debris cleaned out.* The place where the hose attaches into the vacuum just twists in there and is often hard to attach/remove. Like the nub that holds the cord, there's no click or snap, you just wedge it in there.* The location of the power button is poor. You can't turn it on with your foot and you can't reach it standing up.* Cannot go from hardwood to rug without having to lift up the vacuum.Yes, I know it's an $80 vacuum and the suction is good. But if that's all you're after - cheap and good suction - then this is the vacuum for you. If the little things matter and if you vacuum a lot, look elsewhere.

WARNING: I'm going to be specific and it's going to be gross. You should know that these results are possible with these pills.A little history: I've been moderately constipated for about ten years now, ever since I quit smoking. I've tried nearly every pill, powder and supplement out there; prunes, Miralax, Super Cleanse for your Colon, Constipation Stop, probiotics (pearls), stool softeners, fiber pills, magnesium, fish oil, Swiss Kriss, that yogurt that makes you poop, Smooth Move tea... you name it, I've tried it. They work, but only for so long. So I just switch up my approach every few months. Saw this product recently and hadn't heard of it before, and the reviews looked positive (though now, they seem suspicious), so I thought I'd give it a try.One last note: this stuff is not for long-term use. In fact, it states not to take it for longer than a week.I thought I would start out strong and take TWO capsules last night. I knew I'd be out and about today, but didn't think it would be that bad. Recommended dosage is 1-2 capsules at bedtime with at least 8 oz. of water. I drank about 16 oz. of water with my two pills. I took the pills about 10pm and within 1.5 hours, I had to poo. Not sure if that was from the pills or not, but the urge was STRONG.Next morning, I had pretty moderate intestinal cramping. I URGENTLY needed to go. I hurried my BF out of the bathroom. The pain was pretty bad. So that's poo #1. Before I left the house to pick up my mom, poo #2 had happened. Both times, intestinal cramping was present and the, er, pooping was, uh, splattery and forceful. Mid-way through our shopping, poo #3. Cramping, again. As I was dropping her off, more cramping and I raced home to have poo #4. So, that's four urgent runs to the bathroom. The intestinal cramping before and during the "movements" was pretty bad. Edit: Poo #5. Mild cramping. Pretty much almost diarrhea at this point.The label states not to use if you have abdominal pain, diarrhea or loose stools. Well, I had all of those today after taking this supplement.If you do some research on one of the ingredients called "cascara sagrada" you'll see it's a powerful laxative and possibly carcinogenic. The FDA has banned it in use in OTC laxatives, but I've seen it in several of these "natural" or herbal remedies. I believe it also used to be in Fiber One bars.At this point, I'm only at one dosage, and the next time I try this, I'll only be taking one pill. I will update after that happens. My advice at this point is to maybe try these out when you can be near a toilet all day, or better yet, don't need to leave the house.Update 01/25/2014: Taking one pill (for me) is the better way to go. The cramping is far less after only taking one pill. It definitely gets things moving, that's for sure. I'll never take 2 pills again! LOL

I've been using these scissors for several light-duty jobs for a few weeks now. They cut cleanly and easily. They do not feel too tight or too lose. They feel great in your hands - I have what I'd call medium to small hands (adult, female).Almost all of the jobs I did with these scissors were light-duty jobs, so at this point, I can't comment on cutting anything like cardboard. **Edit: finally cut some cardboard with these and they did pretty well. I don't think you could cut very thick cardboard, but for lighter stuff, they worked well.** I'm not used to seeing a lifetime warranty on scissors, but that's kinda cool!For my purposes, these are perfect scissors and this pair is now my go-to for all cutting jobs around the house. No complaints!

I am very new to resin casting. Before I bought my first brand of resin, I did my reading and Ice Resin had a lot of good reviews, so that's what I bought. It does seem to be quite pricey compared to other resins (like Castin Craft), but wow, it's awesome stuff. So far, I've made over 40 magnets, some cabochons and some buttons. A lot of them have come out "frosted" on top, but I'm learning that has to do with the mold, NOT the resin. If your mold is matte, the cast pieces will be matte. If you need something super shiny, you can brush a thin layer of resin on top once the piece has cured.The resin is really easy to work with and fairly low odor. I use it indoors, pouring my molds in the basement and bringing them upstairs to cure (since my basement remains about 60 degrees). Just measure equal amounts of part A and B, stir slowly for two minutes (making sure to scrape the sides), then let sit for five minutes and then you're ready! The pieces come out CRYSTAL clear (unless your mold has a matte finish). I'm not an expert at getting out the tiny bubbles, but most bubbles can be popped with a pin after you've poured.My only (semi) gripe is the price. Obviously, the bigger container you buy, the more you save. Other than that, I have no complaints! Make sure to wait at least 24 hours before you even THINK of touching it or you'll get fingerprints on it. Kit comes with stir sticks, measuring cups and bottle pours.

I don't normally spend this kind of money on space heaters, but I was tired of my Lasko only being able to heat within a two foot radius of itself. I am familiar with the Vornado name, so I took a gamble and bought one for $60.00.The first time I flipped it on, I thought it was broken. It was so quiet. So very quiet. But sure enough, heat was coming out. This is a "whole room" heater, so the way in which it heats a room is very different than what I'm used to. I looked at the thermometer in my bedroom (yes, I have an old one hanging on the wall) when I first started it and it was about 71 degrees. Within 20-30 mins, the temperature was rising. I got the temp in the room up to 78 degrees with the heater on it's highest setting (1500 and #7 on the dial). I can't seem to get it go above that, which is OK - 78 is hot enough. My bedroom is 12 x 10, so 120 SF. Obviously, keeping the door closed helps the room heat up better and quicker, and once the heater is off and the door is open, the temperature drops pretty quickly.I tried to heat a portion of my unfinished basement. I built a blanket fort of sorts to try and close off one of the rooms in my all-open basement. I brought the Vornado in my "fort" and was able to get the temp from 60 to about 66, but it took a lot longer and never really felt warm down there. No fault of the heater though - I think the expectations were just too high.The item itself looks pretty nice, but it's all plastic on the outside and the front grey grill feels particularly cheap. The item is made in China, as are most things these days. I had secretly hoped that Vornado had kept production in the US, but I knew they likely manufactured these overseas.Pros:* Tip over protection; item shuts off it it's tipped over. Same if it's picked up - it's off until you set it down again.* Very quiet. You can barely hear that it's on.* Does heat a small, enclosed room quickly and evenly - not just the 2 feet around the device.* Nice-looking device - it looks very stylish.Cons:* No timer of any sort. Would have been nice, for this price point, to include a timer so the item would shut off after X hours/minutes.* All plastic components on the outside.* The handle is shallow and hard to grab completely.The "not sure yet":* I'm not entirely sure how the 1 - 7 dial works yet. It just seems to maybe control the fan speed, though it's referred to as the thermostat. But, I thought that's what the I, II and III settings were for (750, 1150 and 1500W). Edit: OK, this isn't for fan speed and is a thermostat of sorts. Once your room has reached optimal temperature, dial it back and then heater will go off and on, as needed, to maintain that temp. It's kind of imprecise, but I get what it's trying to do.

Works as it should. I use this with my many Android cell phones and it charges all of them just fine. I like this cord the best since it's easy to find due to the super bright green (like a spring green) color.Item appears to be well made and has been a delight to use. Cord length is perfect - 3 feet. Cord feels kinda smooth and buttery, which is nice - makes it feel like it's a good quality rubber.It's my favorite cord to use due to the color.

For the price, the quality is quite good. And, it's been a riot at the office. Sad to see they don't carry women's sizes, so I'm stuck with a men's sweater, but I'll live.This sweater makes me smile, makes others laugh and the quality, for the price, is good. Win-win. HAPPY FESTIVUS!

I've been wanting a sewing machine for quite some time, but have been intimidated by them for years since I know much of a struggle it was to use my mom's back when I was a kid. Obviously, the times have changed, but sewing machines still seemed more complex than I wanted to deal with.This is the first sewing machine *I've* ever owned. Admittedly, I was intimidated by the thing since I hadn't used a sewing machine in 20+ years. If I ever needed to sew anything, I just did it by hand, or worse, used fabric glue or stitch witchery.Setup was not intuitive to me. But, I muddled through the directions and had it up and ready in less than 20 mins. Keep in mind I'm going into this with no real knowledge or experience. However, I managed to get through the directions, thread the bobbin and then thread, er, the rest of it. Placing the bobbin in the base was always the intimidating part to me. There were parts of the quick reference guide that seemed confusing to me, but I got through it. I struggled with each part of the threading, but still was able to get both done in under 20 mins. The needle threader was something I didn't know existed - I kept thinking "how I am I going to get that thread through that little hole (manually)?!" So when I finally figured out that it did it for you, well, I was blown away. LOLI popped in a little fabric square and make myself a free-form pocket. I didn't know what else to make.In reading through the complete instructions, this machine does a lot! I'm pretty impressed. It does twin needle stitching, will allow for cylindrical pieces to be stitched, has bunches of styles of stitches, has a buttonhole making feature, zipper insertion attachment, quilting options and tons more. Maybe this stuff is standard fare, but again, this is all new to me.The quality of the machine seems to be quite good. A lot of plastic, but nothing feels flimsy or breakable. It's got some heft to it and looks like it will hold up for quite some time. The included cover is a nice touch, too. You have everything you need to get started and some additional accessories for things like buttons.I have to say, I'm excited about using this machine and I never thought I'd get stoked about a sewing machine. If you're new to sewing machines, obviously read all the instructions and you'll learn everything this machine does. It seems quite diverse and able to handle just about any sewing job you might throw at it!

I have an Acer TravelMate from 2003 running Windows XP which was in desperate need of a wireless adapter upgrade.  The original onboard adapter was essentially a relic, and the USB adapter I had been using was becoming unreliable.  My biggest concern about upgrading to modern hardware is whether my old machine would even accept or handle such a device.The installation went quickly and much more smoothly than I thought it would.  I had absolutely no issues with the T2U’s installation process.  Despite having a decade-old computer, the wireless adapter interfaced perfectly with my new Linksys dual-band 802.11ac router.  The transfer speeds I’m now getting are incredibly fast and the stability is much improved as well.If the T2U works like this on an ancient Acer XP laptop, I can only imagine how much better it would run on a machine with more current specs.  If you’re looking for an affordable USB wireless adapter with up-to-date performance standards, I’d highly recommend this product from TP-LINK.

This was my first experience casting resin. I used Ice Resin and mixed it exactly, per directions. Waited a day before I popped them out of this mold. After reading obsessively about why all my pieces came out matte instead of shiny, I realized it was the MOLD that caused the problem. The backs (or the tops of the pieces) are glossy and shiny, but every surface that touches the mold has a matte finish. Every piece. There's no way I'm going to buff, polish or re-coat these - I'll just get a different mold.I will say that the pieces popped out easily, even with no mold release used. But, the matte finish my pieces had makes this mold a no-go for me.

These two products come in a cute, reusable blue and white tin. Although it would have been nice to see some padding/tissue paper in the tin, there was none. And my tin was ever-so-slightly bent.Both products have a touch of shimmer and a nice fruity scent. As someone who normally wears nothing but chapstick all winter, it was a change for me. Every time I wore either product, people would point out my lips! So the shimmer, though subtle, is noticeable. This product (the Kiss of Shimmer) feels like a cross between chapstick and lipstick - maybe a more firm lip gloss, actually.I liked the stick (Kiss of Shimmer) better than the butter, as the butter was more gummy and gelatinous.Both the pigment and scent are minimal and pleasing. I didn't find either to be overwhelming. They smell pretty good.These would make great stocking stuffers or a nice treat for yourself. If you're someone (like me) who doesn't wear makeup, lipstick or like any kind of feeling on your lips, this might not be for you. I don't wear stuff like this normally, and when I had it on, I could feel it and it came off on anything I ate or touched. No fault of the product itself - just not my preference. The Kiss of Shimmer indicates, light-heartedly, that it "make{s} kisses better", but to be honest, I would not want to kiss my boyfriend with this, as it would leave product on him!

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewHaving tested a lot of wireless keyboards this one from Rii sits closer to the top of their range (the remote bar style model seems to be the top dog with programmable buttons and the IR remote built in) However this style has the more "hand friends" curved shape that some might prefer. It's quite a light unit though the plastics do have decent density to them and the keyboard has a reassuring click when keys are pushed it does feel a step up in build.Standard QWERTY layout with an orange FN button this is used to access the top row F keys and activate the air mouse mode (the AltGr key has this function) as well as a few other key presses such as backlight control, Del, home key (for Android) etc. Quite logical and clearly laid out  (USA keyboard). Full backlight on this pad including the media controls at the top these two dials have on the left side the volume/track skip/play and pause on the right the OK button and cursor keys with home/end/page up/down doubled up via the FN button. The two shoulder buttons act just like a normal mouse for L/R clicks with a somewhat larger "flat" control pad in the middle you can double tap this to select as well.Onto the actual performance nothing to complain about here because the keys are responsive and firm and the track pad is accurate but it is smaller than a laptop touch pad so you might want to adjust the pointer speed it worked well for me though during testing. What makes this stand out a bit is the "air mouse" activate this and you can directly control the cursor by moving the pad around in your hands you don't usually get this on a small hand held keyboard and it's very useful particularly for Android TV boxes or media computers not to mention presentations.Charging is via the top micro USB port it takes a couple of hours to go from flat to full no information on the battery size though the back light will hit it a bit even so I've been testing this all week and the battery seems to be quite good endurance wise. Range was approx. 8 metres clear line of sight pretty good compared to some models I have tried and I didn't have any obvious signal loss. Quickly touching on the 3.5mm audio jack this allows you to connect headphones, and there is a built in microphone. The microphone arguably the most useful addition if you are using Viber/Skype or VOIP software this will prove invaluable and saves the hassle of connecting up a separate one. The microphone is located top right below the control pad so it won't get covered by accident I had no problems getting this to work on the Win 10 pc and Android box I used it's more than up to the job subject to the touchpad being held reasonably close (ie normal sitting position)Any areas I would change? Well this is more expensive than some lower models but it does offer the air mouse function and audio out/built in microphone so it depends on what you're after if you need those extras it could save the hassle of picking up an air mouse or microphone. Potential weaker points the back cover which houses the nano USB receiver it doesn't give access to the battery I would like to have an easy way to change the battery. That said this is a fine higher end mini keyboard and has some very useful extras included.

Note: The supplier sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal view***Geartist GB01 Wireless Bluetooth Car Kit FM Transmitter***I've looked at a few of these FM radio Bluetooth devices and the vary in form factor, this offering has a cable with a USB connector and includes a "twin port" car charger to power the device and gives you a spare USB port. Installation is simple enough, find a good location for the circular control panel (ie within reach of the driver) attach the supplied 3M backed plastic pad and it holds the unit in place with a magnet. You can use either USB port on the car charger (one is marked 1 amp and one 2 amp output)The unit flashes when pairing up just add "GB01" to your Bluetooth phone, all you need to do next is tune it into the radio frequency (pick one that's not near to a radio frequency for obvious reasons) Controls are very simple some dual functions for the buttons play and pause doubles as call answer and reject, the track forward/back also acts as the volume up/down (long press for this)Call quality was good and subject to sensible placement of the unit the speech was clear, as with any device like this you can pick up a bit of background noise, the microphone was better than most I've used to date. In terms of "audio quality" whilst a direct Bluetooth connection will give better sound output, this is close enough that most won't really notice and I was quite pleased with the music output. This also supports Sir if you are an Apple user.Couple of areas where this unit stands out a bit more than some others, the construction is solid with metal trimming on the charger and on the main unit, and the cable quality is also better a thicker more durable cable which is nice to see. The magnetic base is also strong (just make sure to clean the surface and pick a flat spot for the plastic pad) this holds in place very well and won't fall off with a slight knock. User manual is clear and easy to follow too.Not much to nit pick with on this (display is quite bright possibly could be toned down a little), also it might be an idea to have clearer markings for the USB ports power rating (the amps are stamped into the case) not that easy to see but it is well made with a metal rim around the top; a very minor point though and bar that it's near enough ideal for a Bluetooth FM kit in terms of features and performance. Recommended

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewInside this kit are a large variety of smaller sized drivers just about all the bases are covered here including the tricky to open tiny odd shaped ones that some makers put on phones to make it harder to gain entry. Nice to have 7 smaller sockets included with Cross type, Flat, Star, Philips, Hex, Torx and even a U shaped tip where two sides contact the head. I can't think of anything that isn't here it's near enough complete. This is mostly aimed at electronics smaller items like phones/tablets, computers/laptops, cameras/lenses or similar products. It's not for DIY or larger screws the biggest tips are fine for opening plugs but not for door handles or hinges you'll want a bigger set for that type of work.All the parts are housed is a decent quality case this has a spring loaded flip up action and a secure push lock at the front. The main handle has a screw collar for locking the pieces in and a rotating back part (the grey section at the back) this is useful for speed as you won't have to release your grip fully to turn it each time.
