Two extensions are included the longer metal one slits inside the main handle with the tip being magnetic to hold the bit it also provides a magnetic grip on the screw (you can put the bits directly into the handle but it's not magnetic if you do this) as you can adjust the length it's best to use this. Second one is also magnetic but has a flexible stem making it easy to get into odd angles (it's about 12.5cm long)Quality overall is good for the price vastly better than some of the bargain discount shop offerings the tips seem well machined and more than up to the job - it's not Teng tools but it's not flimsy or weedy in any way. Handle and extension are well designed and comfortable to use. The case is pretty strong with thicker plastics and when you close it up there are mouldings on the top to prevent the bits from moving around. One area I would change in the design is to have a smaller opening for the tip slots this would hold them in place firmly if you drop this box when it's open they will come out. On the back is a plastic tab to hang it and it works but it could be a bit more meaty in construction. Both of these points are fairly minor though this is a great little set and one that will prove extremely useful for many users.

This is another Curren watch I added to my collection, this one features quite a striking "tan" strap with black satin case I rather like the look simple but contrasts very nicely.The strap feels quite firm and strong though it says "genuine leather" I suspect it's part leather the outside is finished in a "suede" effect which does feel like the real thing. Bit stiff though with time the strap might soften up a little at least it's not flimsy and quite unlikely to break. Case feels fairly solid, single crown no date here the displayed chronograph is for looks only not functional. The "8" number stands out something a bit different quite easy to read the time on this and the hour and minute hands are glow in the dark, a red second hand works well with the colour scheme. Back cover has engravings on it too.Looks are akin to a more "outdoor" type watch, so far working fine though I'm not sure how the painted case will hold up to use, For the modest asking price it's a nice watch and unusual looking without being a too controversial. Splash resistant so make sure you don't submerse it in water it should survive the odd downfall or accident.

I bought one of these to cut down some sim cards, you can use normal full sized sim card or micro sim cards (you'll need to use the adapter to fit it to the cutter properly for this size) You get the supplied adapters if you need to use the bigger sim sizes again simply slot the card in once it's cut.On the underside you'll see the direction to insert the sim with the angled notch facing the rear, this leaves the "gold contacts" showing underneath with the small hole, you can't really go wrong but take care with micro sim cards to ensure they are fitted to the adapter correctly. Use a flat surface a quick swift push down "punches" out the sim card. Nano sim cards are tiny they are barely larger than the contacts, I've used this a few times and it's worked pretty well. Saying that an "out of the box" sim is cleaner cut but the main point here is that it works. No problems so far but don't rush take your time.

I picked this up for the kitchen and just wanted a small timer I could attach to the fridge or use free standing.Despite being small the display is quite clear (larger numbers are 2cm high) and the viewing angles are good too.Doesn't get much easier for controls set the minutes and seconds with the two smaller buttons and the larger one starts/stops the timer. To count up just reset it to 0 (hold both the min/sec buttons) it counts down when a time value is set (99min 59s max)Power is via a single LR44 button battery cell. Beeps are loud enough to hear. and the build is pretty decent too. Most useful feature though is the stand and magnet giving you a choice. One of the better ultra compact timers I've tried

If you're on the look out for a slow burning drama which is completely different this might hit the mark for some viewers, but the attempt at making an entire film misfires in a few places not the fault of the cast or crew I would add.Tom Hardy plays Ivan Locke a construction manager due to oversee a huge project early in the morning. However Ivan heads off in his car and starts a long drive; during the trip we see him uncover problems with his marriage and conflicts with work and questions over his future direction in both work and his relationships/family. That is basically the story without spoiling what unfolds during the 85 minutes more is revealed during the drive piece by piece.Bar Hardy entering his car at the start the entire film is shot in the vehicle and the supporting cast are only heard never seen this is a one man show taken to the extreme for a film production whilst this puts a lot of pressure on Hardy's performance it also uncovers some weaker elements with the story which could leave some viewers disappointed in the lack of pace or conclusion to the film. Credit has to be given to Hardy he carries his role well and is entirely believable as Ivan and he laps the role up easily if you wanted an intense actor trailer this would be ideal - but we're watching a film and there are times you feel detached from the events.Supporting cast even though they are only heard are up to the job too Ruth Wilson plays his Wife Katrina, Olivia Colman as his former lover/one night stand and Andrew Scott puts a perky performance in as one of the men working for Ivan. Ben Daniels and Tom Holland also have supporting roles too. I can't fault any of the acting in any way all do a fine job and more than I would have expected (not having a visual cue might make it quite a hard task voice acting isn't that easy)A nod has to go to Haris Zambarloukos the Cinematographer; what a nightmare for anyone shooting the film one man a car and that's it you have very little variation in scenes. He succeeds in holding some attention during the film some wider night shots driving, close up shots of Hardy and the control console where he's scrolling though the on-board phone numbers he keeps it as fresh as you can during the near hour and a half run.Where the film fails for me is a few areas the storyline whilst it's quite a good one doesn't reach a satisfactory conclusion there is an event near the end but we never see him leave the car or meet anyone else. It's also unlikely to bear repeat viewings very well as you will not only know the story but the visuals as good as Haris has tried to make them offer little variations for viewers there isn't a lot of chance you'll spot something you missed first time it's dialogue heavy (though moments where Hardy is silent he does that well too) Perhaps over ambitious and trying a bit hard to be off the beaten path possibly worth a look.After 20-30 minutes you'll know if the film is for you if not it will quickly get the off button. The story needs more work and I also think that it was a mistake to have it limited only to the car this hugely limits the scope of audience interest and it really needed some segments out of the car and some visual connection to the other actors at least a little. I blame the director/writer Steven Knight he boxed himself into a corner and didn't allow himself room to move trying to play the "oddball" card with a single extended scene was risky and in my view has not really worked. It has lots of potential but it will divide viewers I can't really call it a satisfying watch even though I admired the cast and performances. You can only work with what you have; here there isn't that much to work withI'm puzzled it got such critical acclaim I'm giving this 3 purely for the acting which is excellent as a story it's a 2/3 out of 10 some viewers might love it many will hate it

I bought a few of these watches from Ohsen (quite impressed with this maker tried various models no problems to date)This one comes with a few case colour variations from black to red/blue/white etc. Bar the makers name the model is: 2810A straight forward watch in many ways main time setting can be in 12/24 hours, the day/date are shown too. Next up is a stop watch with split times available, an alarm set mode which also allows you to set the hourly chime if you wish, lastly the time setting you'll know when you are in this as the number flash as do the two small dials on the top/mid left. Case is mostly plastic resin but feels quite strong and dense with a strap that matches the look it's reasonably thick with lots of spacing holes so getting a good fit is quite easy with this model.Stainless steel case back with it has WR to 5ATM marked on it I've not been swimming with this but it has no problems with a shower or bath or rain. One slightly gimmicky but attractive area is the ability to change the backlight colour you simply press and hold light button and it cycles though the various colours blue, red, purple, green, cyan, yellow and a special "psychedelic" one which flashes rapidly showing all the colours it's a bit distracting for me but I do like the ability to change the backlight colour. As a normal digital only watch it's solid and has the chunky look some like quite a nice model and another decent offering from Ohsen.

0:59 MinsNote: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewPriced a little above entry models this one from Tendak offers a few extra features over lower priced models. Whilst all dash cams have wide angle lenses some are 140 degree this one has a wider 170 degree field of view as well as a build in LED light (useful if you dismount the camera to take video/stills)In the box are the camera (16GB card is included) + mount, manual, a long car lead for power (will easily reach a rear window on most cars) and a mini USB lead plus a lens cloth. The mount can be adjusted in both directions so it's possible to angle it around too which could prove quite handy many cameras have only an up/down adjustment.The included manual does a decent job in most ways of explaining how to use the camera but I did find the illustration of the controls way too small that needs looking at but it's a small point it's pretty easy to work this via the controls which are on both sides of the camera. You do have a HDMI output too if you want to plug it into a TV for playback.With any dash camera it helps to have one that just plugs in and works at the default settings with minimal user intervention. Pleased to report the Tendak did very well here with no real adjustments needed accurate exposure, white balance in daytime and night driving were close to ideal in a variety of conditions; you won't need to hit the settings menu unless you want to adjust say the clip intervals or resolution.Notes:Video can be recorded in HD 1920 x 1080 @30fps or 1280 x 720 @30 or 60fps no standard definition options3 compression settings for video footageA 3 minute clip recorded at full HD will use about 400MB of card space; supports up to 32GB micro SD card sizeYou can take still images (though like most cameras higher resolutions are interpolated) quality was respectable enough for a camera in this price rangeExposure and white balance can be user adjustedTime/date stamp can be imprinted on footageMost of the options you need are here including the option to set clip lengths or turn it off, G sensor and the motion detection (this activates with movement in front of the camera handy if it's parked) The camera responded well to starting stopping without having to adjust any of the sensitivity options start the engine and drive off it consistently picked this up and commenced recording (some cameras need a tweak here)Footage quality was excellent with lots of details in daylight and this was maintained in lower light too without a big drop in frames or over processing on footage. Very little to fault here though a little highlight loss in very harsh light. Top end models do a little better in very dark conditions (this did well though) and you do get more snazzy features like GPS and lane warnings. As a mid ranger this impressed me in terms of the package (decent mount and the included card isn't something you always see) I have used some models that were easier to pick up controls wise as the buttons are on the side it's a little less intuitive but reasonably easy after a short time using it. I'd like the option to punch in a vehicle registration number a small point but at least you can imprint the time and date on footage. One area that stood out not all dash cameras let you adjust the compression settings this can help save card space and is useful for longer trips this model has 3 levels and even the lowest yields decent footage.The most important areas are well covered great default settings, very good video quality if you just want a plug it and go dash cam with minimal fussy or fiddling this is one of the better models I've used and comes with a recommendation

Note: The agent supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the production is my own personal viewI previously looked at the Pyle brothers China biking adventure and found it very enjoyable (as a non biker) For this trip the Pyle Bros drop their BMW Motorrad bikes and gear up with a pair of Royal Enfield bikes (this is the Indian arm of Enfield that bough the rights to the British makers name) hand made custom bikes the guys are using a well known Indian based manufacturer for their mammoth journey. Their route takes them 14,000 km around the country (the China one was a little longer) it's still a huge ride though and one with many challenges including some very poor weather and road conditions they encounter.The episodes are split into 6 segments of 30 minutes each and I'm pleased to say the editing is a big improvement on the prior instalment. Not easy to edit down what is probably many hours of footage into 2.5 hours of viewing and I think the production team have done a good job on this. At the start of each 30 minute episode you get a quick recap on the prior events (not too long and unlike the China one they don't recap all the way back just a few minutes of what went on in the last episode compressed into highlights)Blu ray transfer is to a high level lots of details though a few blowouts at times in harsher lighting. A mix of action camera and from the crew cameras it's well edited for the most part. As you'd expect with such a long trip there are problems (India's roads leave quite a lot to be desired) and the driving conditions in some of the populated areas (Mumbai - also known as Bombay) is quite shocking massive traffic jams and dangerous driving mean even urban rides in this trip are fraught with danger. Two areas I enjoyed (as a non biker) the cultural side to the country and some stunning vistas from the rugged northern mountains to hot desert areas and flash flooding in places too. Weather conditions vary significantly as it's such a large country this presents some challenges for the team. Mechanical problems are par for the course and yes you do get moments where the brothers get down and this is shown clearly. This is a tough ride a little bit of moaning is going to happen they're only human anyone doing a 14k ride isn't likely to do that with a big smiley face through the entire trip! It's hands on and real there isn't any obvious camera play going on here you just see it as it happens good moments and harder ones; that's part of the appeal of the series.For the most part it's a slick production with some experience from previous trips under their belt they've refined and honed the final production and it shows. If there were any areas to improve I'd say that whilst 2.5 hours seems quite long it's maybe over a little quickly for me I'd have loved to see another couple of episodes included though appreciate editing might not be easy. If you're a biker fan you'll love it no question there but even if you're not the journey reveals some spectacular scenery and insight into the customs and cultures of India which is a very unique country.

I bought this for a second desktop computer and to take with a laptop if required.This version only came out a few months ago and is the "HS4" model which is an update on the previous "HS3" card reader. Cable length is 1.1 metres it's a micro USB 3.0 connection on the back. Top panel has the "Kingston" logo which glows/flashes red when data is being transferred.There are a few minor differences the M2 slot is now gone if you are using these smaller MS cards you can use an adapter for the MS slot to read them; Kingston seem to be taking an approach were legacy cards are not supported (M2, XD etc) for most users not a problem just bear that in mind if you use those older cards you might want to try another card reader.The older model could read from the UHS II SD cards though not at the full speed, this one has the additional contacts to read at full speed from these newer cards; so you'll need to push the card in a bit further v the older model. Also UDMA 7 reading speeds are here (older one was up to UDMA 6) These differences are not huge and most of the changes are cosmetic with a white case and grey brushed metal case it's a well made but light card reader (rubber pads on the underside could be a bit softer though for improved surface grip) Performance was a bit quicker than the HS3 reader around 8-10% faster though both card readers do well on performance reading and writing.OS support is Windows (working fine with Win 10), Mac OS X, Linux and ChromeA great little card reader if you're looking for a new on this is the model to go for, if you have the older one unless you need the UDMA 7 and UHS II SD speeds there is little to gain upgrading to this.

I bought this card as a reasonable compromise between capacity and cost (the very fast cards are quite expensive at this size) and 128GB ones even more so, these however are do have faster performance than the older generation cards.Samsung appear to be offering this model in addition to the entry "Blue" and "Orange" cards both are reasonable speed wise though not particularly fast for write times (the Orange EVO is about 15MB/s or a little over that) On paper Samsung quote "80MB/s" but that's the transfer speed (read)In testing I found the speeds to be (on a USB 3.0 card reader):Read: 78-82 MB/sWrite: 21-23MB/sA little variation between tests but not much. That's a pretty good read speed as fast as many cards at the top end almost (some hit 90MB's just) write speeds are about 5-6MB/s over the lower down EVO that's a respectable write performance though not ultra fast still satisfactory enough for many users.Taking the price point into consideration I'm pretty happy overall it's a fair cost for a larger capacity and performs well enough for most users.

I bought this in addition to my 35mm dedicated film scanner so I could provide better quality "print scans" and deal with larger format scanning.This is a fairly sizeable scanner about 48cm long by 28 wide, though more manageable than the higher end models from Epson. The spec on this is very much the V600 minus the Photoshop Elements though at a slightly better price.In the box is a quick start guide, film holders for Medium format and 35mm slides/negatives, a normal length USB cable (if you plan to have the scanner some distance from the desk then an extender cable is necessary) and a good length power cable (figure of 8 connector with a fairy compact power brick.Installation went without issue on a 64bit Windows 10 PC this is also Mac compatible.There are a number of "extras" on the disc these are not essential for normal scanning but add additional functions:Abbyy FineReader 9.0 - This gives you OCR (optical character recognition) for scanning documents and editingEasy Photo Scan - A simplified scan suite which has basic adjustments (exposure, cropping, colour, b&w/sepia etc) and designed to upload files to social media sites; Facebook, Picasa, EvernoteArcsoft "Scan ' Stitch" - This software lets you scan larger posters or non standard sizes putting them together to create a single output file.Copy Utility - This allows you to use the scanner like a photo copier outputting the results directly to the printer, if you have an all in one printer it's probably not requiredMost of the software is useful, though you might not use it frequently it's worth keeping the disc around. More experienced users might pass on the Easy Photo Scan as you have various modes on the normal Epson scan utility.Onto the scanner, markings indicate where to load the trays with a top removable white cover on the inside (you need to remove this for film scanning) The trays are quite flexible though pay attention to the covers that clip in they are there to hold the film flat and need to click into place.On the side the power button and a bank of 4 quick scan options, a capable scanner for documents but more suited to film scanning.The main Epson scan software is fairly easy to follow with 4 main modes:"Full Auto" - Very few options to adjust on this you can set the DPI (up to 1200 on the film mode) and specify a document or film scan, dust removal or restoration and photo orientation."Home Mode" - This gives you more settings and an easy to see drop down menu for the scan type (film type b&w etc, document, newspaper and text, you have more control over the DPI, can specify ICE/Backlight correction and you get a preview"Office Mode" - Dedicated options for document scanning with descreening options, text enhancement, specific sizes etc. If it's not a photo this is the mode to be in"Professional Mode" - You have access to advanced settings for both document and film scanning including levels, colour correction, fine control over every parameter, bit depth, high resolutions, ICE, software dust removal, grain reduction, unsharp mask the whole hog is in this section as well as the settings for document scans.To start off I would suggest the "Home Mode" this is suitable for both text and film scans and you have control over most of the important functions of the scanner.***Notes & Film Scanning Strategy***Digital ICE is a hardware based Infrared technology and it works well for dust/scratch removal on most film, however it doesn't work effectively on black and white silver halide film (the silver particles interfere with the Infrared) and it doesn't work well with Kodachrome; this is due to the specific film in Kodachrome which has a separate Cyan layer which degrades the Infrared (this is just this specific film not slide film in general). In both cases you can use the software dust removal which is fairly effective (3 levels low to high)USM: Unsharp mask this is a critical setting on a film scanner and has a significant impact on scan results. Off with yield soft images that require sharpening later on, medium and high will be suitable for direct printing. The low setting seems like a reasonable compromise allowing some scope for sharpening later on without over sharpeningGrain Reduction: Very effective but it also has potential to remove details too (the presence of grain is a natural part of film) use at the lower settings to maintain good resolution, noise/grain can be removed later on after the scan.Colour restoration: Attempts to rejuvenate faded prints/film though will wreak havoc with normal photos it's quite good but make sure it's off unless the film is faded/desaturatedBacklight correction: Boosts exposure significantly if the image is underexposed, film will show more grain and lower levels of detail only use it for underexposed images as a quick fix.Image type: 48 bit has a high depth suitable for image editing later on use in combination with TIFF files, for more direct results 24bit and low compression jpegs are still suitable for some adjustment later on. TIFF files are huge, but have a large scope for adjustments. You also have options for 16bit and 8 bit greyscale, the former being preferable for images the 8bit perfectly fine for text/most documentsResolution: Consider what you are scanning and how you are going to use the images. For highest quality archival film scans then use a higher setting (the actual optical resolution on film scanners is never the headline figure) Medium format will benefit from higher resolution settings for print output, 35mm film is somewhat harder to scan but good results are possible if you adjust the settings to suit. For example there is little point in scanning old 35mm film taken on a plastic lens camera with ultra high resolution the image just won't have that much detail, on the other hand a good lens and emulsion can yield high details even on 35mm scans a sensible "normal scan" for a good printable image will be around 3200 DPI giving an approx. 12 megapixel image, 2400DPI will still be able to deliver a good A4 size print (just over 6 megapixels) if not a bit more. Don't scan 35mm film at 6400 DPI unless it's something amazing resolution wise (Adox with a Leica/Zeiss lens)Higher resolutions take longer to scan, adding ICE and grain reduction all add to scan times. Speed wise it's reasonable (comparable to my Plustek) but slows down significantly. DMAX (dynamic range) is good you will rarely have problems with the exception of Kodachrome which is a difficult film to scan (high density) I would aim for a neutral slightly flat exposure on the scans this film is unique in that it is hard work for most scanners (even high end professional ones) the Epson does fairly well. To my surprise the Epson did hold up to my Plustek with resolution despite this being a flat bed scanner v a dedicated 35mm one. But the settings are quite important the Plustek applies quite a bit of sharpening by default, the Epson really does need a setting of at least "low" for Unsharp mask.The scanner surprised me in some ways the end result/performance, though I would prefer slightly more robust holders (it might be worth picking up an extra set to load up whilst you are scanning) Even without any image editing software (there are some open source ones around that can help, those who have Lightroom will find that well suited to tweaking) Epson's suite is fairly good though it could use a makeover for the layout.Make no mistake this is a capable scanner whilst it's not quite as high end as the next model up (higher DMAX, consider this for difficult scans) it can punch up with dedicated 35mm scanners in terms of resolution and dynamic range. This model has several important features over the models below it, ICE is worth the extra price alone... if you are looking for good printable results from the scanner the increased features make this ideal for film users who need to scan various sizes of film you also benefit from better print scanning too.

This version is the updated II type which is optically the same as the I model a newer micro motor is present (it's a little faster) and I don't find it very noise though it isn't silent either. This gives an equivalent full frame. field of view of 18-26mm on a 1.6x crop body (ie Canon)Build is something Tokina have a good reputation for at that's mirrored here metal casing with chunky rubber grips on the zoom and focus ring, metal mount as expected and a smooth zoom/focus action. This lens uses a "one touch" focus pull the ring back for manual focus or push it forward for normal AF; I find it works quite well though it might take some getting used to.The main appeal of this lens is two fold firstly it's unusual to have an F2.8 lens for such a wider angle, this would be quite useless though if the lens were optically poor at such an aperture. Good news is that even at F2.8 from 11-16mm the images are very usable with excellent sharpness in "most" of the image area, there is some drop off of sharpness in the extreme corners and edges but not horribly so (not mushed out just softer) stopping down to around F4 improves things with F5.6 really stepping it up. In short for "printable" results (even at fairly large sizes) F2.8 is usable and you shouldn't hesitate to do so in dimmer conditions. For normal daylight stop down as usual though there is little to gain going below F8Supplied petal hood fits on securely and is well made it can be reversed though this will block much of the focus ring area. This is a lens which does benefit from using it as there are a couple of weaker areas with the lens. Distortion is well controlled a simple mild curve which is easy to correct.There are a few drawbacks firstly flare can be visible with the sun or bright light sources (lens produces decent sun starts at smaller apertures) other than using the hood or a hand to block stray light there isn't a lot you can do about it. I don't find it a big issue for most shooting conditions it has improved a bit since the Mk I version (new coatings) Second weakness is CA this can be visible at all apertures though more so at the faster ones it doesn't entirely clear up stopping down, this has a distinct "purple" line which tends to show up around higher contrast edges (not always but it's there in with strong highlights) This is relatively easy to remove in post processing even using the auto correction in PS/LR. Min focus isn't anything to rave about (1:11.6) less of an issue as it's for a crop body you can get to about a foot from a subject in the real world still close enough to provide some wild dramatic shots.A few uses for this lens bar obvious landscape work (it's quite a hard lens to use for this type of shot as foreground is very important) Interior shots are ideal for this lens the faster aperture means you can if required use the lens hand held (tripod is better but you can work it at F2.8) you can get a lot of room into photos with the lens. Wedding another possibility with the faster lens speed available light shooting is realistic. An UWA lens is something of a specialty but also can be quite rewarding it can give a dramatic view that normal lenses can't and it's certainly one that deserves a place in the bag here you get lens speed and sharpness trading a shorter zoom range (it's only 5mm but it's a big difference between the two but at 16mm you are still wide). For owners of the Mk I version there isn't any obvious reason to upgrade to the II model they have the same optical formula just the motor is improved a little and the coatings.For me the stronger points outweigh the weaker ones it's a must have lens for any crop body shooter

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis set came supplied with a micro USB charging cable, a clip for the flat cable and 3 sets of "stabilisers/retainers" (to help hold the earpieces in the ear) and 2 different sizes of silicone tips. You do need to get a good fit on these and seal the tip to get a strong vibrant sound so play around with the tips to get the ideal fit.Build is good solid plastic these are 3cm in depth from the tips to the back of the case above average however the sound output is also more "beefy" than many sets I've listened to. 3 main buttons on the controls the central one power on/off and play/pause as well as call answering with the usual skip buttons dealing with volume and track selection (short presses for volume long ones for tracks)Takes about 2 hours to charge from flat and I got about 5.5 hours playback and normal volume levels that's better than many sets I've used. Bluetooth range was around 8 metres clear line of sight. As the microphone is on the panel it's quite close to your mount and it picked up speech clearly.Onto the sound quite a lot of action in the bass department it's smooth but deep and not too laid back of thumpy either. Mids and highs a little less emphasis but the balance was quite good with a crisp clean sound these buds do hit the mark on this level. Soundstage was also good a closer presence it feels direct and I like it though it's better suited to pop/rock and other tracks though a quick tweak on the EQ yields good results on acoustic songs too.This is one set of buds where you do have to fit the silicone retainers to grip the outer ear sections I don't mind the extra length. A few nice features including the ability to pair to two phones at the same time and a battery level on iOS devices, and a cable clip that lets you take up the slack on the flat cable; being sweat proof makes them well suited to sports or outdoor activities . A nice set and recommended for those who like a more potent bass output.

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal view(I don't accept payment for reviews I give honest opinions this isn't a 5 star wow review)You get a supplied USB cable with this keyboard it has a male connection, female port (to allow you to plug the nano receiver in) and the mini USB plug built in, this allows you to charge the keyboard from the same cable and avoiding the need to unplug the receiver (handy if you are using a console or Android box)The keyboard is 26cm wide by just over 18cm, all the keys are flat with a touchpad to the right and brushed metal finish on the underside (this also has an area to store the nano receiver) and two rubber pads. Back section has the mini USB port and on/off switch and two LED's one blue when it's on and the other a low battery red LED (this also glows red when charging and goes out when complete) Standard USA qwerty layoutTouchpad serves a few functions firstly you can single or double finger tap for the left/right mouse functions (this is duplicated on the far less with buttons), or for just moving the cursor around. It can also be used to "scroll" pages with two fingers held drag them across the touch pad at the same time.This will work with a PC (from XP onwards), Mac, Linux and Android devices too as well as consoles though some of the functions might not match. It's possible to access the media and shortcuts by pressing the "Fn" button (marked blue) with the other dual function buttons along the top and cursor keys etc. I found the keyboard to be well made with a solid feel the keys are also slightly raised on the F and J button this is to help touch typists but as one myself it's obviously not as easy to touch type on a smaller keyboard though it's possible with some adjustment.I found the range to be about 5-6 metres, if you are using other wireless devices like mice bear in mice you might want to check the channels they are using. A few places I'd modify though this isn't backlit which would be nice though likely to eat the battery a bit more (doesn't take long to charge about 90 minutes from flat), a way to turn off the touchpad might be useful too. Quality is good though the style and design are attractive and as good as you would hope for a keyboard of such small dimensions. Plug and play as all RF devices are this worked just fine on the Android box I used it on and a Windows PC you might want to tweak the mouse speed as this is linked to the touch pad.It's a nice keyboard though I see it being used mainly for TV boxes (which are a pain with normal remotes particularly for text input) possibly some tablet users will find a use for it. Worth considering if you want the compact size.

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewAt just over 3" by 2" this tiny speaker has a very nice "soft touch" finish to the exterior and it adds to the quality tactile feel. Controls are very basic as you'd expect; A power button on the side, +/- buttons to select tracks (short press) long ones to change the volume with the play button for pause/play and call answering. You get a small strap, Aux 3.5mm jack and micro USB charging cable with this.On the underside is a rubber flap covering the micro USB port and Aux input. Pairing worked well with a range of around 8 metres, charging takes a few hours from flat and it managed just over 6 hours at mid volume levels pumping it out at the max will shorten that quite a bit but even lower levels will yield longer play times, that's well above average for a speaker this size. No problems with the microphone either subject to being a reasonable distance from the speaker it worked well.I didn't expect much for the sound on this speaker it's small and has a 3 watt speaker, but it seems to be using the underside grill to boost the bass frequencies when placed on a flat surface and it works rather well. Sound is very good for such a small speaker clean and crisp with no obvious distortion to date one of the best sounding units I've tested in this class (size) Very little to fault with the speaker it's water resistant, good battery life and sound plus it looks "good" too. Comes with an easy recommendation

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThe model I looked at is the larger capacity 16500mAh/600A version this is capable of staring larger engines (a handy guide to approx starting power required for engine sizes is on one side of the case central divider) In this kit you get a nylon reinforced zip case with hand strap which includes:- The power bank rated to 16500mAh- Jump start clamps (insulated the jaws have a no contact casing around them)- Micro USB lead for charging phones/tablets etc- Lead for plugging in the "8" supplied laptop/power connectors- Home power 3 pin charger/adapter and a car chargerTo "jump start" a car open the rubber flap and just plug in the jump leads (fool proof design you can't reverse polarity on the power bank) It can do this via capacitors that are built into the unit to store the required current (like a flashgun) power it on and connect the leads to the battery terminals. The Front panel has a fast charge 2.1 amp USB output you can either plug in the supplied micro USB cable or use your own (Apple etc). On the left front the output port for powering laptops here you plug the single lead in and pick the required adapter plug: press the "power button" quickly to select the voltage for this output 12/16/19 volts as a safety feature the voltage can't be change with a lead plugged in to avoid damage to a device.Next to the power button are 4 LED's to indicate the charging status/capacity of the battery. A single input for the 2 chargers is provided, this will take overnight to charge via the 15 volts wall adapter (from flat) but you can easily top up the battery as required. Front has a white LED torch this is quite bright and more than enough output to see clearly with 3 modes here each selected by long pressing the "power button" for a few seconds a continuous torch, SOS flashing and a continuous flashing mode. There is a larger red panel on the top to start the flashing mode on this a quick double press.A few reasons these "jump start" power banks are becoming quite popular – you can toss the jump leads out once you have this it's far easier and more convenient to connect this to start a car/van then messing around trying to drive up close enough to get a connection with the traditional leads. Secondly this also doubles as a portable "power bank" capable of charging phones, tablets and even laptops thanks to a connector and tips which are also included. At 16500mAh this requires a fairly long charge overnight (around 13 hours if not a bit more) but you can top it up at any time.Areas I liked: The supplied case makes it easier to put all the leads and cables back in compared to a hard shell plastic ones some come with (small point here) Rubber feet are on the bottom of the battery case helping it grip a surface the build feels quite good for day to day use I can't see it being a problem (I do like the shock proof casings on power banks and it would suit this product well).Could be improved: Instructions are passable but could benefit from a few more diagrams and a bit of translation work it's not hard to operate this but the manual could be a little better. The micro USB cable is handy to have but I prefer the “4 in 1” connector that has the mini/micro/apple connectors.In conclusions minor points aside this is a very useful starter/power bank which as a package makes it's a must have for most motorists. Not only can you get rid of the jump leads you have an emergency light/hazard warning and if you're caught out for juice on a phone/tablet/laptop you have that covered too. A strong recommendation for this one particularly if you need the extra power capacity for larger vehicles.

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal view.Box contents: Tracker, User manual, mini screwdriver, and micro USB charging cableAt around 5cm by 5cm this small compact unit is a robust little device the outer casing has a good quality soft touch effect to it, with additional dust and water sealing on the port cover/buttons and the top section which can be removed via 4 screws to fit the sim card.This is one product where you do want to read the manual not because it's difficult to get started or up and running, but you need to know the "commands" to control the settings (which is done via SMS) This takes a normal sized sim card, if you have a smaller one then you'll need an adapter. All you need is some credit (if it's pre paid) or a live contract card.Once you insert a sim card the system can be powered on this takes about 30-40 seconds to boot up and get a lock on the network signal/GPS. A blue LED flashes to let you know it's locked on. To find the location of the device you can call or text the number of the sim card used, you get a text back telling you the locations in coordinates, battery status and speed (if any) a link is in the message you can just open this with a browser (or use the installed maps on your phone) No extra software is required to use this, but you can install the "app" or go online to the TKSTAR website and log into that to use the tracker online. You do have to enable GPRS on the tracker sim this is done via text message and you will need to set the APN number (this is different for every network but easy to find)A few other features this has: SOS button this can be set again by text so that pressing it notifies a user set phone number. It's possible to reset/format and control the sleeping action/time of the tracker via text. Bands supported are: 850/900/1800/1900Mhz. I used a 3G sim for testing without problems.I found it quite easy to set up no problems getting it to work just bear in mind a few things firstly the network signal if you are in a remote location no signal means no communication with the tracker networks will vary here it's not likely to be a problem for most users. GPS is accurate to around 5-6 metres, though indoors will vary outside there were no issues with it locking on consistently. The maker quotes a battery standby of 180 hours it's hard to test this without extensive use but the power saving settings can come into play here.I like the design it's small and rugged in build and easy to find a place in a bag/car or being carried on a keychain/pocket. The manual has most of the important information you need, but could use a translator to give it a going over the essential stuff is easily picked out though. App worked well without any stability problems. Quite a few applications for this a child, friend or relative going away or on a trip, if you want to just keep tabs on an object or car it's ideal for this purpose. I can see a few would be detectives going for this too, small enough to tuck away discreetly, though pets are another potential use. Over time I can see the technology developing with products like this but right now this is affordable and works well.

I picked up one of these on a special deal an ex display model, with 12 months warranty. The X-E1 has been discontinued, but remains very attractively priced if you can find older stock or a second hand buy. This model sits between the entry X range and the X-Pro 1 and X-T1 and has been replaced with the X-E2. This bundle includes the XF 18-55 mm f/2.8-4 OIS lens this is quite a good optic and is a cut above the normal 18-55mm kit lenses being both better build and faster aperture wise it's a good all round lens.Warts aside the camera has had some significant firmware updates, and retains the same X-Trans CMOS sensor that the X-Pro 1 has, even though there are newer models the image quality is virtually identical between all the cameras (at least in raw)My summary of stronger and weaker aspects of the camera having shot with one for a few weeks nowGood points:+ Solid build, partial magnesium alloy it's not quite as beefy as the X-Pro 1 but a step up in build v the entry models+ Good high resolution EVF 2.3 million dot OLED+ Excellent sensor, good details and dynamic range lots of latitude for raw processing at both ends+ Very good jpeg processing (in fact much nicer than the newer models) contrast isn't too high, dynamic range is very decent and it doesn't suffer from the aggressive noise reduction new models do+ Great low light performance (though Fuji are overstating the actual ISO somewhat)+ Easy to use and mostly intuitive operation Q Menu is very useful and makes most settings within easy reach+ Some useful features like panoramic sweep, electronic level, option to store up to 7 custom settings+ AF + MF allows you to manual focus after autofocus (with latest firmware update)+ Focus peak feature useful for manual focus or using non Fuji lenses with an adapter, 2 levels of magnification+ Metering and Auto White Balance are mostly on target, appealing tonality and “look” to images (very subjective but many do like the Fuji look)+ Traditional “range finder” feel in both handling and style, shutter speed dial and exposure compensation give a more “hands on” experience, two buttons can be user set to specific functionsWeaker aspects:- EVF lags in lower light conditions (quite a bit)- Rear LCD is a perfectly usable 460k 2.8” panel but it's not up to the newer displays nothing stand out here- No way to remove the EV compensation on the EVF display (cuts into the image on the left hand side)- Continuous autofocus isn't great, central AF point only not really suitable for action or moving subjects (at least not moving quickly)- 2.5mm microphone socket the whole world uses 3.5mm and Fuji picks a non standard size (you can buy an adapter for it)- No shutter speed setting on the dial for the 1/180 sec flash sync speed. No “auto” setting for min. shutter speed (you just set it, not focal length aware useful but not as good as it might be) EVF doesn't show actual exposure until half pressing the shutter button (can be an issue in low light)- Cannot change battery or card when on a tripod (door is covered)Notes:Buffer depth is approx 12 frames at 6fps for raw (with a fast card)Battery life is quote at 350 frames, it's near to that actual world shooting (get a spare though)Video mode has no direct access though you can set it to one of the Fn buttons, you have a few options (not many) you can use an external mic and video is 1080p or 720p at 24fps (and only that)Video quality is passable but shows some signs of false colours and not really for serious use.There are no scene modes you can access shutter priority via the top dial (and use the D pad to select speeds in between those marked) Aperture priority is on the lens or if you have a lens without the ring on the rear dial. The closest to Auto is A setting on the shutter dial and A on the lens (i.e. a Program mode)The pop up flash works reasonably well though it's not hugely powerful, you have a hot shoe for external flash, a mini USB connector and HDMI out are under a door on the left hand side.**Firmware updates**Over time Fuji have done some significant updates for this model the latest firmware is:Ver.2.40Updates have included improvements to AF speed and accuracy (it is now on a par with the X-M1 X-A1 models) Min shutter speed can be set to 1/500 second, focus peak function was added, Fn 2 button added (to the bottom D pad button) option to MF after AF is confirmed (menu setting) and more.There are some important differences for users who are using non Fuji lenses with adapters, the viewfinder alone helps stability and hand holding significantly, the min shutter speed is 1/500 second (this is capped to 1/200 second on the entry models) this is a better choice than the X-M1 or X-A1 esp for longer focal lengths. For other users this is in most ways very much a “back to the old ways” type of camera, no face detection only a handful of features (panoramic and double exposure) and a complete lack of “scene modes” you are back to a shutter speed dial and aperture ring (if the lens has it) putting the emphasis on simplicity and not on snazzy features. For new users they might feel more at home with the entry level X models to start with, but more experienced shooters will probably enjoy the simplicity of the camera.Whilst the weaker points are worth looking at, esp the lag of the viewfinder in low light (the X-E2 resolved this), the camera still has a lot going for it, image quality is excellent even the jpegs strike a good balance between details and noise reduction (much better than the newer models here for some reason). Dynamic range is very good though do experiment with the DR settings 200% and 400% which improve the highlight details more. Newer models have ironed out the kinks and niggles of this camera and it doesn't sport the improved AF or some of the more advanced features/big EVF of the X-T1, but you can pick one of these up for a song and even if you don't have a lot of Fuji lenses DSLR users can pick up an adapter and use their own lenses (you'll have to focus and change aperture manually but in some ways that adds to the retro charm)I have one of these in addition to my SLR equipment, it makes a useful side kick and a capable camera in it's own right, but it's not for action shooters (the AF isn't up to the job) but for other tasks like landscape and portrait/street work, it's still a capable model. Something of a flawed gem but still worth hunting out.

Note: The maker sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewLED lights are all the rage of late and this headlamp offers not one but 4 LED's allowing you to pick a type of light that suits your need. The main unit is powered via 3 x AAA batteries (you get energizers in the box, but rechargeable ones make sense for longer term use) Main modes are selected via a single rubber button on the top section these are:- Main double power light (rated to 90 lumens max) with a range of 40 metres- "Twin" single power LED lights these are on the sides (16 lumens and a range of 25 metres)- A single "red" LED lamp which doesn't have a power rating and can't be dimmed but it's enough to see your way in total darkness (or to use as an SOS light)Both of the main lighting modes have adjustable power output this is achieved by holding down the button once the light is on it moves up and down in power slowly until you release the button. In addition the twin and red LED's can be set to "blinking mode" where they flash repeatedly.I've no way of accurately measuring the output, but the main double power light is strong more than enough to light up areas quite a distance in front of you, this main light is also warmer v the cooler light of the twin LED's this makes it quite easy to work out which lights are active. The twin and double power lights have a good side spread with a concentration in the middle more obvious with the single light. To activate the red LED you hold the power down for about 3 seconds and it comes on. It doesn't take long to work out how to control the unit it's quite straight forward and it's not a bad idea to have just one button ton control all the modes.Onto the main light this has a hardened outer shell with the lenses in front of each LED to control the light it's dense and feels thick and unlikely to have any issues durability wise. The back section can be angled via "clicks" there are four positions from straight ahead to a downwards angle. For normal walking along you might want to set it slightly down.The strap is elasticated and fully adjustable comfort is good, though make sure you don't make it too tight if you are wearing it directly on your head the headband is wide and won't come off that easily. Power via the 3 x AAA batteries will vary the maker quotes at full blast the double power light can hit 43 hours of use, and 150 hours at the lowest setting, Twin LED's have 90 hours and a whopping 250 hours at the min power. One strange area was whilst the unit is IPX4 rated (resistant to splashes of water) it doesn't have a rubber seal on the battery compartment, still if they are happy to offer a lifetime warranty then that puts longevity at ease somewhat. I did use the light in a modest shower and didn't have any water invasion issues, but I will update the review if any concerns come to light.Quality overall feels very good in all areas nothing cheap about this it feels solid and strong which is important for any light which could get dropped at some point. As far as the light quality it's excellent and the ability to dim the main two lights is extremely useful at full pelt the main light is likely stronger than you would need and this way you can "tune" the light to the power you want. The red LED is said to help night vision I've not tested this extensively (it's based on the rods/cones of the eye and the rods being active in darkness and they are not sensitive to red light but provide some sight albeit without colour or details but exposure to normal light will ruin night vision, red won't) Either way it's nice to have it as an extra, though most folks will use the two main lights.Uses for this are quite extensive really plenty of times I've needed to use my hands and not hold a torch fixing the car or working outside, fishing, cycling, camping, hiking, or just walking the dog you don't have to be a rock climber or cave explorer to find a use for this (though I'm sure it works a treat for those activities) I do have torches but this is much more useful to have. Overall a top tier headlamp is almost every way it's a flexible lighting product that is well made and designed. Highly recommended

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewNo shortage of USB charging options on the market but this one seems to strike a good balance price/quality, a nice extra is the "intelligent" output of the 3 ports. No need to worry about which port to plug in to (usually rated at 1 or 2 amps on most chargers) this one is smart enough to provide optimal charging for whatever you are using be it Apple or Android phones/tablets as well as the advantage of running an in car GPS or Dash camera off the ports if you want. This can fast charge all 3 ports too at up to 2.4 amps per port not something you see on many 3 port chargers.The main charging unit is plastic but it feels quite dense and covered with a nice "soft touch" rubber finish it adds a bit of class to the product. 3 ports sit on the top section with an LED power light below that. Metal areas are gold coloured and with a smart blue trim it's an attractive item but the icing on the cake is yet to come.Included is a "coiled cable" not any old cable I would add, a normal micro USB cable which plugs into the charging port this is not. Coiled up it's about 70cm long, but extends to over 2 metres with ease allowing you to connect up devices for back seat passengers with no problems at all. The cable deserves a special mention not just for the "coiled" part but the build on the cable is something else. It feels ultra robust and has quality grips on both ends, the cable girth is significantly higher than most cables I've seen (the maker states it is optimised for charging and won't work for data transfer) it looks and feels super strong and likely to withstand some serious abuse.At this price point this is easily one of the best I've used overall in terms of the package on offer (the ultra tough longer USB cable alone is worth the asking price almost) No problems to report this charger is well made, very competitively priced and oozes quality, the fact it also has a high output on all ports and they are all intelligent ports makes it an outstanding buy in my books. Highly recommended

This SD card from Transcend is rated at class 4 speeds, which is adequate for some devices speed wise. But with newer cameras and higher resolution video becoming the norm the performance is starting to lag a little.Build is fine standard plastics on the case I've had this card for a few years and it's fine for use in an older compact. I tested the speed at:Read: 11 MB/sWrite: 5.7 MB/sThat's a little above the required class 4 rating, but a normal class 10 card will give around double the write speed and most class 10 cards I've tested will get near to 20 MB's pulling files off the card (ie read speed). If you're transferring larger files the read time on slower cards like this can come into play. It's not a bad card not had any problems using it, but only really recommended for non video/photo use or older cameras with smaller files. You can save a bit with the lower speed if you want a big capacity, the small price premium you pay for a class 10 card has effectively made class 4 cards redundant for most users. Not bad, but starting to look a little dated in 2015 speed wise

Note: The maker provided me with a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThe M04 headphones come nicely boxed with clear and simple instructions very easy to follow. Build wise the headphones are a cut above what you might expect at this price point, good quality plastics, metal rails in the adjusters on either side and some excellent very soft padding on the headband and ear cups. It takes about 2.5 hours to charge these up (LED lights red whilst charging and goes out when finished) I got over 15 hours of playback at fairly high levels, endurance is good for a set of Bluetooth headphones lower volumes will yield longer play time.Controls are straight forward to pair up the phones press and hold the power button (this also doubles as a call answer/end control) on the left hand side the LED's flash red/blue pair up the "M04" and it's ready to go I tested the range and got about 8 metres this will vary depending on the transmission device (ie tablet/phone) and if you try to punch through concrete walls the range will be less but certainly above average performance here.On the left hand side you have separate volume control buttons, next to the power button at the front is a "mesh grill" the microphone sits behind this, this performs well being quite clear picking up sound (though it can pick up background noises a bit) it does however have the advantage of being integrated into the casing and near to where your mouth is. Right hand side has 3 buttons track forward/back and play/pause very easy to get used to this wearing the phones the track and volume buttons have raised dots so you can by feel know what you are changing.**Audio Quality**Very good, the phones would be best described as "smooth" in terms of sound, bass is well reproduced not overly thumpy either nor too laid back, mid tones and treble as balanced not overly harsh but clear and defined. I tried quite a few different styles of music from instrumental to metal and pop a very satisfactory listening experience in all cases. If you like edgy and hard this might not suit your listening style, for me though they occupy a middle ground where you can adjust the EQ to suit your taste in output.Stereo separation was also very good well above average here for the price pointBeing "closed type" phones sound isolation is good with not much sound leakage, this won't annoy people at moderate volume levels if you're in a quiet place**Areas for improvement**My experience mirrors that of another review here in that there are a few minor points to note with the headphones. I would agree that the "mini" USB cover (cable is included for charging) is difficult to open, it's a harder plastic covering and quite stiff even with a fingernail it can be tricky to remove, one solution might be a rubber material or I found leaving the cover just slightly raised helped no end. If you push it back fully it's not so easy to open up.The other niggle is the powering on it's easy to go into pairing mode by accident if you are wearing the phones you'll notice the ascending tones when it's powered on, if you hold it for another few seconds it will try to pair up. A longer delay between powering up and pairing (or moving the pairing button to play/pause) would solve this.I wouldn't mind the choice of having a 3.5mm cable to plug in (to use with non Bluetooth devices) but that's a very small suggestion**Conclusion*A special mention must go to the comfort and design of the phones, to date one of the most comfy pair of phones I've used thanks in part to a generous soft padding on the ear cups and the headband. Weight is very light too really you won't even notice you have them on, top marks in this area.I'm slightly torn on rating with these the minor points noted could be addressed, but the supreme comfort and warm smooth sound output genuinely are impressive and really the phones punch well above their price point in these areas. On balance Ausdom have a winner here well made, good sound easy to recommend as very good affordable over the ears headphones.

Note: The maker sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewModel: BTSP-10POpening up the box this speaker is quite a nice small size 17cm length by 5 cm wide and stands about 6.5cm tall. In the box you get a felt pouch to store the speaker, a micro USB cable for charging, and a flat style 3.5mm male to male lead (gold plated) Build is solid with a "soft touch" effect on the case, a nice contrasting red speaker grill area. Controls are dead simple the top section has the Bluetooth logo (press and hold it for about 5-6 seconds to enter pairing mode - the LED glows red/blue on the front and you get a 2 tone audio beep this turns to blue when it's paired), this button is also your play/pause control. The +/- buttons as expected control the volume output. On the right side is the power switch, micro USB port for charging and the 3.5mm auxiliary input this switches over automatically if you plug the lead in. The underside has 4 soft rubber pads to help it grip and absorb vibrations.**In use**Charging from flat takes just over 3 hours the manual cautions about using a faster than 1.0 amp charging output (many chargers will regulate their power output but to be on the safe side pick the 1 amp ports) Battery life was very good I got over 9 hours at fairly high volumes with some power still left, at more modest volume levels you should be able to extend that a bit and even more if you use the Aux input as the Bluetooth won't be in use.The call functions of the speaker are controlled by the Bluetooth button a single press answers and ends calls a double press redials the last number. Built in microphone did a good job of picking up my voice clear and easy for others to hear me. Bluetooth range I tested it at around 8 metres this might vary depending on the device you transmit from and if it's a clear line of sight (walls will reduce it a bit) no complaints here a clean signal and no dropping out either.**Sound quality**This speaker has 2 x 3 watt output power quite good for the dimensions of the unit. Sound output was well balanced with some good bass reproduction, and clean mid tones and treble, the maker has done a good job of ensuring no one area swamps out the others vocals a crisp and the bass is strong enough without being over bearing on the other frequencies. In terms of volume it's quite a loud speaker (more than you might imagine for the size) but the important part is the quality of the sound rather than just the volume and this speaker delivers a very good sound that will suit a variety of difference music tastes. As will all speakers of this type you can adjust the EQ on the connected device though it didn't really need a lot of tweaking. Sound was good though the Aux input though you might need to adjust the volume on the device playing don't ramp it up too high.**Areas for improvement**Not many areas to nit pick the speaker has good build and sound output, and it's nice to have the small bag to keep the speaker protected and the cables with it. I wouldn't mind a micro sd card slot it's not essential but it can be handy to have one (the cards are cheap and you can pre-load a lot of music onto the card)**Final thoughts**For this size of speaker it's nice to see some attention paid to the larger capacity battery and the sound quality. It's small enough to carry with you or take out for a day trip, but has a sound that is full enough to satisfy most users. A very nice speaker and a quality product in this price range.

This card reader offers support for all the main card formats out there, including some older ones that don't get used much (XD) Support extends to SD cards up to XC, Compact flash type I and II, micro SD, all the memory stick formats (duo and pro) and the M2 one too. Pretty much all bases are covered here.I tested cards of 64GB with no issues larger cards should work as well.The unit is quite well made, solid feeling plastics on the white areas, a blue LED glows when a card is inserted and flashes when transferring data. The reader can push down into the misted semi transparent plastic protector, pushing in the sides released it upwards to allow cards to be fitted. This is useful if you are travelling with the card reader as it prevents damage to the contacts or debris/dirt getting inside. On the bottom part you have a rubber pad in a cut out square shape to help hold the reader firmly on a surface. CF slot is well recessed this should help to avoid any bent pins.The supplied cable is approx. 110 cm in length and uses a micro USB 3.0 socket on the rear of the card reader.Being a USB 3.0 card reader speeds are quick across all the card formats (subject to a USB 3.0 port of course), USB 2.0 can also be used.Performance wise I compared it to my Kingston USB 3.0 card reader and there was nothing in it much, a few MB/s either way for both readers so I would call it a draw on that side. There are a few areas though where I feel the card reader falls down a little, firstly inserting SD cards they tend to stick a little more than the Kingston not enough to worry me but not as smooth as that unit. The second point is the "press in tabs" on either side to release the reader on my sample one tends to get stuck "in" this doesn't stop you using the reader or opening/closing it but for a more expensive reader I'd look for flawless mechanics. It might just be my sample but it's worth a mention.In terms of the Lexar V the Kingston both are fast and both are solid feeling card readers (the Lexar is a bit larger and heavier) The Lexar does have the advantage of supporting XD cards, this isn't on the Kingston USB 3.0 reader (all the other formats are) if I had to pick one I think the Kingston is the better reader overall just by a hair on the smoother card insertion. I use the Lexar with a laptop and I think it's the better card reader for travelling thanks to the push down design. But for desktop use the Kingston USB 3.0 reader is better value for money. Either will likely please users.

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis hard drive enclosure is made entirely from plastic, though it feels quite good in density and fairly solid to the touch. Installation is quick and easy slide off the top cover, insert the HDD or SSD put on the cover again and it's ready to use. There are no drivers to install it's plug and play, to get the best speeds though you should ensure you use a USB 3.0 connections but it works perfectly well with USB 2.0.In the box is a small sticky foam pad this can be used to prevent a thinner hard drive from moving around this unit can take up to 9.5mm drives most of the bigger 2.5" drives (ie over 500GB) are this size. The USB cable connects via a standard micro USB 3.0 connection, this is quite thick and feels of good quality.Performance will largely be based on the host USB controller, but this was just as quick as recent similar enclosures I've reviewed so nothing to complain about speed wise here. The fastest SSD's will exceed the USB 3.0 bandwidth but at that level you can move huge files around and very quickly it's really not something likely to bother most users it's much quicker than the older USB 2.0. On the front is a blue LED that glows when powered and data is being transferred, there is a DC 5 volt socket too. A nice touch is the auto power save function this spins the drive down to idle if it's not used for half an hour.No obvious complaints here this does the job well and is certainly up to par on speed. I wouldn't mind a few rubber pads on the bottom of the case if you have it on a desk to stop it moving around, vibrations are rarely an issue on 2.5" hard drives and obvious not a concern at all on SSD's. This unit is probably better suited if you are likely to change the drive more frequently, the other model (FE205) has an aluminium top and a different method of insertion. This one is faster to change drives, the other one does feel a bit more solid in the hand.

This is the "uprated" version of Sony's higher speed weather resistant SD cards, the first model was quite quick for read times (over 90MB/s) but somewhat below the comparable SanDisk extreme cards for write performance.Both cards look very similar, but take note of the "3" in the U box which is the newer faster speed rating (rather than the "1" number) I reviewed the original card and it was about 39-40MB/s this newer version tested quite a lot faster for the write times:Read: 87MB/sWrite: 60 MB/sThere was some variation in speeds for read times (it got over 90MB/s in some tests) this is the average figure I came to. Write times were consistently on the specification of 60MB/s making this card on a par with the SanDisk Extreme PLUS, in fact a bit faster on read speeds (that card is rated 80MB/s read 60MB/s write) and it's slightly cheaper too.You don't get a case with the card it's in a "eco pack" The case material is strengthened over a normal SD card and resists shock, temperature, water and X-rays just like it's competitor. In camera performance was also excellent and buffer clearing times are a good bit improved over the first Sony model. One minor area where Sony could improve the warranty is 5 years, whilst I doubt many people return cards years after purchase some makers are offering lifetime warranties.To get the full benefit from this card you need a camera that is UHS (ultra high speed) compatible, though it will work with any device that can support the larger card size. The "U3" designation requires that a card meet a minimum of 30MB/s speed read/write this far exceeds that and is also rated for use with "4K" video capture. If you've been using the U1 Sony cards and felt the write performance wasn't as good as it might be, then this gives you a 50% boost in write speeds and it's quite noticeable especially if you do a lot of action and hit the camera buffer frequently. Sony do have a 90MB/s (write) card out there which I have yet to test, but the speed of this is likely fast enough for many without attracting the price premium some of the fastest SD cards do. A solid card it's fast, well made and an attractive price. Recommended

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal view**Model no. YH-700C**This is the second model I have tested from Avantek, branded as “Aperlite YH-700C”, this is very similar in appearance to the DF 660 externally but there some important differences in this model.The flash is very well specified; in feature set it is comparable to the Canon 580 EXII that means not only is it a fully dedicated TTL flash, but it's capable of acting as a “master” and “slave” flash and it offers HSS (high speed sync). In effect you're getting a “fully featured flash” for off and on camera work that is complete in functionality and lacking almost nothing (bar weather sealing) Included in the bundle are soft bag for storing the flash, a flash stand and instructionsI tested the unit side by side with a 580 EXII flashgun and rounded up a list of stronger and weaker points.Good points:+ Decent build overall, plastics are quite dense and the unit feels well put together, metal shoe+ Supports advanced features such as TTL Master/Slave flash (with ratio control), HSS (high speed sync) and a modelling light, flash exposure bracketing+ Fast re-cycle times around 3 seconds at full power+ Strong power output and consistent exposures in TTL off and on camera+ Optical slave mode with or without pre-flash suppression+ Full manual control from 1/1 to 1/128 power in 1/3 of a stop increments for a fine degree of control+ Auto zoom head with manual control of the zoom possible, has audible “beeps”+ Relatively simple operation, which will be familiar to anyone who has used a Canon OEM flash+ Built in “wide angle panel” (14mm) and white bounce card+ PC sync socket and port for power pack+ Remarkable feature set for the price+ Excellent bright AF assist beam (spraying a pattern of lines to allow focus in low light)Weaker areas:- Viewing angles on the LCD are not great top/bottom (but fine from side to side)- I would prefer a better quality “flash pouch” where you can store the flash and the stand- Some buttons have “dual functions” not marked on the flashgun, would be better if the back-light button could activate for longer, or if there was a mode to turn it on so any button would activate the back light- Custom settings show just a number (you'll need to look at the manual to see what settings they change or check the camera in the external flash settings menu)- Pilot button doesn't light when ready (but you have audible beeps and a confirmation in the viewfinder)Notes:I fired 35 full power shots in quick succession, there was no sign of the flash shutting down or over heating (there is a safety cut off feature) it's unlikely to be an issue in day to day use of this flash (test cells 4 x Eneloop AA's)Key differences between the 580 EXII flash and the YH-700CThe 580 EXII is weather sealed the YH-700C is notThere is an “E” mode on the Canon flash this meters off the flash sensor (not the camera, aka Auto mode, like the Metz “A” mode) the 700C does not have thisThe 700C uses a four way pad v the dial on the Canon flashgunSlightly fewer custom settings on the 700CThe 580 EXII flash does not have an audible beep function, the YH-700C does (but no pilot light)The YH-700C has a traditional “screw down” lock the 580 II has a quick lock mechanism**In use**I used the flash in combination with a 580 EXII flash on and off camera switching between the two models and taking turns as a master/slave unit. I had no problems with the 700C flash in fact the exposures were almost identical to the Canon flash and hard to tell apart only minor variations using a tripod mounted camera. Power output is very slightly less than the Canon but I would say not even 1/3 of a stop in difference. No issues to report with reliability either (will update the review if required)Operation is near on identical between the two flashes (though this flash has a 4 way pad v the dial on the Canon flash) the main buttons are:Mode: This bigger button cycles between the 3 main modes E-TTL, Manual and Multi (strobe flash)Light button: Turns the back-light on, with a longer press enters the custom settings modeArrows: This cycles the HSS mode on/off and activates second curtain syncMusic button: This controls the audio signal on/offZoom button: Manually change the zoom of the head, a long press enters the “wireless flash modes” (where you can use E-TTL off camera wireless as a master/slave or the optical off camera mode)Central button: Pressing this lets you set the flash exposure compensation or the flash bracketing mode. Used in combination with the 4 way controller you can adjust settings in other modes.Pilot: This fires a test flash to reflect the settings (ie strobe or manual etc)If you've used a Canon flash like the 580 EXII then this will be very easy to get used to it's the same display and very similar button layout, though some might not find it as immediately intuitive as some other flashes it doesn't take long to get the hang of it though. The main drawback of using the Canon system is the lack of identification on the custom menus (just a number) the Avantek flash has a few less than the Canon.**Final thoughts**It's possible to find a few areas where the flashgun could be improved the addition of lettering for the “dual functions” most notable the wireless flash settings require a long press of the zoom button to access them. More recent flashes from Canon have moved the interface forward a bit (and offer built in radio flash) with quicker and easier controls, the 580 EXII was for a long time the “work horse” high level flash for Canon users, with a full feature set, good build and lots of power output. This flash takes 98% of that and puts it into a flash body that costs a fraction of what a higher end OEM maker flash goes for. Importantly the addition of Master flash control via this unit means you can control other dedicated flashes off camera, and it's even more useful if you have a body that doesn't have a built in flash.For a long time to get a “high spec” does it all flash you'd have to outlay pretty hefty sum to get there. Whilst this isn't a perfect flash, some third party flash makers have been working hard to move past simple manual flashes, incorporating high end features into much more affordable flash units. This latest flash raises the bar even higher and the gauntlet has been thrown firmly down onto the ground no longer do users have to pay very high prices for a flash to get the “Full Monty” of features. This is a warning shot to all the main camera makers and from a customer viewpoint this is fantastic news you can buy 3 or 4 of these flashes making a very cost effective off camera set up (but fully usable on camera with no limitations) for far less than one high end OEM unit. A quality flash, it does almost everything you could want and at a price that makes any minor niggles fade away. I only hope this model is ported across to other makes. Third party flash has “come of age”

Note: The marker provided me with a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis pack of "four" micro USB cables includes 2 x 1 metre cables and 2 x 2 metre ones. A lot of products come with cables shorter than 1 metre, very few come with ones as long as 2 metres. So you have handy selection here if you need some replacement cables or extra ones.Instead of the usual PVC cable casing these have a good quality "braided" cable which seems to hold up better in use longer term (it doesn't split easily and is firmer).
