The interesting aspect of these cables are that they have a different design to a normal USB plug usually you have the plastic section at the bottom with the contacts on top of this (thus can be inserted only one way) here the maker has decided to use a central part with contacts on "both sides" (see attached photo)This works well as you can insert the plug in both directions and it's fully functional for charging and data transfer. Do bear in mind that these are "USB 2" cables (as a normal micro USB cable is USB 2.0) that means around 30MB/s speeds. No problems to report charging or using the cables for moving around data. A simple product but some extra thought has gone into these, and the cabling quality is a cut above many offerings. Recommended

Note: The maker sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewModel: Neewer NW985 NThis flash unit comes boxed with a clip on diffuser, a padded bag (with a section to store the flash stand) a flash stand with a brass thread and instructions. Third party flash makers have in recent times been "upping their game" offering more and more features on flash units that cost far less than OEM makers.This model has a significant important addition over some budget flashes, the ability to do HSS (Auto-FP) older third party models were usually limited to manual or basic TTL, Auto-FP can be very useful as it allows you to use fill flash at all shutter speeds (even above the cameras official sync speed) it does this by very fast strobe bursts, whilst range is limited (power is reduced in this mode) it means you can use fill flash outside in bright light with faster lenses, and it can be useful for some flash tasks (which require a fast shutter speed)I've been testing the unit quite extensively and have rounded up a list of the stronger and weaker points of the flash unit.Good points:+ Solid build quality, tight joins on the flash body and metal shoe+ Operation is intuitive and straight forward very easy to grasp+ Large and bright LCD panel with colour coded display for flash functions good viewing angles+ Supports a wide range of features including I-TTL dedicated flash, TTL wireless flash (CLS), optical slave flash (with or without pre-flash suppression), "multi" strobe, flash bracketing and full manual flash control (in 1/3 stop increments for fine tuning) and Auto FP+ Good bundle includes a well made padded case, diffuser and flash stand+ Mostly consistent exposure v a dedicated Nikon flash (slight tendency to be about 0.5 EV half a stop under at times) easy to adjust output and not a huge problem+ Built in WA panel and white card+ High speed flash shooting is available at 1/16 output @12fps, supports rear curtain sync+ AF assist beam is quite effective (a sprayed out pattern of dots outside the central area)+ Audio signals (can also be turned off)+ Port to add external power pack+ Has a pc sync portWeaker points:- GN (power output) a bit lower than the headline figure I tested the output v a Metz 58 AF-2 (which is accurate) and calculated the actual GN to be about GN 48-50 (a bit less) still quite powerful just not as strong as some higher end units- Flash shuts down when it overheats (would be better to slow down the re-cycle times) see flash heat test below- Supplied diffuser a little fiddly to fitNotes:Manual power output is 1/128- 1/1 in 1/3 stop incrementsZoom can be set to "auto" (will zoom the head when you change the lens focal length or zoom) or manual from 18-180mmRe-cycle times at full power were about 3 seconds**Flash overheating test**I fired off 25 shots at full power (normal room temperature) and the flash started to emit a rapid beep, this was the overheat protection kicking in, it took about 3 minutes before the flash could be used again. Once the flash was operational I fired off another 17 shots and it took a fairly lengthy 8 minutes before it would let me fire the flash. You can change settings but you won't be able to use the flash until it's cooled down. In normal day to day use it's not that likely you will be firing the flash at full blast in rapid succession, so you might not encounter the overheating (to be fair even some expensive flashes will shut down) it is preferable though to slow down the re-cycle times rather than shut down.**What it doesn't have**Whilst the flash is well featured for it's price, there are a few points to note where some of the high end OEM makers units offer a bit more, firstly there is no "modelling light" this fires a burst of shots so you can see where the shadows are, you can mimic this mode by using the "Multi mode"The flash isn't weather sealed nor would I expect it to beIt can't act as a "Master" flash that is control other flashes via TTL, again at this price point it's not something I'd look for, but you can set the output manually and another optical slave flash controlling it that way**In use**Operation is simple the mode button cycles though the i-TTL mode, Manual, Multi (strobe) and Wireless. To enter the custom functions simply push and hold the central button (surrounded by the 4 buttons) and you can adjust settings like bracketing order, audio signals, AF light (Auto FP can be activated here) Using the 4 way controller/buttons you can cycle though the settings. A pilot light test fires the flash and lights when it's ready to fire. Holding down the on/off button controls the power.The supplied manual was easy enough to follow though the translations were quite poor in places fortunately the flash is intuitive to use and it won't take long to get the hang of itFlash head does not have a locking mechanism but is quite stiff moving it around at various angles very unlikely it will be knocked out of place easily**Wireless flash**There are 3 settings here i-TTL dedicated slave off camera flash this is a metered exposure and you can use multiple flashes in combination, you have 3 groups and four channels it's possible to set the zoom manually from 18-180mm.The other modes are "optical" off camera flash operation S1 fires the flash instantly when it sees a flash, S2 is "pre flash" delay if you are using the on-board or a TTL flash then this will have a pre-flash. This mode also allows you to use the flash with any other camera (even compacts)^^^Notes for Nikon users: NW985 N^^^The entry level bodies in the Nikon range do NOT support Auto FP, this is because the bodies won't allow it (a Nikon design choice not a flash issue) this includes models like the D3100, D3200, D3300, and D5100, D5200, D5300. Models above this do work with Auto FP such as the D80/D90, D7000/71000, D200, D300/s, D600/700/800 in short the mid level "enthusiast bodies" and all the semi/pro level bodies will work with Auto FP. As a workaround pick up an ND filter this reduces the light to the camera and will allow you to use fill flash with faster lensesThe lower end bodies also don't support i-TTL "wireless flash" control with the built in flash (again it's been left out) that means D3000-D3300 bodies and D5000-D5300 all Nikon bodies above this do allow the built in flash to act as a commander. You can still use the built in flash to trigger the flash optically (or pick up radio triggers) and you can fire the built in flash with manual power (no pre-flash)It's still a viable alternative to the SB700 in most ways bar the ability to act as a Master/Commander flash.**Final thoughts**There are some niggles and points to note with this flash, but really considering the very low cost and overall strong feature set most of the compromises are unlikely to be a major problem.Both the build and bundle are impressive for such a low price, the flash performs well in use both on the hot shoe and in wireless mode with a good range on the optical sensor too. The addition of Auto FP sets this flash apart from other models, this usually is reserved for mid level OEM makers and you'd normally Neewer would have a top tier flashgun at a cracking price, as it is they've managed to get most of it right and this flash is very capable and does most of what a higher be looking to spend quite bit more; to see it on a flash at this price point would have been unthinkable a few years ago.With a few tweaks and improvements it would be near perfect, as it is though it's still a strong offering and a capable affordable flash

I picked up one of these on a special deal an ex display model, with 12 months warranty. The X-E1 has been discontinued, but remains very attractively priced if you can find older stock or a second hand buy. This model sits between the entry X range and the X-Pro 1 and X-T1 and has been replaced with the X-E2.Warts aside the camera has had some significant firmware updates, and retains the same X-Trans CMOS sensor that the X-Pro 1 has, even though there are newer models the image quality is virtually identical between all the cameras (at least in raw)My summary of stronger and weaker aspects of the camera having shot with one for a few weeks nowGood points:+ Solid build, partial magnesium alloy it's not quite as beefy as the X-Pro 1 but a step up in build v the entry models+ Good high resolution EVF 2.3 million dot OLED+ Excellent sensor, good details and dynamic range lots of latitude for raw processing at both ends+ Very good jpeg processing (in fact much nicer than the newer models) contrast isn't too high, dynamic range is very decent and it doesn't suffer from the aggressive noise reduction new models do+ Great low light performance (though Fuji are overstating the actual ISO somewhat)+ Easy to use and mostly intuitive operation Q Menu is very useful and makes most settings within easy reach+ Some useful features like panoramic sweep, electronic level, option to store up to 7 custom settings+ AF + MF allows you to manual focus after autofocus (with latest firmware update)+ Focus peak feature useful for manual focus or using non Fuji lenses with an adapter, 2 levels of magnification+ Metering and Auto White Balance are mostly on target, appealing tonality and “look” to images (very subjective but many do like the Fuji look)+ Traditional “range finder” feel in both handling and style, shutter speed dial and exposure compensation give a more “hands on” experience, two buttons can be user set to specific functionsWeaker aspects:- EVF lags in lower light conditions (quite a bit)- Rear LCD is a perfectly usable 460k 2.8” panel but it's not up to the newer displays nothing stand out here- No way to remove the EV compensation on the EVF display (cuts into the image on the left hand side)- Continuous autofocus isn't great, central AF point only not really suitable for action or moving subjects (at least not moving quickly)- 2.5mm microphone socket the whole world uses 3.5mm and Fuji picks a non standard size (you can buy an adapter for it)- No shutter speed setting on the dial for the 1/180 sec flash sync speed. No “auto” setting for min. shutter speed (you just set it, not focal length aware useful but not as good as it might be) EVF doesn't show actual exposure until half pressing the shutter button (can be an issue in low light)- Cannot change battery or card when on a tripod (door is covered)Notes:Buffer depth is approx 12 frames at 6fps for raw (with a fast card)Battery life is quote at 350 frames, it's near to that actual world shooting (get a spare though)Video mode has no direct access though you can set it to one of the Fn buttons, you have a few options (not many) you can use an external mic and video is 1080p or 720p at 24fps (and only that)Video quality is passable but shows some signs of false colours and not really for serious use.There are no scene modes you can access shutter priority via the top dial (and use the D pad to select speeds in between those marked) Aperture priority is on the lens or if you have a lens without the ring on the rear dial. The closest to Auto is A setting on the shutter dial and A on the lens (i.e. a Program mode)The pop up flash works reasonably well though it's not hugely powerful, you have a hot shoe for external flash, a mini USB connector and HDMI out are under a door on the left hand side.**Firmware updates**Over time Fuji have done some significant updates for this model the latest firmware is:Ver.2.40Updates have included improvements to AF speed and accuracy (it is now on a par with the X-M1 X-A1 models) Min shutter speed can be set to 1/500 second, focus peak function was added, Fn 2 button added (to the bottom D pad button) option to MF after AF is confirmed (menu setting) and more.There are some important differences for users who are using non Fuji lenses with adapters, the viewfinder alone helps stability and hand holding significantly, the min shutter speed is 1/500 second (this is capped to 1/200 second on the entry models) this is a better choice than the X-M1 or X-A1 esp for longer focal lengths. For other users this is in most ways very much a “back to the old ways” type of camera, no face detection only a handful of features (panoramic and double exposure) and a complete lack of “scene modes” you are back to a shutter speed dial and aperture ring (if the lens has it) putting the emphasis on simplicity and not on snazzy features. For new users they might feel more at home with the entry level X models to start with, but more experienced shooters will probably enjoy the simplicity of the camera.Whilst the weaker points are worth looking at, esp the lag of the viewfinder in low light (the X-E2 resolved this), the camera still has a lot going for it, image quality is excellent even the jpegs strike a good balance between details and noise reduction (much better than the newer models here for some reason). Dynamic range is very good though do experiment with the DR settings 200% and 400% which improve the highlight details more. Newer models have ironed out the kinks and niggles of this camera and it doesn't sport the improved AF or some of the more advanced features/big EVF of the X-T1, but you can pick one of these up for a song and even if you don't have a lot of Fuji lenses DSLR users can pick up an adapter and use their own lenses (you'll have to focus and change aperture manually but in some ways that adds to the retro charm)I have one of these in addition to my SLR equipment, it makes a useful side kick and a capable camera in it's own right, but it's not for action shooters (the AF isn't up to the job) but for other tasks like landscape and portrait/street work, it's still a capable model. Something of a flawed gem but still worth hunting out.

Note: The manufacturer provided a sample for review, no attempt was made to influence my opinion.First impressions are good with a nice solid build (aluminium casing)The unit is portable enough to carry around size wise, though there is a bit of weight to the unitQuick summary of good and bad pointsGood:+ Big capacity 10000mAh, very suitable for tablet users or higher capacity devices+ Good finish, and build quality, LED indicators for charge remaining and charge status (1-4)+ Dual outputs both 5 volts as per USB spec, first port is 1A and the blue port is 2.1A. The 2.1A allows for faster charging+ Compact and thin body+ Built in protection against over charging, short circuit, and temperature+ Good value/quality for the price paidCons:- Not the lightest power pack good for travelling or a briefcase, maybe a bit weighty for a purse or pocket (around 250grams)- Micro USB cable is a bit short, I'd prefer a longer one- Would be nice to get a case to protect the aluminium finishIt does take a while to charge the power pack fully on a normal USB (ie laptop or desktop) I do have a mains to USB charger (for another device) that shortens the charge time quite a bit.Overall a thumbs up from me bar a few smaller niggles this is a nice power power with a larger capactity and very useful for smartphone and tablet users.Some of the smaller capacity power packs can struggle to charge tablets (which have high capacity cells) no problems with this unit.A good buy at this price

This hot shoe adaptor has a few uses, it's designed to fit the inverted hot shoe found on Minolta and Sony bodies. But do note that the new Multi Interface shoe has front contacts so whilst this will work with flashes that have the new hoe shoe it won't provide TTL. If you want to use TTL dedicated flashes with the newer multi interface shoe then you want the Sony ADP-AMA adaptor this offers full functionality for older flashes on the latest bodies (A77II, A99, A58 and newer E mount ILC bodies)The main advantages of this are:1: Allows you to use standard hot shoe flashes on i-ISO hot shoes (you won't get TTL though as all the contact layouts are different between makers and brands)2: Adds a PC sync port to your camera, only the semi pro level and up bodies have this but this adaptor will give provide one handy for lower end bodies3: If you're doing some video and want to shoe mount a standard ISO hot shoe microphone you can now do soBuild is good with decent plastics on the casing, the fit is firm on the cameras I tested it on. This has a button on the right hand side you press this in and pull it off to release it, it's an auto lock mechanism (locks as soon as it's fitted to the hot shoe)Whilst this does add a bit of height I didn't find any problems with durability with a flash mounted on top of the camera. It's worth having one of these around whilst you don't get TTL with other flashes you can use them in manual mode and the PC sync port is something worth having on it's own if you have bodies that lack this. It does the job well for it's intended purpose.

Being a bit of a fan of the first game I had to check this one out and pleased to say this offers some improvements over the original game. I will say though it is a steeper level of difficulty on the first instalment the game eased you in on the first couple of nights, but here it seems to have ramped things up a little so you'll need a bit of patience when playing this one.The story now has you playing Jeremy the security guard at Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria, this time around though there are a few key differences, we now have a total of 10 animatronic characters and there are no doors to block them off. Instead you are equipped with a "Freddy Fazbear mask" and a torch to ward off the enemies the torch has limited power in the batteries. You also have a "music box" that needs to be wound up to keep playing if it stops you can be attacked by some of the animals and you can track their movements again with the CCTV cameras.Another difference is when you die/fail you get to play one of 4 "retro looking games"Just like the first game you have 5 nights to get through, once you've done that you complete a sixth night and this one is very difficult to beat a real challenge for players. If you manage to beat that you open up the AI settings for characters and can play a variety of pre-set challenges.The only real downside is the balancing I think it gets fairly hard quite quickly so persist with this and you'll get through it. It is an evolution of the first game, and if you liked that you'll probably love this too. It can be a bit frustrating esp with the Freddy mask you can be so close sometimes and just a little late putting it on and it's all over. I've played this a lot with my son and we both enjoy if you want something simple but scary and fun this is well worth a look.

The D3300 is a minor update to the D3200, it does offer most of what a new user might be looking for, or a decent choice for someone moving up from a bridge or compact camera, wanting to expand their photography knowledgeIt's also easy to use and learn on.There are a few limitations though compared to higher priced bodies, which I will go into later on. This won't matter to many users, but they are worth a mentionA quick summary of the notable strong and weaker points of the cameraPros:+ Excellent image quality from the 24mp sensor, good dynamic range too. Nikon removed the optical low pass filter this increases the resolution a bit, you can shoot RAW and JPEG+ 11-point AF system with central cross sensor is quite good enough at this price point+ Nicely made and a smaller more compact size for a DSLR, quite comfy in the hand+ Fairly well featured for an entry DSLR, has most of what you might want to start off with (bear in mind cons section)+ Has HD video 1920 x 1080 50p which is sharp and clean. You do have autofocus (contrast) with the AF-F mode+ 3.5mm mic input+ "Guide mode" can be useful for some people it can help with shooting situations, but it's not perfect+ Range of creative effect/filters to play with+ Metering and WB are improved over the previous model quite consistent in most situations+ Built in white light AF assist (helps the camera focus in lower light) it works, though it can be distracting for people shots inside+ Good battery life around 600 shots+ 5fps continuous shooting is quite fast for an entry level camera, buffer is quite small though (about 6 frames raw)Cons:- No exposure bracketing (about time at least something was added here), no depth of field preview- No Auto FP (High speed sync), this allows your external flash to sync at all shutter speeds with the camera, particularly useful for daylight fill in flash photography, where you will easily go over the normal 1/200 flash sync speed with faster lenses or on a bright day. Camera doesn't support it so you will have to use ND filters as a workaround (to reduce light to the camera)- No built in AF motor in the body. This is less of an issue now that most recent Nikon lenses have motors built into them, but if you are digging around for second hand (or non AF-S)lenses it's something to consider. You can still use screw driven lenses but manual focus only- Live view is fairly slow to focus, it's ok for non moving subjects though. Video AF-F can jump about a bit trying to focus- No support for wireless (CLS) flash with the built in flash. You can use radio triggers though or optical slave flashes (Yongnuo etc)Body controls wise, fairly straight forward. Menus are easy to use and navigate. There is a lack of some controls on the body, direct buttons for some important functions are not present such as ISO and WB settings. You can set the "Fn" button on the left hand side under the flash raise button can be set to (WB, ISO, image size and active D lighting) this helps quite a lot. As does using the "info" button which allows you to change settings on the rear LCD by moving around with the D pad.Nikon probably could do with re-vamping the controls a bit on their entry models, ie more direct controls. But it's ok for this segment.There is no vertical grip option from Nikon for the D3300. You can use the IR remote ML-L3 with the cameraCanon v Nikon:I won't get into this major debate, both makers have large and extensive systems, in terms of lenses and bodies.As a general guide Canon tend to be a bit more generous on entry bodies in terms of functionality (Auto FP, Wireless flash, DOF preview, bracketing) Nikon offer higher resolution sensors with better dynamic range, all their bodies have a built in AF assist light (none of Canon's do) If you are taking a photo course Canon might be a slightly better choice (those missing things might be useful for learning)Try both (and other makers too) and see what you like best. You can't beat a real hands on with cameras some bodies might just feel right, some might not. There are no real right or wrong choices, everyone is different. But it's worth thinking about what friends/family are using you can borrow and use lenses and other items. Look at the practical elements of your choice too.The removal of the optical low pass filter and slight increase in frames per second are the main improvements over the D3200, it is not a huge update over that model so if you have a D3200 you might want to look at the D5300 or even D7000/7100 to step up a bit to the next level.Second body shooters:The D3300 makes for a relatively inexpensive back up body, but the limitations on flash (esp Auto FP), less controls and no built in AF motor could be a factor. Look at what your needs are. This will do the job, but you might want to pick up something else if you need that.Image quality is very good, but 24mp is stretching things a bit on some cheaper lenses, it's worth looking at lens choices to get the most out of the camera. 24mp is overkill for most users, including many serious photographers..though landscape shooters won't complain. Don't just buy the camera just for 24mp, it won't make you a better photographer, it can yield excellent prints if you have good optics and with good processing of images Low light is quite good but resolution drops off as it does on all 24mp APS-C cameras, you can reduce the jpeg image size if you wish.So overall a pretty good entry level camera, it would be nice to see Nikon improve things a bit more esp in relation to the flash limitations and lack of bracketing (the last one has been a bit of a sore point for ages now) For the outlay it's capable of excellent results. It's also quite a bit cheaper than the D3200 was at launch.Is there more to buy? Well that's down to you, one reason for DSLR's being a popular choice is you have the flexibility to get lenses you need or might want (macro, telephoto, ultra wide angle) You can spend a fortune on equipment, or just buy a few lenses that interest you. Building up a system takes time and can be very expensive. So take it easy for a while and learn the basics first.

Note: The maker supplied a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis grip from Neewer fills a bit of a gap for the DF which doesn't have a dedicated grip, whilst the battery life of the DF is excellent, this has the advantage of doubling up the battery (the battery tray takes 2 x EN-EL14a cells) but if you have a flash and heavier lens mounted vertical shots can be a bit unbalanced and it's here where I find grips most useful.Onto the grip itself it's very much in the normal style of SLR grips. Fitting is simple remove the battery door from the DF insert it into the door holder near the battery stem, push it into the battery compartment and tighten it up. You have a short cable with a jack that plugs into the grip near the latch, the other side connects to the remote release port on the DF this is required for the shutter release to work.Fit and finish the grip is good at this price point with decent plastics used. The latch on the battery cover is metal, you have a reinforced metal plate inside too where the bottom tripod thread is and this has a large rubber pad on the bottom to stop it slipping about. Couple of points I look for in grips firstly the thumbscrew where you tighten this up to the body it doesn't rattle that has been an issue on some grips I've used so pleased to see this isn't a problem. The other is how well it integrates with the body, the DF is a retro looking camera and this grip is a normal style but to my eyes it matches up quite well considering, the texture on the front and read rubber pads is coarser similar to the DF. The rear pad has a nice moulded section for your thumb to rest and it's comfortable to hold, on the front rubber it has a grooved area where your fingers fit a good secure feel.Now there are some limitations, firstly you only get a shutter release there are no control dials or buttons that's down to Nikon for not designing the DF for use with a grip. The other is that the SD card slot shares the same compartment as the battery so if you're taking the card out you will have to remove the grip; no idea why Nikon don't have a separate SD slot on the side but that's how they made the camera. Really it comes down to if you like using grips and for some types of shooting they do have a place.Can't really nit pick much on this (well packaged, instructions are clear and easy to follow), Neewer have done as good a job as you would expect for a model that hasn't been designed for a vertical grip (and if Nikon did a grip they'd charge a hefty amount for it) Worthy looking at if you have a craving for grip for the DF it's also keenly priced too. Recommended

slow down the re-cycle times) see flash heat test below- Supplied diffuser a little fiddly to fitNotes:Manual power output is 1/128- 1/1 in 1/3 stop incrementsZoom can be set to “auto” (will zoom the head when you change the lens focal length or zoom) or manual from 18-180mmRe-cycle times at full power were about 3 seconds**Flash overheating test**I fired off 25 shots at full power (normal room temperature) and the flash started to emit a rapid beep, this was the overheat protection kicking in, it took about 3 minutes before the flash could be used again. Once the flash was operational I fired off another 17 shots and it took a fairly lengthy 8 minutes before it would let me fire the flash. You can change settings but you won't be able to use the flash until it's cooled down. In normal day to day use it's not that likely you will be firing the flash at full blast in rapid succession, so you might not encounter the overheating (to be fair even some expensive flashes will shut down) it is preferable though to slow down the re-cycle times rather than shut down.**What it doesn't have**Whilst the flash is well featured for it's price, there are a few points to note where some of the high end OEM makers units offer a bit more, firstly there is no “modelling light” this fires a burst of shots so you can see where the shadows are, you can mimic this mode by using the “Multi mode”The flash isn't weather sealed nor would I expect it to beIt can't act as a “Master” flash that is control other flashes via TTL, again at this price point it's not something I'd look for, but you can set the output manually and another optical slave flash controlling it that way**In use**Operation is simple the mode button cycles though the E-TTL mode, Manual, Multi (strobe) and Wireless. To enter the custom functions simply push and hold the central button (surrounded by the 4 buttons) and you can adjust settings like bracketing order, audio signals, AF light (HSS can be activated here) Using the 4 way controller/buttons you can cycle though the settings. A pilot light test fires the flash and lights when it's ready to fire. Holding down the on/off button controls the power.The supplied manual was easy enough to follow though the translations were quite poor in places fortunately the flash is intuitive to use and it won't take long to get the hang of itFlash head does not have a locking mechanism but is quite stiff moving it around at various angles very unlikely it will be knocked out of place easily**Wireless flash**There are 3 settings here E-TTL dedicated slave off camera flash this is a metered exposure and you can use multiple flashes in combination, you have 3 groups and four channels it's possible to set the zoom manually from 18-180mm.The other modes are “optical” off camera flash operation S1 fires the flash instantly when it sees a flash, S2 is “pre flash” delay if you are using the on-board or a TTL flash then this will have a pre-flash. This mode also allows you to use the flash with any other camera (even compacts)**Final thoughts**There are some niggles and points to note with this flash, but really considering the very low cost and overall strong feature set most of the compromises are unlikely to be a major problem.Both the build and bundle are impressive for such a low price, the flash performs well in use both on the hot shoe and in wireless mode with a good range on the optical sensor too. The addition of HSS sets this flash apart from other models, this usually is reserved for mid level OEM makers and you'd normally be looking to spend in the region of £200 to get that to see it on a flash at this price point would have been unthinkable a few years ago.With a few tweaks and improvements Neewer would have a top tier flashgun at a cracking price, as it is they've managed to get most of it right and this flash is very capable and does most of what a higher priced flash does for a fraction of the price.

I've been using a variety of Ni–MH batteries for a while now but for sheer reliability and longevity the Eneloop ones are hard to fault. This is the 4th generation of the Eneloop range the first coming to the market in around 2005, over time the number of charges has increased from the original 1000 cycles up to a claimed 2100 as well as extending the charge they retain in storage for longer. Since Panasonic took over Sanyo in 2013 the they retain the Eneloop branding, this model is BK-3MCCE the prior generation is HR-3UTGB the cycles up from 1800 on that model.It's easy to spot the newest model purely because they are Panasonic brandedThe cells are quoted as retaining up to 70% of their capacity for 5 years and are ready to use out of the boxI tested the pack I got and the capacities ranged from 2020-2078 mAh this can vary a bit but you're guaranteed a minimum of 1900 mAh. Unlike some other makers you can be sure you'll get the quoted capacity Despite the higher cost per battery the longevity of the Eneloop batteries has been very good I've had sets for a good while now (over 5 years) and they're still going strong where as some budget offerings have lost their capacity or worn out after a few years. I've also never had a problem with the Eneloop cells fitting, in the past a few makers have played around the standard AA size and some are a bit longer or larger in diameter this can cause problems on some devices fitting wise.On the packaging Panasonic recommend using their own chargers, but I've never had a problem with a good quality third party smart/intelligent charger with any make of battery it's well worth investing in one of these as it can extend the life of cells and avoid overcharging problems that some timer/manual chargers have.**A few chargers worth looking at**Maha MH-C9000 (very advanced high end charger)Powerex MH-C9000Technoline BL-700 or BC1000Foxnovo F-4SThe official Panasonic charger is: BQ CC16 this is an intelligent charger with individual monitoring and charging of cells, I don't recommend the basic BQ CC18 it works fine but it is timer control only.A decent budget 8 cell intelligent charger is the KooPower 8 Bay smart charger (this seems to be available in a few brand names same design though)Some of the top end chargers have multiple charging speeds and testing capabilities as well as discharge/re-fresh cycles. If you don't need these features then just go for a normal smart charger it's worth the small additional cost.There are some cheaper batteries out there, and some decent budget offerings too. But despite the higher cost this seems to be levelled out with the lifespan of the batteries. Hard to fault really a very reliable and solid offering and suitable for use in a wide variety of appliances even heavy drain items like flashes and digital cameras. For super high capacity users take a look at the Eneloop Pro range

Note: The supplier provided me with a review sample, no attempt was made to influence my opinion of the productThis alarm system is designed for mostly driveways but you can use it for other locations (maybe a shed or outer building or area where movement isn't expected)In the box you have a Receiver, Transmitter and 3 raw plugs and screws to fix both items. The included manual is well written and very clear in both operation and how to install the alarm.Firstly the receiver unit should be placed inside the house, this can run off of 3 x C 1.5v batteries "or" a power adapter rated at 6 volts max (this isn't included) You can wall mount it or it will stand up on it's own. On this unit you have 3 positions to set it to, off "low" and "high" the last 2 being the sound levels of the alarm. Personally I found the "low" setting to be good enough but if your receiver is placed in another location in the house you might want to set it to high.Now the main part the transmitter, this takes 3 x AAA batteries (no cells are included in this kit) and has a detection range of "8m" max, in field testing I found this to be accurate and it's certainly capable of working up to or near this distance. Actual range distance from the transmitter to the receiver is quoted as up to 100m for outside no obstructions I had no problems placing it down the garden and the receiver in various rooms the range is good on this unit.The transmitter sensor works off a passive "heat" and "movement" detection so this is where you need to think about where you will place it. In particular with pets and animals (birds for one) my cats frequently move around various parts of the driveway and shed and paths and they will set it off, even a strong burst of sunlight in a shadowy part can also at times trigger it (but not often) It's best to find a spot where there is less likely to be activity of any kind. The sensor covers about 100 degrees horizontal direction so firstly I experimented with height and you can avoid most cat/dog issues by making sure it's placed higher up a wall. But not so high that a person wouldn't trigger it, it didn't take too long to play around and find a suitable location.Consider wildlife too esp if you plan to fit it to a shed as birds and other animals can set it off. As the senor has a decent range spend a little time on the position and you'll get very good results.As this is a passive type of system (rather than active) the upshot is according to the maker much better battery life (they quote months, but I'll update the review on that if anything comes to light)In use I have to say once it's all set up (and it doesn't take that long, just the positioning of the transmitter takes more time) the system worked a treat with my testing the alarm fires off reliably and on the high setting you'll be sure to hear it. You could possibly use it as an internal alarm if you were away on holiday (works off the same type of sensor) but really it's for outdoors and I wouldn't say this model is a substitute for a full blown house alarm.Build wise the unit is well made and using decent plastics on the parts it feels like it would last the distance with normal use. For the fairly modest asking price it's a good system and easy to recommend.

Note: The manufacturer sent me a review sample no attempt was made to influence my reviewYou get quite a comprehensive bundle with this kit including the 7" TFT LCD, the door bell/video camera unit as well as mounting plates for both. Also a decent bit of cable comes with it (I think enough for most users, but huge houses might need to extend it somewhat) There are some wall plugs and screws as well and the instructions which show you how to set it up and the various functions available on the unit.**LCD Unit**This has 4 touch screen buttons and 3 dials on the right hand side. The front controls allow you to accept a call, monitor the outside video, third one down means you can hook up an electronic door opening to the unit (this opens the door/gate) and an interphone is the last button allowing unit to unit communications (if you have other LCD units around the house)These buttons also "double up" (press and hold) allowing you to change the melody/ring tone, back button light on/off, and even a baby monitoring option.Right hand the 3 dials simply control the contrast, brightness and volume.The LCD display is very clear and easy to read a decent size 7" with good resolutionOn the back you have the wiring connections and a bracket can slide on here to allow wall mounting*Doorbell/Video Unit"This is a nice quality thick solid metal with a brushed finish, you get a supplied backing plate for flush mounting, there is a single larger button for calling (this has a blue LED which turns on) above that the speaker, with the main camera surrounded by 3 LED's on each side, a small circle to the upper right is the microphone.On the reverse connections for the cable audio, video and power input as well as an electric lock input. You can adjust the speaker output and microphone sensitivity with a small screwdriver (the slots are recessed into the back of the doorbell unit)**Setting up and in use**I found it fairly simple to set up and the instructions were pretty good for the most part (though a few niggles on some areas)It's a simple as plugging in the supplied adaptor to the main LCD unit, and one part of the supplied cable and then using the push fit buttons on the back of the doorbell to provide power/video and sound. It's quite straight forward. Most of the work with a unit like this is going to be mounting and fitting the external doorbell, and the cable work, the actual hooking up is very easy to do. I don't have access to an electric door but the input and aux cable is provided for you if you want to add that.**Overall Quality**Build wise very little to complain about solid feel to both units, brushed metal bell is very strong and solid the LCD display isn't a thin as I might like but it's solid feeling and not at all fragile.Video and audio quality were very good, the wide angle lens gives a nice field of view and audio was clear both from the LCD to the main doorbell and vice versa. There are 16 selectable melodies including your usual ding dong bell (which I think is the choice for most) and some songs including some well known classical tracks even the theme tune to "Titanic" is here if that tickles your fancy! Not bad here I've never been a huge fan of melodies on door bells, but a selection is better than none.**Areas for improvement**The user manual is quite good, but some of the diagrams could be a bit larger same for the text a bit on the small size, for the most part it shows you the installation in an effective way.I'd prefer a dedicated onscreen menu you change the few settings there are by holding down the main 4 backlit touchscreen buttons, not that there are many settings to change, but a point to note. LCD unit isn't a thin as expected but it's far from bulky either.This isn't a cheap unit by any means, though the quality of the parts does feel a cut above some of the budget offerings I've seen and tried (no feeble plastics here) but this isn't for everyone you either want a video call doorbell or you don't.Wrapping things up a very nice unit with impressive build and quality all around, bar a few smaller niggles it's a quality offering for folks who are looking for a video door phone.

I bought one of these for a desktop PC, I've found adapters like this tend to work better than the cards you install inside the PC. One advantage of this model is you do get a bundled cradle this allows you to move the position around and improve the signal pickup, and it also avoids the problem of having a dongle poking out of the PC (which can be vulnerable to damage)For Windows computers this works with XP, Vista, 7, and 8 and is fully compatible with IEEE 802.11 b/g/n 2.4GHzThis isn't the fastest adapter out there it sits mid range, but it's plenty fast enough for most usesThe software is straight forward and it's easy to set up the adapter quickly. Once installed I had no problems with network connection, speeds were good and it picks up the Wi-Fi quickly after booting up. You do have a "one touch" connection button but I rarely use it.The only real complaint I have is the build quality the plastics creak a bit, the USB end doesn't feel that strong and there is a bit of play in it, likewise the cradle has some wiggle in the USB input socket. I've not had any problems to date with the performance or reliability but it does look like a weaker point of the product. I would suggest using the cradle as this will help to keep it tucked away from knocks or damage.

This hot shoe adaptor has a few uses, it's designed to fit the inverted hot shoe found on Minolta and Sony bodies. But do note that the new Multi Interface shoe has front contacts so whilst this will work with flashes that have the new hoe shoe it won't provide TTL. If you want to use TTL dedicated flashes with the newer multi interface shoe then you want the Sony ADP-AMA adaptor this offers full functionality for older flashes on the latest bodies (A77II, A99, A58 and newer E mount ILC bodies)The main advantages of this are:1: Allows you to use standard hot shoe flashes on i-ISO hot shoes (you won't get TTL though as all the contact layouts are different between makers and brands)2: Adds a PC sync port to your camera, only the semi pro level and up bodies have this but this adaptor will give provide one handy for lower end bodies3: If you're doing some video and want to shoe mount a standard ISO hot shoe microphone you can now do soBuild is good with decent plastics on the casing, the fit is firm on the cameras I tested it on. This has a button on the right hand side you press this in and pull it off to release it, it's an auto lock mechanism (locks as soon as it's fitted to the hot shoe)Whilst this does add a bit of height I didn't find any problems with durability with a flash mounted on top of the camera. It's worth having one of these around whilst you don't get TTL with other flashes you can use them in manual mode and the PC sync port is something worth having on it's own if you have bodies that lack this. It does the job well for it's intended purpose.

I bought this looking for a "smaller" case for the Fuji X10 I bought recently. I have many larger cases and didn't really want anything too big, this is ideal size wise for that model you can fit the Fuji in no problems with the lens cap (you can fit it just about with the filter ring, but the hood is too big not a problem as I rarely use it) The Fuji X-A/M1 with a 27mm pancake will also fit in this as will some other premium compacts or ILC models. You've enough space to tuck the strap in too and zip it up, fit is excellent not too tight or loose. Internal Dimensions are 7.5 x 6 x 12.3 cm.Quality wise as expected from Lowepro very good, padding is decent, the double zip at the top has an inner lining so when zipped up the metal parts of the zip are cushioned from the camera. Inside in the top section is a small elasticated section to fit a spare SD card. Around the back you have a novel double Velcro belt strap so it's quite secure attaching it to a belt, and covering that another section which is also Velcro and padded but useful for horizontal attachment. In short both systems should allow you to attach this to photo belts, normal belts or other camera bags with no problems.You also get a shoulder strap which attaches to the fabric loops on the back.Very good little bag, but one minor niggle nowhere to really put a spare battery. You can if you wish put one inside the case (might need to leave the strap out), I'm not crazy about the idea of a battery knocking around inside though if you wanted to you could cover a battery in bubble wrap and put it in there. My solution was to use a neoprene CF card holder which fits the batteries I have for the X10 perfectly I just attach it to the hooks on the strap. A small point for improvement for Lowepro even a single outer mesh panel on the side would solve the "where to put the battery" issue. Or to make the case slightly taller and have another section inside the top part to fit a battery.Otherwise shove a spare in your pocket! The Lowepro Portland 30 has space for a battery but doesn't come with a should strap (which I use frequently)Small niggle aside it's a good quality case, which is priced fairly and manages to carry the camera in a small package (which was what I wanted) For other users do check the Lowepro site and use the bag finder to see what options you have for various models.

Note: The maker provided me with a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewUSB 3.0 hubs are quite common, but this model offers a built in LAN port in addition to the 3 USB 3.0 ports. You might wonder why that could be useful, but many ultra books or super compact laptops don't have a LAN port, some makers offer a USB to LAN this gives you the benefit of 3 ports plus the Ethernet.Cable length is about 30cm, this is really aimed at laptop users but you can plug it into a desktop though a USB extension cable might be needed.The top section has 3 LED's with the ports numbered 1-3 when a device is plugged in the corresponding number lights up, front section houses the 3 main USB 3.0 ports and the LAN socket is on the right side. Build is good with dense plastics a solid feel all round.I tested this on a number of Windows PC's this is simple plug and play for both the USB ports and the Ethernet you don't need drivers or a CD. It takes just a few seconds for the device to be recognised and it's ready to use. Whilst it's USB 3.0 it will work perfectly fine with USB 2 as well though without the speed advantage of the faster port.I connected up an external USB 3.0 hard drive to the hub and some USB memory sticks all worked perfectly there is enough power here to use a 2.5" external hard drive though if you need multiple hard drives connected you might want to use a powered port. Ethernet supports 10/100/1000Mbps and supports wake on LAN and cross-over detection.A very useful hub to have if you are short on laptop USB ports or if you have an ultra book you get the benefit of the extra USB and the built in LAN

Note: The manufacturer sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis is quite an interesting concept rather than just having a normal iPhone case this one doubles up as a wallet and card holder too.Opening up the gift box (it comes in a nice black box) there is the immediate odour of quality leather and examining the case be in no doubts this is a high end product.The leather is of very fine quality I have a few Italian leather products myself this is a harder wearing type of leather but with age leather tends to develop a more subtle feel. Inside the case it's lined with a fine felt, the surrounding plastic section also feels dense and strong with cut out sections for the volume controls on the side the lower ports and a gap for the camera on the phone.Moving onto the "leather part" you have a front section which can hold a card and a few bank notes, this is stamped with the Huskk logo. Around the edges the bottom part has a section that's attached to the plastic case to prevent items slipping out you also have 2 of these on the left hand side, one on the bottom right part and at the top a magnetic section that closes off the top of the "wallet section". On the back of the plastic there is the Huskk logo and name stamped into this area.The main wallet section can easily hold quite a lot of cards the maker suggests 8 that's not unrealistic but will largely depend on how much cash you have in there too or bits of paper/business cards etc. Design wise it works and it works very well this really is an alternative to a wallet except in one obvious area, you can't really carry coins (unless you put a few in the front pouch area) In terms of fitting with the iPhone it's spot on nice and secure when pushed inNow I've tested quite a lot of iPhone cases and they vary hugely in price and quality, this is no question a high end offering for any phone case, I'm not in any doubt about the quality of the product the leather is top tier, the construction and design are to a similar standard. I've not touched a case that's a classy, refined or well made as this. On the other hand the price is a factor (it is expensive no question) and well my only concern is leather of this grade and quality can last decades and only gets better with age it's a shame that it will easily outlast the phone itself. I'm slightly torn on rating here as the product is a 5 star one easily (materials are superb the design is strong in fact quite unique turning a phone case into a wallet thinking outside of the box as some would say and to great effect), it really comes down to the price in the end.The quality of the product is there no doubt about it this isn't a passing purchase and not for everyone (plenty of more affordable cases out there some are quite good) But as my title suggests this is a case that demands respect, and among iPhone cases it is without question "the boss" of them all

Note: The maker sent me a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewI've looked at quite a lot of Bluetooth speakers and this one is a little unusual in appearance, but I have to say I like the look of it. The cube is 9cm in all dimensions finished with a soft touch effect. On the bottom the entire area is covered with a rubber pad this stops the cube slipping around and probably helps with the acoustic side too.Top deck houses the main controls in a contrasting silver effect volume up/down track back/forward and the play/pause button which doubles up as the accept/reject/end call function. On the rear an input for a 3.5mm aux jack and the micro USB charging port.You get a supplied male to male 3.5mm lead and the micro USB to normal USB port for charging. It takes around 5-6 hours to charge the cube up from flat.**In use**Paring up just select "magic cube" and off you go make sure you disconnect the previous device if it's in range of the cube. Connection was strong and I got over 15 metres range from a tablet (this might vary depending on the device used) range is well above average for a Bluetooth speaker. Built in microphone did a decent job and calls were very clear so no complaints on the phone call aspect of the speaker.I ran the cube for an extended time and the battery was still not flat so I don't doubt the makers claims of 20 hours at moderate volume levels, this is quite a lot more than most Bluetooth speakers are capable of usually they're good for 6-8 hours rarely above that.**Audio quality**Looking nice and having a good range/battery life is all well and good but the really important part for any acoustic speaker is if it delivers the goods in the sound department. This varies a lot with speakers most sound quite good, a few sound really good. The Avantek cube is probably the best sounding Bluetooth speaker relative to it's size I've heard to date. Sound is clean, crisp and extremely well balanced with strong vocals, a deep bass and clear treble. The sound surprised me somewhat as it outperformed my expectations for a speaker this size. Someone has sat down and really paid attention to this part of the cube.Volume levels are good, it can kick out a loud enough sound, but all too often I hear distortion or parts of the range breaking up. No such worries here, a smooth and detailed sound and not a hint of problems.**Areas for improvement**It's hard to nit-pick with the cube but if I were to think of a couple of areas for improvement it would be possibly a micro SD slot or USB input, some speakers have built in radios too but I'm splitting hairs really because the other areas are really very strong on this product. I am pleased to see an Aux 3.5mm input though as this is very useful to add other non Bluetooth devices to the speaker.**Conclusion**I'm very impressed with the cube in a lot of ways it's well made with an attractive design, instructions are clear and easy to follow as is operation. It has a bigger than normal range and an outstanding battery life for a Bluetooth speaker. To top it all off it sounds great and delivers a really impressive sound that's warm and complete. For it's size/class and price it's one of the best sounding speakers I've listened to, An excellent speaker and very highly recommended without reservations.

This fact based story is one of a love triangle created on-line that has devastating consequences in real life. Thomas Montgomery is a former US Marine, now in his later 40's with a family, but a dull boring life compounded with problems, he escapes into a fantasy world in an on-line gambling game and chat room via his "marinesniper" on-line name.He meets Talhotblond in the chat rooms (the screen user name of an 18 year old girl) and plays out a life where he is a young marine and thus able to appeal to a much younger woman. Soon rivalry shows up in the shape of Brian Barrett (beefcake is his user name) , a co-worker Thomas knows in person.Ultimately this is a story of tragedy with the pointless loss of a life over a love triangle which never existed in the real world. Later on the shocking truth about Talhotblond is revealed, all is not as it seems.The film starts unusually with a voice over from the victims perspective, we have interviews with Montgomery, Rex Beaber a Clinical Psychologist, several case detectives as well as Brian's parents. Tim Shieler who is the father of the girl in question, is quite visibly shaken and emotional during his interview scenes. The documentary is well produced, though has quite a lot of the text used during the conversations on-line (much of which is unsuitable for younger viewers due to the graphic nature of the messages), a little slow to start but it picks up mid point.This film certainly makes you ponder about the dangers of posing as someone you are not, the tragic elements are in many directions, a mentally ill man who takes his compulsion out on a fellow co-worker, the girl whom neither man has met, and the final details about the exact identity of the girl in question really throws an unexpected punch. Fantasy and reality clash in this sad but true story where nothing is as it seems, and nobody should have been hurt or killed. Certainly worth a watch if true crime stories are an interest.

This is something a bit different and might not appeal to everyone but this drama holds quite a good storyline that does provide you with plenty to "think about" and that's a good sign for the most part. At times it can be a little slow and pondering, but there are some fine performances from the cast and the story is something most of us can relate to.I quite like Joaquin Phoenix he's certainly a capable actor and this role works well for him. Here he plays Leonard Kraditor somewhat of a loner Leonard is a keen photographer and has recently had some difficult moments. The opening scenes show Leonard attempting to end his life (but in a half hearted way and abandons the idea), it becomes clear he's had bad luck in his life romance wise.His parents are naturally concerned and arrange for him to meet up with the daughter of his father's business partner (Vinessa Shaw who plays Sandra Cohen) the two seem to get along fine and they arrange a future meeting with a view to dating. However Leonard soon meets neighbour Michelle Rausch (Gwyneth Paltrow) and strikes up a friendship which soon turns into something which captivates Leonard, he's torn between his potential "nice/sensible but not that exciting " girlfriend and the new found Michelle who is the exact opposite, outgoing, likes to party hard, very pretty/sexy (Vinessa Shaw is an attractive woman but she's been deliberately under made up for the film) Leonard is somewhat hooked with the attraction and fast pace of Michelle.Unfortunately for Leonard the girl he likes most is Michelle, but there are complications namely she is involved with a married man by the name of Ronald Blatt (Elias Koteas) I won't spoil the plot by giving away too many details, just to say Leonard has to make a choice between the evasive and hard to pin down, and "complicated/with problems" Michelle, or the rather less interesting but kind hearted Sandra as he tried to juggle relationships with both women.I liked the film for a few reasons firstly the cast on all levels are very good Joaquin has that deep intensity that makes Leonard believable as a character, and both female roles are played equally well and contrast the differences between the two women. Direction is solid, leisurely paced at times, script is strong as is screen play. I personally like the ending it's something that's a bit unique in that Leonard ends up with one girl not really by choice but how events are played out and has no real control, it leaves things a little uncomfortable for the viewer, but then I'd rather that then a production that was obvious story wise from the start.Not going to be everyone's cup of tea that's for certain, but if you like a slower moving considered but intriguing romance drama this could be worth a look. Quite a lot better than I expected, partly down to the strong cast though.

Note: I was provided with a paperback copy of the book for review evaluation, the opinion of the publication is my own personal viewChris Parker's story features a serial killer on the rampage pursued by a detective called Peter Jones an experienced investigator whose skills are tested to the limit as the bizarre murders unfold; he is forced to turn to a friend "Marcus Kline" a man of great perception and expert on "influence" in order to bring the killer to justice.This is quite an intense read (some readers will like this others may prefer a more traditional crime thriller) and I wouldn't want to spoil the story with too much detail. Whilst the plot is good it is really the character development and interaction that is first class we explore many sub plots in the novel which intertwine with the main storyline, this makes for an unusual read this isn't a standard detective story by any means.You will straight away notice that the author is something of an expert in this field, but do not let the theoretical explanations put you off. It took me a few pages to get into the book. but it was absolutely worth it. The characters are well developed varied and unusual; the story is well paced and you will not find the culprit that easily, this one gives very little away and feels all the better for it. An impressive book and one that really stands out in this crowded genre. If part two is up to this level this should make for an outstanding trilogy.

Note: The maker provide me with a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewChamois leather cloths are well regarded for their soft non scratching and highly absorbent properties but this offering is remarkably similar to the real product (the term Chamois refers to the species of goat whose skin is used for the leather) This animal friendly product is made from PVA (Polyvinyl alcohol) and comes in an oval box the cloth is sealed in a bag open this up and it's slightly damp and soft to the touch.The maker recommends washing it and line drying it, and that it's best to store the towel/cloth slightly damp in the container. Just like the real thing this will dry up though you can re-fresh it's feel and properties by making it damp.At just over two foot long this is a good size to have though some might prefer to cut it in half to make two cloths. One side of the towel has a dimple effect on it, the other is smooth in appearance. In use this works just as the normal leather one does and is esp useful for leaving a streak free finish on car paintwork or windows/mirrors. Being highly absorbent this can soak up water quickly and this is part of the reason for the non watermarked finish. It's also strong resisting tearing very wellIn a blind test I'd say it would be near to impossible to tell this apart from the leather one it's that good and using it for cleaning and washing it's basically on par with the traditional Chamois to the point I really can't see any need to hunt one of those out. It's always good to see a maker come up with an alternative material which is up to the job in this case it's fully deserving of praise.I've used a few synthetic cloths that tout themselves as being a Chamois alternative this one lives up to that claim. Outstanding

Note: I was sent a review sample for evaluation, the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis mount includes the waterproof casing and suction cup but with a quick release allowing you to take the WR casing off.Inserting the cue you have a double safety latch on the side compartment you have to move the switch and then pull the latch open, once that's done you insert the cube, the fit is good thanks to some pads on the back compartment which stop the cube rattling around. Reverse the procedure and the cube is now contained in a WR section. On the back door is a rubber seal whilst I've not had any problems with use I'd suggest checking this for debris every time you use the cube just to be on the safe side.A button on the top section allows you to take photos/start and stop video.The bottom suction mount is rotated to lock it into place, there is a tab to help removal of the suction part. Once it's locked in the it's very firm and worked very well on glass or other shiny surfaces. If you're mounting it on a car body then I would advise you to clean the mounting area with a cloth just to make sure you have a good contact with the surface. It's important to note that once the suction is mounted there is no rotation possible so ensure it's lined up properly, the top section can still be tilted up/down though which is pretty handy for getting a good angle on footage.Overall I liked this mount it's solid, well made and the suction cup sticks very well when locked in. Whilst the cube has a degree of weather resistance it can't be submersed in water this allows you to use the cube in harsh weather or under water. The maker claims depths of 10 metres I didn't test it that far down but it didn't have any water leakage problems at a depth of about 3 metres during field testing.Recommended for cube users who want a decent WR case

Note: I was sent a review sample for evaluation the opinion of the product is my own personal viewThis "bike mount" lets you attach the cube with a clip on attachment, you get two rubber pads provided (one spare) this slots inside the mount (with a bobble moulded on it to prevent it moving) The top section rotates and has click stops to adjust to the position you want. On both sides there are tabs which when pressed in allow you to remove the top section. The cube itself clicks into place on the top part.A few thoughts on this mount, firstly the cube clicks into place pretty firmly I wasn't worried about it popping out. The snap on section I have not had a problem with, but if you are doing vigorous off road mountain biking it could get knocked off position or off the bars. It holds firmly enough for normal road cycling. I did find the quick release a bit fiddly to remove though for some reason it didn't always come off easily even with both tabs pushed in.I'd also prefer a normal mount which can be secured completely with a locking mechanism, this would ensure that the mount just can't come off at all and would be a better design, the quick release would allow you to take it off quickly. Make sure you check the size of the handlebars as this fits standard 1" ones, and some of them can vary a bit.Not bad, but not as good as I was expecting

2:18 Mins I bought one of these to "upgrade" from an older USB 2.0 card reader, this Kingston card reader supports most of the main card formats you'll encounter (with the exception of XD cards) the cards supported are:* CompactFlash, CF Type I (UDMA 0-6), CF Type II (UDMA 0-6)* SD, SDHC, SDHC UHS-I, SDXC, SDXC UHS-I, micro SD, micro SDHC, micro SDXC* Memory Stick/M2, Memory Stick, Memory Stick PRO, Memory Stick Duo, Memory Stick PRO Duo, Memory Stick M2Operating systems the card reader is certified to work with:* Windows 8, Windows 7 (SP1), Windows Vista(SP1, SP2), Windows XP (SP3)* Mac OS X v.10.6.x and higher* Linux v.2.6.x +Cable length is about 1.1 metres from tip to tipBuild on the unit is excellent with a brushed metal finish on the top plate, the card slots have good connections and importantly a deeper compact flash slot which should help avoid issues with bent pins, which can be a problem on shallow slots, on the underside rubber strips are on the front and rear sections to help stop the reader slipping around on a desk.The red "Kingston" logo glows read when accessing or writing to a card to let you know everything is working fine.Notes:The reader supports UHS-I cards and benefits from the speed boost they have, the newer type of UHS-III SD cards have additional contacts behind the main ones these cards can be used on this card reader, it won't fully exploit the speeds of the UHS-III cards but as the transfer speeds are very fast anyway this isn't really an issue.CF UDMA cards also show good performance on the reader as it supports these cardsIt's fully backward compatible with USB 2.0 but the speeds top out at the interface max which is about 30MB/s or near there. To get the full advantage of the card reader USB 3.0 is neededSpeeds wise it will vary on the cards being used but head to head this is very close to the Lexar Dual slot card reader (which has CF and SD slots) but doesn't support the other media devices. The Kingston is quite a bit cheaper and performs almost as well this earns a very easy recommendation. An excellent card reader.

I've a good range of SD cards and have tested most of them to date, I vary the brands as it makes it easier for me to find cards that are empty or that I use with specific cameras.This Sony card is a UHS-I class, so can take advantage of some devices that support this protocol (it's fully backward compatible with non UHS cameras etc). The headline figure though is only for the read performance which can be a little misleading for some buyers. The card is far from slow overall, but it's a bit behind the SanDisk Extreme 45MB/s offering in terms of in camera write speed. It is though quite a lot faster for reading and file transfer so weight up what your requirements are first.I benched the Sony card using a USB 3.0 card reader and using software I got close results from real world file sizes (video and photo) to the benchmark I ran.Read speed: 87MB/sWrite Speed: 38MB/sA bit of variation from test to test (a few MB/s either side) on paper the Sony is near enough to it's claimed max speed for reading files. The Extreme 45 MB/s does write a bit faster though (over 45MB/s as indicated and it hits that speed for read times too) Really it comes down to what you need.If you need faster in camera speeds (which most do) then the Extreme 45 MB/s is quicker, if you want even faster speeds then the 80 MB/s is the one to go for (that card writes a lot quicker than both) super speed demons might want the Extreme Pro series or equivalent offerings.The Sony isn't a slow card when compared to a normal class 10 quite a lot faster really, and does have the advantage of a toughened casing which is less prone to damage being waterproof, x ray proof, shock proof just like the Extreme range offer. Warranty is a bit less than I'd like at 5 years Sony should really increase that to come into line with rivals. There is a newer version of this card out (and it's evidently even faster) As it is if you transfer big files a lot this is fast, it's quite fast in camera too just not as quick as some other offerings. That doesn't make the Sony a bad card but it would be a lot more helpful if they just told you what the speeds for both were.Worth a look at the right price if it's quick enough and you need some protection from rough handling or the environment.

The Fujinon 16-50mm is bundled with various X mount camera kits but also available to purchase on it's own.Being an XC lens it doesn't feature the aperture ring of XF Fujinon lenses (aperture is controlled via the camera control dials), and the barrel is devoid of an OIS on/off switch.Despite being a "kit lens" a few points stand out, firstly the build is somewhat better than most kit offerings with dense more solid feeling plastics used, neither is there a hint of any wobble with the lens extended and the zooming action is smooth from wide to telephoto end. The mount is plastic, the copy I am reviewing came with an X body kit and included a hood, supplied is a push on rear lens cap, and a centre pinch front lens cap.After testing the lens I've listed out some of the stronger and weaker points of the lensGood points:+ Very good sharpness across the focal range in the centre even wide open, at 16mm f3.5 edge performance is very good improving a bit stopping down, very usable at 50mm f5.6 too. Corners are a bit behind the central performance at 24-35mm but still very acceptable wide open.+ Build is a step up from most kit lenses with decent plastics used in construction+ Useful focal range offering an equivalent of 24-75mm on a full frame camera+ Compact size, weight under 200 grams pairs well with some of the smaller "X" series cameras+ Autofocus is quiet and fast to acquire focus (this will vary on the body being used) no issues with AF to report+ Effective OIS system means slower lens speed can be compensated to a degree, I'd estimate 3.5-4 stops from the OIS+ Fairly good out of focus rendering, quite smooth 7 blades rounded apertureNot so good:- Cost is high for a lens of this type when bought outside a kit bundle, for the asking price it should really have a metal mount- Some CA at the wide end edges even with correction (not extreme by any means)- No aperture ring or OIS switch (both are controlled via the camera body), would prefer a "real rear lens cap"- Rather mediocre close up performance min focus distance is 0.3m (at the 50mm end) Magnification of 1:6.7 (0.15x)Notes:Optical distortion and vignette (darkening of the corners) and most aberrations are corrected in camera and in most common raw converters (the bundled Fuji software and well known products like ACR/Lightroom) In most cases you won't see the effects of this at all even working in raw, but you can if you use some of the lesser well known raw conversion software out there. There is a fair bit of distortion esp wide end being corrected and darkening in the corners, but it's mostly invisible to the user and likely a non issue, but worth a mention anyway just in case you use other software for your raw workflow.Filter size is 58mm the front element does not rotate on focus or zooming, the lens extends about 3.3cm at the 50mm positionLens zoom and focus rings are made of the same plastic as the casingAperture varies across the focal range the approx. lens speed is as follows:16mm F3.518mm F3.620mm F3.823mm F425mm F4.228mm F4.530mm F4.735mm F540mm-50mm F5.6Lens speed is typical for a lens of this class though the benefit of good OIS and the ISO performance of the X series bodies does dampen the loss of speed somewhat.There is no focus distance scale on the lens but this shows up on the camera which can be of use. Manual focus is "by wire" thus electronic response fairly good though I would prefer a mechanical focus action (which feels better in my view)Probably the most interesting aspect of this lens is unlike some other "kit" offerings which usually start at 18mm (roughly 27mm on a 1.5x crop body) The Fuji offers a very nice wide angle equivalent of 24mm which could be of interest for scenic and landscape shooters, with the 50mm taking you up to a normal short telephoto 75mm on a full frame body. The range is without question very appealing even if the lens speed isn't fast. There is quite a difference between an 18mm lens and a 16mm one more than you would expect, the real issue with the lens has less to do with optics but price. I was pleasantly surprised by the lens resolution which is to a level few kit lenses reach, though not perfect this lens is unlikely to disappoint even fussy shooters (it compared well to a Tamron 17-50mm f2.8 when I shot both side by side)The one let down is the max magnification which really is a bit below par compared to other lenses I've used the Fuji can't focus as close as most zoom lenses (the 16-50mm is 0.15x the Tamron 17-50mm can manage 0.22x which is quite acceptable), though it might be adequate for some types of shooting a low cost option would be to add a close up filter to bring the lens closer to the subject.Cost wise I think Fujifilm need to look again at the lens I think most buyers will pay a bit more for the extra wide end,  either that or Fuji should have included the aperture ring and a metal mount (this would have offset the price to a point) Still if you do manage to pick one of these up it's a lens that offers quite a lot and is in it's own right a capable zoom lens that will find quite a bit of use as a standard zoom.

The Fuji X-M1 sits in the entry segment of the X series models but this one has the unique X-Trans CMOS sensor (the X-A1 has a normal bayer sensor) in other areas though these models are the same (controls/functions etc)Being an entry model there are a few compromises here, firstly the most obvious one is the lack of viewfinder, secondly controls have been streamlined over higher end models and this doesn't feature the newer on sensor phase detect autofocus of the X-T1 (contrast AF here) despite this the camera still manages to achieve a very small size (very similar to the X10/20 compacts in fact slightly smaller) and it has most of the important requirements aspiring shooter might want.I've been testing the camera extensively for a while now and made up a quick fire list of some of the better points and weaker areas of the camera. The camera is a good one overall though like most cameras does have some areas that could be better.Good points:+ Excellent image quality easily as good if not better than equivalent rivals (with a similar sensor size) Tonality is very appealing and attractive (very subjective but I like it)+ Huge latitude in raw files both highlight and shadow end with outstanding low light performance very minimal noise+ Build is solid despite being plastic feels well put together no poor joints or creaking at the seams+ Full manual controls quite good customisation and menus+ Autofocus is good for accuracy in most cases (it's reasonably quick though can't match DSLR's for speed)+ Start up is quick and the camera is responsive with no signs of lag+ Fairly good buffer around 10 shots raw and about 31 jpegs at full resolution, able to take some advantage of faster cards too+ Continuous shooting rate of 5.6fps is decent (note the points about AF)+ Large clear 3.0” LCD is the same aspect ratio as the sensor (3:2) and sharp with a 920k resolution as well as partially articulated (up and down positions) option to brighten it up for daylight shooting (it's a bit reflective though quite clear in most light)+ Battery life is quite good for a compact sized camera (I got about 390 shots per charge) flash use will shorten this+ Q menu is well laid out and avoids trips into the main menu system for most common settings+ Fn button can be user set, C position on the mode dial allows for a memory of settings to be stored (shame it is only one)+ Hot shoe allows the use of dedicated flashes or other accessories, built in flash extends a decent bit though power is a little low (GN 7)+ Consistent metering and white balance required little intervention for most shooting+ Excellent flash exposures (though will increase the ISO if you let it a little too much)+ Manual focus “peak” is useful though could use more colours (red/yellow)+ Video is acceptable for a consumer level camera reasonable details and resolution and decent microphone quality, limited options though (you can set aperture before you start but not adjust it during recording) see cons on “moire”+ Good in camera raw conversions you can adjust quite a few settings too (this creates jpegs from raw files but it's handy to have)Weaker areas:- No viewfinder, and no option to add one, no AEL button (Fn can
