The theory with these cans is convenience I suppose, you spend your money and get something all mixed and ready to add some tequila and ice, and presto, margarita! Well, here's a recipe that isn't much harder, and tastes a LOT better:3 oz tequila (really good tequila is for sipping, something cheap is fine here)2 oz lime juice (you should squeeze a lime, but use the bottled stuff if you must)1 oz triple sec (or use simple syrup)Mix together and pour over ice.It's not that much harder...

Really fun curtains for a kids' room. They block out the light quite well, think curtains for a media room or hotel curtains, but have a fun, sort of silly monster theme (on the ones I got). The quality is excellent, heavy material and well made. The price feels a bit high for what you get, hence the four stars, hard to be fully excited about them at the cost.

It's a basic mesh bag with lots of outer pockets. It's with our beach gear for sun screen, bottles of water, rolled up towel, and swim goggles. The bag dries very quickly and didn't accumulate much sand inside of it even after a couple of days of use. It's not a fancy item, but functional for shower or beach use. If I had found it in a dollar store, would consider it an excellent buy. Here it's a bit expensive.

I am not a fan of the Keurig single cup coffee machines, and find that the resulting coffee is often pretty iffy. However my office now has a Keurig machine not very far from where I sit... And this is the best option that I have found for making coffee with it. The French Roast makes a good 10oz cup of coffee. It might not be as interesting as the coffees I roast, grind, and brew at home, but it's not bad at all and the price is fair for all the Keurig disposable bits.

There is something inherently alienating about the concept of travel writing, and Theroux himself spends some quality time in this book discussing the too-often-displayed travel hardship model of travel writing. Part of it here is the notion of the Cape Cad and Honolulu-dwelling great writer (outsider right there) traveling primarily through the African-American Deep South of poverty and an utter lack of books. As always, there's the outsider to write about the experience, but this is a passionate outsider who, I think, empathizes greatly with those he writes about. In fact, the more I thought about this writing process the more I realized the alienation and the notion of difficulties inherent in the writing said about my willingness to discuss race rather than anything the author was doing here.As one who greatly respects Theroux's travel writing (most relevant to this book is the fabulous Dark Star Safari (and its lesser sequel of sorts, The Last Train to Zona Verde) and it's stinging critique of development funding in the third world) I took the rambling style of the book for granted, and enjoyed the odd byways and partially realized stories of the people encountered in the book. Theroux took trips through the South over the course of several years, and only a few of the tales seem completed. Mostly those that ended with deaths. It's as it is in the real world, ongoing stories, and any visitor only gets to see the briefest of moments.The pre-publication copy of the book I saw did not have photos, but if the ones on the amazon book listing page are any indication, they're likely to add quite nicely to the book.

The book tries hard to be complex and employ the Victorian style while at the same time acting as a critique of the values of the era. But it doesn't really pull it off. There's little of the excitement or shear weirdness of Lewis Carroll's Wonderland to be found here. We might meet some familiar characters along the way, but it's their familiarity from older material that makes them interesting, not their new treatment. Alice and Wonderland have been fertile ground for many re-imaginings over the years (including the under-rated SyFy Channel Alice) much as Oz has been. So it makes sense, perhaps too much simple sense, for Gregory Maguire to come visiting. I just couldn't get much enjoyment out of this book.

...in the guest bathroom. This one looks good, holds the shower curtain and the shower liner apart from each other (which helps cut down on the likelihood of mildew) and is held by tension against the walls. You do need a tape measure and the included hex keys to adjust this correctly. The tension pads probably should have been made of a different, softer material. It takes a good deal of pressure to get the smooth, hard pads to hold on the shower enclosure walls.

This is almost six hundred pages of material taken from a number of other Dummies business books. As all Dummies books try to, this one aims to be fun and funny, at least in parts, amongst the useful information. It covers a lot of territory, and therefore is somewhat thin in many of these areas. But, and here's how I think this book is best used, everything gets a mention, there's a page about typefaces followed by clip art and stock photography. And it's enough to get you started, or get you thinking of the right search terms to plug in to find out more information. Another example, the cost of goods sold expense methods are described in less than two pages, including highlighting that this is advice for small business owners rather than for accountants. It assumes you'll have an accountant, but it also shows you what else you can learn about in this direction.

...this is a good racket, solid feel in the hand, and very lightweight in action. My hands are big though, and the handle starts to flare out at the bottom leaving my little finger in a somewhat uncomfortable spot. This racket was then turned over to my partner whose (feminine) hands are a bit smaller, and the racket was more comfortable there. That said, for a short game it works for me. I can't honestly figure out what a handle made of "anatomic italian composite" means.

Not sure about the three pound weight limit, that seems like a lot! But for small framed pictures, or larger matted prints, these hang them nicely on the wall. Do read the instructions! The strength of the velcro is highest in the indicated direction (see the arrow on the strips), and then can be removed by lifting.

It's a far better solution than trying to spray for the beetles. I have used these in years when there were full on invasions of the beetles, and then last year when there weren't a whole lot of them. The only problem I've run into with these traps are that the bags, before they start to fill with beetles, blow around a lot in the wind and seem to not catch many bugs when they're blowing around. Adding a little weight to the inside of the bag seems to help with that.

This is a very simple, and appropriately vague, game. You hang a hook on the wall, attach a ring by a string to the ceiling and throw the ring onto the hook. Okay, so what you get in the box is a wooden board with plenty of dings and the typical Chinese-made machine marks on the wood, a hook, a ring, some string, and some fasteners. Probably you should just make your own... But if DIY isn't your thing, this is a fun game, at least after a few beers.

First off, you really do want to use a burr grinder for your coffee. The blade "mills" produce a lot of fines, coffee dust, that isn't useful to end up in your cup. We've used a simple, inexpensive Cuisinart burr grinder (DBM-8) for many years. It's plastic, works alright, and makes a good ground coffee to go into the Technivorm (best brew coffee maker by far!).So, the KitchenAid, well, it's all metal and glass and the glass bowls are easily removable for simple cleaning. The coffee ground nicely, and reasonably quickly, especially in the medium grind region. And the unit looks very nice on the counter!There are some design flaws with the KCG0702ER though. In particular, the glass bowls felt very lightweight, and I have read comments that they are not replaceable if broken. The grind adjustment needed to be adjusted as well before it made coffee acceptable for brewing as well.

I had been overdue for replacing the strings on my fretless bass, and these strings gave me the opportunity to do a significant string upgrade as well. The selling point for these stainless strings is a continuous "nanoweb" thin coating over the full round wound string. You definitely notice the difference in feel running your fingers over these strings. (These are made by the folks who brought us Gore-Tex.) The tone is good and quite bright. The strings stayed nicely in tune as well.String sizes are 0.045, 0.065, 0.085, 0.105, and 0.135, so pretty light.

The concentrate makes up 64 gallons of usable spray, which should last for a good long time. I didn't see a shelf-life indication on the bottle, but the old one I had seemed to be working fine years after purchase. Liquid concentrate, in my opinion, is the easiest way of making up most sprays, and then you can use the really inexpensive 1 gallon sprayers (Menards or Home Depot) for smaller jobs or the backpack 5 gallon sprayers (Harbor Freight) for your dispensing. Just mix up the quantity needed and you're good to go. I keep one sprayer with only herbicide use and then the other for insecticide or fungicides. Try not to spray too much, but small applications on ornamentals as needed is okay by me.

This works nicely to adapt the USB port in my Subaru Outback to my iPhone. A longer cable is more of a tangle in the little bin under the radio/navigation screen. Works fine and is recognized as a supported Apple device.

It's hard for me to picture exactly who the target consumer is for this herb and vegetable kit. They are easy to start, and the plants are up and seem happy, but this makes for a very small garden. Maybe a container's worth, except that the cucumber is unlikely to be very productive in a container. And it's a bit pricey for what you get, though to be fair if you only want one of each plant, seed packets are pretty wasteful.Okay, the plants, all germinated and look good, there's fertilizer in the growing mix and the early growth was especially fast.

Bitch Magnet. Hmmm...I remember the name, but definitely never saw them, unless maybe they opened for The Damned in 1989? I didn't see them at All Tomorrow's Parties when they reformed, but had seen some of Jon Fine's excellent music journalism over the years. I went ahead and re-listened to the albums while I was reading the book, and it all does fit together into a sensible package.Music autobiographies are a touchy business. You need to make something readable for both the fans and hopefully new fans to be, be sensibly nostalgic about great times but not be a bore or completely stuck in the past, slag on those other bands that did better financially but not turn into an exercise in bitterness, and make it clear that you're cooler than the reader, but not a total a-hole.So, success by and large here. I got a feel for the touring, and for the attempts at success during "Indie Rock's Failed Revolution" which is, to my taste, a nearly perfect subtitle. It was a time of great hope for small scale music going big. Interesting sounds that could sell records (okay, CDs). At the time I was in Chicago, and the energy was amazing. Liz Phair learning to play guitar and then selling a bazillion disks. Veruca Salt making it big. No more hair bands in the charts.Anyway, I enjoyed the book and that's enough for me.

At least I wasn't able to smell the "scare off the deer" aroma. As for the deer, well, I haven't seen them near the back of the house where I've set these out (half hanging and half on their ground stakes) recently. Quite possibly working, but hard to tell.

I especially liked the larder items, good items to make ahead and useful in both recipe and off-the-cuff north african and Mediterranean cooking. The smoked paprika and toasted garlic vinaigrette is amazing with roasted veggies (and meats as well). The photography is beautiful, and the recipes that I have tried have turned out well. Yes, some of the ingredients aren't the easiest to find, but that way it'll be a good challenge.Other high points: Simple foods like the charred brussels sprouts with anchovy butter and the chicken skewers with arab spices. Also some of the more complex recipes such as the Greek-style paella. Good stuff!!!
It's not just a visual joke (the familiar Klein Tools padded handle tool, but it's a bottle opener) but it's actually a good bottle opener.

This is a very uneven set of semi-academic essays on warlords, drug dealers, the warming world, and related topics. Definitely something to be learned from each chapter, mostly having to do with the dangers in the modern world. The look at the inability of renewable energy (in climate change) to transform the energy sector in any real time scale was especially interesting and led me off on some fairly extensive reading.

Took mildew/mold off of the north side of my house, fiber-cement boards, with a little bit of scrubbing and a little bit of spraying. Had previously used a similar product to clean deck chairs with reasonable success. Don't expect miracles, but the cleaner works alright with some scrubbing. Harder to use on spots that you can't get a brush onto. A brush on a pole ends up with relatively little pressure on the surface and doesn't seem to work well.

These are a lot thinner and cheaper in feel, but significantly more expensive in price, than the either the generic bags from Menards or the house-branded Costco bags. Also the drawstring is especially suspect for an "extra strong" bag. These will get used as basic trash bags, but they aren't anything special at all.

This replaced an older, well-worn mattress cover on our bed. It filled the washer when we did an initial washing of the cover, but seemed to have cleaned properly in a normal cycle. When unpacking, there was a good amount of crinkling/creaking noise presumably from the waterproof layer, but I hadn't noticed that after washing or with the cover on the bed. The cover is soft and plush, but doesn't really add any appreciable thickness to the mattress. The cover is "bamboo-rayon" and the fill is poly.

I have been using this case occasionally, when I think I'll need additional portable power, and switching back to my normal (bumper) case when I don't need the battery storage. The battery/case looks well-made, and not very heavy for a 3000 mAh lithium battery, plus the case functions.This works fine as a spare battery in a decent form factor, and seems to be a decent case as well, but there's more (and it's not all good). The case can connect to the Incipio Off-Grid docking stations, and when you open the box you find a micro-USB charging cable (oh, another cable to carry) and a headphone extension cable in case yours didn't fit.In the end, a nicely made case with useful battery capacity (more than the phone has to start with) but with the annoyance of additional cables. The case went on and off relatively easily.

The good - it works as it's supposed to. The mop is good and absorbent and holds just the right amount of water when spun out to let me damp mop a wood floor without worrying about it, and if you DON'T spin it out, it holds enough water to get my whole tiled kitchen good and soppy wet, but WITHOUT dripping when I lift the mop up.  Seriously, I've never had a mop that held this much water and DIDN'T drip before, I'd love it just for that.  Also, my kids are not excited about mopping because the spinning is so cool! :-)  I mean, really, how can you beat that :-)  The bucket is easy to assemble, easy to drain, I had NO problems with the plug leaking.  I like the way it breaks down to store the bucket inside the other bucket.The bad - ok, think about  this and it should be obvious, but people seem to expect that the spinning will leave you with a clean mophead.  It will not - it spins out the dirty water, yes, but it does nothing to RINSE the mophead, so whatever dirt is in the mophead will get into the 'clean' side of the bucket.  That said, I did find that the 'dirty' side was significantly dirtier than the 'clean' side, but don't expect the 'clean' side to stay pristine.  It definitely is cleaner than the old one-bucket method.The ugly - they SERIOUSLY need to come up with a latch system for holding on the mophead rather than the 'snap it in and pull it out' system.  You are supposed to spread the mop out on the floor, place a foot on either side of the mophead, and pull straight up.  This is a HORRIBLE idea.  For one, I'm SURE that over time, I will pull those strings out from stepping on them.  But more importantly, the first time I did this, I BLACKED MY OWN EYE when the mop handle came out and hit me right in the eye socket!  Ouch!!  Please, please, be very careful when taking the mophead out, don't do what I did!!That said, I do like it, and will keep using it.  It's a good mop and it does what I want it to do - just from now on, I'm going to make sure it's pointing away from my face when it's time to take it apart...

This is fun game for people who like 3D puzzles in real-time, and I'm also pleased with how well it works as a puzzle.  It works like this - you have a board with 7 round spaces on it (a circle of 6, with one more in the middle) and rows around it for storing three each of five different colors of spheres.  The player boards are a heavy, thick cardboard, and - clever bit here - they are held up off the ground slightly by three thick foam circles that you put on the back of each board.  I was a little concerned that a cardboard playing area would not hold up well for a real-time game, but this is so sturdy that unless you have a fairly destructive kid, it should be fine.  Yes, a determined person could bend the board and ruin it, and make sure the kids don't leave it on the sofa and sit on it.  But a minimal attention to care should let these last a good long time.  The spheres are exceptional quality - heavy plastic, heavy enough that I'm reasonably sure they are solid through and through, and the surface is lightly textured so the spheres don't slide around on each other.  Which is good, because in this game you have about a minute to build a sort-of pyramid with 7 spheres on the base, 3 in the middle, and one on top.  Where the game comes in is, you also have six cards in front of you that show the parameters for your pyramid - qualities like the blue spheres can't touch other blue spheres, or there have to be exactly 2 orange spheres, or the green spheres are only allowed to be on the top level.  There's a huge deck of these qualities, and with six in each game, the replayability is really high.  Sometimes the cards contradict since you are drawing randomly - there's a point system for how many of the qualities you can solve for with a given pyramid, so you can either accept that you can't get ALL the possible points sometimes, or you can toss the contradictory card and draw another - there are PLENTY in the deck.Now, my nine year old son LOVES puzzles, but doesn't like to be timed, so he's just been drawing cards and working out a solution, starting with four cards at a time, and working his way up.  So, even if you don't care for the timed aspect and just like spatial puzzles, I'd highly recommend this, you can absolutely play it just as well as a spatial puzzle.  Enjoy!!

Got this for my daughter and she loves it for playing with her friends.  It's comfortable and the sound is clear.  And big bonus for parents - the headphones only cover one ear, so none of this "What?  Mom, I didn't take out the trash because I didn't hear you, I was gaming" nonsense :-)  Another parental bonus - the earphone that DOES cover the one ear has big slits in it, so if they are turning the volume too loud, you will be able to tell.  This really is the best compromise for parents - your teen can game with her friends and you can still talk to her and make sure she's not destroying her hearing.

This is an odd attempt to make a casual wear short out of sporty performance materials and it really doesn't quite work.  It fit well.  It was comfortable in the heat.  But it looks slightly shiny, which looks odd on a casual short, and it feels like plastic on the outside.  Fortunately, it doesn't feel that bad on the inside, my husband said it was comfortable enough from that side, but every time he brushed his leg it was a little jarring to feel that plastic feel.  It is well made and well constructed, and if you have been longing for a casual short made from performance materials, maybe this will work for you.  But I wish the outer shell had been made of a more normal fabric for a casual short.  As it is, he'll probably just wear these for yard work.

This game is the third in a series of similar games.  You play a character that you develop with new items and skills over time, gaining new stuff every time you win a game.  You and your fellow characters work together to explore a number of locations that varies depending on the number of players, making die rolls to defeat monsters, disarm traps, or acquire various helpful things, from new allies to new weapons.What's new about this entry in the series is that it adds cohorts (special allies that are with you at the start of the game and do not count against your card limit), mythic paths (a way for a character to become super powerful by gaining and discarding mythic charges), and the corrupted/redeemed trait on some items.  It adds a high level of challenge to what was already a challenging game.  The very first scenario in the game is meant to be a sort of easy introduction and a chance for the team to get some good items for their characters before going on to the more combat-heavy episodes.  I played this with two other people.  Each of these games comes with several episodes already in the box, and then adds several small expansion packs  that can be used to add several more episodes each.  I had played through the original base game and most of its expansion packs.  One of the other players had played through the entire first game and all the expansions and most of the second game's expansions too, and the third player had played through both base games and all the expansions, many of them twice.  We got our butts kicked :-)  It is definitely a challenging game, and if you are familiar with the system and have been wanting a tougher version, you will love it.  If you are new to the system, I would suggest getting the first title in the series, Rise of the Runelords because it will be much easier for you.  Tremendous game though, lots of fun!

I had never tried a beach waves hairstyle before, but had admired it, so was pleased to get the chance to try this.  I tried it two ways - once as directed on the package, to just twist my straight hair around with my fingers to get a beach wave look.  This was really not very successful, unfortunately.  I tried it again using a curling iron to curl around my head in a back, up, forward pattern and this was very successful and very attractive.  I did not really think it smelled of salt, but my husband did.  I thought it smelled like green apple - it was a pleasant enough scent, just not salty.

My husband is a frequent traveler, so these have been very helpful for him to keep items separated and neat on the road.  They are soft sided and collapse easily, so he can just lay them flat as they get empty.  One case (I do not know why they are called 'cubes' when they are clearly rectangular) will hold a week's worth of undershirts rolled tightly, so that should give you an idea of capacity.  I will also use them for my kids to take to summer camp, at least that way they will know where the clean underwear is :-)  They seem sturdy and well constructed.

Very helpful book on courage and its consequences - a lot of books talk about how to make yourself be braver, this is the only one I've read that is realistic about the fact that if you are brave often enough, you will fall flat on your face sometimes.  But this book will help you to be ok with that.  Brene Brown is an inspiring writer and I'm going to have to look for her other books.

My daughter got mad at this after about a minute when she discovered that anyone could bypass the password and open the notebook simply by pressing the reset button on the back of the journal.  Seriously.  If a child really wants a private journal, this is NOT going to be it.The password feature itself is also very very picky - you pretty much have to pick a one or sometimes two syllable word and say it with the exact same intonation each time for the password feature to work.  Even then sometimes it would not recognize the correct password by the correct person.  Which I suppose is why they put a reset button on the back in the first place, but really, seems like it would have been better to use a better voice recognition chip that doesn't DEFEAT THE PURPOSE OF THE TOY.I've giving this two stars instead of one because my son then confiscated it and had a GRAND time programming it to insult people who tried to open it with the wrong password.  He's also learned a lot about how voice recognition works and so it had some unintended scientific value.  But I can't say it worked as it was supposed to.

Excellent test prep.  We have not used the online portion, but the book is very helpful.  I really like that they have the subject by subject strategies that 'dig down' a little deeper into the details of how the test works for various subjects.  If I have any complaint, it would be that I wish more practice tests were included - I know there is more material online, but I think the paper test experience is best practiced with a paper practice test.

I absolutely love these!!  They come unshrunk, so wash them before use - the care label says cold wash, but that's clearly ridiculous for a kitchen use item,. so I washed mine on hot.  I figure if that ruined them, then I wasn't going to use them anyway as I'm not going to use kitchen linens that can't take enough heat to kill germs, right?  Well, I needn't have worried - they turned out absolutely fine.  I line dry mine because they are so thin, I think the dryer might wear them out prematurely.  But they line dry VERY quickly, as little as 20 minutes on a hot day.They are terrific for drying dishes, too.  They are nice and large, so you only need one for a small load, or two for a typical family dinner for four load of dishes.  The most I have needed is three towels for a larger than average load..  They have not left ANY lint.I don't know that they would be that great for crafts - a few of them have some minor bunching along the selvage.  But for kitchen use they are fantastic!!

I got these for my daughter who is taking an art class in high school and wanted some watercolors to experiment with for some Japanese inspired watercolor paintings.  These worked a lot better than the ones available to her in her class.  She still was not happy with how bright they are, she wanted brighter colors, but at least she said these were considerably brighter than the ones she had been trying to use.  They are easy to clean up - the paint seems to cling to the brush better than cheap watercolors do, so it's easier to get everything where you want it, too.

We really wanted to like this, but I'm afraid it just doesn't work very well.  It's very messy & easy to spill.  When we filled it with cold water, it was a little painful on the gums.  Our bathroom water isn't filtered, so warm tap water isn't very tasty for us.But worst of all, we just couldn't figure out how to get it to floss properly.  Every time anyone used it, we used regular floss afterwards and got debris out.  It just didn't seem like the water flosser was actually flossing...  Maybe we used it wrong somehow, but we read the instructions and they seemed clear.  But even the high pressure didn't really seem to do a lot.  Wouldn't recommend it.

I got this to use as a homeschool planner/grade book for my high school aged daughter.  This was EXACTLY what I was looking for - I had been having a hard time finding a notebook that had enough room for both daily work and still had a monthly overview.  Each month has a two-page spread with daily blocks that are about 1 1/2 by 2 inches, which is plenty of room for me to write the grades for that day.  After that, each week is spread over two pages, with about 7 1/2 by 2 1/2 inches for writing for each day.  That is plenty of room for writing down the assignments & appointments for that day.  And bonus - there is NOT pre-printed subject area stuff or anything else - you don't have to pigeonhole your life into someone else's idea of what works for a homeschool like so many of the academic calendars or grade books I keep running into.  There is also a very large Notes section in the back - perfect for keeping a running reading list or writing down trig formulas or whatever she needs.It is a very pretty teal.  The cover is flexible plastic, so should hold up well.  I am a little concerned that it won't be stiff enough & will bend as the year goes on, as my notebooks tend to get stood up for storage, I don't lay them flat.  So I will need to be careful with this to make sure it doesn't get flopped over too much.  But small price to pay to get a decently formatted calendar.

This router really seems to have helped with some persistent device range issues we've had - before I got this router, I couldn't download anything onto my Kindle Fire when I was in the bedroom, and there was one spot on the sofa where you could not sit & have a phone conversation.  Both issues are SOLVED now, yay!!!I am not a tech person, and this was very easy to set up for me. I just turned off the old wireless & plugged this in.  You DO have to rename the wireless on the new router to make it talk to your computer, I didn't do that at first & got very frustrated, but my husband pointed it out.  If you can plug things in & change file names, you can set this up.I have a teenager, so the parental controls are nice, and easy to set up.  It also had log files so we can monitor what is being done.My husband says we cannot access the router from outside the network, and apparently we should be able to.  He says  the linksys smartwifi app says  the system is offline & it's not.  I have no idea what that means or why it matters, but he told me to put that in for you tech folks :-)  Apparently it is something that will let your control your network when you are not home?  I just know that when I AM home, I can sit on the sofa & make a phone call now!! :-)

I LOVE to listen to music while I'm doing housework, and I'd been on the lookout for a replacement for my 20 year old CD 'boombox' for sometime - this was the perfect choice!!  I've also recently switched from an android phone to an iPhone 5C, so the fact that this system would play music from my phone was a big plus.The sound is terrific - much better than both my old boombox and my phone on its own.  (And the phone sound by itself was already an upgrade from my previous phone!)  I'm not a serious sound expert or anything, but everything sounds GOOD and like I expect it to sound. I was listening to some old 80's songs that I had previously listened to on my old boombox, and had just assumed I was tired of them because on my old boombox they just didn't sound very exciting any more.  But popping them in this system WOW!  They sound so much better now!!Mostly I have used the CD player for audiobooks from the library, and the phone dock for iTunes radio and my music.  Both work just fine - I guess some older versions of this had problems with the CD player, but they seem to be all straightened out now.  I have not really used this to listen to FM radio, sorry.  Since I use this in the kitchen, I was also pleased that it is mostly smooth plastic, no unnecessary design elements that make it hard to clean.  The manual buttons in the back are small and a little tucked away, they might be a little hard to clean if they get dirty, but since they are not front & center they are not likely to be affected by a spill or something like that, just a little normal dust.  That's what compressed air is for :-)My only complaints - the instruction manual is a fold out one sheet, very thin paper, like a big thin paper map.  That was really annoying, but since you barely need it because it is pretty easy & intuitive to use, I'm not too bent out of shape about it.  Also, I have to take my phone out of its protective case to fit it into the dock, but I guess that's pretty standard, I just dislike doing it.

This is a very nice edition of this classic game.  They kept the retro art, which is very cute.  The gameplay is simple, basically you play mile cards to move ahead, hazard cards on your opponents, remedy cards on yourself to fix the hazards opponents play on you, and safety cards to protect yourself from hazards.  The worst thing about this game is that you have to wait until you draw a Go card to start moving at all - it's like in Sorry! where you have to get a 1 or 2 to get out, so if that doesn't bother you, this won't be a problem.  It doesn't bother us, but some people get irritated with the slow start to the game.The rules booklet is kind of a mess, I'm afraid.  It was kinda hard to understand - I own over 200 board games and read a LOT of rules, so believe me there are worse rule books out there, but for this simple of a game, it should not have been that hard.  For an example, the rules for the two to four player game at one point informs you that if an opponent plays a hazard on you and you happen to have the remedy for it already in hand, you may play it immediately instead of having to wait for your turn to apply the remedy.  Fair enough, but  the rules then go on to say that this is different from the "Coup Fourre" move.  There is no "Coup Fourre" move in the two to four  player rules.  That move is in the team play rules.  So why mention it at all in the two to four player rules?  All it does is confuse.That said, other than the rules this is nice.  It comes in a nice small tin & the cards are reasonably thick.  If you don't already know how to play this game, though, look up the rules elsewhere.

OK, it might seem a little weird to review a notebook, they all are the same, right?  WRONG!  The Mead line of sewn binding notebooks are our absolute favorites - I just got this one as a review sample from Vine, but we have used the wide rule, college rule, and the graph paper versions of these for YEARS - I won't buy anything else.  The paper is sturdy enough to not rip when erased (you'd be surprised how often that happens with cheap notebooks), the lines are never off-center from the previous page (something that sends my future engineer daughter into fits), and as a left-handed person, I REALLY appreciate not having to develop a row of spiral bound indents on my hand when I need to write something!  My soon-to-be-third grader took off with this notebook for a board game design project he is working on, I just looked through it and see that the lines are perfect for him to write legibly on after 'graduating' from the primary loose leaf paper we used with him in second grade.  After fifth or sixth grade (depending on individual hand-eye coordination and general neatness) we switch to the college-ruled.  We go through at least a couple dozen of these every school year, absolutely the best!

...then this is the book for you!  This is the second of her books based on her popular Dinner: A Love Story blog.  The first book mostly tells how SHE did it, this second book breaks it down & tells you how YOU can do it.  It's a menu-planning guide for giving yourself a 30-day reboot to enjoy cooking again.  It is NOT a beginner cook's menu planning guide!  This will have you in the kitchen daily, breaking down recipes into prep steps to pre-prep as much as possible, AND getting the rest of the family involved in cooking too.  An experienced cook can bread cutlets while directing a child to wash greens and remember to make twice as much rice so you have some for Tuesday's dish, but a beginning cook might end up weeping in a corner with all that going on at once!  You have to know what you are doing & be organized enough to keep on top of a lot of little details.The first thing you do is pick a start date (she suggests the following Sunday, whenever that may be), and  then get your family to help pick recipes.  This was the part that almost made me quit before we started!!  My husband picked REALLY elaborate and/or expensive dishes.  I vetoed the Middle Eastern delicacy that called for $35 worth of fresh herbs (and that's not even counting the lamb!), but I did make the cabbage rolls that had four sub-recipes and took three hours to complete.  My daughter picked out nothing but Chinese dishes.  My son picked out quiche lorraine, ham & cheddar frittata, bacon & monterey jack scrambled eggs, ham & swiss hash with poached eggs - seeing a theme here? :-)But we are halfway through, and it IS working.  The kids are really enjoying rating their picks, and I'm having more fun cooking now.  Believe it or not, it was the three hour, four sub-recipe cabbage rolls  that was the turning point.  At first I thought that was CRAZY - my weeknight family dinners have been in a rut of protein with a sauce, steamed veg, and rice or bread (I have the only kids in the world that don't like potatoes).  So it has been awhile since I've done anything that took longer than 30 minutes, and it HASN'T really been fun cooking for a long time.  But, I made the sub-recipes ahead of time, and as I was stuffing the cabbage rolls with the help of my eight year old son, I realized that I was having fun again.  I liked taking the extra time to make it more interesting!  I liked the challenge of trying to make Ma Po Do Fu as authentically as possible (Szechuan peppercorns really DO numb your lips!).  And it was great to see the kids getting excited when 'their' picks came up.  So, it's working really well for us!  I would recommend this to anyone who likes cooking as a hobby but is having trouble incorporating it into their busy life.

We got these for my daughter to use for her Drawing for Engineers class.  She came home the first day RAVING about these & how much nicer they are to use than the Derwent or Faber-Castell pencils she had been using before.  They give much cleaner lines and allow her to be more precise in her drawings, while still going on dark and clear.  She showed me some of her work & she's right, the new drawings look much more professional than the old ones.  She also uses them for regular drawing sometimes, and says they are great for sketching too, she just uses a lighter lead.  The erasers also erase very cleanly without a lot of debris.  Very nice set!

Great fit and color. My son is almost 6 so I ordered the XS and it fit great. Will likely be able to use it right through next Fall.Paying the $10 extra for the shoulder covering is worth it for the weather here in the PNW.Once again pleased with Columbia wear.
More than we need and designs that we weren't looking for, but quality was decent and kiddos (and adults) loved it as a henna alternative for our Diwali celebration.

Two stars because it is HARD to find Diwali decorations Stateside, so I was happy to find this.However, VERY poor quality with corrugated cardboard backing. Required a bit of work on my part to reattached parts that fell off and tidy up the decoration.

PERFECT for a shared kids' bathroom with toothbrush handles of various sizes. Plus everything AIRS out. Pair this with Steripods, and you can have a fairly sanitary toothbrush situation during flu and cold season.
Works consistently well, but it has a small soap reservoir and no way to adjust the large amount of soap it puts out.Just okay, compared to other  electric dispensers we have.
Kids (and I) love the music. Have added most songs to their nightly dance party playlist mix. Plus, encouraged a glow in the dark dance party!

This fits our 9yo boy's head and adjusts up to his father's head equally well. We like the light on the back. Steady red or flashing. We have a variety of helmets in our 5 person house ranging from $20-$100 (Giro, Bell, Specialized...). This helmet seems appropriately priced for construction and quality. Plus, other than the Tater Tot helmet we had for my son as a toddler, none of our other helmets have come with the back-of-head light.Overall, pleased, though still deciding who will get it permanently.

Son LOVED it for Halloween. It was his costume and finding Garfield anything is HARD. Worth the money, it fit his very large 5yo head and MINE as well. It seems sturdy enough to last for awhile as long as they don't tug at it. It isn't fuzzy double-sided fleece like many of the hats you find out there, but it does keep one's head super toasty.

This book was an o-k read for me. I'm a reading specialist teacher who works K-5. I know some girls (and a few boys) who would enjoy reading this book, but they have very aligned interests too.At the elementary level a lot of kids tend to lean either to heavy fantasy or non-fiction. I like that this book bridges that gap, though I am personally not a fan of the 'real' animal images used.The reading level is appropriate for any student who reads at mid-late 2nd grade level in terms of ease of language. The content/story is honestly more suited for kindergarten. HOWEVER, gives quite the subject-matter vocabulary boosts and does a decent job of representing much harder terms with images.Overall, I think it's an okay book and would work well for the 2-3grade readers who are interested in the topic of cute fuzzy animals who help each other. 'More advanced' readers would find it babyish and developing readers (who would gravitate to the content and story) would struggle with the reading.

Paired perfectlyand easily with our Xbox One and makes playing anything beyond Minecraft while the kids are going to sleep possible.Sound quality is decent, but more importantly the fit is pretty comfortable...which I rarely say about headphones.We debated over the placement of volume and power buttons. I thought they made sense but my main squeeze says it would work better further down or even in the front. User preference I suppose.All in all a decent WIRELESS set for the price point.We've had other headsets for other systemes that were wired and much more expensive, so by comparison we are o-k with the price-value balance here.

Awesome book of fairly easy creations that will get you 'cooking' with your kiddo.I don't like doing stuff for my kids as much as getting them to do it with me...especially when it comes to meal prep.Many of these recipes are familiar from a Cooking Adventures class my two youngest took in preschool.Just a wonderful, family-friend guide to healthy snacking and prep.

Finally the answer to needing extra storage space WITHOUT tipping the stroller with a shoulder bag or backpack.I like that it works with my folding stroller (City Mini) as well as it might work with any general umbrella stroller.Why it might not be the perfect fit for you is you like to carry your extra stuff everywhere you go. This isn't really meant to be a carry-around bag. I often resist having 100 different bags with all the same stuff in it. That said, being able to pull the stroller out for a walk without having to throw on the backpack is a bonus.It honestly boils down to what you feel you need. So if you like the idea of a little extra storage that is well built and designed with the needs of mom and baby in mind, then you'll likely be happy with this nice add-on

Pretty darn cute. Doesn't offer a ton of compartments like other bar-mounted snack holders (using this with City Mini belly bar) but equally it is not as encroaching.Start it with your 4-6mo old maybe and expect it to be entertaining as late as 15mos maybe.I mean the snack holder part will always make your munchkin happy, but the added play features won't be interesting for nearly as long.

So this isn't boundless fun, but it is pretty good. Across three boys (15mos, 5 and 8) and one girl (4) this has been a very welcome addition to water guns, water balloons and other sprayers. It is as advertised in all specs.I would say this is BEST suited for the 2-3yo range. My son would have obsessed over it then. Where as my 15mo nephew is too young.Still a good toy for the price.
Cute but too narrow at the widest part of my foot. Also, the sole was too rigid.I prefer Teva Northwater.Had to return them.

Love Frank Deford as a commentator and heard high praise for this book.Though I am NOT reading it, it was a VERY welcome gift by a newly graduated journalism major who has a passion for sports journalism AND is a bit of a funny man.If you know about Frank Deford, then you know why this would be a perfect gift for such an up and coming journalist.
Just okay.I was being cheap and so I bought cheap and got cheap. They are think and flimsy AND unlined...I should have paid better attention.Still, they are chart-sized paper pads.

This game borders on between good and great for me.Some of the boards have vowel sounds that are NOT introduced in kindergarten, so render those useless. I like this best as a team game so they can check each other's work.BEWARE that fact that your students will build phonetically correct words that are not spelled correctly and be ready to talk about that other than just saying 'Nope'.I also get my kiddos to tell me to use words in sentences in order for them to decide if the word is 'real' or not.

This is a such a great visual aide to use with my math groups. As my students struggle to figure out something like 9+?=17, I can remind them the various orders the numbers can go in and show them how "If you figure out one, you figure out all of them."They always find one they can solve and then fill in all the remaining blanks.Cleans off well too.

These things are very big. Best for a regular student desk, but not a more compact kidney-shaped small group table. Will likely trim them down somehow.Otherwise at least as solid as more expensive options I've seen out there.

If you like the big purse look and are done stuffing your own purse with diapers then you are in luck with this bag.Everyone I showed it to said the same thing "Looks like a purse" but has all the functionality (and organization) of a diaper bag.And lets be honest: don't we want that kind organizing ability for our own purses anyway?This a great crossever bag. It comes in a selection of styles and  colors so find the one that's right for you.

Very cute and practicall with it's many compartments. If your little one can reach the back of your seat with their feet this will get dirty in no time flat.However if you need to have things at arms length while drive (really not sure why your cell phone would really spend much time in it) then this can be handy...especially for some longer day and road trips.I'm always left wondring if these are meant more for the mom or the kids...depends on your own needs I suppose.

I've packed a Kind nut bar in my lunch bag for a couple of years now and was curious to try something new.I can compare this to the Kashi Dark chocolate and sea salt grain bar by saying it tastes MUCH better.That said, grain bars in general don't set well with my stomach.This Kind bar seemed to do better than others, but will probably stick with the nut bars.

We always have pizza Friday in our house, and we have a picky bunch of pizza eaters. This little oven is GREAT for quickly cooking a variety of pizzas.While the directions call for you to place the pizza directly on the ceramic plate, this isn't possible with most take-and-bake pizzas. For example, with Papa Murphy's you HAVE to use the provided tray. The pizza does cook well enough, but the crust gets done sooner and the center of the pizza isn't quite as crisp, though it is cooked through.Frozen pizzas can go directly on as well as well some pre- or partially baked crust pizzas (such as mini personal pizzas the kids love to make).It's nice not having to fire up the entire regular size stove to get our pizza's cooked, especially as the summer approaches.You are limited to 12" (which is generally a medium pizza). Also this has a fairly large foot print, so if you don't have a dedicated counter space for it you might run into problems. I have a small prep cart I use for storage and this is where it lives.Overall, if you're a pizza lover and prefer smaller baked-to-order pizzas, then this might be a great option for you.

Have had a 'golden' set  that has held up very well over the last decade. These are even higher quality manufacturing so I'm very hopeful.As with my other set, it's worth getting a good quality shower bar that has few to no ridges as the rollers are much louder when on ridged bars.Very happy with these.

Got them to use when our many little cousins come to visit, but they can be handy for more!Sure, they could be giant clothes drying racks (kidding)But they actually VERY easily disassemble for on the  go trips.We took three of them camping with us over the weekend. Our 50" kiddo opted not to use one because he's just a touch too big, but the 5yo and 4yo used. Keeps them from rolling all over the place as compared to plain old sleeping pads. And because they're so low to the ground, there wasn't too much cold air passing under them.Over, really much more versatile than stackable napping cots!

We are a 2010 Subaru Forrester household with three kids. I am in a constant quest to find seating options that support 3-across seating.So far the Diono Radian has been the ONLY seat to accomodate our needs.Diono in general are heavy duty, extremely well constructed seats. No complaints on that end.If you go off the specs alone you'd think this booster has the same or even a slightly smaller footprint than the Radian...this is absolutely NOT true.While base measurments are similar, the Monterey opens up like a butterfly. Seat maximum width is 18in compared to the Radian's near 14in. Back and shoulder width for the Monterey is a hair over 19in compared to about 16 for the Radian.These are huge differences for a household that wants their children safe but can't afford a new car to accommodate these larger boosters.Look, Diono is in line with every other standard booster out there, plus they are much better quality. IF you do have the space then know the Monterey is an EXCELLENT booster and very comfortable. I appreciate the efforts to keep it narrow and have swing-out cup holders.However, if you are like me and have limited seat space in your car I would HIGHLY recommend the Radian as a solid booster to 100lbs. All you might need (with either of these styles) is a seat belt buckle extender so little hands don't get squeezed and scratched digging down for the buckle.

Truly an unpleasant pillow.After opening it we left it out and by an air filter for over a week waiting for the smell to abate. We are not chemical sensitive by any means, but the smell was overpowering and hasn't quit...just died down at this point.That said, the only memory this foam has is of once having been a firm solid piece of bamboo.This pillow is not responsive at all. To compare it to down in any way is simply false.To recommend it for back or stomach sleepers boarders on irresponsible.I grant the possibility that we just received the most hard packed, tall, smelly version of this pillow, but even so I  just can't recommend it.If you are looking for a just-right pillow for you then I'd recommend going to a store and trying one out before buying it.

Even though I'm an adult, I like this smaller kids sized water bottle for my own use.  It fits easily in the refrigerator water dispenser area and doesn't get water everywhere when filling.  The mouth is a good size--big enough to drink easily, small enough to not spill.  The top opens easily with the click of the button (no twisting), and it actually opens (I have one that doesn't).  The kid size is also good because it fits better in the center console cup carrier.Contigi is generally a good brand, though I had significant issues with a previous kid-sized water bottle rhat failed inexplicably after a month of use.Hopefully this one holds up better.

These are great for finer cutting work by the hands of slightly older students. The age recommendation of 6+ is appropriate, but they might better used in the 2nd grade.Bottom line, they're scissors and do what I expect. Time will tell about their overall durability in little hands.

This definitely gave a boost to my ab workout, but I do offer a word of caution: when it says consult your doctor or whomever, think about that seriously.I didn't try any new moves with this mat that I don't normally do EXCEPT for the side situp, which is much more intense with this mat. This felt great until the second use that triggered a muscle spasm in my left shoulder that has been an on and off problem for two years. I didn't expect this to aggravate it as I have a rigorous aerobic routine with regular ab work, but I can't attribute this spasm to anything else.I'll continue to use the mat for regular situps, but will stay away from the side ones.I don't blame the mat, but all the same the experience just made it o-k for me.

I've had many types of screwdrivers over the years and plenty of power drivers (including Black and Decker, Ryobi and Craftsman)I have to say this is probably one of the most thoughtfully packaged screwdrivers you can get for the money.Seriously if you only ever buy ONE to have around the house for small jobs and projects, this would be ideal.It comes with many of the standard screw heads, plus some oddball allen and hex heads. It also has a narrow-tip Phillips head as well, which is very handy if you're dealing battery compartments.The built in light is a useful and valuable feature if you aren't a head lamp owner,  but even if you are, the driver itself will often block the light.A built in charge meter won't have you guessing about how much battery life you have left (which is typically the case with past power drivers).And compared to other power drivers this one is LIGHT and maneuverable.The only minor qualm occurs when trying to pivot the head: I'm still trying to figure this out without engaging the trigger. I'm sure it's just my problem more than a manufacturing oversight.Overall VERY pleased.

This is a pre-summer review based on fit and past brand comparisons.I'm super, super picky about the sandals I get for my kiddo. They have to be closed-toed first off. Second they need to work wet and dry. Third they need to offer a felxible footbed support. Fourth, they need to provide all around foot protection. Fifth, they should keep his feet fairly cool, dry and fit well so blisters won't form.In the past I purely bought Keen Newport H2 sandals. They were often too heavy and stayed wet too long, but provided excellent protection for all summer activities.Last summer we tried Teva Toachi's. These kept his feet super cool, but super exposed. Yes they are closed-toed but otherwise his feet were about as exposed with regular Teva sport sandals and the increase of injury ensued. That said, he liked them.He never had any rubbing or blistering issues with these other shoes. They were not easy for him to put on or take off by himself (either pair). Neither of the other pairs have much growth flexibility. The Teva toe strap is purely decoration. So if you choose either you should wait till you absolutely need sandals in case your kiddo's foot has a sudden growth spurt.What I am liking about these Timberlands (which come in at the low end of the same price point as the other two):-Comparable construction falls between the Keen and Teva. More airy than the Keen while less exposed than the Teva.-Easy on and easy off for my kiddo. Yes he's 5 now, but this design would have been easier for him at 2 as well.-Flexibility for growth of foot. The way the shoe is designed helps to hold the foot in place even if it's not touching the end. Leading off of this, the sole of the shoes is more flexible across its entirety than either of the two other shoes. Keen is the least flexible and Teva has good flexibility just at the ball of the foot.-Though my son's feet aren't wide, these shoes could accommodate a wider foot.My concerns looking forward to everyday summer use are the sweat and contact rubbing with the neoprene lining. I assume these won't be an issue as my son's foot should be a snugger fit.Overall I feel confident about these sandals but realize that choosing one of the other two might make sense depending on your needs.Much more water play: Teva.Much more rocky terrain: Keens (for their thicker, more rigid soles especially)The Timberlands, however, appear to be a good middle ground sandal.Will update this review further in a few months.UPDATE 1: the boys wore these around over the weekend with no complaints once we resolved a small issue. When both boys put the shoes on there was a question about the "tongue". On both shoes (though I thought I was being attentive) I missed a place on the inside top side portion of the shoe that should go over the "tongue" but got trapped under it. This rubbed the feet the wrong way. Be sure when strapping on the shoe that all the edges are where they should be so no unnecessary discomfort or rubbing occurs.

Very protective case, but not easy to take on the go. It doesn't fit easily in my son's overnight bag when he goes to his dad's.Also, the type of headphone it can take is limited to one with a completely straight-in pin and plastic component. This has made several of our headphone sets unusable.All told, GREAT protections, but some practical limitations that don't make this ideal.

Just okay for us. Far too thick. My partner used the bread knife to shave off about an inch and half, then he used the leftovers to roll a neck pillow for himself.So we made this a good situation, but weren't pleased with the thickness of the pillow as it came to us.

My skin isn't particularly sensitive, but it had been developing dry patches recently. I switched to this a couple months ago and the dryness is noticeably improved.However, if you wear make-up, this isn't excellent for removing that. My organic mascara mostly smears under my eyes. I don't like have to rub around my eyes that much longer to get the mascara off.

Bought these for the kids, but I use them all the time. I take a smoothie in the morning to work and I pop one of these in my to-go cup. I just pop of the cup's lid and viola! I can drink with ease...smooth or thick smoothies.
Absolutely what you need if you have boots you wear regularly and are tired seeing slumped everywhere.I have three pairs of boots and this has made storing them by the other shoes totally manageable.

I have gone through almost a dozen carseats trying to find a combination that would work three-across for the back of a 2010 Forrester.This is an unbelievably difficult task.Currently I have a 4yo, a 5yo, and 7.5yo. I'm tired of wasting money trying to figure this configuration out. I'd heard good things about these seats from others and this is where we are at: one in the middle, one behind the passenger (both using the 5-pt harness) and a booster WITH a buckle extender behind the driver for the 7.5yo.I think this was worth the investment in order to make this car work for us for a few more years...always rotating the smallest to the center where the leg room is the least.Overall, very pleased.

Great for the wall...great as table decorations for a birthday party too. Durable as far as I see and they haven't unpeeled in the 3 months they've been up.My son preferred the bad guys and robots mostly.

This is the cheese grater I've been looking for! I know nothing about Joseph Joseph, but I know a whole lot about cheese: not only do I make some of my own, I love to cook with it, too. And I cook a LOT -- it's part of my job. So I'm always on the lookout for kitchen gadgets that: (a) work well; (b) are easy to clean; and (c) save space... because the space in my kitchen is unfortunately finite.This grater has impressed me on all counts. It's easy to use to shave cheese over a plate, or you can attach the slide-on cover and neatly grate away. The cover even has measuring notches on it so you know if you've grated enough. Once done, wash the thing by hand OR run it through the dishwasher and slide that cover over the top to keep the grating surface sharp while protecting your hands.As if that's not nifty enough, you can press a button on the side to swivel the handle so it works like a kickstand and holds the grating surface upright over your cutting board. With that easy-peasy move you can grate as much cheese -- or chocolate ribbons -- as you'd like.I find this so much easier to use than my box grater, particularly since I have arthritic hands. It's very well thought out, letting me grate on an angle rather than vertically, so my hands don't ache when I'm done.I'd highly recommend this. In fact, I may very well be giving several of these as Christmas stocking stuffers this year. I'm that impressed!

I received this caddy as a gift after putting it on my Wish List. It's the second one I've owned -- the first having lasted two years before I dropped it during cleaning and cracked the wood on the front edge so deeply that it hurt my arms the next time I used it to read in the tub. Between the two, I briefly tried a different bath caddy which I liked at first but which held my book so high over the tub that I couldn't get comfortable while trying to read.This caddy is perfect. The way the wire extension arms on the side shaped means the tray sits about an inch lower than the top edge of your tub. That was important to me since the other caddy actually raised my book 1 1/2 inches over the edge. There are ample drainage holes so water doesn't collect, but it's a good idea to dry it off after use anyway. (I learned with my first one that if you don't dry it the arms will eventually grow rust and the finish will start wearing off.)Most importantly, for those of us who love to read or watch Netflix on their iPads or Kindles in the tub (just slip them in a Ziploc bag and you're good), the book rest is angled perfectly for tub reading/viewing and the grooves on the tray really do keep your book/tablet from slipping. That wine glass holder is pretty nice, too.I absolutely love this thing!

This was a gift for my birthday and it's one of the best ones I received! I soak in the tub nightly to deal with my arthritis. Not surprisingly, that means I've tried a lot of products that promise to make my bath time more comfortable. Until now, I thought finding a truly comfortable bath pillow was just a dream: I've had several, and most of them have been a disappointment. The vinyl-covered bath neck roll put a kink in my neck. The plastic-covered single-piece bath pillow wouldn't stay in place. The larger plastic-covered pillow was okay but there was such a huge gap around the suction cups that it quickly developed mildew, plus it wasn't much of a cushion.This pillow feels like your head is resting on a bed pillow in your tub! The seam between the neck roll and the rest of the pillow allows me to perfectly place the roll to support my neck, and the rest of the pillow is wide enough that my back doesn't touch the hard tub. Between the strong suction cups and the fabric pillow cover I no longer feel like I'm sliding all over the place, too. I use this for an hour nightly and was very surprised to find it was bone dry the next morning, even though I didn't wring the thing out. That's important to me since I don't want it to get mold or mildew but, thanks to my arthritis, there was no way I'd be able to squeeze it dry as I feared I'd need to.

This is a gorgeous rug: very soft underfoot, very well-made, and the price is outstanding. I received it as a gift since I'd added it to my Wish List as part of my plan to add more blues to my bland living room. This rug certainly packs some punch! Although it appears somewhat faded and powdery blue on screen, it's actually more of a turquoise in color. That worked with my color scheme, though I wasn't prepared for how vivid the color is. Rather than placing it in an open area (where the vivid color would pull focus from the rest of the room), I'm making it work by placing it beneath a coffee table.

Although these are attractive, they don't stay on my head! The fabric is very silky slick, and with my fine hair there's no traction to keep it in place. Since these are narrow tubes that slickness has led to the thing literally popping off my head when I've worn it as a cap.

I've been using these for occlusion therapy for my psoriasis: putting the medicine on before bed then covering it to keep the medicine from being wiped away by clothing and bed linens. I'd been using plastic wrap and surgical tape, but that gets very sweaty at night and is awkward to use on knees. Someone suggested giving these a try and I must say I'm very impressed -- they stay on even through a shower, though that's longer than I need. I wish they didn't cost so much since I need four each night, but hopefully after another round I won't need them anymore.

I loved the slingback look and price. These shoes go with a variety of my spring and summer outfits, too. They fit wonderfully if you adjust the back strap properly, and they're comfortable enough to wear all night out dancing. My only complaint is that I hate the nubby feel of the insole when I first put them on. That same texture also means they can't be worn with tights, which I find frustrating.
My two cats enjoyed this for about 15 minutes. I did not. It's incredibly loud. Now they're only interested in it on occasion -- usually if I've hidden it for a few days and brought it back out.

I always get compliments on this shirt. The fact that the design is off-center is extremely figure-flattering, too. (Though it might drive people with true OCD a bit nuts.) It's soft, drapes beautifully, and is just the right length.Be sure to hand-wash it, though. The fabric is likely to snag or the pattern wear off if it's put through the machine.
It's a sticker. It looks like the picture. It's thick. But it took FOREVER to get here, and by the time it arrived I'd forgotten about ordering it and had found a more suitable replacement.

I love the coral color and style of this shirt (with the bell sleeves and lace applique on the shoulders), but the fabric confounds me. It's thin but it seems to drape heavily so I definitely need shaping undergarments beneath it. That's fine but it definitely means I won't be wearing this after sumer temps set in.
Comfortable, fits perfectly, and fun to wear to band practice. I wish it had a front pocket like most hoodies, though -- it'd be nice to have a place for my phone.

This is a very good-looking outdoor mat that has truly brightened up my deck. I appreciate that it lets water flow through so I don't need to worry about the wood rotting beneath it, and I love having it under the table so I don't have to worry about splinters on my feet. I worried at first that my deck table and chairs would snag on the woven texture, but they haven't. The material doesn't get super hot on sunny days, either. All in all, this is a fantastic addition to my outdoor living space.

Twelve years of blogging have taken their toll on my posture and waistline. With recent health studies proclaiming that "sitting is the new smoking", I decided it was time to look for a standing desk. There are plenty of industrial- or commercial-looking standing desks, but I wanted one that worked with my home decor. This one looked like it would fit the bill, and I liked the price, so I ordered it. Based on its looks, I figured I could always use it as a home bar in the living room if I didn't like using it as a desk. But, wow, have I been impressed!I assembled it myself in 20 minutes without any problems (you only need a medium-sized Phillips screwdriver) and set it in my home office where I can easily move my laptop from my regular desk to this one. The first day I could only stand for 20 minutes at a time, even with an anti-fatigue mat, but I kept working at it. Now, just a few days later, I'm spending most of the morning at the standing desk, followed by a quick (seated) lunch, and then I alternate between the sitting and standing desks for the rest of the afternoon.Of course, I wish I could add "and in that time I've lost 10 lbs!" or something life-changing like that. Sorry, but it's only been a week. I can say that my posture is better, and that my Fitbit says I'm getting a lot more steps in throughout the day (probably because it's easier to pace when I'm thinking now). Oh, and I notice my creativity improves when I work at my standing desk in the morning -- maybe it's just the increased circulation, or maybe it's the change of view, but whatever it is, it's been nice.So I wholeheartedly recommend this desk for anyone who's been thinking about getting a standing desk. I wish I'd bought this years ago!

I've hated our deck table and chairs set for years due to the inferior cushions they came with. Being a plush-bottomed woman, you'd think I had enough cush on my tush that any ol' chair would be comfortable, but you'd be wrong. The cushions that came with our chairs were so thin that I'd feel the seat's supportive webbing straps beneath me, and the back cushion provided little to no support. Last year, I got fed up and replaced them with a set I picked up at Home Depot, but within a week they, too, felt flat and unsupportive. (It wasn't just me; my thin family and friends agreed.)Both of those sets were essentially just fabric over squares of foam, as cheaply made as they were priced. This year, I decided I'd pry open the wallet and get a GOOD set, maybe not top-of-the-line but several steps up from what I'd been used to. Saw these, and both the description as "overstuffed" and the button tucks (or whatever they're called) made me suspect they'd be firmer. Boy, was I right!These are fantastic cushions: sturdy, solid, and plush (like me!) but at a price that I liked. I bought mine slightly out-of-season, so I got a set of two for $37.43 but see they've gone up considerably now that it's officially spring. Even at the current price, they're worth it. They do feel top-of-the-line, with support both beneath and behind, and the fabric is as vivid as it is on screen. My deck furniture looks new now that I've swapped cushions, and both I and my guests are quite comfortable. Highly recommended!

This tea, which I received free for evaluation,  is a delight for the senses. The Fab Flowering tea looks absolutely gorgeous as it steeps, particularly when made in the Tea Beyond clear glass teapot (of which I'm not as fond). Watching the tea flower open, like its blooming, is mesmerizing. Surprisingly, the tea tastes good, too, and being able to make several pots from the same tea flower is nice.I love a good Earl Grey, so I was particularly thrilled with the double bergamot tea in this combo. The Jasmine was far too strong for my taste on first brewing, but after a second round it had mellowed and was enjoyable.But the Caramel Black Tea ROCKED my world. A splash of milk, a cube or two of sugar, and it's like drinking dessert. I've never tasted anything like that, and almost wasn't willing to give anyone else in the house a chance to try it. I finally relented, and they were just as impressed. It's a truly wonderful tea.All in all, I would heartily recommend this Combo package as a thoughtful gift for the tea-lovers in your life.

I'm an avid tea drinker, so most evenings I brew a small pot of a Pu-ehr or an herbal tea if I have an early morning. I also collect tea-related decor and love to display it in my kitchen. When Tea Beyond offered to send me a tea pot for consideration I jumped at the chance. Although I'd seen a photo of this teapot online, I was not prepared for the delicate beauty of the thing.This glass pot with built-in infuser was designed by Jane London, owner of Tea Beyond. It's a lovely, organic shape made of perfectly clear glass. On top sits a small glass butterfly which, honestly, is a bit girly for my tastes but I'm sure some find it cute. Using the teapot couldn't be easier: boil a kettle on the stove, preheat the glass teapot with hot water from the tap, and when your kettle whistles dump the glass teapot then add boiling water and insert the infuser filled with tea leaves. Once your tea is ready simply lift the infuser out, return the lid to the pot, and pour.Do note, this is a small teapot. Since it's glass it doesn't keep the tea warm for long at all, which is fine because the pot will be empty after pouring tea for two.But as the headline says, it is a very, very delicate beauty. By the end of the first use the handle on mine had cracked at the bottom and tea began leaking out. Not fun! I've kept the teapot because it's attractive and looks nice with my other tea decor, but I obviously can't use it since it leaks. Even if it didn't, I'm not sure that I'd use it very often -- since it only makes enough tea for two people, it's easier to microwave mugs of water and pop an infuser into each.

UPDATE: My initial order arrived with only one of the two lamps working. I'd left a rather displeased review, and was flabbergasted when the seller contacted me to offer a free replacement. The replacement worked beautifully, and I am so thrilled with these lamps. They're gorgeous, and they make my deck look lovely.

I'm a recently-converted Whovian who binge-watched the Doctor Who reboot for free, then bought this season so I'd be caught up before Season 9 starts. As a result, my first Doctor was Eccleston, and I liked his brooding yet manic energy. When he regenerated, I was upset (I didn't know the premise) but it took less than one episode for me to start raving about Tennant. He, too, came across as simultaneously contemplative and boyishly enthusiastic. When he, too, regenerated it took me several episodes to begin liking Matt Smith, but by the middle of Smith's first season I was crazy about him. And then came Capaldi.I like Peter Capaldi. I think he's a phenomenal actor, and I can't say I fault him for anything that seems to be going wrong with the show, but there IS something wrong with the show. The Doctor's love of humanity and all other species has been replaced by scorn. How many times have we heard the Doctor say to some hideous new alien, "Look at you, you're beautiful!" but now the Doctor seems condescending and disdainful. He's unlikeable and, frankly, he's downright mean. All of the enthusiasm and compassion is left to the companion to express and, although I do like Clara, the series is supposed to be about the Doctor. This season seems to have lost sight of that, just as it's lost all of the verve in the writing.Supposedly, Moffat intends to change things up in Season 9 to make the Doctor less dark, and the companion less the focus. We'll see. Rule #1: Moffat lies. Moffat has also said that Doctor Who has at least five more years, which makes me think he doesn't grasp that Doctor Who has and will continue to exist regardless of Moffat, and he owes it to the series' legacy to contribute to the mythos, not destroy it.

This is a great little vacuum for quick cleaning of hard flooring, which is what I bought it for. Since it's lightweight, I can use it even with my arthritic hands, and my son doesn't have any problem using it when I'm not in the mood to vacuum the kitchen myself. I didn't realize at the time that it came with a crevice attachment, much less that I could remove the handle and use it as a hand-vac. That makes me love it even more since I can now use it in my car! It couldn't be easier to clean, either: just press a button, open the case, and tap the filter over the trash can until it's clean.

There's no comparison between a manual and electric toothbrush -- the manual just can't get your teeth nearly as clean. Our ortho is adamant that his patients use electric brushes, so once my son got braces I went out to buy him a Philips. Two years later, that one broke when it fell two stories off the windowsill. (Long story.) There was no question about replacing it with another Philips immediately -- they just work that well. I love that the timer tells him how long to brush, he loves that the Philips does all the work for him, and our ortho loves how clean his teeth and brackets stay. Worth every penny.

I'd read many places about the benefits of avocado oil for the skin, particularly for psoriasis suffers like me. After looking at several brands, I decided to go with this one -- I cook with their grapeseed and sesame oils all the time, so I know they're high quality. Sure enough, this is a lovely, green oil that is super moisturizing. I absolutely love how my skin feels after adding 2 tablespoons of this to my garden tub and soaking for an hour. Some day, I might even try cooking with it.

I started using the lavender WEN last month and thought it would be nice to have another fragrance so I could switch things up now and then. Well, this is NOTHING like the lavender one, which I'd loved. It feels different in my hand, and it certainly feels different on my hair. I don't like it. I've had an itchy, flaky scalp every day that I've used it, and my hair has absolutely no texture. I won't buy from this seller again.
Bought these to let sweet peas, and later cucumbers, scramble upwards. They arrived in great condition and look good in the garden.

I bought this to replace a different auto-feeder that broke after my kid dropped it on a tile floor. The attraction about this one, besides the promise of keeping the food dry, was that it's weighted so I could set it on the hood over an open section rather than attach it to the side of the tank using the G-clamp, an arrangement that doesn't work with our tank configuration. The first day it worked fine, but at some point on the second day it tipped into the tank, so all the food got wet and my fish freaked out. I don't feel like I can trust it to stay propped on the hood by itself now, so I won't be using it unless we go on vacation -- at that point, I'll have to leave the hood open so I can make use of the feeder's g-clamp.

Easy to set up. If yours is rattling loudly, chances are you didn't get the J-shaped pipe inserted properly. That's not the filter's fault! Follow the directions as written and it works wonderfully. This is the quietest filter we've ever owned.

Pretty easy to set up, and much better looking than our old hood. Since this is smooth, it's easier to clean and should look new for quite some time. Unfortunately, it's made of a thinner plastic so it doesn't feel as sturdy. That thinness also means more noise if the water levels get low and the filter starts "waterfalling". Love the night light option, though!

This is a fun, fast-paced card game for 2 to 6 players (the more the better). It's very similar to the card game called "Joker", using numbered cards like Joker does, but with the addition of "Karma cards" that provide some vicious twists. The cards are laid out the same: three face-down table cards, three face-up table cards, six cards in each players' hand to start, the deck to draw from, and a discard pile. Game play is simple:1. Player one draws a card from the pile and discards one from his/her hand.2. Player two draws and then must play a card with the same or higher number. If unable or unwilling to do so, the Player can play a Karma card.3.
