The buttonholes also have red thread.  It is a clever look.The fabric is pretty stiff though, even after washing a couple of times.  It does not get worn very much because of this.

This is a very thin, almost transparent shirt, that is actually a light nice looking plaid but it is emblazoned with a huge American Hawk logo across the back.This shirt is transparent enough to be able to make out objects through one layer of it.The logo is just garish.  The photo in no way represents what it looks like in reality.  It kind of looks a little like a rustic work shirt in the photo.  In real life, it looks garish.

The first day the furnace comes on in my house is a sad day for my skin.  I don’t know why but even if the air has been on all summer, nothing dries out my skin more than the furnace.  So I sit in my office, itching and scratching.  This year I thought I was having an allergic reaction to something and was just all whiney because I was going to have to track down a new allergen.  Not so.  It was just dry skin.I slobber this lotion all over myself in the shower, not worrying about slippery greasy hands.  This is a lot more effective than the body creams that don’t seem to penetrate very well.  (I’m looking at you Bath and Body Works!)  Plus, the body creams are more difficult to wash off hands.  So this Eucerin is very useful!

This is another very pretty design that is very lightweight and shiny.  I am not always against lightweight and shiny, except just recently.  This tree of life has a classic look to it.  The design is just simple and elegant and timeless.The chain on this is for presentation purposes.  It looks pretty but then gets tangled and snaps at the slightest pressure.  That could be a good thing.

This is one of those cases where I liked the picture of an item better than the item.  I can’t figure out what is wrong with it when I hold it in my hand.  I like the design of it a lot.  However, it is a very bright silver and very light weight.  It just seems mean not to like something for those reasons.  However, the design would look better larger and made with a heavier metal.The chain is wimpy and tangles easily.  It is more for presentation than use.This is more like a child’s piece of jewelry than an adult’s.

I have had the most noticeable effects from glucosamine chondroitin when taking a Schiff brand called Move Free so I was really happy to see Move Free PLUS melatonin because it makes it much more likely that I will be faithful to taking both.  I might say, “Meh,” during the day about swallowing some (G-CH) horse pill or I might say “Meh,” at night about melatonin, but not to both.I only take one of these at a time because the dosage of melatonin is higher than my sleep doctor recommends.  He says 1 or 2 mg and, if it doesn't work,  that may have some relationship towards why I don’t take it every night.

Pretend play has always been so important to children’s development.  I love the cars and dolls and tracks that make children make up their own stories to go along with them.  Imaginative play helps children learn a lot of things, especially social skills.  It is a lot more fun to listen to them making up stories than watching them with headsets on and laptops open.This is a cute little set that would make a great gift for small children.

This sweater is a very pretty blue and the design on the front of it is really classic looking.The ribbing at the sleeves and the waist takes away from the quality of this sweater though.  The waist keeps its shape even when pulled on.  The sleeves are the problem:  the edges are just too rough and loose.  This is fine if the sweater is going to be worn cuffed but otherwise, it is going to come loose.The hood also seems like something of an anomaly.  This sweater has a really classic look, with the knit pattern in the front and the little pockets but then has a hood?  It just looks a little incongruous.

This is a nicely made cardigan.  It is 60% cotton and 40% acrylic.  It is just the perfect blend to allow the sweater to keep its shape throughout the year.  This is the perfect uniform sweater, but can also be used for over dresses.  I like the navy color to it, too.  I like the diamond pattern that is on about the top 1/3 of the sweater.  It is an effective design for preteen girls.I have not been as happy with the quality of some of the Eddie Bauer school clothing because it seemed like it was just too much polyester.  This sweater is much better than many of the uniform pieces I have seen.

These pants fit small boys exactly right in the waist and legs, just not the length.  I liked that the skinny fit didn’t mean microscopic fit.These pants look well made to my eye.  This is important to me because they end up being hand me downs in my house and the smallest one likes his clothes to be comfortable and broken in.One of the things I did not like were the metal decorative Hawks near the waistband.  It just seemed like so many different ways to scratch a child, either his waist or his hand going into a pocket.  They came off pretty easily but left holes in the name tag on the pants.  Taking the tag off led to more problems.

These pants fit small boys exactly right in the waist and legs, just not the length.  I liked that the skinny fit didn’t mean microscopic fit.These pants look well made to my eye.  This is important to me because they end up being hand me downs in my house and the smallest one likes his clothes to be comfortable and broken in.One of the things I did not like were the metal decorative Hawks near the waistband.  It just seemed like so many different ways to scratch a child, either his waist or his hand going into a pocket.  They came off pretty easily but left holes in the name tag on the pants.  Taking the tag off led to more problems.

This is one of a number of flea fighters that should have worked on the flea problems my dog has been having since summer.  I have used Frontline, Capstar, BioSpot, and a prescription med.  I have just been pulling my hair out, or he has been pulling his out, trying to figure out why he keeps getting them back.  Yes, I have been following frequency guidelines for medications.  It usually takes about a week for them to come back.  I have pretty much resolved that he is getting the fleas from his environment somehow but I can’t figure out that one either.  (Wild rabbits are a horrible problem sometimes but I haven’t seen any lately.)Anyway, this item probably works fine on everyone else’s dog.

It is really difficult to see a dog struggle with becoming middle aged, especially when he was extremely active.  This is our dog who used to jump straight up in the air to catch frisbees.  Now, he stops after 5 or 6 throws.  He comes back a little while later, but he likes his breaks.  It could be he is just trying to ditch the terrible thrower and then relents when he realizes I am his best bet.My dog disliked the flavor of these supplements.  Because of the strong, sort-of-cheese flavor, I wasn’t able to hide them in cheese or meat.  I am able to hide human grade glucosamine and chondroitin in his food so at least I can get some into him.

I love a lot of the new devices that have come out for iPads and iPhones.  This one I downloaded on an iPad as I don’t want to mess around with the tiny print on the iPhone in my kitchen.  (See my few words below on how much I hate the Apple store.)Many of the top latest recipes on my app were liquor involved, a lot of things I would never have thought of, like Orange maple Daiquiri or Strawberry mojito.  For some reason, the drinks were on top.  It took a bit of scrolling but there were a lot of interesting foods to make.  I found Healthy Peanut butter bars.  One of the ingredients was Medjool dates so I immediately requested a substitute ingredient and did not receive one.  It was very sad.  So onward and upward.The recipes on this app are just amazing.  Mini blueberry cobblers.  Basil butter.  Salsa fresca.  French toast.  (The secret ingredients seem to be butter and sugar.)  The recipes have stars and/or comments.  Most of the recipes seem to be from Drop Kitchen but I also saw some from Saveur and Spur of the Moments.To change to Ounces, go to the drop down menu (three flat lines) on the top left.  Scale.  Change to OZ.  Then go back to menu and it is back to g on the recipes.  So go back to drop down menu and find settings on the bottom.  Change weight to ounces.  YaY!If you find, as I did, that your scale does not work, there is a nice little help center in the same drop down menu, near the settings, that offers some common causes of the battery not working, like that you may not have removed the tab or it may have jarred in transit.  In my case there was not a tab, so it must have working in transit (assuming it actually works).  The battery is CR2477 3V by Panasonic.  Renata CR2477 are 5 for ~$20.  (Here.)  I found that Drop Customer service gets right back to you and offers a solution to the problem.  Excellent service.And here are my 102 words on the apple app store:  This store hates me.  It is always like a half an hour to log in to make a purchase and that includes an exchange of emails to get a password link because the password I ACTUALLY KNOW does not work.  Then I have to find the debit card and give it the information that the STORE ACTUALLY KNOWS.  Then I have to accept the new terms and conditions, which means I must be offended to the core of my being.  Then and only then, may I purchase a FREE APP.  Then, instead of downloading, I have to tell it my password again.

One of my dogs has been struggling with fleas this summer and fall.  I have used his regular Frontline for Large dogs every two weeks, supplemented with Capstar and another brand my veterinarian carries.  I used some that were lower dose, just to see if they would be effective as I hated giving him that much medicine.  I also tried this brand in between other treatments, just hoping something will work.  They all seem to work initially but then a week or so later, new fleas.  We have no idea of how he is getting them back.  Or why, of three dogs, only one has a problem.It's hard to blame any one of them when none are working.

Even though I know the science on it is not reliable, I have taken Glucosamine Chondroitin supplements to try to help with my knee pain.  I have a knee injury from kickboxing that has been exacerbated by arthritis.  The last time I saw an orthopedic surgeon, he said it wasn’t terrible enough yet to require replacement AND he got the injured knee wrong.  He said to take glucosamine chondroitin (Now I am just showing off knowing how to spell it) and come back in a few years.  Whatever.This has an added twist to the normal Glucosamine Chondroitin adding MSM.  I don’t know what the MSM is, except some kind of anti-inflammatory.  I have been taking a Glucosamine chondroitin for over a year now, ever since I flunked out of Physical Therapy, and have been able to increase activities, including walking, ellipticalling, and going up and down stairs over the past year.  I did not notice that this brand had any different effect than the others I have tried.  But that it worked was OVER my skepticism.  To the best of my knowledge, Glucosamine chondroitin was developed for horses.  And in fact, a new horse mix, Regenex, has MSM in it.  I have seen it work miracles on a dog though.It may have been the Glucosamine chondroitin or it may have been time.  I don’t know.

These pills are much bigger than many daily multi-vitamins.  It says they are coated but I think it is with invisible pixie dust or something because I’m not seeing it.  My husband doesn’t care about the size of these though.  He believes that he needs ALL of the vitamins in a multi-vitamin.  He likes these.I found the same B vitamin issues with men’s as women’s:  WHY is there 3333% of DVs of Thiamin (B1)?  Why is there 2941% of Riboflavin (B2)?  What is the deal with the Bs?  And then at the bottom of the barrel, 1% of potassium (for men and women)?Just as a side note, I find it curious that one of the bullet points on the UltraWoman claims *Hair, Skin, and Nails (Another is for Stress factors) without saying what it does for them.  However, the corresponding bullet points on the Ultra Man says *Sexual Health and *Immune Health.

These are giant.  As much as I would like to be an Ultra Woman, I could not swallow one of these.  This is the reason I don’t end up taking daily vitamins.  I focus on the small supplements I know that I need.The other problem with this is that WHY is there 3333% of DVs of Thiamin (B1)?  Why is there 2941% of Riboflavin (B2)?  What is the point of that?  And then at the bottom of the barrel, 1% of potassium?Also, this says take two.  That makes it a 90 day supply, not 180.

There were no directions included in my package but it is pretty easy to put together.  (It does say on the box that there will be a speaker and what looks like a booklet that could be directions.)I have to say that I have tried a number of these in the past and they have ~never~ worked.  Not on fleas, mosquitoes, mice, rabbits, deer, dogs or any other living creature.But I have high hopes.  The idea seems sound.  (LaLaLa!)  It makes sense that a particular nose would offend pests enough to make them leave.  I don't know what that sound would be but even if it were drums, I would be willing to go along with it.I have put this up on a 26 foot sailboat in our backyard where it could get some sun and will hopefully scare away squirrels and mice who seem to want to move in.My problem right now is that I am in Michigan.  It is November and the next time this may be fully charged could be May.

The design of this bracelet is much tighter and smaller than the picture looks.  I like it better than the picture.I was not sure how I would feel about gold plated anything but this is very pretty and has the (garish) brightness of my 24 k solid gold jewelry EXCEPT that it is much stronger.There is a clasp and a button open on this so it is more likely to be secure.  It was really flat looking when I opened it, but I squeezed the two sides (one hinged) to make it rounder.

I have never seen flashlights this bright, ever.  960 Lumens is a lot more than I could have imagined.  This light puts all others to shame.This kit comes with one large flashlight that has a zoom ability that pretty much is capable of throwing daylight to the end of my yard, 125 feet away.  It has two rechargeable 3.7 V batteries and a dual charger.  This kit also includes a smaller flashlight that uses one AA battery and puts to shame almost all of the flashlights I had in a drawer of flashlights.  My husband loves flashlights and I thought we had some good ones.  We didn’t.These flashlights have a great feel to them.  They are solid.  The larger flashlight fits comfortably in my hand and easily expands to zoom. The smaller flashlight is very lightweight in comparison but still feels good in hand.I was looking it over and was curious about the shape of the end of the flashlight.  It has waves in it and I discovered that this is useful for breaking a windshield.  This is a definite safety device to have in a car.  It would probably be good to have several of these around for different needs – in the house, on the boat, in the car.  They are just enormously useful and powerful.I received this product at a discount for review.

I put this in three of the dog bowls, the ones they use daily.  Then I put their regular food in the last bowl that no one uses, so that they could make a choice in food.  They ate up the lamb and left theirs until morning.I have mostly been feeding them Limited Ingredient Foods but this offered many of the same benefits without the 3 item rule.  This food is gluten free (not that I am worried about them being allergic to gluten) and far more importantly, grain free.  The other important part that is important is that it doesn’t have wheat, corn or soy.The best part is they like it.

This is a good basic surge protector for 6 plugs.  Its only flaw is that there is only room for two oversized plugs.  The second to last one may take a kindle charger, but the cord needs to come out the side, but not anything much bigger.  The last position, like most, can take just about any size as long as it doesn't interfere with the one next to it.The 3 foot cord makes this sort of ideal for the place I have put it, on a book shelf behind the couch.  That means I can go around the shelf once and not have it falling off constantly.I live in a city of less than 1k year round residents.  We have problems with electricity and surges on an on and off basis, so to speak.  This has taught me to always have some protection.

This is a cute idea and a cute set up that encourages imaginative play.  This is one of the best dollhouses we have ever had because it allows different setups and styles.  Indoor pool?  Kitchen upstairs?  No floor?  There are tons of little pieces that can be used to decorate however you like.My biggest problem with it is that any time it is jarred or when a piece is added, the whole thing can start falling down.  Usually it is just a wall then another, and then the next one linked.  It is a domino effect.  It is cute but it needs more than magnetics to hold it together.

This book had a lot of great ideas and suggestions to customize a little girl’s birthday party.  It was easy to just take the parts that we need from the book and not worry about getting overly fancy.It was also extremely useful because I am able to encourage the little girl to collaborate so she sees what kind of planning goes into any family event.My criticism is that none of these seem easy to set up.  It’s just so many steps…

It is about two weeks before gun-hunting season starts in Michigan and this is just the perfect time for this cookbook.  I generally get tired of venison because we just end up grilling venison steaks and that just is not a good way to eat them.  Some of the recipes in this book  just sound fabulous:  Rack of venison with sorrel berries, ground cherries and sautéed cattail hearts (p 233) or Roasted venison saddle with wood garlic, crosnes and wild mushroom jus (220).  I was hoping for more venison recipes because people just don’t bring me caribou or bear.There is also a great section for Wild Boar.  We used to have wild pig fairly regularly on Maui but it was always prepared pretty much the same way.Some of the game bird recipes are fantastic.  I found a lot of the directions for game birds to be incredibly informative.  I have never especially liked game birds because of never knowing what the quality of the bird is going to be.  But it is clear in the descriptions that the flavor is dependent on how the hunter prepares the bird after killing.Hunting is a complicated issue.  My father taught me to hunt and fish when I was small.  He taught his children to track animals and to respect the animals we killed.  As an adult, I am never quite sure how I feel about hunting, having mixed feelings about Bambi and not needing to hunt for sustenance against the need to cull the herd to keep the animals strong.

I don’t understand the sizing of these pants at all.  There is 6, 8, and then 10-12.  12s don’t fit children who wear size 10s.  They are about 4 inches too long.The waist fits our size 10 boy perfectly.  He is tall and narrow.  The pants are way too long, too long to even roll over once.This kind of sizing is appropriate for big things like sweatshirts, but not for pants.

I don’t understand the sizing of these pants at all.  There is 6, 8, and then 10-12.  12s don’t fit children who wear size 10s.  They are about 4 inches too long.The waist fits our size 10 boy perfectly.  He is tall and narrow.  The pants are way too long, too long to even roll over once.This kind of sizing is appropriate for big things like big sweatshirts, but not for pants.

This is an incredible story about a horrendous event that never should have happened.  That this mother was able to make it past this cold dark day only to be attacked by the Tin Foil Hat Brigade is a horrible reflection of our society.  Free speech and all that but to attack a mother who has lost a child?Someone must have tipped the trailer park and let all of these barely literate out.Truthers?  All of your friends are here and they are waiting for you.  Conspiracy theorists UNITE:  http://www.amazon.com/Wheres-Birth-Certificate-Eligible-President/forum/Fx3O0GUS5OOQ7GV/-/1/ref=cm_cd_topf_p?_encoding=UTF8&asin=1936488299

This is a cute little toy that does not get a lot of play time.  I throw all the dog toys into a bin at the end of the day and they pull them out during the day to play with.  This one was taken out a few times but not many and it slowly worked its way to the bottom of the toy bin.

These are beautiful boots.  The tread on them just looks amazing and it also says that they are slip resistant because of chemical treatment.  I don’t know what the treatment is.  The boots have a good support inside.  There is a flex design that looks artistic and makes the boots easier to get on and off.  They have a tiny tab at the back to pull them on.I was a little bit worried ordering ~any boots~ online of a brand I haven’t tried before because sizing between brands can be so weird and I have several children with funny shoe needs.  But I tend to use my son’s smallest size when selecting boots, as boots as a style tend to run large.  He starts at a 10 in boots and can wear up to 11 in outdoor sports shoes.  These fit perfectly except that they were a little tight in the heel.  They are leather though, so I expect them to loosen up.I don’t know how long lasting these are or what they will stand up to yet.  I do know Bogs to have a very good reputation.  All of my children, tiniest to the biggest, are hard on shoes, so I will know shortly.

I wondered how Dot would work without her sidekick Dash.  Dot appears to be the brains.AS soon as we downloaded the app, we were able to fool around with it making lights blink and having Dot repeat things.  Our ten year old was absolutely fascinated with it.  The developing complicated nature of Dot is really appealing to him.  Then a little while later, he showed up in my office door to show me what he was doing with Dot, and said, “I’m going to need Dash.”The Wonder app can be downloaded from iTunes store.  This allowed a child to start using Dot right away.

A great pack of ten quality cables.  These cables work great and are now scattered about my house wherever I tend to plug in my electronics. I love the extra protection the braided material provides and it adds a bit of flare to an otherwise dull cable as well (bright, fun colors are always a plus in my book) The cables easily plug into our phones and tablets, we have had no problems with them and plan to continue enjoying them for some time to come.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Boxeroo provided me with their cables to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

This is a great mold that produces diamond shaped ice cubes. It was carefully designed to insured wonderful looking diamond shaped ice cubes. They aren't very big but they look great. It might take a little extra work but I can't wait to make Chocolate diamonds in this mold I plan on using a little syringe to put the chocolate in each pocket and not make a mess.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Silicone Alley provided me with their Ice tray to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A nice wallet that holds my credit cards and my phone. The PU Leather has a soft lambskin like texture on the inside while the outside is a bit tougher probably because of the braids. The wallet holds my phone, my cards, my cash, everything else I really need it to. It does exactly what it is advertised to do .As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Roybens provided me with their Wallet to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

This is a fabulous set of inexpensive make up brushes. This isn't a high end item and certainly shouldn't be expected to be. When it arrived I opened it up and noticed that it needed to be aired out a bit. It smelled like plastic (Go figure, it is plastic) however after leaving it out overnight to air the stored plastic smell dissipated and left me with a wonderfully soft set of brushes that work well and that I don't have to be terrified that my five year old is going to get her hands on them. They will and have survived the attentions of my daughter and I can feel happy that my expensive set is up where she can't reach it.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Roybens provided me with their Make up brushes to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

This is a great travel kit. It has everything that I can think of that I may need in an emergency while I'm out camping plus more. There is also enough room in the case if I move stuff around to add to and customize the sewing kit if needed. I'm sure we'll think of something once we've used it a few times. I love that it is a zip up case, that way if something falls out of place it remains in the kit (At least until opened)As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Evergreen Art Supply  provided me with their Sewing kit to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

Definitely runs small so keep that in mind when ordering, if you are a big girl pass on this one as the XL is more like a Medium. That being said, it is exactly as advertised. a fun angle wing pattern is cut into the back. The material is soft and comfortable. Over all a great product if you order the right size.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, MAKIYO provided me with their Tshirt to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A strong and sturdy chain. Since it can hold around thirty pounds it had been able to hold everything we've thrown at it. I think it will ultimately end up holding a bird feeder next spring. With winter in the air the birds have all flown south for the moment though. For now it's holding up a planter of what's left of my herb garden.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, GrayBunny provided me with their Hanging chain to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A beautiful and fun set that is more than just the traditional copper mug.  Also included in this set is a handy ice spear mold and an absolutely adorable little copper shot glass. The copper mug itself is unlined, which is how I prefer them as it brings out the flavors in my drinks better. The handle is welded on instead of riveted which provides a sturdy handle without having to worry about leaks. I am very happy with the quality and beauty of this set and look forward to many happy evenings with it.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Felmark provided me with their Copper mug set to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A beautiful Aromatherapy diffuser that works wonderfully. This difusser reminds me of a lovely crystal decanter or perfume bottle (it's not made of crystal, it's plastic but it's still pretty) It has two easy settings, one that runs continuously and one that alternates on and off every thirty seconds. It also has a great safety feature that automatically turns it off when it runs out of water so I don't have to worry about getting distracted or falling asleep while it's on.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Senyoo provided me with their Defuser to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

I love this shoe rack, because it's so large I can finally but all of the family's shoes in one area cutting down on the mess and disorganization. A ten tier rack means there is plenty of room for everyone's shoes and they are easy to see. Now if I can only get the kids to start putting their shoes on the rack instead of anywhere they please...As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Ohuhu provided me with their Shoe rack to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A great, small hose that is easy to store.This hose shrinks up to a third of its 25 foot size once drained of water which makes it easier to store and handle. I have had no problems with kinks or tangles. It is important to note that you should always turn off the tap and discharge the hose after every use as a build up in pressure or unexpected freeze could cause it to pop rendering it useless.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Ohuhu provided me with their Hose to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

I found these head phones to be very comfortable with decent sound quality. While I can't say that these are the greatest thing since sliced bread I think they are a great pair of headphones for their price range. I love that they have such a long battery life because getting my family to plug things in to charge is like pulling teeth around here. It also comes witha nice carrying case for when we want to bring them somewhere or just store them.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Sentey provided me with their Headphones to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

This is a decent set of inexpensive pliers. These are by no means professional grade pliers and at the current price point I don't think anybody expects them to be. They do, however, do their job and are perfect for my twelve year old who enjoys fishing but has a bad habit of loosing just about everything.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case, Booms Fishing  provided me with their fishing pliers to test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

A fun wig to use for dress up or costuming I had a little difficulty styling the wig correctly and ended up with a lot of flyaways, nothing I can't work with though. While not my favorite wig of all time, I've had a lot worse and I can use this for future costuming ideas.As a blogger companies sometimes provide me with samples of their products, and in this case,FLC provided me with their Wigto test and review and to give my honest opinion of the results

Works great! Definitely better quality than some of the other filaments I have used in the past. Great adhesion and extrusion. A nice shelf that holds over fifteen pounds. It holds a bunch of different electronic items without a problem. (Sadly not the X-box One though) I had a few problems while installing my shelf and I had to change my ideas of what I originally planned to keep on it. A great little trash can for our bathroom. We put it in a corner and it works well. This is a small three liter can (Less than a gallon.) There are other larger cans out there if you need something bigger. We've had this can for two weeks now and it doesn't have any dents in it. After spending more than a year backpacking across Asia, Nick Sunder finds himself in Pakistan and accused of murdering one of his traveling companions. Knowing that the police are more interested in a quick conviction than justice, he takes what he thinks will be the easiest out and bribes smugglers to get him out of the city and on a path into Indian-controlled Kashmir. Things go awry when Nick is stranded in hostile territory without identification, money, or an alternate plan until two Kashmir Muslims trekking home allow Nick to join them.What starts out as a formula misunderstood-foreigner-in-trouble story becomes something much deeper as it explores the unique geography and people in an area of the world few North Americans have experienced. There are vivid descriptions of the dangerous, unique, and beautiful terrain that makes up the section of Asia tucked under the western Himalayas down into Pakistan and India and characters that represent the wide variety of peoples and languages that populate the area in various states of conflict, harmony, religions, politics, and ways of looking at life. The events and trials he experiences on the way along with the insight he gains from conversations with his new friend, Ghulam, lead Nick to a better understanding of himself and his own life choices.There is also parallel story of two children from a small village in Kashmir and the very different choices and paths they take into adulthood as the villagers help the girl to become a doctor while the influence of foreign mullahs in a local madrassa convince the boy to become a violent mujahid. Their stories eventually intersect with Nick's journey with profound consequences for them all.Recommended.

Sister Valentine Driskill has returned to her home near Princeton, NJ, and is anxious to share some alarming information from her research in the Vatican Secret Archives with her brother, Ben. Her research has led her to the discovery of a trail of murders that can be traced back to associations made during the Occupation of Paris in World War II between priests assigned to the area and Nazi officers. Before she can meet with him, Val is murdered in a chapel on her family's estate.There are several layers of conspiracy and mystery woven throughout this book's thriller plot, including doses of history of the Vatican's intrigues dating back to medieval times.For mystery lovers, there is an elaborate one offered here to unwind along with the main characters, Ben Driskill and Sister Elizabeth, as they each take separate paths to track down the real people known to them only as code names, and to find the reasons that one of those on their list is killing each of the others in turn.For conspiracy lovers, there is a decades-old one that reaches out from the past that threatens to affect the election of a new pope as each of the leading candidates try to cover up past indiscretions by whatever means necessary.History, covert dealings, and papal politics all blend together to build a satisfying thriller and mystery. For those who are unfamiliar with the often nefarious and shockingly political goings-on of the historical Roman Catholic Church and Vatican, it could offer a revelation and an introduction to parts of history that might be explored further outside of the confines of this novel.Highly recommended.

This book is a must-read for animal lovers, owners of rescue dogs, and anyone considering adopting a rescue dog.The number of dedicated people across the country who devote time, effort, and money to saving the lives of thousands of dogs that would otherwise be put to death in shelters who are described in this book are true heroes. Not only do they save the lives of these dogs, they help match them to new forever homes and temporary foster homes where they can be nursed back to health in order for them to eventually make it to their forever home. The amount of work involved in this is astounding from maintaining websites, vetting applications for prospective new owners, to going out and finding and choosing which dogs are considered to be adoptable and knowing that they can't save them all. The descriptions of the conditions of many of these shelters and neighborhoods are often appalling, and it is heartbreaking to read of the many dogs that cannot be saved.The author traveled along the long and unglamorous road that many of these dogs take from being rescued from shelters and streets in southern states to the eventual road trip to the mid-Atlantic states and beyond to their new families. The determination of the volunteer workers and the driver of the truck for "Rescue Road Trips" keep the flow of rescues going despite the foul weather, the apathy and sometimes hostility of public officials, and the tight budgets all for the big payoffs of "Gotcha Days" when the dogs are united with their adopting families.There is a list of organizations at the end of the book with contact information for those readers who would like to help these volunteers with their efforts to save more dogs and to help keep the "Rescue Road Trips" on the road.Recommended.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

Based on the title, one would be led to believe that this autobiography by one of the partners of a leading Swiss private bank would argue with solid examples of just why a banker's life would not be all about money.What the reader gets in the first half of the book is a disjointed catalog of how the bank was founded and his ancestors, remembrances of his youth and family, descriptions of his time as an undergraduate during World War II at Lehigh University, an apprenticeship in a New York bank, graduate study at New York University, and the financial side of the founding of Israel. There is also a lot of name-dropping throughout the text about the famous scientists and artists who visited his parents' home (his father was a physicist and his mother a sculptress). The name dropping continues throughout the book ranging from politicians to musicians to other prominent bankers. There is little about what a banker is actually doing all day, every day for his firm. It was a chore to plow through the first half.I strongly recommend that the author and publisher consider the addition of a glossary to the book if there is a second edition. Having definitions for much of the terminology that is used in regard to banking structure, policies, and accounting as a reference would have made much of the book more understandable and meaningful to us non-bankers.The second half of the book shifts to academia, music, art collecting, and more name-dropping. Near the end of the book, the inquiry into the Swiss "dormant accounts" that may have been held by victims of the Holocaust and the results of the extensive audit of Swiss banks is detailed. There is a concluding chapter where Baer outlines the current state of investment worldwide and what portion is controlled by the Swiss banking industry and a few predictions for future trends. I was disappointed that he did not cover or comment upon the changes that have taken place in the banking regulations that have removed much of the privacy protection from accounts, specifically when it comes to reporting to the US and other foreign governments for taxation purposes. The second half was much more readable than the first half.For something that is labeled an autobiography, I found the omissions to be puzzling. For most people, meeting one's future spouse and the birth of the resulting children are high points in a life. While there is a chapter dedicated to his wife, Ilse, it seems very sparse on details with even the birth of their children only mentioned in the context of a broken leg soon after the birth of their daughter to put the event in perspective as to time. Mrs. Baer does appear in other remembrances through the last half of the book, usually in the context of being a companion on various travels. The children are not even given that mention until they have reached adulthood and then only in passing when mentioning an in-law or the next generation of bankers. What becomes clear is that the author was a workaholic who had little to do with his family during their formative years.The conclusions I drew from the book was that yes, it is indeed all about money, for without it, the author would not have been able to attend the various universities, travel, acquire his collection of artists' works, nor be a supporting patron of the Zurich classical music scene. Yes, he had talents, but without the money from his family's business he would not have been able to have indulged his interests or gotten the same level of training to exercise those talents.Not recommended as a whole, but sections or chapters might be cherry-picked by a reader depending on the specific interest in a topic.

Ex-cop turned small farmer Abby Mackenzie finds more than fresh pastries waiting for her when she stops by the local patisserie with a delivery of honey. Chef Jean-Louis Bonheur is lying dead on the floor and his usually pristine kitchen is in chaos. The local police chief is quick to close the case as a probable suicide, but Abby disagrees with his assessment. When Jean-Louis's brother Phillippe comes to town to claim his brother's body, he hires Abby to prove that the death was due to foul play, not suicide.This book is a nice blend of a cozy mystery to solve, police procedure and forensics, and enjoyable characters. Abby is a strong character as is her best friend, Kat who is still a member of the town's police force. A number of supporting characters were introduced, many local business owners, who I would expect to figure more prominently in future stories. And maybe in a future story we'll find out if there is a hidden joke in everyone always referring to Chief Bob Allen by his full name and title.Reading about the amount of work that Abby does to maintain and grow her farmette business while juggling her investigative assignment is both exhausting and inspiring for those of us who count gardening as a favorite pastime. The attention paid to details of police procedure and chain-of-evidence by a former professional law inforcement officer is a nice change from the many amateur detectives found in cozies and adds a touch of reality to the investigation. A careful reader can connect the dots from the clues to solve the mystery along with Abby and Kat.There are bits of farming wisdom from the "Henny Penny Farmette Almanac" at the beginning of each chapter and a recipe or other advice on beekeeping or gardening at the end of each chapter. The recipe for Maisey's Low-Country Bourbon Pecan Pie looks especially inviting.Recommended. I'm looking forward to reading more mysteries from this series.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

Sheriff Lil Eller wakes up handcuffed in the trunk of an big, old car being driven along bumpy mountain roads. Questions arise immediately such as where is her deputy cat, Boris? And even more importantly who in Crazy would be crazy enough to kidnap a sheriff?I'm hooked on this series. It's got a nice balance of interesting recurring characters, a serious mystery, and the running sub-plot of the Littlepage-Eller feud with Lil in the middle of the two families. There is just enough of Boris to add some fun and to see the caring side of Lil without the presence of the cat taking over or saving the day too often. It's not sweet or syrupy as are many other cozies with an animal sidekick, but it does contain some humor thanks to the quirky characters that inhabit the town and surrounding area.This mystery is different in that it has Lil as the victim and placed in the unusual position of having to survive, wait, and allow others to do the investigating and the saving. There are plenty of twists and surprises to follow along the way to figure out both the complex reasons behind the why of the kidnapping and the who that set it all in motion.Highly recommended.

Cy and Lou may be retired, but their successful career in homicide detective work isn't over yet when they're asked to investigate a probable murder by a sheriff in another county. As luck would have it, the victim, Col. Portwood, was a mystery writer they had met a few days earlier at the annual state book fair. Always ready to solve a new mystery, the boys get to work at unraveling the events leading up to the author's death.This book is back on track with a good, old-fashioned mystery to be solved. The series bounces back and forth between being heavy on running jokes about the detectives' lifestyles and the presentation of a well-thought out mystery. This one has some generous dashes of lifestyle humor, but delivers a tough solve-along mystery to the reader. I could have used more detail in the explanation for the motive which seemed a weak justification for murder.The characters introduced are distinct, varied, and believable. I only have one nit to pick about the brother and sister of the victim who came across as over-the-top dumb hicks and who don't seem to have come from the same universe as their brother much less the same family and upbringing. The point had already been made about their differences with their brother in the description of their home and their jobs without overdoing the poor grammar.Instead of the seemingly endless menus and food descriptions in earlier books of the series, we now get lists of authors and their mysteries that the main characters are reading which can quickly become just as tedious as the meals had become. Food has not been abandoned though since many restaurants that the boys visit are mentioned as though parts of the book have become a travel guide to Kentucky. The real mystery is what, if not bacon, is in Kentucky Bacon Pie?Recommended for cozy lovers who like humor mixed into their mystery. Oh, and watch out for Elmer.

This collection consists of two separate trilogies, each with its own form of nuclear destruction and the aftermath. The rating is an average for the six books included in the set.Radioactive Trilogy:The first trilogy begins in San Diego and centers around Jim Farr, an ex-Navy intelligence officer turned contractor specializing in marine mechanics.The first book in the trilogy, Radioactive Book 1, is the strongest of the boxset and on its own would rate four stars. The story is based around a dirty bomb being detonated on the San Diego naval base and the hero's escape from the city along with his cat and his co-worker to Phoenix to ensure the safety of his sister and her daughter. Farr is presented as someone who has prepared for emergencies, keeps his cool, and plans ahead, yet he never considered planning for an alternate route to Phoenix. Small inconsistencies such as this crop up at various spots of the book either as oversights or as plot devices. Overall it's a good page-turner of a thriller.The next two books of the trilogy don't measure up to the possibilities introduced in the first.Radioactive Book 2 - The City Burns is very short, but doesn't make much sense at all as a follow-up to the situation set up in the first book. Farr's brother-in-law, Matt, is being held and tortured for some unknown piece of information by persons unknown. Somewhere in all of this the line defining who are the good guys and who are the bad guys gets very blurred and confused. Oh, and there is a conspiracy too. The stars are falling as this segment of the trilogy falls to a stand-alone three stars.Radioactive Book 3 - The Resistance is all about special forces-style operations against the conspiracy. Somehow Farr has morphed from ex-Navy into a soldier without any explanation, along with his sidekick mechanic from the previous books. Not just any soldiers either, but the kind being sent into special ops situations complete with explosives and snipers. Other poor decisions by the people in charge of the anti-conspiracy forces cause the events in another plot in the book. What type of witness protection program gives out home addresses of the people they're supposed to be protecting? As in the other books, basic mistakes, oversights, and continuity problems such as this are in place simply as plot devices. The results are lots of heroics and action, but few answers about the conspiracy, the conspirators, or what the purposes or reasoning behind the conspiracy are forthcoming. This book rates only three stars.The Decay Trilogy:The second trilogy revolves around a series of terrorist attacks that include first a bombing of Wall Street which is then followed up by the detonation of several nuclear bombs in the eastern United States. One plot follows a family separated after the attacks and another follows a Polish tourist caught up in the attack on Wall Street by being in the wrong place at the wrong time.The first book in this trilogy, The Decay, sets up the characters and the overall situation. Sacha, a Polish tourist, is in police custody after the Wall Street bombing simply because he was in the area, but once introduced is not heard from again in this first book. Paul Thompson and his step-daughter Julie are in Pennsylvania when one of the nuclear bombs goes off nearby and rush to get out of town and away from the radiation. Complicating matters is the fact that Paul's wife is on a business trip in Denver. They are determined to head west to try to find her and reunite their family.Paul is an unlikable character with a bad temper and seems to be determined to do one dumb thing after another by making a string of bad decisions. Julie, despite being only twelve years old, seems to be the smarter of the two. A sub-plot involving some thugs looking for Paul's employer has no good purpose to the overall plot and is never explained except as a device to give Paul a weapon before they begin their travels. The book gets a shaky two stars for taking a long way around to get not very far along with the story.The Decay: Episode Two, has Paul and Julie still in Pennsylvania and determined to get to Denver with the help of an ex-military officer, Jordan. Unfortunately Jordan is only moderately better than Paul in decision making. Overall this book is better than the first with the group finally making some progress towards their goal and the introduction of more characters from a gated community led by a man known as the Sheriff and a cult leader, Sister Bonnie, and her followers. Approximately three weeks after the attacks are covered as opposed to only one day in the first book, so there is much more happening as events move along. The character Sacha who was briefly introduced in the first book is not mentioned at all in the second book. This entry in the trilogy gets three stars.The Decay: Episode Three, rolls the time line back to re-introduce Sacha who is still in police custody as a terrorist suspect. The time line jumps back and forth between what has been happening to Sacha over the ensuing weeks and back to Paul and Julie as they make their way across country to Denver. We also finally meet Samantha, Paul's wife, and learn what she's been up to during the emergency. Toss in a new conspiracy, an underground bunker, a bunch of terrorists, and more poor decision-making by Paul and you've got the makings of a thriller. Unfortunately, the execution of the thriller is riddled with a lot of wildly improbable coincidences that go far beyond anything a reader should be expected to accept. We're down to two stars for this effort.Overall the boxset is not recommended, but if the first book of the Radioactive trilogy can be found as a stand-alone book, it is the one book from the collection that would be worth reading on its own. The rest of the collection can be skipped without fear of missing something important.

I had been looking forward to reading this book of Pierre Trudeau's recollections of his life and his time in the office of Prime Minister of Canada and had great expectations of finding new insights into his career and the important events that shaped his tenure in office. I came away from reading it with a feeling that a lot was missing, not the least of which was the personal side of Trudeau's life with the exception of his early years before politics.The memoir itself was constructed from a series of oral interviews which were then back-filled with specific information and corrections of dates, places, and so forth by Trudeau and his aides. No doubt if this book had been written in the more typical way of most memoirs, with time to reflect and analyze the various events and to add the details that otherwise would be unknown outside of a select circle of participants, many of the important events mentioned would have been given more than a few sentences or paragraphs each. Other events that would have seemed important to an observer, such as his first meeting with the Queen after becoming prime minister, don't even rate a mention. The result is a rather impersonal cataloging of impressions of a select subset of people and events spanning his years in office.The major highlights of Trudeau's career are his handling of the FLQ terror attack in Quebec, the patriation of the Canadian constitution from Great Britain, and the creation of the Charter of Rights as part of that new constitution. Those events are covered more thoroughly than most others, although the constitutional fight is told more from the perspective of a political battlefront with the provinces and specific provincial premiers rather than about the elements of the constitution and Charter themselves.The book contains a wealth of photographs to illustrate the life of Canada's most famous politician, many coming from the private collection of the Trudeau family.Recommended for those interested in Canadian history and politics and those interested specifically in former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau.

Apartheid is still the rule of the day in the Republic of South Africa, and there is still a tension between the descendants of the Boer settlers and the English. The small town of Piemburg is a perfect example of this multi-leveled class structure. Police Kommandant van Heerden is an Afrikaner, but has long envied the English way of life, so when he is called to the estate of Miss Hazelstone after she calls in the report of a murder, he is beside himself with the thrill of finally getting to see inside Jacaranda House and be of service to the fine lady. When that fine lady confesses to being the murderer, van Heerden finds himself in the worst nightmare of his career.This book was originally released in 1971 and shows its age. At the time apartheid was still in force in South Africa and there was certainly a class system that carried over to the Afrikaners and English.Putting that history aside, the book still suffers from the basic fact that the author tried much too hard to be shocking rather than humorous. The humor rises only to the level of the mentality of twelve year old boys in that it is titillating and outrageously silly with many sexual references. Just as modern day comedians are finally wearing out the shock value of f-bombs and other similar language as substitutes for true humor, this book depends not so much on funny situations, humorous characters, and witty turns of phrase as it does on pulling one more shocker out of the bag of tricks. It may have shocked the readers in the 1970s and specifically the government of South Africa of the time, but now it just comes across as un-funny and rather sad since there was a potential for humor in the story of the incompetent police department personnel rather than with the repeated insertion of the salacious, sexual non-humor into the story which became tedious and embarrassing.Not recommended.

Widowed with two sons to look after, Lady Elizabeth Grey approaches the new king, Edward IV of the York line of Plantagenets, to ensure that she and her boys will have their lands restored to them. Her request is a bold one since her husband had been killed while fighting for the Lancastrians against the York claim to the throne. Lady Grey gets more than she bargained for when the young king takes a fancy to her and eventually proposes a secret marriage.It took me a couple of tries before I could get into this book because the first few dozen pages read more like a romance novel than a serious work of accurate historical fiction. Initially, I found the first person narrative was difficult to accept since it was from the viewpoint of a real, historical person rather than a conveniently created fictional one simply observing the events or the usual technique of a third person narrative. Unless there is considerable contemporary documentation of the state of mind, motivations, and emotional state of the historical character, I shy away from the presumption of knowing what went on inside their heads. Once those hurdles were jumped, and I got used to the first person narrative, I was drawn into the intrigue and manipulations that saw power shift from one faction to the other and back over the coming decades.There were still some bumps in the book besides the romantic interludes. I found the sections dealing with the mythology behind the Melusina story became tedious and took the focus away from the main event, often at unwelcome times. Repeatedly revisiting the myth seemed even more out of place in a book that was otherwise well-grounded in fact rather than fancy.I appreciated the bibliography listing at the end of the book to assist in choosing further reading and study of the personalities and actions of the era. I hope that one of these can lead me to the historical basis for the sections of the book that suggested a changeling took the place of one of Edward's sons in the Tower of London while the real prince escaped to Flanders. This is the first suggestion I have come across in my reading on the subject that puts forward this alternate as a serious possibility.Recommended, but with the suggestion that readers with a low tolerance for fantasy may wish to skip the sections dealing with the Melusina myth.

This cookbook may look thinner than others on the subject, but it's packed with fabulous and authentic recipes for breads. Even if you've only managed to create basic breads or rolls so far, there is enough hand-holding information and illustrations of techniques to get you over your fears of shaping and proofing to produce these wonderful examples of classic breads.For beginners and intermediate bakers, there is an extensive section, "Baking Essentials," explaining the various ingredients and tools that are used in bread baking. In the section "Basic Techniques," the mechanics of mixing, proofing, kneading and illustrated and described in detail. Even experienced bakers can pick up some new tips and tricks for using starters and shaping techniques.I especially appreciated the photographs and step-by-step instructions for braiding and making twists and knots for specialty breads and rolls. The page showing the before-and-after results of various types of glazes that can be used on breads will help the home baker decide which is appropriate for their finished products and is a good reference to use for recipes other than those in this book.The recipes themselves go from basic breads using the bare minimum of basic ingredients all the way to enriched breads, flavored breads, quick breads, and breads for festive occasions that include fruit and nuts. There are many ethnic breads from which to choose including Pane Semola, Hungarian Potato Bread, Zopf, and Swedish Dill Bread to name a few. Several flat breads are included in addition to the more familiar leavened loaves.The ingredients lists are given in both American standard cup measurements and by metric weight for most items, except for small amounts listed in teaspoons and tablespoons.Some of the preparation instructions may seem to be a bit over the top and the more experienced bakers will probably make adjustments to the techniques to suit their style; however, less experienced bakers won't go wrong following the instructions in this book until they gain enough confidence in their own skills to make the changes that work for them.Highly recommended.

Deanna Durbin was a Hollywood star contemporary with Judy Garland, but unlike Garland, Durbin's movies featured classical music and operatic arias as well as light, popular tunes. This CD features a mix of a few classical selections and several popular songs her movies.The audio quality of the transfer is, unfortunately, not as good as the voice deserves. Several of these songs have not been available previously on Deanna Durbin collections, so it's a trade-off: either accept the noise, pops, and uneven audio levels from track-to-track or not have them at all. The worst example of this is the track "Perhaps" which is littered with background noises, presumably from the action in the movie soundtrack.There are no liner notes provided about the contents of the CD beyond a simple list of titles and timing. The composers and lyricists don't even rate a mention. At the very least, it would have been helpful to note the movie from which the track was taken and the year of release.Personally, I would have preferred the CD to be all classical pieces since the popular tunes have historically been easier to find while locating the classical ones is somewhat of a treasure hunt. I had been looking for the "Russian Medley" from my favorite of Durbin's movies, His Butler's Sister [VHS] and was thrilled that it is included on this disk. Luckily it is one of the better transfers and suffers less from the noise than do other songs, but does drop slightly in audio level from the previous track. "None Shall Sleep Tonight" (an English translation of Nessun Dorma) from the same film is wonderful.The popular tunes are an odd mix of what would be considered standards such as "Night and Day" and the wartime "Say a Prayer for the Boys Over There" and many lesser lights that have not stood the test of time. This version of "Night and Day" suffers from an oddly chosen arrangement that does not mesh well with Durbin's beautiful voice and includes a long added-in musical introduction that probably had more to do with the movie's story line than the popular song.Five stars for the voice, but the poor job of re-mastering has to pull the rating down to a mere four stars.Recommended for classical music mavens, old movie fans, and anyone wishing to listen to one of the best of Hollywood's singing leading ladies.

Who would have thought that working as an intern at the National Endowment for the Arts could be hazardous to your health? Trent Norris finds out that his usually boring internship has become exactly that when he answers a telephone and takes a message with hidden meanings meant for one of the agency's bosses. One day and a dead congressman later, Trent finds himself sought by the law as the assassin. Using some unconventional tactics and the aid of an ex-engineer turned high-priced call girl, Trent tries to find the real killer and reason behind it and to clear his name while the death toll and list of charges against him grows ever longer.This book takes the basics of a plot for a serious conspiracy thriller and adds just the right touch of humor to take it out of the ordinary and make it fresh. Trent is presented as a likable guy who tries to do a decent job on his assignments and to be pleasant with his co-workers and bosses, all while keeping his head down and trying not to be bored to death, pretty much like most interns. The clever schemes he cooks up and the various risks he takes to dig up the dirt on the movers and shakers of several government agencies and contractors in order to prove himself innocent are entertaining without being too outlandish to be believable.The story is set just far enough back in time to make use of some old-fashioned technology as part of the plot. Those of us who remember the older computer systems, Wang word processors, and a time when there were pay phones on every corner will get a few flashbacks to those not-always-simpler times and a dose of nostalgia as a bonus.Recommended, especially for conspiracy thriller lovers who need to lighten it up a bit as a change of pace.

Cinnamon and Burro are investigators for New Mexico, but they are not detectives, per se. Their job is to get to the bottom of an alleged civil rights violation in a middle school that is preventing an autistic boy from getting the therapy and instruction he needs. What they find is a lot of hostility from the school's administrator and staff, and possibly the murder of the boy they've come to help.This story is not your ordinary cozy mystery. The investigators are not trying to find a murderer, are not well-meaning amateurs, and do not reveal clues along the way for the reader to solve the mystery along with the characters. I generally prefer mysteries that allow me to match my solving skills against the characters'.There was a back story to the character of Cinnamon that is reference several times throughout the story about how her mother abandoned her and her father when she was very young. Her mother ended up in New Mexico which is why Cinnamon (which was also her mother's name, just to keep things confusing) now works in the state as she tries to find places and people her mother may have encountered. I found this sub-plot to be distracting from the main plot, and I was unsympathetic to an adult who is still not able to simply move on from childhood disappointments decades later, especially when it is distracting her from her job.So why the four stars? It's because the important part of this story is not the mystery, it's about bigotry and the misunderstandings surrounding autism. It's an important topic, often with answers that are not always the obvious ones, and that sometimes the people in charge of the presumed answers shouldn't be.Mildly recommended.

Caswell "Cash" Harrison is in his last year of law school at Columbia when the US enters World War II. Unable to join the military due to a medical problem, he searches for another way to serve his country and make a difference to the war effort. Through acquaintances and connections in his hometown of Philadelphia, he is offered a position as a law clerk to one of the Supreme Court Justices for a year. Cash is urged to take the opportunity, but he soon finds that the road to justice is not always as clear cut as he would want to believe as cases decided before the Court are often more about the war, politics, and ulterior motives than constitutional law. Cash soon suspects there is something more sinister to the selection of clerks and the deciding of cases to be heard before the Court than is apparent from the outside, and believes he could be in danger if he continues to investigate those suspicions.There are elements of historical fact, fiction, legal thriller, conspiracy, and mystery all woven into this book as told from the viewpoint of the somewhat idealistic and naive main character. Thrown into the deep end of the Washington shark tank, he's unprepared for the environment in which he finds himself. There are also elements of a coming-of-age story as Cash grows into his new position and learns that secrets are shared and favors traded as part of the workings behind the scenes of government. After getting off to a slow start with a bit of nostalgia for the time and some flowery prose, the book picks up the pace and moves along swiftly once Cash finds his way to Washington and his desk at the Supreme Court.The important focus of the book is the background information about the major cases that come to the Supreme Court as part of the war effort, more specifically those dealing with the detention and internment of Japanese Americans living on the West Coast. Other important cases of the era are mentioned, some in depth, such as those dealing with the Jehovah's Witnesses' refusal to recite the Pledge of Allegiance and the rulings that allowed the trial of German spies captured on US soil to be tried in military courts rather than civilian courts.There are appearances by many historical characters including J. Edgar Hoover and his number two man, Clyde Tolson, Hugo Black and Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court, Attorney General Biddle, and various members of the Department of Justice and Department of War. The author has included an extensive note at the end of the book pointing out where fact ends and fiction begins for each of the supporting characters mentioned in the story.To be entertained by a book is a joy, but to be both entertained and educated is a greater one. This book shows what goes into background manipulations, thought processes, political realities, and trade offs that occur as part of the workings of both the courts and the federal government in general when dealing with the legal system. There is no reason to believe that the basics of the processes have changed much in the intervening years.Highly recommended for those interested in the history of the World War II era, Supreme Court processes and landmark cases of the early 1940s, and anyone enjoying a complex thriller.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

I think I gained at least five pounds just reading this book. There are so many scrumptious recipes and insider techniques for using them in this book that it could easily keep a home baker in new creations for years. The strong point of these recipes is that they can be used in multiple ways by changing the fillings, toppings, and shaping to come up with different types of pastries.After sections introducing the home baker to the necessary equipment, gadgets, ingredients, and basic techniques needed in order to create these masterpieces, the book gets into the preparation of the fillings and toppings that are mixed-and-matched with various types of doughs such as Almond Paste Filling, Apricot Butter, and Chocolate Custard, for example.The text is dotted with "Baker's Secret" entries giving more insider information on various topics such as on how to shape various types of dough, how to choose the best ingredients, and the best way to freeze and thaw extra portions. The recipe and technique instructions and hints are clearly presented and explained.The recipes for the doughs are the main event of the book. Most of the recipes given such as Bundt (not the formed cake that most people think of), Babka, Gugelhopf, Stollen, and Strudel make fairly large amounts, but clear instructions are given on how to store the excess doughs for later use in other recipes. The flexibility of each of these doughs when paired with different fillings or shapes to make the many old-world pastries that were a mainstay of local ethnic bakeries is nothing short of astounding.Highly recommended for both beginners and experienced home bakers.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

The town of South Cove is sponsoring a charity 5K run and walk in aid of the California Mission Society. The event seems to be a hit with the participants until one of them takes a fall and lands on a lifeless body hidden near the course. As if having a murderer running loose isn't bad enough, one of the local businesses has become the target for a vandal. The owner of Coffee, Books, and More, Jill Gardner and her Aunt Jackie, who have a reputation for solving crimes, decide to help find some answers.This book has a lot going for it. The small town setting makes you wish you lived there among all of the unique shops and friendly people with an easy walk to the beach. The cast of supporting characters, with one or two exceptions, are people that you'd like to have as your friends to meet for lunch or just to hang out on the beach together. The two mysteries give the reader puzzles to solve while enjoying the town's atmosphere and its good vibes. The murder mystery is presented in a way that allows the reader to solve it along with Jill and Aunt Jackie, which is the type of cozy I prefer.I like the main character, Jill, too. She is a competent and independent woman who manages to juggle the demands of her business, her work with the town's business committee, her love life, and her obligations to her family which includes her aunt and her employees. No scatterbrain or whimpering damsel, instead she is an educated, modern woman who can hold her own without panicking or waffling. Her septuagenarian aunt is an older take-charge version of Jill rather than a stereotypical doddering old lady. Both could be considered wonderful role models for younger readers.I have not read the previous books in the series, but that lack of background information did not detract from the story or in understanding the characters. This book works well as a stand-alone story.Recommended.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

There's a crisis on its way to France in the form of a flotilla of a hundred rusty ships carrying almost one million poor, starving migrants from Calcutta. As the ships slowly make their way to the Mediterranean, the popular media gush about how best to welcome the newcomers. More pragmatic observers realize that the entry of all of these people en masse will change the West's way of life forever and try to sound the alarm to save the country from the invasion.This book was written in 1973 and made available in an English translation in 1975, but the vision of a Third World invasion of the West as described in the book is even more relevant today as we see in frequent news reports of troubles with migrants in Europe and our own political rhetoric in the United States about immigration issues.The writing style is very literary and at times a bit flowery with many twists of scene as events are repeated from various viewpoints. It is not a quick read and will require the reader's concentration to navigate among the various metaphors, concepts, and personalities.Abandon any thoughts of "political correctness" when reading this book. It presents the reality of the world's population rather than a Utopia of the brotherhood of mankind. As a a non-white character from the book, Monsieur Hamadura, who has embraced France and its culture points out, it's not only race that matters, but the whole common culture, language, and heritage that is threatened by a massive influx of people of other backgrounds. The message and the warning presented is: in a war of the haves versus the have-nots, it is the haves who will lose if they are unwilling or unable to defend themselves against the invaders.Recommended.

Once you open up the bottle and take a sniff of the contents, you'll probably recognize it as that special scent that's in those scrumptious sweet rolls that you buy at an old-fashioned bakery. It's a bit butter-y and a bit citrus-y and it adds an extra flavor punch to your own homemade cinnamon buns and sweet rolls.I use one teaspoon of the Buttery Sweet Dough flavoring in my cinnamon rolls in addition to the vanilla called for in my recipe that makes a dozen rolls. For larger batches, use more flavoring in proportion to your other flavors. It's definitely worth the tiny bit of extra effort to get the extra raves for the rolls.Recommended.

Ray Doaks is returning to the farm where he grew up after spending two years in prison. What he finds is his closest friend, Pete Culpepper, trying to juggle a failing farm, a small time racing stable down to its last gelding and a couple of broodmares, and a pile of debt. He also finds that Sonny Stanton, the ne'er do well son of the local billionaire, has been trying to buy up the farms to turn them into a housing development and golf course while using some underhanded tactics to force some of them sell out.The book is slow to get moving while introducing the characters, their circumstances, and their relationships, but picks up speed once the introductions are made. Once it gets rolling, the payoff that is coming is worth the slight delay.Most of the characters are plain folks just trying to do a good day's work and make a living, but the one bad guy stands out for what he is: a bully who will use his father's money and influence to push other people around without ever suffering any consequences.The main character, Ray, is someone who always tries to make things right even if he has to use questionable means to set things straight. In the book, a character calls him a "Robin Hood" which pretty well sums him up. The complex plan he cooks up and puts into motion to set things to rights is a classic.Other characters who the reader will want to cheer for include Paulie, the animal-loving poor relation; Etta, a dutiful daughter trying to save her father's farm while he sinks into senility; and Jackson, the horse trainer and manager who tries to keep his boss's stable running in spite of Sonny's actions.Recommended, especially for those readers who like a good sting operation or just like to see bullies get their just rewards in a clever and entertaining manner.

Yes, even long-time Linux users have stacks of old floppies with archived information that sometimes needs to be accessed.Recent Linux distros should be able to recognize and mount this device with just a couple of mouse clicks. I tested it on a couple of currently supported Mageia distros and had no problems with it being found and was able to read several floppy formats without a glitch.Older Linux distros may take a bit more prodding to find the device, but usually just a reboot with the device connected or a scan via the distro's administrative tools will find it and mount it. I tested it with an older Mandriva distro and was able to mount it manually via a command line as root within a terminal session.For Windows users, I also tested this floppy on Windows XP, Windows 7, and Windows 8.1. All recognized the drive and mounted it for use without any additional user interaction necessary. I will caution users planning on upgrading to Windows 10, that it will not include drivers for USB floppy drives by default in its main package. You will need to download a driver for the floppy drive for Windows 10 from the manufacturer of the device (Sabrent) or from Microsoft after your installation or upgrade of the operating system.Recommended.

The United States has been split due to an assassination and coup by a renegade politician, Simon Sterling, and his cronies and who has established what he has called the Unified American Empire. A section of the former USA calling themselves the Pacific States of America, has elected Howard Beck, a computer science genius and industrialist, as their president. In his sanctuary in the Rocky Mountains, Beck has a plan to defeat the usurper and restore the republic using his high-tech expertise with the help of his advanced artificial intelligence software he calls Hal.A warning: Don't try reading this book unless you have first read its predecessor, Collapse (New America-Book One), or you will be thoroughly confused by the cast of characters and the reasons for their actions. Take the time to read that one first to save time trying to understand this book and to be able just to enjoy the fun instead.This book follows the same pattern with multiple seemingly unrelated subplots that were initiated in the first book continuing here. They are each important to the overall plot, but often in ways that are not clear to the reader, but they do become merged into the main story at various points. Think of it as getting several stories for the price of one umbrella story.The battle of the PSA versus the UAE sometimes seems like something out of a Star Wars movie, but that's part of the ride. The political thriller is alive and well underneath the gee-whiz gadgets. The characters are still heroes and villains, good guys and bad, and Howard Beck is still an eccentric genius who cares about his country.Recommended for anyone enjoying stories with high-tech gadgets and political thrillers.

There's been a death out in Paint Hollow, home of the Collier family and all of their relations.
