It's pretty much a no-go zone for outsiders, but Sheriff Lil and Boris, the deputy sheriff cat, have to brave the hostile group when they try to investigate the death of the family's matriarch, Vera Collier. Complicating matters is the fact that Vera did not leave a will, but did leave a house full of stuff that rumor says includes a hidden fortune in stock certificates and cash.This book is a double dip of a humorous look at insular small towns and family connections plus a better than average mystery.There are plenty of twists and turns to the mystery and a long list of possible suspects to keep things moving along. There are a some sub-plots outside of the murder mystery involving some of the more colorful Crazy residents and the on-going feud between the Littlepages and Ellers.Does anyone besides me wonder why Boris isn't getting top billing? I've known many cats over the years, and Boris's actions and reactions are spot on. The only unusual thing is that lie detector tail of his that I have yet to see in any other cat, but it's a very useful thing for a deputy sheriff to have.The first book, Crazy, VA (Lil & Boris #1) (Lil and Boris Mysteries), set the scene of the town and inhabitants of Crazy, but this book can be read as a stand-alone mystery. Enough of the background of the town is restated early in the book to fill in a newcomer to the series.Highly recommended for cozy mystery lovers, cat lovers, and lovers of humorous small town characters.

Alicia Krupa has turned her hobby of making scented soaps and lotions into a small, but thriving business. To launch a new line of products, an extravagant party is being held at her home and the products are well-received. But the party comes to a sudden end when Alicia appears at the head of the stairs, screams, then falls to the bottom of the stairs dead. An investigation ensues.After an intriguing set up and murder scene, the book quickly took a turn for the worse. What credible police department would allow a group of women whose day job is running an ice cream parlor to all but take over a murder investigation? The premise of many cozies have a talented amateur or two looking for clues in parallel with the official investigation, but this one has a tag team of amateurs who take turns attending interrogations, poking around crime scenes, and telling the police detective what he should do. If the graduate students working at the shop were majoring in criminology, psychology, or some other related disciple, it might be plausible to have one or two of them around the crime scene as interns or trainees, but for English and civil engineering majors to not only be invited to observe but actually to be asked to assist with the investigation and taking on the bulk of the work from the police? No, I'm not buying the scenario.The mystery itself has lot of red herrings and dead ends mixed in with a lot of wheel spinning by the semi-official investigators. The solution of the crime was credible, but the investigation would have been even more credible without the ice cream girls seeming to be in charge instead of remaining in a supporting role to the real investigation.Not recommended.

The Little Detective Agency consists of Bernie the brawn of the agency and Chet the brains of the pair. By the way, Chet is a dog. When an illegally transplanted Saguaro cactus mysteriously appears in their elderly neighbor's yard, Bernie and Chet dive into the case in order to clear their neighbor of any wrong-doing, but there turns out to be something much more sinister going on than stealing cacti from federal lands, and the two soon find themselves in the middle of a murder investigation and more.The gimmick of this cozy is in the narration from the viewpoint of Chet, the dog. He's dedicated to both Bernie and his professional standing as a detective who tracks down perps and puts them into orange jumpsuits, as we find out through his telling of the story. We also find out that he does not have a good memory for details, although bits and pieces of previous investigations are threaded throughout the current story. It's a cute way of telling a story, but at times it gets too cloying and repetitive to the detriment of the flow of the mystery. Perhaps if the book's point of view had switched from Chet to Bernie and back it would have kept the idea fresher and moved the story along more smoothly.The mystery is basically a good one with a lot going on to keep the reader interested. The ending was marred by some loose ends left hanging and some missing explanations as to the motives of various characters' actions.While the premise of a dog detective and story teller make a fun cozy, this book is not appropriate for younger readers due to occasional rough language and descriptions of violence.Mildly recommended for those readers who don't mind a rougher edge to their cozies.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

The United States has suffered an attack from unknown enemies using multiple EMP devices that takes out seventy percent of the nation's electrical grid and electronic devices. The population in those areas is suddenly without all of the infrastructure and support services that they rely on for day-to-day life. A small portion of that population has prepared for such a disaster, but now their greatest challenge is not doing without the electrical grid, but fighting off those who would take away what they have.This is more than a book that is simply urging preparedness for emergencies and cataloging a list of supplies or actions towards that effort. There are two other important plots woven in, one about a militia group and their not-quite-sane leader, and another about an overall conspiracy behind the initial EMP attacks and the attempt to alert authorities before the wrong enemy is punished for the chaos it has caused. There are also minor subplots dealing with the attempts to repair a segment of the generation grid which underlines the difficulties and frustrations that would exist if a similar event were to actually occur, and another about a group of Wall Street brokers who are caught by the event while on vacation.The descriptions of the civil unrest in urban and suburban areas are chilling, but in a real event, I fear could be much worse than those described in the book and would begin much sooner after a massive shutdown. Overall the book entertains while giving a warning of what could happen.The conspiracy portion of the plot does not contain a lot of details on the who, why, and how, but would be an excellent topic to be explored in a prequel to the events in this book.Recommended, but with a warning to those who may be put off by some of the more brutal events and actions described in portions of the book.

Howard Beck has created an empire with his innovations in computer science and software development and has reaped a fortune from his inventions. His crowning achievement is an ultimate artificial intelligence program which he has guarded closely. When the United States finds itself beset by a second Great Depression followed by number of natural disasters, the country is plunged into martial law after the death of the president. The lives of an escaped convict, a small town police chief, and Beck cross paths and join together with Beck's A.I. to try to remove the tyrant and restore the country to its people.After being introduced to the reclusive main characters, Beck and his A.I,. there are several seemingly unrelated subplots inserted with a variety of characters that seem to be out of place and far from the main action. From a hurricane in coastal Texas, to a prison escape in California, presidential politics and dirty dealing, a homeless family in New York City, and anarchy in Florida, the author manages to bring together all of these subplots into the main story and make them relevant to the overall plot.There are a few minor plot points that seem to have been lost along the way, such as whatever happened to the two pet cats rescued in Texas, but overall the juggling of all of these various characters comes together as the pieces of the plot puzzle are fitted together. Especially fascinating is the shifting of some characters who originally are cast as bad guys who turn out to be not what they seem and vice-versa for several of the good guys. It helps to keep up the reader's interest while also keeping the surprise level high.The book ends in somewhat of a cliffhanger in order to set things up for the next installment of the story in part two of the series, Resistance in the New America series.Recommended for those who enjoy political thrillers, stories about advanced artificial intelligence, and dystopian fiction.

The town of Ellington is staging a massive event of coordinated yard and garage sales in order to bring in tourists to spend money at the sale and with their local businesses. Sarah Winston has been hired by the town's manager to organize the event and ensure its success. When a series of fires are set around the town and a body turns up in one of the local shops, the ensuing investigation turns up more questions than answers.There are several elements that make up a good cozy mystery: interesting characters and their relationships, a clever mystery with lots of clues for the reader to share in searching out the perpetrator, and enough twists to the plot to keep things fresh and interesting. This book has those three elements.I had not read the previous book in this series, so I was not familiar with the background events, but that did not detract from my enjoyment of the mystery. It can be read as a stand alone without affecting the mystery or its solution; however, it would have clarified the past relationship between the main character, Sarah, and her ex-husband CJ the town's chief of police for one of the sub-plots and that knowledge would have made the interplay between them more understandable.The theme of garage and yard sales and thrift stores was simply part of the scenery to me just as much as the setting of the small New England town. I'm not a garage sale maven, so the descriptions and details about holding them or buying from them were foreign territory and of no interest to me except as they moved the story and mystery along.The mystery presented is many-layered and generates several of the sub-plots of the book most of which converge to help to uncover the murderer. This is not a simple, straight-forward whodunit so those readers who prefer a bit more complexity to their cozies will not be disappointed.Recommended for those who prefer the more complex cozies.A free copy of this ebook was provided to me by the publisher for review purposes.

Investigative journalist Michael Chenault is presented with information about the murder of a retired professor of history in upstate New York that may tie into the murder of the wife of Utah Senator Brockston Ratchford, a front-runner in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Chenault heads out to Utah to track down how and why the two murders could possibly be related.There's a nice mix of history, investigation, mystery, treasure hunt, and conspiracy in this book along with a very likable main character in Michael Chenault. The history and organization of the LDS church is mysterious in and of itself to most readers, and as such offers a wealth of possibilities for the story to evolve around it. The unlikable politician, Ratchford, and his minion Fiske show the shady side of politicians and their aides, so it's easy for the reader to root against them as they use their position to try to derail Chenault's investigation.I found some elements of the ending somewhat predictable, but that says more about how many thrillers I've read over the years rather than anything negative about the build-up to the exciting ending of the book. I would welcome another book featuring Chenault on another investigative adventure.Recommended.

My HP laptop kept overheating and shutting down under heavy use that required a lot of disk drive or DVD drive activity, so I needed a solution that would be lightweight and portable yet deliver the cooling power required to keep it running.This Cooler Master product fits my requirements beautifully. It's lightweight, so it doesn't add a lot of extra ounces to my laptop bag. It will fit in my bag along with the laptop, but it is a tight fit and requires a bit of wiggling to get both in. If you've got a slimline case or sleeve for your laptop, you may need to upgrade to a larger case to fit them both properly.It's quiet, and it puts out plenty of cooling power, which will be even more welcome this summer since some of the cool air blows out from under the laptop right at the user. Just a whisper of a breeze, but noticeable.The one possible point of future failure that I can foresee would be the wire that connects the USB plug to the unit. The wire is thin enough to allow it to be flexible so it can be seated within a channel under the unit in such a way to allow the user to connect to the laptop's USB port on either side. It is not reinforced where is goes into the plug or fan. There is a "parking spot" for the USB plug under the unit to secure it when not in use or when in transit. There are posts to wrap the wire around when securing the plug. With excessive use, I could see this wire wearing or breaking off near the connection points. With careful handling, this should not be a problem for most users, but should be kept in mind when securing the wire and plug or changing the side on which the plug is used on the laptop.Recommended.

This series of books is designed for beginning bakers and contains some helpful information, but repeats the first four chapters in each book. Once you've read one book, you've already been instructed in the basics of equipment, types of sweeteners, fats and oils, and so forth.Once the reader gets past the first four chapters, the specific information about pies and pie crusts finally begins.There are basic recipes for one and two crust pies with detailed information about how to create a flaky crust for your selected fillings. There are also recipes for more unusual crusts such as a Double Cheddar Pie Crust and two types of cracker crusts. I've never seen a pie crust recipe that suggested vodka or gin as a possible cold liquid to use in a crust. I think I will pass on this idea and stick to ice water in my crusts.Filling recipes include Berry Pie, Apple Pie, Key Lime Pie, Strawberry Lime Pie, and Oreo Crust Pie.Each recipe has detailed instructions to lead the home baker through each step, hand-holding the beginner or intermediate baker through to an edible dessert. I would caution a true beginner from trying the Oreo Crust Pie as a first attempt since the filling preparation is much more complicated than that for a fruit-filled pie.There is a section at the end of the book containing various conversion charts and tips for baking, including high altitude adjustments to recipes.This series is short on recipes in each volume and high on general kitchen and baking information. I would have preferred if the author and publisher had chosen to make one stand-alone volume with the general information, then concentrate on the specifics of one facet of baking in each successive volume to avoid the repetition of content. It would have allowed more space for more recipes and specific baking tips. For example, I would have liked to have seen a section on how to do decorative pie crusts such as fluted edges or lattice tops instead of the repeated data that had nothing to do with pies and crusts.Still there is worthwhile information here and the recipes are well-presented. For someone who has not read any of the other ebooks in the series, the first four chapters will be new and instructive.Recommended for those who want basic information about how to to bake pies and pie crusts or to improve their skills.

Nancy Keller and her ex-husband, Ron, are business partners in a coffee shop and bakery. The partnership is suddenly brought to an end when Nancy finds Ron dead on the shop's floor early one morning.Cozy mysteries usually rely on a variety of well-drawn characters to pull the reader into the story. There are a lot of characters introduced in this book, but none of them, including the main character, are very well defined. Superficial information is sprinkled into the text such as age, hair color, and height of various characters, but little else. What makes these characters tick? Besides age and hair color what differentiates one from another?Cozy mysteries are also usually more relaxed when dealing with normal police procedures, leaving those details to the more rigorous types of police procedural mysteries. Cozies should still be bound by the basics of common sense as to the way the authorities must investigate a crime. There is no way that a person who is a possible suspect, related to the victim, and is the one who discovered the body would be allowed to sit in on interrogations of other suspects even if she is dating the sheriff. But that is precisely what the author had the main character doing repeatedly. No, that simply won't fly, even in a small community.There were also no consequences forthcoming when Nancy admits to her boyfriend sheriff that she's removed evidence from the scene. How about "tampering with evidence" or the ever-popular "obstruction of justice" charges? According to the flow of the story, the sheriff didn't even raise an eyebrow at the revelation. What is he doing investigating a crime in which his girlfriend is involved when there are other members of the police force in the town?The dialog is simplistic and comes across as stilted and unnatural. There are several detours into descriptions of the steps of making a pie or cake that go on for no good purpose. Even the reason behind the murder didn't make a whole lot of sense and doesn't stand up once the reader thinks it through.The book also suffered from formatting difficulties.Not recommended.

If you're the type of Internet user who checks out the photographs and captions on the "I Can Has Cheezburger?" website as part of your daily routine, then this book is for you. It's packed with the same type of silly cat pictures with even sillier captions as the website, but in the more permanent format of an ebook.I dare any cat lover to page through this book without breaking out in chuckles, giggles, and/or LOLs. You've got to wonder how people not only got their cats into such poses, but how they had the camera ready for just the right moment. What's amazing is that the photographs and captions are just as funny time after time. This truly funny stuff just doesn't get old!If you need a laugh, a distraction, or just want some fun, this is the place to find it.Highly recommended.

I first discovered Milka Chocolate products when I was on a business trip to Germany. I came back home with my carry-on bag stuffed with Milka bars. I was thrilled when I found that I could get the same good German Milka chocolate from Amazon.And unlike some chocolates that are European brands but made elsewhere under license and often with modified recipes, these chocolate bars are really and truly from Germany. It's the same recipe, the same chocolate, and the same taste that I got when I purchased them in Germany.If you've never had a Milka bar, you're in for a treat. They are smooth and creamy tasting and melt in your mouth. No waxy taste, no grainy sugary taste, just high quality milk chocolate.The bars came in a purple box of ten just like the boxes used for store display shelves.Highly recommended. Treat yourself!

Lauren Atkinson has spent her career as a lawyer fighting for inmates on Death Row to try to get their sentences changed to life in prison without parole. She's won a few fights and lost many, but now her principles are going to be tested when a tragedy strikes close to home.There are no easy answers to the debate about the right or wrong of the death penalty, and none are given in this book for the reader or for the characters. It is the story of how a family reacts to and deals with the results of a heinous crime and comes with a mystery to be solved as Lauren tries to find a murderer.This book does not argue for or against the death penalty. Instead, it puts the reader into the life of an attorney who is passionately opposed to the use of the ultimate penalty, and how she uses her knowledge of the system to work her way through her own personal tragedy. It becomes more a story of how one's principles can be tested when they are placed squarely up against personal realities rather than are simply some abstract concept and ideal. There is battle that takes place within Lauren that tears down and changes her relationships with those around her including her husband, Michael; her law partner, Gary; and even her clients on Death Row.The characters are well-drawn, the dialog believable, and the situations could be pulled from police files. The reader can grieve with the victims and their families and see the dark side that is the reality of prisoners' and criminals' lives.Highly recommended.

A stolen day with a young man visiting her village turns to love quickly for Felicity Sims. The problem is, the young man thinks he's spending the day with Rita Rodgers. Once he finds out the truth, will he be able to forgive Felicity for the deception?What starts out as a sappy romantic interlude and a description of young yearning love with no Poiret in sight, eventually fast-forwards into the setting for the mystery a decade down the timeline. The reader may want to have a diagram to sort out the relationships of the characters since it gets complicated, but it's necessary to understand them in order to follow the trail of events. While the relationships are complex, the mystery itself and its solution are fairly simple ones.Like most of these Poiret mysteries, the characters' dialog will seem very unnatural and stilted to modern readers.Moderately recommended as a quick, simple, soapy mystery to use as a time-filler.

A rural reporter and stringer for a London newspaper happens to be at the right place as a story unfolds in a village restaurant. Poiret is present as well to unravel the truth behind the story being told.The mystery itself seems rushed and without much "meat" to it. There is little for the reader to grab onto to follow the reasoning behind the conclusions Poiret seems to jump to in order to solve the case. For anyone trying to follow the logic behind the supposed clues, it will be a true mystery even after the big reveal of the crime and culprit as to how Poiret managed to jump to his final accusation.The more amusing parts of the story are those that feature the tabloid editor and his correspondence with the distant reporter. The amusement continues as the harried editor passes judgment on the reporter's submissions and makes edits to save the gentle sensibilities of the newspaper's readers. This view into the workings of London editorial practices of the time was more entertaining than the mystery itself.Not recommended. This is one of the weaker examples of the Poiret series of short story mysteries set in early 20th century England.

Mel, Angie, and Tate are partners in a new cupcake bakery in Old Town Scottsdale, with Tate being the bankroll while the girls mind the store. Things seem to be getting off to a good start until Tate's fiancée, Christie, is found in her design studio with one of Mel's specially made cupcakes in her cold, dead hand.The big selling point of cozy mysteries to me are likable characters who you would love to have as friends if they were real people, and this new series delivers them. The relationship among the three main characters makes you want to pull up a bucket of popcorn and join them in one of their movie nights. The supporting characters are a good mixture of understanding good guys, meddling relatives, and even a slightly-evil competitor who are all unique and add to the atmosphere of the cozy.The mystery can be classified as a solve-along, which is the type I prefer. The clues are there just waiting for the reader to pick them up along with Mel. The story moves along at a quick pace and weaves the workings of the bakery into the investigation and interactions of the characters.The descriptions of the cupcake flavors are clever and will probably become dangerous to the readers' waistlines as they can cause cravings to occur. Several of the cupcake and frosting recipes mentioned in the story are included at the end of the book, as is a preview of the next book in the series.Highly recommended. I've already begun reading the next book in the series.

I have to prepare to give a presentation every week and have found these highlighters to be a terrific tool to use in my preparations.I really like that I can use these pens for both underlining by using the pointed end of the tip or for highlighting by using the entire flat edge to emphasize a section of text. The fat, round form of the pens make this easy to do while reading or reviewing material with a simple twist of the fingers.The colors are bright and don't bleed through most weights of paper including all-purpose 20 weight paper commonly used in printers and copiers. The yellows are easiest to read through of the selection included in the set. Unless the text is not standard black print on white paper (such as a grayed font or dark-colored paper), all of the colors can be read through easily.Recommended.

Dekker and Murdock are called out of semi-retirement again to solve two apparent murders at County High School's 20 year reunion celebration. Everyone seemed to have a motive, but lacked opportunity. In spite of the general opinion of good riddance of the victims, the detectives follow the clues and uncover another mystery that's been hidden for two decades.This book, although it contains a pretty good mystery, is dragged down by the repetitive descriptions of the off-time pursuits of the two main characters. Yes, I like to have background characterization of the people in cozy mysteries, but there is a point where it becomes tedious, repetitive, and acts more to pad out the size of the book rather than to endear the characters to the reader. That point was reached in this book.It's nice to know that our tubby detectives are trying to lose weight, but how many Wii Fit sessions do the readers need to sit through while they do it? Instead of cataloging how much gravy and what kind of desserts they enjoy as done in previous books, we now learn how many cherry tomatoes or olives they have with their salad and so on. For every meal. Too much information! I got the point the first time.The same thing goes for the reading lists of our heroes. I began to think I was part of an infomercial for a mystery book club with the lists of authors and books they planned to read. Twice.I did enjoy the mystery, but I found myself way ahead of Dekker and Murdock and kept waiting for them to catch up with me on figuring out the clues while they repeatedly Wii-ed, discussed their reading list, and prepared meals.My favorite character in this book was Lightning, Dekker's yellow VW bug.Moderately recommended for those following the series and characters, but others would probably become frustrated by the story's many delays and wanderings.

Detective Poiret is visiting his friend Inspector Watkins who is explaining the breakthroughs science has made in police work in the form of a primitive lie detector. Poiret objects and claims that his powers of observation and knowledge of psychology is superior in determining guilt or innocence. He soon gets a chance to prove it as a man in seedy clothing is brought in for questioning.This short story presents a look into the police methods and the antics of some portions of the idle rich of the English peerage of the early 20th century. The mystery is an amusing one that has enough background explained to set up the situation and to make it possible for the reader to follow along with Poiret to connect the dots and come up with the correct conclusion.Recommended as a quick, amusing diversion.

It's just days before Christmas and the village's annual baking contest is in progress. Rachel Murray has gone all out with her entry of her special gingerbread house with hopes to win the top prize. So does Katie Jones with her yule log, along with a host of other contestants with their baking masterpieces. Everything comes to a sudden halt on the night of the contest when the judge declares that there has been sabotage.The situation in this short story is easy to relate to. Who hasn't tried their best to compete in a friendly competition such as a neighborhood baking contest, spelling bee, or county fair only to be disappointed when something (or someone) throws their plans off course? Each of the characters have their own motivations for presenting a winning entry and each is presented in a sympathetic way building to the revelation of the culprit, the motive, and the surprise winners.Included at the end of the book are two cookie recipes that use metric measurements. They are fairly simple recipes, so if you have a kitchen scale that does grams, they should be easy to recreate.Recommended as a sweet story sure to bring a smile to your face during any season.

I've been using Post-It Notes as page markers for many years. Full sized Post-It Notes, small sized Post-It Notes, and even in desperate times large Post-It Notes. I've been known to sit at my desk with a pair of scissors to cut up a few regular sized Notes into strips to use as page markers. Not the best use of my time, and I could never get those strips the same size consistently anyway.But no more! I now have these wonderful COLORFUL Post-It Page Markers that were made especially for the job. No more wasting a big Note for a small job. No more sitting and cutting strips. These are ready to go, as is. 3M was also thoughtful enough to make the sticky portion of each strip a little bit wider than on a regular Note, so the strip will be held securely to the page position where it is placed.And the best part are the colors. I love the rainbow!Now I can use these Page Markers to color code places in books or reports as to what type of information I'm marking. Think of all the possibilities! For example, when marking recipes in a cookbook you can use one color for main dishes, one for desserts, and another for side dishes. You could highlight technical details or financial ones in a business report based on the specifically referenced item. Or for a knitting pattern book, you could use different colors to indicate whether the marked pattern is for a sweater, accessory, or an item for the home. Or even go deeper into organization and use more colors for whether it's a man or woman's sweater pattern. Not exactly endless possibilities, but with ten colors from which to choose, you can get pretty specific in your categories.These are the best invention since, well, the Post-It Note itself.Recommended.

Young Jess Williams is on the trail again, this time in search of Tim Sloan, his twin brother whom he's never known. Work comes to him that his brother is waiting for him back in Black Creek in order to kill him for a $10,000 bounty placed on his head by a ranch owner who hates Jess for killing his only son.Those who have read the first installment of this series, THE RECKONING: A Jess Williams Western, will be familiar with the story of how a teenager became a bounty hunter and fast drawn artist. Mentioned in that first story was the revelation to Jess that he had a twin brother who was taken from his mother at birth. Most of this book deals with their inevitable meeting.Students of psychology will also know of the on-going argument of nature versus nurture in the development of a person's value system and personality and the debate over which one is more important. This book sides strongly on the nurture side of the argument as the "good" twin, Jess was raised in a loving home with solid traditional values instilled in him while the "bad" twin, Tim, was raised mostly by his mean-spirited, poker cheat, misogynist father who passed all of these negative traits onto his son. The contrasts are not subtle.There is a somewhat humorous subplot involving two nave, would-be bounty hunters from back East whom Jess befriends.While the story is gripping, the book fails in its atrocious formatting and poor copy editing. The formatting is slightly better than that in the first book, but it still needs a lot of work to make it consistent and more readable throughout the book. A copy editor who knows what a past participle is and how to use it properly is also sorely needed. These failings cost the book a star in my rating.I'm hooked on the series and the Jess Williams character now, but I hope that the problems of formatting and editing improve with each new installment.Recommended for those who enjoy gritty Westerns.

Dame Frevisse is a nun at St. Frideswide monastery in the mid-15th century who has an uncanny knack at solving mysteries. Included in this collection of stories featuring Dame Frevisse are "The Witch's Tale," "The Midwife's Tale," and "The Store-Worker's Tale" along with a preview of the full length novel, "The Novice's Tale." All of these stories have appeared in various collections over the years, and may be familiar to readers of the series.The bonus included in this book is "A Guided Tour of St. Frideswide" which is a detailed explanation of the workings of a 15th century monastery or nunnery with specific information about the fictional St. Frideswide and its relationship with the neighboring village. This section is a must-read for all Frevisse fans and newcomers to the series to better understand the medieval world in which the stories are told.The author was somewhat of a scholar of medieval history and that knowledge shows in the detail of 15th century life and times."The Witch's Tale" is the story of a man's murder and the accusation of murder and witchcraft. A village woman with knowledge of herbs is thought to have used her knowledge for a foul purpose. Dame Frevisse knows the woman would do no such thing and uses her wits to find the real culprit."The Midwife's Tale" begins with a death in childbirth, but Dame Frevisse and Dame Claire are called away from that tragedy to the side of a man who has been found unconscious nearby with a broken skull. What at first seems to be a simple accident is soon revealed to be something done deliberately. But by whom and who would profit by the man's demise?"The Stone-Worker's Tale" occurs at a church building site when a talented stone mason hired by Frevisse's cousin Lady Alice has gone missing. When it is discovered that one of Alice's maids has also going missing, Frevisse starts asking questions to find a different and darker motive than young love behind their absences.Highly recommended to those who enjoy cozy mysteries and medieval history. To those already familiar with Dame Frevisse mysteries, the Guided Tour section is a must-have for your collection.

Captain Haven has been invited to visit an old friend at his cottage in the Lake District, and Detective Poiret decides to tag along. When they get to the cottage, Poiret's observations lead him to believe that Haven's friend is acting oddly and that the situation is not quite what they expected.This short story presents a quick mystery that is solved not through forensics or stealth, but through simple observations and conclusions arrived at from those observations, then confirmed by Poiret's questioning of witnesses afterward.Poiret is an odd duck of a detective who always refers to himself in the third person for reasons not explained, except perhaps by less than perfect English skills. It is not explained where he works as a detective, nor is a reason given for his accompanying his friend on this journey for which he seems ill-prepared and uncomfortable. Since this is one of a long series of stories involving the character of Poiret, I would assume that these details are explained in previous installments of his adventures.The writing is a bit archaic and stilted to modern readers, and the story meanders at times and seems overly rushed at others.Mildly recommended as a quick diversion for mystery lovers or those who like to peek in at the lifestyle of an earlier age.

I've got both this small offset spatula and the medium size. When I bought them, I thought I'd be primarily using the medium one for decorating and frosting tasks, but I've actually found more uses for the smaller 4.5 inch one.Not only is this smaller spatula easier to handle when making frosting swirls on cupcakes and along the sides of full sized cakes, it's the perfect tool to use when spreading filling for jelly roll style baked items such as cinnamon buns. I also use it to even up strusel toppings on coffee cakes before baking, lifting brownies out of a baking pan, and spreading fillings between layers of cake batter. The smaller size makes it so much easier to get into the corners of the baking pans.The spatula is sturdy and has a real wood handle. The stainless steel flexible blade means that you won't have to worry about rust or discoloration over time.Well made, affordable, and versatile. Highly recommended.

Like many of us, I grew up with the original Oreo cookies. The addition of multiple versions and flavors to the Oreo line has been a terrific marketing choice by Nabisco.When I saw this Mega Stuf version of the cookies, I was thinking that since I liked Double Stuf Oreos, I'd like these even more. Who wouldn't love more Stuf?But when first taking the cookies out of the bag, they didn't look any different than the ones I'd been buying that were labeled Double Stuf. Mega to me means it should have noticeably more filling than the Double ones. If they do have more, it's such a tiny difference that it's not noticeable.They still taste like Oreos with crisp chocolate cookie layers and creamy filling, so they won't go to waste. They just don't say "Mega" to me.One note about the packaging of the cookies. The pull up and re-seal package makes it harder to get to the cookies on the edges. It's also more difficult to re-seal securely. Why not go to a simpler design of a zip-lock seal on the end of the package? The tray of cookies could slide out to take out what you need, then slide the tray back into the bag and zip it closed.Recommended, but you can get pretty much the same thing with the Double Stuf Oreos that have been available for years.

Times are tough for Bezu Gordon and it's gotten to the point that she's had to take in lodgers to help pay the bills. Things get even tougher when one of those tenants drops dead one night after eating one of Bezu's homemade muffins.I enjoyed the first installment in this cozy mystery series set in Savannah, Georgia, and had been looking forward to revisiting the same characters in another story. While the first book was narrated from the viewpoint of Cat Thompson who did most of the detective work, this book was told from the viewpoint of Bezu.The reader isn't told much about Bezu except that her old, historic house is falling apart, and she has a mountain of debt. How has she found herself in this predicament? Why hasn't she found some paying work in the city? What does she do all day besides sip sweet tea? None of this is explained or even hinted at, which makes it harder to relate to the character. Since Bezu was the focus of the mystery and the narrator of the story, I would have expected to find out much more about her.Another thing missing from the story is the Chubby Chicks Club as they were introduced in the first book. A big factor that made the first book engaging was the close and supportive relationship this group of friends had. One of the members was the victim of the last book, but also missing this time was one of the lead amateur detectives from the first story, Annie Mae. I was expecting another case of the club members rallying together as an ensemble to solve the mystery, yet it came down to just Cat doing the legwork with Bezu as her usually ineffective and bland partner. Policeman José from the Club only pops in to share information when needed to move the story along.Those who have not read the first book in the series, Dying for Dinner Rolls (Cozy Mystery) Book #1 (Chubby Chicks Club Cozy Mystery Series), may be confused by the many references to characters and events that from that book.The mystery itself wasn't much of one. The outcome of the case and the characters' actions were predictable to the point that the big reveal wasn't a surprise since even a moderately observant reader would have seen it coming halfway through the book. There were no red herrings, multiple viable suspects, or misleading clues to distract from the straight line leading to the culprit.Not recommended. Those who prefer a more challenging solve-along mystery will be disappointed at the simplicity of the plot.

If you're the type of baker who is looking for some new ideas of how to dress up your cupcakes for special occasions, this book is for you. Even if you're not into doing any fancy decorating, this book is worth a look just to admire the talent and creativity shown in these uber-fancy cupcake decoration ideas.There are no recipes for cupcakes included. All of these ideas start with plain baked cupcakes or pound cake and go from there.Each design lists clearly the additional ingredients and adornments necessary to recreate the cupcakes shown in the photographs. Some of the most complicated looking designs are really quite easy to do. The instructions are clear and detailed and easy to follow, step-by-step.The designs included are cupcakes that look like mounds of spaghetti and meatballs, sunflower cupcakes, cupcakes that look like lattice-topped pies, fancy high-heeled shoes, and a herd of adorable sheep that use pound cakes rather than cupcakes with mini-marshmallows and other edible embellishments.Recommended.

An apparent terrorist attack on a Florida nuclear electric generator plant is followed up by an attack on a scientist who has found a way to generate electricity from the Gulf Stream. The events draw ex-CIA director Kirk McGarvey into the investigation to find out how the attacks are related and who specifically would most benefit from the shut down of alternative energy sources.For anyone who has been following the fictional career of Kirk McGarvey, this latest installment of his adventures will not be a disappointment. The character seems to have gotten stuck in his mid-fifties, and despite the loss of his family in the previous book, is still at the top of his game. I do wonder though about all of the younger women who seem to find him irresistible.To those readers coming to this book without having read the earlier books in the series, you can still enjoy it as a stand-alone thriller, although the relationships and backgrounds of McGarvey and his CIA computer genius, Otto, would be clearer with the earlier books as a reference point.A clever and ruthless nemesis is introduced in the person of a South African mercenary, Brian DeCamp. After reading many recent thrillers that center around terrorists and religious fanatics, it's refreshing to find a bad guy who is motivated by lots of cash rather than jihad or political radicalism. He's a complex character whose abilities make him a worthy opponent for McGarvey.Recommended.

At the very least I thought that a book claiming to offer "new, unique and original" names for pets would give something more than seemingly endless lists of mostly unpronounceable nonsense syllables.The lists of names are presented with a border of pink or blue so you can tell if they are meant for a female or male pet. Of course, if you are reading the book on an eink reader, you will be unable to distinguish the border or font colors.These "names" offer no origins or meanings of the proposed names. There is not even a guide for pronouncing some of the stranger combinations of letters and syllables. Do these "names" come from any languages, myths, or countries in particular? How does one pronounce "AFYSYA" or "UNSFERE" or "FEGYAL" or "SYNAAL"?Do yourself and your new pet a favor and skip the "names" suggested in this book. If you really are having a difficult time picking a meaningful name for your cat that matches his or her personality, I would recommend looking in a book of baby names (the kind meant for humans) that lists the origin and meanings of each name. The name you choose will have to last your pet a lifetime. Don't hang an unpronounceable "name" of unknown origins on the poor kitty that you both will regret.Not recommended.

I've got several laptop bags around that I've obtained during my career, but I needed a new larger bag for my wide-screen laptop. This bag is wide enough to accommodate my 16+ inch laptop without a struggle to get it in and out of the main compartment. I also borrowed a 17.3 inch wide laptop model to try in the bag which was the size that this bag claims to fit. The larger laptop fits, again with a minimum of maneuvering to slide it into the main compartment.Overall this is a good quality, well constructed bag with sturdy stitching and good padding around both the main laptop section and the outer zippered accessory compartment. The accessory compartment has a zippered area across the width of the pocket to store papers or other thin, flat items, two open slots for pens or pencils, and three open top flat pockets for small accessories such as an iPod cable, cell phone cable, or earbuds.Where most other laptop bags would have a large, unpadded pocket in the main compartment for file folders or papers, this bag has an additional padded pocket to accommodate another device such as a tablet or Kindle ereader. I tried my Kindle Keyboard with and without its case, and it fit just fine. Another item that will fit in this pocket is a USB device such as an external floppy drive, DVD drive, or hard drive.There is even a small outside zippered pocket on the opposite side of the accessory compartment that would be a nice place to park your cell phone or MP3 player. This small pocket is nicely padded too.The handles are padded and comfortable when carrying the loaded bag. A shoulder strap that can be snapped onto the bag is included.So what improvements do I think can be made to this bag?The laptop's AC adapter and cords are easily the bulkiest laptop accessory most people need to carry. The depth of the gusset around the accessory area needs to be increased by about an inch so that the bulk of the adapter and cords can better be accommodated without the lumps and bulges that will, over time, degrade the padding of the zippered outer flap.The other change I would make is to the size of the flat pockets within the accessory area. By changing where the stitching is for each pocket, one pocket could be made large enough to hold a thin DVD/CD jewel case securely. This would make the other two pockets slightly smaller, but still of usable sizes for small items such as charging cords. To make these pockets even more versatile, each one could be made with pleated edges instead of stitched flat against the lining; then they could hold slightly bulkier items such as flash drives instead of being limited to relatively flat items.If I could give a half-star, this bag would receive a 4.5 stars rating. It's a very good bag, just not quite perfect.Recommended for the wider-than-average laptops.

If you only have room on your shelf for one book on cupcake baking, this would book be your best choice. It has all you need to know to get started baking and decorating all sorts of cupcakes for everyday or special occasions. The book is packed with detailed and close-up photographs to illustrate techniques and finished products to serve as inspiration to the home baker.The book takes the reader by the hand and starts out with the basics of needed equipment, items for decorating your baked cupcakes, and how best to store or freeze various types of frosted and unfrosted cupcakes.One feature that many of these recipes share is the option to make from scratch or to start with a boxed cake mix. For those pressed for time, this can be an important bonus feature.There are many options and types of frostings to be mixed-and-matched with the various cupcake flavors. Nutritional information is listed for both cupcakes and frostings, each given separately so whatever combination of flavors you come up with can be calculated easily, if needed.Most of the recipes for cupcakes make 24 standard sized cupcakes. Unfortunately many of these recipes call for an odd number of eggs or egg whites which makes halving the recipes a bit more tricky if you only want to bake a dozen. Hint: If you need to halve a recipe calling for three eggs, the most accurate way to solve the problem would be to use a kitchen scale to weigh the beaten eggs on a scale, then use only half of the weight for your current recipe, then save the other half of the beaten eggs for another use. Perhaps for an omelet for lunch?What types of cupcake flavors are there? To list a few: the standard white, yellow, and chocolate, Lemon, Orange Soda, Chocolate Whoopie Pie, Dried Cherry and Pistachio, Malted Milk Ball, Gingerbread, Double Coconut, and Strawberry Colada.And what flavors of frostings? A few to get your mouth watering: Chocolate Cream, Vanilla Buttercream, Orange Buttercream, Peanut Butter Buttercream, Cherry Nut, Maple Nut, Fluffy Butterscotch, Fluffy Peppermint, Cream Cheese, and Browned-Butter Buttercream.Roughly half the book is given over to ways to decorate your cupcakes you've created using recipes from the first half of the book. Decorating ideas range from the simple swirled frosting with sprinkles to more complex creations such as Chocolate Moose Cupcakes with pretzels for the antlers, an array of Princess cupcakes including one with a frog, several ideas for Halloween, an Easter Basket complete with tiny eggs and a bunny, and a stacked double-decker Fireworks Tower that uses both a regular sized cupcake with a mini cupcake to create a fountain effect for the frosting and decorations. My personal favorite decoration idea is the Cupcake Slider that has been dressed up to look like a small cheeseburger complete with faux lettuce and ketchup.Highly recommended.

For anyone starting out in home baking or wanting to increase their confidence in their skills, this book starts out by explaining the basics of equipment, tools, and ingredients before getting into a discussion of techniques. The emphasis is on "how to" and "with what" to give the reader a good understanding of terms used in cooking and baking.This book is one of a series of First Timer's guides for various baking techniques. Each of them follow the same pattern of instruction. In fact, each of the books are basically the same only differing in the chapter containing the few recipes for the type of baking mentioned in the title.The list of tools and equipment may overwhelm a true beginner starting with an empty kitchen, but a bit of common sense (and perhaps a visit to your local thrift store) can cut this list down to a manageable size. Hint: One item I did not notice on the list, which I consider important to have when making biscuits or pie crusts, is a pastry cutter to cut the butter or shortening into the flour. In a pinch a pair of table knives held parallel to each other can be used as a substitute, but can be awkward to use. A pastry cutter is so much easier to use and is an inexpensive, low-tech item to add to your tool drawer. Not to mention less messy than using the "rubbing" method mentioned in this book.Ingredients are covered from eggs to types of flour to leavening agents and more. Substitutions are suggested for some of the items in case your pantry is missing an item for a recipe. Simple recipes for creating your own sour cream, caramel (which for some reason the author calls "carmel"), and corn syrup are given, but I have not tried them and would wonder about the changes in taste and texture the homemade substitutions might make if used in a recipe.Techniques in mixing ingredients are covered briefly as is the why or science of how baking works.Recipes are given for Lemon Blueberry Muffins, a batter for pancakes or waffles, Zucchini Bread, and very rich, buttery biscuits. At the end of the book there are also a few topping recipes: whipped cream, lemon glaze, cinnamon sugar, and strusel.The remainder of the book contains information adjusting a recipe for high altitude and how to make adjustments to recipes for which you wish to halve or double the yields. There is an example of how to use baker's percentage based on weight instead of volume measurements (cups and teaspoons) as most home cooks use. The biscuit recipe listed earlier in the book is used as the example recipe given in baker's percentages with the arithmetic on how to transform this into a recipe that uses weight. This conversion can be confusing to even experienced bakers, so have your calculator and scales ready if you want to give the more professional method a try instead.Anyone looking for recipe cookbook rather than an instructional manual on baking basics should look elsewhere, but if you're just learning or trying to improve your existing skills, this would be a good place to start.Recommended for beginners and intermediate bakers looking for an instructional guide.

Teenager Jess Williams returns to his parents' farm to find his family all brutally murdered. He knows the men who did it were the ones he had passed on the road to town, and swears that he will find them and avenge these deaths.From the brief description, the story sounds like so many others of revenge that have been told down the centuries, but what sells this Westernized version of the story is the main character. The youthful gunslinger is the key, like a John Wayne in training with a bit of Robin Hood thrown in as he tracks his family's murderers while finding plenty of other villains worth teaching a lesson along the way. He's a new old-time hero to follow as he journeys across the country on his mission of retribution.The bookends to the story that set up the provenance of the six shooter that Jess finds are Twilight Zone quality fantasy and can be ignored by the purists, but luckily the bulk of the book is just good rip-roaring Western justice.The mechanics of telling the tale are somewhat awkward when it comes to some of the dialog and punctuation, but since this is the first in a long series of books, hopefully these kinks will be worked out and in future installments. That's all that's keeping this one from earning that fifth star.Recommended.

Standard procedure requires that a courtesy phone call be made to inform a police officer when a prisoner he helped to arrest and convict is scheduled to be released from prison. Alex McKnight receives one of these calls from the Detroit PD telling him that Darryl King, a suspect he had arrested on one of his last cases, is being released. The news brings back a flood of memories, all bad, which prompts Alex to drive down to Detroit to try to put some of those memories to rest, but in doing so ends up with a new set of questions instead of closure.I've been hooked on this series since the first novels and usually prefer the stories that take place in the Upper Peninsula and surrounding areas. This book takes place on the Lower Peninsula, but offers an exciting and challenging mystery with enough twists and turns to make up for the change of venue.The story does an excellent job of pulling in the background that we have learned throughout the series about Alex McKnight and his character's sense of justice, and then using it to build a mission for him to find the truth behind what was supposed to have been a closed case.Aside from the mystery the important supporting character in the story is the City of Detroit, both before and after the economic collapse. I remember attending hockey games at the Olympia and driving by the old Tiger Stadium decades ago, and the references to those places brought back memories of good times. The sections that describe what these areas of the city have become make me glad that I haven't been back to ruin those good memories. For those not familiar with Detroit, these contrasts of before-and-after will be a revelation of just how far the city has fallen onto hard times.Read it for the mystery to solve, but also to understand better the disaster that has occurred to what was once one of the country's leading cities.Recommended.

Most of us are use to having all of the modern conveniences in our kitchens, all powered by electricity. But what happens when the power fails?This book attempts to make some suggestions on how to add low tech, non-electric features to your kitchen just for such a power outage. It starts out with the basics such as having a good set of knives to replace your food processor and a manual can opener to use instead of the electric kind. But after a few common sense basics, the book loses its way after only a few pages.Telling the reader not to open the refrigerator or freezer during a power outage is more common sense advice, but no alternatives are suggested beyond recommending that you cook whatever is in there before it goes bad. And how are you supposed to cook them if the power is out and you've got an electric stove? According to the author, one option is an alcohol burner such as you might use with a fondue pot. Other suggestions include an outdoor wood fire or barbecue grill which must be used outside in a well ventilated area. That simply isn't a practical solution for most homes, especially if the cause of the power outage is a hurricane or ice storm, and it is certainly not practical for the quantity of food in most refrigerators and freezers. Even if you were to be able to cook that amount, how do you keep it from spoiling once cooked if there is no refrigeration available? The book offers no advice for that.The last portions of the book include a recipe book for soups and stews to "cook in a crisis." Over the wood fire, the reader must assume. Information is also included about dehydrating food for long-term storage, but the methods discussed all require a stove or appliance that require power.Not recommended.

Who could resist a sweet, purring bundle of fur?The people who wrote the anecdotes included in this collection certainly couldn't resist them. These stories explain what the rescue and adoption of their pet has meant to them, and how their lives have been enriched by the inclusion of that little bundle of love and companionship.The photographs of the pets included with most of the stories serve to personalize each tale as you read about the cats' stories of how they came to be rescued and loved.Just be careful. These stories may be the encouragement you need to go adopt a rescue cat and add some extra special love and joy to your home while saving the life of a cat in need.Recommended for all animal lovers.

The Victorian era brings to mind honor, duty, and a steadfastness of character that is often called stuffy by those of later decades. The credit for this image should go not to Victoria herself, but to her consort, Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. This book describes Albert's extraordinary intelligence and sense of duty and how those qualities were nurtured and trained by mentors and tutors for his future role as husband and advisor to the ruler of the world's most powerful empire.The author had unique access to letters written by the Prince Consort to his older brother, the Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha and was able to interview three of the surviving children of Victoria and Albert in their later years all of which lends additional insight into the Prince Consort's character and motivations.The book covers the path that Victoria took to the throne, the manipulations those around her attempted to gain influence over the future queen, and the plans for her eventual marriage to her cousin, Albert. The pairing of the inexperienced and only partially educated queen with the intellectually curious, dutiful Albert was one that allowed the British Empire to thrive under his wise guidance and advice. His sponsorship of the Great Exhibition, patronage of artists and museums, restructuring of the military, and interest in the sciences all added to the growing legacy that would become the Victorian Era.The one area that I wish the book had covered more in-depth was the relationship the Prince Consort had with his children. There were nine children, but except for the Prince of Wales; Victoria, the Princess Royal; and Prince Alfred who later inherited the dukedom of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, there is barely a mention of the other children beyond noting each birth. Was the Prince Consort aware of the of hemophilia in the royal family that would be passed on through his children to royal families across Europe? The condition or his lack of awareness is never mentioned in this book.In all, this is a solid biography of Prince Albert's accomplishments that will give the reader a better understanding of just who was the driving force behind much of what was achieved in the British Empire during the Prince's marriage, and an inkling of how much different that era would have been without a man such as he filling the role as consort and advisor to the woman who ruled the most powerful empire in the world.Recommended.

Betsy Devonshire finds herself in the middle of another murder investigation when a body is found floating in the swimming pool facility she has been attending for water aerobics classes. How could a murderer access the locked building and pool? When one of her regular Crewel World customers begs her to help solve the puzzle, Betsy agrees to investigate.This mystery was a nice twist on the classic locked room mysteries. The clues are presented in such a way that the reader can solve the mystery along with Betsy, which is a feature I prefer to have in cozy mystery novels.The supporting characters who are regulars in this series are all present in this installment. Godwin, Jill, and the Monday Bunch members are all included, which is one of the things I enjoy most in these books. The supporting characters are like old friends from book to book and seem to grow as their lives move along with the years rather than remaining static and unchanging.That's not to say that this book cannot be read as a stand-alone mystery. It will be more enjoyable to those who already know the characters from previous books in the series, but the mystery itself does not suffer from not knowing these characters' backstories.Recommended as an enjoyable puzzle in an entertaining package.

Oh my! There goes the diet.For anyone who has wanted to try their hand at making their own truffles, this book offers some very good advice and instructions on how to best approach the project. It has suggestions on the best technique for forming the candies, melting the chocolate, and which ingredients make the best truffles. The instructions for each recipe are written in a clear and easily understandable style.This recipes include a nice combination of familiar truffles such as Dark Chocolate, White Chocolate Almond, and Parisian Chocolate Truffles, and a number of unusual flavors such as Chocolate Vegetarian Pumpkin, White Chocolate Apricot Hazelnut, and Strawberry Truffles.Several of the recipes feature liqueurs as flavorings for the truffles. For some reason the author placed photographs of liqueur bottles and product packages among the recipes where photographs of the actual truffles would have been more useful. At times the oddly-placed bottle photographs disrupt the flow of the recipe, so I hope in the next revision of the book, these might be removed to improve the readability of the text. The photographs are a nuisance rather than a deal-breaker.Recommended for non-dieters and chocolate lovers.

Warner Brothers Studios produced a string of cookie-cutter popular detective series back in the late 1950s and into the 1960s that mainly differed in the locale of each show. One of these was "Hawaiian Eye," set in Honolulu, but filmed in California. WB's musical director, Warren Barker, was in charge of music for most of their television shows, including this one.The show featured a hotel lounge, The Shell Bar, as a device to include a bit of music in between the detecting. These segments usually featured Connie Stevens and occasionally Poncie Ponce who both had regular co-starring roles in the series. Both performers have a track on this CD. Miss Stevens' does a sweet, light version of Cole Porter's classic "Let's Do It." Poncie Ponce does a very nice "When My Dream Boat Comes Home" complete with ukulele.The one sore thumb on the CD is the track "You're Getting to Be a Habit with Me" sung by series star Robert Conrad. He tries very hard, but his voice is better suited to a shower stall or at-home parties, especially when compared with the much more musically talented Mr. Ponce's contribution to the CD.The rest of the CD is taken up with two versions of the show's theme song and a sampler of some incidental music used in the show.The liner notes are extremely sparse, only one page of general background about the show and the music. I would have liked to have seen more information included in these notes and perhaps a few photographs of the stars.Recommended only for those who were fans of the show looking for some memories.

Kimmy and her best friend Jess suddenly find themselves homeless just days before Christmas. With some fast talk and quick thinking, they land themselves jobs as house sitters in the upper crust part of town. It's a dream come true for Kimmy who dotes on celebrities and fancy cooking. But the ideal surroundings are marred by what seems to be a malevolent spirit determined to get them out of the house as soon as possible.This was a fun story based around very likable characters, although I must admit that Kimmy's addition to the pop celebrity world at times wore a bit thin. Most of those references flew right over my head, since they were UK-centric as was much of the slang which I could not parse into any form of English with which I'm familiar.What seems to be a light-hearted holiday story actually has several layers besides the two almost-homeless young ladies and their initial troubles.There is an element of romance as Kimmy pines at first for her boyfriend Adam who had asked her to leave their apartment because she wouldn't settle down into his idea of a stable future, then later as she is attracted to Luke, the handyman for the house they are minding. But there is a deeper meaning behind these attractions as Kimmy starts to realize as it dawns on her that one expects her to put aside her dreams and ambitions for a more practical life while the other is urging her to use her talents to pursue her dreams of success.Another layer of the story deals with Kimmy's celebrity worship as she sees first hand what celebrities have to deal with on a day-to-day basis. The paparazzi, the malicious gossip, and the less than perfect lives they really live come home to her as she befriends a neighbor in the upscale development.Wrap all of these elements up in a bit of a mystery of the apparent hauntings, inventive cupcake flavors, and a bevy of unique and sympathetic characters, and you've got a very engaging story for a cold winter's evening.Recommended.

Lt. Dekker and Sgt. Murdock are again called out of their semi-retirement when a woman is found dead in her full-service apartment. Several factors are causing problems with the investigation because of the locked apartment door, the timing of meals, and the apparent time of death. Dekker and Murdock leave no mound of gravy un-turned as they search for the answers.I find this Dekker-Murdock series of cozy mysteries to be very frustrating. The quality of the mystery in each book varies so greatly from book to book I'm never sure what I'll be getting each time I start to read one. This one falls into the disappointing category with the emphasis on the running jokes of Dekker's immense appetite and Murdock's relationship with his Wii Fit rather than weaving a tight mystery.I also found the motive for the murder rather thin and unconvincing, and some of the actions of the murderer were confusing and not well explained at the time of the big reveal.I'll keep reading the books in this series as I come upon them since some are very well told with solid, solvable murder mysteries plus a touch of humor, and I enjoy the cast of characters. I wouldn't want to take the chance of missing one of the real winners just to avoid a possible disappointment from one of the lesser mysteries.Recommended only for fans of the series in order to keep up with the characters.

Thanksgiving is coming and the whole Curtis family is expected at grandmother's house for the usual big feast, no excuses allowed. Six year old Davey is already making plans for his own special form of fun, especially that part of the fun that involves Grandmother's dog, Treasure. When the dog ends up missing and the creature on the platter doesn't look like a turkey, the question quickly becomes "who killed the dog."Anyone who has been forced to attend boring family holiday gatherings will enjoy this short story. It's got a strong, demanding matriarch, an Uncle Elvis, "children, grand-children, and associated hangers-on" all with plenty of quirks that will probably remind the reader of some of his or her own relatives and why those family gatherings can be a chore to be avoided whenever possible. Add in the mystery of the odd main course, a missing Treasure, and the mischievous Davey and you've got a very entertaining story.Recommended.

A young woman pulls a daredevil stunt by jumping off the tallest mountain peak in South America. Fitted out in a special suit and vaguely heart-shaped parachute, she rides the wind currents for a wild and dangerous ride.Even putting aside the technical problems behind a stunt such as described in this short story, there still wasn't much here that made sense. Important details such as the "why" of the stunt were missing. Just as a lark perhaps? There really wasn't much to the story, and whatever point the author was trying to make with it, if any, wasn't clear.It only takes a few minutes to read, but gives the reader little reward for the time invested. It leaves most questions a reader is likely to have unanswered, and thus leaves the reader less than satisfied with what was offered.Not recommended.

This add-on to the 6 cup Aroma rice cooker makes it easy and efficient to cook vegetables with the same appliance as the rice, saving both energy and clean up time.Before I purchased the rice cooker and this steamer insert, I'd have to use two burners on my stove to cook my rice and steam my vegetables for a meal. It also meant that there were two pots to clean as well. With this steamer, I can have my rice cooking in the bottom portion of the appliance and then add my vegetables to this steamer tray freeing up my stove top and using only one plug-in appliance's worth of electricity instead and smaller items to be washed up after it's finished.As a bonus, using this steamer tray on the rice cooker even when not using it for cooking additional items will keep the Mt. Vesuvius effect of the rice cooker to a minimum. Since there is a "buffer zone" of a couple of inches of head space provided by the steamer tray between the cooking rice and the lid, less spraying, steamy water is ejected from the rice cooker. Less spray, less clean up around the cooker. Even if you don't need this steamer tray for its designed purpose of steaming foods, it's worth buying just to keep the rice cooker from spitting up all over your clean counter top.The handles are attached to the steamer tray with screws rather than the cheaper method of spot welding that can loosen or be broken off over time. The use of screws means that if the handles become loose, they can easily be tightened back up. It also means that for cleaning if necessary, the handles can be removed entirely, the unit cleaned, then the handles re-attached.Recommended.

The role of an enforcer in hockey is to protect his more skilled teammates from getting injured. The role of an enforcer in a criminal organization is to keep the other mob members and customers of the criminals in line, often resorting to brutal force when necessary. Connor Dunsmore finds himself filling both roles when he signs on to play hockey in a very minor professional league when the owner of his team hires him to do extra work outside the rink. Connor soon finds himself in a deep hole which may well end up being his grave.I picked up this book because I'm a big hockey fan. It doesn't matter what level or league, I'll watch it whenever I have a chance. It's a good thing I'm also a big fan of hard-boiled thrillers, because that is what this book is, in spades.Connor is given a backstory of having suffered a near-death on-ice injury just before his draft year which ruined his chances to become a star in the NHL. This accident and the other player involved in it is woven into the book through recurring nightmares that join with the horrors he has seen occur during his sideline job with the mob. The spiral downward into the more grisly aspects of mob assignments pulls at Connor more deeply as the nightmares become more intense, yet the character still comes across as a good guy the reader can sympathize with as he becomes entrapped by the evil of his boss, Mr. Ojacarcu.Other notable characters are Connor's girlfriend Dana, his rescue project Jera, and his sometimes friend, sometimes antagonist Petre. Lurking in the darkest of places is the evil character Dracul who probably even frightened his mother when he was born, and the head of the local mob, Mr. Ojacarcu, each with their own unique backstories in Romania.This is not for the weak of stomach or the easily offended by rough language and situations. It's tough and hard-nosed, but the payoff is a terrific story.Recommended.

First, I should admit that I had never heard of Marcella Hazan before I picked up this book to read. I'm not a fan of Italian food and had no idea who she was or why she might be enough of a celebrity to be writing a book about her life.I was drawn into the book by the descriptions of Marcella's life in Italy before, during, and directly after World War II. There are many memoirs about the Blitz in England and similar stories of life during the war that are based in various areas of the rest of Europe, but I had never read any about rural Italy and how the people coped during the war, so this was a very welcome surprise.The rest of the book traces how once married and settled into domestic life, Marcella had to learn to cook based on her memories of the foods she enjoyed growing up. I found it fascinating that she had not learned to cook as a child and it was only upon becoming a homemaker she finally began to learn to apply these memories into practical recipes and meals. Even more fascinating was how this grew by chance into a teaching and cookbook writing career. It's a riff on the "immigrant makes good" stories we've all heard.No, there are no recipes included in the book, but there are many photographs from a life well lived that range from small town Italy to world travels to celebrities who have attended Marcella's cooking classes.Recommended.

Attorney Don Tremain has just left one corporate job to join another, newer corporation, Caldera Geothermal, that specializes in alternative energy sources. He's hoping that this new gig will be just what he needs to revive his career path that had stalled out at his old job. What he doesn't realize is that his new company has become the target of a group of unscrupulous vulture investors who have begun a systematic approach to ruining Caldera by using any and all methods necessary, including bribery, insider trading, and even murder.This book was an education in the legal ins-and-outs of the corporate world and bankruptcy as well as a high-powered thriller with a lot of action. I can easily picture this on the big screen with all of the dirty tricks, car chases, corporate moles, and an assortment of suave and sleazy bad guys. No doubt the movie version would leave out the educational legalistic portions of the story, but those are the backbone of the plot and need to be there in order to make some sense of what's happening to Caldera. It does make for some heavy sledding at times, but it's worth the trouble to understand how the system can be gamed to the benefit of the unscrupulous.The main character, Don, often seems to be the only one with any integrity or loyalty as he becomes buried under the work load of trying to keep his corporation afloat. He's one worth cheering for.Recommended.

A young woman's body has been found in an isolated cave, but rather than calling the police, the leaders of the community call in a medical student, Jacob Christianson, they feel they can trust to determine the cause of her death. This is a closed community populated by a splinter sect of polygamists who prefer to keep the authorities out of their business. But what if this trusted investigator determines that the cause of death was murder? Will the elders cover up the crime or allow justice to be served?The murder mystery is a gritty, hard boiled one as is the ensuing search for the truth behind the reasons for the crime and the perpetrator. I really liked the character of Jacob with his calm demeanor and willingness to question those in authority in the community despite his age and lack of official standing. His sister Eliza was also a character who the reader gets to know and care about as she acts as her brother's eyes and ears within the women's sections of the farms and residences.This book contains a lot of disturbing material. Not only are the details of the crime grizzly and horrifying, the settings and attitudes in the polygamist communities are difficult to digest. The idea of women being treated as possessions and regarded as breeding stock in the 21st Century United States and Canada is repugnant to me and was disturbing to read about even in fiction that is loosely based on some isolated realities. There is also a lot of information not usually available to non-Mormons about the details of temple rituals, many of which seemed somewhat reminiscent of Masonic rites and mysteries to me.All in all, the mystery and Jacob's relentless investigation that sold this book for me. The unfamiliar surroundings and details about the polygamist towns gave it an almost voyeuristic feel and made for some of the twists of the plot that made the last half of the book a real page turner.Recommended, but would not be suitable for those who have a weak stomach or who cannot handle the polygamist angles of the plot.

This book would be of no use at all to a beginner wanting to learn how to knit. It is not "easy," "complete," or a "Guide To Creating Amazing Patterns" as the subtitles claim. It accomplishes none of these claims. Anyone trying to use this book as their only method of learning the processes of knitting would find the lack of detail and clarity in the text frustrating.There are no diagrams, illustrations, or photographs to demonstrate any of the necessary techniques to cast on, knit, purl, or cast off.
