One could argue that both Gounod’s First, and Bizet’s C Major, along with their Viennese forebears, helped to influence Sergei Prokofiev in the composition of his own Classical Symphony in 1917.Ironically, Gounod’s First Symphony was so well received in its 1855 premiere that he quickly composed his Second Symphony, this time somewhat lengthier than its immediate predecessor with slightly enhanced orchestral forces and in the key of E Flat Major, possibly influenced by both Mozart’s 39th and Beethoven’s Eroica which are in that key (Schubert’s early symphonies also seem to figure into the mix as well).  Again, the symphony, fairly well proportioned and full of wit, was very well received by audiences of its time; but it too has since languished in relative obscurity.The other piece on this 1997 recording by Sir Neville Marriner and his Academy of St. Martin In The Fields is, of course, the Walpurgis Night Ballet Music that is heard in Act 5 of “Faust”, where Mephisto presents the all-too-ambitious Faust with illusions of seductive and mythic beauties.  The ballet suite here climaxes with the rather grisly “Danse de Phryne”, which helped enhance the opera’s reputation, and also for enhancing the reputation of French composers of exploring the macabre in music (e.g. Berlioz’s “Symphonie Fantastique”; Saint-Saens’ “Danse Macabre”).Marriner and the orchestra he had founded in 1959 give exceptionally superb performances of the two still relatively unknown symphonies of Gounod’s; and the performance of the Faust Ballet music is as good as one can get in a modern context (though Paul Paray’s brilliant 1962 recording of it with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, on a Mercury Living Presence CD of French opera excerpts, also includes the famous waltz of the opera’s second act).  Gounod should be much better known in recordings and in concert halls than he is; and hopefully Marriner and the ASMF have helped make his resurrection in the public music sphere just a little more possible.

Given how much early on in his life he labored under the shadow of Beethoven, it is a wonder that Johannes Brahms was even able to get to finish his First Symphony, let alone compose three more.  But this is what he managed to do, combining the structural form of Beethoven, and the lyricism inherent in Mozart and Schubert, to produce four masterpieces in the form.  The last of them, along with his two concert overtures, is featured on this CD that is taken from recordings made by Leonard Bernstein and his New York Philharmonic in the early 1960s.The Fourth Symphony, in E Minor, is a very solemn-sounding affair from the get-go, its opening measures suggesting the autumn of Brahms’ years, while the work’s Andante movement (in E Major) suggests an inner strength through peace.  The third movement has some of Brahms’ largest orchestration, with tubas, trombones, and a triangle in evidence, and is the only official full-blown symphonic scherzo he ever wrote (he had avoided writing at this tempo in part because the symphonic scherzos of Beethoven so overpowered him), while the final movement is in the form of a Passacaglia, but also returning at times to the waltz-like tempo that occurs at the opening.  Part of this tempo may have had a fair amount to do with the friendship he shared with the Vienna waltz king Johann Strauss II.The two concert overtures, both from 1881, don’t necessarily sound like they could have been written by the same composer.  “One laughs, the other weeps”, Brahms was noted to have said.  The Academic Festival Overture, which begins in C Minor but ends in C Major, was a work that the composer dedicated to Breslau University, which had recently bequeathed him the title of Doctor of Philosophy; it has the largest orchestra of any of his major orchestral works, including not only a triangle but crashing cymbals as well.  The Tragic Overture is an entirely different work—a turbulent work in D Minor, the same key as his First Piano Concerto and the Beethoven Ninth, rife with tensions, and climaxing with an overwhelming sense of darkness that tended to inform Brahms even before this, if only in small parts.All three works were given very solid performances by Bernstein and the New York Phil, and there seems not to have been any age put on them, despite the fact that they were recorded over half a century ago (the Fourth on October 9, 1962; the Academic Festival Overture on October 7, 1963; and the Tragic Overture on May 1, 1964).  As such, this CD (the 21st of the 100 in CBS/Sony’s Leonard Bernstein Royal Edition) is highly recommended, and should be sought out for the solid renderings of these late 19th century warhorses contained within.

In today’s corporate-run radio world, especially when it comes to country music, it isn’t too surprising that a Canadian singer with a Hispanic surname like Lindi Ortega isn’t a bigger star.But that doesn’t mean it isn’t a travesty, because it is—a HUGE one.  With the exceptions of Carrie Underwood and Miranda Lambert, country music has thrown a lot of potentially great women under their Silver Eagle bus in favor of the grotesque junk called “Bro Country”; and Lindi, no matter how “indie” she is or how “retro” she looks, is one of them.  Although she has been around since 2002, I have only heard about her recently.  But now, with her new album FADED GLORYVILLE, I wish her all the best.  This is shaping up to be among the best albums of 2015.Lindi’s quirky style, though rooted in authentic country and R&B styles, also runs the gamut, from classic Elvis and Johnny Cash to the Bakersfield sound of the 1960s, the 1980s “cow punk” of Maria McKee and her band Lone Justice, and even the classic country-rock of Linda Ronstadt.  Wisely, though, she incorporates those styles very fluidly without ever sounding deliberately imitative of her predecessors.  There’s a lot of genuine spunk in her voice on songs like the classically rockabilly track “Run Amuck”, as well as “Run Down Neighborhood”, and more traditional 1960s honky-tonk twang on the almost autobiographical title track, and the quirky “I Ain’t The Girl” (in our current context, it can be easily interpreted as a riposte to those faux-country “Bro Country” boys like Florida-Georgia Line, Jason Aldean, or Luke Bryan).  Lindi also does an R&B-flavored version, inspired by Nina Simone’s rendition, of the Bee Gees’ classic 1967 hit “To Love Somebody” (which they supposedly wrote for Otis Redding [sadly, he didn’t live long enough to record it]), and does justice to it.  And a little bit of Linda’s influence rubs off on Lindi (subliminally) on songs like “Half Moon” and “When You Ain’t Home” (which has some of the influence of Linda’s 1976 version of “That’ll Be The Day”).Much like some of my recent favorite female artists (Tift Merritt; Caitlin Rose), Lindi is someone who deserves to be taken seriously because of her very studious ability to channel her many influences into something truly authentically her.  If that kind of authenticity is passed over by a country radio format soaked in frat-party anthems and booze, then it’s country radio’s fault AND its loss, and not Lindi’s.  Fans of country and roots-rock that’s both traditional and progressive should get this album post-haste!

Her millions of fans, and the generations of female peers in the music business who have been influenced by her, were heartbroken in August 2013 when Linda Ronstadt announced that her voice had been forever silenced by Parkinson’s Disease.  The loss of Linda’s great voice, in an era where people take great singers for granted now and where Autotune and other studio gimmicks are accepted as givens, was enormous.  And yet, the Arizona-born songstress left a body of work, t he diversity of which is unlikely to ever be heard of again.  It is a body of work that encompasses a staggering amount of genres: pop; rock; R&B; blues; country; jazz; opera; Mexican rancheras (which she grew up extensively on as a youngster); gospel; folk; and bluegrass.Absent any hidden material in the vaults, compilations are likely the only way anyone is going to be able to hear Linda now.  But the latest one, JUST ONE LOOK: CLASSIC LINDA RONSTADT, is a big 2-CD collection consisting of thirty of Linda’s greatest vocal performances, many of them hits, and others very classic album cuts, spanning from her start in the Stone Poneys with the folk-rock classic “Different Drum” in 1967 through to the album tracks on her tragically underappreciated 1993 album WINTER LIGHT.  All of these have been re-mastered in a way that still keeps the focus on her incredibly wide-ranging voice, whose range went from alto to soprano, even to coloratura soprano for her journeys into classical opera in the 1980s.  Inevitably, people will comment (rightly, I think) on the absence of such unquestioned classics as “Long Long Time” (her second hit, from 1970), or tracks from her albums of American standards and Spanish-language projects; and one hopes those will be re-mastered at some point in the future as well.Still, whether one is a die-hard fan or a first-timer, this is a great way to get started into hearing what people growing up between the late 1960s and the early 1990s knew about Linda.  Obvious hits like “You’re No Good”, “Blue Bayou”, “Poor, Poor, Pitiful Me”, and her huge 1989 Grammy-winning duet with Aaron Neville, “Don’t Know Much”, are included in there, but so are some forgotten (at least by the current generation of radio listeners) gems as “Love Has No Pride”, “Crazy” (her torchy take on the immortal 1961 Patsy Cline classic); “Just One Look” (Linda’s 1978 revival of Doris Troy’s 1963 hit that serves as this collection’s title); “Someone To Lay Down Beside Me” (written by her good friend Karla Bonoff); “I Can’t Help It If I’m Still In Love With You” (her big 1974 revival of the Hank Williams classic, featuring her pal Emmylou Harris on harmony vocals); “I Never Will Marry” (the traditional Appalachian folk ballad that has Linda on acoustic guitar, and her other TRIO pal Dolly Parton on harmonies); and her impassioned version of her former backing band the Eagles’ classic “Desperado.”  And there are also her 1980s hits “How Do I Make You?”, “Hurt So Bad” and “Get Closer” that are going criminally neglected on so-called “oldies” radio stations that have gone all-Eighties on us.  And all that is just for starters.It is a shame that up until her Parkinson’s diagnosis, Linda was all but forgotten in the mainstream press; on the same weekend that she announced her diagnosis, it was overshadowed in the media by the overblown focus on Miley Cyrus’ idiotic “twerking” at the VMAs.  And even in the industry, it took the powers-that-be in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame an unconscionably long time to induct her into their “club.”  But this huge 2-CD collection hopefully will remind people of how big a deal she was, from Emmylou, Nicolette Larson, Rosanne Cash and Jennifer Warnes, through to Trisha Yearwood, Martina McBride, Lucinda Williams, and Sheryl Crow, and up to present-day singers like Tift Merritt, Caitlin Rose, and Lindi Ortega.  It will also hopefully remind people of just how much further Taylor Swift still has to go in order to be in Linda’s class as well.Linda Ronstadt is someone deserving of all the accolades she receives, even though she is arguably modest to a fault when talking about it all.  This collection just helps to solidify her stature, which is right up there with Elvis and the Beatles.

Besides a very long stint as the general artistic director of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, as well as a frequent conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra (plus recordings of Schubert’s and Schumann’s symphonies in the late 1960s and early 1970s with the Dresden State Orchestra), the German conductor Wolfgang Sawallisch served a solid ten-year term from 1993 to 2003 (and from 2003 to his passing in 2013 as Conductor Laureate) of the Philadelphia Orchestra, continuing a great tradition handed down from Leopold Stokowski to Eugene Ormandy and Riccardo Muti (and being continued today under the young French-Canadian conductor Yannick Nezet-Seguin).  His impressive recordings of the many tone poems of Richard Strauss with the orchestra for EMI are among the greatest that they’ve ever received.Among these other things, however, he conducted some relatively less-known works of the Austro-German repertoire for the orchestra’s own record label as Conductor Laureate.  This particular live recording, made in 2007 and released in 2010, is just such an example.The disc opens up with a surprisingly lesser known work of Felix Mendelssohn, his “Calm Sea And Prosperous Voyage” concert overture in D Major, which begins serenely on the open sea at sunrise, and then depicts the progress of the wind and sea currents as it guides a ship safely to its port-of-call before it ends as serenely as it started.  The work is inspired by the same two poems by Goethe that inspired a similarly titled cantata of the same name by Beethoven; and Sawallisch and the orchestra handle it with the right pacing and drama.Sawallisch and the orchestra also feature two very prominent overtures for a pair of operas by Carl Maria von Weber that more or less began the genre of the German Romantic opera, those to “Oberon” and the work that is generally regarded as the composer’s masterpiece in the form, “Der Freischutz.”  While I don’t know how many times the Philadelphians had performed these overtures before, if at all (perhaps under Ormandy’s tenure), they do handle them very well under Sawallisch’s concise and dramatic direction, with their fabulous string section very much in evidence.The disc also includes two works by Robert Schumann.  The first of these is the highly dramatic overture for his only opera, “Genoveva”, composed in 1850.  The second of these would be considered an actual symphony save for the fact that it lacks a slow movement, the 1841 Overture, Scherzo, and Finale, in E Minor and E Major.  Sawallisch had recorded this three-movement “mini-symphony” as part of his Schumann symphonic cycle in 1972 for EMI with the Dresden State Orchestra; and he gets impressive results from the Philadelphians as well.Philadelphia and its world-class orchestra were fortunate to have Sawallisch at the helm, extending the tradition of great music-making, from the famous strings to the burnished brass section; and the live performances of works that one doesn’t often hear from American orchestras was proof of how much he valued that tradition.  One should not hesitate to pick this recording up.

It seems like one of the most quixotic pairings of works on a CD—the thoroughly American historical piece that is Aaron Copland’s “Lincoln Portrait” being combined with the toweringly self-autobiographical symphonic tone poem “Ein Heldenleben” (A Hero’s Life) of Richard Strauss.  And yet that’s what London/Decca’s Japanese imports division has done on this particular CD, both featuring the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra under the direction of Zubin Mehta, the conductor that, during his 16-year tenure from 1962 to 1978, elevated this orchestra to the world-class prominence it has held ever since.Lincoln Portrait is fairly self-explanatory, a work for narrator and orchestra whose text takes from the various important speeches in the life of our nation’s 16th president, Abraham Lincoln, including his views on freedom and slavery, and those important words that he said on the battlefield at Gettysburg (“that Government of the people, by the people, and for the people shall not perish from the Earth.”).  Such a great work, though only fifteen minutes in length, requires an orator of considerable stature; and that’s what this recording has in the form of the legendary actor Gregory Peck, who would actually portray Lincoln in the 1982 CBS-TV miniseries “The Blue And The Gray”, and had won an Oscar in 1962 for his role of Atticus Finch in TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD.  This particular recording dates from 1969.The performance here of “Ein Heldenleben” dates from 1966, and illustrates the way Mehta had of integrating the large-scale Romantic Viennese sound of Strauss and his contemporaries into what everyone used to think of as a provincial West Coast orchestra (people tend to forget that the influence was already in many of the orchestra’s musicians, who enjoyed careers in the various film studio orchestras around town).  Mehta and the L.A. Phil managed with this recording to supercede what Fritz Reiner had done with this work with his Chicago Symphony (they’d pull that trick again two years later in 1968 with the composer’s “Also Sprach Zarathustra”, in the immediate aftermath of that work’s opening measures being used in so cagily a cinematic way by director Stanley Kubrick in 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY); the stentorian Strauss brass sound, especially the horn section, is rendered with maximum impact, even after close to half a century.We here in Los Angeles have reason to be proud of the L.A. Phil, but we should also congratulate Mehta’s fine stewardship with the orchestra for having made it into one of the world’s great orchestras.  This pairing of two “heroic” works from two extremely different composers is ironclad proof of this.

It’s hard to think of anything that Meryl Streep hasn’t done in a career that goes all the way back to the 1970s.  But with RICKI AND THE FLASH, we find out something brand new.  She rocks!  Literally!Re-teaming up with SILENCE OF THE LAMBS director Jonathan Demme (the two had worked together on Demme’s 2004 updating of the 1962 Cold War classic THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE, where she played Angela Lansbury’s part), Streep stars as Ricki Randazzo, a wanted-to-be rock and roll star who had one brief moment of success in the 80s, but is now consigned to play out her strings (all six of them) out at the dingy Salt Well club in Tarzana with her band The Flash and her boyfriend (played by Rick Springfield, he of “Jessie’s Girl” fame).  But soon, she has a calling from Indianapolis; the family she left behind to follow her rock and roll dreams is rapidly falling apart, most noticeably in the suicidal tendencies of her daughter Julie (Mamie Gummer, who is Streep’s real-life daughter), and her ex-husband (Kevin Kline, teaming with Streep for only the second time, the first being 1982’s SOPHIE’S CHOICE) trying to hold things together with a new wife (Audra MacDonald).  With real life intruding in, the collision of her love for performing and wanting to set things right with her family, Streep’s character sometimes looks like she’s closer to having a nervous breakdown than even her own daughter.  But with Springfield’s help, she comes to her daughter’s wedding (with the band in tow, unbeknownst to the uptight, upper-crust crowd there who know very little of her past), and manages to redeem herself in a lot of great ways.Streep, who had done music-themed movies before (having done her own singing in 1990’s POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE, and portrayed a music teacher in 1999’s MUSIC OF THE HEART), just doesn’t seem capable of doing any wrong in films, and so it is sometimes quite easy to take her and her generation for granted (though contemporary Hollywood often seems to take that generation for granted way too many times).  Playing Ricki, however, was quite a stretch for her all the same; and she manages to pull it off quite well, doing quite the job of playing acoustic and electric guitars and singing for this role in a way that, dare one say it, could have her in line for yet another Oscar nomination, if not another outright win.  This shouldn’t take away from the other great supporting performances, including Springfield, Kline (whose wryness and off-the-cuff humor are exceptionally refreshing), and MacDonald, let alone Gummer, who has some extremely interesting scenes with her mother (though reportedly they spent very little time together off the set during the making of the film per Demme’s instructions).  Demme’s direction is also quite good (he refrains from doing the straight face-on shots of previous films); and the film features longtime Eagles/Joe Walsh backing musician Joe Vitale as the Flash’s drummer, and a soundtrack that includes a lot of rock classics that Streep sings on her own (quite well, I would add).This is not a typical summer-movie flick with high-octane action (unless one considers Streep’s stage presence an example of an “action” scene); and yet RICKI AND THE FLASH will likely end up being considered one of the best films of 2015.  It’s already one of mine, for sure.

Although he was known for having made a lot of grand statements in the musical language of his native Bohemia, notably in his last four symphonies, and various symphonic tone poems, Antonin Dvorak was also able to think small, as was the case on this 1981 Delos recording by the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra under their then-Music Director Gerard Schwarz.The most popular of these works, and indeed the work that bought Dvorak his first real attention, whether in Bohemia or beyond, is his 1875 “Serenade For Strings”, cast in the most unusual key of E Major and scored strictly for the string section in the manner of Mozart’s celebrated “Eine Kleine Nachtmusik”, but with two middle movements, one of which is a Waltz and the other a Scherzo, that show the effects of the Romantic movement in music that was occurring at the time.The second work on this (surprisingly short, at 40 minutes) CD is “Waldesruhe”, also known as “Silent Woods”, a work that Dvorak originally composed for the piano duet “From The Bohemian Forest”, and then extended out as work for cello and small orchestra.  It differs quite substantially from its gigantic cousin the B Minor Cello Concerto, because of its very pastoral nature, and as such it is not as widely well known.  But after hearing this performance, with the LACO’s principal cellist Douglas Davis in the solo role, you will likely have to wonder why that is.The third and final work here is the “Notturno” in B Major for string orchestra that had originally appeared in his 1870 E Minor String Quartet, but expanded it into string orchestra form.  Although it does bear the effects of some of Wagner’s modernism, it really has more in common with Beethoven’s “Grosse Fugue” and Mozart’s “Adagio And Fugue” than Wagner; and it remains one of Dvorak’s most spiritual pieces.Despite the shortness of this CD, the performances by Davis and his fellow musicians under Schwarz’s direction make this a superlative recording to have, especially for those who want to know if Dvorak could think in smaller but no less compelling musical terms.  He clearly did here.

The first two decades of the 20th century were very active ones for Russia’s leading composers, especially in the area of instrumental concertos.  This was particularly true in the field of the violin concerto, where the true supreme Russian contribution, namely the D Major one of Tchaikovsky, had become an established part of the repertoire by the beginning of the 20th century.Alexander Glazunov’s A Minor violin concerto leads off this particular collection.  Cast in three uninterrupted movements and lasting twenty minutes, it was the first post-Tchaikovsky concerto for that instrument to attain success around the world, and is most likely this composer’s greatest and best-known work.  The lush romanticism of the piece is very evident, giving us a glimpse into what was to come in terms of other Russian violin concertos, including the other one on here.Sergei Prokofiev’s Violin Concerto No. 1, in a traditional D Major key, though it ventures into other keys as well, was one of the many ways back in 1917 that he responded to the criticism that his music was too dissonant and that it had no form.  Save for the orchestration that requires a snare drum and a single tuba, however, this concerto is proportioned more along the lines of the classic lines of concertos from Beethoven and Mendelssohn through Brahms, Tchaikovsky, and Glazunov.  In that same year of 1917, Prokofiev would also go even further back, symphonically speaking, with his ever-popular Classical Symphony (#1), which was an homage to the late 18th century Viennese style of Haydn and Mozart.The other work on this recording is “Stihira”, a large-scale work by the modern-day Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin that the composer described as a “Hymn for the Millennium Of The Christianization Of Russia” (slightly premature as, when this work was premiered in Washington in 1987, Russia was still under the, albeit loosening, yoke of atheistic Communism).  It is scored for a fairly huge orchestra, with four extra groups of percussion players, in a way that would make this piece even rival Tchaikovsky’s famous “1812 Overture.”The great German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is on hand to deliver sterling performances of both of the early 20th century Russian violin concertos in a way that brings out their lush Romanticism and irony; and both of those works, plus “Stihira”, are excellently performed by the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington D.C. and their music director (and legendary cellist) Mstislav Rostropovich, who led the orchestra from 1977 to 1995.  This is a great combination of 20th century Russian works to have in one’s collection, and is thus highly recommended.

Throughout his conducting sojourn, from his early years in Boston, to Buffalo, to being associate conductor of his own hometown Los Angeles Philharmonic, Michael Tilson Thomas has shown an enormous passion for the music of George Gershwin, music that showed the composer to be more than a tunesmith of some of the greatest songs ever written on our shores.  This has held true since having become music director of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra in 1995, succeeding Herbert Blomstedt.  And in 1998, he, the orchestra, and a trio of all stars got together to celebrate what would have been the composer's 100th birthday, a birthday celebration that was wisely captured on this 2-CD collection.For this event, recorded at the orchestra's home Davies Symphony Hall, Thomas assembled a very solid pair of vocal soloists, Audra MacDonald and Brian Stokes Mitchell, to take on the songs featured in the Catfish Row Suite of the composer's landmark opera "Porgy And Bess" (arguably the American equivalent of "The Marriage Of Figaro" and "Carmen" in terms of operas). including "Bess You Is My Woman Now" and "Summertime" (the latter a song that has become an incredibly durable standard, also being a big pop hit in 1966 for Billy Stewart, and even recorded by Janis Joplin).  Thomas then does double duty conducting the S.F.S.O. from the piano in the composer's (surprisingly seldom recorded) 1931 Second Rhapsody, which is frequently known as "Rhapsody In Rivets."  After hearing the performance of this piece, one can only surmise that the overwhelming popularity of the earlier "Rhapsody In Blue" is the one thing that keeps this work from being better known than it is.The second CD on this collection begins with Thomas and the orchestra giving us a spirited version of the composer's "tone poem" "An American In Paris", with its vivid jazz-like phrasings.  Then Thomas retakes the podium to conduct the composer's Piano Concerto In F, leaving the piano solo duties to the marvelous Garrick Ohlsson, who clearly knows his way around the piece, a work that, with so many twists, turns, and piano crescendos, makes it every bit a challenge as the concertos of Rachmaninoff and Ravel.This 2-CD collection is a tremendous way of celebrating a composer who, as much as anyone else, helped define the sound of American music in the 20th century.  Thomas, his orchestra, and his soloists should be congratulated for making this a great birthday present.

If you are a concert pianist worth his or her salt, the twenty-seven piano concertos of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart are essential to your repertoire.  And if you are also a conductor, then Mozart should always be in your repertoire.Such is the case with Andre Previn.  While most remembered for his recordings of 20th century English composers like Walton and Vaughan Williams, plus works by such Russian titans as Prokofiev, Shostakovich, Rachmaninoff, and Tchaikovsky, even Previn, whose career has featured tenures in London, Pittsburgh, and Los Angeles, as well as a very solid composer of film music (BAD DAY AT BLACK ROCK, in 1955), knows that one must tackle the core Viennese repertoire.  This he does on this recording from the mid-1980s, in which he does two of W.A. Mozart’s piano concertos, conducting, from his place at the piano, the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.Though these two concertos are by the same composer, they are also totally different as well.  The 17th concerto, in G Major, which Mozart composed in 1784, is a lightly orchestrated affair; but No. 24, composed less than two years later, is, because of its C Minor key, the darkest and most turbulent work Mozart had composed in the genre (also the only concerto, besides the D Minor 20th, in a minor key), and with the largest orchestration of any of them (sans trombones).  Yet both these concertos would have a profound influence even beyond Mozart’s tragically truncated lifetime, with Beethoven taking inspiration for his C Minor Third Piano Concerto from Mozart's 24th.Previn, known more for his conducting than his piano work (except when going into jazz), nevertheless is able to manage the exceptionally tricky feat of performing these concertos from the keyboard while conducting the frequently-hard-to-please Vienna Philharmonic.  This is a pairing of concertos that is duplicated by Irish pianist John O’Conor and conductor Sir Charles Mackerras (with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra) on Telarc; and the Previn/Vienna version here (originally released on the Philips label) is on a par with the O’Conor/Mackerras/SCO version.  It is highly recommended.

If Leonard Bernstein had an inkling of his own morality as the 1980s came to a close, either he wasn’t yet aware of it or, in concert and on recordings, he was going to give the most of it, no matter how much slower his conducting tempos had become since his golden years of the 1960s.  This seems to have been borne out in his recordings of Tchaikovsky’s final three symphonies that he made with his New York Philharmonic for Deutsche Grammophon.This particular recording pairs the composer’s Fate-orientated Fifth Symphony (in E Minor) with perhaps the most popular of his symphonic tone poems, the Romeo And Juliet Fantasy Overture.  The two overriding Fate themes in the symphony’s opening movement (unsurprisingly extended in length by Bernstein’s arguably hyperemotional approach) are overriding concerns that the composer wrestles with; while the D Major slow movement (though rent with some violent outbursts) is more tranquil and a touch heartbreaking at times.  The third movement, basically a kind of off-kilter waltz in A Major, is one that has led a lot of people to argue that Tchaikovsky’s symphonies are too balletic in nature (and vice-versa for his three ballets, thought by some to bee “too symphonic”).  All the tensions are resolved in a very triumphant finale, in which the two Fate motifs of the first movement are intermingled with vigorous outbursts for a resolution in E Major.  This is also the only major work of Tchaikovsky’s, symphonic or otherwise, following the Third Symphony, to eschew any extra percussion (cymbals; tam-tams), so that it can be argued that it is closer to a more traditional Brahms-type work.  But Lenny and his forces spare nothing else otherwise.Of course, the piece-de-resistance is “Romeo And Juliet”; and as seems to be typical of Tchaikovsky, he deals with tragedy in its purest form in his depiction of Shakespeare’s timeless story of star-crossed lovers belonging to warring families who are only able to bring those sides together by doing themselves in.  From the work’s portentous opening to the fight scenes, the heart-wrenching love theme, and the cataclysmic finale (with rumbling timpani), the work is done exceptionally well by the N.Y.P.O. and its conductor.  It helps that Bernstein knows a thing or two about this work and its origins; after all, he himself, along with Stephen Sondheim, created a Romeo And Juliet-inspired work entitled “West Side Story.”The Fifth Symphony was recorded in November 1988, and Romeo And Juliet recorded in October 1989 (around the same time as Bernstein’s recordings of the composer’s Fourth Symphony and Francesca Da Rimini), both times before live audiences at the orchestra’s home of Avery Fisher Hall (but with the almost undoubtedly vociferous applause left off).  The intensity in Bernstein, even with his advancing age and his slower tempos, never flagged in his final years; and that is borne out in this Tchaikovsky recording, one that should not be missed.

The old saw about Leonard Bernstein is that, from the energetic dynamo that he was during his official term from 1958 to 1971 as music director of the New York Philharmonic, as he got older, his conducting style and tempo got to be more and more eccentric, arguably more over the top, and also arguably far slower, especially towards the end of his life, when the vast majority of his recordings were being done for Deutsche Grammophon.All of those arguments have validity, but they don’t tell the whole story.  In particular, they don’t tell all that much about how Bernstein, the man known for championing composers like his fellow countryman Aaron Copland, and Gustav Mahler, handled the final three symphonies of Russia’s greatest composer Tchaikovsky during the last five years of his life.This particular recording, of the composer’s Fourth Symphony and the nightmarish symphonic fantasy “Francesca Da Rimini” is a case in point.  The opening movement of the F Minor symphony is very elongated (out to just over twenty-one minutes), not to mention emotionally overwhelming, with the typically huge orchestration (floor-rattling timpani and cymbal crashes) the composer is known for; while the slow movement that follows, though far less intense in volume, is about as tragic as any single symphonic movement ever composed by anybody.  The third movement, of course, is primarily a pizzicato string affair (though with some brass underpinnings); while the fourth movement opens with a huge cymbal crash and ends with what seems to be a triumphant finish (though “seems” is the operative word here when we’re dealing with Tchaikovsky).In the meantime, “Francesca Da Rimini”, drawn from the fifth canto of Dante’s Inferno, is probably as close to an approximation of Hell as I think most people want to get; and with orchestration so large it even puts Wagner and Mahler to shame, Tchaikovsky paints a fiery portrait of Francesca and her lover Paolo being stabbed to death by the jealous hunchback Rimini and forced to spin forever in infernal whirlwinds.  For all that people say about Bernstein’s conducting slowing down as he approached his final years, he gets every last ounce of this work in a way almost no other conductor ever could.  This particular performance of “Francesca Da Rimini” is about as extreme a performance as there has ever been of any single work in the history of recorded classical music, bar none.  But an extreme work like “Francesca Da Rimini” requires an extreme performance, and Bernstein delivered it big time.Both these works, recorded live at Avery Fisher Hall (though the applause, which was undoubtedly quite vociferous, was left out) in October 1989, are given enormously powerful interpretations by Bernstein and his former orchestra (in what may have been the very last pairing between them before Bernstein’s death the following year).  This recording is not to be missed.

Disney, with only a handful of notable exceptions, (THE BLACK HOLE; 20,000 LEAGUES UNDER THE SEA, and WALL-E chief among them), has not really gone whole hog into the science fiction genre all that much in its history.  But with the 60th anniversary of the opening of Disneyland in Anaheim (an event that took place in July 1955) in mind, they went ahead and made TOMORROWLAND, a cinematic, special effects-laden expansion of what is perhaps the most popular section of that park.In doing this kind of film, which asks us to imagine and subsequently make a better world out of one that seems rapidly heading towards apocalypse, the film’s director Brad Bird (RATATOUILLE; MISSION IMPOSSIBLE: GHOST PROTOCOL) has taken what must seem like a radical approach for what we normally think of as “Disney fare.”  In it, George Clooney portrays a cynical grumpy inventor whose idea of a jet pack, which he built when he was a kid, bombed at the 1964 Worlds Fair in New York, who encounters an extremely inquisitive and adamantly optimistic teen (Britt Robertson), and subsequently takes her and a robot child named Athena (newcomer Raffey Cassidy) on a journey to change a future that is rapidly going downhill in all the many ways people in the late 20th century had warned about.  The subsequent journey is filled with a lot of peril, some of it fairly hair-raising (even for a ‘PG’-rated Disney film), and a lot of twists, turns, and ponderings of space-time continuum that we saw in the 2014 sci-fi epic INTERSTELLAR, and which would make visionaries like Arthur C. Clarke, Rod Serling, and Ray Bradbury beam with pride in the Great Beyond they occupy.  Hugh Laurie, known for his extremely caustic role on the Fox hit show “House M.D.”, portrays the sinister Nix, who nevertheless gives the admonishment that a bleak future is always preventable…if there were only more young people like Robertson (and her NASA engineer father, played by country music star Tim McGraw) to make it happen.The lengths that this movie goes are so outside of what we think of as traditional Disney convention.  Occasionally, it is a touch preachy, but nevertheless very fantastic, and willing to bend the Disney narrative for the sake of futuristic cinematic storytelling that might otherwise have been left to a Stanley Kubrick or Steven Spielberg.  Bird, who also co-wrote the screenplay with Damon Lindelof (the two also co-authored the story with Jeff Jensen), really does a great deal of mixing science fiction and fantasy with typical Disney charm.  In short, even if TOMORROWLAND is in some ways a plug for its flagship theme park on its 60th anniversary, it doesn’t flag too much during its 130 minute running time.

Without question, Dmitri Shostakovich was one of the pre-eminent composers of the 20th century, often forced to compose works that reflected the dictates of a bunch of tin ears in the Kremlin and the Politburo in his native Soviet Union.  But the man knew his way around musical irony, which is clearly reflected in the fifteen symphonies that he wrote over a period of just slightly under half a century, beginning with his first in 1925.  And while those works were so blatantly misunderstood and misread by the elitists in his own land, they found favor on our side of the Iron Curtain because Shostakovich had conducting friends in high places, especially here in America.This is true of the composer's fifteenth and final symphony, composed in a shockingly short span of time in the summer of 1971.  Typically large in terms of orchestral size, and moderate in terms of length (45-50 minutes), it is a work full of the composer's trademark originality and irony, though it also pays witty homages to some of his own past works, and alludes to such things as Rossini's famous William Tell Overture, and the "Fate" motif of Richard Wagner's famous (or infamous, depending on how one feels about him) Ring cycle.  His own son Maxim gave the work its world premiere recording in early 1972 with the Moscow Radio Symphony Orchestra.But on our shores, the composer entrusted this symphony (and the two that came before it) to one conductor, Eugene Ormandy, and to one orchestra, the Philadelphia Orchestra, to give it its Western premiere.  Ormandy was always an active proponent of Shostakovich's works; and this recording of the 15th Symphony, made in October 1972, is proof of that.  It captures the composer's black wit in a way we'd expect all the great recordings of Shostakovich to do.  The work's greatness shines through, as do Ormandy and the fabulous Philadelphians.While we have had many fine recordings of this very modernistic work since this one (notably Bernard Haitink's 1978 recording with the London Philharmonic), the Ormandy/Philadelphia one is still really the one that sets the standard, and it should be sought after without hesitation.

Michael Crichton, who passed away in the fall of 2008, may not have realized the kind of goldmine he struck when he published his dinosaur novel "Jurassic Park" in 1990; but with director Steven Spielberg's help, that goldmine was open for business with the original 1993 film version, and then with its 1997 sequel THE LOST WORLD.  Due to Spielberg being heavily involved in making A.I.: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE in 2001, the third "Jurassic Park" film was left in the hands of director Joe Johnston, with Spielberg staying on as executive producer.  Incredibly enough, another fourteen years would pass until the move-going public got the fourth in the series, JURASSIC WORLD.Twenty-two years after John Hammond's experiment at producing an innovative theme part with genetically-created dinosaurs on an island some 200 miles off of Costa Rica came crashing down with the dinosaurs consuming several people, now that same island, Isla Nublar, is now home to Jurassic World, a highly innovative theme park with bigger and better dinosaurs, and, hopefully, with greater controls.  One of the workers, an ex-Navy seaman (Chris Pratt), has become especially attuned to a number of the raptors in the park, and has managed to earn their trust.  At the same time, the park's principal supervisor (Bryce Dallas Howard) has been overseeing the creation of a super-dinosaur, made up of the DNA of the previous species of dinosaurs, including velociraptors, and tyrannosaurus rexes, that has guaranteed an up tick in revenue and park attendance.  But as with anything involving the technology used in creating creatures that have been extinct from the Earth's surface for sixty-five million years, soon everything turns upside down.  This doesn't stop the park's main security chief (Vincent D'Onofrio) from seeing a way to use these dinosaurs as a weapon of war, over the vehement objections of both Pratt and Howard, as well as one of the original scientists (B.D. Wong) from the original Jurassic Park.  Upping the ante still further are the fact that Howard's two nephews (Nick Robinson; Ty Simpkins) have come to the island to be with their aunt; instead, they find themselves having to behave like responsible adults in the most horrible way possible when the mayhem created by the "super-dinosaur" allows all the other species out of their enclosures.  When D'Onofrio's megalomaniacal ambitions result in his death, it is up to Pratt and Howard to destroy the super dinosaur with all the weapons at their disposal.As with JURASSIC PARK III, Spielberg's involvement in directing another film (in this case the Cold War II spy thriller BRIDGE OF SPIES) led him to taking the role of executive producer, allowing Colin Treverrow, whose only feature film credit before this was the romantic comedy drama SAFETY NOT GUARANTEED in 2012, to direct it.  With help from co-writers Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver, and Derek Connally, however, Treverrow managed to cobble together elements of the first three films into a coherent, if not necessarily letter-perfect, science fiction/suspense thriller that, in some interesting twists, pays homage not only two its three predecessors, but also to Spielberg's 1975 classic JAWS (as the super-dinosaur eats a Great White shark to the amazement of the 20,000+ people in attendance), and to Alfred Hitchcock's 1963 horror classic THE BIRDS (as the avian dinosaurs attack the park visitors from the air with sometimes bloody results).It is not a mark against either the film or Treverrow to say that the film misses the verve and panache of the first two movies that were directed by Spielberg in masterful fashion, though one sometimes wishes he had concentrated as much on characters as he did on the mayhem.  Nevertheless, Pratt (ZERO DARK THIRTY; GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY) and Howard (LADY IN THE WATER) do really good turns as a pair, despite the rather clichéd bickering they do at the start; and Robinson and Simpkins make for as appealing a pair of kids as Joseph Mazzello and Ariana Richards did in Spielberg's original.  Michael Giacchino's score is impressive as well, and he wisely interpolates John Williams' themes from Spielberg's first two films while also incorporating some of his own ideas.The final verdict when it comes to JURASSIC WORLD is that, despite its tendency to fall into predictability in terms of the dinosaur attacks and some cardboard characters, it is far better than most summer CGI film fare, with enough Spielberg influence to keep it from being just another blockbuster.

It has been known for decades that, of all the major cities in the United States that are vulnerable to massive earthquakes, both Los Angeles and San Francisco rank at the very top. Not only are there many fault lines running underneath each city and its outlying metropolitan areas, but there's also what is arguably the most notorious fault line on the planet, the dreaded San Andreas Fault. Scientists have said that a major quake usually occurs along this fault line every one hundred fifty years; and in the year 2015, that time is severely overdue; and while there have been significant quakes in that period, they've occurred on rift zones other than the 800 mile-long San Andreas, which runs all the way from Eureka southeast to the Mexican border. But in the 2015 sci-fi/disaster opus SAN ANDREAS, California's time has run out.Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson portrays an L.A. Fire Department chopper pilot who is expert at saving people's lives, but who wasn't able to save one of his daughters during a whitewater rafting trip that turned tragic; and soon his life is turned upside down when his wife (Carla Gugino) serves him with divorce papers. In the meantime, over at the seismological lab at Caltech in Pasadena, the school's chief seismologist (Paul Giamatti) has detected ground pulses in southern Nevada, which unfortunately start a chain of horrific ground events, beginning with a massive quake destroying Hoover Dam. Yet this is only the beginning; to him, it indicates a possible chain reaction on the San Andreas Fault Zone on the 400-mile stretch between L.A. and San Francisco. Sure enough, his predictions come true with extreme consequences, as all of California is hit with a swarm of quakes in the 7.5 to 9.5 magnitude range along the infamous fault line, with Los Angeles and its surrounding environs being hit first. Johnson is thus forced into action to rescue Gugino from a crumbling high rise in Downtown Los Angeles; and with the knowledge that his only surviving daughter (Alexandra Daddrio) is up in San Francisco, he and Gugino must outrace the continuous destruction to get her.Without question, like a lot of Hollywood blockbusters that rely so heavily on CGI, SAN ANDREAS suffers at times from plausibility issues, as real-life Caltech seismologists Lucy Jones and Kate Hutton pointed out. There is only minimal scientific evidence that ground pulses of the type mentioned here could trigger seismic events on any other fault lines, let alone a monstrous catastrophe along the San Andreas Rift Zone. Still, in terms of certain important rescue and destruction scenarios, like many older buildings collapsing with nightmarish results, SAN ANDREAS does things right, especially with the presence of Johnson playing an Everyman type of hero.Though it shares its scenario with two other important films of this type (1974's EARTHQUAKE, and the 1990 made-for-TV film THE BIG ONE: THE GREAT LOS ANGELES EARTHQUAKE), SAN ANDREAS also borrows liberally from more recent high-octane sci-fi/disaster films like 1998's DEEP IMPACT, 2004's THE DAY AFTER TOMORROW, and, perhaps most especially, the 2009 end-of-the world spectacle "2012." But while director Brad Peyton is not in the human-interest category of a Steven Spielberg, he is still able to get the best out of his six main cast members, who are not stereotypical cardboard clichés, even with a script and storyline with plausibility problems. Several moments in the film, like the rescue of Daddrio from a San Francisco high rise swamped by the tsunami, are quite frightening. In the end, SAN ANDREAS, whatever gaps there are between illusion and reality, does serve up the goods in true Hollywood fashion. But it also warns that the people in both Los Angeles and San Francisco are at risk from The Big One now more than ever before. For those reasons, I am willing to forgive its occasional "faults" (pardon the pun).

One of the most heavy-duty symphonies in the active concert repertoire, requiring between seventy-five and eighty minutes on the average to perform, the Seventh Symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, known as the "Leningrad", is also one of the darkest and grimmest works in the repertoire, outside of Mahler or Tchaikovsky.  Composed around 1939 and 1940, as the composer's native country was becoming embroiled in World War II, it was a work he had originally dedicated to the first leader of the Soviet Union, Vladimir Lenin; instead, however, he dedicated it to the city of Leningrad (known today, and before the 1917 Communist uprising, as St. Petersburg), which endured a 900 day-long siege in which half a million of its own citizens were killed, some of them in orgies of cannibalism because of extreme starvation.  That horror is reflected in this work, but in the end it was a triumphant work for the composer, even though his conflicts with the tin-eared Stalin and the Soviet state apparatus were even then becoming legendary.From the very start, despite the sentiment it held on either side of the Iron Curtain as a bulwark against Hitler's tyranny (as well as Stalin's, to the ears of the more artistically inclined in the West), its extreme length, irony, and emotionalism have made it a challenging work to program among many orchestras in the West, although impressive recordings abound (Leonard Bernstein's 1962 recording with his New York Philharmonic being one; and Bernard Haitink's 1980 version with the London Philharmonic being another)  And, in one of the final recordings that he made before dying tragically in a plane crash in 1993, the Mexican-born Eduardo Mata made this recording of this gigantic Russian masterwork with the orchestra he had elevated to national prominence beginning in 1977, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra.While many would argue that Mata and his Dallas orchestra bit off far more than they could possibly chew when it came to the Leningrad symphony, in light of the classic recordings that came before, I would argue that this recording, despite some minor flaws, can stand up to close scrutiny.  The performance is naturally quite huge, and proved to be a fitting, albeit a tragic, memoriam to Mata's sixteen years at the helm of the orchestra (he would be succeeded by Andrew Litton, who would carry on the tradition).Sure, it's not quite on par with Lenny's, but the Mata/Dallas Shostakovich 7 still deserves to be considered.

Many composers' works often reflect the music of their own native soil, as with Dvorak's and Smetana's Czech/Bohemian roots, and Vaughan Williams' works influenced by the folk music of his native England.  And that holds true for Jean Sibelius, the greatest composer that the nation of Finland has ever produced.  Besides such hugely popular single-movement orchestral works like "Finlandia" (his nation's anthem in all but actuality), "Valse Triste", and "Tapiola", Sibelius managed to also compose seven austere symphonies that reflect both the wonder and, sometimes, even the icy terror of his native homeland.  It is the first and last of these symphonies that are placed on this recording by the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra and their Conductor Laureate, Herbert Blomstedt.Although the second (in D Major) and fifth (in E Flat Major) are generally considered the most popular and recognized of the seven, that doesn't mean the others are merely chopped liver.  The First Symphony, composed and first heard in 1899, gives one the idea of where Sibelius' creative genius lies, in sizeable orchestral ideas painting his nation's icy beauty, with elements of both Dvorak's New World Symphony and Brahms' 4th (both of which are also in this symphony's home key of E Minor); while the Seventh, composed in 1925 and in C Major, is noted for being a single-movement work encapsulating the normal four-movement symphonic form into an uninterrupted form.  Much of this can be tricky to maneuver through.But much in the way that the late Sir Colin Davis did with the Boston Symphony in the 1970s, and Lorin Maazel with the Pittsburgh Symphony in the late 1980s, Blomstedt and the San Francisco Symphony commit themselves most spectacularly in these works, bringing out their inherent drama and icy beauty without making them sound too cold and grim.  Part of a great Sibelius cycle that Blomstedt and the SFSO did for London/Decca during Blomstedt's decade-long tenure in the Bay Area, this is without question one of the great Sibelius symphony recordings of all times, and is well worth owning.

They are two works that are linked by more than just who composed them: the Choral Fantasy for piano, orchestra, and chorus, composed and first performed in 1808; and the Ninth Symphony, composed between 1817 and 1823, and premiered in May 1824.  The Choral Fantasy begins as a fantastic display of piano virtuosity in the portentous key of C Minor, develops into an elaborate mini piano concerto whose principal melody is vaguely familiar, and then utilizes that orchestral melody for the choral setting of a poem by Christoph Kuffner in the triumphant key of C Major.And of course, not much more need be said of the Ninth Symphony, which for all intents and purposes is probably the most forward-looking of any symphony in the concert repertoire, from its portentous opening measures to its thunderously triumphant finale and the Ode To Joy.Two interconnected works by Beethoven.  But when, and how often, have audiences been able to hear both works side-by-side in the same concert?Fortunately, that managed not only to happen, but the end result was actually recorded, at Avery Fisher Hall on the night of February 2, 1983, when the New York Philharmonic, under their then music director Zubin Mehta, programmed both works, and got some heavy hitters to support.  This 2-record set of the concert (given that the Choral Fantasy usually takes twenty minutes; while the Ninth Symphony is close to 70 minutes in length) features Emanuel Ax, then ascending to becoming one of the great American pianists of modern times, handling Beethoven's challenging keyboard passages in the Fantasy, while Dame Margaret Price, the legendary Marilyn Horne, Jon Vickers and Matti Salminen are the vocal soloists in the Ninth's famous "Ode To Joy".  In both works, the New York Choral Artists are featured, under the direction of Joseph Flumemrfelt (who also was known for leading the Westminster Choir).  And one can't forget Mehta's and the New York Philharmonic's considerable contributions.RCA, which originally released the set back in 1983 (it is now run by Sony), would be well advised to re-release this pairing on a 2-CD set.  All the same, however, the combination is well recorded in this classic vinyl set, and it can be considered a desired recording because of the relative infrequency of hearing both works in the same concert.

Mozart excelled at every form of classical music that he laid his hands on, whether that was operas, symphonies, or serenades.  But one form where he truly set the standard for all of those who would follow in his footsteps (including Beethoven and Chopin) is in the form of the piano concerto.  With seemingly inexhaustible ease, the young tyro from Salzburg elevated the piano concerto in Zen-like fashion, composing twenty-seven such examples during his incredibly short time.  Many of them, particularly the final eight (nos. 20-27) set the gold standard in the form.  Two excellent examples of W.A. Mozart's genius un the piano concerto are in form on this CD.Dame Mitsuko Uchida made an absolutely superlative cycle of Mozart's concertos for Philips in the 1980s with Jeffrey Tate and the English Chamber Orchestra that demonstrated why she is one of the great pianists of the world in the last forty years.  On this CD, Uchida and Tate take on two concertos, nos. 18 and 19, that were written in the same year (1784) that Mozart collaborated with Lorenzo DaPonte on their hugely successful opera "The Marriage Of Figaro."  The 18th concerto, in B Flat Major, is a wonderful example of Mozart's virtuosity with a touch of lightness, the two outer movements in the home key bracketing a typical Mozartean Andante in the key of G Minor.  The 19th, in F Major, is also a fairly light (but no less profound) work that has foreshadowing of the pianism demonstrated in the eight that would follow, and the composer's way with slow concerto movements (in this case, an Adagio in the key of C Major).  Neither of these concertos is martial in nature, hence the absence of trumpets and timpani.As with the other concertos, these two works are well served by Uchida and Tate; and the English Chamber Orchestra, an orchestra with an extensive history as regards to Mozart, are clearly on their "A" game here.  Whether a part of the entire box set made by these forces, or in this individual CD, these are performances well worth having.

Some of our nation's smaller orchestras have been able to do well by exposing audiences and listeners alike to many works that aren't as well ensconced in the public imagination as others are.  This is very true in this particular recording by conductor Donald Barra and the San Diego Chamber Orchestra.It is lesser know works by two great Spanish composers of the 20th century that are on this recording, made at Torrey Pines Christian Church in La Jolla in the spring of 1992.  First up is Joaquin Turina, who is well represented here by two small but enlightening works that highlight the orchestra's string section: the "Rapsodia Sinfonica" for piano and strings, featuring Gustavo Romero at the piano; and one of Turina's best known and most loved works, "La Oracion Del Torero" (The Bullfighter's Prayer), also for string orchestra.The other composer is Joaquin Rodrigo, best known for his works for classical guitar such as the ultra-popular "Concierto De Aranjuez" (despite the fact that not only did he not know how to play guitar, but was also blind), but here are featured three pieces that reflect other aspects of his native Spain.  "Cuatro Madrigales Amatorios" (Four Love Songs) is a beautiful four-song cycle based in the traditions of Rodrigo's native Andalusian region, and is scored for soprano and chamber orchestra.  Ruth Golden is the soprano soloist in this case, and she acquits herself quite well.  The other two works by Rodrigo, "Tres Viejos Aires De Danza" and "Zarabanda Lejana Y Villancico" invoke a modernistic approach to older musical forms, both from Spain and Europe, though on a somewhat smaller scale than, say, Ottorino Respighi's more colorful Ancient Airs And Dances.As the classical CD market is not flooded with recordings of these works, this particular recording is a good way to get acquainted with them.  But more than that, the San Diego Chamber Orchestra and Mr. Barra do a wonderful job of unearthing these lesser-known 20th century Spanish treasures.  It is a CD well worth owning.

Although he was born in India, Zubin Mehta was very well trained in the Vienna school of music in his rise to becoming a conductor, whether it was during the short stint he had as the Montreal Symphony Orchestra's music director in the 1960s, or his tenure at the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra that put that orchestra and that city on the classical music map forever, or his lifetime appointment and music director of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.  One conductor he certainly specialized in as much as any was Richard Strauss.And one work that had become a house specialty of his was the composer's Nietzschean-inspired symphonic tone poem "Also Sprach Zarathustra", a work that was always a sonic spectacular on record, but which really took off in the concert hall after its opening "Dawn" passage was used to exceptionally cagey effect by director Stanley Kubrick in his 1968 sci-fi masterpiece 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY.  Indeed, in that same year that "2001" made the work so insanely popular, Mehta gave it one of its all-time greatest performances in a recording that he made with the L.A. Philharmonic.  Eleven years later, in late 1979, into his second season as the New York Philharmonic's music director, he revisited the gigantic orchestral palette and existential world of that work.The difficult challenge that any conductor, no matter how good, has in doing this work is in sustaining interest in this work beyond its exceptionally portentous opening with its three-note C-G-C motif (the so-called "World Riddle Theme"), because it does become a deceptive and enigmatic work from that point on.  That famous "World Riddle", however, is a motif used at various points throughout; and Mehta has the New York Philharmonic on its toes throughout the work's 34 minute running time.  Although I think his earlier 1968 recording for London/Decca (made at UCLA's Royce Hall) is sonically the better recording to this CBS recording from Avery Fisher Hall, it isn't exactly a slouch either.  And Mehta is truly one of the great conductors of all time because of exploring such a challenging work.  This is a fine recording to have, even if you have many "Zarathustra" performances (including the aforementioned 1968 one) in your record/CD collection.

One would have thought that everything that needed to be said about director Sam Peckinpah's dark and troubled 1973 Western masterpiece PAT GARRETT AND BILLY THE KID had been said in the many books about this most maverick and ornery of Hollywood directors, plus the 2005 Special Edition DVD release.  But there is quite a bit more; and in fact, Paul Seydor, whose book "Peckinpah: The Western Films--A Reconsideration" is one of the touchstone books on Peckinpah's cantankerous but never-a-dull-moment career, has focused in on that film specifically for his book "The Authentic Death And Contentious Afterlife Of `Pat Garrett And Billy The Kid'"This book not only details the film itself, but its antecedents--the very legend of Garrett and Billy (with its myriad interpretations and contradictions); and the screenplay adaptation that Peckinpah wrote early on in his career (in 1957) of Charles Neider's book "The Authentic Death Of Hendry Jones" that was loosely based on that legend (but which, once it reached the screen in 1961 as ONE-EYED JACKS, did not feature his name in the credits).  Seydor then proceeds on to how Peckinpah eventually got the original screenplay by Rudolph Wurlitzer that would form the basis for his film; and then things get even more interesting.Much has been made about the fact that PAT GARRETT AND BILLY THE KID, owing to problems involving the camera equipment (a bent lens flange on one camera that caused any shots using that camera to be out of focus), an epidemic of influenza that overtook everyone on the set in Durango, Mexico, and Peckinpah's conflicts with MGM (the studio financing the film) that were worse than any he had ever experienced in his enormously stormy career.  All of this is enhanced by new information that Seydor uncovered through the kind of meticulous research that one needs for this director.  But it's what happened in the post-production process, accelerated by the film going significantly over budget and schedule, that we see just how much of a torture it was for all involved, including the principal film editors Garth Craven, Roger Spottiswoode, and Robert Wolfe.  Owing to a three-prong combination of booze, paranoia, and the after-effects of the flu he had suffered while on location in Durango, Peckinpah was falling dangerously asleep at the switch just when this film, easily the darkest and most tragic of all Westerns (and arguably the best the genre offered in the 1970s), really needed him the most.  Its prestige has risen considerably since its truncated release (poor reviews, mediocre box office, and all) in 1973.  But the 2005 Special Edition release also caused its own problems, with many Internet reviewers severely taking Seydor to task for allegedly "altering" the film.  As Seydor points out in the book, he didn't do all that much to it, as everything in it was shot by Peckinpah and edited by his regular crew; and as he also points out, Peckinpah never actually even finished the film because of all the problems he had, many of them, let's be truthful about this, caused directly by his own hand.  He left the film in an unfortunately unfinished shape.All of this points out what an enormous tragedy Hollywood filmmaking can frequently be, especially if the director is as much of a "troublemaker" (at least in the eyes of the moneymen) as Peckinpah was.  But Seydor, in this excellent book of his, nevertheless makes a clear and convincing case for PAT GARRETT AND BILLY THE KID, even with the problematic elements in its execution and all the troubles involved in its actual making, being one of Peckinpah's best, approaching the stature of THE WILD BUNCH.  For anyone fiercely interested in filmmaking in general, and this director in particular, Seydor's singular, hard-hitting, but still hugely sympathetic look at PAT GARRETT is absolutely essential.

From the very moment it saw its first light of day in 1919, British composer Gustav Holst's monumental seven-movement, astrologically-inspired suite for large orchestra, "The Planets", has been a worldwide mainstay, and not just in straight-ahead classical music circles.  Holst's concept of the seven known planets in out Solar System (Pluto not being discovered until 1934) has clearly informed many a science fiction and space opera film score, whether it's the opening "Mars" sequence influencing John Williams' thinking of the STAR WARS films, or the isolated, distant combinations of celesta, woodwinds, and wordless female chorus on the work's final movement "Neptune" that influenced Jerry Goldsmith's score for STAR TREK: THE MOTION PICTURE, or David Shire's on "2010".There's no question that it is an orchestral showpiece to end all orchestral showpieces, with an orchestral component that would have made both Richard Wagner and Gustav Mahler green with envy.  Orchestras the world over have performed this work ever since its premiere; but the number of recordings of it just exploded with the advent of the space race, and, of course, with the outer space film scores that were clearly influenced by it.  This particular recording, made in 1973, is a prime example of just how influential "The Planets" was.  Andre Previn, having first come from a jazz and Hollywood film music background, had developed a solid taste for the English classical music of the late 19th and 20th centuries (Elgar; Vaughan-Williams; Walton) during his tenure as the music director of the London Symphony in the 1970s; and as such, there was no way he could have avoided putting his own stamp on it.  He brings an extremely violent energy to "Mars", a joyous approach to "Jupiter, The Bringer Of Jollity" (naturally), and a serene isolationism to "Neptune, The Mystic."  It also doesn't hurt that the orchestra itself pretty much had had this work in its blood from the beginning, but they are never for one moment on autopilot, since Previn had proven himself to be one of the foremost conductors of his time.  The final movement features the wordless women's voices of the Ambrosian Singers.This sonic free-for-all has had an infinite number of recordings over the years, and my favorites have been: Zubin Mehta's 1971 recording with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; Eugene Ormandy's 1975 recording with the Philadelphia Orchestra; and Mehta's later 1989 New York Philharmonic one.  This recording by Previn and the London Symphony is, in my opinion, very much worth standing comparison with those, and it's one you can't go wrong if you want a true interstellar orchestral experience.

Unless one counts his First Symphony (the "Titan"), then it is the Fourth Symphony that is the most popular of the nine symphonies of Gustav Mahler.  Mahler's symphonic visions were often very large in orchestration, and, in the case of nos. 2, 3, 8, & 9, enormously long (each takes 85-100 minutes to perform).  But the Fourth, although close to an hour in length itself, is the one closest to the traditional classical structures of Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, and Schubert, dispensing with trombones and tuba, but including sleigh bells.This work, which Mahler composed during 1899 and 1900, but which had to wait until the fall of 1901 for its first performance in Munich, owes a fair amount of its existence, like its three predecessors, to the song collection "Des Knaben Wunderhorn."  As such, it is a light work of sorts as well, with its fourth movement, a setting of the Wunderhorn song "We Enjoy Heaven's Delights" (intended initially as the seventh movement of the already-gargantuan Third Symphony, before Mahler thought better), for soprano and orchestra.  In the case of this early 1980s Philips recording, it is the great English soprano Dame Margaret Price; and the orchestra in question is the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Edo De Waart.Price, De Waart, and the S.F.S.O. bring out the best in this work, in the manner of many other recordings of this work (Judith Raskin/George Szell; 1965) (Barbara Hendricks/Esa-Pekka Salonen; 1992) (Dawn Upshaw/Christoph von Dohnanyi; 1992).  As with a lot of Mahler's works, even one as light as this, the Fourth is not by any stretch of the imagination an easy work to pull off; it can sometimes slip into schmaltz, or be done in a ham-handed fashion.  Fortunately, the best recordings of it avoid falling into either trap.  And this recording is clearly among the best of the bunch.

The novels of Donald Westlake (writing as Richard Stark) have really provided a lot of grist for the Hollywood mill since the 1960s.  The first example was the 1967 John Boorman-directed film POINT BLANK, with Lee Marvin, based on Westlake's book "The Hunter", and now considered a cult classic.  After that came 1972's THE HOT ROCK (with George Segal and Robert Redford), 1974's THE OUTFIT (with Robert Duvall and Robert Ryan); and 1974's BANK SHOT (with George C. Scott).And in 1968, there was THE SPLIT.Based on Westlake's book "The Seventh", the film is a classically themed Hollywood heist film, involving a group of thieves robbing the cash office at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum during a playoff game between the Los Angeles Rams and the Atlanta Falcons. Former NFL legend Jim Brown, who turned to acting after retiring from the Cleveland Browns in 1965 and became a star in Robert Aldrich's 1967 classic THE DIRTY DOZEN, is the leader of this group that includes his fellow DIRTY DOZEN cast members Donald Sutherland and Ernest Borgnine; Jack Klugman (one of the jurors in the 1957 classic TWELVE ANGRY MEN); and veteran character actor Warren Oates. The heist goes off with almost laser-like perfection, but it's what happens thereafter--the complications; the screw-ups; and the betrayals--that are the real payoff. Gene Hackman, who had at the time recently leaped to acting prominence as a result of his role in BONNIE AND CLYDE, portrays a seedy Los Angeles cop (perhaps presaging his Oscar-winning turn in THE FRENCH CONNECTION); and Diahann Carroll and Julie Harris are the women involved. James Whitmore plays a superbly seedy landlord at Carroll's apartment.By 21st century standards, this must seem terribly old-fashioned: there are no hyper-violent, over-the-top stunts, no CGI bloodshed, or any of that extraneous junk. And this is clearly a film of the late 1960s, in terms of costumes, hairstyles, and all of that--this and, of course, the fact that the Rams were L.A.'s pro-football team too. And yet, even though it doesn't necessarily stand out among the many great crime heist films, from Stanley Kubrick's THE KILLING to Sam Peckinpah's THE GETAWAY, the original 1974 subway thriller THE TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE, or even the 1988 blockbuster DIE HARD, there's still something hugely fascinating about THE SPLIT, in terms of the way suspense is built up. Perhaps part of the reason it isn't as well-known as it should be is that the director, British-born Gordon Flemyng, was not a known entity, save for a couple of episodes of the classic TV series "The Avengers", and the campy 1965 film DR. WHO AND THE DALEKS. All the same, though, the cast still does well under Flemyng's direction, with very good cinematography by Burnett Guffey (who won an Oscar for BONNIE AND CLYDE), and a taut, early action film music score by Quincy Jones, who had done major work on THE PAWNBROKER, IN THE HEAT OF THE NIGHT, and IN COLD BLOOD. This was also the first film to be released following the establishment of the movie ratings system by the MPAA where the for-adults 'R' rating was placed, even though it is closer to a 'PG-13' rating by today's ultra-violent standards.Yes, the film is extremely dated; and despite its length of only 90 minutes, it's not an especially super-fast movie.  But given its limitations, it still has much more to it than most action films even today.

Without question, Igor Stravinsky, a student of Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov and an admirer of Tchaikovsky, was one of the most important composers of the 20th century.  Whether it was in neo-classical works like his orchestral suite "L'Histoire Du Soldat" or "Pulcinella", or innovative works like "Symphony In C" and the "Symphony Of Psalms", there is no dispute that this great Russian-born composer, who lived from 1883 to 1971, influenced much of 20th century music, even as far as Hollywood film scores, such as those of John Williams, Bernard Herrmann, and Jerry Goldsmith.  And where his genius was most fully exposed was in the field of ballet.This two-CD collection of recordings made by the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in the early 1980s for London/Decca under their legendary music director of the time, Antal Dorati, showcases four of Stravinsky's ballet scores in their complete form: the 1911 opus "Petrushka"; the lighter 1928 "Apollon Musagete"; and the two "Big Bangs" of 20th century music, to wit "The Firebird" and "The Rite Of Spring".  All four ballet scores require orchestras who perform and/or record them to be on their toes, because Stravinsky's orchestration, besides being very complex and occasionally even dissonant, is also explosive at times, perhaps nowhere more so than in "The Rite Of Spring".  Fortunately, both Dorati and the Detroit Symphony were well up to the task in these recordings.  The string section of the orchestra dominates in their recording of the "Apollon Musagete" score in a way that combines modernism with the neo-classical style.  "Petrushka" also receives a stellar rendition; and no matter how many other orchestras have recorded "The Firebird" or "The Rite Of Spring" in their complete forms (normally, only the suites that Stravinsky extracted are recorded with extreme frequency), they got performances from Motown that are equal to any other such recordings.The years when Dorati was the Detroit Symphony's music director, from 1977 to 1983 (and Conductor Laureate from 1983 until his passing in 1988), were one of four important "Golden" eras for the orchestra, the others being Paul Paray's 1952-1963 tenure (which really put Detroit on the classical map); Neeme Jarvi's from 1990 to 2005 (he is now Conductor Emeritus); and the current one with Leonard Slatkin as the Music Director.  This Stravinsky 2-CD pack should keep people aware of the great classical tradition that flourished in Detroit over the decades, and continues to thrive to this day, even in the midst of all the fiscal horrors that the Motor City has faced these last few years.

I think it is safe to say that the city of Los Angeles owes a huge debt of gratitude to Zubin Mehta for having put the City of Angels on the classical music map for keeps during his sixteen-year tenure, from 1962 to 1978, as the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.  What had largely been a provincial orchestra in 1962, at a rundown Philharmonic Hall, when Mehta took over at the age of 26 became, before the 1960s were even over with, one of the great orchestras in America, and, eventually, the entire world.  A great deal of that was owed to his training in Vienna, but also the realization on his part that the orchestra had some of the best musicians in the world, many of whom worked in Hollywood (which would remain true into our present day).  Thus, he was able to cover not only the hard-core part of the repertoire, but also those works not nearly as well known to the public.  This release, an import from the Japanese division of London/Decca, is just such an example.The best known of the two is Camille Saint-Saens' monumental Symphony No. 3 In C Minor, which, for obvious reasons, in the second and fourth movements, is the Organ Symphony.  This is a work that never fails to test the sound systems of anyone's sound systems, both with respect to the organ and the extremely large orchestral forces required in the finale; but even beyond that, this work, composed by Saint-Saens in 1886, was probably the single most popular symphony to have emerged from France since Berlioz's graphically violent "Symphonie Fantastique".  This particular Mehta/L.A. Philharmonic recording, made in March 1970, features Anita Priest at the organ.A little over two years earlier, in the fall of 1967, Mehta and the orchestra made a very impressive recording of another work that calls for an organ (or a harmonium) and a fairly huge orchestral component: the Fourth Symphony of the Russian composer Alexander Scriabin, which he called "Poem Of Ecstasy."  A work of more recent vintage, composed by Scriabin between 1905 and 1908, it is a fairly modernistic work, full of suspense and tension for its twenty-minute length, and fairly perfect for Mehta and the orchestra.  It probably isn't too much of a stretch to say that Los Angeles audiences, if not indeed the world at large, got to know this work through this performance.Both works are paired quite cagily onto this import record, but the Organ Symphony in particular is given one of its great renderings, right up there with the 1957 Mercury recording made by the Detroit Symphony Orchestra under Paul Paray (with Marcel Dupre at the organ) and the later 1983 Philips recording by the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra under Edo De Waart (with Jean Guillou handling the organ duties).  Either work, though, showcases both the L.A. Philharmonic and the conductor that put it on the map in the first place at their finest, one of the truly great orchestra/music director combines in history.

I cannot think of another director that ever worked behind a film camera who ever caused the kind of uproar in their lifetime that Sam Peckinpah did during his.
