Coming from a pioneer family in central California that had already been active in politics and the law for decades, Peckinpah's true love, however, was the theater; and in the decades to come, that eventually morphed into a great deal of work in TV, including his own short-lived 1960 television western "The Westerner", and then finally a film career that, to put it mildly, was a radically turbulent one right up until his untimely death on December 28, 1984, less than two months short of his 60th birthday.One of the best books chronicling this ultimate Hollywood "outlaw" is this one, "Peckinpah: A Portrait In Montage" by Garner Simmons, who, as a student at Northwestern University in 1973, met the director of such classic but disturbingly violent films as THE WILD BUNCH and STRAW DOGS, and was shanghaied into portraying one of the guards of Emilio Fernandez in the director's truly bleak and despairing 1974 film BRING ME THE HEAD OF ALFREDO GARCIA.  Simmons, in very exacting detail, gives a look at all of the aspects of this often controversial director and what went on behind the making of his movies, and the rapid montage style of editing that radically changed the way Hollywood action films are shot and put together.  Of particular interest in reading this chronicle was in reading the battle between the director and producer Jerry Bresler on the 1965 Civil War-era western epic MAJOR DUNDEE, which included the fact that Peckinpah had selected locations in Mexico for that film that were at times hundreds of miles apart, which hurt efforts to get the script, which wasn't even finished at the time shooting had begun in February 1964, into final shape.  Simmons also details Peckinpah's travails after being fired from THE CINCINNATI KID, shortly after DUNDEE, an event which left him all but unhirable in Hollywood for a couple of years.  At the same time, though, we get a solid overview of the making of THE WILD BUNCH, THE BALLAD OF CABLE OF HOGUE, STRAW DOGS, JUNIOR BONNER, THE GETAWAY, and the troubled PAT GARRETT AND BILLY THE KID, six incredible pieces of work released within a period of four and a half years, from mid-1969 to the fall of 1973.Inevitably, though, Simmons details Peckinpah's downfall, due not only to his abuse of booze but, worst of all, also to his abuse of cocaine, which often left him in no real shape to do anything the way he had done in the past (as could be witnessed on THE KILLER ELITE, CROSS OF IRON, and CONVOY, despite several moments of brilliance in all).  This revised version of the book then details the brief and minor comeback he had in 1983 with THE OSTERMAN WEEKEND, and then with the heart attack he had in Mexico that sent him back to L.A. and his premature death.Simmons' book is one of three, the others being "If They Move, Kill `Em: The Life And Times Of Sam Peckinpah" by David Weddle, and "Peckinpah: The Western Films--A Reconsideration" by Paul Seydor, that are the most detailed about Peckinpah's groundbreaking work as a director and the unfortunate demons and dark parts of his being that he often had to wrestle with and which he ultimately lost to.  Nothing is glossed over, but the extensive interviews that Simmons conducted with the director, the actors who starred in his films, and such associates as film editors Roger Spottiwoode, Bob Wolfe, and Lou Lombardo, and legendary composer Jerry Fielding, give a great and even-handed portrait of this extremely complex director who, in spite of all the odds he was up against an old Hollywood system that disintegrated in the 1960s and his own reputation as a wild, out-of-control macho man, somehow managed to, in paraphrasing Joel McCrea's famous line in the director's 1962 classic RIDE THE HIGH COUNTRY, enter his house justified.Anyone who is interested in great biographies in general, and those in particular that involve Hollywood, should not wait to get this book to get a look at a director whose impact is still being felt some three decades after his death.

What is it about Gustav Holst's "The Planets" that has made it so unbelievably popular for almost an entire century?  Given that Holst himself was actually bothered by its initial popularity when it was premiered in 1919, one can't help but wonder.  But once one looks at a number of classic science fiction film scores, notably those of John Williams (STAR WARS; CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND) and Jerry Goldsmith (STAR TREK: THE MOTION PICTURE), the influence of this seven-movement work is indisputable.From the violent opening measures of "Mars The Bringer Of War", through the peace of "Venus", the sprightly "Mercury", and finally to the disembodied desolation of "Neptune The Mystic" (with its wordless female chorus, a la the "Sirenes" movement of Debussy's "Nocturnes"), "The Planets" is one of the ultimate examples of orchestration, requiring orchestral forces so large that it often seems to put even the big-scale works of Richard Wagner, Richard Strauss, Arnold Schoenberg, or Igor Stravinsky in the shade.  But this also often poses a difficulty for conductors who get their hands on this work: How do make a recording of this warhorse truly stand out?This is something that conductor Zubin Mehta grapples with on this Teldec recording of Holst's masterpiece--and doubly so, because this version with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra from 1989 is actually his second go-round with it.  The first one was in 1971 for London/Decca; and on that recording, he had the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the orchestra he really made world famous in his sixteen-year tenure there, at his command.  That particular recording is still considered one of the greatest the work has ever received.Given this, does this New York recording match or exceed it?  Not necessarily, but it does come fairly close.  There's no question that the New York Philharmonic retained the world-class status it had achieved in all of the years that Leonard Bernstein was on the podium under Mehta's 1978-1991 tenure; and the explosive outbursts in "Mars" and "Jupiter" are well conceived, with some of the same intensity that the L.A. Philharmonic bought to the work in the early 1970s.  The disembodied female voices of the New York Choral Artists in "Neptune" provide the brilliant interstellar gravitas to conclude the piece.The market may be saturated with recordings of this warhorse, but that's why it is a warhorse to begin with.  This recording may fall a touch short of what Mehta did in L.A., but it is still a standout one to listen to.

Unquestionably one of the greatest composers of all times, Johannes Brahms was, however, a man caught in between two musical polarities in the time he composed, the middle-to-later 19th century.  On the one hand, he was, especially in terms of orchestral music, generally deemed a follower of the traditions of the classic Viennese era (Haydn; Mozart; Beethoven; Schubert); on the other hand, he was surrounded by musical "radicals" like Liszt, Bruckner, Wagner, and Mahler, who greatly expanded the scope of Western music by enlarging their orchestral works to unbelievable dimensions, thus setting the stage for what would come in the 20th century via Schoenberg and Stravinsky.  Brahms is still thought of as something of a musical conservative, but this hardly means he was ever a merely popular composer.  Such can be gauged here in this recording that combines the inner two of his four symphonies.Composed in the summer of 1877, after his first foray into the symphony took some two decades to finish because of the composer's lingering fears of Beethoven's shadow, the D Major Second Symphony is a work that still carries the influences of Beethoven, mixing the idealism of the Pastoral Symphony and the obvious heroic elements of the Eroica Symphony into what is nevertheless a cohesive and completely original symphonic whole.  Brahms' only concessions to the Romantic era in which he lived were the inclusion of a tuba and three trombones, most prominently at the triumphant climax of the fourth movement.  In an ironic turn, part of the melody of the work's opening movement bears a close similarity to the composer's beloved "Wiegenlied", more commonly known as the Cradle Song, or Lullaby.The Third Symphony, composed in 1883, is really more in line with Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony, being as it is in the same key, F Major; and it excludes the tuba from the orchestration.  Oddly, it is perhaps the least played of the four symphonic efforts of Brahms, not because of any defect in the way he composed it, but because, in contrast to so many symphonies, all four movements of this work end in relatively quiescence and tranquility.  The finale is particularly notable for starting in the stormy key of F Minor before making its quiet exit in the home key of F Major.Both of these symphonies are given first-rate performances by the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam under their esteemed conductor from 1964-1987, Bernard Haitink; the Third being recorded in May 1970, and the Second in June 1973, as part of a major 1969-1980 Philips survey of the major orchestral works of Brahms that Haitink did with the Concertgebouw.  Neither of these symphonies is taken at too slow a pace, nor are they taken at what I call the "fire sale speed" approach of period instrument performers.  Haitink's experience with Brahms is evident in both works, with the Concertgebouw performing like the world-class orchestra it has been for close to a hundred and twenty-five years.If any recording of these two symphonies back-to-back is being considered seriously, this one by the world-class conductor/orchestra of Haitink and the Concertgebouw should be among the first.

One of the composers that the late, great British conductor Sir Colin Davis specialized in throughout his career was one Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.  And during the 1980s, he essayed nearly the entire final third of the composer's symphonic output for Philips in recordings made with the Dresden State Orchestra (Staatskapelle Dresden).  This particular recording of that entire set, incredibly enough, pulls together four of those symphonies, principally since none of them are much longer than twenty minutes.The 30th Symphony is a work that Mozart premiered in Salzburg in May 1774, and it shows the composer rapidly maturing his approach to the symphony.  Some of the elements of it echo the symphonies in the same key (D Major) that his good friend and much older contemporary Franz Joseph Haydn was composing, and the orchestration is starting to get progressively larger.  That would happen to a greater degree with the so-called "Paris" Symphony, No. 31, also in D Major, composed four years later after a terribly unsuccessful job-hunting sojourn to the French capitol.  That work had the largest required number of orchestral forces of any Mozart symphony up to that time (it was the first one to utilize clarinets), with trumpets and timpani very much in evidence.The 32nd Symphony (in G Major) s a short eight-minute work consisting of three movements played without a break, but with noticeable changes in tempo (fast-slow-fast), laid out as if it were an Italian overture (indeed, some would say that it was intended as the overture for Mozart's opera "Zaide", though this isn't likely); this was composed in 1779, shortly after the composer returned to Salzburg from Paris.  Also from that same year came the 33rd Symphony, in B Flat Major, employing only oboe, bassoon, and horn, along with the string orchestra compliment, making it the lightest scored of the ten symphonies that Mozart had composed, back to No. 24.With the possible exception of the "Paris", these symphonies don't necessarily enjoy the kind of recognition of the symphonies yet to be, or even the "Little G Minor" (#25), would.  After listening to the way an expert Mozart conductor like Davis, and an orchestra that is historically steeped in the composer's music like the Dresden State Orchestra, you will wonder why that is.  These performances are well worth getting this recording for.

The symphonies of Beethoven are all compelling works to listen to, even those that are not necessarily thought of as "profound" statements in the way that word has often been used.  This is the case made by this particular recording, part of the late German conductor Wolfgang Sawallisch's early 1990s Beethoven symphony cycle made for EMI with the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.The Fourth Symphony in B Flat Major, composed in 1806 at a time when the increasingly deaf composer was also working on the grandiose statements of the Fifth Symphony and the Violin Concerto, is considered a "lesser" work in Beethoven's symphonic canon because it has none of the explosiveness of the two works that it is sandwiched in between; Robert Schumann would later refer to it as "a slender Greek maiden standing between two Norse giants" (the Eroica Symphony being its immediate predecessor).  And in truth, it doesn't seem as if it breaks any new ground per se, needing the smallest amount of orchestral forces of any of the symphonies (including just a single flute).  In truth, though, what it might lack in profundity, it does gain in Beethoven showing a lighter side, still partly stuck in the Haydn/Mozart frame, but also anticipating what would be coming in the ensuing ten years from his much younger contemporary Franz Schubert, in its bumptious third movement, a cross between a Minuet and a Scherzo, and a scurrying finale that somewhat anticipates the opening movement of Schubert's Second Symphony.The Seventh, of course, is one of Beethoven's supreme achievements, an experiment in rhythmic vitality.  Wagner himself called it "the apotheosis of the dance", with the fierce vitality of the Scherzo and finale.  But there is also the elongated first movement in the work's home key of A Major, its slow intro leading into the dotted, almost Scherzo-like rhythms of the main body; and the darker Allegretto, in A Minor, which found its way into cinematic usage twice in 2009 via THE KING'S SPEECH and KNOWING.Having made a solid Schumann symphony cycle for EMI in 1972 with the Dresden State Orchestra, and having also held down the top artistic positions at the Bavarian State Opera and the Philadelphia Orchestra in his time, Sawallisch clearly knew his way around a significant amount of the standard Austro-German repertoire, and it shows on this recording.  The pacing of both the Fourth and Seventh symphonies is right where it has to be, and the Concertgebouw Orchestra is at its world-class peak here for Sawallisch, as it had been for Bernard Haitink, and would continue to be for Riccardo Chailly.  This is a great Beethoven recording to own, highly recommended.

Without question, when one hears the name Giuseppe Verdi, one thinks of the greatest composers of opera in history--"Aida"; "Macbeth"; "Falstaff"; "La Forza Del Destino"; "Othello", and many others.  Beyond opera, of course, there is his Manzoni Requiem, perhaps the best-known setting of the Mass For The Dead after Mozart's, and one of the most apocalyptic works of any kind composed in Western music, period.  But there is another choral work of Verdi's worth exploring...or rather, a collection of four sacred settings that he composed in the final twelve years of his life, and which are grouped under "Quattro Pezzi Sacri", or "Four Sacred Pieces."  They are: "Ave Maria" (which he set in 1889, though he considered it only an exercise piece); "Stabat Mater" (from 1886-87); "Laude Alla Vergine Maria"(1886-88, a setting of the prayer in Canto XXXIII of Dante's "Paradiso"); and a setting of the "Te Deum" composed in 1895-96.In comparison to the Manzoni Requiem, of course, "Four Sacred Pieces" is not nearly as frequently recorded; and the fact that, despite the significant size of the orchestra required, it is not anywhere as apocalyptic seems to make it extremely obscure.  But on this singular recording, made in April 1970, Zubin Mehta makes the most of this combination, working in collaboration with legendary mezzo-soprano Yvonne Minton, the Los Angeles Master Chorale (under the direction of their founder, Roger Wagner), and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, which, by that time, under Mehta's direction, was really becoming a serious world powerhouse in classical music.This recording has been combined on CD in recent times with Fritz Reiner's 1959 Vienna Philharmonic recording of the Manzoni Requiem, but it one that deserves to stand another release, this next time with one of the separate recordings Mehta made during his sixteen-year tenure (1962-1978) as the L.A. Philharmonic's music director.  This vinyl recording, in the meantime, can, I believe, be considered the absolutely definitive recording of this rarely recorded and performed choral work.

Where to begin?Given the huge success of director John Carpenter's 1978 horror/suspense classic HALLOWEEN, it was almost inevitable that its story of teens being stalked (and frequently killed) by a maniac would be exploited by other films.  What nobody anticipated, of course, was to the extremes to which this would happen--not just with a handful of films, but with tens, hundreds, and, by now, perhaps even thousands of them.  And the 1980 film FRIDAY THE 13TH was perhaps the biggest of the HALLOWEEN-inspired imitations.One doesn't have to go into the particulars of the story, because, after three and a half decades, we know what the drill is: the summer camp at Crystal Lake re-opens some twenty years after a young boy named Jason Voorhees drowned there due, in no small part, to the neglect of the camp counselors there.  Some things, though, apparently don't change, because, as before, the camp counselors and their teenage underlings engage in all matters of sexual activity; and soon, one by one, they get basically chopped up, skewered, eviscerated, and dismembered in every gory way imaginable for that time, in the manner of what may be this movie's true progenitor, the 1971 Mario Bava film TWITCH OF THE DEATH NERVE.  As happened in HALLOWEEN with Jamie Lee Curtis, the only one still left standing is the one of them (Adrienne King) who didn't engage in illicit sex.  The irony, though, is that when she encounters what seems to be a kindly old woman (Betsy Palmer), she meets up with the actual assailant, as Palmer is the stark-raving bonkers, vengeance-seeking mother of Jason, resulting in some actual suspense, but also with a climax and coda that would be repeated with variations for almost every other film in the series (only then, it is Jason himself doing the stalk/hack/slash thing).It has to be said that director Sean S. Cunningham, who produced director Wes Craven's controversial 1972 horror cult classic LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT, does some inventive things early on, given that he had a budget of just over half a million dollars (which probably wouldn't even cover the catering on most typical Hollywood big-budget films).  A number of the daytime scenes at Camp Crystal Lake have some of the disturbing aura of director John Boorman's 1972 classic DELIVERANCE (itself something of a horror film).  And there is an early appearance here by Kevin Bacon, basically the only person in the cast who went on to bigger and (needless to say) better things, as one of the teens who, of course, ends up getting butchered.But in general, the whole reason for the existence of FRIDAY THE 13TH, besides to cash in on the success of the relatively blood-free HALLOWEEN, was to show the inventive and extremely graphic ways people can be hacked up, which can be credited to make-up effects wizard Tom Savini, who worked on the 1978 George Romero classic DAWN OF THE DEAD.  This really points out the fact that the very reason for the film's success is that it is also its own Achilles heel, not to mention that the fact that so many of the victims killed here are women, ushering the kind of misogyny that would become a big part of these films from here on in.  In no realistic and unbiased way can FRIDAY THE 13TH be considered a truly classic horror film in the manner of either HALLOWEEN or PSYCHO.  There are things about it that work well enough, but it still falls far short of what came before it.

The difficulty with assessing any Beethoven symphony recording comes with the fact that this composer's nine symphonies, whether as part of a cycle or individually, have been recorded thousands of times already, and are likely to be recorded thousands of times more.  Whether it's with traditional symphony orchestras, smaller chamber orchestras, or those of the period-instrument/authentic performance bent, Beethoven's symphonies are timeless and universal.  Thus, the problem becomes of how to put a new, or even distinctive, "spin" on works that most everyone knows so well.This is something that the late German conductor Wolfgang Sawallisch, whose many conducting stints included the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and the Philadelphia Orchestra, contended with in the Beethoven cycle he did for EMI in the early 1990s with the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.  This particular recording focuses in on two works that don't necessarily seem like they come from the same creative mind, but do.The First Symphony, which was composed in 1797, was the only one of the nine Beethoven composed that was written while he still had his hearing intact.  It is a work that, understandably, still shows the influences of Mozart's and Haydn's later symphonies, but with a few twists: a slow introduction to the first movement that showcases the wind section of the orchestra in a way that alienated reviewers of Beethoven's time; and a third movement that is marked as a Minuet, but is in fact an embryonic example of the Scherzo, which would come to be an important part of his symphonic language, as well as that of his later contemporary Franz Schubert.The Third Symphony, the all-encompassing Eroica, originally composed in 1803 and dedicated to Napoleon until the latter's delusions of grandeur so savagely inflamed Beethoven, is where Beethoven became his own man.  From its elongated opening movement (the longest symphonic movement up to that time, to be surpassed only by the finale of the Ninth), to the highly-charged Funeral March, the intense Scherzo, and the finale, which is a series of variations on a theme found in the composer's only ballet "The Creatures Of Prometheus", this is a work that basically thrust the symphonic form from the 18th century into the 19th, with the first two hammer strokes.Even if there's not much to any of these performances that is absolutely new, again because the works themselves are so familiar to audiences, Sawallisch nevertheless gets a lot of mileage from them, as does the Concertgebouw Orchestra, one of the premier orchestras of the world.  There are other fine pairings of Beethoven 1 & 3 (Leonard Bernstein's with the New York Philharmonic from 1964; Nikolaus Harnoncourt's with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, from the late 1980s; and Herbert Blomstedt's with the San Francisco Symphony from 1990), but this Sawallisch/Concertgebouw recording is well worth consideration.

Absent any hidden gems from the vaults of either Capitol or Warner/Elektra that her fans don't know about, the order of the day when it comes to Linda Ronstadt will be compilations and repackages of her output, since Parkinson's robbed her of that four-octave voice that made her among the most influential female pop singers of the last fifty years.  And it definitely was a glorious career.This is where ICON comes in.Although there will understandably be quite a lot of quibbling over the fact that this compilation from the vaults of Capitol has a mere eleven tracks on it, it does have a number of her most essential songs, including the two songs, "You're No Good" and "When Will I Be Loved", from her final Capitol album, the career-making 1974 classic HEART LIKE A WHEEL, as well as her first two hits, "Different Drum" (her first hit, with the Stone Poneys, in 1967), and "Long Long Time", which hit #25 in the fall of 1970 and gave her the first of twenty-seven Grammy nominations.  We also get her rendition of Jackson Browne's "Rock Me On The Water", from her eponymous 1972 album, that featured backing from a couple of guys named Glenn Frey, Randy Meisner, and Don Henley (three-fourths of what became the Eagles), and "An American Dream", the 1980 hit by the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band that featured Linda on a kind of hard to miss harmony part.  All of this points out the arena of music where she was at her most influential, the Los Angeles country-rock movement of the 1960s and 1970s, and how much that influence continues on in her fellow female artists, from her good pal Emmylou Harris, through to Trisha Yearwood and Sheryl Crow, and up to more recent roots-rock women like Tift Merritt and Caitlin Rose.ICON concludes with the straight pop balladry of "Somewhere Out There", her bit hit duet with R&B singer James Ingram that was the theme to the Steven Spielberg-produced 1986 animated movie AN AMERICAN TAIL, and "Tell Him I Said Hello", the opening track of her 2004 jazz album HUMMIN' TO MYSELF, that would, according to Linda, be the very last song she ever put down on an album with just her name on it.  It is a fitting and, at the same time, poignant way to end this compilation album, coming after her induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and her receiving a National Medal of Arts.Even though this is a compilation of material that probably every one of her fans has, the songs on it are a reminder of how high a standard Linda set, and how enormous the challenge will be for current media darlings like Taylor Swift to have careers both as long-lasting and memorable as Linda's was.

What happens when you combine CGI, "found footage" video, and the revival of the disaster film craze that enveloped the cinema during the 1970s? This is where INTO THE STORM comes into play.Set during a turbulent spring in the Midwest, the film depicts a professional group of storm chasers, led by Matt Walsh and Sarah Wayne Callies, who thus far have had no luck in getting close to any real tornadoes in the previous two years.  This time, though, their "luck" changes when they find an extremely violent cold front is barreling through the midsection of the United States, and conditions are forming for a record formation of tornadoes.  The crew hightail it for the small Oklahoma town of Silverton, where they see monstrous super storm cells starting to form over the open plains on all sides of town.  At the same time, however, the town is also seeing off a lot of its kids for graduation at the high school; and unfortunately, the school, the town, and everybody in it are in the sights of these supercells.  Walsh is so desperate to get the footage on film that he will put himself and those around him at risk, something that truly alienates Callies, an experienced meteorologist, no end.  But instead of just merely filming and documenting the twisters, the team find themselves rescuing many townspeople, including the high school vice-principal (Richard Armitage) and the students when six different twisters touch down and ravage much of the town.  And then in the end, they are confronted with a three mile-wide monster tornado with winds in its center approaching a mind-busting three hundred miles per hour.The entire premise of INTO THE STORM is a good one, given that Midwestern towns like Moore, Oklahoma and Joplin, Missouri were each nearly wiped clean off the map by monstrous tornadoes during the typical season for these storms at the height of spring, when cold, dry air funneling out of Canada collides with the warm, humid air coming northward from the Gulf of Mexico.  If this premise had been followed through with the same kind of care as the creation of the computer-generated twisters had been, what we might have had here was a truly frightening film along the lines of the 1996 Jan DeBont-directed film TWISTER, which this strongly resembles and which it will inevitably be compared to.But even with all that great CGI on display, there are three things that keep INTO THE STORM from reaching the level of TWISTER.  The first is that not enough time is taken to really draw realistic characters out of the main principals involved, though Callies and Carey (the latter as one of the Silverton teens caught up in the super destruction of the town) do good turns.  The second is the excessive use on the part of both director Steven Quale (FINAL DESTINATION 5) and writer John Swetnam (who wrote, among other things, the screenplay for the 2013 horror film EVIDENCE) to rely on the "found footage" and high school student "time capsule" things, since it blunts the edge the film might have had over other summer blockbusters.  And I really think the film could have done better without the appearance of a couple of extremely irritating and stereotypical redneck wanna-be storm chasers (Kyle David; Jon Reep).Absent the aforementioned flaws, the comparisons to TWISTER, which benefited from good performances by Helen Hunt and Bill Paxton, would not seem to be quite as unfavorable as this review appears to be.  Still, INTP THE STORM, when it focuses in on the storm chasers, the townspeople, and the super storms themselves, works with almost the same degree of success as TWISTER.  It is a fairly typical summer blockbuster film, of course, relying, perhaps a bit excessively, on creating spectacular disaster scenes instead of giving us more in the way of characters.  But as many other such blockbusters rely even less, or almost not at all, on things as important as plot and character, INTO THE STORM is far from a total bust.

British trumpet player Alison Balsom has become a superstar in the classical music in the last few years.  Her recordings of various and hugely popular trumpet concertos from such composers as Haydn and Hummel, among others, have earned her considerable plaudits, as has her ability to handle both the modern-day trumpet (with keys) and the valveless one of the Baroque and early classical period.  It is the latter one that is put to good use on this 2012 EMI/Warner release in which Ms. Balsom she teams up with conductor Trevor Pinnock and the period instrument orchestra The English Concert.This release focuses in on the royal music (of which a lot was composed) by the two titans of English baroque music, namely native son Henry Purcell, and the German émigré George Frideric Handel.  With assistance from countertenor Iestyn Davies and soprano Lucy Crowe, Balsom weaves her way through these pieces, many of which are not necessarily the best known works of these composers, including suites from Purcell's operas "King Arthur" and "The Fairy Queen" and the Water Piece In D of Handel, which, if it seems at all familiar (and it should), is a loose arrangement of themes of the composer's D Major Suite from the Water Music collection.  Befitting the royal nature of these works, and the fact that numerous of these pieces are in the very royal key of D Major, it will surprise nobody that the timpani have their place, which is enough to put even 21st century audiences back to the turn of the 18th century.In all honesty, I have to say that I am not ordinarily a fan of too many period instrument performances, because I feel that there are times when, well-intentioned as they are in bringing the works of two or three centuries ago back in what might be conceived as the way they actually sounded back in the day, they feel rushed, as if the performers and the conductor were off to a fire sale they didn't know about.  Here, however, I think an exception has been wisely made, because grandiosity is the order of the day; and Pinnock and his English Concert, who made a huge impact with their recording of the original all-wind version of Handel's Royal Fireworks Music, do a solid job of bringing the grandiosity of these works.  Similarly, Ms. Balsom's trumpet playing, on the valveless natural trumpet of the Handel/Purcell period, is as good as it gets when it comes to period instrument authenticity.Even if you're not normally into such authenticity, this recording is still highly recommended for its ability to put the listener back in time to when royalty was the name of the game in England.

It is arguably the best film ever made for television, and one of the most terrifying and sweat-inducing movies of any kind every made.  It is DUEL, that superb 1971 masterpiece of suspense directed by a young man from Phoenix, Arizona named Steven Spielberg, concerning an average businessman (Dennis Weaver) being terrorized and stalked along desert highways in Southern California by the unseen but clearly psychopathic driver of a greasy gasoline tanker truck.  It is the ultimate daytime nightmare as brilliantly conceived by veteran science fiction and horror writer Richard Matheson.And now, it is the subject of an entire book--and an excellent book.Writer Steven Awalt looks in thorough and exacting detail at how a story that began with a frightening encounter that Matheson and fellow writer Jerry Sohl had on a canyon road in Ventura County on the day of the JFK assassination with a monstrous-looking rig, and culminated with the airing of DUEL on ABC on the night of November 13, 1971.  Not only does he include the close-in details of the storyboards and the locations (all in the isolated canyon areas that lie between the San Fernando Valley and the western Mojave Desert), but he got interviews from Spielberg, Matheson, Weaver, the film's producer George Eckstein, Billy Goldenberg (who composed the film's nightmarish avant-garde score), and DUEL's first assistant director James Fargo.  In reading this book, alongside a viewing of the film itself, it is remarkable that DUEL went from first frames exposed to airing on ABC in less than ten weeks, which seems extremely incredible nowadays, if not downright ridiculous, even for television.  And everyone moved quite fast to make it happen, on a tight shooting schedule, and a budget that would absolutely not cover the catering on most Hollywood films nowadays.  But the end result was a classic of the suspense thriller genre, and the launching pad of Spielberg's film career, which has continued to flourish well into the 21st century.This book is a thoroughly fascinating look at the making of a great movie, and is well worth getting, especially for true cineastes and Spielberg fanatics.

During the early 1990s, Irish pianist John O'Conor and the legendary conductor Sir Charles Mackerras made a number of recordings for Telarc, with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, of nine Mozart piano concertos (17, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23,24, 25, & 27) that, while they may not have necessarily been revelatory, were nevertheless excellently crafted, and among the best that the particular concertos in question had received in their time.  This particular recording is of perhaps best known of all of Mozart's keyboard concertos, and his final one.The C Major concerto, No. 21, is a quintessential work not only in the arena of the piano concerto as Mozart imagined it, but a pivotal work in that entire field.  Framed by lively and energetic outer movements, which make prominent use of trumpets and timpani and allow for pianistic virtuosity, the inner slow movement of this concerto was elevated to "big hit" status in 1967, when Swedish director Bo Widerberg utilized it in his romantic movie ELVIRA MADIGAN.  Not surprisingly, that is the (admittedly anachronistic) nickname this concerto has because of its cinematic use.  The 27th, in B Flat Major, omits trumpets and timpani, and was the last of the concertos that Mozart composed for the piano (he premiered it in early 1791, just ten months before his untimely demise).  The work is shot through not only with virtuosity, but also with a certain kind of poignancy.All the elements of these two concertos are bought out by O'Conor, Mackerras, and the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, an ensemble very familiar with the works of the wunderkinder from Salzburg.  This is what, for me, makes this Telarc recording well worth having, even if you already have other recordings of these concertos in your collection.

Gustavo Dudamel's (thus far) five-year tenure as the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra has been, quite simply, extraordinarily unique in the way he has done things.  Of course the same thing could be said about Zubin Mehta, Carlo Maria Giulini, Andre Previn, and Esa-Pekka Salonen (Dudamel's immediate successor); but Dudamel has really set the bar high, not only for the L.A. Philharmonic, but for a lot of other young music directors of the world's major orchestras.  The recording that Dudamel and the orchestra made of the Mahler Ninth, one of the most emotionally extreme symphonies in the entire repertoire, was one of the best recordings of 2013, classical or otherwise.  And this recording of John Adams' combination opera/oratorio "The Gospel According To The Other Mary" is on that level for 2014 as well.After the 1982 recording of Giuseppe Verdi's opera "Falstaff", which was done with Giulini on the podium, this is probably the longest and biggest recording the L.A. Philharmonic has ever taken on, running to two hours and thirteen minutes.  But this very contemporary work from one of America's finest composers, a continuation of themes first broached in Adams' previous Nativity piece "El Nino", is rendered quite vividly, with the stories of Mary Magdalene and Martha given a contemporary touch, thanks to Adams and the staging of Peter Sellars (who handled similar duties on "El Nino").  And it comes complete with a solid cast: Kelley O'Connor as Mary Magdalene; Tamara Mumford as Martha; and Russell Thomas as Lazarus, along with countertenors Daniel Bubeck, Brian Cummings, and Nathan Medley.Along with great assistance from the Los Angeles Master Chorale, superbly prepared by their director Grant Gershon, Dudamel and the L.A. Philharmonic prove why they are one of the great conductor/orchestra combines of our age.  Is "The Gospel According To The Other Mary" a masterpiece?  Only time will tell, and I think that's up to the gods of music.  But for my tastes, it is definitely one of the great recordings of 2014, classical or otherwise.

Believed to have been composed between August 1775 and January 1777, the Concerto In E Flat Major for two pianos technically counts as being the tenth of Mozart's twenty-seven concertos, that huge and prodigious body that would set the standards for all piano concertos from Mozart's time forward.  Although it is not performed with the same frequency as his later works (especially the final eight concertos, 20-27), this "Double" piano concerto, believed to have been composed by Mozart for performance by him and his sister Maria Anna ("Nannerl"), is nevertheless a fascinating experiment of Mozart's, one that requires a pair of solid keyboard virtuosos to do (and for the composer's Seventh piano concerto, you needed three soloists).Fortunately on this 1984 Teldec recording, we have the required two keyboard virtuosos, both of whom come from very divergent musical backgrounds.  Austrian-born pianist Friedrich Gulda came from a classical music background and began exploring jazz later on in his life; while Chick Corea is one of the best-known pianists in American jazz music, and, like fellow jazz musicians Wynton Marsalis and Herbie Hancock, developed a great feel for classical music.  The two men first got together for joint performances; and for this recording, they reconvened in Amsterdam to record Mozart's Double Concerto with the Concertgebouw Orchestra and conductor Nikolaus Harnoncourt.  Also added on this recording (since the Mozart is only twenty-five minutes long) are two works for two pianos, each written by the soloists themselves: Gulda's "Ping Pong"; and Corea's "Fantasy For Two Pianos".Both of the two-piano works make for very solid encores that combine classical and jazz very brilliantly, and on the Mozart they acquitted themselves quite well with what is still (even after nearly two hundred forty years) a very innovative  work, proving that Mozart wasn't content at resting on his laurels.  Harnoncourt, often the target of criticism for taking liberties with many of the Classical-era works he recorded that many reviewers have found bizarre and even perverse at times, here plays it straight in his conducting, with the Concertgebouw Orchestra being at its usual world-class best.This is highly recommended.

Knowing that his symphonies were much too large for audiences of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to understand, Gustav Mahler was fond of remarking, "My time will come."  And it did.  But it took a couple of World Wars, and a thorough going over by such conductors as Otto Klemperer and Bruno Walter, who knew Mahler when they were young men, for all of that to happen.  The true Mahler revival really came in the 1960s, when those conductors plus others like Rafael Kubelik, Leonard Bernstein, and Zubin Mehta took up the cause.  And one orchestra in particular was seemingly tailor-made for Mahler's gigantic symphonic pallet.  That orchestra was Amsterdam's Concertgebouw Orchestra.Perhaps no orchestra has ever had the kind of intimate history with Mahler that the Concertgebouw has, and this goes back to Willem Mengelberg and Edward van Beinum, who also knew Mahler quite well.  During the acceleration of the Mahler revival in the late 1960s and early 1970s, the orchestra was led by Bernard Haitink; and their surveys of the Mahler symphonic canon were extremely acclaimed.  One example can be found in this recording of Mahler's Firs Symphony.Known by many as the "Titan" Symphony, and for good reason (though the composer dismissed the appellation after initially approving it after he had composed it in 1888), it bears many of the early hallmarks not only of Mahler's output but also of what music would be like for much of the 20th century.  The eerie depiction of dawn, signaled by a high `A' in the strings, hunting horn calls, and the like in the first movement is then followed by a second movement Scherzo highly influenced by the Austrian dance form known as the Landler.  In the third movement, the dark side of Mahler emerges in a distorted D minor riff on the French nursery rhyme "Frere Jacques"; and as that dies off, the fourth movement begins with an almost apocalyptic scream and eventually evolves into a firestorm, capped off by a final chorale that sounds much like the "He shall reign forever and ever" passage of the Hallelujah Chorus in Handel's "Messiah."Both Haitink and the Concertgebouw had recorded the Titan Symphony once before in 1962; but this recording, made in May 1972, is really one of the most solid ones this work has received, on par with this same orchestra's 1987 rendering of it with Bernstein on the podium (for Deutsche Grammophon), though not quite as extreme.  Not counting the Fourth, the Titan Symphony is probably the most popular of Mahler's nine examples of his gigantic symphonic vision; and this 1972 recording of it is incredible proof of why that is.  The sheer professionalism and intensity of the performance is a marvel to behold.

Director Walter Hill's 1993 film GERONIMO: AN AMERICAN LEGEND was one of the finest Westerns to be released in the wake of the huge successes of DANCES WITH WOLVES and UNFORGIVEN.  Taking a very even-handed look at the U.S. Cavalry's hunt along the US/Mexico border in the mid-1880s for the maverick Apache warrior known to his people as Goyakla, but know to us "White Eyes" as Geronimo, the film is quite rich with authenticity and realism in a way that hadn't been seen with too much regularity in Westerns or action films since the days of Sam Peckinpah.  It is a shame that it was only a modest box office hit when it was released in 1993 (though a very good Western released at roughly the same time, TOMBSTONE, may have had a little bit to do with that).One of the ways that GERONIMO: AN AMERICAN LEGEND works so well is because of a key component of Hill's creative team, and that is roots music legend Ry Cooder.  Cooder, a mainstay of what we now call "Americana" since the mid 1960s, provided Hill with an ultra-traditional country/folk score for the director's violent 1980 opus THE LONG RIDERS.  For GERONIMO, the music here is a mixture of military brass band music, American folk songs ("Poor Wayfaring Stranger"; "Battle Cry Of Freedom", etc.) and authentic Native American music, the latter featuring "shaped note" orchestrations by George Clinton.  In not too dissimilar a fashion from what Leonard Rosenman did in integrating Native American influences into his score for the 1970 western A MAN CALLED HORSE, Cooder's integration of such influences helped to increase the authenticity of the film--authenticity being something that Hill (like Peckinpah before him) was a stickler for, but also which Hollywood studios weren't known for.  It can also be compared to the way Jerry Fielding mixed in ethnic Mexican influences for Peckinpah (THE WILD BUNCH; BRING ME THE HEAD OF ALFREDO GARCIA); and just as Fielding's approach wasn't really appreciated fully in his time, neither was Cooder's for this film--save for the true film music connoisseurs.It would seem that this soundtrack score is out of print everywhere else but Amazon.  And that's why anyone with a fondness for ethnic American music, especially when revived from the distant past as it was by Cooder for this film, should get it without hesitation.

Up until the late 1960s and early 1970s, a great deal of the music-listening public didn't realize how significant a composer of symphonies Franz Schubert really was.  Unless it was his Fifth, Eighth, or Ninth symphonies, most of the public didn't know that the young Vienna native, during his short life, had been able to work in a discipline that had been mastered by legends like Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven.  This, of course, has changed, with more orchestras and conductors willing to explore this aspect of Schubert's career.  One of the most prominent, and, for many, controversial conductors in this aspect is Nikolaus Harnoncourt, who recorded the Schubert symphonic cycle for Teldec in 1992 with Amsterdam's Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, of which this recording is a part of.The Third Symphony, in D Major, even for the work of an eighteen year-old, which is the age Schubert was at in 1815 when he composed it, is one of the least known of the symphonies, even though, in terms of orchestral proportion and format, it isn't so terribly far removed from its models, with a highly enjoyable slower second movement, and a third movement that is a cross between a Minuet and a Scherzo, plus a Beethoven/Rossini-influenced finale.  The two other symphonies on this recording, the chamber-like Fifth (which might be seen as Schubert's Pastoral Symphony), and the two-movement Eighth (the legendary "Unfinished") are the ones that audiences are the most familiar with; in many ways, like several of Beethoven's symphonies, the Unfinished is a work that looks forward towards Brahms, Bruckner, and Mahler.The reason Harnoncourt's interpretations of Schubert are controversial in some quarters lies in the perception that he takes a number of eccentric liberties, in part based on his original background in period-instrument practices, that are rather bothersome to some people.  Those aren't evident in the Fifth or the Eighth, where he largely plays it straight (though there is a drop-off in sound at the end of the first-movement exposition of the Fifth).  In the Third, though, he does seem to emphasize the loudness of the trumpets and the timpani in the opening movement and the final two movements in a way that many find jarring, and understandably so.  There are solid recordings of this symphony available that are less emphatic than Harnoncourt's, both by U.S. orchestras: Kurt Masur's with the New York Philharmonic (also on Teldec), and Raymond Leppard's with the Indianapolis Symphony (on Koss Classics).Still, the classical recording market is still not as flush with Schubert symphonic cycles as it is with those of Beethoven or Mahler; and there are only a handful of individual recordings of the early symphonies (and even fewer by our own American orchestras).  So for all its rather strange eccentricities, this Harnoncourt/Concertgebouw recording is still worth searching out.

Along with some of the broken works of Erich von Stroheim (GREED) and Orson Welles (THE MAGNIFICENT AMBERSONS), director Sam Peckinpah's 1965 Civil War-era Western MAJOR DUNDEE, the gritty and somewhat violent sagebrush epic of an obsessed Cavalry officer (Charlton Heston) out to prove himself by forming a ragtag mix of Union officers, Confederate prisoners, and other miscreants to hunt a murderous renegade Apache named Sierra Charriba into a Mexico occupied by French forces in the last six months of the Civil War, is one of the best known examples of the Hollywood studio system nearly bringing to his knees an admittedly truculent director with a vision far different from the studio (in this case, Columbia) and the producer (Jerry Bresler).  Time has been far kinder in recent years to this film; even though it is still a flawed film, and a problematic one, it does show the path that Peckinpah would take from THE WILD BUNCH onward.But one of the reasons Peckinpah was so infuriated with both Columbia and Bresler over MAJOR DUNDEE, and one of the reasons why he for all intents and purposes disowned it, is in the music score by the Russian-born composer Daniele Amfitheatrof.  Almost certainly at the insistence of both the studio and the producer, since Peckinpah was only working on his third film (and first with a large budget), and had none of the creative controls that many directors, Peckinpah included, would insist on in later years, Amfitheatrof composed the score in a way that would be quite appropriate for a traditional cavalry western, with refrains of "Dixie", "The Battle Hymn Of The Republic" and such, and with a good deal of martial music (one theme of which resembles nothing so much as "Three Blind Mice") and a signature three-anvil "ping" sound meant to represent Charriba's presence, complete with Mitch Miller's Sing-A-Long Gang doing the "Major Dundee March" ("Fall in behind the Major", etc.).  In a way, it's like the scores of Dmitri Tiomkin or Richard Hagerman (the latter of whom worked with John Ford).  It was from a time when films had wall-to-wall music in them, even in sequences where it might have been better not to have it there.All this is good and fine...again, for a traditional cavalry western.The problem, however, is that MAJOR DUNDEE is not a traditional cavalry western by any stretch of the imagination.  It is much harder-edged, more fraught with tensions, and the violence is much more in evidence.  It was a film that needed a score that was much grittier and more enigmatic--something akin to what a composer like Jerry Fielding (who would work closely with Peckinpah soon enough) or Jerry Goldsmith would be able to deliver.  It was also a big reason why, when MAJOR DUNDEE was re-released to DVD in 2005 for its 40th anniversary, it had a brand new score on it as done by Christopher Caliendo.  The bottom line is that Amfitheatrof's score is serviceable as it is, but it doesn't really fit the movie it goes with.What would be most interesting, and what should be done in the future, is to have both this score and Caliendo's more ethnically-inclined 2005 score put on the same CD, as had been done for the 1976 western THE LAST HARD MEN (with the original and unused Leonard Rosenman score, and bits and pieces from previous Goldsmith scores), for comparison's sake, and let the individual listener decide which one is more appropriate to MAJOR DUNDEE, a troubled but very worthy mid-1960s Western opus from a director whose stature would soon loom large over the way Hollywood would do Westerns and all other kinds of action films from the late 1960s to the present.

Much of opera, like all the best art of any kind throughout history, has dealt with issues of the human heart; and occasionally that falls into politics, whether it is in the high Italian comic opera of Mozart's "The Marriage Of Figaro" or the struggle fro freedom in Beethoven's "Fidelio".  And in our time, there is longtime movie music composer Don Davis' "Rio De Sangre" (or "River Of Blood").Davis, a native of Orange County here in Southern California, is remembered for his work in motion pictures, from helping with the orchestrations of DIE HARD 2 and TITANIC to eventually doing his own scores for the Warchowski Brothers' MATRIX films, and in 2001, with John Williams' hearty approval, JURASSIC PARK III.  With all these successes in a field that is not only not fully understood but still not highly regarded as "serious" music in all quarters, Davis was taking a huge risk in not only doing an opera, but one with a political subtext to it that comments on many recent events.  But with help from a very solid librettist in Kate Gale, that's what he did here.  "Rio De Sangre", sung totally in Spanish, is set in an unnamed country in Latin America racked by war, violence, and a military coup d'etat that the characters are caught up in.  Even for opera, this is fairly heavy subject matter; but again, like all good art, it makes a comment on contemporary issues that are not so easily ignored.  In this recording, its world premiere, the opera is given a first-rate treatment by Milwaukee's Florentine Opera Company, which had also given us a magnificent performance of William Aldridge's opera "Elmer Gantry" a couple of years ago as well, and a solid cast.  Joseph Rescigno is on the podium to conduct the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.Because of its Latin American setting, Davis' music is chock full of Latin influences like meringue and salsa, much like the scores of films set in Latin America.  The end result in "Rio De Sangre" is an opera of enormous brilliance for our time, and one just plain worth acquiring, tragic though the story may be.

Without a doubt, director Stanley Kubrick's 1971 film A CLOCKWORK ORANGE remains one of the most controversial and disturbing movies of all times.  Alongside Sam Peckinpah's STRAW DOGS, released also around the same time (near the end of 1971), it was a scathingly intellectual and blackly comic film about the nature of crime, violence, and sex that offended a great many people on both sides of the Atlantic.  And much of that film's impact, not surprisingly, came from the way Kubrick integrated classical music into the internal fabric of the film--albeit much more cynically and ironically (and for good reasons too) than the way he had used it in his earlier 1968 sci-fi masterpiece 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY.Beginning with the ominous, futuristic, and synthesized adaptation of baroque master Henry Purcell's "Music For Queen Mary's Funeral" in the arrangement by Walter (later Wendy) Carlos, of the landmark 1968 album SWITCHED ON BACH, the soundtrack contains a mixture of straightforward orchestral versions of well-known pieces, such as the Pomp And Circumstance Marches 1 & 4 of Sir Edward Elgar, Rossini's Thieving Magpie Overture, and parts of the second and fourth movements of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, along with weird electronic versions of Rossini's William Tell Overture (heard in that wacky ménage-a-trois that Malcolm McDowell has with the two girls he brings home, shot at warp speed by Kubrick), and the aforementioned Beethoven 9th excerpts as arranged by Carlos, as well as one of Carlos' own ultra-futuristic pieces ("Timesteps").  The bizarre and dark comedy of the film also allow for off-the-wall pieces like Terry Tucker's neo-Renaissance "Overture To The Sun" and Erika Eigen's "I Want To Marry A Lighthouse Keeper" (heard in the home of McDowell's parents after he has been released from his "treatment") to fit into the proceedings that maybe only Kubrick could have ever figured out.  And at the conclusion, we have the famous use of Gene Kelly's original version of "Singing In The Rain."The use of electronic and synthesized music here must seem a peculiar oddity in our EDM (electronic dance music) society, as compared to the early 1970s, but it definitely fits in here, since the film is more or less set in a very clinical near-future England.  In particular, Kubrick's utilization of the Beethoven 9th, especially its fourth movement "Ode To Joy", in both electronic and orchestral form, became the film's musical calling card, as Richard Strauss' "Also Sprach Zarathustra" had become for `2001"; and its use here was said to have inspired director John McTiernan to persuade Michael Kamen to use that piece in the 1988 blockbuster action film DIE HARD.Despite what some see as outdated electronica, and to what now seems an allegedly "tame" horrorshow on ultra-violence, the soundtrack to A CLOCKWORK ORANGE still remains quite vital and powerful, and is a must-have for any serious music connoisseur's record collection, classical, motion picture, or otherwise.

It’s late in 1898, and in Clearwater, Texas, Katie Elder is about to be buried.  Her three oldest sons have been summoned by the preacher, though only two have arrived in time to attend the service.  Or maybe not.Oldest brother John (John Wayne) is a gunfighter of some fame, Tom (Dean Martin, partnering with Wayne for the first time since “El Dorado”) is a gambler who’ll bet on anything and occasionally behaves a little like a con artist, and Matt (Earl Holliman), though much quieter than either of them, hasn’t been home in three years and has apparently made several tries at starting a business, all of which have failed.  Youngest Bud (Michael Anderson, Jr.), almost 18, was his mother’s hope: she connived and struggled to get him to the School of Mines in Colorado—but he doesn’t want to go; though he was almost too young to remember John and Tom when they left (they haven’t even seen each other in a decade), he’s heard enough about John especially to want to partner up with him and “be famous, like the Dalton brothers.”  There’s also some question in the minds of the older boys about the ranch that used to be theirs.  Their father, Bass Elder, though he gambled a good deal and was apparently not a very good provider (even John says “I don’t know how [Katie] put up with him”), somehow managed to acquire 1200 acres of good riverside land, on which the quartet grew up.  Six months ago he was shot in the back—on the very same night he had supposedly lost the ranch at blackjack to Morgan Hastings (James Gregory), who has six witnesses and a signed quit-claim to back his occupation of the land.  To John and Tom, especially, this seems more than a little suspicious.  Hastings even admits that he needed the Elders’ water in order to make a go of his gun factory.  (To his son Dave (Dennis Hopper) he privately observes, “You wanta own a town, you gotta lay out some.”)  And he’s imported a hired gun known as Curly (George Kennedy) to make sure the Elders—especially John—don’t make any trouble before they scatter again.  But scattering is the last thing on their minds.  When they find out that their mother had proposed a bold horse deal with Charlie Bob Striker (Rhys Williams) of Pecos, they persuade him to let them try to carry it through so they can at least get enough money to pay for Bud’s schooling and fulfill their mother’s dream.  Then the respected veteran sheriff Billy Wilson (Paul Fix) is killed while on his way to question the boys about a Wanted poster issued on Tom, and his overconscientious young deputy, Ben Latta (Jeremy Slate), organizes a posse.  Sentiment against the Elders is high, and Ben decides to take all four of them to the U.S. Marshal at Laredo.  But what he doesn’t know is that Hastings has already suborned his drivers, and an ambush on the road brings the four brothers to the very edge of death.Well supplied with both action and humor, this is one of Wayne’s better later movies and has something to say about family and what it means.

Make way for the guinea pigs!  Darwin (Sam Rockwell), Blaster (Tracy Morgan), and Juarez (Penelope Cruz), plus their computer expert Speckles (Nicolas Cage), a star-nosed mole, and their “eye-in-the-sky,” Mooch (Dee Bradley Baker), a housefly, are G-Force, a very special team of agents trying to earn accreditation by the FBI.  They were assembled and trained by human Ben (Zach Galifianakis), who was clever enough to realize that animals do talk—to each other, in their own languages—and, with his assistant Marcie (Kelli Garner), was able to create a computer program that converted their sounds to English, plus a dazzling arsenal of miniaturized equipment for them.  Obviously, tiny rodents are much less likely to be noticed sneaking into buildings than humans are, and Ben has high hopes that a forthcoming Bureau inspection will not only renew his funding but legitimize his “guys.”  In quest of this, he sends the team into the headquarters of home-appliance mogul Saber (Bill Nighy), who’s been under investigation by the Bureau for the last couple of years.  And in the secret inner circuits of the company computer they find something that looks to them like a program for world domination.  But when the Bureau team arrives, it not only rebukes Ben for an “unauthorized search,” it cuts off his funding and orders him closed down.  At first the team is threatened with becoming literal “guinea pigs,” but they manage to sneak aboard a nearby delivery truck and join the “stock” of a pet shop, where they meet the overweight Hurley (Jon Favreau), a food-loving guinea pig, Bucky (Steve Buscemi), a hamster who’s thought to be part ferret, and a trio of tuneful mice (Hoyt Yeatman IV, Max Favreau).Desperate to get back to Ben and try once again to prove their worth, the guinea pigs get separated from one another, and Speckles is thought dead.  But once on the loose, Darwin discovers something very sinister about Saber appliances—they actually come to life, and with obvious belligerent intent.  With bare hours remaining until the sinister program activates, the team must find a way to recover their equipment and, pursued by the FBI, get into the corporate computer to insert a virus that will bring the whole thing down.  This delightful and fast-moving take on spy/caper movies features an engaging trio of heroes, rapid-paced action, wonderful gadgetry, and a great twist at the end.

Leonard Nimoy (who also served as co-executive producer and co-writer of the original story) and William Shatner were 60 when this movie was released, DeForest Kelly and James Doohan were 71, Nichelle Nichols was 59, and most of them were beginning to show their age, or at least sound like it (notice how rough Nimoy's voice often sounds), so it's not surprising that it was the last of the franchise to feature the original crew.  In fact, at several points Kirk and McCoy mention that they're retiring in a few months.  But if they had to go out, at least they do it with a bang, and in doing so they lead directly in to the situation that will obtain in ST:TNG.Sulu (George Takei) is now captain of the "Excelsior," and apparently the only one of the old company who's still in space.  While on a routine mission, his ship detects a massive explosion on Praxis, an industrialized moon of the Klingon homeworld, Kronos.  Two months later Kirk (Shatner), McCoy (Kelly), Scotty (Doohan), Uhura (Nichols), and Chekhov (Walter Koenig), along with several other members of Starfleet's high command, are summoned to a briefing by Spock (Nimoy), who reveals that the occurrence has doomed Kronos itself: in 50 Terran years the planet will exhaust its oxygen.  Faced with this massive humanitarian (or should that be Klingonitarian?) crisis, Spock, urged by his father Sarek (Mark Lenard), has been in contact with the Klingon rulership and has managed to set up a peace conference.  The Klingon Chanceller Gorkon (David Warner) will be coming to Earth--and the Enterprise has been chosen to escort him.  Despite objections from some of the officers, notably Adm. Cartwright (Brock Peters), and Kirk's own misgivings ("I've never trusted Klingons and I never will," he says, noting that he's been unable to forgive them for killing his son, David Marcus), he and his bridge crew are still Starfleet officers and must go where they're sent.  With a new Vulcan navigator, Lt. Valeris (Kim Cattrall), they set off for the rendezvous point.Following a state dinner lubricated by entirely to much Romulan ale, the Klingon ship is suddenly attacked by torpedoes, then boarded by two figures in magnetic boots who begin firing on Gorkon and his crew, inflicting heavy casualties, including the Chancellor himself.  Enterprise's databases insist she fired the torpedoes, but none are missing from her payload.  Kirk and McCoy beam over to try to save Gorkon, but his wounds are too serious.  The Klingons accuse them of plotting assassination, arrest them, and take them to Kronos for trial, where they're found guilty and sentenced to life at hard labor in the dilithium mines on Rura Penthe, a bitterly cold planetoid where survival on the surface is virtually impossible.  It's up to Spock, Scotty, and the rest to find out the truth about the attack and rescue their fellows--who, meanwhile, have been contacted by a fellow laborer, Martia (Iman), who offers to help them escape.  But Martia may not be all she appears.There's plenty of action, as we've come to expect, in this last outing for Kirk & Co., yet we also learn that Klingons care for justice (perhaps a natural outgrowth of an honor-obsessed warrior culture): they provide their prisoners with a defense attorney who seems to be sincere about his work.  And it turns out, too, that in this Universe Sherlock Holmes really existed: Spock reveals that "an ancestor of mine" once declared that "Once you eliminate the impossible, whatever remains, no matter how incredible, must be the truth."  His efforts at detection, aided by the rest of the bridge crew, are a high point, and of course the effects, the aliens, and the music add immeasurably to the enjoyability quotient.

In 1969, Penny Chenery (Diane Ladd), a Virginian by birth, is living in Denver, married to lawyer Jack Tweedy (Dylan Walsh) and the mother of four—two teenage daughters and two elementary-school sons—when word comes that her mother has died.  Returning to the Thoroughbred farm where she grew up, she finds her father (Scott Glenn) sliding into dementia and her brother Hollis (Dylan Baker) talking about selling out.  But Penny’s a horse lover, and she knows that two of the farm’s mares are in foal to Bold Ruler, a horse known for his speed but unable till now to sire anything with staying power, a gift she hopes the Chenery mares can provide.  When she learns that her father’s will includes a codicil leaving the disposition of the farm to Hollis but that of the horses to her, she knows she has the leverage she needs—because what is a Thoroughbred farm without horses, and where are horses to live but on a farm?  Willy-nilly, Hollis and Jack must accept that Penny will run the farm even if it means missing out on much of her family’s lives.The following spring, one of the much-anticipated foals proves to be a chestnut colt whom everyone on the farm calls simply Red, but whose official name (after some wrangling with the racing authority) is Secretariat.  Though he “loves to run,” he loses his very first race, at age two, but with the subsequent help of French-Canadian trainer Lucien Laurin (John Malkovich) and his countryman jockey Ronnie Turcotte (Otto Thorwarth), he wins seven races in four months and is named Horse of the Year.  Although some believe that the longer races in which three-year-olds are entered will be his downfall, Penny and groom Eddie Sweat (Nelsan Ellis) never lose their faith in him, and in 1973 he sweeps the Triple Crown, the first time any horse has done so in a quarter-century—and sets records in each of the three races.The pace of the movie is somewhat slow, but Penny’s stubborn resolve and her evident love for her horse are inspiring for family viewing, and the race sequences are thrilling.

If we ever harbored any doubts that J. J. Abrams’s new Trek franchise was taking place in an alternate Universe, this second movie should lay them to rest.  During it we learn that Spock (Zachary Quinto) and Uhura (Zoe Saldana) are, or have been, apparently physically involved, and that the planet Vulcan was destroyed at some point in the recent past (how and by whom is not revealed, although Spock is never said to be the last of his race; there were probably millions of Vulcans in Starfleet or on colony worlds who survived).  And Kirk (Chris Pine) and his hotshot young crew, including Sulu (John Cho), Chekov (Anton Yelchin), and Science Officer 0718 (Joseph Gatt), who appears to be a cyborg, not only endure the loss of their patron, Capt. Christopher Pike (Bruce Greenwood)—who, of course, lived on into Kirk’s 30’s in the classic TV series—but find themselves confronting one Khan Noonian Singh (Benedict Cumberbatch) long before they did so in the original Trek reality.When a supposed Starfleet archive site under the city of London is destroyed, protocol requires that all Starfleet’s senior captains currently on Earth meet at Fleet HQ to discuss the act and its repercussions.  It takes Kirk’s quick, unconventional mind to realize that the sabotage may have been bait to get them to do exactly that—but not soon enough to prevent a violent commando assault that kills Pike.  Kirk manages to cripple the attackers’ small ship, but the leader gets away with a personal transporter unit (much advanced from the kind the Fleet uses: it can, and does, send him lightyears away—to Kronos, the Klingon homeworld).  Eventually the Enterprise crew discovers that Khan is a product of the eugenics effort of some 300 years ago, bred to be a superior example of humanity with a warrior’s thought processes, and later found and revived from suspended animation by Adm. Marcus (Peter Weller), whose daughter Carol (Alice Eve) has wangled her way on board.  Marcus, it seems, believes that Starfleet’s peaceful exploratory mandate is insufficient to meet the building threat of the Klingons, who have attacked several planets in the Federation sphere, and plans to use Khan and the Enterprise to launch a war.  In the end, after Spock has somehow contacted his alter ego Spock Prime (Leonard Nimoy)—how is never clarified—a savage space battle ensues between the Enterprise and Marcus’s heavily modified ship, on which Scotty (Simon Pegg) has stowed away, and Kirk must risk his own life to save his crippled ship in a twist ending that will astonish and delight viewers who’ve enjoyed the original franchise.  The door is left open for still more entries—I hope that there’s some intention to explain who was responsible for Vulcan’s fate.  The special effects are, of course, a lightshow unequalled since the Jefferson Starship played the Fillmore, and the score is majestic and thunderous.

There’s a celebrity making news (or should that be “mews”?) in Mercy, S.C., and he has four legs and a tail.  His name is Clyde, and he’s a huge, sweet-tempered orange tabby cat who has just walked more than 200 miles (it took him two months) to return to his master, Norm Jeffreys, who had sent the cat to live with his sister while he endured the last stages of liver cancer.  When he got to Jeffreys’s door, though, the man was already dead.  As Jillian Hart’s good friend, Deputy Candace Carson, observes, “if not for Clyde, his body would still be lying there undiscovered.”  But it’s now been three days since Clyde’s return, and the authorities are still investigating Jeffreys’s death, which makes Jillian think they suspect foul play.  Meanwhile the local animal shelter, where Clyde has been lodged until it can be decided who should have custody of him, is besieged with TV reporters, so Jillian has agreed to have Clyde smuggled into her house and take care of him until his future can be decided.As it turns out, foul play did indeed take place: the bottle of digitalis in Jeffreys’s home didn’t contain enough pills for when the prescription was last filled.  Who overdosed him, how, and why?  Says Candace, “He was gonna die, but apparently not soon enough, according to someone out there.”  When Clyde slips out of Jillian’s house and once again homes in on Jeffreys’s, Jillian and Candace find the man’s home-health aide inside, murdered.  Digitalis OD could conceivably be an accident, or even suicide, but Buford Miller’s death wasn’t.  Meanwhile Jillian and her not-quite-fiancé, Tom Stewart, discover that Norm Jeffreys left an estate of “at least a million dollars,” which, as Jillian realizes, might well be a motive for murder.  But was he killed by the same person who killed Buford?  Dealing with a pushy Asian-American reporter who sees Clyde as her steppingstone to national fame, as well as with a constellation of Jeffreys relatives either odd or unpleasant, Jillian soon finds her home security system compromised, her house broken into, and Clyde on the loose again.  Long-buried secrets are revealed as she, Tom, and Candace pursue the missing feline.  A nice sound entry into the Cats In Trouble mystery series, with a good unexpected double twist at the end.

In the sixth Magical Cats mystery, it’s early December in Mayville Heights, Minnesota, and librarian Kathleen Paulson finds life good.  She’s decided to settle in permanently as head of the local library; she and her sometimes guyfriend, Detective Marcus Gordon, have finally come to an understanding about Kathleen’s tendency to get involved in Marcus’s cases; and Rebecca Nixon, one of Kathleen’s best friends, is going to marry her childhood sweetheart, Everett Henderson, after nearly 50 years of yearning.  Then, at a fund-raiser for one of the library’s juvenile programs, an unexpected guest—Dayna Chapman, who happens to be the ex-wife of Burtis Chapman, another of Kathleen’s friends, and the long-estranged mother of his sons—dies of an allergic reaction after eating a cupcake.  Why she even came back to Mayville Heights is a mystery to everyone, including her ex, and how pistachio nuts (the trigger for her reaction) happened to get into her cupcake when baker Olivia Ramsey is herself allergic to cashews, is another.  But the police lab discovers that all the chocolate cupcakes in the box from which Dayna took her treat were coated with pistachio oil—which suggests that somebody intended to kill her.  When Burtis’s son Brady is suspected of being that somebody, Kathleen and her two mysterious cats, Hercules (who can walk through walls) and Owen (who can make himself invisible at will), get involved in the investigation.  As Kathleen notes, both cats “somehow knew what was a clue and what wasn’t,” and they guide her past assorted red herrings until she discovers that the murder actually ties in to a long-ago robbery.  Like Kathleen herself, you’ll probably be surprised at the killer’s identity.  A sound, enjoyable entry into an interesting small-town cozy series.

This entry into the Marvel mythos takes us back to the dark days of World War II, specifically 1942, where we meet Steve Rogers (Chris Evans), a "90-pound asthmatic" from Brooklyn who, in his boyhood, "didn't know enough to walk away from a fight" and consequently spent most of his life getting beaten up.  Now he desperately wants to serve his country, and a factory job isn't enough: he wants to fight.  He's tried five times to enlist, and been rejected each time.  Then he's noticed by Dr. Abraham Erskine (Stanley Tucci), a refugee from Germany who, apparently unaware of the Fuhrer's plans for world domination, originated for him a serum that can make an ordinary man into a "super soldier"--and worked, to a point, on its first subject, Johann Schmidt (Hugo Weaving), but also transformed him into the grotesque, crimson-skinned Red Skull, the head of a secret military program called Hydra.  Impressed by Steve's devotion to his country, Erskine gets him into the program, and the serum works even better this time: suddenly Steve's cells can regenerate (thereby curing his various maladies), he can bend iron, punch through armored glass, sprint at 40 MPH, toss grown men around like beanbags, and jump 50' or more.  But a German spy has infiltrated the audience, and Erskine is killed and his machines destroyed.  "He promised me an army," growls Col. Chester Phillips (Tommy Lee Jones), "and I got...you."  Unwilling to risk the only super soldier the US is likely to have, he sends Steve off on a tour to drum up the purchase of war bonds.  Then Steve learns that his lifelong buddy, Bucky Barnes (Sebastian Stan), has been captured by the Germans while trying to put a stop to Hydra.  Helped by British MI5 liaison Peggy Carter (Hayley Atwell) and wealthy defense contractor Howard Stark (Dominic Cooper)--probably Tony "Iron Man" Stark's great-grandfather--he sets out on a lone commando raid and manages to rescue some 400 men being used by Schmidt as slave labor.  But in the process he learns that Schmidt has somehow obtained a mysterious artifact (supposedly "left on Earth by the gods") which he has used to create weapons that literally disintegrate their targets in a flash of blue lightning.  What's more, he's decided that with it he can make himself--not Hitler--the master of the world.  Now it's up to Steve--"Captain America"--to find and obliterate Schmidt's hidden weapons factories, and stop him before he can take off in his giant flying wing, the Valkyrie, to destroy New York and Chicago.As always, the special effects are great and the characters, despite their fantastic powers, retain comprehensible human emotions that make it easy to root (or hiss) for them.  It would have been nice to know something more about Schmidt's artifact--what *is* it, really?--but presumably even he wasn't quite sure how it got where he found it.  And, of course, there's plenty of fast, violent (but not graphic) action.

The original Anthony Hope novel on which these movies were based was the founding father of a string of "Ruritanian romances"--swashbuckling adventure tales of, usually, an Englishman or American who finds himself in a picturesque European kingdom somewhere within a day's train travel from Paris, and gets involved in intrigues, usually falling in love with a princess or noblewoman by the way.  It's been filmed in two classic versions--one with Ronald Colman in the leading dual role, the other, 15 years later and in lush, vivid Technicolor, with Stewart Granger, but both with virtually identical scripts.  (There was another movie in 1979, and a mini-series in 1984.)  In 1897, Englishman Rudolf Rassendyll (Colman/Granger), a retired officer in Her Majesty's service and member of a noble family, travels to Ruritania for some trout-fishing, wanders onto the royal game preserve in the province of Zenda, and there is discovered by Col. Zapt (C. Aubrey Smith/Louis Calhern) and Capt. Fritz von Tarlenheim (David Niven/Robert Coote), military attaches to King Rudolf V, who is about to be crowned in the capitol city of Strelsau.  Thanks to an affair between Rassendyll's great-great-great-grandmother Amelia and their mutual great-great-great-grandfather Rudolf III, the two men are not only fifth cousins but virtually identical--which proves to be fortuitous, for the King's wine is drugged that night and in the morning he's still out like the well-known light.
