If he doesn't appear for the coronation, his jealous half-brother, Prince Michael, Duke of Strelsau (Raymond Massey/Robert Douglas), will proclaim himself Regent, set the King's cousin, betrothed bride, and heir apparent Princess Flavia (Madeleine Carroll/Deborah Kerr) on the throne as Queen, and then force her to marry him so he can sit on the throne.  If Rassendyll will consent to pose as the king, however--just for 24 hours or so, till the drug wears off--Michael can be confounded.  Reluctantly, he agrees--only to find that when Flavia presents herself to swear homage to him, he falls in love at first sight.  Then, when he and Zapt return to the King's hunting lodge, they find that he's been abducted.  Unexpected help comes from Antoinette deMauban (Mary Astor/Jane Greer), Michael's mistress, who knows that if he marries Flavia she'll never have him, and is willing to go into exile with him if it will save his life.  But the king is imprisoned in the fortresslike castle of Zenda, stronghold of Rupert, Baron Hentzau (Douglas Fairbanks Jr./James Mason), who has an agenda of his own.  And will Rudolf be willing to rescue him if it means losing Flavia?Rassendyll's and Flavia's love ("I love you now with all my heart," she says, "when I never even liked you before") always seems rather implausible to me, but the intrigues of the story, the twists and quick action, make it enjoyable simply as adventure, and in that spirit I can recommend it.  It's also, like almost all pre-1970 movies, a good family flick and may even provide talking points about love and duty.

There are scams, there are stings, and there are capers, and this movie grafts the last onto the comedy-Western and succeeds delightfully.  It’s 1877, and Sam Whiskey (Burt Reynolds) is a gambler, drifter, and jack-of-all-trades who can never resist a bet or a pretty woman, and often gets in trouble for his pains.  Born in a snowstorm while his parents were crossing the plains, he was orphaned in infancy and raised by a saloonkeeper who, apparently ignorant of his real name, called him “Whiskey” for the barrel that was his first cradle.  He’s also a veteran of the Union Army who “shot Ben Pinkerton in the leg once,” apparently by accident, since Ben holds no grudge; in fact, he’s recommended Sam highly to Laura Breckenridge (Angie Dickinson), the daughter of a well-regarded family who needs a man to do a very unusual job.  It seems that her late husband decided to finance a filibustering expedition by stealing $250,000 in gold bars (a bit over 1300 troy pounds, or 975 standard ones, at 19th-Century prices) from the Denver Mint and replacing them with gilded lead.  The gold was loaded onto the riverboat Bonnie Blue, which sank in 15 feet of water in the middle of the Platte River.  Now the Mint is scheduled to begin coining the supposed gold it holds—which will mean the discovery of the lead.  Laura wants the base metal replaced with the real gold (which, of course, first has to be pulled up out of the wreck) before the substitution can be found out (though why she fears her husband will be connected with it is never explained).  And she’ll pay $20,000 to any man who can do it.Sam recruits Jed Hooker (Ossie Davis), a literal black smith, and an old friend from his Army days, O. W. (Oliver Wendell?) Bandy (Clint Walker), a soft-spoken, well-read, bespectacled, and incredibly strong inventor (he’s developed an automatic corn sheller, a household fan, and something that looks suspiciously like a Gatling gun (actually patented in 1862)), and sets off to dredge the gold up from the Platte—which brings on a confrontation with Fat Henry Hobson (Rick Davis), a smooth-talking river pirate with glasses that look more like Mason jars than anything, and a gang of river trash (led by Del Reeves and Anthony James) from whom Sam barely manages to rescue his partners.  From there it’s on to Denver, where Sam must impersonate a Federal inspector (Woodrow Parfrey), fool the Mint’s director (William Schallert), and figure out how to sneak the gold into the vault and the lead out under the noses of a detachment of military guards.  How he does it is worthy of the best caper artists in modern literature.  Despite some risqué moments between Sam and Laura, this is primarily a quite family-friendly movie that might make a good double feature with “Who’s Minding the Mint?”

Originally published as a six-chapter magazine serial in 1949 and paperbacked eight years later, this is the story of a man who knows he was unjustly condemned but can't clear his name without blackening someone else's.  Captain Dan Gentry has been court-martialed and cashiered for supposedly leading his 20-man detachment, which was bringing vitally-needed remounts to Fort North, into a canyon where a band of renegade Apaches trapped and effectively massacred them: only Gentry and his sergeant, Tim McCune, survived.  What Dan knows quite well is that it wasn't he, but his lieutenant, who gave the order.  Unfortunately the lieutenant was the beloved son of Dan's CO, who is in ill health--the shock of learning the truth could kill him--and has been Dan's hero ever since they first met, during the Civil War, when Dan was only 15 and served under the man for the first time.  So Dan has made a conscious decision not to tell the truth, which means he has no option but to go far away and try to start over.  But before he can get away from the Fort and the nearby mining camp, a train of freight wagons is likewise attacked and wiped out--except for one man who escapes, and a girl whom Dan finds in the wreckage of her wagon, undiscovered by the hostiles.  Three of the wagons were loaded with hardware--stock for the new store to be opened by Caleb Ash, part-time cavalry scout and full-time horse rancher, whose purse will only be fattened when the Army has to replace the horses lost with Dan's detail--and Ash claims it's paid for, to the tune of $1820 wholesale, and therefore his.  The girl, who says she was the wholesaler's daughter and kept his accounts, says different, even after Ash produces a receipt.  Now Dan begins to get suspicious--once may be bad luck, twice may be coincidence, but three times is definitely enemy action.  Is Ash connected to these occurrences?  Is he tipping off the renegades about prime targets so he can profit?  And how can Dan prove it without destroying Major Fitzhugh's picture of his son's character?  With only two allies--Sgt. McCune and saloonowner Mike Clears--he has to try.As always, Dawson weaves a deft plot full of intriguing twists and decisive coincidences, with a hero who thinks quickly and creatively but is far from sure of himself.  This is one of the author's lesser-known Westerns, but a very good one just the same.

The final volume in the Intellectual Devotional series offers 365 capsule biographies--one for each day, except Leap Day--of "the world's most celebrated, brilliant, despicable, and memorable characters."  There are leaders, philosophers, innovators, villains, authors and artists, rebels and reformers, preachers and prophets, beginning with the Pharaoh Khufu (aka Cheops) and going on to Benazir Bhutto.  The bios are arranged in roughly chronological order (if it had been me, I'd have sorted by birthdate), and each includes the subject's dates and major accomplishments (although I noticed a couple of omissions in that of Theodore Roosevelt, hardly surprising in a man who wore such an assortment of hats in his busy life), plus two or three "additional facts" at the bottom of the page.Of the 365, only eight were still living at the time of publication: Desmond Tutu, the Dalai Lama, the Unabomber, Mikhail Gorbachev, Margaret Thatcher, Radovan Karadzic, Gunter Grass, and Vaclav Havel.  Of course, as in all such lists, your mileage may vary; personally I'd have ignored these and included instead Christopher Columbus, Beethoven, Robert E. Lee, Martin Luther King, Jr., John F. Kennedy (for getting a man on the moon, facing down Russia in the Cuban Missile Crisis, and establishing the Peace Corps), Lyndon B. Johnson (for Vietnam and the Great Society, though the latter was something of a bust), Hitler (who almost singlehandedly caused World War II), and Jawaharlal Nehru.  The print is a bit small, which may cause problems for some readers, and the index would have been improved by bolding the page number on which each bio actually appears.  But it's still an interesting assemblage of influential people, and longer than many.

Tim O'Hara (Bill Bixby) is a young Midwesterner who relocated to California after college and became a reporter for the Los Angeles Sun.  One day, assigned to cover an attempted supersonic test flight, he oversleeps, and while he's still on his way to the base, the plane is passed “like I was standing still” by a UFO.  The base CO, not wanting to foster another UFO story, refuses Tim any information about the flight when he arrives, and Tim has no choice but to get off the base.  On his way home, *something* screams by overhead and crashes in the brush by the roadside.  When Tim goes to investigate, he finds a small one-man spacecraft and its pilot—a very humanoid Martian (Ray Walston).  Seeing that the Martian is badly shaken by the crash, Tim—without any thought of broadcasting his find—takes him home to the three-room apartment he rents over a double garage belonging to Mrs. Lorelei Brown (Pamela Britton).Thus begins an unusual friendship.  To fend off the curious, Tim presents his guest as “my Uncle Martin.”  Since the spaceship was badly damaged by the crash, and its repair will require assorted elements and devices that Earth hasn't discovered yet, he hides it in the padlocked bay of the garage and offers the Martian the hospitality of his home.  He learns that the Martian civilization is very advanced (“about 30,000 years” ahead of Earth) and that Martians have a long slate of fascinating powers—among other things, Martin can read minds, understand animal languages, levitate just about anything by pointing his finger, and vanish by extending a pair of silvery antennae.  He's also 450 years old and “a professor of anthropology specializing in this primitive planet”—he's been visiting since at least Shakespeare's day.Before long the two have grown genuinely fond of each other, though their relationship is fraught with problems--everything from Martin's odd ailments (like the time he comes down with VDM-974, or Vitamin Deficiency in a Martian, or gets a toothache in his eye tooth and it affects both his vision and his levitational powers), his attempts to get back home (either by repairing his spaceship or hitching a ride in someone else's), and the difficulties of protecting the truth about his identity (how do you apply for a driver's license if you're a Martian and Martians don't have fingerprints?).  They also have to and fend off the attentions of the widowed Mrs. Brown, who finds Martin very attractive.  But they also learn from each other--Martin introduces Tim to both hard science and high culture, and Tim helps Martin to understand humans and discovers such truths as that trying to change yourself into something you're not for someone else's sake will never lead to happiness.  Of course the whole thing is played for laughs, but there are also morals hidden in the scripts (many of the episodes were written and/or directed by James Komack, with whom Bixby would team in the following decade for "The Courtship of Eddie's Father"), and at root it's the story of a friendship--how it develops and grows and how important it becomes to both the parties.

In this book, explains its author, you'll find "beautiful, strong and honest names of American men and women who made their mark in our nation's past, demonstrated great acts of personal courage, accomplished important things in life, and have shone as beacons of inspiration."  Rather a tall order, but in fact Danforth assembles a very respectable list--Presidents and First Ladies, signers (of the Declaration of Independence), military figures, authors, artists, actors, scientists, explorers, sports stars, politicians, inventors, musicians, and even a few slightly scandalous types like the 19th-C. actress and dancer Lola Montez, some of them born here, some elsewhere, including "many heroic Americans you never knew about."  (I can think of one I'd have added: Casimir, after Casimir Pulaski, the Revolutionary-era "father of American cavalry," which could be shortened to Cass.)  With each entry she provides the derivation of the name, foreign forms, variations, nicknames, and at least one capsulated essay on a famous bearer of it, with his or her dates and something of their claim to fame.There are a few errors of fact which a good editor or proofreader might have caught; for example, diet maven Adelle Davis's dates should be 1904-74, not 18; Kansas was no longer "Indian Territory" when Laura Ingalls Wilder went to live there; Brigham Young did become President of the Mormon Church (in 1847), but he didn't run for the US version in '44 (Joseph Smith, the founder of the church, did); Clinton Hart Merriam was born in 1855, not '85; the Flathead Indians were not Cree; Ernest Hemingway commanded a French village militia unit, not US troops; Kit Carson did have two Indian wives, but he also had a Spanish one from New Mexico.  (It's this carelessness that makes me give the book four stars instead of five.)  However, like Lorilee Craker's "A is for Atticus," it's a baby-name book that's both uniquely focused and interesting to read on its own account.

Based on fact (the Denver & Rio Grande and Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroads really did get into a rather messy argument over a pass called Royal Gorge in 1878-80; it was ultimately settled in court, with the D&RG being allowed to lay the tracks, then lease them to the AT&SF to operate trains on), this is the story of how a man's private quest for truth and justice plays out against the larger events.  Bourke Rold comes to Pueblo in '79, heading for Canon City to find out how his brother Frank ("the only family I ever had") really died (supposedly he drowned, but he was a good swimmer).  Finding his old commander, General William Palmer, the President of the D&RG, visiting the town in his private car, Bourke stops in for a courtesy call and finds himself hired to keep an eye on one of its tie contractors who sold out to the other side before signing his current contract.  The contractor, Tom Kimbrell, turns out to be rather suspiciously interested in buying up the freighting company that was co-owned by Frank, and the doctor who examined his body died unexpectedly only two days before Rold gets to town.  Coincidence, or did someone want to make sure he didn't talk?  Meanwhile Rold's fiancee has come looking for him--and the Army, from which he quietly absconded when he heard of Frank's death, would like to have a few words with him too.  Then there's the question of why Frank was calling himself Ames, not Rold.  Dawson, as always, builds a surprisingly complex plot filled with apparently minor choices that make all the difference.  A good sound Western with a hint of mystery and a cast of outstanding characters, each an individual.

“I'm lucky,” says six-year-old Eddie Corbett (Brandon Cruz).  “Most kids have fathers who are just dads.  But I have a father who's my best friend.”  Eddie's mother died some time ago (we're never told exactly when or of what, although Eddie remembers her telling him that it was his job to look after his father, a charge he interprets as meaning he has to help "find girls" for his dad to date; he was probably about five, because he apparently hasn't been to kindergarten, and when it comes time to enroll him in first grade, his dad wonders if it's “too soon”).  His father, Tom (Bill Bixby), is the 32-year-old managing director of “Tomorrow,” a newspaper-insert magazine.  They live in a high-rise apartment in Culver City with a breathtaking view of L.A., and their Japanese housekeeper, Mrs. Livingston (Miyoshi Umeki), who comes in by the day, calls Tom “Mista' Eddie's Fatha” and has succeeded in teaching Eddie to speak rather respectable Japanese (their exchanges tend to leave Tom baffled).  Peripheral members of the family are Tom's free-spirited art director (and Eddie's honorary uncle), Norman Tinker (played by series producer and occasional writer or director James Komack), and ditzy secretary Tina Rickles (Kristina Holland).Bixby and Cruz bonded almost instantly, and the chemistry between them is very real (indeed, the show's success spurred bachelor Bixby to get married and have a son of his own).  This is one of the last of the gentle, old-fashioned “family” sitcoms that could address problems in a semi-serious way, but it also has a definite late-'60's/early-'70's vibe, and with seldom more than two guest stars, it also has a cozy, intimate feel.  Many of the episodes focus on the kinds of problems endemic to child-raising, such as when Eddie is branded “teacher's pet” after Tom begins dating his teacher, or on bullying (a very young Jodie Foster appears as Josephine “Joey” Kelly, whom he, of course, can't hit back when she beats him up), first-day-of-school jitters, honesty, responsibility, academic stumbling blocks, following one's conscience, or the concept of generosity with one's possessions; but, as the title suggests, many others come from Tom's and Eddie's search for “a new mother for us.”  Eddie has all the innocent frankness of his age and sometimes speaks before he thinks, but he's also very good-hearted (once, concluding that Mrs. Livingston is “all alone,” he brings home a little Japanese boy to be her son), bright, and eager to please, and he and Tom spend a lot of time together (the teasers and tags show them on a variety of father/son excursions, from the beach and the amusement park to sailing and fishing to exploring the zoo and a large aviary, usually with Eddie asking questions).  This is a sweet, enjoyable sitcom that everyone can enjoy.

Deputy U.S. Marshal Merlin Fanshawe is back for a seventh adventure, but still in many ways the bronc-stomper and cowhand we met in "The Bodacious Kid," almost a decade ago (six years in his time).  He's also a little down, for his long-time lady friend, Pandora Pretty Hawk, has grown "tired of waiting and worrying during my long absences, and married another."  That may be why he proceeds as he does when his boss, Chance Ridgeway, sends him to the rich and bustling town of Butte to find out whether a tip that wealthy mineowner Marcus Daly has been targeted by a professional killer is true.  The informant, Digby O'Dhoul, is rather too fond of the bottle, but the fact that he's recently disappeared makes Ridgeway suspicious--why would such an inconsequential person vanish unless someone had reason to fear his wagging tongue?  Merlin learns that O'Dhoul did in fact go to Butte, where he has relatives--and was recently found dead, an apparent suicide.  The local law seems to think it's an open-and-shut case, but Merlin's not ready to give up so easily, especially after he meets Digby's sister.  Then he remembers a snippet of information that Ridgeway included in his description of the dead man, and realizes that it must have been murder.  Now all he has to do is find the killer and prevent Daly's death--but how?Lynde provides a vivid description of what was then the biggest and richest town in the Montana Territory, and a large cast of fascinating characters, including Daly himself, whom Merlin finds to have the common touch, and Karen Killgallen, a visiting actress who can "perform parts written for both men and women, in voices ranging from a bass to a lilting soprano."  If you're like me, you won't guess the killer's identity any sooner than Merlin does, and the twist at the end will leave you startled.  This is one of Lynde's best to date.

The pseudonymous Peter Dawson, although he wrote a long string of Western novels, was also the author of well over 100 short stories that were published chiefly in the later pulp magazines.  Despite the time pressures of this kind of work (a pulp author had to grind out a lot of product in a comparatively short time if he hoped to make a living at it), his stories are tightly plotted and surprisingly polished, almost like miniature novels in themselves.  This volume collects six of them: "The Bullet," in which Sheriff Tom Marolt must break a ring of stock thieves or find himself ruined by a prickly editor's prose; "A Notch for Bill Dagley," whose title character finds himself caught squarely in the middle of a war between two big outfits; "Stone Walls," in which Yuma parolee Lee Anders is forced into a marshal's job even though he's not allowed to wear guns; "Doc Gentry," whose title character wearies of "digging Wagon Hammer lead...out of people" and makes up his mind to practice a little hot-lead surgery; the title piece, which follows Joe Dorn in his efforts to clear himself and his partner of a charge of rustling; and "Outcast Deputy," the longest, in which Hugh Conner, pushed off his little land claim by the local Big Auger, conceives a clever scheme to get back at the man and finds himself (much to his dismay, since he's wanted) deputized by the new sheriff.  Dawson's prose is brisk and his plots often surprising.

Actually, I'm not sure whether I want to give this book four stars or three and a half.  It certainly has its fun points, but it's not for everyone.  Soon after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, Barry Laverty, new-minted doctor just out of his "houseman" (residency) phase, is "24, single, no responsibilities," and not sure whether he wants to go into general practice or a specialty.  Since most of his classmates have very clear plans, he feels rather an odd duck, so he's answered an advertisement for a doctor's assistant in Ballbybucklebo, a short railroad journey from Belfast.  His first surprise is his new boss, Dr. Fingal Flahertie O'Reilly, a big man with a rough tongue and a boxer's bent nose.  His second is the people of the village, all of them--to put it charitably--originals.  And then there's Patricia Spence, the would-be civil engineer and childhood polio victim whom he meets while on the train to the city for his day off, and who, as he quickly comes to realize, is the Only Girl.The great strength of the book is Taylor's vivid renderings of the Ballybucklebovians, every one an individual: Mrs. Kincaid, a.k.a. Kinky, Dr. O'Reilly's housekeeper, who performs magic in the kitchen; Lady Macbeth, the cat who's left on the doctor's doorstep, and Arthur Guinness, the doctor's Labrador, who has an R-rated Thing for Barry's trousers; the half-dozen patients who come in regularly for a shot of "tonic" (Vitamin B12) in their hindquarters; Maggie MacCorkle, whose headaches occur "a good two inches" above her actual head; Councillor Bertie Bishop, "Ulster's answer to Adolf Hitler," who owns half the countryside and isn't above using chicanery to accumulate more of it; Seamus Galvin, the carpenter who never seems to do an honest day's work, and his wife Maureen, who's arranged for them to emigrate to California; Major Basil Fotheringham, a confirmed hypochondriac, and his enabling wife; Mr. Coffin, the aptly-named undertaker; and a large cast of others.  Barry's cases range from the generally unwell to childbirth, and he soon learns that you have to speak to country folk in a language they can understand--no jargon--and have insight into their real concerns even when they can't clearly voice them.  Like all young doctors, he makes mistakes, but he has his triumphs too.  Above all he has to adjust to the powerful personality of Dr. O'Reilly, who would drive many a lesser man away in short order.  But in only a few months they're becoming good friends, teaming up to give Bishop a dose of his own medicine and bring happiness to a girl who's gotten pregnant without benefit of marriage, and O'Reilly is sufficiently impressed that he offers Barry "partner in a year."Readers should be aware that there are a few rather graphically described medical procedures, including a childbirth, but on the whole the book is probably not unlike a human-doctor's version of James Herriot's veterinary adventures.

This Golden Story Book ("128 pages in full color") will delight all young cat-lovers with its five stories (two poetical and three in prose) of cats both real and fantastical.  There's the unnamed young cat who wants more than anything to go to sea, and when three separate captains refuse him a berth on their ships, originates a clever plan that not only gets him the experience he wants but ultimately leads him to a permanent home.  There's Tiger, the "small striped kitten," who lives a vivid life of "pretend," and the little white kitten who longs to be like his mother and his four sisters (all of them black) until he sees a big and very clever white cat "walking down the street with a big fish in his teeth."  There's Terrible Tomkit, the very naughty kitten whose wise grandmother finds a way to improve his behavior, and the Tolliver family, who have "so many cats...that nobody knew just how many there were"--until the cats eat up the family's fish dinner!  Every page is illustrated with lively color pictures by Aurelius Battaglia.

It's darker out where we live, and I just got a new grill and have been waiting to use it. The light was a struggle, so I went searching around here on amazon and found this one. The light is great! The light it provides is nice and bright, and has not let me down yet. Mounts very well with my grill to.
