I purchsed this directly from Samsung and my S4 phone is charging just fine using a Verizon branded WCP-700 Qi charging station I had purchased last year for my HTC Droid DNA.Interestingly enough, my S4 is far less sensitive to how I put it on the charger every night.  I do not think that I have had to "tweak" its placement even once.  With the DNA, it had to be centered exactly or nothing would happen.It is charging even tho it is inside the Otterbox Defender case.  Having two layers of protection is not stopping it from working.It is a bit thicker and stiffer than the original back and the plastic part of the Otterbox case was quite difficult to get it to snap together.  I removed the inner lining of my Otterbox case and it finally fit together, but it is a very tight fit.1 day later and I notice that the sides of my screen protector are starting to bubble.  Too tight of a fit apparently.  I may trim the edges of my screen protector.The unexpected bonus of the tight fit is that I can now fell the S4 vibration alarm when using the Otterbox case.  Very nice side effect.

GoPed is known for their powered scooters and somehow someone put electric in the description here at Amazon, but this is just a plain manual push scooter that will likely be used by your great grandchildren after you (or your young kids) are done with.The 400 lb weight limit and beefy wide wheels (6"x2") make it a good choice for us as my wife and I are over 200 lbs and live in Chicago, where the sidewalks and parks are full of uneven pavement.  6" = 152mm.  Our other scooter has 200mm wheels.  Bigger is better for not injuring yourself on larger cracks.  Smaller is better for portability.  Though 6" is larger than many other folding scooters, I still have had this come to a sudden stop (once).This scooter seemed to be about the only foldable/portable scooter available that we felt was sturdy enough to handle 200+lb adults riding on it for a quick run to the corner Walgreens or keeping up with our kids during our scooter/bike rides without fear of it breaking or catapulting us head over heals at every raised sidewalk edge.  Not having the folding mechanism behind the front wheel, having a solid frame between the two wheels, makes it feel much more sturdy than other folding scooters I have tried.Dual brakes is nice.  A touch more braking power than the rear brake alone.  Especially if you happen to be caught in wet conditions and the rear brake becomes useless.The wide deck makes it much easer to stand with both feet on the deck as you switch feet.Ordering it from Amazon is considerably cheaper (when you include shipping) than getting it directly from GoPed.The top of the handlebars to the top of the deck is 35 inches and the top of the deck to the floor is 3.5"It is a comfortable height for my 6' tall frame.The deck is a about 1 inch higher compared to others so it requires a slightly deeper knee bend to push off.It is also about 1 inch more clearance. The extra height does make it less likely to bottom out as you ride over raised sidewalk cracks.It folds nicely (just pull up on the spring loaded sleeve) and mine came with a black nylon strap that wraps around the rear fender to keep it folded.Also nice is that they sell directly from their website, every single part on it, should something need replaced.I wish it had:- an option for a kickstand, but I see a couple of interesting options on eBay.- 8"x2" wheels to better overcome the larger cracks in the sidewalk (think tree roots pushing up the side of 1 slab)- a deck that was about 1 inch lower without reducing the clearance or the weight limit or increasing the cost (yes I think it is very possible with just a deck redesign.)- somewhere that I can thread a standard bicycle loop-ended cable or heavy duty chain to lock it up on the street.  You can use a U lock behind the front wheel and a very thin cable would fit between spokes in the wheels.<Update: I just rode it to work this morning.  A 10 mile commute and it took 100 minutes including lights and a couple of rest breaks.  It was actually less tiring than riding the bike, which takes 60 minutes with the same unassisted effort.  It is now sitting in my office under a couple of chairs and you would never know it was there.Tho I did use my biking fingerless gloves, I still failed to keep my hands closer to the stem, so I have a blister starting in my palm where the end of the handlebar was digging into my hand.  I need to learn to fight my instinct to seek better steering control by moving my hands out away from the stem.The deck height issue turned out to be a non-issue.  I did not do a deep knee bend on every single kickoff, rather for each knee bend, keeping my body still, I used five to ten pendulum style kickoffs on one side, then switched feet and repeated followed by 2 feet on deck coasting for a while and repeat, thus cutting the number of knee bends considerably.I cannot imagine doing that with a narrower deck. I never tried to "center" my feet.  During the entire trip, my feet never crossed or touched the center line.  I simply kept my foot where it was during the 2 footed coasting effort.  Less effort that way I figured and it worked well.Unlike biking without a motor, there was no sign of knee pain or saddle sores.This scooter held up well and not once did I encounter a sudden stop due to a crack in the sidewalk, tho my taking a bike path between the cars and parked cars for 90% of the distance help there a lot.  Did not have to worry about getting a flat.  No chain to get my pants or hands dirty.Did not have to bring tools or spare parts to fix anything.  Did not have to bring heavy chains and locks.  Did not have to spend time locking it up.  As I passed Home Depot, I realized how easy it would have been to simply stop at any store along the route.  Much easier than it would have been had I ridden my bike. Saw more than I usually saw since I was going 1/2 the speed.  Rode the entire distance with my backpack on the handlebars strapped tight as they would go with the sternum strap also as tight as it would go.Shared a cab with co-worker on the way to a meeting on my way home and had no problem putting this and my backpack between my legs and wound up with a conversation starter.Got tired on the way home, hopped a train in the middle of rush hour (no bikes allowed then) and the conductor had no issues with my tucking this and my backpack between my legs on a crowded train.Nice.  Other than it seemly taking forever to get anywhere (compared to biking with a motor) and a blister, I encountered pretty much no negatives, all positives.>

I have had this pen in my front pants pocket with my keys every day for about 3 years now and it is small enough that I never even notice that it is in there.This pen does not write as smoothly as any of my pens in my desk, but it does write very acceptably in nearly every scenerio I have wanted it to and has never failed me yet. It has never leaked.  It has gone thru the washer/dryer and still works afterwards and it did not create any ink stains. Would I be willing to carry any other pen in my pocket at all times on the chance that I may leave it in my pocket to be washed?I have never been able to say any of this about any other pen.In storage mode, it is small at 3 3/4" x 3/8" with an extra 1/8" width for the clip, so it fits nicely in the zippered pocket in my phone holser.In the writing position it is 6 3/8" long and respectably thick.  It feels like any other normal pen and has a nice weight/balance to it.I do wish it had a flat side because it rolls away quite easily and the clip (my first one came with a clip) will get lost quickly because it just slides right off.

Mine came with a 5v 0.7 amp wall wart with a 5' cord and micro USB end. It also came with a clear plastic case for carrying the fully charged battery around protecting the battery.Having a separate charger means being able to charge the dead battery later and without having to remove the protective case and backing to do a 2nd battery swap in order to charge it within the phone.So far, I do not see a difference between using the 2 amp charger that came with my S4 and the 0.7 amp charger that comes with this box.  Either way, it seems to take about 2 hours to fully charge my battery. It is difficult to remember to keep an eye on the unit to tell when it turns green to be certain however.

So far, I have received 2 MHL 1.0 EPL-3FHUBE adaptors inside a MHL 2.0 ET-H10FAUWEGWW box (via ebay) and 2 MHL 2.0 adaptors that have both worked beautifully (at least until I broke my first one).  All of them came with a snap-on ferrite core to reduce magnetic/electrical interference.I have tried both the ET-H10FAUWEGWW (via ebay) and ET-H10FAUWESTA (via Samsung's website) and both of them have the same model number stamped on the unit itself and use the same UPC/EAN#: 8806085519558.The box from Samsung has a holographic sticker on it that none of the others had, saying Samsung Original Mobile Enhancement and it was the only one without a plastic tray.With my Samsung S4, I am getting crystal clear 1920x1080 60Hz edge to edge display (with no over/under scan) on my home made 15.6" 1920x1080 monitor as well as our Samsung TV set via an HDMI cable.HDMI to DVI has been a particularly difficult challenge with MHL 1.0.  However with this MHL 2.0 adaptor, I am getting the same 1920x1080 60Hz signal on both my Flatron W2246 and Dell U2212HM.I can also listen to the sound via the phone's headphone jack while it is plugged in (since monitors do not have speakers).I have not needed to provide power to the adaptor.  There is a micro usb port for power, but I have not needed to use it (unless I want to charge my phone).Nowhere on the box does it specifically say it is for MHL 2.0, but the description on various websites say that this is the main reason for this adapter's existance.Note that it is designed for Samsung's 11pin micro MHL 2.0 pin configuration, which I do believe that no one else is using yet.  Which means it is for the Samsung Note II, S3 and S4 and that is about it right now. Only the S4 however will utilize the MHL 2.0 aspects of this adaptor. With the Note II and S3 it is supposed to behave just like the MHL 1.0 adapters that have been out for a few years now.I have been on a quest since I first got my HTC Droid DNA to have an Android Phone project a 1920x1080 image onto portable monitor for remote desktopping so that I can stop carting around my very heavy, very expensive (please do not steal this if I leave it in a hotel room or the car while on vacation) notebook computer.Turns out the HTC Droid DNA was not quite capable of this, so I got the Samsung Galaxy S4 and the SmartDock.  Turns out that the SmartDock would also not spit out a 1080p signal to a monitor.With this adapter, I finally have my solution.  A pocket sized thin remote computer subsidized every two years by Verizon.One downside is that I had to tweak my Otterbox case for the plug to fit as it is wider than any other MicroUSB plug I have seen.

I heard first hand and read many a tale of phones that survived significant falls due to this case and I did not want to pay for insurance any more (especially now that I have multiple android phones available as backups) so I decided to give this a try.The two plastic pieces snap together nicely and come apart well (lift at the tabs).The rubber that wraps around these two plastic pieces seems to be a very good material and should last a long time and should have no problem with being removed and replaced many many times.  Plus it make the phone feel good and non-slippery in hand as you use it.The clear screen protector was okay, but I did eventually remove it and the double sided tape that held it into place came off quite well with little to no residue.  I put on a Steinheil Spigen SGP Ultra Crystal screen protector instead.  There are many advantages to having a screen protector of the highest quality and physically attached to the screen, but the biggest one is that should the screen crack, it will still be usable.  My wife dropped her phone and was able to use it just fine for months with a very cracked screen.  It is now our daily alarm clock.I had to shave and round off and the prongs at the bottom around the USB port so that it would fit into my modified SmartDock, which also has 3 parts removed so that I do not have to take off the case for either my S4 or my wife's Note II.  Well, I have to take the rubber part off of this case, but that is no real issue.  It was also required for the MHL 2.0's rather large MicroUSB plug to fit without removing the case.I am generally afraid to handle my phone without this protector on and with it on, I feel I can use my phone all I want without fear.The belt clip fits well and does not seem like it would break or slide off as easily as past ones have for me.  Update: It has slid off a couple of times these past few months, however the phone is none the worse and I have a tracker enabled should I discover it missing.One negative is that I can never feel it vibrate (keep reading for an update on this point)Another is that the clip is uncomfortable when I do not have a shirt tucked in.Another negative is that, while the clip allows you to stand it up in landscape mode, it is at too sharp an angle (about 85 degrees I'd say... I think 60 to 75 degrees may be better)After getting this Case, I purchased the Samsung EP-CI950IBUSTA Wireless Charging Cover and found that this case does not work well with the thickness of the new back cover.  I finally got it to snap together by removing the inner lining of the plastic case for the back of the phone.The unexpected bonus of the tight fit is that I can now fell the S4 vibration alarm when using the Otterbox case. Very nice side effect.Overall, now 5 months later, I am very pleased with this purchase.

I have 2 Canon BP-809s and I used to be able to charge them just fine with the Canon version of this Canon 2590B002 CG-800 Lithium Ion Battery Charger for 800 Series Batteries (Retail Packaging).However, that charger had gone missing, so I thought I'd save $50 by getting this highly rated charger.Battery 1: even tho this charger says it is fully charged (green light after charging overnight) the camera says it is empty and needs replacedBattery 2: this one also charged over night and turned green but this time the camera says it is only 50% charged.Maybe I just got a bad one.  I returned it, ordered a 2nd Canon 2590B002 and both batteries are charging just fine once again.

Update: The most recent update being pushed by all carriers, including Verizon, now allows MoveApptoSD.  The 16GB internal limit is not as much as a big deal anymore.  Also, Verizon now sells the 32GB version.If you are reading this, you are likely debating between this and the HTC Droid DNA and the Note II (the only three 4 core phones currently available on Verizon).  I have used all three and like all three for different reasons.  I like the pen on the Note II and my wife is completely in love with hers, but I would never use one.  It is just too big and it is not 1920x1080.  My reason for switching from the DNA to the S4 is so esoteric, I am not sure it really applies to 99% of the people that are purchasing phones.  I really do like my DNA.  In many ways, I much prefer it to the S4.My Phone History: I am coming from a HTC Droid DNA and it is generally the same size, so I have no problems at all with the size.  I just cannot see myself carrying a Note II sized Otterbox on my belt.  Before now, all of our previous 6 phones have been HTC smart-phones.Speed: After having the DNA for 6 months, I can already tell you that you will quickly get used to having a 4 core processor and any old single core phone you pick up later will seem irritatingly slow.  The S4 is theoretically faster than the DNA, but in reality I do not really notice a difference in day to day usage.Display: Like the DNA, it has a FHD 1920x1080 display and I have pretty much stopped using anyone else's computer to browse the web when I visit them or even using my own notebook.  Watching movies directly on the phone is a bit mesmerizing.  You see so much detail, you kinda forget that you are watching a 5" screen.Screen Rotation: I find the S4 to be far less responsive to noticing that I changed the orientation from Portrait to Landscape than my HTC DNA and it annoys me no end.Tiny Fonts: Some would have issues with the tiny default fonts, however I like very much being able to see more information on the screen at once and I find it very readable and easy to zoom in whenever I want to make it a bit easier to read (or ensure I am clicking the correct box).Dedicated Menu Button: I do prefer having the menu button as a separate button because so many apps do not integrate so very well the 3 dot icon that appears when a phone does not have a dedicated menu button and the DNA equivalent of the active/recently used apps menu is just as easily reached via the long press on the home button on the S4.  The long press of the home button on the DNA takes you to the new Google Now.Touchwiz: The Samsung software will take time for me to get comfortable with. I have been using HTC phones for many years now and I did like their tweaks to stock Android.  Eventually I hope to get use to Touchwiz, but for now, it is a bit frustrating trying to work with an Android phone they way I am accustomed to.  Many of the screens are still a bit cartoonish compared to the more professional looking HTC equivalents.Web Browser: HTC has auto-text-re-flow when you pinch to zoom.  Samsung does not, but the double click seems to take you automatically to the maximum zoom you can have and still see all the text, so maybe it is just a learning curve.  I cannot get the S4 to always default to DesktopView like I was able to with the DNA, which I find very annoying.  HTC also has a cool swipe in-from-the-side way to reach all the options to remain full screen all the time.  HTC's web browser wins by a mile.Flash: I am able to view Flash content on the web just fine with FireFox (one installs the Flash apk separately directly from Adobe's website).Calendar App:  The S4 wins here easily.  Nice interface.  It includes Tasks from Exchange quite easily, however there is no TODAY button when changing the date of an appointment.Mail App:  I like both, but there is one feature HTC has that I really, really, really miss.  It remembers the folders to which you moved mail recently.  Samsung does not.  I have to scroll and scroll and scroll every single time I want to move an email.  I will likely be forced to rename my folders 01 Personal, 02 Client A, 03 Program A, etc. and keep changing them as my currently active workload demands.Folders:  Another feature that HTC has that I miss is that when you add an app to a folder of apps (e.g. Games A-F) it will automatically hide the icons for any apps that are already in that folder.  Samsung will not and will gladly let you add the same app icon again and again every time you did not realize it was already in there.Clock: On an HTC, which you click on a HTC Clock home screen widget, you are brought to the clock app so you can set the alarm or start a timer.  Samsung's Clock does nothing.  You need to create a 2nd static icon just to get to those options.  Quite odd in my mind.  Quite odd indeed.  However the Transparent Weather Clock apps works quite well.Build in Keyboard: The Default Samsung keyboard has a Swype style keyboard built in AND it has a dedicated number row (very very nice).  I do like the tab below the cursor to easily move the cursor to the position you want.  I am missing having the backspace delete the entire word as Swype does.  It is now a habit and causing a lot of rework.  Swype is also built in and I have just changed to it as the default.  Hopefully, one advantage of having it built in will be that it will work in all parts of the phone's interface.  On the DNA, I frequently find that the app I am currently using is not letting Swype add a space after words automatically soIwindupwiththisasamytextentered.External Keyboard: It is working fine with both my wireless USB Keyboard and my Bluetooth keyboards, however it refuses to let me keep Swype as my default on-screen keyboard when I use and external keyboard.  Very odd and very annoying.Text/Messaging: HTC's app will show the emoticon before you hit send (and they were very cool icons).  Samsung's does not (and they are rather boring and unclear anyway), so I have stopped using emoticons because I have no clue what it will actually look like and have no idea how they would be interpreted by others anyway even if I did as they are so understated and cryptic.I wish the Samsung had another feature that is on my HTC DNA... when I side swipe to get from home screen to the next home screen and I reach the end, the Samsung S4 just stops.  if the app I was looking for was to the right and not to the left of the base/middle screen, I have to rescroll past all the screens I just saw to get back to the right most screen.  On the HTC Droid DNA, they are in a loop.  Scroll to the left from the left most screen and you find yourself on the right-most screen, which I like a lot.Unique Samsung apps: I have no use for gesturing or eye-tracking or DriveMode or many of those features. However, I can foresee liking very much:The temperature gauge and barometer (accessible via the SHealth or WeatherStation apps)The IR to remote control the TV when I cannot find the Remote (have not yet tried)Smart Stay / Smart Pause (Smart Rotation is not quite working for me)S TranslatorMultiWindowSamsung HubAirView for some reason defaults to individual items turned off.  If it is "on" and not working, just dig deeper as there are more option underneath.  I am a big fan of the idea of AirView.  It is the one feature of the Pen on the Note II that was most tempting.  In practice however, it only worked on half of my emails and simply clicking the date in the calendar worked better and it seldom really showed enough to really help anyway.If Found Contact: There is an OwnerInfo section in Lock Screen Widgets to have your name and work phone number scroll across the lock screen, which is VERY nice should you loose it.  For HTC, I had to create a graphic backgroud file.WiFi disconnect - DLink Routers:  Apparently there is a conflict with this phone and D-Link routers.  All Verizon would tell me was to update my firmware in order to maintain a connection (or buy a new router).  However, both were already up-to-date.  It took a few days of trial and error and google searches, but I think that I finally got the S4 and my DLink Routers cooperating (Different high # fixed channels, Mixed n and g, WPA2-TKIP only)SmartDock: The #1 reason I am upgrading so soon from the DNA (after just 6 months) is to be able to use the SmartDock.  This way I can have simultaneous use of OTG (on the go USB hosting) and MHL 2.0 (to view HDMI in full HD glory on any monitor) and charging.  I found the DNA sorely lacking in this regard.  In theory I could stop carrying my notebook now and do real work via RemoteDesktopping while on the road.  For certain I can now play and video/movies (mostly Windows Media Center recordings) on a portable USB hard drive or flash memory stick projected onto any larger monitor using external speakers no problem.  However, I can only get it to output a 720p signal to my HDMI monitor, not the full 1920x1080.  Disappointed.  Fine for movies, but not so much for RemoteDesktopping.  For video at home, instead of copying files to that USB hard drive, instead I use ES File Explorer and MX Player to play any of the video/movie files on our home network onto our bedroom TV.MHL 2.0: Samsung is selling a Galaxy S4 HDTV MHL 2.0 adaptor, just not in the US yet.  I had to order one from HongKong (it is on its way).  Maybe a SmartDock2 will support MHL 2.0.  My hope it to have a 1920x1080 display on my portable HDMI FHD monitor for RemoteDesktopping.  I will just need to find a better bluetooth keyboard.Replaceable Battery: I am also really liking having the ability to carry a 2nd charged battery.  I do not actually have it in hand yet, but in all my phones prior to my DNA, I carried an extra battery around with me at all times and the extra battery I ordered comes with a charger, which will save me my old hassle of swapping out batteries a second time just to keep both charged.  The main reason I like a removable battery: I do not have to bother trying to conserver battery power.  With the HTC DNA, I was so cautious.  I usually wound up with 70% available at the end of the day, but I wanted to be on the safe side just in case.  With the S4, I can thro caution to the wind as I will have a backup available should the battery die.  But so far, I have yet to kill the battery and I only charge it at night.  The nice thing about this being a high volume phone is that you are more likely to find someone still manufacturing new batteries 4 even 8 years from now.Replaceable MicroSD Card: I found that with the HTC DNA, not having a MicroSD card made it annoyingly difficult to back up my information.  I like having a drive letter and the xtra speed when attached to the computer when the card is in a fast USB 3.0 reader.  However, for some odd reason, I cannot access the MicroSD card while it is still in the camera with its own drive letter (the tool I use to compare folders cannot understand "camera mode", no can any other folder comparison tool I have found so far).  With a 64GB card, it is nice to carry around with me the shows no one in our house but me wants to watch, so I can watch them on the train.Flexible back: I like the more flexible plastic back as it makes it easier to change the battery or take out the MicroSD card than it was on my previous phones.  I do not worry anymore that I might break the back.Qi charging:  Samsung sells an alternative back that enables Qi wireless charging.  I have it and it was a very tight fit to get the Otterbox case to snap together, but I removed the inner backing and that helped a lot.  It is very convenient to just lay it down on my Qi charger at night.  It is very generous as to positioning (unlike my old DNA) and as a bonus, the tight fight in my case means I can now once again feel the vibration alarm.  Samsung Galaxy S4 Wireless S Charger Kit (inductive type) - Wireless Charging Black Cover & PadNote that the defaults for storing files (such as Photos) on the SD Card are hidden within the Settings in their MyFiles app.Camera: The S4 does take better noticably pictures than the DNA during my indoor at night side by side test using default and night and HDR modes.  The S4 had richer (and still accurate) colors and more detail.High Volume Sales benefits: Unlike the DNA (or many other phones) and more like the iPhone, nearly everyone makes a version of their accessories for the Galaxy line, so I already had in hand before receiving the phone:Otterbox 77-27434 Defender Series and Holster Case for Samsung Galaxy S 4 - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - BlackSPIGEN SGP Samsung Galaxy S4 Screen Protector Clear Steinheil [Ultra Crystal] Premium Crystal Clear High Definition Front Screen Protector for Galaxy S IV Galaxy SIV i9500  (yes, I remove the Otterbox screen)and soon the: Samsung Galaxy S4 Spare Battery Charger (2600mAh Battery Included)Android 4.2.2: I have been using Android 4.1 for six months now and found it a big improvement over any version prior to that and can easily see (once I fully investigate the changes) liking Android 4.2 even more.  I thought 4.2.2 had multiple login ability (work with password and home without password), but so far, I cannot find it on the S4.Accessories: It comes with the same 2amp charger and 58" cord as the Note2 does as well as a headset with mic built in and a half charged 3.8V 9.88Wh 2600mAh battery.Samsung Account: As you set it up for the first time, it asks if you want to create or sign into a Samsung Account. There are a lot of cool options there: account.samsung.com  It may prove useful if you are new to Samsung to check out this page before you activate your phone (tho you can always create the account later).Date in Lock Screen: Before it will actually SHOW the date, you need to go to Settings/More/DateAndTime/SelectDateFormat and select any one of the date formats.I will keep tweaking and updating this review as I have previous reviews and will generally answer comments soon after you post them.

I got this for my 8 year old because I wanted a scooter that had large softer wheels that can easily handle the cracks in the sidewalk and would be easy for him to apply the brakes with his foot and telescoping handlebars that can adjust as he grows and can easily be taken in the car. For that purpose, I found this scooter with its soft 200mm (7/8") wheels to be the best option out there.My only negative is that, as an adult, I found that the front folding assembly is a bit too loose for my tastes for any long distance riding.  I strongly suspect all those bolts will not be able to handle the stress (as another reviewer has already pointed out, they did fail on him).It rides fairly low.  The good part of that is that it will not be as tiring to repeatedly push off as you ride.  The bad part is that you will scrape the bottom as you come across a section of sidewalk pushed up by tree roots.  For a 70lb child, this will likely not be too much of a problem.  For a 200lbs adult, it may shorten its life considerably.I had no issues with riding it with my 8 year old on my foot holding onto the handlebars, which means that it can handle 270 lbs at a fairly brisk speed without breaking a sweat.  It will likely not last as long and there is probably a 50% increased chance that the folding pins will break, but it did not show any real signs of duress as we were riding it.  The company told me that they are currently working with their suppliers on a design that will support over 250lbs.  The stated max on this scooter is 220lbs and they have no other model that is designed to support more weight.  Now that I have spent some time on this one, I will likely get the 400lbs limit bullet-proof Know-Ped for myself with its much larger deck.To be fair, I should point out all parts are easily replaceable and you can likely make this scooter last forever.  My bicycle is over 25 years old now with over 40,000 miles on it, but almost nothing except the frame is original to the bike that I purchased, so this philosophy is right up my alley.To fold, there are two pins with springs that are pushed in simultaneously as well as a folding locking arm (as you would find on a quick release tire on a bicycle). (Update - 2 years later, it no longer folds).The handles can also be pulled out of the stem.  This is how it arrives in fact.  I suppose it saves a bit of space, but I'd rather see a 1 piece T for better longevity and rigidity.There is also one "ball" style click point for the telescoping handles at full extension.  All other points are strictly controlled with the clamp and there is a groove to keep the handlebars in alignment with the wheel.My size 12 shoes fits just fine on the foot board, but a size 13 may be tight and anything over that will likely require your foot to be at an angle.Another reason I bought this one... I like having a kickstand, tho in practice we seldom used it.. :-)After 2 years, all three of my kids have used it extensively and I have even used it to make a quick run to the local Walgreens for bacon for that morning's breakfast.This was a stepping stone from a 3 wheeled micro mini from this same company to eventually riding a bicycle.  My kids were orignally fearful of going from a 3 wheeled scooter to a 2 wheeled scooter, but all agree with me now that this was the right choice.A big advantage from my perspective is that a 2 wheeled scooter helped them learn how to balance and now, just 2 years later, we went from all three not riding a bicycle without training wheels to having all three riding two wheeled bikes no problem (currently ages 7, 9, 10).  Which means that this scooter is no longer used by anyone, but I feel it was still a good decision and we will likely give it to someone so it can be put to use.

It does not seem as protective as the Sedio Active Case I had on my last phone, but it should work just fine.  Time will tell as experience has shown that I will eventually drop it onto concrete.  I am a bit reluctant to test it tho on purpose.It did push up the edges of my screen protector.  Quite annoying.  Kept pushing them back in/under and the case kept pushing it back forming a long bubble all around my phone.  I did a hatchet job trying to trim the already installed screen protector and that fixed it.  I will likely at some point buy another screen protector and trim it properly before installation.My phone does charge wirelessly with this case on.The one fault (which should be fixable with a Dremel) is that many of my micro usb cables do not fit into the gap provided by the case and I am forced to pry open the opening a bit for it to seat properly.

I was looking for a bluetooth mouse to use with my HTC Droid DNA while operating a Remote Desktop session with Splashtop2.This worked okay, however I returned it.  There was too much of a delay too often to not be annoying.

I was pulled in by books 1 to 3 and loved reading them.  The concept of living in a bunker for generations was intriguing and the books were well written.But around the middle of book 4, the story started to loose it in terms of continuity and believability.  It was actually a chore to finish the series... ("oh come on... really")... just to find out what happened.  They really needed a better independant editor.I am glad I read the entire series.It does end on a happy and optimistic note. Reading some of those reviews could lead you to believe otherwise.  I am not sure those reviewers made it past the sloppy sections to actually read the ending.I probably will read more of his books in this series, tho now that he has his million dollars, I hope he hires a better editor for the remainder.What Hugh SHOULD do is take a page from George Lucas and rework books 4 and 5 and re-release the series somehow.

<Update - this is the 3rd year we have put this up around the tree.  My 10 year old son set it up this year on his own.  Still works as good as new and it does get a good amount of use each Christmas season.>The quality of this set is 10 times better than the Bachmann trainset we picked up at Costco a few years back to put under our Christmas Tree.  The track is 40" by 60".The Hershey theme works well with the concept of little children and Christmas.There are a lot of videos on Lionel's website regarding its operation and maintanance (see comments) and this set came with a DVD as well.The cars interlock very nicely (there is a release under the couplings) and it stays on the tracks very well at high speed, forwards and backwards, and has not yet had a spot on the track where it would stop every time (i.o.w. the electricity flows well from track to track even tho we have cords running under the track to the tree and to the transformer).The smoker and whistle work well, tho we seldom bother with the smoker.There are switches under the engine to turn off the smoker and to make the train go forward only.My only two gripes are related to the transformer.  It always emits a noticable hum, so I want to be able to turn it off when not in use, however there is no off switch.  You must unplug it every time.I solved this problem by using a cheap on-off switch that goes between the plug and the outlet.

This is working perfectly on my HTC Droid DNA.I can see a mirror image of my phone on my HDTV, including every app I tested.I can RemoteDesktop using Splashtop2 at FHD and the text is clear (as with my HTC Media Link HD test, the cheap old dell monitor, the text was fuzzy) and the delay is minimal.I can hear the audio from my phone's headset jack OR the HDMI output device. If I plug in headphones, the sound transfers to the headphones, if I unplug them, the sound transfers to the TV.It works just fine without power, but if I plug in a microUSB power cable, the phone does charge while the HDMI out is functioning.Out of curiosity, I plugged my OTG cable into that micro usb power port, but it did not work.As expected, HuluPlus is the one exception as they have disabled all video out on all Android Devices (except the Vizio tablet), including HDMI, MHL and DLNA.I received the one where the power outlet is parallel to the cord.I tried three different HDMI-less monitors and I could NOT get this to work over a HDMI->DVI adapter (tho there are MHL->DVI cables)

I purchased this for my HTC Droid DNA after sending an email to HTC tech support and receiving a reply that this adaptor would work.It did not even fit into my phone.  Apparently there are two (or three?) different plugs for MHL adaptors.  5 pin and 11 and 12 pin.  The latter has a squarish dual purpose port and the former is a standard micro USB port.

It has been in one of our phones for 48 hours now and it still works like the original battery at a much lower cost.  Time will tell however how long it lasts.Update: 3 months later and now I have an interesting story to tell:I ordered this 4 pack because we have a 4 phone system and one of the phones was acting up.  It says the battery was full, but it had trouble staying connected, so I figure that it was worth trying a new battery.Less than a month after swapping out that 1 battery, the phone started acting up again and I figured that the problem must have been with the phone after all.I looked at the battery and sure enough, it was an original Panasonic battery (not this Fenzer replacement).  It was a different phone acting up.  So the problem was now definately not the phone but the battery and the new battery was fixing the phones.Today, I am 1 week short of having these batteries for 3 months and the last phone started behaving oddly yesterday and sure enough it was the only phone left with an original Panasonic battery and replacing it fixed the phone.  All four original Panasonic batteries bit the dust within 3 months of each other.It is still too early to predict how long these batteries will last. However... so far so good.  For now, I have four fully functioning phones once again for a relatively small amount of $$.

I have used these every day for a few months now and get a nice close shave and seldom cut myself and have no issues with razor burn (tho it helps that I use baby oil as a pre-shave oil).I get my close shave with two passes: one with the grain and again, against the grain and I change out the blade every Sunday morning.It came in a box of 20 packages of 5 blades each and each package looks just like the one you see on the screen.Each plastic box has one side that flips open to reveal a storage section for used blades, however I stored the used blades in a old peanut butter jar, figuring that some day, many years from now, I may send them off for metal recycling.

The shaving cream is soft (not as hard as the stuff I usually use), which I expected, so it makes for a decent travel shaving soap, since you do not have to spend so much effort getting enough soap on your brush to make a good about of foam.However it is not really a travel sized container, as I had imagined.  It is quite large.  However the lid does screw on tightly so I do not have to worry about leaking, so I will continue using it for travel.I have found that I prefer to just put a small amount onto my brush and then whip it into a foam in a larger empty bowl with a touch of water.  I get a mor consistant and lighter foam and use less soap that way.As far as the soap itself is concerned... I do like it... a lot, but for home use, I will stick with the 6 times cheaper bar soap I have been using (at least until I have used up the 12 bars I ordered from Amazon already... I like using it as well).

This book would be very helpful for someone who is an absolute beginner at saving money.  If you have never shopped sales, if you eat out a lot and buy a lot of convenience foods, this book will help you.However, if you already know these basic things, you aren't going to learn anything much in this book.  The "instructional" part of the book is only about 70 pages at the beginning [and quite a bit of that is "introduction" type info on her family and her history of shopping].  The rest of the book is recipes - this is really mostly a cook book, not a book on saving money.I did enjoy reading the recipes - they are quite a bizarre collection.  She has everything from Ethiopian cuisine to Thai Food to a weird hot dog stir fry and lots and lots of recipes using ramen noodles [including using those seasoning packets to flavor the food].  Most of recipes are not especially frugal [most include meat, and sometimes expensive cuts of beef or salmon - things that we literally can never afford to eat at our house].  This is quite possibly the strangest collection of recipes I've ever seen [and I am a cookbook junkie].  But I did enjoy reading the recipes and I found quite a few that I want to try with our family.I agree with other reviewers that said she's exaggerating by saying you can feed your family for $75 a week - there is just no way.  I do think this book will help you shave money off your grocery bill if you are inexperienced with frugal shopping.  But, I don't believe that you will be feeding your family for even close to $75 a week, even if you do every single thing she tells you to do.I was also annoyed that a lot of her "tips" and info were repeated in several places in the book.  For example, her "tip" to puree onions before you put them into foods so that your kids don't pick them out.  This was interesting the first time I read it.  But then, it repeats as a "tip" in two more places.  There were a lot of things like that.  I had the feeling that the author did not expect anyone to actually read the whole book from cover to cover [which I did], and the book repeats itself a lot.However, this book is well written and easy to read.  It is enjoyable to read.  If you are a complete beginner to saving on groceries, this book will be great for you!  If you already do the obvious things to save money on groceries, this book isn't going to do much for you [though you might enjoy reading it anyway].  If you are a veteran frugal shopper, I recommend that you skip this book and get "Cut Your Grocery Bill in Half with America's Cheapest Family" by Economides.  That book is far more comprehensive and has a TON of ideas that you may never have thought of.

This book is fantastic!  I am an experience gardener, living in the Southeast, and I SO wish I'd had this book 20 years ago!  So many gardening books are written for people living in other climates.  It was so wonderful to finally find a book that deals with what *I* struggle with trying to garden here in our beloved hot & humid Southeast!The first chapters on Gardening were very helpful - much of it was good, basic information that I already knew; but I still learned a lot that will help me in my garden.  I think that reading these chapters will definitely help me improve in several areas.Then the "month by month" section in the middle that goes through exactly what to do each month - that is *priceless*!  I'm so excited to have this information just written down plainly for me, without me having to try to adjust for my zone in my head and translate instructions meant for those in the Midwest into what I should do here down South.... this is incredibly helpful!I also loved the end section with specific information on each different plant and how it does in our area.  This was extremely helpful as well.This book is excellent - well written, fun to read, and jam packed with helpful information.  Well worth the money!

This book was mostly too basic to be much use.  It is only about 150 pages, and I was disappointed by the lack of in-depth information.The first part of the book gives a history of financial collapse and talks about what could happen in the future.  Most people buying a book like this are probably already very aware of these possibilities.Then the book moves on to a chapter on Debt Reduction and gives some extremely basic advice on financial management.  You'd be much better off buying a Dave Ramsey book and following that plan.  It will give you a LOT more information.He includes a long chapter on currency, but I am at a loss after reading it as to why I'd want to bother with any foreign currencies.  The author says himself that it is hard to predict which currencies might be used if the dollar fails - and I honestly don't see people  accepting any paper money in a serious financial collapse situation.  I thought this chapter was confusing and did not make a whole lot of sense.So, basically, the first 86 pages of the book were a waste of time, in my opinion.  Then I got to the chapters that were actually helpful [barter and trade goods, bartering skills instead of stuff, safeguarding valuables, & investing in self sufficiency].  Those chapters were very helpful and well written.  I appreciated the information [and they are why this review is getting 3 stars instead of 1or 2].  But when you consider that the  entire book is only about 150 pages long - not getting anything helpful till page 87 was a bit frustrating.  I was left with the feeling that I would have been better off to google a couple of articles on this topic online for free than to pay the purchase price for this book.

This book is not nearly as good as the previous books in this series.This book is not as well written and readable as Mr. Warnock's previous books.  It doesn't flow as well.  I found it much more tedious and less enjoyable than previous books in the series.  I put it down many times and walked away, it did not hold my interest like his other books did.There are also quite a lot of editorial mistakes - the editing was not done well for this book.  [This was not a problem in previous volumes].  This bothered me a lot in a supposedly professionally done book.  For example, on page 67, there is a sentence that reads "Put the on the chest."  An editor should have caught such an error and corrected it.  On page 61, a sentence says "Studies show garlic helps fight some cancers from growing."  This isn't really proper writing.  There were many little editorial errors like this through the book, and I found it very annoying.The book is also poorly organized.  The book begins with a separate introduction for each author.  It is followed by a chapter on "How Herbs Work" and a section on harvesting and using herbs, dosages, et.  Then there is a part of the book that is devoted to a few specific herbs that the authors like a lot.  Each herb has its own mini-chapter.  Then there are mini-chapters on various cures for specific illnesses - broken bones, etc.  These mini-chapters are not that great - too brief to be really helpful, and confusingly organized.This book also continues with the extensive self promotion that was found in the previous books.  I really don't mind hearing about his seed business, but it really starts to be obnoxious when it is mentioned over and over and over again in almost every chapter.  I do feel like I paid for an advertisement in a lot of ways.All of this said, it is a decent primer on some basic herbalism.  I think there are much better books on the market for this; but if you know nothing about herbs, you will learn a good bit in this book, once you get past these other issues.  You would not want this to be your *only* book on herbal medicine though, it is far too superficial.I own all of this author's books, but I don't know if I'll be buying any more than come out moving forward.  The quality of this book was definitely not up to standard.

I thought this book had a lot of great information in it.  And, like the first book, it has gorgeous photography throughout.  This book is a pleasure to hold in your hands and to read - a real beauty and well written.This author is extremely knowledgeable and his books are super easy and fun to read.  They hold your interest and really educate you.  I have implemented MANY of his suggestions in this book already and plan to add many more as the seasons go on.I do agree with some other reviewers with a bit of criticism:  this book is FULL of self promotion.  While a mention or two of his previous/next book or his website would have been fine, he *constantly* mentions them.  He refers readers to other books he's written [and I own all of his books, so that worked for me, but I bet it would have annoyed me horribly if I did not own them].  He mentions his website and his rare seeds ad nauseum.. I mean seriously, in some parts he mentions it on every single page.  [Although, I gotta give the guy credit, because I guess it worked.  I now buy many of my seeds from him... lol!]  It was just a little over the top for me, though, and started to really get on my nerves.  [at one point, I felt I'd paid good money for a long string of advertisements!]I absolutely loved his information on gardening with raised beds and creating them for little or no money.  That chapter alone was worth the price of the book for me.  In general, I love his "voice" in these books and I really enjoy learning from him.  I really like his philosophy on life and on self sufficiency, and I find him an excellent teacher.I will continue to buy his books - just hoping for a tiny bit less self promotion in the ones that follow.

I really wanted to love this book, because I am very interested in growing a sustainable diet.  And there IS good information in this book - I think anyone reading it will pick up some helpful information.But I found this book so dry and hard to read. This is a subject that I feel passionately about - something that I can read about all day long and never get bored.  But, this book bored me.  I kept putting it down and walking away.  [I have still only managed to read about 3/4 of it after 2 months of ownership - usually I devour a book in about 2 days].  The author's writing style is very dry and very "text book".  I think that she is an extremely knowledgeable person, but her writing style does not allow her to convey her wealth of wisdom in a way that is enjoyable to read.The book is also organized strangely to me - for example, jumping right into "garden maps", without really any information on how or why one would draw these maps.  It would make more sense to me to talk about how to set up the garden and why [before drawing a map of it] - but she does not do that.  The chapter on garden maps is really just a collection of rough drawings of her own garden maps and what went where in her own garden.  I did not find this very helpful for my own situation.  In general, I felt like the book did not flow well at all - it sort of jumps around and the information is poorly organized.She LOVES worksheets.  This author would have done well as an accountant, because she is very in to the minutiae of listing things.  She provides copies of lots of different worksheets that she's created that work for her.  I found these tedious, personally, and would have preferred a broader discussion of the hows and whys of figuring out how much to grow to provide for all of your needs..  I felt like a lot of the worksheets were really just common sense things that people could work out on their own [plan around frost dates in your area, for example...].She also frequently references a gardening DVD that she did some years back [which I cannot find available on amazon - not sure if it is still around?].  I had the feeling that perhaps all of this book would have made more sense and been more easy to follow if maybe I had seen that DVD first.  It didn't work well to keep referencing the DVD and talking about the DVD, when most of her audience will not have seen the DVD.In short, this book was useful, but  not nearly as useful as I had hoped it would be.  I recommend "The Resilient Gardener" by Deppe as a much more useful and informative book on this subject.

This book is really, really helpful!  I have been both Paleo and Vegan at different times of my life.  I felt MUCH better, and am healthier, eating Paleo.  But eating all of that meat was really bothering me.  This book makes Paleo Vegetarian easy to do in a healthy way.  I really appreciate it!The book is extremely readable and enjoyable. I liked the author's writing style.  She takes a good, clear, no-nonsense approach to this style of eating.  The book is full of great information to  help you regain good health [and energy and healthy weight] through a Paleo Vegetarian diet.  She covers the pitfalls and things to be aware of.  She has lots of ideas and great suggestions about doing it right.This book makes being a Paleo Vegetarian very do-able.  I'm enjoying this way of eating and I feel absolutely fantastic!

This book is truly comprehensive!  I got it a couple of weeks before I got 2 goats, and it has been a lifesaver!The author writes in a style that is very readable and enjoyable.  I liked all of her "been there, done that" stories in the book.  Her examples were very helpful and interesting.  This book really tells you everything you need to know to get started with goats!One thing I will mention - she does look at goats from a "pet" standpoint instead of a "livestock" standpoint.  She spends a lot of time talking about how cute they are, etc.  This works for me, because our goats are definitely pets, not food.  But it might be a little annoying for someone who is trying to raise a herd of meat goats, for example.I'm really glad I got this book - I think my goats and I will be a lot happier now that I have all of this knowledge!

I found this book extremely useful, and I've been working on self sufficiency for many years now.I can understand some of the negative reviews - the first part of this book is a manifesto about his personal feelings on why self sufficiency is important, why we can't keep living the way we do, how we are killing the planet, etc.  A lot of time is spent in the first section trying to convince people that self sufficiency is important.  [I had already purchased the book - obviously I already agree that it is important!]  He also has some unusual opinions that are pretty strong.HOWEVER, if you get past those introductory chapters, this book is FULL of useful information.  I was impressed by the range of subjects he managed to cover and also by the depth.  I strongly disagree with other reviewers who said this book is too shallow or worthless.  I don't think they really read the book.  I found it extremely helpful.  Does it give you encyclopedic knowledge of every single self sufficiency topic?  Of course not - it isn't a 20 volume set!  But I found a lot of information in this book that I could use, and I've been doing this for almost 2 decades now.  I already had a lot of experience and knew a lot - if I found the book helpful, I think anyone would.  And if I had been a relative beginner, this book would have been an absolute gold mine!This book also helped me rethink my current plans and improve on some of my goals.  It helped me sort out why and how I'm doing things, so that I could do some things better.I also found the book very readable and enjoyable [once I got past the preaching at the very beginning].  The author has a very good writing style and I enjoyed his stories and tales from his past experience.You won't go wrong with this book - it really is great!

These are really good, without that gross "fishy" aftertaste I have found in every other form of cod liver oil or fish oil that I've tried.  These don't give you any bad aftertaste and they still give you all the benefits of the cod liver oil.  I plan to take these for the rest of my life.  I'm so happy to have found this brand!

I am so glad I bought this book!I own a bunch of emergency prep books and I think this one is the most *practically* helpful one I've read.  It does not assume that you are a paranoid loner with a bunker out in Montana somewhere.  This book was written for real people with real lives and real loved ones that they care about.What I loved about it:1.  It gives specific information on every kind of emergency preparation situation you can imagine.  Seriously.  The info is very specific [what do you do to survive if someone detonates a dirty bomb near you?  How about a volcano?  Well, now I know...!]2.  It does not assume that you are willing to sacrifice every other person on the planet to save yourself.  This book tells you how to keep yourself and others safe.  In fact, the book encourages caring for the people around you - not just your family either, but neighbors and others who may need help.  [Personally, I'd much rather live in this author's post apocalyptic world than the world of many of the other survivalist authors out there.]3.  It has great information on prepping for people who may be elderly or infirm or for those who may be caring for the elderly or infirm.  You don't plan to leave Grandma and Grandpa to die when the Big One hits?  You need this book!4.  It gives very detailed, specific instructions on everything related to survival:  from all of the different ways to provide safe water to everything you ever wanted to know about alternate means of heat and cooking to how to know when to Run Away and when to Stay.  It also includes an extremely helpful section on weapons for personal protection.  This book is truly comprehensive in scope.5.  It was easy and interesting to read.  The author is a talented writer who held my attention.6.  This book has the BEST section on prepping with pets and keeping them safe that I've ever read.  I really appreciated that, it was tremendously helpful.  I don't plan to leave my dog to die if TSHTF [and I wouldn't want to be in a survival situation without her actually, she's an incredible asset].  This book really helped me figure out how to account for my dog's safety if trouble comes.  Any pet owner who feels the same would benefit from purchasing this book.7.  It gives realistic information about the government and the assistance the government is likely to provide.  It is not anti-government at all, while also being realistic that the government may not be able to act as quickly as we might like in an emergency situation.  I thought it was fair and balanced and avoided the "tin foil hat" theme which runs through so  many emergency prep books.The book also had some problems, which kept me from giving it 5 stars [aside from these few things, it was definitely a 5 star book]:1.  The editing was very poor.  There were errors throughout the book in spelling, grammar, and formatting that should have been caught by a good editor before it went to print.  The beginning of each section where it includes scary "actual headlines" about different disasters was particularly prone to editorial issues.2.  There was a lot of wasted paper.  It is a big, thick book, but the way it was put together leaves lots and lots of blank space.  If it had been formatted in a better way, it could have easily used about 2/3 the paper it uses, without all the waste.3.  It gets very repetitive in the final section on different disasters to prepare for.  Seriously - the first direction of almost every section was "prepare your 72 hour kit" followed by many other instructions that were exact repeats from other sections of the book.  That got a little annoying - I wish the author had just assumed you'd take the "standard" advice in the rest of the book and had included only information specific to each disaster in the final section.Over all I thought this book was WELL WORTH the money.  I learned a ton of new stuff and I'd already done a lot of learning, reading and prepping before I picked this book up.

Honestly, I didn't expect much from this inexpensive E-book.  [I've ended up with a LOT of bad books that have no business being in print at this price point].I was VERY pleasantly surprised!This is a comprehensive book that gives the history of ghee, the medical benefits, the culinary benefits, how to make it yourself, and includes many wonderful recipes for using ghee.  The author wrote well, the book is easy and entertaining to read, and it really motivates you to try ghee.I enjoyed learning how to make my own ghee and I cannot wait to try these recipes she includes - there are a bunch of them and they all sound tantalizing.This book is well worth the price!!!

I was pleasantly surprised by this book.  I've gotten a little jaded about these inexpensive ebooks because I've gotten so many that were just plain terrible, but this book was worth every penny!This is a great short introduction to the Paleo diet for the uninitiated, and it includes specific advice for switching children over to this way of eating.  This is a fine "quick start guide" for the entire family.  It is well written and fun to read.The recipes are wonderful - I own several Paleo cookbooks at this point and I still found several new, innovative recipes that I had never seen before.  All the ones I've tried have been delicious and I can't wait to try more of them.This IS a short book - I saw one reviewer complaining that she "wished there were more" - but in this price range, this book is actually quite comprehensive.  There are many full length volumes available on going Paleo that include many hundreds of pages and every detail you can imagine, but that's not what this book is.  [Those books retail for many times more money than this book does, this book isn't *supposed* to be a comprehensive encyclopedia of Paleo....].For the money, this is AWESOME bang for your buck - gives you everything you need for a fast start to Paleo living for you and your whole family.  It is complete, concise and a quick read that will help you immediately get started on your way to better health and a better life.

This book frustrated me.  The plot of this book is a mess and the characters are not well done or believable.  [Mild Spoilers Below]The whole premise never made any sense - I read all the way to the end to see whether they'd explain why all these kids die when they are 19.  Nope, no explanation [by the end of the book, I swear I thought they just had them die at 19 so they could have sex at 14 and it not seem creepy].  This is a supposed post-apocalyptic world that just made no sense - never any idea given as to why the world ended, why these kids are in the situation they are in, why everyone dies so young....just nothing to make this world come together and be believable.The characters behaved in ways that were illogical and senseless.  One character repeatedly does something wrong, knowing that she will be exiled from the city and face certain death if she keeps doing it.  And it isn't anything she does consciously or for any purpose, she's just basically screwing around.  She ignores several warnings and then ends up kicked out to die.  Great.  It made no sense at all, especially given the extremely harsh world this is supposed to happen in where only the smart and strong would have a chance to survive to reproduce.  And this particular character was *supposed* to be smart and strong.Throughout the book I kept encountering characters doing things that just weren't rational - it was as if the authors had certain plot points they had arbitrarily decided must happen and they forced the characters to do stupid things that made no sense.  It really annoyed me.  It is hard to enjoy a book when you keep thinking "Nobody would really do that in real life..." or "why would anyone do something so stupid?"I also don't believe that these authors have a very good grasp of how human beings are likely to behave in a real survival situation.  The premise of this book is that these kids work day in and day out non-stop for the main bad guy - doing back breaking, grueling work and handing everything over to him for a handful of basic rations.  Nobody ever thinks "Gee, there's a lot more of us than there is of him, let's take over".  Nobody even thinks of maybe trying to produce some food for themselves...  they just appear to be mindless robots with no human spirit of survival or any ambition of bettering their situation in any way.I agree with other reviewers who said the info in the book on which foodstuffs would have gone bad first and which would have lasted was incorrect.  Not a big deal, but just one more poorly done thing about this book.This book is sold as a "Young Adult" novel - given this, it really annoyed me that the authors put a fully described sex scene in the book amongst two of the young teen characters.  I thought it was inappropriate in this genre [when I read "Young adult" I expect something along the lines of "Harry Potter" or "Percy Jackson" not "Shades of Gray" - OK, it wasn't quite that graphic, but still... no sex scenes in books aimed at young readers, please!]  The whole "romance" was so pitifully done anyway that it was ridiculous.  We are supposed to believe that these two people who didn't like each other and barely spoke, fell madly in love and "partnered" for life within days of meeting each other for no apparent reason....never mind that one of the partners was supposedly mourning the death of his last partner who was killed in a horrific manner - which was supposed to be his whole driving force.  And this couldn't have happened long ago, because their child was still a baby.  Regardless, if this had been billed as a novel for adults, I would have had no problem with the badly done romance and the sex, but not in a young adult book.  I work in the maternity ward of a hospital and I see enough pregnant 13 and 14 year olds as it is - we don't need books making this seem like a romantic, wonderful thing to do.So, I think this book is really pretty terrible and I won't be reading the sequel.  It started as an interesting premise but that's about it, and the premise went nowhere.  The only reason I gave the book 2 stars is because by the end of it I did actually care about a couple of the characters, so there was some small positive in all the negative about the book.My advice:  look elsewhere for a better book!  This one is not worth your time.

I've wanted to get started with Pressure Cooking but had no idea how to go about it.  This book changed that!I love America's Test Kitchen and I appreciate this book because it makes Pressure Cooking seem do-able and the recipes are awesome!

This book spends a lot of time telling you that you can make a lot of money working from home as a free lance writer, but really doesn't tell you how, exactly, to accomplish it.I enjoyed reading about the author's personal experience and how she decided to build her career, but after reading this book I have no more of an idea of how I would do this than I did before I read it.The book IS very readable and well written; the author is a good writer.  There were quite a few typos and errors though, which is a pet peeve of mine in a book that I paid for.  [I don't think you should charge for an ebook unless it has been professionally proofread and corrected].I gave the book 3 stars because it is entertaining and because it does give you an idea of what is possible as a free lance writer.  But if you want to know HOW to do it, you will have to look elsewhere.If I had it to do over again, I would not have paid for this book, personally.

This "book" is a scattered, disorganized mess.  She wrote an introduction and then strung together a whole bunch of old [separate] blog posts and added a conclusion.  The result is disjointed and very hard to read.  [You are reading her "play by play" from back when this all started].I also got frustrated with her saying "I'm terrible at math" over and over and over again. Truly, I "got it" after the fourth or fifth time.  She must have repeated it 20 times in this short ebook!  Very annoying.I did not think her writing was good - perhaps her writing is great in her fiction, but this book was really bad.  There were some issues with editing as well.  I felt like this book was a rip off - just a bunch of old blog posts that were not very helpful strung together to make a "book" with a sensational title to grab people's attention and get their money.I didn't learn one useful thing in this ebook.I am very sorry I wasted my money on it.

I thought this was a great little ebook!  It was quick and easy to read but packed full of concrete advice on how to involve the whole family in Emergency Preparation.  I already knew a lot about prepping, but this book did have some ideas I hadn't considered before.  It had GREAT advice on how to handle prepping with kids in a way that empowers them without scaring them to death.  I got lots of great ideas from this book that I have put into use with my kids.  This was well worth the money!!!

I had high hopes for this book, based on the overwhelmingly positive reviews.  I've been looking for the male equivalent of "The Care and Keeping of You" [which is outstanding for girls] for my Tween-aged son.  There is a shocking lack of good books on this subject for young men, in my opinion.I was very disappointed with this book.  It is intentionally "high graphics" - it seems like they wanted to make it look almost like a comic book.  I found the format very distracting & annoying.The topics are covered *very* superficially and in a artificially "cool" voice - like grown ups trying way too hard to sound like "cool guys".  I was really looking for straightforward, straight shooting information for my son.  I did not find it in this book.Also, depending on what type of Christian you are, the teachings in this book may conflict with your religious beliefs.  For example, the book promotes masturbation as a normal, great thing [as long as young men don't look at pornography while they do it].  It goes on to say that the Bible does not teach that masturbation is wrong.  Many Christians faiths do not share this opinion, so for a book claiming to be from a Christian perspective, I thought it was a little surprising that they took this position.  At the very least, they should have given both sides of the argument concerning this practice and encouraged young men to do more study in light of their own faith and beliefs.Over all, I thought it was a low quality book, poorly written, too superficial to be helpful, and written in a way that was annoying to have to read.  I expected better from Focus on the Family, quite honestly.I'm still looking for a great growing up guide for boys.

I was very impressed when I removed the V-Light from it's box.  It is constructed well, of all metal except for the base, finished in a nice black enamel, with strong, precise, adjustable joints and a perfectly weighted black plastic base.  The 36 white LEDs light your work brightly and evenly.  It can throw a broad swath of light across an entire desktop and it does so without any heat and with only minimal electricity - in fact, it only uses 3.5 watts!  It comes with a small, DC power supply which plugs into the base.  The power switch is located on the back of the base - it's a standard rocker switch and it works well.  You can easily adjust the height and angle of the light, almost with one finger.  The lamp shade also swivels easily and precisely so you can direct the light exactly where you want it.  And even though the height and angle adjusts easily, it stays where you set it.  It looks attractive on my desk and I'm very happy with it.The only thing that is missing is some sort of rubber feet or felt on the bottom of the base to protect your desktop surface.  I used a couple of strips of self-stick felt and that works great.  I'm surprised they didn't include rubber feet or felt in the box.Other than that, I was very impressed with this lamp.  Highly recommended.
