I was offered a free Zoe Diva Select Olive Oil Variety Pack to review and I accepted.  It consists of one bottle of Zoe Diva Select Arbequina and one bottle of Zoe Diva Select Cornicabra Extra Virgin Olive Oils.  I tried some of each tonight with some old school Italian bread and noted my experience with each.I'll start with the Cornicabra.  It smelled fruity and tasted fresh.  The initial flavor was very fruity.  However, it had a bitter, peppery aftertaste that I did not care for.  I tried it multiple times to be certain that I was tasting what I was tasting, but the strong bitter aftertaste was definitely there every time.  I don't think this olive oil would be suitable for me.The other bottle was the Arbequina.  It offered a completely different experience.  It too, smelled and tasted fresh.  There was an initial fruity note, however, it was mild and less pronounced.  The aftertaste had a little pepper, but it lacked the strong bitter notes of the Cornicabra.  It was buttery and smooth and quite pleasant.  Needless to say, I preferred the Diva Select Arbequina hands down.Both bottles of Diva Select have dark green glass (which is protective) and both were packaged really well in a tough multi-layer cardboard box that was specially designed for shipping.  I would imagine the box could take a lot of abuse and still protect the bottles of olive oil perfectly.I will spend a little more time with the Cornicabra before I outright condemn it.  I can't imagine liking it though.  On the other hand, the Arbequina is very good.  It's hard to believe that these olive oils are both award winning and are both from the same company.  I'm going to rate the pair at three stars.  Really it really should be four stars for the Arbequina and two stars for the Cornicabra.  I think I would skip the variety pack and just order the Arbequina.

I just got my Anova Precision immersion circulator a few days ago.  I decided to try it out tonight on a frozen, marinated, wild-caught, Alaskan salmon filet that I buy at Costco all the time.  The filets come individually vacuum sealed, and so I thought, perfect for sous vide cooking!  I normally make these straight from frozen in the microwave, which is 1100 watts, for 3.5 mins.  They come out okay, but I knew they could be a lot better.  So I looked up info regarding sous vide salmon cooking temperatures and times on the web, taking into consideration that I was planning on going straight from frozen into the water bath.  I decided to go with 130F for 40 minutes.  I attached the Anova Precision to a standard 4 quart stainless pot (see photos), set the temp for 130F and when the water was ready, dropped the straight-from-the-freezer, frozen salmon filet into the bath.  I didn't bother with the timer on the Anova Precision, because to me, it is difficult and clumsy to use - probably the needlessly weakest part of the otherwise super easy-to-use interface.  So I just used the timer on my phone.  As you can see from the photos, I strung a line across the pot (a lettuce tie), sort of like a clothes line, and attached it to the pot and the salmon via binder clips - worked great!  The only issue was that the salmon wanted to float, so I used a big spoon to hold the bottom of the salmon down.  Well, 40 minutes later, I removed the salmon from the water bath and opened the sealed bag directly into a dinner plate.  I used an instant read thermometer and tested the center temperature which read to 127F when I pulled it out (and it was still climbing slowly) - so I knew it was done temperature wise.  I was so happy when I put a fork in it!  It was moist, flaky, pink and delicious!  Very rich and flavorful!  A restaurant quality salmon filet in every way!  I will never microwave these again!The Anova Precision seems to be a very high quality device.  The stainless steel is thick enough as to not feel flimsy at all.  I had read that the unit operated silently, and it does, but I was surprised at just how much water the pump moved!  The water jet is pretty darn strong!  In the case of the salmon, cleanup was almost non-existant since I didn't need to sear the marinated salmon so there was no pan to clean.  Of course, the Anova and the pot were just in clean water, so although I did quickly soap up the pot, the Anova dried itself in minutes, the metal still being warm.Pro Tip: The stainless steel tube on the Anova Precision is removable for cleaning and you should clean the stainless tube, inside and out, before you use it the first time.  Mine had a very thin layer of black soot inside which is by product of the rolled stainless steel.  You couldn't actually see it, but if you slid your finger across it, your fingertip would be blackened.  I cleaned it using dish detergent and a brush that you would normally use for cleaning the inside of drinking glasses.  Also, there is a thin layer of protective plastic on the control surface that is difficult to remove as there are no tabs - you can hardly tell it's there and many people mistake it for scratches.  I used masking tape to pull up an edge and then removed the plastic easily revealing the perfect glass touch surface beneath.So my first experience with sous vide cooking using the Anova Precision turned out well and I'm a happy Anova owner!  Next up, sous vide pork chops!Update: June 23, 2015Pork Chops!So I did two boneless, 3/4" thick Sterling Silver pork chops for dinner tonight.  I made them according to the instructions at ChefSteps(dotcom).  A quick 30 second-per-side pre-bath pan-sear right out of the fridge, then into the ziplock bags with some avocado oil for 45 minutes at 144F.  I used the water displacement method for the bagging, which worked well, but you pretty much have to stop the Anova to do it or deal with a lot of water turbulence.  That wasn't a problem, I just pressed stop on the Anova and then when they were bagged, sealed and attached to the pot via binder clips, I started it back up again.  45 minutes later, I removed them and patted them dry.  I also noted that some of the fat from the pork chops had rendered and was left with the oil in the bags.  I gave them another 30 second-per-side quick sear in the pan and served them with long grain rice and peas (yeah, rice and peas with butter! yum!)  So how did they come out?  They were easily the best pork chops I ever made at home.  Slightly pink sear to sear, moist, tender and juicy.  I don't have any photos of these, but I will try to get photos the next time I make them.  But trust me, they came out GOOD!  The sear part is definitely messy.  Lots of oil splatter.  I have to figure out a better way to do that.  I'm already seriously considering buying a Searzall.Update July 21, 2015Uploaded pics of boneless, 3/4" Sterling Silver pork chops prepared in a similar manner to what is described above, except they were grilled to finish.  First, you see the raw pork chops, right out of the refrigerator, ready to bag.  Here's another tip, when using Ziplock type bags, always carefully fold the lip of the bag down and over before adding the raw meat.  This keeps the exterior and zipper area of the bag clean and also helps the bag stand up so you can easily insert the raw meat.  Then you see the pork chops in the water bath at 144F for 45 minutes.  The next pic shows the pork chops as they appear right after taking them out of the bags - not very appetizing!  I assure you, they are perfectly cooked, but they are literally grey on the outside.  That's okay though, I am going to add color when finishing them on the grill.  The next pic is what they look like after grilling them for approximately one minute per side on a 500~600F grill.  I then drizzled them with my own delicious spiced butter concoction.  They were excellent!  They came out moist and tender, especially good for pork chops, with just a little pink inside.  Also, grilling is definitely the way to go in order to avoid the mess and cleanup of pan frying to finish.Next up, steaks... just have to get the pics done...

I was offered a free bag of Diamond shelled California pistachios to review... so of course, I accepted!  The pistachios feel, smell and taste fresh.  The expiration date on the bag is just over a year out.  The only problem is that they are so easy to eat, they're downright dangerous!  You can just keep eating them with no work to get them out of the shell!  If you manage to put the bag down, you should refrigerate it.  Actually, you should refrigerate all nuts to keep them fresher longer as all nuts contain oils that go rancid and refrigeration will slow that process.  Note that these bags are only 6 ounces (1.5 cups), so the bags are smaller than you may expect.  However, since the nuts are shelled, there is no wasted space.  So if you have a recipe that calls for pistachios or just a hankering to put some on your ice cream or in a salad, these shelled California pistachios are a solid choice.

This review is for the Thor - Stylish, great hand feel, great drop protection, but missing a hole to accomodate the bottom microphone.  This compromises the in-call sound quality, the speakerphone and the noise cancellation.  There are holes for the microphone and the IR remote on top.  There are holes for the headphone and the USB port on the bottom.  There is a hole for the speaker on the back.  But there is no hole for the bottom microphone which is located between the headphone and the USB port.  It is completely covered and sealed by rubber case.  I am not happy about that.  Luckily, I use a Bluetooth headset 99.9% of the time, so the covered mic doesn't affect me very much at all.  But if you don't use a headset, the missing mic hole will affect you.  Its too bad because if it wasn't for that design defect, this would be a perfect case.

To my knowledge, I have never knowingly consumed goji berries before.  I was offered a free one pound bag and, as probably most of you would, I decided to try them out...Well, they have an interesting and unique flavor.  In fact, I'm having a very difficult time figuring out a common reference to give you for comparision.  They have a mild sweetness and a slight tang.  As these are dried goji berries, I can assure you that they are very dry... I'd say they are easily far drier than the average raisin.  In fact, the outside is kind of hard, but they are chewy with a slight grit to them (which I believe is the due to the tiny seeds contained therin).  However, they are not at all unpleasant.  Eating them straight from the bag is addicting and I have also added them to a salad, to which they added flavor and their chewy texture.  They also work well in oatmeal, in trail mixes (with nuts) and in muffins (which I haven't tried yet).  I know there are many healthful claims regarding goji berries, but I don't know if they're worth $17 or more per pound - that is your decision.

I'm not a fan of electric shavers.  I don't shave every day, but when I do, I normally use a Gillette Fusion Proglide razor, Proraso Shaving Cream and a Badger Hair Shaving Brush.  I get a close, comfortable shave and I can easily trim around my sideburns.  In the past, I tried a Philips Norelco electric shaver, but I wasn't happy with it.  It was a dry-shave only model.  The shave was not as close or as clean as a blade shave, it was impossible to use it to shave around my sideburns well - there is just no way to get a precise edge and worse than that, it wrecked my neck every time I used it.  I was recently offered a sample of the Wet/Dry Remington XF8550 to test and I thought I would give it a try.To charge the XF8550, you must place it into it's charging cradle - there is no way to plug the electric cord directly into the XF8550, so you are relying on the batteries at all times.  Luckily, the XF8550 is equipped with the more reliable lithium-ion batteries like a modern cell phone and not the older nickel-metal-hydride batteries which start losing their ability to charge significantly in short order.  The battery is rated to deliver a 50 minute runtime after a two hour charge.  I'd estimate that runtime figure is pretty accurate and if you shave every day, you can easily go a week on a single charge.  Still, the batteries are not user replacable and the lithium-ion battery will fail at some point.  So with no option to run the XF8550 in a corded mode, you are buying something that has a limited life-span... maybe a few years... maybe three or four before the battery becomes a real problem.The XF8550 is very comfortable to hold with the handle covered in a blue, hard-rubberized coating.  The power button is integrated directly into the blue rubberized coating and is placed perfectly for your thumb to operate.  There is a pop-up sideburn trimmer on the backside which is also easily deployed by your thumb.  The shaving head does pivot by maybe 10 degrees, but I wonder if it really does much of anything to keep the blades in touch with your face.Since this is a wet/dry razor, I've been using it wet.  Actually, I've been using it with the same Proraso Shaving Cream I use when I use my Gillette Fusion Proglide razor.  The shave from the Remington XF8550 has been decent.  It doesn't shave as close a blade, but it does a good job.  It doesn't wreck my neck like the Philips Norelco I tried in the past.  My only complaint is that like other electric razors I've used in the past, there is no way to shave close to long sideburns or a beard well.  I know this has an integrated trimmer, but it is just that, a trimmer - it is not meant to shave around well defined sideburns or beard.  Like other electric shavers I've tried, it's always too vague as to where the shaving edge is.Cleanup is a breeze as you can just pop off the foil assembly and rinse the Remington XF8550 off under the faucet.  Then just shake off the excess water and let it air dry.  I store mine on it's stand-up, foldable charging cradle.Overall, I like the Remington XF8550 better than other electrics I've used in the past, but don't expect as close a shave as what you would typically get from a blade.  And if you have long sideburns or a beard, you'll not be able to shave around them too well.  If you don't have a long sideburns or a beard, this may be a great razor for you.

I like jerky.  I don't eat it too often, but it's a great source of protein when travelling or as a snack every once in awhile.  I was offered a sample of this Chef's Cut Real Steak Jerky in the Variety Pack.  One of the things I noticed immediately on the label was that it claimed the jerky contained no added nitrates, other than that naturally occurring in the celery powder and sea salt.  That's a good thing since nitrates are not good for us.  The variety pack contains four types of jerky... Honey Barbeque Chicken, Original Recipe Turkey, Original Recipe Steak and Chipolte Cracked Pepper Steak.  I wrote down my impressions when I tried them, each on different days so that the favors would not affect one another.First, what I considered to be the best of the four varieties, the Honey Barbeque Chicken.  It had a nice sweet, smokey taste with the flavors of honey and spices.  There was some very mild heat.  The texture was moist, but hard.  It was lean and chewy, but not oily.  There was an aftertaste of smoke and heat.  Overall, I liked this variety and I may order more of it.Second, the Original Recipe Turkey.  It had a meaty, sweet flavor with lots of smoke and very mild heat.  The texture was somewhat moist but very hard.  It was chewy and not oily.  There was an aftertaste of mild smoke and heat.  Overall, I thought it was okay, but I wouldn't order it again.The next flavor I tried was the Original Recipe Steak.  The favor was sweet with mild spice and just a little smoke.  The texture was soft and a little dry, but very tender and easy to chew.  There was an aftertaste of pepper.  Overall, I did not like it.And finally, the Chipolte Cracked Pepper Steak which I ate just minutes before writing this review.  The taste was overpowered by strong, high heat with some sweetness.  Also present was smoke, pepper and spice.  Like the Original Recipe Steak, the texture was soft and a little dry, but very tender and easy to chew, but with pepper seeds present on the surface.  The aftertaste was that of heat and pepper.  Overall, I did not like it, but if you're into heat, you may enjoy it.So, for me, the variety pack was hit and miss.  The chicken was pretty good and the turkey was okay.  But I wasn't happy with the flavors of the steak at all even though the meat was tender.  If you're interested in this jerky, try the variety pack to see if any of it is the right jerky for you.

The new flavor of Barilla pasta sauce is Bacon & Cheese.  It says so right there on the label.  The ingredients label includes "uncured cooked bacon crumble" as the third ingredient.  Both provolone and parmesan cheeses are also present on the label, much further down on the ingredients list, almost last in fact, but they are there.  Yet I cannot detect even a hint of bacon or cheese in the sauce.  Mind you, I like the sauce.  I like the flavor.  I just cannot dicern the taste of bacon or cheese.  It is a nicely sweet tomato sauce with a nice tang and I thoroughly enjoyed it on spaghetti and on the bread I ate with it.  To me, it was delicious.  My sister on the other hand, did not like it and said "there is an artificial aftertaste."  Now, my sister really doesn't like anything, so take that with a grain.  I explained to her that there is nothing artificial in the sauce and I detected no aftertaste.  My dad liked the sauce, but he also did not taste any bacon or cheese.  In that respect, it was disappointing, but again, I did like the sauce.I included a photo of the Nutrition Facts and ingredients of the Bacon & Cheese flavor:

So I've had this Shark Rotator TruePet Powered Lift-Away for just over a month now.  I also have two other vacuums to compare it to: my eight-year-old Dyson DC17 Animal and my very recent Eureka Airspeed (AS3008A).  Like the other vacuum cleaners I own, the Shark Rotator has some things I really like a lot and some things that I'm not thrilled with.As this is the top-of-the-line Shark, it comes with a lot of extras.  Unpacking the box was an adventure in itself.  There are A LOT of interesting items in the box.  I'm pulling things out of the box and I'm thinking, what is that?  And how does that have anything to do with this vacuum?  At one point I thought I had accidentially ordered a small R2D2 like droid.  Following the diagram, it was easy to assemble, but it was more complex than either of my two other vacuums.  This Shark Rotator has a quality finish that is actually attractive and suprising for a vacuum cleaner - but again, it is top-of-the-line.The first thing you'll notice when you turn it on for the first time are the super bright headlights.  A full array of white LEDs shine brightly from the vacuum head when using the Shark on carpets - a light that is much brighter and far more useful than the lights on any other vacuum I've seen.  You can and I have used this in an otherwise completely dark room, no problem.  It lights up all the ridges and dirt on the surface of your carpet.The second thing I noticed was how comparatively quiet it was.  Its certainly not silent by any stretch, but it is much quieter than either of my other vacuums and any other vacuum I've used or heard in the past.The power button is right on the front of the handle, which is a good place because it allows you to easily control the power to the Shark both when using it as an upright vacuum and when using the accessory hose.  I know there are times when I'm using the accessory hose and I accidentally suck something in that I don't want sucked in - well you can cut power to the vacuum quickly without having to search for the power button because its right there.Just below the power button is a lighted three-position sliding switch which is used to adjust the Shark to work on bare floors, which turns off the beater bar, and two carpet heights, low pile and high pile.  So although carpet height adjustment is not automatic like it is on my Dyson DC17, you don't have to bend over to set it like I do on my Eureka Airspeed, because the switch is right there on the handle.Also on the handle is another bright LED light which turns on and works well when you use the accessory hose.  It does a good job of lighting up corners and furniture like the areas between cushions and even walls.  The accessory hose and wand work well.  The hose is high quality and very flexible but may be a little heavier than necessary.  The main body of the Shark has space for two attachments - an ingenious combination of a crevice tool and dusting brush in one and a regular upholstery tool.  This model Shark also comes with an additional dusting brush, a motorized mini brush, a hard floor genie and a wheeled chassis for using the Shark as a full-fledged canister vacuum.  The electrically motorized mini brush attaches to the accessory hose or wand and provides a powered mini-beater bar which is good for cleaning furniture and stairs.  It works well and since it's electrically powered, it doesn't take anything away from the suction.  The hard floor genie is an accessory which combines the vacuum and a microfiber mop pad.  I have not had the opportunity to use hard floor genie so I cannot assess its effectiveness.The Shark works really well as an upright vacuum.  The swivel carpet head allows you to easily maneuver and steer the vacuum.  In addition, the carpet head is a little narrow at 12" wide which also helps it to maneuver easily (my Dyson and Eureka are both 13.5" wide).  The handle is smooth and shaped well allowing you both good grip and good control.  The carpet head fits easily under the threshold of most furniture, but the attached canister might get in the way of going too far under.  Ah, but luckily, the canister on this Shark detaches completely allowing you to get very far under almost any furniture - my Dyson DC17 and Eureka Airspeed can't do that.There are a few things about this Shark that I'm not thrilled with.  First, even though it comes with three smaller attachments, (and two larger ones) there is only enough space to carry two on the main upright body.  I can understand not carrying the larger ones, but there should be space for all three smaller attachments.  And second, when using the accessory hose with the Shark in its standard upright configuration, the Shark has a strong tendency to fall over.  It happened to me many times and its a pain in the butt because you have to stop what you're doing to tend to it.  I think it happens because the base of the Shark is relatively small and the hose is attached too high for the Shark to be stable when using the hose.  As a result, you really have to keep the Shark very close when using the hose or the body just falls over.  This also happens on my Eureka (for a different reason), but not on my Dyson.  Of course, if you use the Shark in the canister configuration, this is not an issue.One of the coolest things about this Shark is the dirt canister.  I know, you're thinking, the dirt canister is cool?  Really?  Well, those of you who have bagless vacuums know how disgusting it is to empty the canister and that a lot of filth sticks to the screens and grills in the cyclone area of many vacuum canisters.  Well, not on this Shark.  They designed the dirt canister in such a way that it actually separates the dirt from the cyclone area.  No more filth sticking to the cyclone grills and screens!  So of the three bagless cyclonic vacuums I own, this Shark is by far the easiest one to empty with as little fuss and drama as possible - in fact, this is the first one I can recommend to people living in an apartment.  Good job Shark!So it works well, it handles well, it lights up your dirty carpet, it has the best dirt canister design.. but I'm not totally convinced that it out cleans my Dyson or Eureka.  Don't get me wrong, it does a really good job, but I feel like the Dyson and the Eureka may do a better job on my carpets.  I'm not positive though.  Its definitely close.  Could it be a false perception because the Shark is relatively quiet?  Maybe.  I have to do a test with empty canisters, where I use one vacuum and then try another and see if the second or third picks up what the previous ones did not.  If I do that I'll update this review with the results.In summary, this Shark has some great features and abilities that neither of my other vacuums have.  That said, with all of its modules and detachments, its kind of complex as compared with the other vacuums I own.  Its not a light weight and its not inexpensive.  And although it does a great job, I'm not convinced that it does a better job than my eight-year-old Dyson DC17 or very inexpensive, but very effective (and lightweight) Eureka Airspeed (AS3008A) on carpets.

I was provided with an AccU-Rate SM-310 free of charge in exchange for an honest review.And I'm glad I was asked to review the SM-310 because I was not even aware that small devices like this existed.  I am not a health nut, but I do watch what I eat.  I try to be especially aware of the ingredients in the food I eat and have been avoiding soy, trans-fat and HFCS for years.  I take certain supplements like fish oil, vitamin D and resveratrol.  Even so, I feel fortunate that my health has been excellent but I've always been curious to know if I was getting the most out of the exercise that I do.  Plus there are certain things that you just cannot measure at a yearly visit to the doctor's office.For instance, with the AccU-Rate SM-310 you can easily and accurately measure your resting heart rate in the morning when you first wake up.  For it is when you first wake that you can get the most accurate measurement of your heart rate at rest.  And your resting heart rate can provide a good indication of your overall heart health.  With the AccU-Rate SM-310, you can measure your resting heart rate in seconds and you can measure it every day if you want - just keep it by the bedside.You can also easily measure your heart rate during and after excercise.  You can literally pick up the SM-310 and slip it on your finger while walking, running, cycling, in between sets of push ups, etc. and within seconds know your current heart rate.  You can even use it when doing chores like mowing the lawn.  So you can get a fast, accurate measure of your heart rate while actually exercising, which can be difficult if not impossible to measure manually without first stopping - and even if you stop, its not easy to manually measure a 150+bpm heart rate.  But the SM-310 will accurately tell you your heart rate in seconds.  Knowing your heart rate during exercise is important as it recommended by the American Heart Association to keep your heart rate between 50% and 85% of your theoretical maximum heart rate while exercising in order to see the most health benefit.  You can easily look up your maximum theoretical heart rate on the web.  You should probably consult your doctor before starting any exercise regime.The unit itself is small, lightweight and very easy to use.  Just slip it on your fingertip and turn it on.  Within about ten seconds you'll see your current heart rate and blood oxygen saturation percentage on the large, bright, crystal clear, high contrast OLED display.  The finger well has a smooth, almost silky feel and its designed to effortlessly expand to work well with any size finger.  There is just enough spring tension to hold it comfortably and securely on your finger without any pain or pinching.  Remove your finger and within about ten seconds the SM-310 will power down automatically.  It could not be easier.The SM-310 operates on two AAA batteries, a pair of which are included.  Also included is a soft silicone protective case, a fitted canvas-like carry case which has a belt loop and velcro closure and a detachable lanyard.Overall, I like the SM-310 a lot.  It's one of those things that I wish I had for years and I think this kind of item will become more common now that the size, cost and accuracy of these devices are as good as they are today.  The AccU-Rate SM-310 is very reasonably priced and it works great.  I would recommend it.

These small treats are very tasty, especially for lovers of coconut.  But the key word here is small.  Each one of these treats weighs only half an ounce and is literally the size of a stack of six quarters - and that is not an exaggeration.  They are very good.  The taste of lightly toasted and barely sweetened coconut is delightful and they are not sweet or chewy at all - just perfect taste and texture in my opinion.  But they are such a small bite, a tease if you will.  At $21 for a pack of 24, these are almost a dollar apiece and they are not even close to being worth it - thats $21 for 12 ounces of coconut.  For my coconut fix, I purchase a pound of organic, unsweetened coconut chips for $6 or less (and I do, all the time).  For me, this pack of 24 tiny tasty treats would have to be even less than $8 for me to bite.

The XGB3 is compact, light and it feels good in the hand due to the 1/16" rubber surround.  There is one full size USB port located under the rubber lid which you can plug your phone or other devices into to charge.  There is a micro USB port also located under the rubber lid for charging the XGB3.  The XGB3 comes with a 48" USB to micro USB cable that you can use for charging the XGB3 or you can use it to charge your phone or device with a micro USB port, but it does not come with a charger.  You can plug the XGB3 into any powered USB port to charge - charging time will vary greatly depending on the strength of the power source.  There is a small LED near the top that pulses red when the XGB3 is charging and it turns solid green when the pack is fully charged.  In order to charge your phone or other device, you plug it in to the full size USB port and press and hold the power button on the XGB3 until the LED turns green.  The LED will turn from green to red when the capacity of the XGB3 falls below 80%.  You can turn the XGB3 off at any time by pressing and holding the power button again until the LED turns off.  Fully charged, the XGB3 is rated to deliver 3000mAh@1A - good for phones, but not so much for tablets.  Additionally, the XGB3 can act as a passthrough and charge a device while being charged itself.Due to the light weight of the pack and the 1/16" rubber surround, it can probably survive small drops onto concrete, but I wouldn't push that too far.  NOCO touts the NEMA IP65 rating, but if you look into it, NEMA IP65 just means that the battery pack is "dust tight" and "protected against low pressure water jets from any direction with limited ingress permitted."  It does not mean that the pack is water proof or protected against impacts.  So don't think that this pack is military grade or anything close, because its not.  In order to test the water resistance, I subjected the XGB3 to running water in the sink at various angles and I also submerged it under about 4" of water.  No water was present under the lid and the pack still worked fine.  Just keep in mind that the same result could be achieved with any battery pack and a ziplock bag.But one of the issues I have with this pack is with the lid.  The lid is made of 1/16" rubber with an additional 1/16" double lip that fits lightly, not snugly, into a very thin plastic opening on top.  It does not snap closed in a positive way that requires any effort to open.  In fact, the lid opens far too easliy if you carry the pack in your pocket and it would probably open in a purse as well.  When the lid opens, dust, debris, pocket lint and whatever else happens to be around will get in to the USB and micro USB ports - precisely one of the things this pack was meant to avoid.The product is way over packaged for what it is consisting of a relatively large, heavy cardboard, really high quality, printed inner box contained in a plain outer box... excess packaging which I can see no benefit for what is supposed to be a rugged battery pack.  Most other quality, compact 3000mAh battery packs are less than half the price of this NOCO XGB3.  Even discounting the issue with the poorly designed lid, if you think that the 1/16" rubber surround, the IP65 rating and the excessive packaging are worth double the price, then by all means, this is the battery pack for you.  Personally, I would make a different choice.

I already have a Bissell Lift-Off Steam Mop, but I'm not entirely happy with it.  For one thing, it has a small leak.  But most importantly, you must keep a manual trigger depressed in order to generate steam.  That literally ties one hand behind your back when using the device.  I wanted to try this new Dirt Devil which addresses both of the issues I have with the Bissell and it does so at half the weight and half the price.The Dirt Devil 2-in-1 Versa steam mop arrives disassembled and snaps together easily and positively using springloaded, interlocking pins and grooves.  The metal handle has two segments which snap together and then that handle snaps into the steam pod.  At the other end of the steam pod you can either snap in the mop head for cleaning floors or the cleaning nozzle to use it as a steam pod to clean just about any hard surface.  There are two pegs on the handle you can use to neatly wrap the cord around like you would on a vacuum cleaner, but the cord doesn't have a plug with a locking head like you would think it should, so the end of the cord just dangles there.  Also, neither of the pegs rotate allowing you to instantly deploy the cord.  Finally, as I found out the hard way, the edges of those pegs are much sharper than they need to be and one of them cut my finger.  The power cord ends in a standard two-prong polarized plug and the cord itself is sixteen feet long - so it allows plenty of range from an electrical outlet.  The Dirt Devil 2-in-1 Versa comes with a small, well designed filler cup, two washable microfiber mop covers and a "carpet glide" attachment.This seems like a good time to mention that I think the instruction manual sucks.  It is of the multi-fold, mixed language variety, but with all of the languages mixed under each topic instead of having individual sections for each language.  So you must wade through paragraphs of the wrong language to get to the next section in the language you're looking for.  Not that there is a lot of documentation, but I like to know all the details before I start using something.  Also, there's no mention of the "carpet glide" attachment until the end so at first you may be wondering what it's for - it's not even mentioned on the inventory list.Using the Dirt Devil as a mop, I attached the mop head with a microfiber mop pad, I filled the reservoir with filtered tap water and flipped it on.  Unlike the Bissell Lift-Off Steam Mop, there is no trigger that you have to keep pressing for the unit to generate steam - once you switch it on, you're ready to go.  After about ten seconds, the unit started to put out a woosh of steam and I started cleaning.  Along with the light weight, one of the things I liked is the rotating mop head which sort of automatically rotates to hug walls and corners.  Using slow, steady strokes, I was able to clean my entire kitchen floor on one tank of water - the mop pad was filthy and I was happy.  I found the handle comfortable and the whole process was quick and easy.  A word of advice - never leave the mop in one spot for too long - depending on the type of floor, you could get a water spot on wood or you could literally alter the surface of linoleum.  If you need to stop, be sure to turn it off and let it cool before letting it stand.I detached the mop head and the handle, attached the cleaning nozzle and refilled the tank.  I cleaned my stove top, dishwasher door and microwave inside and out.  It worked great.  The 1200 watt steam pod generated steam fairly steadily with some pauses, but it was steady overall.  When the tank runs out, the unit starts to vibrate.  I switched it off and refilled the tank with water as necessary.  Even after a few hours of steady usage, the steam pod never got hot to the touch, which I appreciated, and I detected no water leaks.  For me, that is a solid design.I did some unscientific steam temperature testing using my Polder and Weber digital probe thermometers.  The room temperature was approxmiately 75 degrees Fahrenheit (F).  I found that the steam exiting the very tip of the Dirt Devil cleaning nozzle was approximately 205~210F.  At one inch away, that steam temperature expectedly dropped quickly to approximately 165~170F.  And at two inches away, the steam temperature was measured to be approximately 140~145F.  This is important to note as temperature recommendations range widely for killing bacteria, but from the research I've done, the recommendations fall between 160F to over 300F.  The effectiveness of steam in killing bacteria depends on the strain(s) of bacteria involved, the type of surface, the temperature of the steam, the pressure of the steam, and the duration of exposure to the steam.  Generally speaking, the higher the temperature and pressure of the steam and the longer the exposure time, the better.  At 205 to 210F, this Dirt Devil falls towards the bottom of the acceptable range (IMO) and as such it will kill some bacteria, but it will not sterilize surfaces to medical or scientific standards, which require extended exposure to steam at or above 273F at much higher than normal pressure.  As far as I can find, only the best commercial steamers will generate steam at or above 270 degrees Fahrenheit at high enough pressure - probably due to the cost.  So although the Dirt Devil will clean surfaces and kill some bacteria, don't expect that it will sterilize surfaces to any scientific or medical standard - I doubt that any small consumer level steam cleaner will.That said, I like this Dirt Devil 2-in-1 Versa much better than my Bissell Lift-Off Steam Mop, it's quieter, much lighter, easier to use and it's half the price.  So if you're looking for a steam mop or a steam cleaner, I would say this Dirt Devil does a good job for a reasonable price.  I'm writing this review after using it for only one day (I was so happy with it), so I'll see if the good feeling lasts or if it develops issues.  I'll update this review in the future after using it more, but so far so good.One last thing... Keep your kids and hands away from the steam at all times.  At 200+F, the steam is extremely scalding hot!  Do not allow small children to get access to this unit.  It is no joke.  If you can do that, I think you'll be very happy with it.

Let me start out by providing some specs for the IonBank 10k since they are not all included in the description...Dimensions: 4.84" x 3.15" x 0.98" (12.3 x 8 x 2.5cm)Weight: 11.28 oz (320 g)Battery capacity: 10,000mAh, 37WhInput level: 5V at 0.5~2.1AOutput level: 5V at 0.5~3.6ACombined simultaneous output: 18W.The aluminum sided case is very attractive.  It has two Type A female USB ports into which you can plug the devices you want to charge.  It can charge two devices at once - any combination of phones or tablets.  Next to the USB ports there is a five-segment, white LED capacity meter and a small button which you press to show the current relative charge level of IonBank 10k.  As the IonBank 10k charges, those lights blink to indicate that the IonBank is charging and they indicate its current relative recharge level.  The finish and build quality of the pack are excellent.  One side of the case slides open smoothly to reveal a three-inch, hardwired USB cable with a Type A USB connector - this is used to charge the IonBank 10k.That's all great.But the IonBank 10k is not ideally suited for users of modern Android devices.  Why?  For the following reasons:1. In order to charge up the IonBank 10k, you must plug it into a USB port or charger that you already own, like one you use to charge your Android phone or tablet.  This wouldn't be a big deal since Android users probably have at least one and maybe more than one USB chargers around - except that you must plug it in via the built-in, hardwired, three-inch-long cable ending in full size type A USB connector.  This is not good because if your USB phone/tablet charger is plugged into a wall outlet, you'll have to hang the IonBank 10k off the charger and the wall since the three-inch cable is not long enough to reach the floor - and the IonBank 10k is relatively heavy (the specs list it as 11.28oz).  Or, for instance, if your charger is on the floor, you'll have to charge the IonBank 10k right down on the floor with it.  You could buy a USB type A male to type A female extension cable, but for a $100+ device, I shouldn't have to do that.  Ideally, it should have had a micro-USB female port that you could just plug the cable that you already use to charge your Android phone or tablet directly into it in order to charge the IonBank 10k.  For me, the lack of that micro-USB female port is a fail for this $100+ battery pack - especially for users of Android devices that probably already have a charger set up with a micro-USB cable plugged into it to charge your Android phone or tablet.2. You must have a USB cable with you in order to charge your Android device.  Unlike it's IonBank 5k sibling, the IonBank 10k does not have a built-in micro USB cable to charge your device.  Instead, you must provide and plug a separate cable into one of it's Type A female USB ports.  This is not ideal especially considering the IonBank 10k already has the hidden compartment with the poorly considered 3" charge cable that shouldn't be there.  It should instead have been a similar short cable with a micro-usb male connector capable of charging your Android device.  Another fail for Android device users and the users of most modern devices (other than Apple's) that charge through a micro-USB port.3. You cannot charge a phone or tablet when charging the IonBank 10k.  The charging ports are disabled when the IonBank is being charged, so it cannot charge or act as a passthrough.  I was surprised since I have other battery packs that allow you to charge a device while charging the battery pack.  Unfortunately, that is not the case with this battery pack.  Even when IonBank 10k is fully charged, it still cannot act as a passthough to charge your device.  So you must unplug the IonBank 10k from your charger and plug your phone/tablet device into it or your charger.  That sucks.I've been testing this battery pack for about three weeks now.  It takes about five hours to fully charge the IonBank 10k from complete exhaustion using a 5.3V 2A output USB charger.  If you have a 5.0V 1A charger, you're probably going to be waiting ten hours.  The pack gets warm, but that's expected.  For my most excellent 2014 Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet, I get about an extra five hours of serious 3D gaming when using this pack.  If I were only web browsing or doing some other light to moderate tasks, I might get an extra seven hours.  A fully, recently charged IonBank 10k can fully charge an exhausted 2014 Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 once with a bit of power leftover.  However, I noticed that when the IonBank 10k is down to about 40% capacity according to its own meter, the voltage drops off considerably and it can no longer keep my 2014 Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 fully charged when the IonBank is still supposedly charging it.  It drops off quickly from there.  I suspect that the LED capacity meter on the IonBank 10k isn't very accurate and the 40% mark is more like 10%, at least on mine.  Additionally, if you fully charge the IonBank 10k, store it and then use it a week later, don't expect to get the full 10,000mAh capacity.  The battery slowly discharges over time and even though the meter may read full, you're probably missing 10~20% of the capacity already.  So don't count on this to save your butt if you haven't charged it in awhile.  Finally, it comes with a very unusual if not pathetic case/pouch that I find less than useful - especially for a $100+ battery pack.All things considered, it is an okay to good battery pack.  But due the inconvenience of the design when charging and using the pack as an Android device user, I would say check out other battery packs before you purchase this one.  I'm not saying don't buy it, I'm saying there may be other battery packs available of similar capacity that address the issues I cited above.  For me, this is a classic case of form over function.  It's a pretty pack.  It's physically well made.  But the fact that it forces you to use the short 3" cable to charge the IonBank 10k, and with no built in cable to charge a device with, for me it's not ideally suited for users of modern Android devices.

About eight years ago, I purchased a Dyson DC17 Animal.  It is a seriously great vacuum cleaner.  It works great but it has three downsides - One, it's expensive.  Two, it's relatively heavy and three, emptying the bagless canister is an exercise in controlling filth.  I HATE emptying the canister.  But in order to have a second vacuum, I thought I would give the bagless Eureka AS3008 Airspeed a try which comes in at a fraction of the price of my Dyson.  I've had it about two months now.The first thing is that you'll need to assemble the Eureka as it comes disassembled in major parts which snap together easily in minutes if you follow the included instructions.  Once you assemble it, you'll be amazed at how lightweight it is.  But don't let it's light weight fool you - this is a powerful vacuum cleaner.  Even though it's not self propelled, the low weight makes it easy to clean carpets with a lot less effort than any other vacuum I've used.On my very first and many subsequent uses, I would say that the Eureka Airspeed did as good of a job if not better than my Dyson DC17 on medium and low pile carpets.  It was very impressive, especially considering the weight difference.  The Eureka Airspeed is so much lighter than my Dyson DC17, it made vacuuming almost fun.  Almost.  I also find that it expells a lot less hot air than my Dyson.  That may not sound like a big deal, but trust me, when vacumming in the heat of the summer, its nice.  And the excellent two filter filtration ensures that exhaust air is clean.  One of the filters is washable - just hose and wring a few times then let air dry.  The other filter is for finer particles and its replaceable, but it doesn't have to be replaced very often (and as of now, I can't even find a Eureka EF-7 filter on Amazon).  I still hate emptying the bagless canister, but its easy to do with no surprises.  The canister snaps off with a lever, and snaps back on when emptied.  In fact, I find emptying and cleaning the caninster on this Eureka is easier to do and the results are better than emptying and cleaning the canister on the Dyson DC17.  Additionally, on the Eureka, you can hose down the entire canister assembly including the root cyclone part, so you can get it completely clean.  On the Dyson DC17, you can only hose down the canister, but Dyson warns against getting the root cyclone part wet, so it stays filthy.  Either way, I empty mine outside on the back patio.  Yuck!  I can't see getting a bagless vacuum if you live in an apartment... I would not be thrilled if I had to deal with this indoors.There are some features on my Dyson that I miss on the Eureka though.  For one thing, my Dyson automatically adjusts to different heights of carpet.  This Eureka Airspeed does not.  The Eureka has a five setting height dial on the head to adjust for bare floor to high pile carpets.  That's no big deal, but is it noted.Two, and this one is the biggest difference, my Dyson DC17 allows you to just grab the accessory hose at any time and use it.  When you put the Dyson DC17 in full upright, the beater bar is disabled and suction is automatically diverted to the hose.  When you put the hose back and put the Dyson at an angle to use on carpet, the beater bar activates and suction is returned to the carpet head.  When you want to use the hose with this Eureka Airspeed, you must turn a knob on the frame of the vacuum to divert the suction from the carpet head to the hose - And most importantly, you must remember to turn that knob back to divert the suction back to the carpet head when you're done with the hose.  As a person who is used to the Dyson, there were a few times I was pushing the Eureka around a bit with the suction diverted to the hose until I realized it.  Additionally, on this particular model AS3008A, the beater bar does not stop when the unit is at full upright or using the hose and there is no manual switch to disable it.  The accessory hose and tools do work well, but here is where the light weight of the Eureka Airspeed is a negative - The Eureka Airspeed is so light that you have to secure its body when using the hose or the Eureka will simply topple over.  You literally cannot use the hose on anything without worrying about what the vacuum body is doing.  I find that I have to keep a hand or foot on it at all times in order to keep it from falling over when using the hose - not an ideal situation.  Luckily, the times it did fall over, the canister stayed securely in place!  Whew!I cannot predict its reliability or durability over time but so far, so good.  Overall, I would say as an upright vacuum cleaner, this Eureka Airspeed does a great job - as good or better than my Dyson DC17 - and I say that as a satisfied Dyson owner.  Additionally, the light weight of this vacuum makes it easy to maneuver while using it and easy to carry around, go up and down stairs with it, etc.  But using the accessory hose and tools, even though they work well, is a hassle due to the lightweight body falling over at the slightest pull.  If you can live with that, then this is a great vacuum for the money.

0:20 MinsIt's amazing how far these SD cards have come and in the last few years, Samsung has made some great SD and micro SD cards!  This card works great in my Sony Alpha SLT-A57K with fast photo writes and no problems when recording 60FPS, 1080p video.  Transfers of the RAW format photos I take and the relatively large video files from this card to my PC are the fastest of any card I own.  In order to find out exactly how fast this card is, I benchmarked it on my PC using a Transcend USB 3.0 SDXC UHS-I card reader on a USB 3.0 port and then on a USB 2.0 port for reference (for the folks who don't yet have USB 3.0 ports).  Here are the results: (also see the video)First, over USB 3.0:-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0 (C) 2007-2010 hiyohiyo-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1,000,000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300,000,000 byte/s]  Sequential Read :  90.613 MB/s  <---(the significant measurement)  Sequential Write :  79.019 MB/s  <---(the significant measurement)  Random Read 512KB :  78.434 MB/s  Random Write 512KB :  3.059 MB/s  Random Read 4KB (QD=1) :  6.170 MB/s [  1506.4 IOPS]  Random Write 4KB (QD=1) :  1.748 MB/s [  426.9 IOPS]  Random Read 4KB (QD=32) :  6.551 MB/s [  1599.3 IOPS]  Random Write 4KB (QD=32) :  1.925 MB/s [  470.0 IOPS]  Test : 1000 MB [K: 0.0% (0.0/59.6 GB)] (x1)  Date : 2014/06/21 16:11:13.Now, for reference, over the much slower USB 2.0:-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0 (C) 2007-2010 hiyohiyo-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1,000,000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300,000,000 byte/s]  Sequential Read :  34.956 MB/s  <---(the significant measurement)  Sequential Write :  32.005 MB/s  <---(the significant measurement)  Random Read 512KB :  33.733 MB/s  Random Write 512KB :  4.653 MB/s  Random Read 4KB (QD=1) :  5.675 MB/s [  1385.5 IOPS]  Random Write 4KB (QD=1) :  1.729 MB/s [  422.0 IOPS]  Random Read 4KB (QD=32) :  5.884 MB/s [  1436.6 IOPS]  Random Write 4KB (QD=32) :  1.887 MB/s [  460.8 IOPS]  Test : 1000 MB [K: 0.0% (0.0/59.6 GB)] (x1)  Date : 2014/06/21 16:50:03As you can see, it flies on USB 3.0!  It comes within a nidge of the claimed 90MB/s reads and 80MB/s writes - easily within a reasonable margin of error.  By comparison, my two-year-old, 45MB/s rated SanDisk Extreme 32GB SDHC UHS-1 card tested at 47.9 MB/s read and 42.8 MB/s write in the same test - quite respectible for a card from 2012, but I'll take the newer, faster Samsung card, thank you very much!  Of course, even the new Samsung cannot come close over USB 2.0, but that is no fault of the card.  USB 2.0 just doesn't have the bandwidth necessary to take advantage of the speed this card is capable of.  Overall, this is a great, well made, really fast card!  I'm sure it will be as reliable as the three 64GB Samsung Pro microSDXC cards I have in various devices which have all worked flawlessly over the past 14 months.  So if you have a recent DSLR or video camera capable of using UHS-I SDXC cards and/or USB 3.0 ports on your PC (and a USB 3.0 SDXC UHS-I card reader) and you desire fast, reliable storage and fast transfers, then this may be a great SDXC card for you!

When I first opened the box containing these knives I did so with great caution as you could just tell they were very sharp.  I hand cleaned and thoroughly dried all of them and kept the Santoku knife in the plastic sheath it comes in.  All of these knives are Swiss made from cold rolled high-carbon steel and then ground, tempered, and sharpened.  They all have Fibrox handles.  For those of you who don't know, (and I didn't), Fibrox mineral fiber is an inorganic, biosoluble, glassy material spun at high temperatures derived from molten minerals.  Although it resembles plastic, it is not plastic.  I've used these knives at least a dozen times over the past two weeks.The star attraction of the set I ordered is the Santoku knife.  The knife including the handle is just under a foot in length.  The blade is 6 and 3/4 inches long.  The blade has the telltale Santoku indents attractively machined along it's length which assist in releasing sliced items from the blade.  The five-inch Fibrox handle is solid, tough and hard.  It has a nice texture with rounded edges and is formed to be very comfortable to hold.  I find the handle to be very solidly attached to the blade with exactly zero play in any direction and the handle does not bend.  This Santoku knife as a whole is much lighter than I expected which makes it easier to handle with less fatigue.  It is very well balanced with the center of weight located just where the blade meets the handle.  I've used the Santoku knife for slicing cucumber, tomato, celery and onion for salads.  It goes though everything well and accurately including ripe tomatoes which a dull knife can easily ruin.  As this knife is very lightweight and the blade is thinner than other knives I own, I cannot predict durability, but it is my understanding that these knives take to sharpening very well and should last for years.The peeler has serrated edges and a nicely formed, comfortable Fibrox handle.  It is very light weight and the edges are very sharp.  I've used the peeler to shred carrots for salads.  I find I like the serrated edges and the tiny ridges it imparts to the carrot shreds gives them more surface area and makes them more flavorful.I find the utility knife to be very useful.  Of course, it too has a Fibrox handle.  The blade is serrated from one side (as opposed to both sides) and it is very sharp.  This knife is great for slicing bread at the dinner table - It goes though bread very well with no fuss and beats having a full-sized bread knife at the dinner table.  It could also be used as a steak knife or for anything where a serrated knife is perferred.Overall I like these knives but as I've only used them for two weeks, so I cannot say how well they will hold up over time.  So far so good though.UPDATE: 10/6/2014It's been another month and I've been using these knives at every opportunity.  The Santoku knife cuts london broil like a boss - you can make delicious, super thin cuts of london broil with ease.  I've even used the Santoku knife to cut birthday cake, and cuts it cleanly without any effort or crushing.  The serrated utility knife may seem like a throw in, but I find myself using it constantly.  Along with using it to cut loaves of French and Italian bread at the dinner table, I've used it to cut apple pie as perfect as can be without smushing it or destroying the crust.  I've also used it to cut homemade sicilian pizza with a crispy crust and it did so without crushing the crust and made perfect, clean cuts.  I have to tell you, both of these knives are super sharp and you have to be careful when handling them and especially when cleaning them.  They will cut you if you don't respect them.  I'm very happy with these knives so far.

This stand assist is easy to assemble and use.  I had it set up on a recliner my mom used all the time.  I found that I was able to recline even with the assist installed - basically, the frame would recline with the chair.  I don't think that won't work with every recliner, but it did work with ours.  The only caveat so far is that depending on what you're using it on, the end of the legs may stick out a few inches creating a hazard when walking near it.  On the recliner we used it on, the legs of the stand assist stick out the sides by only a few inches, but it was enough for my dad to trip on it.  Luckily, he didn't fall, but that worried me.  If you're using it on a couch, the legs probably won't be a problem.

I already had a pretty good phone mount - an older Arkon model SM410, but it is a two piece design where the cradle that holds the phone slid into a groove on the ball joint.  The problem was that the cradle didn't *lock* into the groove on the ball joint and recently the cradle, with phone attached, slipped out while driving.  My phone fell onto my dashboard and luckily I caught it in time, but I had to pull over to remount it.  That incident encouraged me to investigate a new mount.I saw this new Arkon model MG279 mount and it looked sleek but sturdy with a nice strong vise action to hold the phone in the mount.  When I received it, I have to admit that at first I didn't like the way the vise action worked as the vise is always under tension to grip the phone with no way to release it.  But I quickly learned how to easily install and remove the phone with no fuss.  Now I love this mount!  The vise action is strong, smooth and precise.  The two fingers that hold the phone are hard rubber so once your phone is properly in place against the flat mounting surface behind the phone, there is no play even when using the touchscreen.  (At the moment, I have a 4.7" LG Optimus G in a Body Glove case, btw)The suction cup on this mount has a sticky surface and it really helps it to grip my windshield.  Not that I ever had a problem with the "regular" suction cups of previous mounts, but this one is even more secure.  Regular suction cups work best with a little spit on them first, whereas this sticky cup works bone dry.  Spit would have the opposite effect on this mount as it would diminish the sticky property of the suction cup surface.  It takes a little more effort to remove the sticky mount from the windshield, but its worth it.  If you get this mount, I suggest you keep the thin plastic protective sheet that ships on the suction cup and cover it back up when you're not using it in order to keep it clean.  I never leave the mount on the windshield as it just makes your car a target for crime - whether or not the phone is in the car.. a thief wouldn't know that.The rest of the hardware also works well.  The joint which holds the arm to the suction cup has tiny teeth that keep the arm firmly where you set it once you tighten the screw.  The ball joint works smoothly and it allows you to tilt your phone easily but firmly if you have the ring tightened properly.  There is one issue though -  For some reason, Arkon put what I can only describe as a "tab" right behind the ball joint and that tab limits your ability to tilt the phone.  I see no reason for that tab to be there and I may remove it from my mount.  That tab aside, this is a great quality mount that will hold your phone securely to the windshield that is easy to set up and use.

I purchased this pan in the hope that I could use it to reheat and cook some items better in the microwave as opposed to normal microwave heating or turning on the conventional oven.  Summer is coming and I hate to turn on the oven in hot summer weather.  So I was really hoping this pan would function as more of a conventional oven in the microwave, but it doesn't.  What it does is function exactly like an overheated frying pan in the microwave.  The cooking surface gets really hot really fast and you can't control the temperature.  You also can't see the food while its cooking since its under the cover and in the microwave.  Because the cooking surface gets so hot and you can't see the food, food burns easily - far too easily - and it will burn the bottom of the food in contact with it much faster than it reheats or cooks that food.  A difference of 30 seconds or a minute could be the difference between very burnt but uncooked food and still uncooked-but-not-yet-burnt food.  Without any control over the temperature, the pan has limited usefulness for me.  And there are other issues.  Let me explain.Last night I decided to try to make a hamburger in the pan.  You can't get simpler than that, right?  I put a very tiny amount of coconut oil in the center of the pan - less than half a teaspoon.  I put the raw hamburger in, put the cover on and popped it into my 1100-watt microwave.  I put three minutes on the clock.  Went to turn the burger over and the pan is filled with smoke already - and now so is my kitchen.  Additionally, the grease from the burger was splattering all over the place when I had the cover opened to turn the burger - exactly as if I was frying the burger in pan.  Furthermore, I can see that some grease is getting in behind the seal that surrounds the pan's cooking surface.  This is a big problem, since you can't immerse the pan in water, you can't put it in the dishwasher and you can't remove the seal, so its literally impossible to remove what grease gets in there.  By the end of cooking the burger, the kitchen had its share of smoke and stinks of burnt fat.  There is grease all over my stove just from the time of checking/turning the burger.  And while the burger cooked okay, it would have come out much better under the broiler in my oven, or in a conventional frying pan for that matter.  So I won't be making burgers in this pan again.After that experience, and some others, I just don't see anything this pan can do well for me.  I may experiment with it a little more, but knowing that it functions exactly like an uncontrollable, super hot frying pan, I just don't see much use for it.  If I need to fry something, I'll fry it in a conventional pan where I can control the heat and see the food as it cooks.  That food will come out much better than it will in in this pan.  Just because this pan has slightly raised ridges, doesn't make it it a grill.  It's a frying pan for the microwave.  Who needs that?

I have Verizon FiOS for TV and internet at home and for all you Verizon FiOS users, you know that the Actiontec wireless router provided is not exactly the best for strong wireless signals.  I have an older model MI424WR-GEN2, so the best it can do is wireless-G.  It does not have AC or even N.  For years I had to deal with weak wireless signal throughout my house, especially in the bedroom which is located furthest from the router, two floors up and across the house from the router which is located in the basement.  Additionally, where I live, there are a TON of other wireless installations in the area, all of which are competing with my wireless for signal strength.  I could only get one bar of strength in the bedroom, even with the antenna on the router aimed correctly and with the best channel selected.Enter this TP-LINK TL-WPA4220KIT Advanced powerline/wireless kit.  This kit works by adding a second wireless access point to your house which you can place in an ideal location.  It doesn't have to be anywhere near your router because it links back to your router via an ethernet-though-powerline connection.  It sends its signal though your house wiring, so you don't have run ethernet cables throughout your home.Setup can be a little tricky and if you're not a computer person, you may need to borrow or rent somebody who is.  I have a Windows PC, so I cannot speak for Mac users.  This is the installation in a nutshell for a Verizon FiOS user, since the Actiontec router does not have a working Wi-Fi Clone function.  First, install the included software onto your computer.  The "Powerline Utility" is used to locate and configure the the base unit.  The "Powerline Scan" is used to locate and configure the wireless access point.  It would be nice if there was one program which did both functions, but its no big deal.Then, plug the smaller, wired connection into an open LAN port of your router with an ethernet cable (this kit includes two if you don't have any).  Now plug that unit directly into a wall outlet - Note that you shouldn't plug it into any kind of surge protector, UPS or power conditioner.  If you do, you may not get the maximum speeds this system is capable of or it may not work at all.  Now if you run the "Powerline Utility," you should be able to see the base unit show up in the list.  Now plug the larger, Wireless Access Point (AP) unit into another wall outlet.  For the purpose of configuration, just plug it in near your computer and the base unit.  Don't worry, you can relocate it later.  Now press the "pair" button on the Wireless AP unit, and then press the "pair" button on the base unit (it doesn't matter what order).  If everything went well, the powerline lights are now lit or blinking on both units and the two units should now be communicating with each other over your house wiring.  Also, the larger Wireless AP unit should now show up if you run the "Powerline Scan" software.  Now you have the hardware installed, but not configured.Now open a web browser, and go to 192.168.1.1.  This is the default IP address for the larger Wireless AP unit.  Note that this default default IP address for the TP-LINK *may* interfere with your router or another device on your home network, so it wasn't the best choice IMO.  You log into it using the default username/password provided.  And from this web interface, you can configure your new Wireless AP exactly as if you were configuring your home router - for instance, you can control the SSID, wireless security, network type etc. of the new Wireless AP.  From here you can set up the remote unit to be a duplicate of your main wireless AP, or set it up with a different SSID, preshared key, etc.  Once you have everything set up the way you like, you can simply unplug the larger, Wireless AP unit and locate it where you need it to be in your house.  It will automatically reconnect with the base unit - you don't have to re-pair it with the base unit or do anything else, just plug it back in.I have my new TP-LINK access point set up in a room on the 2nd floor of my house as a duplicate of my original wireless setup, except I have it set to wireless-N only and I have it set to a different channel for maximum performance.  Now when I connect to wireless in my bedroom on my LG Optimus G or 2014 Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1, I can get the full speed of my FiOS setup, which is 50 Mbps down and 20 Mbps up, where I could barely get 5 or 10 Mbps down before.  Additionally, the remote wireless AP unit has two ethernet ports which you can plug computers or other devices like game consoles or DVRs into directly or install a network switch or hub without having to run ethernet cables through your home.  On average, I'm seeing amost 200 Mbps when plugged in directly which is much faster than my internet connnection is capable of.For me, there are only two minor downsides.  For one thing, I'm losing two electrical outlets.  The units have no passthrough.  That's no big deal, but it is worth mentioning.  And second, because of the nature of my installation, where my Verizon Actiontec router only has wireless-G and I have the new TP-LINK access point set to wireless-N, and I have them manually set to different channels for superior signal strength, my wireless devices do not switch between them automatically when I'm closer to one access point or the other.  Again, this is no big deal for me as it takes only seconds to cycle the wireless off and back on my devices after which they then pick up the strongest (closest) access point.  I think if I had them set identically to wireless G and to the same channel, my devices may switch between them automatically, but I haven't tried that - and I'm not going to use the new TP-LINK access point on slower G when it has N.  Since in my case, they do act independently, I may set up the TP-LINK with a separate SSID, etc., so I know exactly which one I'm connected to.Overall, I'm very happy with the kit and it solves a problem I've been having for years.  You may need assistance setting this kit up, but once its configured, it works great.

Until recently, I had been using an previous model Norelco QT4022 which I got in 2011.  It worked well, but the battery was starting to show its age - meaning that the battery charges weren't lasting very long.  In addition, it developed this extremely unusual problem where it would not work corded in my bathroom, but would work corded everywhere else I tried!  That drove me nuts!  That model also had the issue of the mystery battery charge as there was no indication of the status of the battery when using or charging the unit.This new Norelco BT5275 is improved over that previous model in many ways.  Most importantly, the motor speed is faster, so it cuts faster and it cuts closer to the skin if you so desire.  It seems to vibrate less and it feels more precise than the QT4022.  Beard and sideburn trimming are fast and precise.  They don't show it in any of the photos here, but there is a hard plastic length guide that snaps into the top of the unit.  You snap that guide in, and then you turn the nicely rubberized grey wheel in the center of the unit to select a length.  The wheel is notched and it has numerical markings on it to indicate the desired trim length.  As you turn the wheel, you can also see the guide get higher or lower over the cutting blade.  This guide allows you to trim your beard or sideburns to any length you desire, quickly and easily without having to worry about making mistakes.  Take the length guide off the unit and you can make precise edges on your beard or sideburns - or you can trim your beard down to fine stubble to make it easier to shave.  The top of this unit actually rotates between the main trimmer and an even more precise mini-trimmer.  I don't have a use for the mini-trimmer, but I can see that some people may find it very useful depending on the style of beard they have.  Since this is a wet/dry trimmer, you can use it bone dry or in the shower or just with a wet face, which I prefer.  Simply rinse the trimmer off and let it dry.  Unlike my previous Norelco, this one has an indicator light to indicate full charge and low charge.  It also seems to have a much better battery management circuit as the unit will stop charging once the battery is fully charged.  My previous Norelco QT4022 had none of this.  Battery life has been stellar so far, much better than I remember it was on my previous Norelco QT4022 even when it was new.  I've used it many times on a single charge!  The manual states 60 minutes of use from a 60 minute charge.  So far, that seems accurate.  Maybe that's because this unit has a superior lithium-ion battery and my previous unit used a nickel-metal hydride battery.  Finally, this unit requires no maintenance and no oiling, so thats one less thing you'll have to be concerned with.There is one thing I don't like about it, and that is the placement and type of on/off switch.  The switch itself is a push-button electronic switch.  It feels mushy and imprecise.  I also feel that the switch is located too low on the handle of the unit.  You have to make an effort to turn it on and off, instead of the switch being located where your fingers fall naturally higher on the handle.  A slide type switch, located higher on the unit would have been ideal.Overall, I am very happy with this trimmer.  It works great, it handles well and keeps my beard the way I like it.

4:20 MinsThis is an all-around excellent Android tablet.  Let me start off with a brief review of the tablet's physical attributes.The first thing you'll want to know about is the display.  It is very, very good.  It is very high resolution by today's standards at 2560x1600 boasting 299 pixels-per-inch (think about how laser printers were once the same at 300 dots-per-inch).  It is also very bright with great color reproduction and good contrast.  The screen uses IPS technology and it has excellent viewing angles - so you don't have to worry about being perfectly aligned with the screen in order to see it clearly and the contrast stays good even at steep angles.  The screen has an aspect ratio of 16:10, so the Note is ideal for internet browsing, gaming or viewing HD video.  The Note also has very good stereo speakers located along the upper right and left edge (when the tablet held in its native landscape mode) - they produce loud and clear audio and the speaker placement doesn't interfere with your hand placement.  Of course there isn't any bass to speak of, but one cannot expect any bass from speakers of this size.  Still, the audio sounds good when playing games or watching internet videos.  As I previously mentioned, the Note is meant to be held in landscape mode, with the hardware home button closest to you.  Of course, the screen content can rotate to portrait, depending on the program.  Most of what I use it for works in landscape, which is good because I prefer it that way.  Unfortunately, the USB 2.0/power port is located in the center of the bottom edge right under the hardware home button.  This can present an issue if you want to charge the battery when using the tablet at an angle on a stand in landscape mode as a USB plug can interfere with the bottom edge.  I think it would have made much more sense to have the USB 2.0/power port located on either the top or right edge of the tablet.  Located just to the left of the USB/power port on the bottom edge is a microphone.  There is a Micro SDXC slot under a cover along the right edge which can currently accept up to a 64GB Micro SDXC card.  This is useful for storing large amounts of media such as music, photos and video files, which can be quite large.  I highly recommend the Samsung 64GB Pro microSDXC card as it currently the fastest and most reliable 64GB Micro SDXC card available.  Moving on, there is an 8MP rear facing camera with LED flash and a 2MP front facing camera.  I haven't used the cameras very much at all, so I can't really comment on them.  There is an infrared port along the top edge which facilitates the use of the tablet as a smart universal remote control with an integrated program guide (for which the software is included).  I know it works because I tried it with my TiVo HD, but I didn't find it very useful for me so I haven't used it since.  Depending on your home A/V setup, it may be very useful for you.  The power and volume control buttons are located along the top edge on the far left.  I feel that those buttons are too difficult to navigate as they are small with very little feel or button travel.  As a result, I installed a software volume control which resides in the Android notification shade that I like a lot better.  The earphone jack is located on the top left edge.  On the top right edge is the slot for storing the S-Pen (along with the actual S-Pen).  The S-Pen, which is one of the main features of this tablet, allows you to draw and write directly on the screen.  I have used it at times for text input and the tablet will recognize your handwriting (either in block or script!) and translate it into editable text, which is really cool.  The tablet feels really good in the hand.  For me, it's not heavy at all and I can easily hold it with one hand.  The back of the tablet has a grippy, faux leather like finish, which I like, but my tablet lives in an excellent Poetic Slimline case, so I don't get to feel that very often.Although the 2014 Note 10.1 can be used for a wide range of things, what I got this tablet for is gaming!  And boy does this tablet deliver.  With it's 3GB of RAM, the latest generation Samsung Exynos 5420 octa-core processor (which is really a dual quad-core) and a Mali-T628 graphics processor, I get excellent gaming performance!  I regularly play Asphalt 8, which looks amazing on this tablet with it's real time reflections, motion blur, advanced lighting and particle effects.  It looks and plays great!  Since I'm a sucker for good racing games, and racing games are a natural fit on tablets since you can usually steer by rotating/tilting the tablet, I also play GT Racing 2, which again, looks amazing playing in the full 2560x1600 resolution of the tablet.  I also play Armored Aces, which is a great, WWII 3D multiplayer tank game, Heroes of Destiny, which is a great 3D dungeon battle game, and Dead Trigger 2, which is an super fun 3D first-person-shooter which pits you against hordes and hordes of very unreasonable zombies in locations around the world.  These are among the latest and greatest 3D games available and they look and play incredibly well on the 2014 Galaxy Note 10.1.  Not surprisingly, 2D games like Clash of Clans also look amazing and play extremely well on the Note.  It also plays video very well both from the internet and local files you store on the SD card.  This device is a great companion for a trip or flight.  Battery life is stellar for me.  I get over six hours of screen time when 3D gaming the whole time (yes, I really need to get a life).  If I were to use it like a normal person, I could easily see getting over eight hours of screen time on a charge.  One minor issue is that I don't feel that the charger is strong enough as it really doesn't charge the battery very much at all when charging while the tablet is in use.  It will charge a few percent, but it doesn't really charge well at all as long as the screen is on.There is one fairly important issue though which I would like to touch on and that is the some buggy behavior with the touchscreen itself.  At the moment, there is an issue where if you touch and hold any area of the screen for 24 seconds, your touch will be reset and it will not work well again for about five seconds.  Why is this a problem, you ask?  Well, say you're playing a racing game that requires you to push an on-screen gas pedal.  After 24 seconds, you won't be pressing it anymore, even if you are in fact, still pressing it.  If you try to immediately press it again, it will immediately disengage again for about five seconds until it acts normal again for the next 24 seconds, and so on.
