That is but one example of the issue, but it could happen with controls for direction in a first-person-shooter or some other type of game.  But really no matter what you're doing, or what software you're running, whether it is a game, productivity software, music, or whatever, if you touch the screen in one area for 24 seconds straight, it will reset your touch and not work well again for about five seconds.  It's a problem.  Through the XDA Developers forum, I verified that this problem likely exists on all of the 2014 Note 10.1 devices (model SM-P600) with firmware MK1.  I believe it is a driver issue.  From what I understand, so far Samsung has not acknowledged the problem.  Hopefully, they will discover and fix this with the next firmware release as it can be a really a major issue depending on what you're doing.  Luckily most of the racing games I play have the option for automatic throttle, but I wish I could use a manual throttle control.  It does affect my Armored Aces gameplay as I have to remember to quickly get off and then back on the throttle prior to 24 seconds in order to avoid a bad situation.  *(4/27/2014: The 24-second-timeout issue with the touchscreen was fixed with new ND2 firmware!)*Overall, it's a great, versatile tablet.  I love it.  In fact, I own two of them and I gave a third to my girlfriend who also loves it.  If it wasn't for the issues with the weak charger and especially the touchscreen, I would give it five stars.***04/27/2014 UPDATE:***Lets say four and a half stars!  In the past week, Samsung released its Android KitKit 4.4.2 firmware update for the US version of the 2014 Note 10.1 (firmware ND2).  I applied it a few days ago and I can tell you along with the update from Jellybean to KitKat, it also fixes the 24-second-timeout issue with the touchscreen.  The KitKat update has made the overall tablet experience faster and smoother.  Samsung made some nice changes to Touchwiz including a better notification shade and a better task manager to name a few.  Unfortunately, the KitKat update also introduces the Google-mandated restriction on which apps can write to the external SD card.  Even though I'm not a fan of this restriction, it doesn't really affect me (yet) and I don't think it will affect most users.  The restriction can be eliminated if you root the tablet.  Overall, I'm very happy with the update so far, and I will report back if I find any issues!***05/17/2014 UPDATE:***One thing I've seen some people complain about is that the speaker grilles either are or get loose and then have a bit of play in them.  Mine were a bit loose from the start, but it wasn't an issue until today.  Today I noticed that the right speaker grille is very loose.  It's not falling out and it doesn't come out, but the top edge of the right grille is literally hanging out.  Just to make sure it couldn't fall out, I tried pulling it off using some masking tape, but it held in place.  The left grille has some play in it but its not nearly as loose as the right grille (yet?).  Since it doesn't snap back into place and the grille is so small and fine, I haven't figured out a way to fix this.  I'm not sure I want to use glue as glue could damage the finish and it may make it difficult to disassemble the tablet, if that is ever necessary.  I'll update if I fix this or if it gets worse.  While this is something to look out for, this is an excellent tablet, and this is not something that should keep you from considering one.***06/26/2014 UPDATE:***I have found Real Racing 3!  (see video)  Wow!  Hands down it is the best racing game on the Android platform at this time!  It has the best physics, the most detailed cars (including interiors) and it is both fun and challenging to play!  There are currently 91 different cars and 12 tracks (many with multiple configurations).  It looks great and plays really well on the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1!  Alphalt 8 and GT Racing 2 are out!

This could have been an all around great relatively compact camera.  It has a full size image sensor for low noise and high light sensitivity - it enables the camera to take images with a high degree of detail and the camera great in low light situations.  It accepts interchangeable E-mount lenses.  It has an amazing flip-up and tilt LCD touch screen with a high-pixel density so images are super clear and you can easily frame and even manually focus shots well if you choose to do so without a viewfinder.  It has almost all the latest bells and whistles such as Wi-Fi, NFC, face recognition, a fast autofocus, touch-to-focus, and full-HD video recording at 60-frames-per-second, etc.  The one thing it does not have is a built in flash.  Surprise!  That's right folks, Sony sacrificed functionality for form factor and this camera does not have a built-in pop-up flash.  It comes with a separate flash unit that you have to plug in and screw onto the top of the unit, which is a pain in the #$$ and I think it kills the overall flexibility of the camera.  If you're buying this camera instead of a larger DLSR, are you going to want to carry a flash around with you, either in your pocket, or mounted on top of the unit where it can be easily damaged?  Sony has other cameras in the NEX line with a built in, pop-up flash such as the NEX-3NL/B.  Why couldn't they have made this camera body slightly larger to accomodate a built in a flash?  What was Sony thinking?  It seems like such an afterthought.  You either have to have the flash unit with you and/or attached at all times or do without the flash.  Either way it limits your flexibility.  A lot of photos are taken indoors, with friends or at functions, etc. and you need a flash.  I want to be able to grab this camera and go.  I don't want to have to think about whether the flash is attached or not.  It's not even like its a hotshoe flash (which this camera does not support, no hotshoe on this model).  Its a dinky little flash.  For me, this takes what could have been a great compact camera and relagates it to only good.  And what a shame considering all of the other technology they put into this thing.  It takes great pictures, clear video, it has good battery life, and it has all kinds of other bells and whistles but I think Sony made a mistake leaving out a built-in flash.

I that find this lantern comes in handy more often than you may think.  Need to get wires straightened under a desk?  Bring the lantern with you to light up the area.  And that's what it does very well, light up an area.  Unlike a flashlight which generally provides a beam, this lantern lights up an pretty good size area, nicely and evenly.  You can carry it using it's very ergonomic carry handle which is nicely textured and feels good in the hand.  You can just put it down somewhere with its very stable, nicely weighted base thanks to the four "D" batteries inside and use it upright.  You can even remove the clear polycarbonate dome, which twists off easily, and use the hook recessed on the very bottom of the base to hang it upside down for use as an overhead light.  It has two brightness settings.  On high, the 260 lumen output is fairly bright and is good for outdoor use or lighting up that project you're working on.  On low, it provides more than enough light to deal with a dark room easily, like if there was a power outage.  It even has a USB outlet which you can use to charge a phone or tablet off of the four "D" batteries.  There is a small, red LED light which blinks when the four "D" batteries are running low - note that when the batteries are low, the light only blinks when the light is on - so the battery monitor apparently does not sap power from the batteries when the light is not in use.  The power switch is rubber coated and so are the sides and bottom of the unit, so its very grippy and feels good in the hand.  The USB outlet also has a rubber cover to keep out dust, dirt and water.  The unit seems very well made and solid, although I'm sure if you drop it onto concrete bad things will happen.  The only somewhat negative thing I can say is that I often find myself trying to turn the unit on by pressing the rubber cover on the USB port... because the USB port is mounted directly over the power switch, which my brain thinks is backwards. :-)  But overall, I think its a great little light!  Pick one up with some "D" batteries just to have for when the power goes out.  But like me, I think you will find it more useful than that.  Trust me, you will not regret it.

This is good toilet paper.  It's soft and absorbent.  It works well for what it's intended for.  It's convenient to have it delivered to your door.But let me tell you the problem with it and with every other brand of toilet paper lately.  Charmin and all the rest of the manufacturers must think we're all stupid.  They keep making the cardboard hubs larger while putting less and less paper on ever increasingly narrower rolls while still calling them "double rolls."  The "double rolls" of today are nothing more than what used to be "regular" rolls of ten of fifteen years ago.  The cardboard hubs get larger, the paper gets smaller.  I get it that we are in a bad economy and I get it that the price of the materials has increased due to inflation and other factors, but when does this stop?  At this rate, we're headed towards "double" rolls with two, two inch square, squares.  Just put the paper on the rolls and charge us for it already.

The GoPro HERO3+ Black Edition has very definite and noticable improvements over the HERO3 Black Edition.  Pretty much everything is better about it!  Starting with the new lens which helps the HERO3+ Black Edition produce much sharper video than before, with better, more lifelike color, better saturation, better contrast and truer white balance (say goodbye to the yellow cast!).  It also has better low light performance with better clarity and color accuracy than before at night and in light challenged situations.  The new microphones and audio system produce video with waaaay clearer, much more accurate and dynamic audio.  The HERO3+ Black Edition has about a 20~25% improved battery life/charge thanks to both a higher capacity battery and better power consumption.  The WIFI speed and range have been dramatically improved thanks to a new WIFI chip.  In my experience, I get a range increase of close to five times that of Hero3 Black Edition.  Even the waterproof case has been improved as it is about 20% smaller, with a much-easier-to-use latch system and much-easier-to-use buttons.  Additionally, the HERO3+ Black Edition has a new super wide angle mode called SuperView which gives you the widest viewing angles yet.  GoPro has really been listening to the user community and these improvements make an already great live-action camera even better!If you do pick one up, be certain to purchase a GOOD, FAST MicroSD card.  I highly recommend the Samsung 64GB Pro microSDXC(MB-MGCGB/AM) card.  I have had zero problems with it in my HERO3 or HERO3+.  I have had problems with SanDisk Ultra 64GB cards and cannot recommend them (I have friends who have also had issues with SanDisk Ultra cards in their GoPros).For those of you who are concerned about the talk of a "focus issue" with the HERO3+ Black Edition mentioned in some reviews, I suggest that you don't listen to the negative reviews without checking out the comment section of this review for links to direct head to head video comparisons of the HERO3+ Black Edition vs the HERO3 Black Edition (I can't post links in the main review).  These videos feature side by side HD footage taken by both cameras at the exact same time using special rigs.  Judge for yourself.  Again, click the comments button below for the URLs.

Based on my many years of experience, I consider myself to be an electronics expert.  I can tell you that good power protection is an important, relatively inexpensive investment that can save you thousands of dollars and even more importantly, help to protect the life of your priceless electronic memories.  I do recommend that if you're going to invest thousands of dollars in an audio system or an expensive big-screen tv or a high performance computer, yes, absolutely, get a good surge protector to protect that investment from extreme events and every day power woes.  Or even better, get a UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply).  But this specific device, with it's claims of "Enhance the Performance of Your Video Display," I cannot justify.  It's simply dishonest hype.At the time of this review, Amazon is selling this two outlet, surge surpressor/line conditioner for $110.For $105 you can get a CyberPower 1000VA/600W UPS with EMI/RFI filtering, RJ11/45 & Coax Protection and nine outlets!  An excellent, more versatile, battery back up system for about the same price!For a little more money, $135, you can get the even better CyberPower 1350VA/810W UPS with with EMI/RFI filtering, RJ11/45 & Coax Protection and eight outlets!  Both of those units have automatic voltage regulation (AVR) which ensures that all your electronics are receiving clean power and the units maintain a safe voltage level.For $79, you can get a Cyberpower CP825LCD 825VA/450W Compact Design UPS with EMI/RFI filtering and eight outlets.  Again, a battery backed UPS, not just a surge protector.Based on its actual specs, the lack of hard proof of any of its dubious claims, and knowing full well they are not true, I cannot recommend this product.  Unless they could prove to this veteran electronics expert otherwise, you would be much better off purchasing another product.

A trimmer is something I don't want to think too much about.  I just want it work when I need it to.  I don't want to spend time wondering if the unit is charged, if it's charged too much or if the battery is near depletion.  Unfortunately, with this otherwise perfectly nice unit, you'll have to keep on top of the battery condition because this trimmer doesn't do that for you.The first problem I have is that according to the manual, it takes ten hours of charging to every one hour of usage!  10 hours charging for 1 hour of use?  Seriously?Second, the battery management is so bad, that the unit has no way to even let you know when it is fully charged.  In fact, there is no battery life indicator of any kind.  When you plug the trimmer in to charge it, a light near the plug base slowly blinks.  Sounds promising, right?  But to quote the manual and counter to all reasonable logic, "After the trimmer is fully charged, the charging light will continue to blink."  Really?  That seems perfectly logical and modern... NOT.  Why didn't they use an inexpensive circut to stop charging the battery once it's fully charged? ?  ???  Really?  How is anyone supposed to KNOW when/if the battery is fully charged then?  Should I summon Karnak the Magnificent?But it gets worse.  Yes, because according to the manual "Continuously recharging the trimmer will reduce the lifespan of the battery" and "Do not charge for more than 24 hours" and "...do not recharge the trimmer between trimming sessions - continue using it until the battery is completely empty" and "Do not keep the cord permanently plugged in" and "Discharge/run down the battery completely twice a year by letting the motor run until it stops"Basically, if you don't manage this charging game well, you'll kill the Nickel-Metal Hydride (NiMH) battery prematurely.  According to a very well known, major manufacturer of electronics and batteries, "extensive trickle charging (of NiMH batteries) can cause battery deterioration due to overcharging, and it is the least preferred charging method concerning battery performance."I don't know about you, but to me, that is too much for me to be concerned about for a beard trimmer when I just want it work when I need it.It's a shame because other than that, it's a nice unit.  It's light, nicely balanced, it feels nice in your hand, it's easy to use, easy to adjust, easy to clean (it can be rinsed), and it does a nice job trimming my beard and sideburns.  Why, oh why did they skimp out so much on the battery/charging section?

I am a lover of dark chocolate.  Unfortunately, this chocolate will disappoint true dark chocolate lovers.  Its waaaay too sweet!  Its not bad chocolate - its creamy, its rich, its got good cacao flavor, but they put too much sugar in it.  I prefer the very complex, slightly bitter, very dark (71% cacao) Dove Silky Smooth Dark Chocolate instead.  Also, the Newman's chocolate is broken into six relatively large 1.5 x 1.25 inch squares - IMO just a little too large to just put one square in your mouth and allow it to melt away.  The Dove is broken into 1 x 1 inch squares - the perfect size to melt on your tongue.  Even the wrapper on the Dove is better as it is true foil and easily allows you to keep the remaining chocolate wrapped up tight.  The Newman's comes in gold paper meant to look like foil, but its only paper - it does not close well.  Overall, disappointed.

If you have to move a lot of data between computers or wish to carry a lot of software or music or movies or backups around in your pocket (and protect it with hardware-based encryption), this may be the drive for you.  It's small and light enough to fit in your shirt pocket (though I wouldn't recommend that) and it has a large, 500GB capacity!  The drive gets its power through the USB cable, so there is no separate power cable to carry or plug in - only a small USB cable (which is included).  Just plug the drive into your laptop or desktop computer's USB port, install the included encryption driver and go.  About the only thing not impressive about this drive is that it's not the fastest drive in the world - its speed is limited by both the USB 2.0 connection and the slow, low RPM (low power) drive itself - so the high capacity and portability has some trade-offs.  The included USB cable is really short (18"), so if you need a bit more length, you'll have to purchase a separate USB to Micro USB cable.  Finally, just plugging the drive in prompts Windows to request for the installation of Western Digital's SES device driver to your PC.  The SES device driver handles the drive's optional 256-bit hardware encryption.  I have no use for the encryption, so I didn't wish to install the SES driver.  Unfortunately, if you do that, you'll be prompted to install the driver whenever you plug the drive in or restart your system.  I never allowed it to install and I don't want it to install so I disabled the SES device in Windows' device manager to stop the prompts.  The average person may not know how to do that.  All in all, if you can live with the relatively low speed, or if you want a portable drive with encrypted data, or you need to move or carry a lot of data or backups around, especially for a laptop, this may be the drive for you.

This is a serious hair dryer, no compromise here.  It's ergonomic, nicely balanced and although it's heavier than my previous dryer, it's also much more powerful.  I like the fact that it has a removable filter on the back for easy cleaning.  I also like the cold air setting which my previous dryer lacked completely, including a separate quick "cold shot" trigger you can activate at any time.  You can customize the heat/speed easily since the heat and speed are controlled by separate rocker switches.  The controls are easy to use, but because of their location and easy movement, you may occasionally change either the heat or the speed setting unintentionally while using it.  I find myself getting used to holding it more and more so that doesn't happen.  Most importantly, this thing has power.  It can really move some air and get that air nice and hot, too.  The outside stays relatively cool.  Interestingly, it's not as loud as my previous dryer either.  If you can get over the color scheme they used, dark purply brown with pink trim, this is a great hair dryer.

I've been using Cottonelle for years, and I can say without hesitation that this is a superior product.  Don't let the fact that this is single-ply get in the way of trying this... it's strong, it's soft enough without being so soft that it disintegrates easily and most importantly, it doesn't shred either.  Since it is single ply, you don't run into a badly spooled split-ply like I would with Cottonelle sometimes.  Another observation is that unlike Cottonelle, you don't get a fine paper mill dust with it that ends up accumulating on the floor - this is a clean product.  These double rolls fit the fixture just fine without any issue.  Let's face it, we all use TP.  You may as well use TP that works well.

I had high hopes when I opened the box.  The device was light, sleek and attractive (for a laptop cooler). Unfortunately, I immediately discovered some major flaws.I plugged the device into my Lenovo Thinkpad R40 which tends to run hot.  There is no mention of this on the Amazon product page, but there is no A/C power adapter included.  The product is designed to draw power directly from your laptop via a split, dual USB cable included with the unit.  If your laptop is short on free USB ports, this could be a deal breaker.  You can use one or both USB leads to power the cooler.  They recommend using both for "maximum cooling," but I only detected a slight difference in the max fan speed when using both USB leads as opposed to using only one (that was while the laptop was plugged into a/c power - there might be a more discernible differerence on some laptops, especially if running from battery power).  But that is the least of your concerns.The cooler has a small, on/off/speed adjustment dial on the right-front side near a tiny, bright, white LED light to let you know when the unit is on (at least theoretically).  I turned the switch so it clicked on and the three 80mm x 10mm fans spin up for a split second and then they stop.  They stopped?  Yes, they stopped.  Hence the unit's first major flaw.  The fans will only actually run at medium to max speed.  Instead of the fans running slowly and silently and then steadily increasing in speed as you turn the dial, I had to turn the dial to max to get the fans to spin up at all and then dial it back to get any speed other than stop or max.  Even then, if you dial it back too far, the fans will just stop.  There really isn't a slient, low speed.I say they are cheapy made fans because of the second major flaw - the fans on my unit buzz, whir and generally make noise.  One of the three fans on my unit even sounds like it's completely unbalanced to the point where it actually makes a clicking noise at lower speeds.  At max RPM, the fans all straighten up and spin right, but they are noisy fans at max RPM.  They make your laptop sound almost like a desktop pc.Even at max RPM, the cooling provided by this mat is again limited by the fact that the fans are only moving air in a straight line of 80mm x 280mm as the three fans are all lined up in a row close to the rear of the unit.  This is the third major flaw.  If your laptop generates heat or has air intakes in the front, the middle or just nowhere near the main area of airflow in the rear, the Chill Mat will be far less effective for you.  It will provide some amount of cooling, but less than I had hoped.Also note that the description boasts that the "Grill is constructed of anodized 2040 aluminum alloy" - but it is only a very thin, surface layer of aluminum bonded to plastic.  90+% of this unit is plastic.  Again, attractive, but not made of aluminum.In my opinion, the flaws are unacceptable for a $60 laptop cooler.  The average person may not even realize that the fans have stopped spinning at a low setting when they are expecting this unit to reliably cool their laptop, let alone an expensive "gaming" laptop.  It only works reliably at or near max rpm and then the unit produces a lot of noise.  Even then, it will typically provide only very limited cooling due to the small area in which the fans operate.  I don't think I would recommend this product.

First thing I'll note is that the packaging for this device is supremely stupid.  It's made of that thin, clear, tough plastic that can have sharp edges, doesn't play well with fingers and it's of a size and complexity that is completely unnecessary for a device of this size - small!  They should have put this in a small, printed cardboard box without all the unnecessary plastic, layers and compartments.Getting past the packaging, you'll see that unit is very small and compact - 2 & 7/8" long by 1.25" wide by 3/8" thick.  The LCD display covers most of the front and there are four rather spongy, rubber buttons along the right side.  Overall the unit is very light and it feels solid.  After you insert the included CR2032 button battery, you'll have to provide the unit with a few pieces of info to set it up.  First the measurement units - either metric or standard.  Then enter your weight, stride length and the time of day.  You can measure your average stride length by marking a point on the floor, taking five or ten steps, measuring the distance, and then dividing the distance you travelled by the number of steps you took.  The more steps you use for your measurement, the more accurate the unit will be - though realize that however accurate you are, this measure can only serve as an approximation.  That's it!  Now you can carry the device in your pocket or purse and it will measure your walking activity - just don't let it swing freely from the included lanyard which will cause it to be inaccurate as it measures inertia.The basic display is large and clear.  It displays the amount of steps you've taken since 2am that day and the current time.  You can press the "mode" button to display the total approxmiate distance you've travelled and the approximate number of calories you've burned that day.  You can also press the "mem" button and then use the up/down and mode buttons to review and compare your activity through the past fourteen days.  There is also a small bar meter along the bottom you can view during activity which will indicate how fast or slow it thinks your moving at that time - of course, the faster you move, the more calories you are burning.The battery is supposed to last for about a year and the unit will shut down the display during periods of inactivity - though the unit is always on and measuring your movements - there is no manual on/off control.If you're looking for a pedometer, this device seems to work pretty well.  It's small, light, solid feeling and easy to read.  My only negatives are the spongy buttons they used and the terribly unfriendly, unnecessary packaging.  Overall, I would recommend it.

I finally got around to brewing this Melitta Hazelnut Creme Brulee (after all kinds of fun in getting the package open) using my Bodum coffee press.  While the aroma is good, the taste left me wondering what they use to flavor this stuff.  It just didn't seem "right" to me.  Over the next few days, I brewed it again and I was left with the same impression - it just tasted artificial to me.  I served it to my brother with no pre-discussion and he didn't really go for it either - so it wasn't just me.  I would have to say pass on this one.

I'm not really happy with these.  I like my pens to feel solid with absolutely no play in the mechanism.  Unfortunately, I feel there is a just a bit of play when putting these pens to paper which I don't like and I can't tighten that play out.  Once you do make contact, the pen does write very smoothly.  But unfortunately, the ink does not dry immediately and it could take some time to set depending on the surface, so you have to be careful not to smudge what you've already written - for me, this is a deal breaker.  The pens do have a rubber grip and I was expecting more of a soft cushion, but the rubber layer is very thin so there is very little cushioning effect for your fingertips.  All in all, I can't say that I'm thrilled with these.  There are much better pens out there.

Love it!  It immediately solved a problem on a day trip during which we needed to use our GPS due to frequent non-reception areas for our cell phones (therefore, no map program availability), and also needed to charge both of our cell phones.  With only two 12v power outlets in our vehicle, this allowed everything to happen at once.  The blue light around the outside of the unit is nice to know for sure that the unit is powered, particularly with one 12v outlet powered all the time, and the other only powered when the engine is running.  Having a cord included was a big plus (we already had one cord in the vehicle for use, but would have been caught short when it became apparent that both phones needed charging toward the end of the trip.  I'm not one to easily pass out a 5-star rating unless a product is among the best options in terms of price/functionality/design.  This met our needs nicely, since we don't have iPhones (note that there are different purchase options for compatibility, so don't blame the unit if you didn't order the right one).  Finally, the power rating is quite welcome - too often, less expensive similar products are lower power, meaning longer charging times, etc.NOTE: If this does not last over time, I will automatically update this review with a significantly lower rating.  There are always going to be a few defective units with any product, but generally electronic items fail quickly or last a long time.  This was used continuously for almost all of a day-trip, with no overheating of the phones or cord, and no failure.  If this review still stands at 5-stars well past the review date, it's still working just fine.

I have my vitamin D levels checked every year at my physical.  Since switching to Nutrigold's D3 about a year ago,  for the first year my vitamin D level is down almost 20 points on the test.  I take 4000 units per day,  and still only achieved 75.8 ng/ml this year, even though it's been consistently above 90 in prior years.  I've just not been impressed with this company, nor the answers I get from them in prior questions I've had.  I'm done with Nutrigold entirely.  These test results are quite conclusive to me, since I'm well within acceptable limits on other lab work and have no other issues.  Either the quantity advertised is not accurate, or there's something else about this company's product that results in poor absorption.  Based on years of monitoring (with consistent results), I ought to get considerably more D3 level than 75.8 ng/ml.

If you ever want to save bacon grease, you cannot do it with this product.  If you just want a simple way of draining it off your bacon, leaving it less greasy, this will do a nice job.  The product is basically a 2-layer product, with the inner (upper) layer being perforated to allow the grease to drip down into the lower portion at the bottom.  When you're done, just throw out the entire pay (it's a single use product).At the current listed price on Amazon, you're paying $1.67 for a single cooking of bacon strips, just for the convenience of not having to lay out a far less expensive sheet of aluminum foil on a cookie sheet (or similar), pull the corners up and fold the sides up just a bit to hold the grease, then fold all that up carefully after cooking is done and throwing it out the same as you would with this product.  Very little extra effort, and far less expensive.  And there's very little else you could probably use this product for.Also, what about recycling?  Aluminum is recyclable, but somehow the grease should be drained out (and separately recycled) before this is put in a recycle bin (I just verified that with a recycling company).  Do NOT pour the grease down the drain (bad for your plumbing, even worse for your city's sewer system).The definition of three stars is, "It's okay."  So I gave it three stars based on its intended purpose only.  It accomplishes it  Otherwise, it's an expensive way to do bacon and creates a recycling problem if you don't go through the trouble of cutting out a corner and draining as much grease as possible before recycling it.  We will not buy it ourselves.  While we're not environmentalist whackos, we do what we reasonably can to preserve, recycle, etc.  This is a wasteful and, frankly, an environmentally irresponsible product from a major corporation.

In concept, just like the original Battleship game, but with a Star Wars theme so that it's more fun.  It's more compact than the original (not counting the OLD way of playing it just with paper back in ancient days <grin>), so that could be a positive or negative factor depending on where or how you're using the game.  It went together easily and the pieces work well.  Pricing on it may be a little high for what it is, but still very well worth considering.Overall, it's a great classic game with a new Star Wars look.

We have used this product for many years, and at the first sign of what appears to be a cold or flu, this simply works.  Usually within hours, or at most a day, symptoms just disappear.  What else needs to be said or asked for!?

After several days of wear, the watch is keeping good time, looks very nice, is study, and the appearance is very nice.  The little blue crystal "jewel" on the stem is a nice touch.  The band seems very study.  Overall, it's a very nice watch as long as someone is not wanting/needing a date or alarm function.

Alias is a great game that gets players thinking and expanding their vocabularies.  It was tested by two adults and two children (ages 10+ and 13+), and all agree it's a good 4-star product.  The 6 year old hasn't yet joined in, but it can be made easier for younger kids as well, and we anticipate it will be a great family game for all.

I own the black version of this same model, so this review directly applies to this watch also (only difference is silver vs. black face).The dial is fairly easily readable, but there are several problems with it. The TINY date window in the center of the circular area at 6:00 is very hard to read anyway, and if either the hour or minute hand are near the 6:00 position, the date window is completely covered. Even when not covered, the date is so small that it's almost impossible to read unless the watch is held up close. Even worse, within an hour of midnight you can't tell what the date is - the date slowly rotates toward the next date as that final hour of the day passes. The date function is purely mechanical, with 31 numbers on it so five out of twelve months you'll have to reset your watch by moving the date forward on the last day of the month.The circle around the date window has 12 metal dots around the outside of it like a clock face, suggesting that perhaps that's a second-hand window of some sort. They're simply decorations with an extremely tuny date window in the middle. You get hours and minutes by the two conventional hands - that's it.Setting the watch? Extremely difficult. Pull the stem out all the way and set the hours and minutes (but make sure you know whether you just passed 12:00 noon or 12:00 midnight, or your date window will be changing at noon rather than midnight). Setting the date is extremely difficult. I could feel no intermediate "click" when pulling out the stem part way to set the date. If you don't get it just right, you won't be moving the date window, but will be moving the hour and minute hands and have to reset them again. Don't be confused by the printed instructions - you do NOT have to screw out the crown (stem). You'll just pull it out like most older style conventional, mechanically set watches.Finally, the clasp. Despite considerable education and some very technical positions in life, I simply could not figure out how the clasp works. The metal "thing" attached under the band simply makes no sense without any instructions (and there are none with the watch). I finally had to call the company. Be sure to save the little tag attached to the watch with the model number on it - you will need that for the customer support person. (Alternately, the watch model is printed in very tiny letters/numbers on the back of the watch case.)The trick is to look carefully at the 4th photo on the Amazon product page, noticing that BOTH sides of the metal piece under the leather band unsnap from the band to open up much wider so it can slip over your wrist. You can't on the watch and then adjust the band to insert the little pin in the proper hole in the leather band in order to fit it to your wrist. You GUESS at the size of the watch band when fully closed, fit the pin through the hole you think might work in the band, then open up both sides of the metal clasp underneath, slip the band over your wrist, re-snap the metal clasp closed, and then slip the end of the leather band through the small straps across the band to keep it from flapping loose (that part is just like a normal leather watch band after you've gotten all the other operations done). When the company representative told me to fit the band BEFORE putting it on my wrist, I had no idea what she was talking about. She said there's an internet page that shows how to do it, but when you go to the web site listed in the instruction insert, it simply says the web site is "coming soon." I have not been able to find any other instructions following a fairly substantial web search. Fortunately, the representative finally said something - I don't even remember what - that made me realize that the metal portion of the clasp that goes underneath the band, snaps and unsnaps in a way somewhat similar to a traditional all-metal watch band that unsnaps, unfolds, and then can be slipped off the wrist, reversing that action to put it back on again. Still, the end of the leather strap has to be fully removed from under the two leather retention bands across the main band, in order to undo the watch band from your wrist. Once you've put the watch back on and re-snapped both sides of the metal portion of the band underneath, you then have to slide the leather portion back under the retaining bands just like a "normal" leather watch band.Even adjusting the leather portion of the strap initially to get the metal pin through the proper hold is a very, very difficult task, until you realize that the metal band that goes across the top of the leather band has an unsnap feature of its own. That allows somewhat (relatively speaking) easier open of that metal area so the leather strap will slide through it without immediately catching the pin in the first or second leather strap hole. You then guesstimate which hole to stick the retaining pin through on the leather band, snap the metal retaining band down tight again, and proceed to figure out the metal retention mechanism down underneath the leather strap.If all that sounds confusing, it's because it truly is! I cannot describe a more logical set of instructions even now that I've done it a few times. It's the most non-user-friendly thing I've ever seen. And the representative on the phone said, "Don't feel bad. You're not at all the first person that has called about this." I suspect that was an understatement.... It would take a slow, stop-action video, with excellent verbal description and arrows pointing to various pieces on the band for a user to fairly easily follow operation of this band. I hate to belabor this point, but the clasp mechanism and strap are just absurd. Another reviewer said it would be difficult for a person with arthritis or some other manual dexterity problem - I fully concur.Would I spend a little over $60 for this watch if I knew what was involved in using it every day? Not a chance, despite the fact that the basic appearance is quite nice (disregarding an almost unreadable date, and no second hand). The $395 "list price" is one of the most absurd jokes I've ever seen on any product. This is by far the most inconvenient watch I've ever owned (I've owned many watches over many years, including expensive watches such as a self-winding Hamilton that I still have from nearly 50 years ago). I've just never seen anything this non-user friendly or poorly designed in my life, masquerading as a quality time piece.At least it has a 5-year warranty, as long as you keep your proof of purchase and send them $15.00 along with the watch you paid to ship to them, including insurance. BUT - warranty exclusions? Everything is excluded EXCEPT the movement itself. The warranty "does NOT cover the watch case, bracelet, strap, crystal, battery or crown, pushers or stem of the watch." So if the stem stops working to set the date or time in the next five years - not covered. And if you have to replace the battery in that five year period, you must contact the company to find an "Authorized Lucien Piccard Repair Center." Failure to let one of those people replace your battery will void your warranty. Nowhere do the watch case or printed instruction sheet provide you with the battery type. Why do I suppose that replacing the watch battery might be far more expensive than with almost any other watch?I recognize that this is probably the most negative review I've ever given a product. I'm not usually that way, even when I don't like a product. But this product is so poorly designed, with almost no documentation to tell you how to properly set it up, and with a very exclusionary warranty that will still cost you money to get it fixed (after you insure and pay to ship it), that I simply cannot give it any more than a solid 1-star review. And be aware that as you read the "Product Description" on Amazon, you're really only reading a generalized description of Lucien Piccard watches, and many of the features in the "Description" do not apply to this watch. And again, be CERTAIN to study the 4th product photo on Amazon carefully, so you can get an idea of how the metal closure mechanism works. It snaps shut on BOTH sides, once you've put it on your wrist, and then you slide the leather band back into the retention straps on the other side.Oh - unlike another reviewer, I did find that it keeps accurate time. After two weeks, it's spot on. But I still can't bring myself to upgrade it to two stars. If I'd had to pay for this watch (I'm an Amazon Vine reviewer), I would never have even considered it, knowing what I now know about it. And if it fails within five years, I would not even bother trying to get a warranty replacement or repair. It's that bad.

This is a very attractive watch.  Setting it was fairly easy (be sure to choose the correct set of instructions in the booklet that comes with it).  Compared with another watch I got recently, the instructions are FAR easier to understand (and they're accurate).  So far, it appears to keep virtually perfect time.The instructions for operating the closure are also quite easy to understand (and it's fairly intuitive even without the instructions, unlike the above-mentioned previous watch.  And if you have a decent jeweler's screwdriver set, you will not need to take it to a watch shop to have links removed or the clasp adjusted.  Those were very easy.  It takes a very tiny jeweler's screwdriver to unscrew the pins that hold the links together, but once they're out, it's easy to remove and rejoin the links to fit your wrist.  A paper clip will work just fine to push in the spring-tip pin in the clasp to adjust it.  Within minutes of arrival, I had three links removed and the clasp adjusted to fit my somewhat small wrist.  There aren't any instructions in the booklet for this, but it's quite obvious what needs to be done.  If one has ever pushed in a pin to remove a watch band, and then replace the band and the pin to hold it to the watch, that's all that's needed on the clasp adjustment.  And instead of spring-loaded pins on the links, it's a simple screw-out/screw-in pin.  Just make sure you use the proper size screwdriver in order not to strip the pin end, and also make sure it's properly tightened.Be aware this is a BIG watch.  Look at the specs on the product page and picture it on your wrist.  It will not fit nicely over the cuff of a long sleeve shirt.  But that's a style many like these days, so it's simply personal preference.  Just be aware that unless your long sleeve shirt cuffs are fairly large, the shirt is unlikely to fit over the watch and down past your wrist.  With some sort of sport shirt or short sleeve shirt, it would be fine, and look great!My one real complaint is visibility of the actual time.  It cannot be read in the dark.  And the black pointers on the minute and hour hands, with a fairly dark grey background, make it difficult to see the time in anything other than fairly decent lighting.  It appears that the crystal may be a bit tinted, but that may just be because the overall color scheme is silver/grey.  Regardless, in low light it will be somewhat difficult to tell time, and in the dark it will be impossible.This last remark is more of a personal preference.  This is a HEAVY watch, not just in appearance, but in actual weight.  I have a cheap Casio multi-function watch for general use that weights 1.8 oz.  This beast weighs in at over ½ pound (8.2 oz)!  It's going to take some getting used to, I think.  <grin>  But I do like the looks of it.  It's a very substantial looking watch - it just unfortunately carries the weight that goes with it (and perhaps even then some!).With those last two items in mind, if you otherwise like the watch, I can recommend it (unlike the one I gave a 1-star review to not long ago).

The set is attractive, and will clearly do the job.  It replaces a set with one less wrench in it, so having the extra size will be nice.  The main shafts on these are rather thin and narrow, compared to "old style" wrenches, but presumably will hold up just fine.  The carrying case is VERY handy.  Yes, it's "just" a piece of plastic, but it's well designed and allows all of the wrenches to fit in a compact area, with easy removal.  The end of the case even functions very nicely as a hand grip for the entire set.The only thing that keeps this from being a 5-star product for me is that the inner surfaces of the closed end wrenches are a bit more rounded than my old set (which had a bit more of a distinct angle on the high spots).  I'm concerned that with a somewhat worn nut or bolt that this may slip easier, but so far I haven't found anything to really test it out on.  It's made in China, and NOT what some of us older guys remember as Crescent quality - but then that's getting pretty universal for most products anymore.  "They just don't make 'em like used to," as the saying goes.Overall, this is a nice set, and for the price, quite worth the selling price.

Very pleased.  It's a foot longer than the original (supplied) Apple cable, and the right-angle keeps the cord from bending as much during data transfer or charging.  I consider it almost borderline for deserving to also have a charging brick, given the retail price, but not quite.  Still, it's longer than some cords, designed specifically for Apple products, and seems sturdy enough, so what's not to like?  If you've already got sufficient power options, it's fine for what it was designed to do (data transfer & charging).

Very, very comfortable, and incoming sound quality really is excellent.  Outside noise is also very nicely reduced despite the fact that these are on the ear, rather than over the ear.Several callers reported that sound was lower volume than with just my regular cell phone microphone, but that the volume was acceptable (therefore not as easy to understand.  However, I learned that I could loop the cord over one speaker and the microphone will hang almost right next to the mouth, and sound quality is better.  However, I have had my wife call me with it plugged into her phone,  and personally listened to the difference between this unit's microphone and her cell phone (identical model to mine), and the difference is very, very significant (FAR better when using the phone microphone directly, compared to this unit).  It just would have been better to put the microphone up higher in the line in the first place (it is the lower black element on the cord in the photo).Also, the plug is a 1/8" plug, so it will not fit many cordless home phones (such as our Panasonic system).  A far less expensive (and far lower quality) headset we purchased for my wife to use with one of our home phones also came with an adapter so either a 1/8" plug OR a sub-mini (2.5mm) plug could be used.  At the cost of this unit, a $2.00 adapter should be included!Would I spend the kind of money this set is currently selling for on Amazon?  No.  The only exception might be if I was a frequent flyer, for example, or often listened to music with a headset, and well over $200 was not an issue.  Then I might consider it because of the incoming audio sound quality and the comfort.  Given the incredible reported frequency response, for example, this is truly an amazing piece of equipment.  Few people will fully appreciate just how good it is, because few ever expect (or even know to want) the kind of performance this is advertised to provide - and apparently does.  Music is wonderful with these!  But the more I've used the microphone with my cell phone, the more complaints I get.So, put the microphone higher (to give better output volume to the other person on a phone call), add an adapter to fit the other common size of plugs for devices this might be frequently used with, and this would be a 5-star product without question.  I shouldn't have to figure out how to loop the cord over one ear piece just to give the person at the other end of a call adequate volume to listen to.

These are great (says the baker/cook in our family)!  Not only are they at least as good as any other parchment paper she's used, but they also lay flat - a nice change from parchment paper cut from a roll.  Yes, you're limited to the size (or smaller) of these sheets, but these work for most uses, and can be cut down further if needed.  What's not to like?!Yes, keep a roll of parchment paper around if you expect to need it occasionally.  But otherwise, these are handy, and lay flat, so well worth also having.  Very high quality.

I was first introduced to these through my employment in a medical facility, where they were issued to employees. I chose to purchase a supply of them for use as needed at home, and particularly for our emergency kit. They are extraordinary, and - if used correctly - provide considerable safety. I highly recommend these over the standard, thin devices available in home improvement stores, for example. These are well worth the little extra money, given the protection of health provided.Though not advertised as such, these are also excellent against highly bothersome odors. I noticed this when we went through mask-fitting at the hospital. Once we had the right size on, they used something that smelled very much like ether to test them, and I never smelled anything despite it being sprayed IMMEDIATELY in front of the mask itself. I also tested this at home with household bleach, since I was using some at full strength to take care of a problem. I gently squeezed a half-full jug of full strength bleach with the mask on my face and IMMEDIATELY over the opening of the jug. There was a muted odor, but it was not a strong smell, and not even much of an actual chlorine bleach smell at that. So while these are advertised to remove (or safely limit) harmful chemicals, they will at least reduce (possibly in some cases eliminate) highly irritating and/or unpleasant odors. Of course the known particulate-stopping capability is well worth it by itself.

Great!  Does its job as a replacement for a much more flimsy cord that came with my wife's laptop lap-fan.  Sturdy, and just slightly longer than 12 inches, unlike some other "1-foot" cords that others complained about on Amazon.  This is the real deal - fully satisfied.

I've been using these for many years in the dryer that came with my Trans-Ear device for single-sided deafness (the same audiologist invented both devices).  My Trans-Ear (a specialized type of hearing aid) has lasted many years between very rare occasions where maintenance or repair were needed.  I attribute that at least in part to the superior reduction in possible moisture-related problems with the drying device and these dessicant "Briks."  HIGHLY recommended for any type of hearing aids.I will note here that I am a patient of the inventor of this and the Trans-Ear by choice.  I started out as the patient of an audiologist locally, with terrible results (and nearly gave up on my Trans-Ear "hearing aid").  But I chose to drive a full day, several states away, stay overnight, and become a patient of the inventor (who owns Ear Technology, Inc.), and could not be more pleased.  So I've got that association solely by choice, but without any prompting on his part, let alone any compensation.  This review is given solely as the result of a purchase on Amazon, and without knowledge of anyone at Ear Technology.  I merely add this here as further evidence of my great satisfaction with both the hearing device, as well as the drying device.  These Dry-Briks are specifically designed for the dryer, and do their job well.  High kudos to Ear Technology Inc. in all ways.

The best I've ever tried - and I was very pleasantly surprised at just how much better they are!  Compared to anything I have found locally, the sound reducing qualities of this product were very evident.  I use them while using power equipment such as a chain saw, lawn mower, or grass edge trimmer.  If you put them in right, the difference is highly noticeable.  HIGHLY recommended!

I was first introduced to these through my employment in a medical facility, where they were issued to employees.  I chose to purchase a supply of them for use as needed at home, and particularly for our emergency kit.  They are extraordinary, and - if used correctly - provide considerable safety.  I highly recommend these over the standard, thin devices available in home improvement stores, for example.  These are well worth the little extra money, given the protection of health provided.Though not advertised as such, these are also excellent against highly bothersome odors.  I noticed this when we went through mask-fitting at the hospital.  Once we had the right size on, they used something that smelled very much like ether to test them, and I never smelled anything despite it being sprayed IMMEDIATELY in front of the mask itself.  I also tested this at home with household bleach, since I was using some at full strength to take care of a problem.  I gently squeezed a half-full jug of full strength bleach with the mask on my face and IMMEDIATELY over the opening of the jug.  There was a muted odor, but it was not a strong smell, and not even much of an actual chlorine bleach smell at that.  So while these are advertised to remove (or safely limit) harmful chemicals, they will at least reduce (possibly in some cases eliminate) highly irritating and/or unpleasant odors.  Of course the known particulate-stopping capability is well worth it by itself.

I certainly would not pay more than the lowest price currently showing on Amazon for this device.  It's functional, but not terribly convenient.  The audio isn't going to rival a Bose, but shouldn't be expected to.  Still, it's more "tinny" than I would expect from modern electronics.  I have a Bluetooth speaker that's around this same price and size, and the sound quality is amazing - this is "adequate" at best.  For emergency use, it's fine.Tuning is a royal pain, to be quite honest.  There is no possible way to move quickly from FM 88.x up to FM 107.x, for example (or AM 540 up to around AM 1600).  You have to push the channel "up" button once per channel frequency.  In other words, if you wanted to go from the bottom of the FM band (88.0 mHz) to 89.0, it would require ten button pushes just for that short span of frequencies.  There is a rapid-tune feature whereby if you press and hold the frequency up or down buttons the radio will then cycle up/down automatically through all the intervening frequencies until it finds the next broadcasting station.  But If you're in a larger city with many, many stations, the rapid-tune feature would be equally frustrating, because you'd have to re-start the "seek" feature every time it stopped on a new station, and hope the station you want isn't at the other end of the band (AM or FM).The crank charging is definitely JUST an emergency feature.  It is not something you'd want to do for very long (there's a fair amount of resistance as you crank), and you only get about 1 minute of talk time on your cell phone for every 4 minutes of cranking time if you need a charge on your cell phone, for example.  Or you get about 10-15 minutes of radio time for every 4 minutes of cranking time.  Fortunately, you can charge this product with the included USB cord, plugged into a wall adapter or the USB output on your computer (remember, that would drain the computer battery though, if not plugged into a wall socket).The LED flashlight is definitely not going to light up a tent, for example.  Would it get you around in the dark if needed?  Yes, but you'd have to go slowly and look very carefully.  It's not at all brightIncluded is a little carrying strap that is designed to loop through two holes on one corner of the radio.  I was never able to push the cord through to the other hole so it could be looped back on itself and actually used.  I ended up having to use a jeweler's screwdriver to loosen both case screws at that end of the radio, use a separate flat blade screw driver to pry and hold open the case, then slip the carrying strap through the larger gap between the two sides so it's threaded between the two holes intended for its use.  Then the screws were tightened back and the strap was looped over itself in order to be used.  Again, poor design - why not just install the strap before shipping it out?The little rubber cover on the bottom hiding the two USB ports and earphone jack is perpetually loose.  It does not hold itself in place very well at all.The radio does seem to have pretty decent reception on the weather and FM bands, but exceptionally poor on AM - you're only going to get very local stations there.Overall, adequate for an emergency kit or when the power is out.  It does have an alarm feature on the weather band for whenever the National Weather Service issues an alert of some sort, which would be nice in a situation where power is out and storms are in the area.  But for everyday use, this is NOT the item you'd want.  Tuning stations is, all by itself, a deal-killer if you thought of using this for general use.  There's no way to put in a specific frequency for one desired station - you simply have to push the button and wade through the entire band to find your desired station.I gave this a 3-star rating, meaning it is probably worth having, but it simply isn't worth what several places are charging for it, and would not be my first choice for such a device.  Perhaps a good three-word summary would be "adequate but underwhelming."

It might be helpful that - until recently - Epson was the ONLY printer we would recommend to anyone.  We've owned more Epsons than we can count, for over two decades, starting with our first dot matrix printer, and including an Epson 600, 777, R300, WF7520, 1400, and others.  We've used their inks in the past, and finally started using one specific company's inks many years ago because they had such high reviews from professional photographers.  Plus, their inks were FAR less expensive than Epson's, particularly when we did our own refilling.  So this review is coming from someone that would not every buy any other brand of printer - until now.We got a different model for our daughter a few months ago, and it died after a week.  Epson very quickly (just two days) sent her a replacement at no cost, and didn't required return of the old one (it was a less expensive model).  No problem.  Occasional problems happen.Then I purchased an Epson 3640 at Office Depot, and as always, declined the extended warranty, figuring I had 14 days to figure out if it worked and I could still bring it back without a shipping hassle.  We've saved so much in extended warranty fees over the years, that we'll just have to "eat" this one.From the start, the color quality was poor on this printer, but despite my long years of experience with many Epson printers, I simply could not figure out what the problem was.  It started with the Epson original cartridges.  I switched to our "old faithful" 3rd party ink company, first with their remanufactured Epson cartridges.  The problem continued.  They sent me, at their cost, replacement cartridges (they use the Epson WF3620 at their own tech services desk, with those very cartridges!).  It appeared to be a printer problem, but they didn't want to put me through the hassle of having Epson trying to blame 3rd party ink and not honoring the warranty.  They even (again at their expense) then sent me a full set of refillable cartridges, full of ink, since we're already used to using that ink in our other printers.  Same problem with ink not feeding first black, then later magenta.  The troubleshooting was far more extensive than Epson ever would have asked me to do - by their own admission once I finally had to call Epson.Epson customer service?  Absolutely no complaint.  They listened to my experience with Epson over the years, as well as the 3rd party ink, and the extensive troubleshooting that other company took me through first, and almost immediately agreed that it was a printer problem  They did, to protect themselves, put a $179.99 HOLD on my credit card until they got the first printer back, but that never converted to an actual charge, as promised, and disappeared within a day of the old printer arriving at Epson.  And I received the replacement three days after I called - with FedEx shipping of a 33 pound box at their expense, both ways.  What else could I ask for?!2nd printer: Dead On Arrival with a 0x69 error code straight out of the box.  2nd call to Epson: again, absolutely superb customer service.  I didn't even ask for it, and they sent the 3rd printer OVERNIGHT by FedEx - again, at their expense, with return of the 2nd printer at their expense of course.  That's almost unheard of customer service, anymore.  Too bad that same ethic doesn't apply on the manufacturing side of Epson.3rd printer: worked OK initially, including using our usual 3rd party ink once the original (absurdly over-priced) Epson cartridges ran out.  Then it started all over again - exactly what happened with the first printer.  This time it was cyan - the ink simply would not flow - at all.  I'm highly familiar with these refillable cartridges, but called the ink company to see if they had any other ideas.  I pulled 1cc of ink out the bottom just in case there was air there, and had no problem with ink coming through.  I then blotted the hole dry with tissue and reinstalled it.  No change, except that there was more ink in the hole when I pulled the cartridge back out, clearly showing that ink was coming FROM the cartridge - it just won't feed through the printer what Epson acknowledged was a hardware issue when that happened with the first printer).So: Epson lost their money for the printer they sold to Office Depot, because they paid for a 33 pound box to be shipped FedEx Ground three times, and one other time at overnight rates.  And I lost my money on the printer because I rolled the dice and lost by not buying the extended warranty from Office Depot.  Office Depot got my money, so they're the only winner.  And I'm not saying I will never, ever, again trust Epson.  They simply are not the same company they used to be.  When our 1400 and WF7520 finally wear out or die, they will be replaced by something other than Epson from then on.Roughly a quarter century of top notch experience with Epson printers is now history.  I don't know what changed, but don't care.  They're junk.  Just read the reviews, not just this one disgruntled customer's trashing of this printer model.  Remember, I've got decades of previous top notch experience with the company.

Both cartridges were apparently over-filled (I thought), and would not feed the tape to print it.  The machine could not pull the tape out of the cartridge for some reason.  Eventually, after tugging gently on the tape, I figured there was nothing to lose, so I grabbed and pulled very hard.  Finally, the tape barely began to be pulled from the inside, and after I'd wasted a foot of tape (a full 10% of the entire roll), it was loose enough that the machine could feed it properly.  After that, printing was fine.When I inspected the cartridges more closely, I saw that the inside of the cartridge is fairly visible from one side, and there is clearly a huge amount of empty space on the inside of the tape area, so it's not a matter of being over-filled.  These are only 10 foot tapes, whereas I  currently have a 23 foot black-on-white cartridge that has exactly the same amount of space inside the cartridge for tape.  With the much longer tape, it simply winds further inside the empty space, leaving less space in the middle of the circular area containing the remaining tape.  For whatever reason, these two cartridges have the tape very tightly pushed up against the outside edge of the circular area containing the tape supply, and the inside end of the tape isn't loosely unwinding itself into the middle to give the tape some slack (like it does with the 23 foot long cartridge).Bottom line: if you have the same problem of the machine trying to print but nothing comes out, grab the colored portion (not the black character tape underneath it in the cartridge) and pull it as hard as you have to, to get it started.  Once you've pulled it far enough to be able to feel that it's feeding fairly easily, try re-installing the cartridge and it will probably work fine.  It's just sad to have to waste 10% of the entire supply on both cartridges in this package.ADDED: As a Vine reviewer, I do not see the selling price, and hadn't gone to look at that before the review.  Before this edit, I had rated this a 3-star product because of the wasted tape due to the apparent internal defect in both cartridges.  I have now downgraded it to a 2-star rating after seeing the price.  I already own one of these Dymo label makers, and recently ordered a black-on-white cartridge that is 23 feet long (more than the combined total of these two cartridges).  As with prior cartridges, there were no problems with the tape feeding, unlike these two shorter (10' "Neon" cartridges).  Yet the price of the 23' tape is only 54% of these two 10' tapes (20' combined).  There's no way that more than twice as much tape should be half the price of a double-pack of the same tape just because they're using different colors in the plastic.  Yes, the two cartridges cost pennies more than one cartridge package, but they're selling in bulk, thus saving costs there on packaging.Worse, I just recently ordered (and received) a replacement 23' cartridge because the old one was getting close to empty.  After doing the initial review of this Vine product, I decided to see if it feeds OK.  It does not!  It too had to be pulled out of the cartridge, though not as far as the 10' cartridges, before it would feed automatically during printing.  It appears that Dymo has a manufacturing problem that goes well beyond these new little 10' "neon" cartridges.  The problem is now also in the old standard 23' cartridges as well - a fundamental manufacturing issue.

It is exactly what it's meant to be.  It's a great small portable soccer goal that is easy to set up and take down.  The carrying bag is a nice touch for easy transportation.  We would definitely recommend this if you're looking for a good practice soccer goal.  Any kid that's into soccer will be happy to have this for practice, or even just play time.

We are very pleased.  No "fish burps," unlike previous products we've tried, and lab results suggest this may be helping to bring down cholesterol (could be other factors as well, but my wife's doctor suggested she take at least 1000mg of Omega-3s, and her lab work shows improvement since then).  Personally, I'm having less lower back pain with a combination of this and organic black cherry juice concentrate.  Both seem to make a difference, based on what happens when I run out of either one (the juice or this product).

Instructions are very limited, and someone not familiar with replacing wiper blades would be quite frustrated.  But preliminary experience with the actual product is very positive.  I recently had to replace my blades during a long cross-country trip, and the truck stop where I purchased my replacements was out of the higher quality brand, so I had to get their "bargain" wiper blades.  They were just "OK" for the rest of the trip.  Since I was only able to get one 18" blade through the Vine program, I installed it and had to leave the other 24" "bargain" brand on the other side.  What a difference!!  While I have no way of knowing the longevity of the product at this point, Bosch products have typically been associated with high quality.  And the initial performance of this blade is excellent.  I really, really want to give it a 5-star rating, but because of the very poor installation instructions (not even as good as the "bargain" brand I got at the truck stop on my trip), I just can't do it.  Just be aware that if you're experienced at installing replacement wiper blades, or don't mind experimenting to figure out which insert to use, or don't mind measuring your wiper arm to determine if it's 7mm or 8mm, this is a top notch product.  Otherwise, be prepared to be frustrated until you get the thing to finally go on properly - then you'll love it.  I trust it to perform well long term, simply because of the Bosch reputation (and my experience with them over the years).  If it fails in just a few months, I'll downgrade this review.  But if the review stands in a year, it means the product performed well long term, not just initially.

Does it work, i.e. does it kill fire ants?  Apparently.  But does it really kill the queen, or just kill some ants and cause the colony to migrate?  I cannot tell, so far.  But what I do know is that I'm not going to be buying this product long term.  I stopped using Ortho products years ago when I kept noticing that I got better results with fire ants (different insecticide chemical back then) from another brand of the same chemical.  Why?  Because Ortho was using a lower concentration of the insecticide - meaning you had to keep buying more of the Ortho product to keep killing fire ants.  It turns out that this particular chemical (bifenthrin) is again at a lower concentration in the Ortho product than some other brands of fire ant treatment using bifenthrin.  This product is only .1% bifenthrin, whereas I've found some other brands that contain up to twice as much.  To me, that looks like the old reason I quit using Ortho products - less effective with the same price, requiring more purchases.Another concern I have is that Ortho does not disclose on the package which type of bifenthrin it is.  In my research (which I try to do before using any insecticide in recent years - we try to grow our veggies as organically as possible, for example, and also protect other welcome animals as much as possible), I learned that there are two types of bifenthrin - one of which is far more toxic to fire ants, but the other is far more toxic to mammals (including humans).  Ortho doesn't say which one they're using.Is bifenthrin highly toxic to humans?  Apparently not in comparison to some insecticides, including some I used to use but that have since been taken off the market years ago (before I bothered to do my own research prior to use).  But just because it's apparently less harmful to humans (and other mammals, and birds), doesn't mean it's completely safe.  And it turns out that it is also "effective" (i.e. lethal) with worms - which I DO want to promote around my yard.So my bottom line is that if I use a bifenthrin-based fire ant treatment in my yard, it won't be Ortho's.  Just my 2, and worth every penny of it <grin>.  Your mileage may vary - just do your homework.

Using the Presto 04820 PopLite Hot Air Popper, the unpopped kernels are almost non-existent.  This popcorn pops up beautifully, with virtually no waste.  Typically there are two or three, maybe four unpopped kernals that fly out into the bowel at the beginning of the popping process, but about the same number that are left in the popper when everything has stopped popping - in other words, virtually no waste.And while I don't like plain popcorn, this is ALMOST good enough to eat without anything on it.  But I'll stick to good old fashioned butter and salt.  Regardless, this popcorn is about the best we've ever tasted, and is the only brand we intend to purchase in the future.  What else could one want: it's organic, non-GMO, has great flavor, and there is almost zero waste!

I have no intention of going into "personal details," but don't mind saying that these absolutely work!  What could take far more time just "sitting," happens far more naturally and with much less time.  Anyone with hemorrhoid problems should LOVE this product, as there is far less straining needed - if any at all.  It's amazing how much difference this product makes.  And a recent guest at our home that used our bathroom came out and excitedly exclaimed, "Oh!  I see you got a Squatty Potty!  Those are great!"They really are.  It's amazing what a difference a simple change in posture makes.  We're very glad we got this version rather than the higher version, too.

One of us loves this, the other could easily do without it.  Personally, I just don't get all that much taste out of it, and I don't even want a seasoning that "takes over" the basic flavor of whatever it's used for.  We'll keep getting it, I suspect, because it's not all that bad - as I said, one of us loves it, and it's not horrible.

While I have preferred 100% cotton just for drying hands, I have to admit that these dry hands better than any cotton towel we own.  And the colors are subtle enough that they also blend well if hung in sight in the kitchen, as opposed to inside a cupboard under the sink, for example.  And even if one doesn't like the feel of the non-cotton fabric, the usefulness of these towels is great.  Not only are they great at the kitchen sink, you could also use them for cleaning glass stove cook tops, windshields of cars and trucks, etc.  They do an outstanding job of polishing after basic cleaning (such as glass stove tops and windshields) without streaking - even removing some streaks left after previous cleaners were used.

I'm taking less and less supplemental vitamins, and finding I don't need most of what I was taking thanks to better diet and exercise.  However, I still need some supplementation, and this seems to be the best balanced, without going to extremes in some vitamins (especially vitamin A), and uses the proper sources/types for them (particularly vitamin A and D³ as opposed to D² for example).  I find it reasonable for the price and appreciate the once-daily routine.  I have yet to find what I'd considered "the" 5-star multi.  This is as good as I've found for my own needs and preferences.

I've only ever found one better product from Australia or New Zealand, but it's no longer available anywhere.  This seals very well, does not thin out over time, and does not deteriorate like natural oils will (I've used a product that actually went rancid and smelled because it was made of natural oils).  Yet there's not a greasy feel to it - it will clean up easily with water.  Best product I've found.Note: it's used with a TransEar device for single-sided deafness that goes deeply into the ear canal and fits very snugly.  If it's not sealed well, feedback will be easily generated that others can hear - and be bothered by.  If you need to get good lubrication for inserting a hearing device, and then good sealing once it's in, I can no longer find a better product on the market.

The bottles appear to be of adequate quality, the droppers are more cheaply made and apparently cannot be separated from the rubber bulb/cap for sterilization/cleaning.  That's a huge problem because the company does not put them together at the time of manufacturing so as to minimize contamination of either the inside of the bottles (tops are completely open from the time of packaging through arrival to the end user, and the droppers are loose and completely separate from the bottles, allowing for individual contamination of each dropper).  Therefore, these should all be considered contaminated upon arrival because of the manufacturing process, requiring complete cleaning/sterilization before use, depending on the intended use by the end user.  For homeopathic remedies, for example, this is entirely unacceptable.  This is not just a shipping issue, they are created this way by the manufacturer

The router was VERY easy to set up.  There were no issues plugging it in to our old modem and using it immediately.  Total set up time was not more than 10-15 minutes, if even that much.  The speed appears much better than our old cable-supplied modem/router.  It has had an ipad, iphones, and blue-ray all running at the same time without any difficulty in any of them.  Where there were problems with the old router in one back corner of the house, it does slow down a bit, but it's still faster than the old router.  In fairness, there are multiple walls between the router and that corner of the house.  Overall, it is a significant improvement over the old router and definitely a "keeper."

I got this in an emergency when my previous lubricant ran out.  I found it to be far too watery to effectively help seal around a hearing aid.  And it never did anything for the mild itching I occasionally had.  What particularly bothers me is the fact that natural oils such as the ingredients in this product), don't last all that long.  Natural oils go rancid.  I ran out of my preferred brand and went hunting for this.  When I opened it, it smelled much like rancid olive oil that's been sitting out exposed to warm temperatures and lots of light for many years.If you try this and decide you like it, just remember to closely keep track of the expiration date!  If you don't, your nose will let you know soon enough.  And who knows what you'll really be putting in your ears by that time?

This is a preliminary review, subject to later updating.  Thus far the seed has not sprouted, but we were delayed in being able to plant it due to terribly wet weather and then inability to properly care for the seed as it began to sprout and grow. I do not want to give it an improper review either by being too early to report on results, or not be thorough.  As it progresses, this review WILL be updated.  Thus far, it appears to be well formulated, reports being almost weed free, and I see no reason why it should not germinate properly.  We're now in a position to properly tend to it each day in order to give it the best chance of success.

ORIGINAL REVIEW - SEE EDITED COMMENTS BELOW THESE:  The Epson XP-320 Printer is a great little printer.  It is small and compact so it doesn't take up too much space in my small office.
