I have been using the wi-fi print and it's perfect.  The colors are vibrant and the speed is quite fast for something so small.  The copier works great as well.  I tried the scanner and though it's a little slow, it did a great job.  It's certainly nothing to complain about.Set-up was very easy and quick.  I love that the paper is loaded from the back instead of the front so that it doesn't have to fold up inside the printer before coming out the front again.  It prints beautifully on card-stock and doesn't jam because of being able to go straight through the printer from the back.I would definitely recommend this printer.  Based on my experience for at least 20 years with nothing but Epson printers, I expect it will last a long time and do a great job.The ONLY thing I don't like about Epson (but I understand it's true of most if not all other companies) is that their "starter" cartridges are filled with just a tiny bit of ink.  Even their "regular" cartridges are, in my opinion, way over-priced (hence the lower price on the printers - you still end up paying in the end, just longer term as you buy expensive ink cartridges that are not filled as full as they could be.  Also be aware that virtually no printers actually tell you the cartridges are empty because they're empty - it's pre-programmed to estimate when it's getting close, and generally there's till ink in the cartridges - you just can't use it.  I'm not downgrading the printer for that, because that is not unique to Epson.  We don't allow our kids to say, "But everybody's doing it," yet companies basically are getting away with that logic.  Epson is no worse than others, and personally I would not have any other brand based on many printers over at least two decades (we generally have at least two printers at any given time, plus I've purchased for our church and gotten Epson).EDITED REVIEW: After working for a short while, it had a fatal error that Epson agreed could not be fixed.  Their customer service was outstanding, and the replacement printer arrived in a couple of days, literally.  The original printer didn't even have to be sent back (apparently not worth it to Epson).  The most I'm willing to give this printer now is a 3-star rating, because it didn't last but a matter of weeks with very little use.  To make matters worse, we're currently now on our THIRD (already dead) printer of a different model (a Workforce 3640) from Epson that we purchased for a different purpose (this one was for our daughter's use).After more than two decades of all-Epson printers, with high recommendations to friends and others over those years, I will not purchase or recommend Epson ever again.  Whatever happened internally, I do not know, but just look at their reviews.  For example the new Epson WF3640 has 20% 1-star reviews!  We've now received three of them, and they're all unusable.  I give up entirely on Epson, which is really hard to do after something approaching 10 Epsons over all these years in our family.  When our current (excellent) Epson 1400 and WF7520 finally need replacement, it will NOT be with Epson.  I can only hope this 2nd XP-320 doesn't die too.

We were really excited to try out this toaster, but quickly found out the limitations.  Don't expect to make a nice grilled cheese sandwich, for example.  In fact, don't expect to make a LOT of sandwiches that have two normal pieces of bread - one on each side with some sort of sandwich filling in between.  Problem?  Read the directions:"Take care when using ingredients that could melt and run out of the food item.  We do not recommend the use of high fat or similar fillings that may drip into the toaster as this will be difficult to clean."[and]"When cutting your paninis or ciabattas etc do not cut all the way through, instead leave the bottom side uncut so that it prevents melted cheese from dripping into the toaster."In other words, this toaster is definitely not suitable for a wide variety of different sandwiches and kinds of toast.  My wife likes to toast in a little toaster oven because she can spread butter and cheese across the top of the slice of bread, lay it flat in the toaster oven, and there is no dripping problem.  You can't do that with this very substantially priced toaster.Does it work?  Yes.  Is it worth spending this much money on?  Probably not for most people, unless they just happen to like to eat a lot of the narrow range of types of sandwiches suitable for this device.  (And frankly, I don't see the justification for the retail price - it's not like there is anything significantly sophisticated in it electronically.Other reviews are pointing out some good practical uses - and there appear to be many.  But the limitations along with the price are what we believe warrant a middle-of-the-road rating for it.

I simply cannot give it five stars due to cost vs. the very small amount that it filters out.  But compared to any of the other alternatives, it's less expensive and much better quality.  I tried not one, but two "Great Value" filters from Wallyworld locally - neither worked at all.  I went to Home Depot and looked to see what they had - $50 for a 6 month filter?  Not a chance.  When I compare what is filtered out by Black Berkey water filters that last 6000 gallons per pair, vs. the tiny amount this filters out for only 6 months, there's no comparison.  I wish Berkey made this type of filter, but alas....  Still, 6000 gallons is a huge amount of water (far more than 6 months), and the list of chemicals plus biological items that they filter out for that long is amazing.  They're about the same cost as three of these (just 18 months worth), and these filter a tiny number of chemicals to a relatively minor degree.  We're basically paying for better tasting water, with little additional safety, at a premium price.So why still four stars?  Because I can't find a better filter at a price that equals the price of this filter - they're all outrageously expensive, and lesser quality.  So, this is probably the best of the mediocre, at a lower price than I can find anywhere else.
We love these!  They last reasonably long, and the device on which they're installed makes cleaning much easier.  Great idea/product.

Great value for the money.  The negative reviews that talk about a shredded folded edge of the card stock simply folded it the wrong way.  It needs to be folded with the recessed side of the fold on the inside of the card.

The birds insisted on a 5-star rating!  What else can I say?  The only reason I rated it as a 4-star rating is the price.  Yes, I got it for evaluation for free through the Amazon Vine program, and would be very tempted to purchase it, except that I looked at the price.  In this 4.5 pound size, the price is outrageous per pound, even without shipping if you've got Amazon Prime.  Yes, the price comes down significantly for the 20 pound size, but then there's another $4.99 shipping (no Prime availability for the larger size).  Now for more specifics of the seed itself.I've been using a very satisfactory product from a large membership warehouse store, and the birds thoroughly appreciated it.  There was some waste, but they just tossed it aside when inadvertently grabbing the little pieces of twigs, etc., out of the feeder.  This product seems to have almost zero waste (other than the natural hulls, of course) - it's all seeds.  And within one day the birds decided they didn't mind something different and had used up more of it in one day than I've almost ever seen eaten on any previous day.  Recently we've noticed additional different (and less common) varieties of birds that we've never seen at our feeder before.  Today, they were back.  Clearly "everybody" still likes the new offering.  So, the birds' vote is 5-stars.Since they're eating more, and my income is fixed, I'll happily use this up but probably go back to the large bags at the warehouse store once this is gone.  It's just too expensive.Bottom line:  much better than average bird seed.  If you can justify the cost in your budget, go for it.  I won't downgrade it simply because of our own budget, since it is higher quality than what we've been using (which - fortunately - is quite satisfactory).

Fortunately it hasn't had to be used "hot," so this review is only having held the primary unit and used the practice canister.  I can see a problem if a larger hand used this, as some others have pointed out, but my wife's hand is relatively small and she merely uses a 3-finger group, not all four, and the stream clears her hand.  However, it's close.  But as my grandfather said, "A miss is as good as a mile."  There are no grips on the practice canister, but the grips on the black "real thing" naturally tend to bring the three largest fingers onto the housing, with the little finger curling under the bottom.The stream was forceful enough to easily reach out 10 feet and do its job without significant drop in the stream.  And it's probable that any "miss" could be corrected almost instantly before an attacker got to the user unless that attacker was sprinting and the user didn't notice it until the closing distance was too little to allow decent reaction.My wife attached it to her keyring and immediately said, "Oh, I could just carry my keys out to my car like this," as she gripped the Sabre case, ready for use.  The "safety" was easy to operate, and worked exactly the same on the real unit as on the practice canister.The only thing standing in the way of a 5-star rating is the very real possibility of gripping the case a bit too high and getting spray-back or blocking the spray altogether.  While unlikely, practicing in the back yard is not the same as a real emergency.  Also, we have no way of knowing just how effective the spray itself is (no, I wasn't willing to be the test subject LOL).  Overall, looks like a VERY good product.  Yes, I'm a Vine reviewer and therefore got the product to evaluate without cost.  But one of my criteria in reviews is whether I would pay the retail price to actually purchase this myself.  $10-15?  Absolutely, particularly when it comes to my wife's safety.  This is close to a 5-star product (something I ONLY give to what I consider to be in the "best of the best" category).

So far, it appears to be a reasonably good product.  I will come back at a later time and update it one way or the other, as needed, to report how it performs longer term.  I got the product for use on an outdoor plastic shed that gets mildew easily.  I cleaned the shed first using bleach, allowed it to dry, then applied the 303 product as instructed on the instructions.  However, be aware that the warning about too much of it can drip and run, and that it needs to be wiped and dried immediately, is entirely a non-issue.  There is a 2nd set of instructions that just continues from the first set, pertaining to either a spray or liquid application (can't tell which, but clearly they switched to liquid application, not the moist towelettes).  It says that excess product might be a problem with liquid, therefore it has to be wiped and dried immediately.  The moist towelettes in this container could hardly be accused of being too saturated.  If anything, I was a bit unimpressed with the limited amount of product actually in each towelette.  I actually ended up using four different towelettes for the first section I did  as a test (something less than two square feet).  At that rate, the product is not going to last long at all, making it a very UNeconomical product to use for something as relatively non-critical as an outdoor shed.  There are only 40 towelettes measuring 7"x8" in the container.  I expect that once I get done with the entire shed, I'll have used a minimum of half the container (probably nearly all of it).  I'm not convinced that I'd want to spend either the Amazon price or the listed retail price just to keep an outdoor shed mildew free for just a few months.  A little bleach will take care of the same problem a whole lot cheaper.IF this really keeps the mildew away for considerably longer, it might be worth it.  And I plan to update this review as needed, since I only did a section to start with (bleached twice as much as I intended to use this product on, to compare return of the mildew on the untreated but bleached portion, vs. the treated portion).  For now, it's just a so-so product, with instructions that were apparently applicable to two different forms of the product.  I was not encouraged when the product itself recommended re-use in just a few months.As for the cancer-causing chemicals some reviewers are all upset about, I'd just ask if they've ever read any OTHER labels for products sold in California.  You need a permit to blow your nose in California, and then have to call the HAZMAT team to come safely dispose of your tissue and supervise the proper washing of your hands and disinfection of your home.  And they'll send you a bill for their services.  (Only a slight exaggeration.)  Those warning labels may have some validity, but California is way overboard with them compared to any other state.  As with any chemical, use good sense.  I simply used disposable nitrile gloves for the job - protected me from the bleach as well as the "horrible cancer causing chemicals" in this product.  LOL.

We've had these right at 3 years, they've held up very well (only two sets rotated between washings), and to quote my wife, she'd only replace them if she "could get 1200 thread count silk, or something like that."  The price is high, but they're very well constructed (thus infrequent replacement), soft, and very, very comfortable.  They may or may not lower the temperature, but they're certainly at least as comfortable in terms of temperature in both winter and summer.  $219 is a real stretch for our budget, but they're lasting at least as well as other very good sheets we've had in the past, and sleeping comfort is outstanding.  That's worth a lot.

I'm surprised, but this is a really nice product.  I did not expect a 1-ply toilet paper to be either strong or soft.  While it's not quite as soft as one of the other Charmin products, that's purely a matter of preference.  I slightly prefer one of the other Charmin products, personally, but when I use this I'm fully satisfied.  I give few 5-star ratings, but this gets one because it's quite acceptable to me as a very close 2nd choice, and it is my wife's solid first choice.  She had no problem with the other product, but once she tried this one, she insisted we keep it in one of our two bathrooms - which she now uses almost exclusively because of this toilet paper.  Frankly, I never thought I'd be writing a glowing review of toilet paper, of all products, but this is really good.  We're finding we're using less of it than we use of the Charmin "Ultra Strong" (my preference, but only very slightly).  If we had to choose one over the other, I'd be satisfied with this one, but my wife would be insistent on this one.  And I have to agree - despite being ALMOST as soft as the "Ultra Strong," it doesn't shred any more than the "Ultra Strong" (and FAR less than their specialty "Soft" version - which I can't stand).

I love it!  We've been using Scotch pads for quite some time and been fully pleased with them.  But this has two advantages: (1) the knob handle makes it much easier to apply pressure and scrub big jobs, and (2) the plastic holder keeps the pad from dripping all over the back of the sink (or wherever else someone might keep this).  OXO took a good product idea and made it easier.  Just be sure not to throw away the plastic "dish" that this will sit in between uses.  Simple idea that makes jobs easier and less messy.UPDATE: Just purchased replacement pads for this a couple of weeks ago.  The original lasted about 60 days, which seems reasonable (and it got considerable use).  Longer term, we're still very pleased with this product and highly recommend it.

Raw, unsweetened, non-GMO, and organic.  That automatically puts this product above so many others, and almost qualifies it for a 5-star rating by itself.  But it would have gotten a strong 4-star rating except for one thing.  My wife is the cacao nibs fan, not me, yet both of use combined got to the 5-star level in our assessment of the product.  She thought it tasted better than a previous brand we got several months ago - and I thought at this level, this type of product would be "you've tasted one, you've tasted them all."  So, despite really not liking raw cacao nibs, I tried some just to see.  And no, I did not like them.  BUT, they seemed less "bitingly bitter" as I've always experienced this type of product to be, and there was very little unpleasant lingering after-taste I normally experience with it.  In fact, I did not have to go find something else to eat to mask the taste - I just let it dwindle and go away on its own, and wasn't particularly bothered by it.  Despite not personally liking it, that's a big plus for me.  So on top of my wife's assessment that it tasted somehow better than the last brand she tried (a good one), and my finding it quite a bit less distasteful, ironically that puts it up to a full 5-star rating for us - a relative rarity.

First, I am very reluctant to give any product or book a 5-star review.  I have worked in positions where the performance evaluation systems have gotten so inflated that it was almost impossible to tell the difference between the 80% of employees that got top-block ratings - at least by looking at their evaluations. Some of those systems were eventually replaced by methods where only a certain percentage could get top-block ratings, only another percentage could get the next level down, etc.  THEN it began to truly reward those that were among the very best employees.  I look at the Amazon review system as being quite similar.With that said, there was no question, before I even finished this book, that it would come out as a 5-star review.  It is simply among the very best of its kind.  But let me back up.As Vine reviewers, we have a period of time in which we MUST review a product, or be temporarily cut off from the program.  The amount of time is adequate for most types of products, including books, but it requires (for a fair review anyway) that the book actually BE read - fully.  I sometimes look at other reviews first, just to see if I'm "seeing" things accurately or not, but rarely look at reviews before even reading a book.  For some reason, I did so in this case, and was disappointed at what I was seeing in some of the lowest rated reviews.  I actually went into the book expecting something quite self-serving, even perhaps exhibitionist in a way.  I ended the book this evening with quite a different feeling, to say the least.  Is Tommy Rosen expressive?  Most definitely.  Does he push the limits of language at times?  Most certainly.  But if one is about to read a book about recovery from addiction, and is not prepared to hear language that is at times offensive to some, that person knows very little about the world of addiction and I would wonder why they're even reading it.  Harsh?  No, reality.Do I use some of the language the author occasionally throws in?  Not in the past 39 years - but that's just me, and my personal choice.  One of the tenets of recovery is often expressed as, "Live and let live."  This book isn't about his personal habits as some criticized, nor his language.  It is about his insight - and that is rare indeed.I am more than well acquainted with the 12 Steps.  I am more than aware of the relatively low rate of recovery associated with them.  Does that bother me?  Very much so - but not because of the program.  It's because of the intensely sad fact that most people do not truly understand what the 12-step programs are trying to teach, and most have probably never even seen the Big Book except across a room when someone sharing in a meeting happens to hold one up as s/he refers to it in some way.  The 12 Steps are one of the most inspired sets of teachings, or even life-instructions, in existence.  Dr. Bob and Bill W. understood things they tried to put into words, but like any other human being, were not entirely able to do so in a way that would resonate with everyone.  That's just the way we humans are.  But it doesn't change the power and depth of the 12 Steps.  Rosen clearly and fully recognizes that, however, and does a masterful job of explaining the 12 steps in a different way than the Big Book does, for example, and he will therefore reach some that weren't reached before.But he goes beyond the 12 Steps.  DO NOT read an implication there that he pushes them back into some 2nd-rate position while still paying lip service to them - not at all.  They are still the core.  And thus he came up with the title of the book: "Recovery 2.0."  It is built ON Recovery 1.0 (the 12 Steps), not a replacement FOR Recovery 1.0.  If you look at the code for any version of a major computer operating system, they all build on the original code for the first version of the system.  Take away all the original code, and it doesn't work.  But build in the enhancements, and it works together in a way that equates to 1+1=3, or 4, or 5.  That is what Rosen does when he adds in v2.0 of Recovery.  Don't like Yoga?  Tough.  Read all the way through it and understand WHY it worked for Rosen.  If you want to use something else like Tai Chi or Qi Gong?  Fine - as long as you get the same things out of it that Rosen describes as HIS benefits FROM yoga.  Yoga isn't the magic.  Just like the 12 Steps, you can "do" Yoga and still not get much out of it.Diet?  Don't like Rosen's 30-day cleanse?  Fine.  Just find something else that works as well.  He even says as much, as he talks about all the different diets out there.The point?  It's not about the 12 Steps, or Yoga, or diet.  It's about the mental transformation that comes with the combination of all of that - and more.  If you TRULY want recovery (not just abstinence), this is, in my opinion, one of THE very best approaches I've ever seen.  And I'll stack up both personal and professional experience behind that assessment, not just some amateur observations from the result of a chocolate addiction and/or taking a psychology class once that had an emphasis on addiction.  Rosen understand the 12 steps in a way few do, unfortunately, and he is intelligent enough to have learned from others how to move even further than is generally possible with the 12 Steps along (again, not in ANY way diminishing them - they are, after all, the core "code" in the program).This is a study-and-contemplate book, not a straight read-through book.  Don't like some of his examples?  No problem.  They're not the point anyway.  Ask yourself, "Was he learning about himself and his recovery FROM his examples, and how can that apply to ME, in MY situations, with my examples?"  I'm just glad I took the entire time, to the end of the last day, before I decided to write this review.  It allowed me to more fully appreciate what's in it.  Sincere thank you, Tommy Rosen.  Despite 39 years in recovery, I now see that the remaining years until that "exhale" are going to be even better.  (You have to really read the book - all the way - to "get" that.)

Electronically, this seems to be a very big improvement over our previous router.  Speed is noticeably faster.  BUT - the documentation that comes with it on paper is next to useless.  It omits some key, essential information.  I'm nowhere near a network expert, but fortunately knew there had to be some kind of security involved.  Yet nothing in the printed instructions even hints at security.  It appears that once you've completed the instructions, you're done.  And even the printed instructions were insufficient.  If you don't know whether you've got a static or dynamic IP address, the instructions just tell you to use the auto-detect function.  I just happened to use the auto-detect function.  The problem is, it "detected" a static IP address for my computer, then asked me to fill in the various fields on the next screen with the IP address, etc.  Ooops!  First, how would I know that?  I wasn't even connected to the internet yet, and set-up wasn't complete.  I happen to know how to use the Windows command prompt to determine IP address, etc., but how many computer users have no clue how to do that?  It would have driven them nuts!  I also happen to know I've got a dynamic IP address, so I went back and changed to "dynamic," and was able to proceed.  What would another user have done if they'd been trying to set up ONLY wireless connections with laptops, for example?  They could not have gotten on line to search the web site (virtually useless anyway).Fortunately, my desktop computer is wired to the router, so I was able to get on line quickly.  But then our laptops weren't able to connect.  Reason?  A different configuration (unspecified by the router screens) existed since our previous router (I used the same name and password).  I finally figured out it was a mismatch on security settings - but which one(s)?  Nowhere on the box, and actually not even anywhere that I could find on the company web site, did it show what settings to use (WPA2 and AES are the pre-set defaults for anyone stuck there).  And at the time I was trying to set it up, all I could find was email technical support with a promise of a response within 2 days.  That's totally unacceptable.  Only later did I find a tech support number, but I'd already sent the email and will just wait for an answer.  The web site and documentation are not at all user-friendly.I finally popped in the documentation disc that comes with it and found that they recommend the above settings for security (our previous router used TPIK - thus the mismatch).  And once I corrected the settings in the laptops, we were on - with excellent speed (apparently far better than our old router).  Signal strength in our house is about the same as our old router (pretty good), if not just a bit better.  Interestingly, my smart phone showed a considerably stronger 2.4GHz signal than the 5GHz signal, though the 5GHz signal was still good at the other end of the house through multiple walls.  (The laptops don't "see" the 5GHz signal.)The CD documentation is NOT user friendly for a novice.  I pity someone that has no clue how to set up a router.  It would be virtually impossible for such a person to ever get this thing working.  So, I give it a 5-star rating on operation, and a 1-star rating for the necessary documentation to set it up, averaging out to a 3-star rating.

We have used this for years as both a dish washing liquid, as well as our general hand washing soap.  We rigged a 1-gallon plastic bottle under the counter and ran plastic tubing up to the dispenser in the back of the sink, so we've always got an almost never-ending supply.  A little goes a long way, there's no fragrance to bother sensitive people, it's gentle on skin, and it really does clean well.  We've quit trying other brands because we're fully satisfied with this one, and buy it by the case (in order to keep the gallon jug full under the sink).  It washes hands well, and does an excellent job of cutting grease and loosening dried-on or cooked on food from pans, pots, plates, and so forth.  It's an all-around great product.

I liked the first movie the Hunger Games and liked similar type movies better so had mixed feeling about seeing the sequel.I loved Joss Whedon's Cabin in the Woods out at the same time. A group of young people in a remote cabin on a weekend are unaware that they are on a reality show and are slowly being killed off in creative and horrifying ways for ratings. The theme is a little similar, and it's a brilliant movie inspired by Sam Raimi's horror classic The Evil Dead.Hunger Games put me in mind of Oliver Stone's movie Natural Born Killers, a keen satire on consumerism and how death somehow becomes entertainment, and villains become icons, a great movie which coincidentally stars Woody Harrelson.Upon the good word of friends and good reviews I decided to go see Catching Fire, and loved it more than the original and I will definitely go see the next one.For one thing, the sequel moves from being a simple action movie, to developing the characters and giving them soul. Katniss is told she will never have to fight again, yet despite the ratings success of the Hunger Games throughout the districts natives are getting restless, and now surviving tributes admired by the public for their fighting skills are viewed by President Snow as a threat which does not bode well for our heroine.  The promoters have to find ways of getting higher ratings while keeping the restive natives from rebelling.As our tributes become heroes they also become icons the people can rally around, yet they are paraded to maintain the status quo. How does a dictator President Snow maintain control, when our heroes are perceived as threats.I loved how this sequel blossomed from a routine adventure movie into more three dimensional characters. I found this added to my entertainment experience.  For one thing there is a deeper relationship between Katniss and Peeta and other characters.We have the romantic triangle with Katniss' two potential suitors, Peeta with whom she agrees to maintain the pretense of love for the cameras, and the Liam Hemsworth character with whom she seems close but can it go the distance.  Can adventure and excitement, and life and death situations ignite the real thing?  Will feigned love blossom into the real thing with her renewed proximity to Peeta, and what new adventures are in store?I am very delighted with how the story developed, managing to surprise me with its twists and turns departing considerably from my modest expectations in engaging ways.I admired what J Law brings to the part of Katniss.  It's hard to imagine anyone doing a better job.As she is paraded in a chariot I  could as easily imagine her playing an iconic role like Cleopatra or Helen of Troy, she has that kind of presence.  She adds a noticeable dimension to this movie, elevating it beyond what it would otherwise be.But not all credit belongs to the actress. Simon Beaufoy creates an excellent screenplay, having previously won the Academy Award for Best Adapted screenplay for Slumdog Millionaire in 2009. Francis Lawrence has previously directed other excellent movies such as I am Legend and Water for Elephants. Both deserve kudos for what they have done here.I think most people will love it, and probably more than the first movie, because in my opinion at least it is considerably better, and I hope this was helpful.  I have high hopes that the third one will be even better.

Say what you will about Delivery Man one thing it has going for it is an original premise. That a man somehow in his careless youth provided 693 samples to a sperm bank which resulted in 533 children, of which 140 or so are engaged in a class action lawsuit to discover the identity of Starbuck their daddy. Meanwhile he has debts, and commitment issues with a girlfriend.I went to this movie expecting to see a regular movie, with punch lines and much laughter, the kind of comedy one often goes to see, full of laughs yet instantly forgettable. What I did not expect was a sentimental and somewhat touching movie. I doubt if the Vince Vaughn of 10 years ago could have pulled off this role in quite this way. Yet at times this movie transcends comedy and becomes touching without ever becoming maudlin.To tell you too much about it would be to render an injustice to the spontaneity of your experience. I found it a worthwhile, and enjoyable experience, and am glad I saw it, and I think most people will feel the same way, and it is an original premise, in a world where recycled premises are beaten to death through overuse, and if you're like me you long for something you have not seen before. Glad to see a comedy that breaks with convention.I think you will love it and I hope this was helpful.

1985. A sexually active, straight, carousing, drug abusing Texas rodeo cowboy collapses. At the hospital he is told he has HIV and has less than thirty days to live. Does he succumb to the diagnosis, or does something else happen entirely?Dallas Buyers Club is based on a true story about Ron Woodruff. I must admit I was unfamiliar with this movie. The ticket seller gave me an unconvincing outline, and I was about to walk away when a couple overhearing our conversation assured me it was a good movie.I am glad to say they were correct. This is the exact type of movie that wins Oscars, and gets many nominations.Matthew Mc Conaughey deserves to be nominated for playing someone battling a deadly disease who takes on big drugs and the FDA, to enable other sufferers like himself to have access to supplements and life saving drugs. He reputedly lost about 40 pounds for the role, and at times does look very gaunt, which gives an added layer of reality to his portrayal.This is a multi faceted movie full of interesting characters, which operates on multiple levels at once. The personal struggle, the parallel struggles and contrasts, and the battle against different facets of authority. Jennifer Garner in a supporting role plays a feisty yet compassionate doctor, while a colleague with more of an eye to profit becomes a doctor shill for big drugs, which are experimental, still unproven, and in the clinical trial stage, and may have toxic side effects, while our protagonist has to chase down a caring and competent doctor in Mexico who was disbarred, for less toxic alternatives.Why does one experimental method, with an unproven drug, take priority over drugs that are unapproved by the FDA? Aren't drugs undergoing clinical trials also unapproved? In both cases aren't people offering themselves as guinea pigs, and why shouldn't they be allowed to do that? After all, it is their lives.I loved this movie, and I found the story far more engaging than I thought I would beforehand. I was particularly intrigued and a little surprised by how hard hitting it was against the FDA, and the role it plays in connection with the big pharmaceutical companies, and how it restricts our access even to harmless supplements.I love it when a character is resourceful, so I loved the answers he gives an FDA official when he is stopped and questioned at the border.As often happens in a movie of this nature, there is more than one great performance. An unrecognizable Jared Leto gives a breathtaking performance as a gaunt transgender woman also undergoing treatment who Ron meets, and who sources customers for him. Ray like others has to deal with Ron's homophobia, and it's refreshing to see how it plays out as the character develops. What I love is the journey the character makes through being confronted with his own mortality, and how that affects a wider circle of people.If Leto does not get an Oscar nomination for his role then there is no justice in Hollywood. He would have to be a leading contender for Best Supporting Actor, as Matthew McConaughey would be for Best Actor.One thing that has impressed me in recent years is McConaughey's transition from lightweight romcom, and pretty boy roles, to more challenging roles. For instance, I consider Lincoln Lawyer to be one of his best roles as a wheeler dealer lawyer but not the type of role for which an actor is typically nominated. He battles the system but has no weakness.Actors win Oscars for playing two types of roles:One is the psychopath, such as Daniel Day Lewis for There Will Be Blood, Javier Bardem for No Country for Old Men, and Anthony Hopkins as Hannibal Lecter.The second is actors battling disabilities or diseases and/or social injustice. Recently Octavia Spenser won for playing a maid dealing with racial discrimination, Meryl Streep for playing a Prime Minister battling alzheimers, and Christian Bale for playing a former boxer battling drug addiction. Jennifer Lawrence won playing a character battling grief who acts out sexually. Bradley Cooper was nominated for playing someone with bipolar disorder in the same movie. Jeff Bridges won an alcoholic country singer. More recently the trend has been moving toward playing real life characters.As often happens the best movies of the year are released in December and timed for an Oscar run. I think most people will love it

I don't know if you're like me, but I have three desires. One, the protection of my data. Two, portability. Three, a smaller laptop type device with all the capabilities of a typical laptop.My previous computer crashed due to a defective hard drive, and I found myself taking the longest time before buying the Chromebook. I also wanted something better than a typical tablet. Make no mistake this is a tablet on steroids. It is not a pc, but it is close offering most of benefits of a pc, and in some respects offers considerable advatages.I bought it at a well known national retailer for about the same price as Amazon. What made me decide to buy this computer was the excellent advice given by someone from google who worked at the store.May I say that in terms of sophistication and ease of use it far exceeds a tablet device. I own a Nook, but I would not use it for buying an airline ticket, for example.The following made me decide to buy:100 gb of free storage for two years, offering considerable saving on online storage.Able after easy setup to walk out of the store with it working.The possibility of google cloud printing.The fact that you press a button and it's on, like a calculator.It updates automatically.It has in built antivirus protection, so you do not have to purchase software.You have the full benefit of the google technology, including drive.You have a wide range of apps available, particularly for document production, and its compatible with MS Office, and ODT.It also has pdf apps that are excellent, and you can easily convert a document into a pdf for easy printing..Other factors I liked after purchasing.It's light, compact, and easy to carry.It's very quick at connecting to new networks if you're roaming.It has great battery life about 6.5 hours, and this can vary depending on the nature of your usage.It even has an indicator which tells how much battery life is left.Google Drive offers you the opportunity to sign in and access your documents from anywhere.You can also create documents from anywhere, and even share documents online and allow other people to edit your document.Comparison to full pc laptop. For an extra $50 you can buy a laptop.On this computer you can do most but not all of what you can do on a regular computer. This is an absolutely excellent internet computing device. It's quick, and can process a lot of content, and you can have multiple windows open simultaneously without any noticeable slowdown. Unlike a regular PC it will never slow down.Automatic updates mean you never have to shut down it down like a regular pc to make updates.It does not have a cd player, so if cd burning is important, this is not for you. You can listen to your music collection on google cloud. I can easily listen to my amazon cloud music for example.It works with apps not with software. There are plenty of applications you can get at the google store many for free.I found that I cannot use Snagit on this computer to capture content. I use my pc for that.I love streaming movies on this machine. The pictures are crisp and vibrant, the sound excellent.I could watch a movie in bed without any of the awkward balancing you might have with a regular pc.Around the same time I bought this I also got a regular Dell PC. By comparison this is way faster to get going on. The Windows 8 apps on my new PC I found very annoying. They do not seem to work very well, and it's like running an obstacle course to get to a regular desktop setting.Although the google cloud printing was a major selling point, I went to another national retailer and bought an Epson 3520, which the salesperson assured me was cloud compatible. It's the most up to date. But when I attempted to integrate it with this machine it was not cloud compatible. So, if you do go for a cloud ready printer, research the makes and models before you go to the store, as salespeople do not always know.I like to Skype, so that was one of the considerations of getting the Chromebook which does not have skype. It does have calling and video calling capabilities called google talk, which I assume are comparable to skype.ExperienceI find that I love the Chromebook, and I tend to use it more than my two regular laptops, which I would be reluctant to take anywhere when I have this more compact, lightweight portable alternative. This is the number one seller in it's category on Amazon, and Samsung makes an excellent machine.As it's a Linux based operating system you will become acquainted with the Google Chrome browsing instead of window. The google drive you can access anywhere even from a different computer, and access your original bookmarks. I bookmark many sites, and I found the bookmarking somewhat preferable on the windows explorer browser.One of the ideas I love is the online storage, which means I could be in a different country yet still able to access 100 gb of content online, which offers considerable advantages over a tablet.I find this to be great hybrid between the tablet and laptop, and I highly recommend it.I think you will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

I must admit I awaited the publishing of this book with some anticipation, hoping that it might go into some detail on the whole 'Hand D' issue which some Shakespeare scholars consider to be Shakespeare's handwriting.  How they can make such an evaluation is open to question, as the only sample to which to compare this handwritten manuscript is six poorly formed and inconsistent signatures.Recently, a scholar named Bruster from the University of Texas accepted this doubtful attribution as fact, and studied spelling variants to claim that Shakespeare wrote the additions to Spanish Tragedy.  If one attempts to make a case based on spelling variants based on a dubious attribution one is on doubly shaky ground.  He des this in hope that two conjectures might equal a fact. However, he fails to acknowledge the evidence and the fact that  according to Henslowe's Diary Ben Jonson was paid for making the same additions shortly before the play was republished with those additions in 1602.I also hoped that it would show the handwriting and photograph excerpts in sufficiently detailed form so that one could make one's own evaluation.  Although the scholarship is quite engaging, the photograph excerpts are not sufficient for one to do one's own evaluation if one wishes, in my opinion.  Another thing is that the presentation is choppy with some many footnotes on single pages, that there may be only several lines of dialogue on a single page.  I found this quite disruptive to the continuity of reading, compared to say reading it on Kindle where one can look up individual words or meanings as one goes along.Sir Thomas More lay unpublished as a manuscript for about two hundred years, then receiving a publication as Shakespeare in book form.  The play was a collaboration between several authors, and several portions of it were subjected to censorship.  The play does have some points of interest particularly in dealing with this Catholic martyr who lived and died under King Henry VIII's reign.For instance as a study in pathos, it's absolutely excellent with fascinating dialogue for example between More and his executioner, who admires him, and so is reluctant, and an earlier scene which I am sure would hold an audience spellbound shows a group in the process of being executed when a pardon arrives for all.A critique of this play is that the cast is too large making it unwieldy for the economics of regular production.All in all, I do recommend this play, there are cheaper and what you may find to be better alternatives.  In my travels I found a rather interesting version online which I could read and enjoy without all the choppiness of showing the different hands, which probably would have been better shown in the appendix.I leave it to your tender discretion, and highly recommend the play, although I would recommend reading another version first, before investing in this particular version.  The Oxford Edition shows passages thought to be Shakespeare which runs to about two pages in that edition, and only about four pages if you reading in a regular format.I think most people will enjoy the play, and I hope this was helpful.

I have to admit that I am not always a fan of watching stage plays recorded on film, much preferring to see the movie like setting varying between real locations, although neither I think is a match for actually being there to watch a stage performance.In the 1960s  Marlowe's  Doctor Faustus was made into a movie starring Richard Burton as Faustus, and Elizabeth Taylor makes a brief appearance as Helen of Troy.While that movie had its good points, and its star power, I particularly loved the note of pathos in Mephistopheles voice, showing that this was a nuanced portrayal as opposed to a stock character.What becomes apparent as you begin to watch The Globe's production of that classic by Christopher Marlowe is that this though this is a staged play it captures every nuance I think of what Marlowe intended, and perhaps a few he did not, and I mean that in a good way because it's all good.  In fact, if you ever wanted to see Faustus, I would highly recommend you get this version over any other.I particularly liked the comedic scenes, where one of the lesser character was accidentally using the magic book to make incantations, and what happens.  Then there is the beautiful and elegant expression of Marlowe.  There is the atmosphere created by the actors, and the response of the crowd particularly gives the play added dimension over staged plays which are filmed without audience participation.One also understands that the play is being performed in the medium in which it was originally written, so it would not be that difficult to go backwards in time and imagine what it would be like to be in an Elizabethan or Restoration period audience, probably loud sweaty and uncivilized, a raucous crowd that react to scenes where Faustus performs magic on the Pope.When one thinks about this particular era, although one tends to think of the Shakespeare plays as emblems of excellence, there were many great writers in that era who did create great works but who have been largely overlooked, and none were greater than Marlowe whose lines echo within the Shakespeare canon."Mingled with coral and with orient pearl."  Tamburlaine"I'll have them fly to India for gold,Ransack the ocean for orient pearl "  Doctor Faustus"Of Persian silks, of gold, and orient pearl."  Jew of Malta"This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart."  Antony and Cleopatra"Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, " Midsummer Nights dream"The liquid drops of tears that you have shedShall come again, transform'd to orient pearl, "  Richard IIII highly recommend this, I think you will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

We're the Millers reunites Jason Sudeikis, former SNL regular, and Jennifer Aniston who both starred in Horrible Bosses.A low level pot dealer played by Sudeikis runs into inventory issues, and has to put together an unlikely family of misfits, which includes a down on her luck stripper (Aniston), a homeless girl (Emma Roberts), and a virgin to pose as a family of smugglers who can get across the border without attracting suspicion.  Good luck.Complications, and numerous adventures occur, and is the stripper hard hearted, or does she have a heart of gold?What impressed me most in watching this movie was Sudeikis' vast improvement and his presence and charisma in the movie.In previous movies he has been the also ran among greater stars, but here he occasionally displays a charisma reminiscent of George Clooney in his comedy roles, and I think this movie will prove to be a major breakthrough role for him, and put him on the map as a leading actor.Jennifer Aniston displays her usual comedy skills, and there are a couple of raunchy stripper scenes which display her physique very well.  Emma Roberts,  Julia Roberts niece, shows that that she is a creditable actress in her own right.  There are a number of awkward and highly inventive situations developed to great comedic effect, and to tell you more might ruin the spontaneity of your experience.Our two main stars will also be appearing in the Horrible Bosses sequel due out next year.I think most people will enjoy this movie, and I hope this was helpful.

Before buying this my familiarity with John Donne extended to his famous Sonnet X, Death Be Not Proud.In the Delphi edition, we have quite an extensive array of poetry, prose, meditations and three separate biographies contained within.  I own a number of Delphi editions and find them to be quite thorough, perhaps the most thorough offering you will get on a particular writer or poet.Sometimes, though an edition professes to be complete, I often find there is a missing piece, and when this is pointed out Delphi are quite good at doing updates.In this case, the Shakespeare epitaph poem from his 1633 collection, which is surprisingly similar to the William Basse poem in Shakespeare's First Folio is omitted.  Likewise Death's Duel, Donne's final sermon though referred to is not included.Contents include a very interesting piece based on Ovid's Flea, and Meditation XVII which influenced Hemingway's famous line 'For Whom The Bell Tolls.'  Donne's sonnets and poems range rather surprisingly from the profoundly spiritual to the bawdy, and the quality of poems and expression is surprisingly good.  Some of the Sonnets I find to be on a par with the Shakespeare Sonnets, and contain intriguing conceits and extremely well constructed conceits, with titles such as'Spit in my face you Jews, and pierce my side,' which is quite a bold and possibly controversial way to start a poem.  Another one starts: 'At the round earth's imagined corners blow.'  One of my favorites is 'Negative Love.'According to Ben Jonson who was not prone to giving compliments, he considered Donne first in the world for some things.For what is contained here and for the price this is quite an impressive collection.All in all, if you like poetry, I see no reason why you would not love this collection.  I think  you will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

I don't know where you are on the whole Shakespeare authorship question, but in 1955 after about 19 years of study Calvin Hoffman Hoffman published this book, which explores the idea that playwright Christopher Marlowe did not die in 1593 as reported but lived and continued to write plays under the pseudonym of Shakespeare.  Shakespeare first emerges as a writer within days of Marlowe's death with a poem called Venus and Adonis, a poem that refers to the poem Hero and Leander by Marlowe which would not appear for another five years.How could a new author's poem contain parallels  to an unpublished poem, and how could the yet to be published piece also contain links  and common references to this new poem.  Many scholars through the centuries have commented on the influence of Marlowe upon Shakespeare, and some Shakespeare scholars have even claimed that some Shakespeare plays were written by Marlowe.Edmond Malone, an early Shakespeare editor assigned Titus Andronicus to Marlowe, and he and others such as Tucker Brooke attributed the Henry VI plays to Marlowe.How important is this book?  Well it is the cornerstone upon which Marlovian theory is built.  He is not the first person to propose this theory and certainly not the last, but this book is probably the leading book which has converted people to the Marlovian camp, and you will find information in here that you will not find in orthodox Shakespeare books.He posts over 200 parallel quotes that run between Marlowe and Shakespeare plays.  Some of the themes Hoffman writes about have been developed since then.  What I found intriguing was his work on as You Like It, and his exploration of all the Anonymous plays that were issued during Shakespeare's lifetime.  Only 17 of the 36 plays which appeared in the 1623 First Folio were published during Shakespeare's lifetime, and eight of these were first published anonymously.One point of interest is that the name Shakespeare appears on several plays that have been discounted as being Shakespeare such as London Prodigal, and Yorkshire Tragedy.  Shakespeare's name was removed as author of Passionate Pilgrim  in 1612 after a complaint by Thomas Heywood to the printer about making so bold with his name.  The 1609 Sonnets were considered to be unauthorized, and there is a False Folio of 10 Shakespeare plays published in 1619 three years after Shakespeare's death where quartos are backdated, and the name Shakespeare added to previously unattributed plays.  The name Shakespeare has been discounted as the author of Sir John Old-Castle, and The First and Second Parts of the Contention.  In addition two versions of The Troublesome Raigne of King John 1611 by W. Sh, and 1622 by William Shakespeare have also been declared forgeries.  The heavily revised King John appears in the First Folio a year later.Shakespeare's name does not appear on any play until 1598, five years after Marlowe's death, which means that every quote in Shakespeare which parallels that in a Marlowe was first made by Marlowe.Certainly, if one is going to explore Marlovian theory then this is a must read book.  I would also recommend the documentary Much Ado About Something which led me to this book.I think most people will find the story of Marlowe quite engrossing, as he is a very interesting character.  Recently a movie was released by Jim Jarmusch called Only Lovers Left Alive, in which John Hurt plays a vampire named Christopher Marlowe.Approximately 80 people have been proposed as the author of Shakespeare, the leading candidate currently being Edward DeVere the Earl of Oxford.Did Marlowe fake his death?  He was arrested ten days before his death, and was likely to be charged with both heresy and atheism if he lived, and at least two people who were at the murder in Deptford were spies, and Marlowe had intelligence connections particularly to Thomas Walsingham and Lord Burghley, so it would appear that we do have the circumstances under which a person might fake their death, and the resources to do so, and being a writer then be free to continue to write under an assumed name.Hoffman's book is by means without flaws, the lack of an index being one, and the assertion that Marlowe had a homosexual relationship with Thomas Walsingham has no supporting evidence whatsoever, yet he claims they had such a relationship while Marlowe was still in University, again without any evidence.  Many authors of Marlowe though have treated Hoffman's speculations as fact.If the subject of Shakespeare authorship interests you, this is highly recommended.  If you are a true believer that Shakespeare was an author, you might want to give this one a miss.

The sheet  music book Selections from The Beatles Live at the BBC contains 25 songs presented in a standard Hal Leonard for Keyboard/vocal and guitar.  This means that it has three staffs, a melody staff with picture guitar chords and chord names, then a piano version showing treble clef incorporating chords and melody, and a bass clef.This book contains songs not performed by the Beatles anywhere else, and sheet music version of many of their popular songs.The book contains the following songs.I'll Be On My WayThank You GirlYou Reallly Got A Hold On MeTo Know Her Is To Love HerA TAste Of HoneyLong Tall SallyI Saw Her Standing There\Can't Buy Me Lovetill There Was YouA HArd Day's NightI Wann Be Your ManRoll Over BeethovenAll My LovingThings We Said TodayShe's A WomanI Feel FineI'm A LoserEverybody's Trying To Be My BabyRock and Roll MusicTicket To RideDizzy Miss LizzyKansas City Hey! Hey! Hey!MatchboxHoney Don'tLove Me DoI bought this on sale, and I have quite enjoyed getting to grips with its contents.  I think you will love it and I hope this was helpful.

I have many books on energy. Yet there is nothing quite like seeing the various energy techniques demonstrated, most of which are new to me.I know I would not be doing these exercises properly if I did not see it demonstrated on the DVD. The method used here is a combination of acupressure tapping, and kinesiology method of energy testing to spot energy weaknesses. She also demonstrates the Wayne Cook posture for balancing energy. I found the Heaven rushing in exercise particularly good.I was particularly interested to learn that there are pressure points for fight of flight response (also the freeze response), which I now use for staying clear.In this package is a guidebook with her biography, case studies and an explanation with diagrams of the body's energy systems and a deck of easy to follow flashcards.There is also a cut glass crystal, with a string for spinning the crystal,which can act like a pendulum. The crystal can be used for chakra cleansing, and I could certainly feel a shift in energy in the chakras as they reattuned to the higher vibration of the crystal.There is also a cd. This package is a great value.If you are like me, you may be wondering which I should buy first, the Energy Medicine book or this kit.This EM kit stands by itself, and the multi media format is more user friendly than a book could be. Also, it is easier to carry around the flash cards than a book, for reference. I highly recommend the energy medicine kit.If you wish to explore energy medicine more, I recommend:Quantum-Touch: The Power to Heal (Third Edition): The Power to Heal (Third Edition) by Richard Gordon.Life Energy: Using the Meridians to Unlock the Hidden Power of Your Emotions the Meridians to Unlock the Hidden Power of Your Emotions by John Diamond MD, one of the best books I have read on energy medicine, and a complete manual.The Touch of Healing: Energizing the Body, Mind, and Spirit With Jin Shin Jyutsu: Energizing the Body, Mind, and Spirit With Jin Shin Jyutsu by Alice Burmeister. It's Jin Shin Jitsu, a complete system, very easy to learn and use.The EFT Manual (EFT: Emotional Freedom Techniques)by Gary Craig is a simple tapping process useful for letting go of troubling emotions. Imagine easily letting go of issues such as anger, anxiety, fear, forgiveness, stress, procrastination, traumas. [...], and buy various books on Amazon.The Emotion Code by Bradley Nelson. Another complete system for releasing trapped emotions using magnets discovered by a chiropractor. A very well written book, which I discovered at a Donna Eden seminar. I have since attended one of his seminars.I think you will enjoy it, and I hope you found this helpful.

If you're like me you have probably dreamed of meeting the public person who most inspires your life many times. Maybe it will happen for you as it happens for some fans backstage on Part of Me.The next best thing would  be going to the concert and hoping that one day, maybe.. you could be one of the lucky few who make it all the way backstage and meet your inspiration, or would you meet them randomly somewhere? It happens.Here then is a rare opportunity to do something similar, experience Katy Perry in concert, get a backstage pass and a fly on the wall behind the scenes look at the California Dreams tour.I will be the first to admit that I am not Katy Perry's number one fan. I don't own any of her albums, but I do respect her accomplishments, her mighty alabaster orbs, her charisma and presence and the fact that she did manage to get five number ones singles off her Teenage Dreams album.In so doing she matched an accomplishment only ever achieved by Michael Jackson for Bad.Her number one Billboard singles were: Last Friday Night (TGIF), California Gurls (featuring Snoop Dogg), the anthemic Firework, E.T (featuring Kanye West) and Teenage Dream.As a writer I loved her use her use of alliteration on songs such as Hummingbird Heartbeat, and cherry chapstick on I Kissed a Girl.Part of me is combination biography, concert tour, real life drama. I loved watching the performances and I think she is a tremendous songwriter with one of the best voices in the business.The bio part shows that overnight success only came after years of hard work, struggle and rejection. It's an inspiring story about persisting against the odds.Although she was going through some tough personal stuff in her life during this tour particularly with the end of the marriage with Russell Brand I found this gave an emotional wallop to the movie. At one point before the concert in Rio she sobs uncontrollably in her dressing room. Her staff wonders if she can perform at all.Then she calls for her makeup artist. On her way to the stage she breaks down again her body racked with sobs. Then she gets on the elevator to the stage, she turns on her lollipops and we see a change in her facial expression as her game face comes on. It's a wonder to behold. What a trouper.Then the fans sing 'we love you Katy' in Portuguese almost as if they sense her struggle and lift her up. These were some of the greatest moments I will experience at any movie this year. The concert scenes I found to be visually spectacular down to the smallest detail with vibrant colors and a dizzying array of colorful costumes that dutifully and beautifully highlight her voluptuous figure.I commend her for letting us get so close and sharing something so deeply personal even though she was hurting at the time. In so doing she has fashioned a remarkable movie.I loved this movie and highly recommend it even if you are not a huge fan but just love great performance and I hope you found this helpful.

I went to see this movie because I wanted to see Whitney Houston's last performance.Sparkle tells the story of three sisters, raised in a nice home by a strict mother, played by Whitney Houston who used to be an alcoholic, but has found the Lord and wants to keep her daughter on the narrow path.As you watch this movie you will begin to notice this strategy has limited success.It's also framed as a cautionary tale about the bumpy road to fame.One daughter is a beautiful talented singer, another Sparkle is a talented songwriter who has always been in the sister's shade but prepared to sacrifice for the good of the group. The other one is simply brainy and attractive.The pitfalls of music and life are explored as the girls form a group and the singer gets into a relationship with a tv comedian and experiences a fall from grace. The movie explores themes of drugs and violence. Will she manage to retieve herself or will tragedy ensue? Rifts occur which threaten the family itself.I found the movie enjoyable. I loved Whitney Houston's singing solo. The quality of songs were pretty good with a mixture of gospel music and 60s motown type pieces.After I saw this movie I watched the original Sparkle with Philip Michael Thomas of Miami Vice, Irene Cara of Fame, and Lonette McKee.I highly recommend you check out the original. If you happen to be an Amazon Prime member as I write you can watch it for free. While the production values of the current movie are better, the original movie definitely has its moments. It features songs by Curtis Mayfield, a funk master, and I loved the singing performances of the girls with their delicate close harmonies. It also has an organised crime element. Events do differ between the two movies.The original is set in Harlem while the remake is set in Detroit. Judging by the reviews the original seems to have achieved a cult classic status with people claiming to have seen it a hundred times. I prefer the original but you may feel differently particularly if you are a Whitney Houston or Jordin Sparks fan. It really is a vehicle for her talent.I think most people will like it and trust this was helpful.

Martin McDonagh, among the best known Irish directors previously won an Oscar for the short movie Six shooter A Collection of 2005 Academy Award Nominated Short Films although he is perhaps best known for the acclaimed In Brugesalso starring Colin Farrell, a dark comedy with tragic overtones about two hitmen on the run.I first heard of this movie last year when I saw the movie The Guard directed by his brother Michael John. A trademark of the McDonaghs is dark humor mixed with some irony and perhaps even some philosophy together with some absurdity. As I loved The Guard so much and it has the biggest domestic box office of any Irish movie ever made, I looked forward to this latest movie with more than a little anticipation.If you're like me and like American directors who also write such as Tarantino with Reservoir Dogs and Kill Bill, or the Coen Brothers with No Country for Old Men, I think you will also like this.Seven Psychopaths centers around an Irish screenwriter nemed Martin played by Colin Farrell planning to write a movie about seven psychopaths. Life begins to imitate art as a similar tableau to the one he writes about starts to unfold in real life.Woody Harrelson plays Sam a local organised crime leader whose dog is kidnapped by Walken and Sam Rockwell's character who happen to be friends of Martin. Sam cares more about dogs than people. The real mixes with the imaginary in very intriguing ways, and kept the movie audience entertained. I particularly liked the scenes with the Vietnamese priest and the hooker, and the Quaker story. There is also a hit man with a white rabbit played by Tom Waits.The revelatory performance in this movie comes from Sam Rockwell when he helps out Martin with the screenplay lending some psychotic absurdity to the scenes although everyone is excellent.What I like is that McDonagh while clearly inspired by Tarantino and Coen imposes his unique style and does not kowtow to Hollywood conventions and delivers a movie that experiments with different styles of humor and yet manages to engross you so much in the moment that you do not attempt to guess the end. If you do you would probably guess wrong.I love how he works the opening scene with two hitmen discussing preparing for a hit and how the scene turns out.While I would not consider this better than say In Bruges there is a certain heaviness in the theme of In Bruges that is not present here and some people may prefer the more light hearted nature of this movie which is a highly welcome and worthy addition to the McDonagh repertoire.I hope the McDonagh brothers will work together as I think they could give the Coen brothers a run for their money.I think you will love it and I hope this was helpful.

Robert Miller appears to have it all, great wealth, great family, supportive wife, a pending sale of his business, and a charming if somewhat cloying French mistress.  But disaster can lurk behind the most distinguished facade waiting for its golden opportunity.Major money off the books, an impatient friend come debtor for his sake, an ardent suitor blowing hot and cold, a frustrated mistress, inquiring auditors, a loyal curious daughter played by Brit Marling, a doltish son, an entitled wife played by Susan Sarandon who may be working her own Arbitrage.Anything that can go wrong does go wrong.  The inciting event occurs early when his mistress dies in a Chappaquiddick style accident while he drives becoming the tragic glass through which the movie is imbibed.Miller faces a succession of moral dilemmas.  The choices being black and white he somehow selects the moral grey.  You may wonder what you would do in his situation.  If you're like me you suspect he might do the right thing under different circumstances.The person who rescues him from this situation becomes the lever police use to get at Miller.  Interestingly, the detective does not pursue people of wealth directly, but puts the poor weak link to the most difficult test  manipulating the system against him.Susan Sarandon looked spectacular in this movie I thought and performed excellently and effortleslly in her scenes.  I have preferred Brit Marling's performances in her Indie movies such as Another Earth and Sound of my Voice.The golden rule: he who has the gold makes the rules.Does Miller learn from his experiences?  Sometimes when a movie does not give you the type of closure you want, it's actually a good thing because it reminds us of how things really are.I think this is one of the best performances of Gere's career.  It achieved a modest $2 million on its opening weekend on a very limited release in 197 theaters yet managed an impressive $10,000 per theater.  Why it was opened in such a limited way is somewhat of a puzzle as it's quite a good movie.I think most people will love it and I hope this was helpful.

In Greek Mythology Prometheus presumed to steal fire from the gods for the progress of mankind. He was banished, punished and bound for daring to interfere with domain of the gods.Similarly the author of Frankentein called her book the modern Prometheus, where a scientist presumed to usurp the very process of creation itself, and created a monster using lightning.In Prometheus the movie scientist Elizabeth Shaw played by Noomi Rapace, and her partner makes a series of scientific discoveries which shows that we were put here by extraterrestrials, and embark on a funded mission to a distant planet to meet these aliens.While the scientists aims are pure other people on board have mixed agendas. We have a soulless humanoid played by Michael Fassbender, and a ruthless female leader played by Charlize Theron and the mysterious owner of the company.Director Ridley Scott directed the Aliens series starring Sigourney Weaver, and I think Prometheus will please fans of Aliens and win new fans. Like Aliens we have a heroic female protagonist played by Noomi Rapace from the Girl with the Dragon tattoo series. Their arrival on the planet sets in motion a series of events with implications beyond the mission.While it appears to be a dead planet there is mischief on board the craft and danger on the planet itself.The alien planet is menacing as you expect, (so rarely do we meet friendly aliens), and if there are alien life forms they may not be friendly.There are several surprises and some well crafted scenes, which were quite originally done, including the duffel bag, and an improvised medical procedure which I found highly intriguing.One of my favorite lines from the movie: 'We may have gotten off on the wrong foot.'I love movies with a strong female protagonist, and Noomi Rapace really excels at this type of role. If you have seen the Alien movies, I think you will appreciate that he has given a style of science fiction that he pioneered a fresh and interesting twist. Who can forget that famous scene with John Hurt in the original Alien?Will Prometheus spawn a sequel? You could argue that it already has. I cannot speak as yet to how it will be on Blu Ray except to say that it was a visually stunning experience in the theater.I think you will enjoy it, and I hope this was helpful.

Having seen and been impressed by Brit Marling's other work Another Earth, it was with some enthusiasm I ventured forth to see this movie. As much as Another Earth has the ability to put on the appearance of being a bigger than Indie movie, The Sound of My Voice is clearly in the Indie tradition, and perhaps the reality tradition, yet manages to convey a sense of the mystical as well.A documentary filmmaker Peter, and his girlfriend penetrate the mysterious, inner workings of a cult. The members shower, are blindfolded, and driven to a secret meeting place. He is a schoolteacher with dreams of being a director. The mysterious and charismatic cult leader Maggie played by Brit Marling, has returned from the future, to save a select group of people, her followers. She breathes through a tube in the nose, yet occasionally removes the tube and seems to breathe with no bother.How one can get a camera in without being seen, and film without being noticed is a rather interesting question.On the surface she seems genuine and legit, though, if you're like me you will wonder, if she is a deluded soul or something more sinister. She appears to have extraordinary empathic and intuitive powers, yet some of what she does raises questions. She punishes bad behavior, and rewards compliance. I found it rather engaging, as when one member is ejected for asking questions, yet she claims this is not the reason for his ejection.Yet other members clearly become more compliant when she reacts like this. These tactics appear to work on the Peter, when she makes a very strange request of him, and she alienates him from his girlfriend. Maggie remains a mysterious character even to the end, with some intriguing twists and I loved the end.If you are new to Brit Marling's movies, I recommend Another Earth more highly. It won two awards at the Sundance Film Festival.Like Another Earth this is quite thought provoking, there are a few parallels such as the search for meaning, and in this case the search for truth.Sometimes necessity is the mother of invention and Brit Marling who was struggling like other actresses to get roles decided to go a different route and write the screenplays for the characters she would play and work with the directors she knew.I really admire that type of entrepreneurial spirit and this type of accomplishment.Last week I saw her in the Richard Gere movie Arbitrage so her strategy appears to have paid off.I do hope she will continue to make these types of movies as it brings a wonderful diversity to our moviegoing experiences.I think you will enjoy it, and I hope this was helpful.

When it comes to the Shakespeare Sonnets I have searched north, south and east, and discovered that of all the directions one can go West is best.When I read Shakespeare Wars by Ron Rosenbaum he recommended Stephen Booth's analysis of the Shakespeare Sonnets, although I find the presentation lacks the aesthetic of an artistic work and at times gets pretty technical which seems somewhat diminishing of the author's intent.When I read the Sonnets (No Fear Shakespeare)I loved the simplicity of putting a personal interpretation side by side with the Sonnets.  I think that the sometimes vague yet sensitive and allusive language is open to many interpretations and really is part of the mystery of the sonnets, so that book would be better if it offered more possible interpretations and hopefully the reader would wonder what else a word or line might mean to exercise and excite their own understanding.  Because it's inexpensive I use it for making notes.You can even get the Soonets for free because they aqre in the public domain having been written prior to 1923, if you want by downloading on your Kindle or Kindle app.  You will get the text without commentary and I like to search to track down a specific reference or theme.I also looked at The Art of Shakespeare's Sonnets version.  It has all the aesthetics of an artful book even producing the original and modernised text yet I found it a little too logical and intellectual.I believe the best way to experience these poems is emotionally with some sensitivity and really to move beyond the ordinary world of consciousnessto the special world of the poet.I consider that West with his particular method offered me enlightenment and enhanced my understanding of several of the poems.  He publishes all the poems followed by one or two page essay/interpretation.  If I were to write a book on the Sonnets his book I think offers the best model for writing the ideal book at once both tought provoking and artistic.One of the mysteries of the sonnets is the apparent difference in experience between what is related in the Sonnets and the known facts of the life of Shakespeare.For we have themes of banishment, disgrace and scandal and anonymity, the dark lady and even the rival poet.  Scholars have attempted to explain this for many years. We know that Shakespeare was not touched by banishment digrace or scandal, and certainly not anonymous.  It has been explained as projection or role playing, although I believe they can be best understood and appreciated as deeply personal experiences.You would hardly choose to write poems about shame and banishment if they were not part of your personal experince, would you?I have also read Wraight's take on the The Story That the Sonnets Tell.  It's a book I would dearly love to own but is difficult to find and not inexpensive if you can.  It is possible though to read it online.  In terms of understading the author and the poems it yields the closest interpretation to the intent of the poet and offers another good model.Shakespeare was married yet the only real mention of a possible married relationship comes near the end of the book though the reference is to love and mistress not wife.Here are some lines on exile:How heavy do I journey on the way  Sonnet 50When what I seek, my weary travel's end,Doth teach that ease and that repose to say,'Thus far the miles are measured from thy friend.'Scandal, exile:When in disgrace with Fortune and men's eyes,I all alone beweep my outcast state,And trouble deaf Heav 'n with my bootless cries,And look upon myself and curse my fate,  Sonnet 29Disgrace, banishment:Let those who are in favour with their starsOf public honour and proud titles boast,Whilst I whom fortune of such triumph bars  Sonnet 25Anonymity, death:The earth can yield me but a common grave  Sonnet 81Coward conquest of a wretch's knife  Sonnet 74So, if you want to get it here on Amazon as I write the price is on the lofty side.I encourage you to price compare with Amazon subsidiary Abebooks.  I think you will be pleasantly surprised.  West is best.  I hope this was helpful and encourage you to read or get the Wraight version too.

As I am currently embarked on writing a book I went to see this movie not knowing much about it and found that it unexpectedly resonated with me.Briefly put it's a story within a story within a story. Bradley Cooper plays an aspiring writer married to Zoe Saldana. Life surely can't be that bad if you're married to Zoe Saldana. He sacrifices every other possibility to be a writer and finds that it challenges his manhood not to be living a life on purpose and in struggling to succeed.Everything changes when he discovers a tattered manuscript within the lining of his black leather attache case. Everyone who reads it acknowledges it as a masterpiece. It enables him to get his other works published and he gets all the acclaim he ever wanted.
