I appreciate the benefits of the Aloe Vera Gel, especially after being in the sun.  This gel is quite fluid rather than thick and gel-like.  I have used it on my face and arms to positive effect.  However, I was really turned off by what I consider an unpleasant odor that lingered on my hands and face.  The odor would deter me from using this except to provide relief to irritated or burned skin.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This serum has a higher than usual percentage of Vitamin C (25% vs. 20% or less with other brands), so it banks on Vitamin C contributing to healthier and brighter skin.  It contains other beneficial elements for healthier skin.  The serum seems to be helpful and beneficial; however, when applying moisture lotion minutes after this serum, it clumps on my face, and I have to wipe it off.  This has not been the case with other serums.  Therefore, I have only used this at night when I don't need to apply moisturizer.  The serum is orange color that makes me cautious about getting it on clothing. I don't know how well it would come out or stain.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This is a super book for teens and young adults, too.  The content is relevant, impactful and necessary; the approach is suited for teen readers who may not be thrilled about reading it.  The contents are well organized into 1-2 page topics dealing with general interpersonal skills, job-oriented skills, and life-enhancing skills.  The assortment of topics are presented in an appealing manner with illustrations and a variety of font.  The author provides education on skills that teens do not automatically learn or practice; in fact, some of them are counter intuitive for teens.  The book also inspires readers to begin thinking about their entrance into the workplace and developing marketable skills that will serve them throughout their career.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This Quest Bar continues to be my protein / meal bar of choice.  I have compared it to several others and it always comes out on top due to ingredients, health contributions and taste.  Its 190 calories, 20 g of protein, 1 g of sugar and 17 g of fiber are the best combination of any of the bars I have tried.  I love the taste and texture too.  I keep ordering these by the boxful.

The Hemp Protein bar emphasizes the heart benefits of hemp seeds that are known to contribute to a healthy heart.  Hemp seeds also provide an easily digestible, vegan source of protein.  The apple cinnamon taste is okay and the texture is soft and chewy.  If you are looking for a vegan, hemp protein bar, this might be an optimal choice.  Since I am not a vegan and don't mind eating a whey protein bar, this is not my optimal choice.  Its 230 calories and only decent taste combined with 10g of sugar to 1 g of fiber does not compare well to my current first choice of protein bar that has 20 g of protein to this bar's 10 g.Overall, I think this is a good choice for vegans desiring a hemp seed protein bar.

These disposable razors are decent for one to two uses.  Each time I have used one, I have nicked my face and drawn blood in a spot or two.  That had not happened to me for six months with my other razors (dollar shave club).  The handle on this razor is also slick when it becomes wet; for me the grooves were not where I hold the razor.  My wife used one for her legs and said it worked well -- for what its worth.Overall, I think these are on par with other disposable razors I have used which is why I rarely use disposable razors.

The Retinol Cream consists of a healthy mixture of elements designed to produce healthy and younger looking skin. I don't think the effects have been dramatic for me. It does seem to contribute to healthy skin that is perhaps rejuvenated.  My skin seems to be on the sensitive side, so I have not been using this in the morning because it contributes to sensitivity to the sun.  I noticed that my skin was a bit red during the day if I used it in the morning.  I have been using it only at night.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

In Forgotten Power, the Rev. Dr. William De Arteaga proves his study and experience of Christian revivals.  His book is well written and enlightening for readers interested in learning about how God has worked to bring revival among his people.  The book highlights Biblical revivals from the Old and New Testaments, historical revivals and contemporary revivals.I appreciated the research that went into drawing out from church history the contexts of the revivals from the Reformation to the charismatic renewal of recent times.  De Arteaga accesses firsthand accounts of the revivals from memoirs, letters, historical books and interviews when possible.  De Arteaga has visited more contemporary revivals to give his own eye witness account.A focus of the book is the role of Holy Communion in the revivals; however, the book covers a variety of revivals and looks objectively at the presence or lack of presence of Communion.  De Arteaga is not critically negative of those revivals that have neglected Communion for one reason or another; rather, he analyzes the positives and negatives of all of the revivals and their fruit.De Arteaga impressively examines the Weslyean revivals in depth while comparing and contrasting them with others.  He does delve into the theology and practices of the various revivals as well as the support and opposition that occurred.  He emphasizes the long term benefits or lack of them for the impact of the revivals.Overall, this is an incredibly helpful book for those praying and working for revival today.  Readers can see how this study prepared the author for his next book Quenching the Spirit.  In this current book, he identifies roadblocks to revivals that must be overcome to sustain the Spirit's work.  He also identifies antinomianism as a danger when church focus too much on the manifesting signs of the Spirit to the neglect of holiness.

I have been very happy with this soccer ball.  I purchased it to serve as a game ball for our competitive team and plan to purchase another one.  I reserve it for use in the games, so it is not getting abused.  It seems to be durable however.

These are well-fitting, wide view goggles that make excellent snorkeling goggles.  They are easy to adjust and are comfortable.  Most importantly, they keep the water out. The goggles have a wider mask than others I have used.I received it at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This is a good travel thermos for hot liquids.  It is secure and keeps the inside hot while not increasing the outside surface's temperature.  The cap screws on and off.  It also includes a tea strainer that fits into the inside top of the thermos.  It is a handy item.I received it at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

If you desire a water bottle that is collapsible for packing and traveling, this is a good option.  You can also freeze liquid in it for cold drinks on the go.  The bottle is squishy and takes some getting used to when using.  The flip open top makes it easy to drink from.I received it at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

A Secure Bottle for hot and cold liquids.  This actually holds around 18 oz and provides excellent insulation.  The shatterproof dual glass and plastic casing is great when kids are using outdoors.  Easy to open and close.I received it at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This product seems to have a beneficial effect to the facial skin around the eyes; it moisturizes, but I cannot discern an apparent reduction in puffiness or lines during the week I have been using it.  I trust it is working to some extent.  It has a flowery fragrance to it (very feminine) that is unappealing to me and irritable to my eyes.  This does not linger long; however, it is enough for me to avoid this product in favor of a fragrance free option.  This is also a small quantity; however, it seems priced on par with the other similar products in this arena.

True Tails II includes stories written from the "pens" of Max & Luther two dog friends whose owners are also best friends and share many activities together.  Max is a three- year old Puggle (half-Beagle, half Pug) and Luther is a two-year old Olde English Bulldog (and admittedly stubborn).  They write about some of their adventures and mis-adventures.  They have also included "Fun Facts" about dogs and other dog trivia for readers enjoyment and enlightenment.The writing is simple but not sloppy.  Max and Luther both have refined their language skills and the stories are quite good and light hearted.  It think readers between 8-12 would especially enjoy the book.  The book includes colorful illustrations and graphics as indicated by the books cover.  Dog lover's will recognize, I'm sure, some of their own dogs' antics in the stories of Max and Luther.I can tell that Max's owner Kari and Luther's owner Carey are very proud of their dogs and support their writing endeavors.  I appreciate receiving this book as a gift in exchange for an honest review.

We placed this light on my son's handlebars.  It is easy to attach and also to remove in order to charge.  The light is bright.  It has three levels of brightness.  The lower levels look red, but at its most power it shines bright and looks white.  It can easily be seen in the dark or dusk by oncoming vehicles.  It also has blinking options.  It can be tricky to turn it on to the steady light; it seems to want to go to the blinking options every time -- that is the only criticism I have.  My son likes having it on his bike.  It has anywhere from 90 mins to 4 hours of charge time depending on how it is used.  Cyclists will have to remember to charge it, so it does not go out during use.

Beyond Engagement takes readers beyond the superficial, apparent leadership techniques to the deep heart of employees and followers where the resources of energy and productivity lie often untapped.  Brady Wilson exposes reasons why so many attempts to motivate, incentivize or reward employees seems to fail.  Even programs with the best intentions may fall flat.  Wilson shows that leaders need to interact with their followers in order to lay hold of underlying needs and emotions.  Once these are discovered and addressed properly, energy is released and creative productivity happens.Although Wilson conveys the brain and heart science of what motivates and rewards people, this isn’t “brain surgery;” his lessons and assertions are simple yet profound in how they can change dynamics and help everyone involved.  To gain the benefits of the lessons of the book, leaders and managers will have to commit to interacting with their employees on personal levels rather than keeping an arm's length.In a well organized and easily accessible book, Wilson lays out the science behind new techniques to replace old, tired models.  He shows why old tricks have not worked and how to adjust.  Each principle has a case story to substantiate the lesson.  In the process, Wilson offers interesting reasons why the principle exists.  Readers discover enlightening facts about human behavior that are transferable to the workplace.Wilson's approach is simple but not necessarily easy.  He identifies the three main threats to any productivity and to all things good in general: narcissism, individualism and consumerism.  He offers the only antidote for all three as "sacrifice."  He suggests that apart from sacrifice there is no sustainable solution for the planet...or our workplace problems.  The key he points out is how to make the right, worthwhile sacrifices.The book won’t take long to read and offers readers sure rewards.I received this book at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

Drone Command follows Troy Pearce, CEO of Pearce Systems, and expert of all kinds of drones that are always at the ready to destroy the enemy or save the planet.  With him in his exploits, is former President Margaret Myers who still wields exceptional persuasion as a power broker.  This time the conflict boils between China and Japan with the USA on the verge of entering WWIII.In this book, Maden continues to prove his political astuteness and technical drone awareness.  The story is choppy and moves from place to place.  Each context is introduced by time and place stamps.  Trying to keep track of the people, places and ships or missiles became tiresome which is why there is a huge list of characters and acronyms at the beginning of the book.  I think Maden takes short cuts in really developing the characters and story in this book.  He does flashback every few chapters to Pearce's teen and college years to give some background to his life.As the book progresses, the suspense builds slightly, as the story reaches a climax and we wonder how the tension will resolve.  This is not a long novel.  Maden seems to have gone for a quick read rather than develop an epic story that lays all the groundwork and character development.  This is shallow but entertaining.

This fruit and nut bar tastes super.  I love the taste and have to exercise self-control not to eat half the box at once.  I love the combination of chocolate, nuts and fruit.  One reason for the sweet taste is the sugar content of the bar.  Although not as sugary or as unbeneficial as a traditional "candy" bar, this treat leans toward the "candy" side of the spectrum more than to the "protein" side of the spectrum when it comes to bars.  The emphasis in the title of "Fruit and Nut" may cause people to think this is a healthy choice for a snack.  Based on the content, I don't think that is the case.  The high sugar to protein/fiber ratio makes this a snack that is not too bad and tastes really good.  It is telling that the Amazon page does not list or show the image of the percentages of fiber, fat, sugar and protein.  It seems perhaps they are trying to market this is a healthier bar than it is.  I think based on all considerations I would probably choose the Kind Dark Chocolate Nut & Spices bar over this one.It is a small bar, so it is gone in a few bites - which is why I'm tempted to eat them all.

If you are interested in purchasing a heavy-duty home carpet / rug cleaner, I recommend this Bissell.  I have used the spot cleaners in the past that are helpful for pet accidents and stains; however, this is a good cleaner for entire carpets and rugs.  It offers two modes -- deep clean and express clean.This is about a quarter to half the size of a professional carpet cleaner and about the same size of one that you might rent to DIY.  It is heavy unlike your typical vacuum cleaner.  Bissell recommends going straight forward the length of the carpet and then straight back the length of the carpet.  After doing two rooms in our house, I was worn out with a bit of a back ache.If you have pets or kids and are repeatedly calling the carpet cleaner, I think this is a better solution and will save you money.  Bissell has an assortment of cleaners for the machine.  I suggest buying a few of the appropriate cleaners when you purchase this machine, because the two bottles that come with it will last only one or two full home cleanings.The cleaner is easy to set up and easy to use and maintain.

This is a super Fish Oil supplement of Wild caught Alaskan Pollock.  It provides all the benefits associated with fish oil and no side effects for me of burping or bloating.  The capsules are a small round shape, too, rather than the horse pill size capsules sometimes offered.  They go down easily.

This light is excellent for lighting up a space such as a closet or cabinet.  We keep it in the kitchen to search in some deep cabinets.  It is useful to have on hand when the electricity goes out.  You don't have to worry about batteries.  It indicates when it is fully charged, so you can always have it ready.  It would also light up a family sized tent, as needed.  The charge life is about 4-5 hours depending on the light strength.  It has four levels and then one flashing level.  It is bright on the highest one.The magnet on mine does not work too well.I received this product at a discount or no charge in exchange for an honest review.

The Emotionally Healthy Leader presents a culmination of Scazzero's experience developing "Emotionally Healthy Spirituality (EHS)." In this book, he designs it specifically for leaders.  EHS seems like a tremendous resource for Christians and especially leaders.  The substance of it is to focus on one's body, soul and spirit in order to bring them in line with Christ's image for us.  EHS sets our personal relationship with Jesus, our spouse and family ahead of anything we might "do" for Jesus.  Spiritual disciplines and intentional time management are key to EHS in general.The content of this book is all good.  I consider it all useful and necessary for leaders to lead according to Christ's model and purpose.  The problem with this book is that it cover four distinct topics that I think each require a separate book.  Instead, this book has too much information that is too poorly organized.  The main topics I perceived are personal devotion, personal inner healing, marriage / singleness, and church leadership.  Tackling all of these as intensely as Scazzero suggests would be exhausting for readers.  Each of these requires real work and focus.  Scazzero includes self-assessments for each chapter in the book, but I think it is trying to assess too many areas for readers.  Based on the readability and cogency of the book, I would rate it less, but it is all good content.

This is a well made and durable belt.  The width is thick and it is nice looking; however, for me, the belt buck area is too bulky.  For other body types (trimmer); it might not be a problem.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.
This is a good, thick and handsome belt.  It is very strong and sturdy and a very good belt at this price.I received this product at a discount or no cost in exchange for an honest review.

This is a beautiful watch -- both the band and the face are exquisitely designed.  As for functionality, it is simple in its telling of time, date and day of the week.  The traditional second hand also serves as a timer in conjunction with the smaller left side timer that keeps track of minutes up to 30.  The time zone indicators can be helpful to indicate the current time of major cities; although, the text is very small and difficult to read if not seen at a good angle.In the hand, the watch feels heavy, and I thought for sure it would weigh down my arm once on my wrist; however, I do not notice anymore weight than with light watches.  The face of this watch is thicker than watches I have previously work.  I am concerned about scrapping it or banging it on walls, doors, etc, because of its width.  After getting the watch band shortened for free at a local jeweler, it fits snugly and nicely on my wrist.  I considered adjusting the length myself, but after watching the jeweler doing it with the unique equipment and skill I believe that was the right decision.  It only took a few minutes to get it just right.I believe this is an appealing watch for its appearance and use.  Its sturdy quality and water resistance also makes it good for outdoor activities.  I have received many compliments on this watch.

The bow and arrow weapon shoots rubber pointed arrows with precision and power.  It shoots as strong as any nerf weapon I have used.  The rubber pointed arrows do not have the traditional nerf (soft & squishy or fuzzy) end; they have a rubbery ball shaped tip that causes them to bounce off of their target.  The bow shoots hard, so I told my son that this is an outside toy only and not to shoot it at someone.the device that holds the arrows is cumbersome and difficult to load fully without the arrows falling out. This is the flaw of this product; it surely could have been worked out better to hold the arrows more securely.  I do not see it continuing to remain useful on the bow for long.

This is a great learning and play table.  It is the fullest table I have seen yet.  It has a multitude of items to play with and various noises and songs.  My personal favorite is the steering wheel and gear stick, but I also appreciate how it has English and Spanish language.  There is some learning tools like numbers, shapes, colors and abc's.  Mostly, I think I child will have fun playing and just might learn something.  The volume has two levels.  The high level is fairly loud.

Ken Burger demonstrates his ability to write stories in this novel that consists of eloquent, descriptive language and colorful Southern characters.  Swallow Savannah digs up the bones of the South's dark history of oppression and corruption.  Burger does not hold back when it comes to depraved characters and tragic events.  In the sense of writing skill and dark characters and events, this book matches Southern novelist Pat Conroy who endorses this book on its cover.  Although not as long as Conroy's epic novels, Swallow Savannah shares some of the same elements that make the books enjoyable but also painful to read.Readers are confronted with downright evil characters who create mayhem and tragedies in their wake while treating South Caroline as their fiefdom.  In some ways, the book is an indictment on the corrupt, painful history of South Carolina, as if Burger is lashing out at the state.  However, he artfully sets the story in the context of beautiful, creative writing that carries readers along despite the horror.As readers move along in the story, it becomes more and more of a page turner leading to a climactic conclusion that finally reveals whether the bad guys will get the vengeance coming to them.

A Fabulous photographic portrait of Pope Francis.  The photographs in this book are simply spectacular.  The color, vividness, scenes and format bring to life the ministry of Pope Francis.  The text offers a brief glimpse of Francis' biography from a youngster to priest and eventually Pope.  Then the book details a year in the life of Pope Francis, as he leads the Roman Catholic Church through the Liturgical Seasons and Feast Days.I delved into this book immediately and could not take my eyes from it until I scanned every picture.  It is a tribute not only to Pope Francis but to the entire body of Christ and the Lord Jesus himself.  We see Pope Francis as a true servant to Christ and his character and devotion are revealed through the photographer's lens.I believe that any devoted Christian would appreciate this book and be blessed by it.  I think every Roman Catholic reader will cherish this book and the faith it represents.

Fall From Grace is an impressive novel about the mysterious inhabitants of the heavenly realms.  Ritchie has created what I consider a top-notch novel exploring lives of angelic beings.  The novel excels on the levels of entertainment, writing, story and plot and character development.  I am an Anglican priest and student of the Bible and what Christians call "spiritual warfare."  I have read a good bit of books on the topic of angels and demons -- not to mention studying Milton's Paradise Lost and Regained as an English Major in college.  I was thoroughly appreciative of Ritchie's treatment of the angelic realm in his book.  His character development is on par with Milton's angelic characters and C.S. Lewis' characters in The Screwtape Letters as well as more recent novels This Present Darkness and Piercing the Darkness by Frank Piretti.  Ritchie's character of Satan reveals the depraved glory of the prince of demons, and his character Michael shows the loyalty and heartbrokenness of the faithful servant of God.Ritchie's story is neither necessarily Biblical or unbiblical; it is congruent with Biblical revelations regarding angels while also limited in what the story covers.  It is not a Christian novel; however, I recommend it to Christians who I think will find it appealing and enlightening.  I am pleased that this is Volume I in a series, because it leaves much to explore in future books.  Mankind plays an indirect role in this story and remains on the outskirts of the drama, even though their creation is a significant issue among the angels' conflicts.  Ritchie's imaginative speculation of heaven and the angels' lives is splendid.  There are areas that I believe might be close to the reality I imagine among angels. Other areas that I write off as only fiction are creative and intriguing nevertheless.  I enjoyed reading this as story and reflected on the possibilities for reality as I understand such things based on a faithful appreciation of Scripture.I think the writing on the moral, spiritual, physical and relational deterioration of the fallen angels is where Ritchie really hits the mark.  He seems to capture very well the pride and destruction that flows from Satan to a major contingency of rebellious followers. Readers see the atrocious evil in the heart and mind of Satan and his followers that resembles the spectrum of evil we see in our world.  Ritchie seems to be answering the question of "How could such a glorious being with such high standing fall so disastrously low?"I will be interested to see how Ritchie follows up this story in future volumes.  He has proven his novelist skills completely in Fall From Grace, and I hope he can extend the story to a proper series.

Navy SEAL officers Jocko Willink and Leif Babin take readers into the battlefield of Iraq in Ramadi, Anbar Province, where fierce fighting occurred in 2006-2007.  The goal of the book goes beyond war writing to culling their experience in SEAL leadership for principles that be applied to the business arena.  The concept they promote is Extreme Ownership -- this is the leadership theme that runs through their book.The book offers excellent writing that essentially puts readers in the battlespace of Iraq, as the authors develop each leadership principle by showing it in action.  This is some of the best battlefield writing I have read.  They do about a good a job as I can imagine describing and verbally illustrating the scenes and scenarios they experienced.  They were officers leading Navy SEALS that included the unit of "American Sniper" Chris Kyle. If you saw the movie American Sniper, that is the context of their battles.After each episode of SEAL training or battle scenarios, they highlight the leadership principle and explain it.  Then they elaborate on it through a case study from their interactions with businesses.  It sounds like the authors have already had considerable experiences working with major companies as leadership consultants.  It also sounds like they have experienced success and effectiveness in the business field, as they did in the battlefield.  If I was a CEO looking for leadership help, I would turn to these men.Extreme Ownership is relevant and applicable to any reader seeking to develop leadership qualities in any field.  None of the principles are irrelevant to anyone in any situation, except the coach potato.  Navy SEALS must be some of the best leaders and soldiers in the world.  Their skills are battletested and proven.  The authors bring into the "normal" world and apply it to leadership.  I am extremely glad that this is a great book on leadership...I have to say I would be leery of writing a critical review of two retired Navy SEALS.The only caveat with this book to take into account is that the battlefield writing takes you there mentally.  It is difficult to stay focused on the leadership issue when you are reading about the horror of the nadir of the Iraq conflict with truly evil insurgents who did horrible things.  Then it can be difficult not to begin thinking about the whole big picture of Iraq, past and present.  It is a case when their is a danger that the anecdote or story used to make a point becomes bigger than and overshadows the point.  These authors along with all who fought with them and fight today are true heroes.

I have been wearing this bracelet for about a week.  I usually notice the effects of carpal tunnel pain during my weekly bike ride when I ride for about an hour and a half on a road bike.  That was my test for whether this bracelet helps.  My wrist usually hurts and is tight soon after I begin riding; however, after wearing this and no other changes, I noticed an obvious improvement in wrist pain while cycling.  This confirms the lack of soreness during the week, as I have tested it with stretching exercises.  I also played golf with no pain (I took it off while playing).  The bracelet is attractive, so I'm not worried about having to explain its appearance.  I've been wearing it the entire week except during golf.  It comes off and on easily after peeling it apart just enough to get on and then tightening it.I would not have ventured that this would help, but I received as a sample in exchange for a review.  I'm glad I did , because it has helped.

These cycling gloves are excellent.  The padding on the palm of the hand helps to absorb some shock and serves as a grip.  No matter where you hold the handlebar, these provide good grip.  The top is a thin fabric, so that my hands have not gotten hot while wearing these gloves.  I like the strings between the fingers that help to pull the gloves off without them getting inside / out.My hands are average size (men's) and the size Large fits very good.I received these as a sample to try in exchange for a review, and I am satisfied with them.  At a low cost, these are a great buy for cyclists.

This combination of supplements to help joints and bones offers good, quality substances in easy to swallow capsules.  I have been taking similar supplements on and off to relieve knee pain following ACL surgery.  I think they are helpful for knee health.  This product's daily dosage offers all three elements; however, other such products recommend higher dosages of each.  I am comfortable taking the recommended two capsules a day as a maintenance supplement for knee joints.  The quality if satisfying.

This is such an easy and inexpensive way to display your phone for using GPS or having better access.  Worked well with an iPhone 5s in a case.  It is secure in the vent and the phone is secure in the grip while also being easy to remove.  At this low price it seems like a great purchase.I received it at a discount or no cost in order to write an honest review.

I received a sample of CLA in order to provide an honest review.  After taking in as prescribed for a week, I cannot discern any noticeable effects.  My main incentive was to burn fat and decrease appetite or lose weight.  After taking two with each meal, I didn't notice any effect -- good or bad. As the comment explains, it may have positive effects on cholesterol that I would not notice without blood work.

This is an easy toy to assemble, so that a nine year old girl put it together, except for the screws and batteries.  The motion of the airplane is appealing to children -- be sure you insert the screws into the airplane; otherwise, it will "crash."  Besides the plane and flying it, the other items are more or less for show.  The truck is playful, and kids can drive it around and pretend to get gas.  The tower is quite flimsy and the table and chairs do not attach, so they will fall over easily.  As with all the children songs, the kids like it, but you probably won't mind when the batteries die.This would be a good toy for a toddler or nursery area.

I have to be honest with you, this V8 Juice tastes really healthy -- that is the good news and the bad news.  I like regular V8 juice, and I know I need the veggie blends in this version, so I thought I would try it.  But I just can't do it.  Suffering through the taste just isn't worth it for me.  I will try to eat more salads instead.  It tastes very similar to the juice drinks my wife has made with our juicer.  This is a bit saltier than her homemade juice drinks which I don't drink either.

These clippers are durable and robust industrial strength for fingernails and toenails.  Easy to use with wide grips and strong compression.  Honestly, I think these would work on Shrek.  The only thing they are missing is a hangnail file.  These should last forever.

Swim goggles can be a constant source of frustration for me if they leak at all, so I am leery of trying different designs and manufacturers.  I have mostly setting on using snorkeling goggles and a snorkel rather than these types of goggles.  I received a pair of these as a sample to review and am very impressed by them.  The adjustable and break-away strap is super -- very easy to size and then to remove and put on.  Best of all, these do not leak!!  No water in the eyes at all.  The fit is pretty comfortable besides a slight pinch around the nose.  For the price, these are a good buy.  With the easily adjustable strap, these would be good for kids, too.

This is a beautiful Jade pendant with a small diamond cluster in the setting.  The silver chain is pretty but very fragile.  I think this makes a nice gift for a woman who likes the color of jade.  I can't think of any flaws with this piece of jewelry or any reason why someone would be disappointed with it.

Fatal Trauma provides a decent, suspenseful story about a male ER doctor and a female ER nurse who find themselves the targets for a gang assassination because a gang member died of gunshot wounds at their ER.  Other twists involve a potential drug dealing operation at the hospital where they work.  Additional plot developments include romance and spiritual searching by the characters.  This is a subtly Christian novel.  The tone is not overbearing and the spiritual quality is realistic and nicely weaved into the story.  The suspense is adequate but by no means gripping.  Likewise, the writing is decent.  It is an easy and slightly engaging read.

So, ok, this is a pretty basic game. You take bean bags, stand at a distance, toss them vaguely in the direction of the boards, and if you're lucky, they end up in the hole. One point for each time it lands inside, and a half-point for when it lands on the light colored part of the board (this I decree, and it shall be so).As I said, a fairly basic game, but very fun to play. And these particular boards make it easy. They're quite sturdy, made of good, solid wood, with quick and easy assembly. The bags themselves appear to be very durable, and I suspect this whole set will last for decades.Further, it's very portable. The two boards pin together and have rope handles you can use to carry them around. I really liked that idea. It's heavy and awkward, but it works.I'm not sure these are worth the price, but they're still quite lovely, and I liked them a lot.

So this is a good vacuum for what it does. It's lightweight and has some good suction to it, though not great. And it's so lightweight that the thing follows the contours of your rug or carpet, whether you want it to or not. It's also fairly small and has a nice little "Dustbuster" feature to it, which could also be useful as a phaser for your first season TNG cosplay. Plus with its size, it'd be great for small apartments or RVs.That said, mine, at least, has a severe problem which means I won't use it ever again. When it arrived, the cord inside was frayed and the insulation largely gone. As I'd rather not risk a shock, I won't ever use this thing again. Which is a shame, because it's a nice tool that gets the job done.

First impressions:-Look and feel extremely clean-Stretch a LOT on first tuning, but once you get them where they should be, they stay intonated pretty well from the get-go.-well packaged; not too much extra stuff to deal with, clearly labeled in separate envelopesPROS:-sound great in all ranges; high range bright and crisp, low end is warm and full, without being muddy.-B string has excellent sustain compared to Ernie Ball Slinkys (my previous strings); coupled with the dense wood and neck-through construction of the Schecter Stiletto Studio 5 I'm testing on, the B rang long enough to create feedback.  If you have never heard feedback off of a note that low, it is a unique experience.-Play styles:  -pick: crisp tone; the strings are so responsive that if you are not careful, you will get more pick-noise than you  are used to.  -fingerstyle: these strings actually FEEL good, especially under my fretting fingers.  Clean sound, nice full overtones. The responsiveness of the strings is a plus here; the effort required to create the same sounds you are used to is minimal.  I'm not working as hard to play things like the bridge of "Bullet in Head," for instance.  -slap: I am not the most accomplished at this style, but these strings helped a lot.  The same responsiveness that serves so well with finger playing helps one economize finger and hand movements, making faster and more controlled playing much easier.CONS:-I am testing the light gauge set, and they have much less tension than other light gauge strings.  They deflect a LOT more than I am used to.  It's not too much of an issue on the lower octave of the neck, but above the 12th fret, if you aren't careful, you can end up bending notes you don't intend to.-obviously, the MSRPCONCLUSIONSI believe the lower tension might be the reason these strings are so responsive, so it is definitely worth the trouble.  I've been playing these strings for a little over a week, and I'm barely having trouble with the inadvertent note bending.  These strings are far and away the best I have ever used; I bought a new fretless bass a few days ago, but I can't seem to put down my Schecter, and it's entirely because of these strings.  Elixirs are well worth the asking price, and the discounts you get on Amazon make them the best option out there.  I have used DR Highbeams, Ernie Ball Slinkys (my previous favorite), Cleartones (would NOT recommend), and various other store brands and smaller companies that I cannot remember. If these strings hold their tone as long as they promise (3 to 5 times longer than competing brands), I am sold for life on this brand.

Here we have a lovely toy. Easy to fill, easy to use, with something like a point and pump interface. The bottom gun part is pretty great. The top part is a bit more awkward to use, and you can't really fire both at once. But otherwise, it's a dandy toy.

I wanted a shelf in my bedroom for quite a while. Thankfully this thing showed up in my Vine feed, so I got it. Am I pleased?I am. This puppy mounted up with about fifteen minutes of effort. It's sturdy and stable, holding my TV and Roku 2 quite easily. Neither are very heavy, mind you, but still.Overall, I couldn't be more pleased.

I had to deal with bedbugs once. It was because of a hotel I stayed at in Los Angeles many years ago. They came with me as a souvenir. It was a deeply unpleasant  They were nasty little critters. I was able to catch the infestation early, so I didn't have to deal with them too much, but it was still pretty bad.So I embrace with great glee these sorts of mattress covers. They basically form a mesh that the bedbugs can't live in. That's good.It's hard to tell, of course, what the long-term outcome of using this will be. I don't have bedbegs currently. Is that because of the cover, or because I just don't have them? Hard to stay. But better safe.

One of the movies I was most looking forward to this year was Avengers: Age of Ultron. It was a decent movie. A solid B. A better film than the first one, but less entertaining.The other big summer blockbuster I was looking forward to was Mad Max: Fury Road. It’s odd, because I have never seen the original movies (despite growing up in the 1980s), and it didn’t seem like one of those sorts of films that I’d be at all interested in. Then I saw the trailer. After seeing that, I thought, “This looks likely to be stupid as all get out, but entertaining as heck,” and I made plans to see it at some point.Then, on Friday, it was released, and the reviews began to come in. Four stars on Roger Ebert’s website (out of four). A great review on Slate. 98% on Rotten Tomatoes. That’s an insanely high-level rating. By contrast, Birdman, which won the Academy Award for Best Picture of 2014 has “only” a 93% rating. For a “genre” film to get that kind of high rating is almost without precedent.And so I went to see it yesterday (and yes, that was partly to annoy certain men’s rights jerks out there), and I was impressed. So very impressed. It’s entertaining as heck, yes, but also, surprisingly, very intelligent, has a good, strong plot, interesting characters, and strong messages about gender and religion.The story concerns Max who, at the beginning of the film, is captured by the bad guys (lead by a religious leader who controls all the local water supply), who plan to use him as a mobile blood bank. He’s glomed-onto by a “warboy”, one of the religiously-minded soldiers his captor keeps around, who attaches himself to Max’s blood supply. This get interesting when a woman named Furiosa (love it), steals a large semi that’s been outfitted as a battle platform. Inside? Several women who are basically the cult leader’s sex slaves. Their goal is to make it to an idyllic “green place”. The warboy goes in chase, dragging along Max (and everyone else, including a mobile heavy metal rock platform), and the movie kicks into high gear.I really cannot overstate how much I liked this movie. It’s easily the best movie this year, and one of the best new movies I’ve seen in quite sometime. Tom Hardy and Charlize Theron turn in the best performances of their careers (which in her case especially is really saying something), and Nicholas Hoult still manages to somehow bring the sexy, despite being covered with way too many scars and what is possibly the worst case of chapped lips in all of human history.The pacing is excellent, despite being basically nothing but a giant chase for most of the film. Also, unlike many films of this type, the action is very well-executed, excellently filmed and easy to follow. At no point does one experience a real sense of spatial disorientation, as can happen with even a lot of the best films (I’m looking at you, The Dark Knight. This, I suspect, is helped by the fact that the director, who made the original 1908s movies, used largely practical effects and vehicles. Yes, almost no CGI is used, and that really shows.If you’re looking for an enjoyable, escapist film that you can have a great time watching while eating popcorn, this is that movie. But, surprisingly, if you want an intelligent, interesting film that’s also great popcorn entertainment, well…this movie is that, too. An astounding feat.One last note; the 3D is well done, but not really required. If you see it in 2D, you’l be fine.

So I'm left-handed. This mouse is molded for, designed for, and has buttons positioned for, people who are right-handed.Now that's perfectly reasonable! That's about 89% of the population, and I don't blame the manufacturer for doing that. But it does make this mouse useless to me. The side buttons are just too awkwardly positioned for left hand use, and I don't particularly feel like using it with my right hand. I wouldn't really be able to very well anyhow.What little use I got out of this mouse was very frustrating. I'm sure it's quite fine if you're right-handed and use it as such. But for people like me, what a disappointment.

Well, if you're making lemon bars, lemon pie, or...well, anything other than lemonade, really, then you can't go wrong with this.This is a lovely liquid lemon essence. It smells fantastic, and it adds a lovely lemon flavor to anything it's put into (though for your own sake, use it sparingly!). Really, if you can't get your hands on fresh lemon, this is a wonderful substitute.

I do love a good pirate story. "Captain Blood" is one of my all-time favorite movies, and much as Johnny Depp has gotten rather annoying, the first "Pirates of the Caribbean" movies were quite good.This is a non-fiction story, and it's not exactly a pirate story. Rather it's about two men and their efforts at finding a sunken pirate ship. It was news to me that only one sunken pirate ship has been confirmed to have been found. These men, experienced divers who had planned to hunt down a lost treasure ship worth tens of millions of dollars, plan to be the second.It's an interesting story that's almost Crichton-esque in the way it focuses on the men and their technology, and I say that in a good way. The personalities of both men come through on the page in great detail, as does the work they're doing. Further, the pirate whose ship they are after (John Bannister, a pirate so obscure he doesn't have a Wikipedia page. Yet), seems like a fascinating individual.Do they find the ship? I won't spoil that for you. But I will say that in some ways, it doesn't really matter. The journey to the destination is where the real fun lies.

Here we have a lovely little set of cheese knives. Now let me point out that when I say "little", I'm not kidding. This is a very small set. All of these will easily fit in the palm of your hand. I'm not knocking them for that, but they are pretty small. That said, they work quite well, and if you have only a small amount of space in your kitchen, but you want a good set of knives (well, and a fork), that you can display and use, then this is a great set for that purpose!

The Dark Eyes series has suffered from one major problem: it isn’t what a lot of fans feel it should be.For those who remember, “To the Death”, the climax of the Eighth Doctor Adventures series, ended with a rather amazing set of tragedies, and the Doctor swearing to do something to change that. From there we went into the first Dark Eyes set, where the Doctor…changes his clothes and gets a haircut. There’s no real follow-up to what he said, and what he said felt very much like a lead-up to the events of the Time War, so we had all had quite a bit of anticipation. We knew we wouldn’t get the war itself, obviously, but just the lead-up to it would have been nice!But no. Instead we got the haircut, the new clothes, and a new companion. Dark Eyes 2 was more of the same, bringing us the new Master, as well as the return of Liv Chenka, a med-tech who had appeared in a Seventh Doctor audio. That story climaxed with the Master somehow kidnapping the Doctor’s companion and, with an additional companion of his own, setting out to do what he does.Now we’re on the third set, and the Dark Eyes concept, while solid, is getting a bit stale. This was by no means a bad set of stories, but it was certainly the weakest of the series so far.Of the four stories presented here, the first is easily the most entertaining while the third is probably the best. The first, “The Death of Hope”, features many elements of a western and is very much a “Doctor-lite” story. In it, the Master, his companion Sally, and their kidnap victim Molly, show up at a human colony that is trying to survive against the Eminence and their Infinite Warriors. The Master has a dark and sinister plan, of course, but implementing it requires that he saves the colony; that he becomes, in his special way, the hero.I quite liked that touch, and the framing narrative of the Doctor and Narvin watching all this unfold worked out quite well. It also did a good job of laying out the stakes for us so we’d have some understanding of the Eminence and what they’re up to, as well as laying the groundwork for the rest of the Master’s efforts.Sadly, the second story, “The Reviled”, didn’t quite churn along as interestingly. It wasn’t bad, and it was a bit dull. It also didn’t help that the alien species on the planet where the story took place had voices that were similar enough to that of the Eminence that I had occasional trouble telling who was who. Also, a note to Big Finish and everyone who works with actors, if you’re going to hire a “name” actor like Sacha Dhawan (previously seen playing Warris Hussien in “An Adventure in Space and Time”), don’t hide them under so much make up (or in this case, modulate their voice so much), that we can’t tell who they are. It reminds me of the Transformers franchise, where Hugo Weaving played Megatron, though not so you’d notice.But then we hit “Masterplan”, which was quite a bit better. In this one we have the Doctor and the Master trapped together in a locked room for quite a good part of the story, and that’s an excellent thing. Macqueen and McGann really work quite well together as a pairing, and I was very pleased with the result of their efforts; so much so that I was annoyed when we kept revisiting what was happening with Sally and Liv.The set rounds out with “Rule of the Eminence”, and this story was…ok. It wasn’t bad, but it was a bit of a “shrug” story, and it leads to the real problem with this box set and with the Eminence in general: they just aren’t that interesting of an adversary.Oh, sure, it’s nice to have a break from the Daleks (very nice), but there are so many other, far more interesting villains out there. The Eminence is a gaseous lifeform that basically causes people to turn into zombies that it can control. Eh. How is this fundamentally different from the Cybermen turning people into cyborgs under their control? Or the Daleks turning people into Daleks?There is nothing especially threatening about the Eminence. There also isn’t much terribly threatening or interesting about the Daleks and Cybermen, but at least with them we have something of a legacy, and we’ve seen them on the TV. The same cannot be said for the Eminence. We’ve seen (heard) them with the Fourth Doctor, the Sixth Doctor and now the Eighth, and they just aren’t working. Big Finish needs to either retire them or rework them, because as it is, my reaction to them tends to be, “Oh. Those guys.” Thank goodness it sounds like Dark Eyes 4 will feature the Sontarans.Now. Can I recommend this set? Well, first, you don’t have to listen to the previous two, but it does help quite a bit. It’s also good background to listen to the Fourth and Sixth audios that featured the Eminence. I will say that the first and third stories really do make for some great listening, and since you have to buy the set to have those two, I suppose that I can recommend it. But not with any real enthusiasm.I do understand that the plans are to retire the Dark Eyes line after the next set. I’m quite ok with that. And I very much hope that whatever comes after it is either a real follow-up to the events of “To the Death” or a return of the Eighth Doctor to the main range. I’m sure I’m not alone in wanting to find out what happened with Mary, for example (I didn’t really care for her stories, but I hate loose ends), and it would be nice to have more than just one or two appearances by Eight each year.In the meantime, I think it’s time to queue up some of the old Lucie Miller stories, and remember what once was.

So this is a very interesting idea! Sending the Doctor to Earth a year before the end of the Dalek occupation. This means that the Sixth Doctor has to be very careful how he acts, lest he create a problem for when the First Doctor arrives.So there’s that ethical problem, and it’s a bit bigger than it might otherwise be, because Peri is still very nervous and uncertain about the Doctor, having reunited with him after several years of being away. To her, it looks like he might just be being a coward.Add to that the challenge, for the writers, of making this a story that could well have taken place during the First Doctor’s run, and therefore having to include Robomen, who were a silly concept, but are used to great effect here.Really, this whole story had a lot working against it, and I’m pleased to report that Big Finish pulled it off and then some. This is one of their better Dalek stories, and probably the best story in the main range for this year.Everything about this story works and works well. The Doctor dealing with a Dalek threat, but not being able to deal with the real Dalek threat is handled nicely. There’s also some great scenes with Peri getting really familiar with dangerous botany.I also have to give my usual kudos to everyone involved in the acting department. Briggs does his usual excellent job with the Daleks, and Baker and Bryant are both their wonderful selves. I also want to praise Tracey Wiles, who takes a new character and really infuses her with some greatness.I’d say if I have to recommend one good, solid, 2014 main range story for a newcomer, this would be it. It’s not part of any great arcs, but it is still a great story.

I do rather like a nice candle, and this is certainly a very nice one. It burns with a lovely, clean flame, doesn't seem to emit much smoke, and has a great vanilla scent. To make things even better, it comes in a nice box with a ribbon. It might be a bit much, pricing wise, but it isn't bad, and if you want a good candle, it's a good choice.

This is a nice pair of tools. You get an impact driver and a drill, and they're pretty darn good. Each is lightweight and easy to use, with reversible motors, a small light, variable speeds and different torque settings.I tested these out with a pair of boards and some drill bits. After some fiddling around, I was able to drill no problem, using the thinnest bit and then the thickest. There were some mild issues at first, with the bit getting jammed in the wood, but we were able to resolve that fairly quickly once we discovered the torque settings.The lifetime batteries are a nice touch. I haven't charged these since I got them, and while I haven't used them very much, it is worth noting that they've held up well and haven't had to be recharged.Really, this is a good set at a good price. Just remember, you'll need to buy separate bits.

This book is preaching to the choir, as it were. I'm an atheist and I've already long-since reconciled any thoughts I have about religion and morality with my own personal set of ethics. I also don't have children to raise.This book is not for me. I got my post-atheist-coming-out morality from the likes of Hitchens.But if you're someone who is recently coming to being an atheist, or if you're someone who has children to raise and you want some good advice on how to raise them sans God, then this is a good place to start. There is quite a bit of good info, and more than a few harrowing stories (particularly about one woman atheist trying to raise her children in Mississippi). The book also shares some of the author's life experiences with things like how to behave when everyone around the table you're sitting at is praying (I just ignore it politely).So...not a bad book. Not one I need, but one I feel I can recommend.

This is a nice, thick, but not too thick, mattress cover. It isn't too hot, which is great, as some of them can be. It's got a nice padded feeling to it, and works well with my ten inch memory foam mattress and pillow. All around, a great product!

Oh, I do love the Lego X game series. They've all been quite excellent, but this one really sets the new gold standard. Everything you love about the previous games is here (characters, comedy, collecting), but everything about it is improved.Let's start with the plot. Brianiac pops up and plans to shrink the world, as he does. Meantime, the various different colored Lanterns pop up to do what they do. At the same time, Lex Luthor, the Joker, and others are scheming their way onto the Justice League Satellite of Love. Oh, and Hawkman is trapped in a gilded cage.Got all that?The controls for flying, especially, are vastly improved in this game game over Lego Batman 2. Like flying in the overworld areas is no longer a massive chore. Even better, you no longer have to look around for a changing station for Batman and Robin, as they can change into their alternate suits at a moment's notice. Further, you get to use the B button as a context button for various different tasks, including instantly changing into a different outfit.That last point I cannot stress enough. It is so darn useful! It's nice to be able to swap on the fly without having to get taken out of the story.Now I did see a reviewer who mentioned they had problems with their controller. I didn't have any problems with mine, except when I tried to do two-player with a friend and his controller wouldn't respond. A reboot of the game fixed that. For the record, I'm using a wired 360 controller.Beyond that, there are about 175 unlockable characters, including Shazam (Captain Marvel), all the various Lanterns, Batmite, and several special surprises that I wouldn't dream of spoiling here. The number and variety of characters really shows how aware this game is of its history. In addition, you get stuff from the 1966 Batman TV series, you hear the Superman theme when Superman flies, and, happily, the Wonder Woman theme when Wonder Woman flies.Really, I cannot think of a single problem with this game. I loved it completely, and I cannot recommend it highly enough.

So this here is a decent set of towels. They aren't terribly thick, but they are absorbent and they work well as your basic dishtowels. They're also a nice, lovely color (though I suspect they won't last long against stains), and a trip through the washer left them in perfectly fine shape. A nice product overall.

So you wanna have all the nutrition of an orange, without actually eating an orange? Well, here you go.This is a reasonably nice little manual-powered juicer. That means you'll be cranking it to get it to work. That could be useful if you want juice while out camping. It's also reasonably small, which could be handy if you're one of those Tiny House people who doesn't want something very big.It was easy to assemble and easy to use. Solids go in one end and liquids come out the other. As to more solids, but they get strained out and/or extruded. You wanna see something weird? Use an orange. You end up with what looks like the world's longest Cheeto.So there you go. If you want a small, hand-cranked juicer, this is the one for you! But...frankly, just eat an orange. They're tasty!

This is a very good little printer if you want something nice for your home office, or for the kids to run off their homework. It's not going to give you laser printer quality work, but it does turn out a product that looks nice and will more than get the job done.Setup was easy. It took about 20 minutes or so for me to get the printer up and working. I will say that the quick setup guide is a little vague on the plastic covers for the ink ports on the cartridges. Yes, you leave them on. I will also say that the keypad isn't very responsive (when you type in your wi-fi password, make sure each character displays as you type!), and the screen navigation could use a little work.But those minor complaints aside, I was up and printing within just a few minutes. An excellent product!

Your enjoyment of this product will vary depending on two things: how much do you like dark chocolate and how much do you like coconut? If you like both, and you like them together, you'll probably be happy.As for me, I'm not a huge fan of either, and the combination flavor didn't really work for me. These aren't bad, and if I had a choice between one of these or being hungry, I'd eat it, but it's never going to be a first choice. It was at least fairly filling, I'll give it that.

(special thanks to the distributor for providing me with a review sample!)This is an attractive glass pot. Nice pink butterfly lid handle. Simple, but lovely pattern on base, and handle.It also has a sturdy feel. I expected it to be a bit more on the fragile side, but it didn't seem that way at all.The interior strainer/holder is also solid and has wide enough slits to allow the tea to infuse well into the water.When "flowering tea" is placed inside, it performs as expected. It takes a few minutes to unfold, and sinks right side up as it should.  It takes a bit longer than usual tea to actually flavor the water (10 minutes at least for my preferred strength) but that's fine since it's supposed to be a visual thing as well. I suppose it has to take the time to unfold and all that.The teapot can also be used to put ANY tea in it.  Loose leaf or bag.  The built in strainer works well enough for that.So overall, a nice little teapot at an excellent price!

This is a lovely little set of lightweight, portable, very bright lights. They're powered by water. Yes, really. You tear off a little strip at the bottom and pour in a bit of water. Voila, light. Very bright, but not very big, so it illuminates only a small area, but it gives you enough light to read by or walk around safely in a dark area without stepping on the cat.Now these are only one-use lights. You're best advised to buy a few and put them into your car's glovebox, your survival kit, your hiking pack or the like. Expect them to last at least 24 hours, and as much as 72. But understand that once they're on, they're on. They don't turn off, and once they're done, you can't get them working again.So if you want some basic emergency lights, these are a great idea![update: It may be worth mentioning that I powered-up the light on the 9th, and it is currently the 13th. We're coming up on almost 96 hours, and it's still going][update: Now it is very early in the morning on the 15th, over 100 hours later, and it is STILL going!][update: NINE DAYS. Still going! I've added a few drops of water every few days. I don't know if that's making a difference, but there you are.][FINAL UPDATE: As of today, the 14th of November, the light has finally died and will not come back to life. Sic transit lumens...emercengio? Still, VERY impressed!]

So you want a compact solar panel you can take with you pretty much everywhere and use to charge your precious USB devices while hiking, fishing, or fleeing a psycho at the lovely Crystal Lake Campground? Well, lucky you! This device is all these things.I must say I was very impressed by how compact it is when folded up. It gets nice and flat. Best of all, if you have several of these, you can connect them together to make your own personal solar farm. Now it won't charge more than a few things at a time, but still.One disadvantage to some other solar chargers I've used...this one isn't really able to be just mounted on a backpack to charge your device while you're out hiking/fishing/fleeing. I suppose you could, but I wouldn't want to try it, as I imagine it wouldn't be terribly stable. Thus you're basically required to stop and open things up if you want to charge.But that very minor complaint aside this really is a great product!

(special thanks to the distributor for offering me a review product)So you want a basic, usable portable DVD player? Here you go! This device has a good screen, good speakers, and will play your DVDs. It's far from the best on the market, but it's very good for the price.It also comes with several extra features. In theory, for example, it can function as a small TV. It really can't, though, not unless you have a digital converter box. It can also function as a radio, more or less. You won't be able to tune in very much, but it does work.But if you're buying this for the video games, I'd suggest moving on. The games are basically a bunch of knock-off NES and arcade games in emulator form. There's a controller, but it doesn't seem very sturdy. While the games might appeal to little kids, I suspect they'd destroy the controller in short order.Still, if you want an inexpensive portable DVD player, I really do recommend this. It gets the job done at a reasonable price.

(special thanks to the distributor for a review set!)I don't often make cupcakes. In fact when I was asked to review these, I think it was the first time since the 1980s. But I hear cupcakes are a "thing" now, so when I was offered the chance to review these, I thought, sure, this could be fun! And it was. :)These cups are just about perfect. I didn't use any cooking spray, but they were non-stick, leaving behind only a slight residue that was easily removed. Also, I found that a quarter cup of batter fit just perfectly when I was making the cupcakes (strawberry flavored, btw). I will say that the one drawback here is that you will need more than one set. The mix I bought made 24 cupcakes, and there were only 12 cups here. But otherwise, they were just about perfect!

If you have a small cooking space, don't want to deal with grease splatters, cook only for one, and don't mind having very flat food, then this is the device for you.You've doubtless seen these advertised on TV, and like most TV gadgets, it does what it says it does, and does it well enough. It will indeed cook your food and catch all the grease in a little grease trap-like thing. The food  There is a little user manual that tells you exactly how long to cook certain things, and the temperature is always correct; no guesswork, no need to wait until there's blood on the patties, nothing like that.So that's all good. Where are the problems? Well, first off, your food will end up quite flat and flavorless. Physically flat, and flavorless because fat is flavor. No fat, no flavor. Throw on enough seasoning and you'll be ok. The larger problem, however, is that this is a very small device. It claims to be able to cook two burger patties at once, but...not really. Sliders, maybe, but the two quarter-pound frozen patties I tested it with were too big to fit on the grill at the same time.But those complaints aside, this does indeed do what it says it does and does it well enough. A good purchase.

These socks are, yes, rather pricey, but they're oh-so comfortable! From the moment you put them on, it feels like your lower legs and feet are in a smooth, snug glove. Plus they have a bit of a traction-like thing on the base of the foot. And the compression feature is rather nice, too. Also, they look pretty darn stylish!But beyond that, they're just...comfy! Definitely a great pair of socks.

This is a lovely little apron! It's comfortable, and it is just the right size for my short (5'6), fat self! I was thrown off for a moment by the neck loop arrangement, but I managed to get it to work after a minute or so. It is also worth noting that the fabric was EXTREMELY stiff when I got it. A simple wash took care of that, and now I have a great little apron!

This is a good, sharp, small knife. It's got a nice grip to it, and those little wavy patterns along the blade that make it less likely that what you are chopping up will stick to it. I will say that it is smaller than I prefer. I like a nice, eight-inch knife, but this one is good enough if you have limited space for storage of kitchen utensils. Plus it's a great price!
So you need a surge protector? Get this one! It's cheap, it's sturdy, and it works just fine. Plus, hey, free extension cord! Sure, it's basic white, but it gets the job done. What more do you need?

Ever since the War Doctor (or the Other Doctor, or the Predator, or the Renegade, or whatever we want to call him), was introduced last year, fans have been wondering just who he is. What was this man like, who seemed so similar to the Doctor we know and love, yet apparently was very, very different? Now we get a glimpse at what this man was all about.The story starts off on a distant planet, where a young woman, nicknamed Cinder, is fighting back against the Daleks. The rebellion isn't going well, and she's about to be killed by one of the Daleks, when the Doctor's TARDIS crash-lands and saves her. From that point, Cinder and the Doctor travel together, trying to unearth the secrets of a new Dalek weapon and save...well, therein lies the conflict. For the Doctor can save the Time Lords, but in doing so would be allowing them to commit a great crime. His moral dilemma forms the crux of the story.I very much enjoyed this tale. It helps that I'm very fond of the old series, so I recognized many of the references ("The Five Doctors" in particular is heavily referenced), but I suspect even new series fans who have never seen an episode of the old series will be able to keep up just fine. I also appreciated the connections between the new series and old. Having an appearance by a certain Lord President of dubious character was quite fun, especially as he's still wearing a glove I like to refer to as "The Hand of Omega", but probably isn't.As for drawbacks, well, there really weren't any, aside from the fact that I was left wanting more. This story is clearly supposed to be the War Doctor's last adventure before the events we saw in "The Day of the Doctor", and so I do hope someone at some point goes back and fills in more blanks. It would be lovely if Big Finish were able to do so, but failing that, more novels would be great.A good story all around and one that I highly recommend.

Well, here we have a lovely little shower caddy. It really does look quite neat! It has this nifty bubble design to it, and the rack itself is nice and sturdy. There's a hook to hang it from your shower nozzle and a pair of suction cups to hold it in place. There is also plenty of room to store your stuff.The one complaint I have about this product is that it is ONLY made to hang from your shower nozzle. I do wish there was another way to hang it up. I say this because I have one of those shower heads that's got a long hose-like mechanism so that I can take off the shower head and use it to spray things that need spraying. That hose kind of gets in the way of the rack.But if you just have a normal shower head, you'll be fine!

If you're looking for a small funhouse mirror to put up in your locker, or office cubicle, or any other small space where you might want a mirror, this is the one for you. It's got a nice, soft, padded frame that you can use for putting thumbtacks in (you even get a few tacks with the mirror), and the entire back is basically a giant magnet that holds it all securely.However if you want a mirror that accurately reflects what is in front of it, look elsewhere. The image here is very distorted. You'll get a basic impression of what's going on if you look into it, but if you want an accurate view, you probably want to duck into the bathroom.Still, it's acceptable for what it is.

Goodness, this is an intense little book. All the characters emotions run right at the surface, and that's a good thing, but at times, it can be really, really overwhelming. Like, "I had trouble falling asleep and shouldn't have read this in bed" kind of overwhelming. You really feel the fear in young Danny, and the terror his mother goes through, as well as the devastation to both the family and the community as a whole.The characters are all deeply interesting and that makes things even more intense. You genuinely don't want anyone to be the murderer, but you know someone must be. I'll say the final reveal wasn't exactly a surprise, but the reasons behind it, and what was really going on, were quite interesting.I've not watched the TV show, but this does make me want to. So high praise indeed, I suppose.

Obviously I cannot judge how these are going to work long-term until...well, a long time from now. Currently I'm using them to power my Stephen Fry alarm clock (yes, it's totally a thing), and they're working well so far. But, naturally, I can't evaluate their usage long-term. I'd try a more battery-intensive device, but frankly, it's either that or a remote control. Everything else I own is powered by a rechargeable battery, including one of my roughly seven remotes.But for now...it works.

So you want some basically plain, neutral placemats that you can use? Ones that will be easy to clean and look basically inoffensive? Well, here you go.Hard to come up with too much more to say about these than that. They seem fairly sturdy, they look decent, and importantly, they're easy to clean. I'm sure if you had kids, these would be fairly ideal.

This series has been really irritating to me on several levels. Everything from the the so-called "big switch", which promised to change everything but in fact changed nothing, right on down to the way this book, supposedly the last in the series, ended. And yet...the story has been interesting enough to keep my attention and if there winds up being another book in this series, I'll probably read it.As before this book follows several characters zipping around a slightly earlier version of World War II doing various things. There's a Czech sniper in Spain (did you know it gets hot in Spain during the summer? In case you forget, you'll be reminded several times), a Soviet bomber crew (did you know bombers get lighter as they drop their bombs? In case you forget, you'll be reminded several times), a Jewish woman living in Munster (did you know the Nazis didn't like Jews? In case you forget, you'll be reminded several times), and others, all of whom have attributes to them that you might forget, but, don't worry; you'll be reminded about them several times.Yes, as you may have gathered, one of Turtledove's more annoying practices is back again. Also, it has returned. On top of that, it's annoying. Plus it's annoying, and back yet again.But...still I read, and still I mostly enjoy. In fact, I was generally satisfied with this book until the very end.SPOILERS from here on out.You see, the war in Europe comes to an end in the last few chapters (and yet again, a major alt history writer misses a chance to put Hitler on trial for war crimes), and that's all well and good. Germany isn't as beaten as they were in the real world, and it could be interesting to see how that impacts things down the line. But if I never found out, that would be ok.What isn't really ok is that the war in the Pacific seems to finally be gearing up to take center stage. Midway and Wake are both taken and things are getting interesting, especially as the marines who invaded Midway are forced to remain there under quarantine for an undetermined time.And...then the book ends. The apparently last book in the series. The war with Japan is just really getting interesting, and the book stops. Doesn't even really end, as far as that part is concerned; it just stops. Now if this is a set-up for book seven, which as far as I know, isn't a thing, that's fine. If it's just the end of the series, then it's very sloppy writing.Sadly, Turtledove seems to have lost his touch in recent years. The Atlantis series was drivel from the first book, so I didn't bother with the second. The Supervolcano series showed so much potential, but the second book was so dreadful, I haven't bothered with the third. Then there's this series, which again, had much potential, but, really, it isn't a very alternate history.All that said, if there is a book seven, I'll read it. If not, I'll probably read whatever Turtledove puts out instead next summer. Even his bad books are still better than most.

Have you ever wanted to brush your teeth with an Altoid? That's pretty much what this is like. SO. MINTY. The flavor is very strong.Beyond that, it did indeed get my teeth clean. Did it whiten them? Hard to say this early in the game. I'll come back and do an update in a month or two, after I've used it regularly, and we shall see. For now, it's a decent product.

and had two kids pestering me (the weak parent) because they wanted to have the macaroni burger.  Honestly, I was interested too but I AM NOT A COOK, so I never bought one (and after A Really Lousy Experience buying from a TV commercial, as in, the never-ending-add-on-you-never-knew-about vitamin order that never seems to be cancelled no matter how many times you call…) I would never buy from a TV program.Amazon, yes, I would have bought here if I’d noticed them. But I did not notice these on Amazon, and ended up being contacted by a marketing company asking if I’d try it and give a review.  So, let me be clear, I DID NOT PAY FOR THIS.  IT WAS A FREEBIE.So, what did I think?  Overall and as per the Amazon star rating system:1 star: I hated it2 star: I don't like it3 star: It's OK4 star: I liked it <-------This.5 star: I loved itI ended up here, but it took a little time and patience to get to the point of liking it enough for 4 stars.I was sent one, and if you decide you are patient then one will suffice.  If you like to speed things up in the kitchen then the multiple item one might be nice to do a factory line type production.The other thing is the instructions were pretty minimal.  Nothing in the kitchen is intuitive for me so a very basic set of directions would have been very helpful.I did practice some Google-Fu and found a couple videos.  That was a time waster as they weren’t professionally done and there were too many pauses and illogical gaps.  A professionally done how-to video would have been great.  Or, an instruction book with pictures.  Something that boils down the steps for the lowest common denominator in the kitchen, which would be me or an 8 year old.Also, in messing about with the thing I managed to pinch myself a couple times in the handle.  I chalk that up to user-error, but still, that was annoying.The other Useful Thing to have been included would have been a couple basic recipes.  Of course Google came to the rescue but not in the way I needed.  Frankly, I have no idea how to cook a burger.  Seriously.  I also did not know bison meat cooks faster.  Oops.  Telling me (in the enclosed paperwork) to make sure the internal temperature of the meat was a certain number of degrees is not helpful.  First of all, that’s a pain in the rear, and second of all, what internal temperature?  The middle is full of other food!  Give me broiler times, pan times or even grill times as an outline.As a piece of personal advice, I would not start with macaroni (or bison burger).  That is not the easiest.  Go simple.  Some cheese, onions and peppers would have been much brighter on my part.  On the other hand, the leftover macaroni was good to eat after burning the burgers (did I mention bison meat cooks faster?).I also recommend you pay attention to the part about lubricating the device with a little oil.  If you make more than one particularly, it gets a tad sticky.Anyway, after a little practice  even an inept cook like me was able to figure out the right amount of meat and stuffing, and how to use the device.  It was fun and the kids even liked it…eventually.  I may even try the macaroni burgers again.  They really aught to be good now I've had more practice.Recommended, but the manufacturer should improve the instructions and directions.  Plus, practice a bit.  And don’t start with macaroni.JTG (the dog enjoyed the first attempts anyway)

Unfortunately the collar is so poorly constructed it did not last more than a week, so hard to say.  Also the 'scent' was strong enough to smell as a human (I wonder if that is a scent added so humans can smell it--it's a pleasant smell--and says 'oh boy it's working').  I should not be able to smell the maternal reassurance pheromone put out by a dog.However, the real issue is that the collar broke off.  My dog did not worry at it, or even seem to notice any more than her tag collar.  Yet the plastic broke completely and I found it at the bottom of her crate in pieces.  It should not have broken...I'd understand if she had been scratching or rubbing it on things in an effort to remove it, but no.
