The dog was completely unconcerned by it (too bad I can't say the same thing about her around tall male humans and other frightening objects....).I purchased this at the local pet store, and fortunately had already ordered the original collar brand with this concept.  That one is on her neck now (and aroma free I might add--no gimmicks to try and convince me something is going on...).Oh well, so one star because the construction was so shoddy there was no way to assess the final response.  I'd like to think it was working because two people petted her that normally frightened her...but it fell apart long before this could be decided.JTG (with XTG who is actually wearing the collar)

My first thought was "Just what I need, ANOTHER ‘get ready for retirement book’ (sarcasm intended)".  Turns out this really is a good one (hence the 5 stars, I'd give 4.5 but it definitely deserves the round up).I get so tired of books and gurus saying they have ‘the answer’ when in reality everyone’s situation is different.  The books have a tendency to oversimplify yet become overly complex at the same time.  This one is nice because it will introduce a standard recommendation or ‘rule of thumb’ and then discuss how to apply or adjust it on an individual basis.  With rare exceptions the book will take a topic, give a basic answer and then proceed to a more complex, yet clear, explanation so that you can best decide how to apply the knowledge to your own situation.At the start of the book there are 10 recommendations for things you should do (not just starting at 50 by the way) to get a grasp of where you stand and where you are heading.  Things like:--figure out your net worth (always good to have a realistic grasp of) and how to estimate it--figure out your spending (your spending relative to your income is what makes or breaks your ability to be independent and deserves careful attention),--reduce your debt (um, get RID of your debt, debt is what keeps you indentured to some other entity…debt is a tool to be used thoughtfully, but overall it ties you down),--how much you should be saving (there is a great graphic illustrating how much of a salary you would need to save vs. age at starting to save to get to retirement…I would argue that your spending is a huge factor, but showing the percentages relative to age at starting to save, very illuminating),--plan your insurance,--your estate planning,--organizing your records.Plus a few more.  In fact, that ’10 recommendation’ section is a nice blueprint for a setting up a solid underpinning for understanding and guiding your financial health.  READ this and grasp it.  I would just add, under the budgeting and future planning…figure out what you NEED and plan accordingly, without blindly using an arbiritary percentage of your income as set in stone as to what you can spend or put into a retirement account--figure out what you need to spend and save accordingly.The balance of the book is divided into sections that are then dealt with in a question/answer type style.  The author writes a finance column, so this makes sense.  It gives focused and useful answers to the questions, and you are able to find the topics that apply to you without having to wade through a longer narrative in a more typical format.I strongly recommend you download a sample or do the ‘peek inside’ feature and you can see what the topics are—this will give you an idea of how useful it is to your personal situation.Basically the sections are 10 years before retirement, transitioning to retirement, living in retirement, maximizing the social programs (SS and Medicare), estate planning, and the final section is ‘the people in my life’—a random assortment of topics that can be very important.For example, the first question is ‘am I saving enough’.  The author boils this down to three simple things—what do you expect to spend, how much money you will need to support this, and how much more you need to save to get to that point.  That’s it.  I like how the answer starts simple and then she fills in the explanation including things that may seem overmuch at first—like the 4% rule, and then how that 4% comes about.  Or, if you need a certain dollar amount and you can’t get to it, well, then go check another question out (linked on the Kindle version) and get an idea on where to revise your spending needs.It also brings up my least favorite 'rule of thumb' where people are directed to look at their income and estimate a percentage of it needed for a lifestyle.  That never makes sense to me, is it your final income (you may not know what that is or it may be significantly different than your 'normal' income)?  Is it your average income?  Is it your typical income?  Is it your fantasy income you hope to have someday in the future?Question 4, tries to simplify the types of retirement accounts.  Okay, that’s a big task, but there is an explanation of the types and then a summary at the end where there is a (relatively) simple set of guidelines to follow.I do pick nits with her portfolio planning (please, don’t let your eyes glaze over, this is important stuff—keeping your savings ahead of inflation).  Naturally the Schwab models are used, and some of them are a little too much for those less inclined to deal with them.Fortunately the next question brings in some simpler approaches.  However, with only 2 questions dealing with investment planning this is one topic you might want to do some additional reading to fine tune a plan. At the level of this book, it’s a good start, but I would have liked a little bit more.While some of this could have been a tad stronger, the vast majority was very spot on at a level useful for most.  I also found some exceedingly interesting things I would not have sought out--like making a system for a spouse to take over if need be, some interesting estate issues and planning for a special needs child.I admit to glossing over the SS and Medicare topics, as I am a few years away and the details and rules are sure to change.  However, I’m better off for at least having this on my radar.So, this book really was a nice addition to my burgeoning ‘finances collection’ on my Kindle.  I loved the format—very easy to pick and choose the needed bits.  I thought the majority of the topics were extremely well covered, and for ones that weren’t so much to my taste, at least they were good guides for what else I might want to read up on.  There are plenty of helpful links both within the book and to sources outside the book (like to estimate social security benefits or jumping to a different question that is related).  Easy to use, follow and understand.Highly recommended!JTG (enjoying her ‘transition years’ working part time to buff up the savings so the plans are well funded)

It's not easy buying for a teenager.  But here is a great item, and it's not even a black t-shirt!  Cool, yet nerdy.  Fits well and is as well made as any other shirt out there.  It's the 'official' product and thus acceptable to the discerning offspring.  A 'win' and highly recommended.Perfect for all colors of dog hair to show as well.PTG (JTG having a naming moment).

Kind of like finding skim milk in your coffee when you were expecting table cream.If you are a Hannah fan there is nothing intrinsically wrong with this one...more of the cozy sameness With Recipes.  The big fail on this is that there were something like 4500 Kindle locations (I don't have it handy to check) which is 360ish pages--not a long book--and a LOT of that is filler (the aforementioned recipes).That leaves a barely 'novel length' story.  A story that stopped halfway through.  Seriously, this can only be described as part one of a complete book.  There was no attempt at resolution of the real problem going on, just a filler murder that was easily solved and easily guessed.If you like Hannah, do buy this book, but only AFTER the next one is out.  That way you can read the entire thing at once.PTG (normally JTG, but I'm having a moment)

It was not a very attractive belt in person as the material was cheap appearing.  The hardware was decent and the construction appeared to be adequate.However, the biggest issue is the sizing.  The manufacturer does not give sizing information and using the generic sizing on Amazon leads to a WAY too small belt.  I have worn other Calvin Klein items (most recently some jeans that sadly had the button apparatus fall apart...hmm I'm sensing a theme here) and that size was consistent with other brands.  Why this belt was so far off is a mystery.Given the substandard materials it was not worth returning for another size.  It was just returned.  (2 stars because the hardware was decent and at least it didn't break in the short time I owned it).Total 'meh'.JTG (currently masquerading as PTG)

I was a big fan of the first book-- a great start for a new/self (?) published writer.  It was little rough in places, but a fun read (IIRC I gave 4 stars), but with a little more depth than the typical 'light read'.  This one does have a few minor typos/gender change/word substitution sorts of things...very minor and not much more than one sees in a trad-pub, but as good as the last one was, THIS ONE IS BETTER.  The humor is not as evident and it was not a book I read all at once--I needed the occasional break, but only because it was GOOD and needed a little more savoring.  The characters move on and move forward and one feels very vested in what is going on with themOne thing I want to point out is that as a follow up book this one leans very heavily on events in the prior book.  Enough so that I wish I had read them consecutively--or at least closer together.  I wanted to go back and re-read the first one but my reading dance card is overflowing and I just didn't, which I regret.  If you can take the time, I do recommend reading #1 in proximity.The other odd thing seems to be with Amazon's cataloging.  When clicking on the author page I don't see both books, and the publication date for the first book appears to be after this one, the second book.  I suspect there was an update to the first book (which may negate my prior comments about the slightly rough edges) as the cause but I don't know.  In any case, this is #2 and #1 is Maid for Mayhem (A Gretchen Gallen Mystery "Maid for Murder Series").The only other issue that may bother some is that, though it's not a cliffhanger, there is a major dangling loose end that is clearly the start of the next book (my best clue being the teaser chapter....).  It is not enough to bug me, but if even the slightest sort of this bothers you, well, it's there.  The big dangling thread left in the prior book was tied in this one, so it does seem to be an effective and planned writing device.  Hopefully I remember that and re-read (or at least skim) this one again before reading #3 and hopefully many more.  And, like last time, I do plan to stalk the author's website, and I plan to do it more effectively this time around!SO, bottom line, a great mystery/borderline thriller in a nice Southern setting and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!JTG (or PTG depending on my mood and current reviewing pen name)

Really Useful.They come in a variety of sizes and colors...the .14 size is the smallest I've seen.  These are perfect for small toys (think Legos/minifigs), yoyo strings, craft supplies, paper clips...anything small and easily scattered.  The tops are clipped close so you can drop them without losing (or loosing upon the environment) everything inside.  They are clear so you can see whats in them, they have a variety of colors which can be useful for organizing or just telling who belongs to what (Green is Jane, Blue is Fred, Purple is Dad, Clear is Mom etc).  They also are built to stack easily.They are made in the UK, which may explain the cool name.  I read the name and immediately had flashbacks to watching Thomas the Tank Engine and hearing the phrase 'A Really Useful Engine'.  Speaking of which, the larger sizes would be great for Thomas sets!I found these at a 'big box office supply store' but was happy to see on them on Amazon.  BUT, do check the Amazon listing to see who is the vendor.  If it's Amazon or a 'partner vendor' you can get prime/super saver shipping.  Vendors change frequently, so look to see who is selling (and if there is a shipping cost). In today's example, well, it's not beneficial to buy with shipping fees calculated in we'll just say.  Tomorrow, who knows.Highly Recommended!JTG

It's hysterical to see her trotting around with it in her mouth as she is a rather medium sized dog (a 50 pound galgo) but she loves moving it from her crate to bed several times a day.  She tosses it, she nits on it, she chews it, she uses it as a pillow and she stomps on it.  The grunt sound is fairly restrained and not annoying to either her or those around her (no one in the house likes squeakers).In this case, not recommended by the greyhound (who is mystified by the concept of toys) but HIGHLY and STRONGLY recommended by the galgo who is discovering her silly side.JTGedited to add:  a month later and she is still in love with this toy.  I added a couple pictures to the 'customer photos' section...the Galgo loves her Duckie.

Well constructed and not flimsy at all, and I like the ear wire quite a bit.  I happen to have a favorite bracelet with an oval darker amethyst stone that is surrounded by two pear peridots.  These are a very nice match in terms of style, but the amethyst color is just a bit different than what the photo suggests.In fact, the only quibble I have with these is that the photo seems to enhance the appearance of the colors.  The peridot is almost there, but the amethyst tone is just a bit darker than what came in the mail.Excellent earrings.  Highly recommended if you understand the shade variations (whether natural to the stones or a monitor issue, which seems less likely given other purchases) and are okay with that.  It is unfortunate Amazon does not allow for uploading customer pictures anymore, the color is beautiful, just not quite what I see and it would be nice to add a photo to demonstrate.JTG

This was a Christmas present for my husband, who really does make the good meals of the house.  He really wanted one believe it or not.The spousal unit reports this maker is 'a little flimsy feeling', but was otherwise very happy with it's functionality.  The waffles we have had so far came out very well and were quite tasty and evenly cooked.  Personally, I would reserve judgement on the flimsy factor as there is nothing to suggest poor quality.  Maybe just not as heavy duty as an industrial model.  But for a family of 4 it seems quite sufficient.  He wanted to rate it 9/10 so I am rounding up to a 5, but will post an update if there are any issues that arise.  In the meantime, I will enjoy the occasional waffle breakfast!Recommended!JTG

Err on the side of ordering larger than smaller.  The twist area (I know from trying on before buying) does gape a bit if the 'assets' are on the more bodacious side.  However, if there is a bodacious quality to one's figure the shirt then fits well to the waist but has enough drape in front for any pooch that may be present.  All in all, a flattering top and the only negative is that the fit runs a tad tight.  Of course, perhaps that was the point and I missed it.Recommended!JTG

I might have a dog with a less than discriminating palate (she won't eat mushrooms..or nylabone brand treats, but those are too much like the dreaded 'toys' for her liking), but she does have her favorites.Pegetables have long been one of her best treats, and I have not always been able to find them for sale (for example they are at a 'big box pet store that does not end in 'co', but not on the main aisle of treats, but on the bottom shelf of a different aisle).  In any case, after a couple years missing these, I found them again, and my old girl started dancing in excitement when she spotted them.On the other hand, I now have a Spanish Greyhound (galgo) who is in the process of learning how to be a pet--she hasn't quite figured out the greenies, Pegetables or the Nylabone Healthy Edibles.  However, she did carry the pseudo-celery to her bed and curled up around it, which was a start.  However, the galgo is not really a good barometer for treats--she only snarfs down anything that is clearly dog food or human food or something in the trash.  Like Jackie, she is puzzled by toys, but also by compressed food-like products in general.Galgo aside, the Greyhound adores these and the treat (USA made) is worthy of her short list of favorites.Highly Recommendedby the real JTG

That said, this is the best decaf I have ever tried, and though I wish they would make more of their varieties available in the single cups, the French Roast, House and Major D's are pretty good.  This year the Holiday Blend was also available which is pretty tasty as well.Basically, the cups I brew in the re-usable baskets vs. the preloaded cups are very much the same.  The choice is whether or not you go for the convenient cups vs. the more environmentally friendly re-usable baskets.In any case, Peets Coffee is my go to coffee and I buy it online rather than going with anything local.  And, like I mentioned earlier, the decaf is the best I ever had.  When going decaf I used to get a decaf Cafe Americano at whatever coffee bar was available in order to get a decent tasting decaf drink.  Any other decaf tastes like dirt to me, but not this one.  I can't even tell it's decaf.So, with the lumped reviews--be careful to note which variety and box count you are ordering, but I do HIGHLY RECOMMEND the Decaf particularly, but really all the Peets.  Peets Rocks.JTG (well, only the grownup humans in the household, no dogs get any coffee of course, though our new foster did try to shove her nose into the spousal unit's mug yesterday).

This is a nice light spray that does its job with my very fine hair.  Usually I'm trying for a straight look with a little control to keep the sides off my face (I don't know the 'real' words'), and when the can functions, it does a great job.  Also, it keeps the frizz down as one would hope with an 'anti-humidity' spray.  In other words, great for my fine hair with a simple style.HOWEVER, twice now I have had issues (the last two out of 4 cans) with the canister itself.  Basically, it was acting like a clog but when I tried to clean it the nozzle came off and was impossible to fix.  I have no idea if it really was a clog--and if it was, that was ridiculous to have happen with the inner workings.  Okay, not very technical, but it seemed to be stopped up and it wasn't on the external parts.Oh well, time to buy something else, which I hate to do because I like the spray.  I imagine I'll try it again in 6-12 months after not finding a decent replacement (whatever I find is sure to weigh my hair down or not hold it well enough...such a pessimist I am today).  Hopefully the production issue with the cans will be fixed.JTG

I wasn't expecting much as this is not an easy thing to evaluate with small online pictures.  I was pleasantly surprised as the frame is a lightweight, yet solid feeling, metal and well constructed.Highly recommended!JTG, USN (Ret.)

My oldest has a bit of a funny sense of humor for a teenager--he likes  Monty Python (I think he's a throwback to the 70s sometimes) and ran around with his friends last year trying to convince their drama teacher to let them re-enact a MP skit as a class project.  Needless to say, this mug is perfect for him.The mug itself is made in China and appears to be well constructed--it's a heavier duty mug with some heft to it.  The glaze is even and no defects in the printing/design.  Though the vendors on Amazon differ (well, Amazon sells this one, the other was from a partner vendor), this is from the same people who sold the Shakespearian insult mug I also got for him.The only thing I could complain about (which is not my son's complaint) is that I would love a quote about the 'machine that goes ping' and perhaps about the airspeed velocity of an unladen swallow.  But there are plenty of great quotes, and only so much room on the mug!JTG(and check out the 'instructional' video for mugs on the manufacturer's website...very amusing!)

My oldest has a bit of a funny sense of humor for a teenager--he likes Shakespearian insults and Monty Python (I think he's a throwback to the 70s sometimes).  This mug is right up his alley for humor--and being cool because he has his 'own' mug now.The mug itself is made in China and appears to be well constructed--it's a heavier duty mug with some heft to it.  The glaze is even and no defects in the printing/design.Highly recommended for those with a more literary sense of humor (well, literary when not quoting MP anyway).JTG

One thing (of a few) that I go overboard on is for throws.  I love throws.  My excuse is that my older dog with little fur or fat gets chilly.  But really, I just like having one within 4 feet of me at all times.This version of the plush throw is an improvement over last year's version, which I liked very much (I'm not including the 'cotton plush throw' that I recently purchased--that one was also good, but a little different in materials).This one is similarly and exceedingly soft and does not shed. There is also no evidence of a chemically odor which had been transiently present on the first version, plus it is just a bit larger which is more comfortable for the adults--still big enough to be used as a bed blanket, but perfect as a throw.The one I bought last year pilled a bit and I expect this one will too eventually, that does appear to be the nature of these synthetic plush items.So far the new one has been reserved for the humans, and it will likely stay this way.  Light, warm, soft and cuddly--highly recommended!!JTG(I will try and add a picture of the one from last year that shows the pilling, but that feature seems to be hit and miss on Amazon these days).

... but makes it easier.Sometimes the economical way makes things harder...in this case instead of a multi-step process of messing around with a bridge threader plus floss, there is a simple one step--tear open the package.  Ridiculous and a first world issue, finding that opening two containers and putting the floss and the threader together together was 'difficult', but the reality is that when fatigued before bed it was too easy to skip the flossing.I have definitely improved my flossing habits by using these.  Pathetic on my part, but true nonetheless.  I just keep an eye out for sales and deals (and add-ons to other shipping) to make them slightly more economical.Highly recommended!JTG

I'll admit to some trepidation when buying a book like this--an unknown-to-me author in the genre of the small town/law enforcement protagonist/murder mystery with a cat theme.  Popular variations of this abound so I was worried about falling into one of the lesser versions.However, this one works and works extremely well, to the point I ended up buying all four of the available titles and reading them back to back.  The protagonist is engaging and her backstory unfolds gradually over the four books, and the supporting characters do the same.  There is a romantic theme added in near the end and it takes wee bit of a crooked path...with knots and tangles that still have some working out to do (though by the end of book 4 it's looking good).  Most importantly, the writing style is engaging and well done, and the characters are believable and all have flaws of some sort.I also appreciated that though the town was a bit quirky, it never went over the deep end.  I've recently moved to somewhere in the vicinity (well a hundred miles or so) of where Crazy aught to be and I keep hunting the maps for it and I love the region descriptions given.Highly Recommended!JTG

I have eaten these crackers off and on for years (decades)--ever since my mother was on a 1970s era health-nut kick and brought them home.  I was quite pleased to see these on Amazon as I have not found them locally.  As with some items check to see who the vendor is (and whether or not the item qualifies for Prime).  Currently these are offered by Amazon, but it's the sort of item that can have multiple sellers.In any case, as crackers go, they are whole wheat with a touch of honey as well as butter, sesame oil and sesame seeds (with yeast and salt rounding outthe ingredients--it's a short ingredient list!).They are quite a nice counterpoint to a strong cheese, but also quite delicious as a straight up snack item.  Well worth the effort to get them via mail and my spouse/children also like them quite a bit.  It's time to reorder.Highly Recommended.JTG

I bought this to give one to my Father-in-Law, who loves it. It's sized for smaller medications and if you have something that needs extra protection, there is a glass container/liner that optionally fits inside (like for nitro I presume).The set comes in various colors so can be shared, or if you have more than one medication, you can color code them. Personally, I have added a few ibuprofens to one and carry that around. It would work for many other meds though (blood pressure, migraine, baby ASA etc depending on the size/type of the pill).Very handy but make sure you only have smaller tablets or items to carry.Recommended!

Okay, this was a pretty ridiculous buy, but much better than expected!  I like having the small pillows for traveling/hotels/sitting in recliners etc.This one has the added benefit in that three people (so far) have asked my why there was a log on my chair.  If you aren't paying a reasonable amount of attention, you can really fall for the look.The only 'criticisms' I have (and may be pluses for others) are that1.  I wish it was a little less stuffed.  The thing is so full that it holds it's shape really well, and I'd like something a little more 'moldable' to whatever position I want it in.and2.  The material could be a little more comfortable/higher grade.  Unfortunately I have been spoiled by the coverings found on the Mogu pillows (sadly not sold outside of Japan anymore) and those are super soft and smooth.  This fabric is good, just not that good.Oh, and one other positive, I have bought this type (okay, just a solid print, not a log version) on the cheap before and those have had a chemical-ly odor.  This one is aroma-free.

Requires fiddling and manipulation to keep it aligned, but works great for little things (like, oh say medicine cups for when everyone in the house is sick and wants liquid versions of medications) and for occasional use.Check the price and see if it's the value you are looking for...it's not incredibly sturdy feeling, but unless you are doing a daily use of it that may not be an issue.  The price-du-jour for me was low (and free shipping) so it's well worth it.  If I had to use it every day I'd look for something better quality.Plus, I like the bright color, it's easy to spot at the back of the 'seldom used item' cabinet.Recommended!

One would think that even an inexpensive scale (with a 5 year warranty per the manufacturer's website) would at least have a modicum of usefulness or accuracy. This scale, not so much.I bought the scale this summer and at no point has it functioned in a reliable fashion. I can get on the scale going from 'out of the shower' to fully dressed including shoes and jeans, and the weight won't change. I can get on the scale twice in 15 minutes (without changing anything) and gain/lose 6 pounds. I guess I could say it's always been within about 10 pounds of my actual weight.Not Useful.Also, the spot that gets tapped to activate the scale is horribly unresponsive and the materials feel cheap and flimsy. Definitely indicative of actual effectiveness.After reading the reviews here and elsewhere it is apparent that my experience is not an isolated one. Too bad I bought it on the fly at XXXXXX instead. I'm now hundreds of miles away from the store, and as I'm sure the manufacturer relies on, it's just not worth the time and effort to try and hold them to their warranty. Great business model--cheap enough so it costs more effort that it's worth for a refund.So, if you are smarter than me and checking reviews before buying (well, it was before I owned a smartphone so it wasn't like I could do it while standing in the aisle at least) DON'T GET THIS ONE. Spend the money, get a more reliable model if you are in need of any semblance of reliability.JTG

It was short, funny and full of the typical things found in a Marr story, though a bit more fluffy.This one counts as what I refer to as 'a slice of life'.  It's not a full blown tale, but more of a 'I can't believe the kind of day I'm having' sort of thing.If you are familiar with the series, you will find this a lot of fun, but perhaps not as 'filling' as you might like.  If you have never read one of these stories, then this one can give you an idea of the style of writing, but just understand that it might not read as a truly 'stand alone' story.  There was a definite benefit to having familiarity with the characters when reading this.Normally I save the 5 stars for shorter stories to those that stand alone well.  However, when something is part of a well established series and it just 'works' anyway, well it gets the full five anyway.  Just be aware that if you are a newcomer to the series, this might be best thought of as a sample to see if the style suits--and this is a little higher on the silly end of the spectrum.RECOMMENDED (the whole series, even the one with **shudder** monkeys)JTG

I find that many books are so full of (albeit useful) information, there is overload that leads to paralysis.  In trying to plan the perfect way to start, plant, plan and manage the gardening, it becomes immensely difficult to just begin.This book on the other hand encourages a simple/proven method that makes taking the first step easy.  Once you start, then you can expand in both quantity and variety with much more confidence.That said, even if you are an experienced gardener, if you are using a more traditional method then this book may also be worth a look.  Some very sage advice that leads to maximizing production while minimizing resources.As for format to purchase I have to confess I bought two versions.  First I got the Kindle version.  The text was fine, but the illustrations are not suited to the e-Ink screen.  I looked at those on my laptop and it was a fine rendition and I did not find any formatting errors.  However, this is the type of book that I personally prefer to do a bit of page flipping in...so after reading the Kindle version I bought the paper one.  Kind of ridiculous, but I liked the book that much.Highly Recommended!JTG

This is the second 'Pinzon' throw I've purchased -- Pinzon being the Amazon private label.  The previous one was a 'microfleece' type (called microtec) which after a few washed stopped shedding, was extremely light and cuddly, but was a little on the small side.  It has now been given to the dog, she loves it.  So, here I was shopping for another one for the non-fur bearing members of the household.  That throw is no longer offered, but the new Pinzon one was, so of course I'm trying it.This one is a 'cotton plush'--an acrylic and cotton blend, supposedly that is eco-friendly.  I have no way to confirm that but I am taking that statement at face value.  Compared to the old version, this throw is bigger--much more amenable to humans snuggling on couches (rather than dogs snuggling on dog beds) and is quite warm enough for cooler evenings.  It does not quite have the easy draping, and feels heavier, but if I had never tried the other throw I would be perfectly satisfied with this one.  In terms of size, the measurements are given, but as a rough guide it's about the size of the flat part of a twin bed.  I'm 5'7 1/2" ish and fell asleep on the couch with it and my feet stayed covered.It feels sturdy and is well constructed, and so far no laundry issues.  It feels durable, and if it turns out not to be over the next few months I'll be sure to update the review.So, basically 4.5 stars--in comparing to other plushy throws it's a tad heavier and drapes just a little less...but it really is quite nice.  The price and color were right and I like the 'eco-ness' of it.  Definitely recommended!JTG

which was silly because I missed out on Prime shipping.  Oh well.This was my second try to get an adapter for my iphone so it will work with my car.  I previously tried iPhone 5 Adaptor - Lightning To 30 Pin iPhone Adaptor Charge Sync With Audio For Docks Cables Cars By CableAndCase which was a failure with my various trials.I bought this one and plugged the 30 pin side into another adapter I have leading into my car (similar to this one 3.5mm Audio Line Out + 30pin Usb Dock Cable for Iphone Ipod).  After one false start with me needing to make sure everything was connected properly, it worked perfectly.  I have my iphone supplying my car music which is very important given my new locale (sparse and generic radio choices we'll just say).  Oh, and it was charging my phone too.The SF Cable adapter also worked with 2 other 30 pin docks in my house (a speaker thing and a clock/radio/ipod base).  I really only care about my car and I'm VERY happy to have a working cable without having to buy from the fruit company directly.The nice thing about this one (other than it actually worked) is that if the vendor continues to be an "Amazon Partner" and keep stock in the Ammy warehouses, if you find it does not work with your particular device, then a return is fairly simple.Recommended!JTGEDITED TO ADD:  Looks like this is one of those items that has the vendor change periodically.  Some vendors of the SFCable keep their stock on Ammy's shelves (thus prime).  Some don't...the vendor du jour on 9.26.13 is the actual manufacturer...price is lower but there is shipping.  Just be aware and check the details when purchasing.

My daughter is at the age now where she's really having a lot of fun dressing up and putting all sorts of weird accessories in her hair and on her clothes. She loves these things!They're tougher than they appear in the photo, and the charms at the end seem to be the thing that "seals the deal" with my girl. The glow-in-the-dark feature is also cool (anything that glows is cool, right?).These are well made and packaged, and while they're not exactly a new iPhone, they would certainly make an awesome stocking stuffer if your young miss is into this sort of thing.

This is a very cool light.It runs on 3 AAA batteries, and the LED lamp puts out a TON of light, much more than expected. The only button on it controls the on/off for the light, and it's sturdy and well placed.What makes this really cool, however, are the myriad of options you have for keeping this thing shining on whatever you're looking at. The green "feet" swivel in such a way that you can either clamp the light directly to something, or you can lock the handle open (sort of like a gas pump) and set it down on something flat. The light itself then swivels around and stays where you put it. You can also lay it on its side and swivel the head for much the same effect. Of course you can also keep the top flat on its base and use it the same way you would a flashlight as well.This product is fairly tough, and I think up to the task of handling most general household encounters. IMHO it's not up to the task of being thrown around in a worksite or shop, but for the uses most homeowners are going to come up with it's more than up to the task.Well functioning, sturdy, handy to have around.

I have this case in black. This is a seriously high-quality, classy case, both in design and construction.Essentially this is a calfskin-leather wallet attached to a very slim--but very solid--case that wraps arounds the outside of your iPhone. The top corner is angled to allow you to take pictures.As an aside, while this case does provide a degree of protection for your phone (especially on the billfold side), I think it's more of an incredibly convenient way to carry your cash and cards with your phone without having to lug a wallet or purse along also. In this capacity it's as perfect as it gets, it's very well thought out.The billfold itself has a crazy strong magnet that keeps it securly fastened to the back of the case with bills and without, and the card pocket is just the right size for several cards, and they won't fall out. The craftsmanship of the leather and stitching are flawless, and the whole thing has a very understated, yet classy feel.If you're the type that prefers a more upscale look over the traditional blocky armor/case dujour, you really can't go wrong with this.Highly recommended.

If you've had any experience with blue-tooth speakers, you pretty much get how this device works:First, the charge, which is typical for this sort of thing at a couple hours. There is a light to tell you when it's done charging.Second, the peering is more or less identical to most items like this (when your device detects it, say 'ok', which varies by device). I was able to peer it with the usual cast of characters... tablet, PC, smartphone, MP3 player, etc... I run both Windows and Ubuntu Linux at home, it works fine with all of them. I did not need the password specified in the product instructions.I was able to easily control/iterate through my music (while showering no less!), controls all function well as advertised.This speaker is indeed waterproof; I've had no issues whatsoever using it in the shower. The suction cup is a beast, I may use it to recover the Titanic one day. And overall it looks pretty cool.The packaging is well done, this would make a good gift for someone that would appreciate it. The instructions appear to be clear and accurate (although a bit small for my aging eyes!), I must admit though that I didn't need them... as I said before, if you have any experience with these sorts of things it's more or less a no-brainer.The only reason I didn't give the product 5-stars is that at $38.95, the price seems a bit steep to me. There's a lot of bluetooth speakers on the market today, and while this does sound fantastic (considering it's waterproof), I just feel like I could get something similar for less. I could be wrong about that though, it is a good product.

This stuff isn't so bad, and for me to say that about instant coffee is actually pretty crazy.I HATE instant coffee.I bought this to have at work in case I wanted an afternoon cup, which isn't something I don't do too often. I did a lot of research online before buying this, I suppose I was looking for something acceptable at a decent price.It took me a few cups to understand that the amount of coffee you add to the hot water has a DRASTIC effect on what the end product tastes like... I don't mean that in a *DUH* sort of way, I mean that this coffee takes on a somewhat more complex profile once you get enough in there. For me, that's three more or less heaping teaspoons in a big travel mug. I also throw in some French Vanilla creamer powder stuff, and all in all, it's an agreeable cup of java. Brewed it ain't though!If you're going to buy instant coffee "stuff", this is a safe bet, unless you want to go the Starbucks route and pay through the nose for far less product. I wouldn't want this to be my only option, but as a backup brew it does the trick.

This DVD is full of useful information for any guitarist that's ready to move beyond playing everything in a single position. The CAGED system is straight-forward and easy to pick up, and this DVD spends a fairly large amount of time on each element, as well as linking the various elements together.The guitar is an instrument of equivalencies; there's usually at least one or two additional ways that you can do exactly what you're already doing, and a plethora of ways to vary each of those but still retain the same overall structure. The CAGED system is geared towards allowing you to easily see the entire neck's "interconnectedness", and honestly succeeds in this task. I've been playing guitar now for the better part of three decades, and I was amazed at how things that were right in front of my face that whole time suddenly became obvious (almost unavoidable) after I adapted this way of "seeing" the neck.This DVD is not for beginners. You should be fairly comfortable playing many sorts of chords, and have at least a basic understanding of how to find single notes on each string. Knowing the basics of the diatonic major scale would also be a huge help as well. If you're beyond that and know some more advanced theory this whole thing will come together fast and furious for you!Recommended!EDIT: I wanted to add something here. There are a lot of arguments going on all over the Internet concerning whether or not the CAGED system is really useful, especially for playing metal leads. I'll be the first person to point out that this system has some serious limitations when it comes to playing extended arpeggio runs and visualizing exotic scales. But I also think that misses the point. Every musician that attains any real level of mastery with their chosen instrument(s) has at some point come to realize an ultimate truth about their craft: there simply are no magic bullets. And while these systems can offer new paths to travel, there simpy are no substitutes for time spent with your hands on the instrument, making music in as many ways as you possibly can. In other words, it's like everything in life: what you get out of it is a direct result of what you put into it. And with that in mind, my toolbox is more complete WITH this system than without it.

This is a great all-purpose saltwater hook for tying streamers. I usually get these guys in the 50-pack (1/0 to size 2 usually) and go crazy tying Clousers and seatrout flies, recently I've been tying a lot of Norm's Crystal Shminnow patterns on them (these are actually the exact hook specified by Ole' Norm himself...).Not much to say about them really, just good quality hooks at a price you can buy in bulk. They've always worked well for me!

I'm struggling to think of what I can add to what the other reviewers have said about this product. It's:- A good looking and well executed design.- Very solidly built.- It seems to be reliable.- Packaged well- Offers great access to your phones inputs.It's very cool that you can charge both the phone and the case at the same time.Bear in mind that this case will add a bit of thickness/weight to your phone, but I think that's to be expected with this sort of thing. The case looks very good on your phone, and the sides are rubber for added protection. For what it is, it's a great product!

I got this doll for my daughter, for her birthday, and she absolutely loves it!At first it seemed to me a bit on the pricey side, but once we got it I can understand why... while it has a somewhat delicate look about, its construction is first-rate and quite tough. My daughter frequently sleeps with it, and I've seen the cats launch some pretty brutal assaults on it, and it's still none-the-worse for wear after a few months. This is the sort of doll that lasts a long time.The whole concept of having one doll's head hidden up the other doll's skirt(!) seemed, well, really bizarre to me at first; I have to admit though that it works... once that dress goes down, the "other" doll is really gone.Well-designed and executed, highly recommended.

This is a really good book for several reasons. It's one of the few that take you all the way from starting with no idea what technical analysis is (or even trading for that matter), all the way up to locked, cocked, loaded and ready to trade. I think after you trade for a while you forget just how daunting those first few steps can be for many people.I've always been more of a technical trader (as opposed to trading fundamentals), it's a way of thinking I was first exposed to as a teenager, and using this perspective I was able to trade futures with a fair degree of success. Since then I've also traded stocks and Forex this way, and I've found that many of these techniques hold-up in, well, any market really.This book covers a lot of ground, from understanding markets and their trends, older techniques such as moving averages, candlesticks, trend patterns, etc... and also using more advanced analysis techniques available with most modern trading software. It's a lot, but it's written in a highly accessible, no-nonsense language that reflects the considerable amount of experience of the author. I found it to be a nice refresher.I don't think this book is really aimed at seasoned traders; it's quite broad, I think seasoned traders wouldn't get a whole lot from it, although I could be wrong about that, I guess I'm just speaking for myself. I will say that if you are just getting started however this book is pure gold, it basically hands you everything to enter the market and not lose your butt!Highly recommended.

I like these a lot!- They're packaged well.- They curl up to basically nothing. One of the many things about conventional earbuds that drive me crazy is that if you're not super-careful and just throw them in heap somewhere, you spend like two minutes untangling them when you want to use them again. Not so with these.- They're fairly resilient as these sorts of things go. In other words, with normal wear and tear, they should last a while.- VERY comfortable, they anchor themselves to my head and stay put.- It has a microphone, honestly I just use them for music though.- Easy to peer up with a music source.- They sound great to me!Again, headphones in general usually end up making me mad... these seem like a fair trade off, and they're very comfortable. They also sound great!The "sweat proof" aspect of these also seems to be accurate, when I sweat it doesn't seem to affect them at all.

I always try to review things at the intersection of price and quality; in other words: value.These bags, for the price and quantity of them received, are pretty good.What I like:- They're inexpensive, and you get four.- The canvas cloth is a nice touch, they seem more "real" than cheap plastic cases, if that makes any sense.- They're reasonably well made.- The zippers seem to function well.- They can be used for much more than just pens and pencils.What I Don't Like:- They could be a little longer so pencils fit in there better.- The cloth is a bit thin, no so bad though.I gave these to my 7-year old daughter. She uses one as an actual pencil/crayon bag at school, and uses another as a "make-up" bag of sorts, and others to hold collections of the sort of trinkets that 7-year old girls have.I could see using this for sewing "stuff", or maybe something to throw change into.So hey, I'm happy. Make no mistake: super-upscale these bags are not, but they're perfectly servicable as cute cheap bags you just need to get a moderate amount of use from.

This is an awesome lamp for the money, very well engineered.It arrives well packaged (it's the same thing you can buy in Target during the 5 minutes they actually have it in stock), and it's very easy to put together.The base is quite heavy. Actually I would think knocking it over impossible. It's also very sturdy. The rotary switch is solid and turns on 3 different combinations of lights, as well as 'off'. The arms are super-adjustable, and don't feel flimsy or short-lived.The pink, purple and white shades are very cool also, they match my daughter's room perfectly.The only complaint I have about this light is the 40w restriction (per bulb), it doesn't throw off a ton of light, but it's certainly adequate, and you can adjust the direction of the lights as needed.Good stuff!

I've been using my Opinel knife for maybe 5 or so years... many, MANY mushrooms have met their demise because of it, and it's still none-the-worse for wear. It has a very understated elegance, very simply built, light in the hand or pocket and meant to be used.Occasionally a bit of grit will get into it that I have to work out because it fouls the action, but it's never anything a shot of WD-40 won't take of, usually I don't even need that, just a good rinsing and drying.As was pointed out in the comments, there is a lock of sorts on the blade. There's a collar that you can turn that will stop the knife from folding. Not something you'll use a lot when you're cuttin' 'shrooms, but there if you need it!As long as you keep it sharp, and clean and dry it when you're done hunting, maybe a little light-oil from time to time, you'll be giving this knife to your grandchildren!Highly Recommended.

Ditto to the other reviews.What's nice:- These gloves are packaged great.- I'm an XL, I have very big hands. Sometimes, even when I order stuff in this size, it still doesn't quite fit right. These gloves are spot-on.- They are quality. These gloves are tough as nails, made of actual leather(!), and are well-finished. I anticipate having them for awhile.- They work great for lifting. They do a wonderful job of giving your hand support as you lift, and keep you from getting calluses and blisters that you'll eventually shear off (ouch!) when you lift something else.- They break in well. I was a little concerned that the leather would make it hard to move my hands and fingers nimbly, but no worries.For the price, these gloves are a home run, good stuff!

You know, every once and a while you run across a product that's almost too good to be true. I've been shaving with a DE razor for perhaps five years now, and I really like trying new stuff, but I must admit I've gotten set in my ways because I've found what works.I usually shave with Bigelow or Proraso cream in a tube, although I'll use a high-end soap cake from time to time, there's a lot of good stuff out there. So one day I ordered some shaving "thing" from someone, and along with the "thing" they threw in a free stick of Arko. Even though I had heard some good things about it, I stuck it up in my cabinet and forgot about it, and went back to using my Bigelow.About two months ago I happened to reach for the Bigelow tube and realized it was empty. Suddenly I remembered the stick of Arko that had been sitting in my cabinet for the last year(!) or so, and decided to give it a try while I was waiting for more of something else to show up. I like to use a scuttle, and the idea of just "drawing on my face" didn't really appeal to me too much, but hey, any port in a storm, right?So I got my face moist with warm water and I basically started "drawing" on it with the Arko stick. The smell is ok, it's just not TOBS or anything like that. I wet my brush down and started whipping up my neck with it and was amazed at how quickly it turned into a nice lather. It took all of 15 seconds. I had a great shave.The really crazy part is that the amount of soap that it took for my shave was essentially too small to notice! Let's just say I got used to this stuff really, REALLY fast, and it's now my go-to shave, at least for the time being. So here we are, at least two months later, and I still have well over a third of the stick left!Highly recommended.I'll say this also: some of these reviews mention the lack of good foam with this product. I've found that the foam is definitely different with the more utilitarian products, its more "soapy" and less "creamy." That being said though, this stuff produces more than enough for me, but that's me. I also know that water hardness makes a huge difference in the foam quality, you might want to try it again, but use some distilled water... the difference can be massive.

I originally reviewed this on the main Condor page here on Amazon, but I bought it through United Cutlery so I wanted to make sure my review was here as well:I bought this parang as a general-use tool to have with me when I'm off road in my truck, for cutting away brush and also to have a general cutting tool for anything else I might encounter. In this capacity it is perfect.What I like:- It arrives well packaged.- The Sheath is breathable and high-quality.- The handle is comfortable and ergonomic, and the flares at both ends keep the tool in your hand as you swing.- It's well balanced.- It keeps a decent edge.- The parang style of machete can be used as both a general machete and as a camping/survival tool. It multi-tasks well.Nothing really stands out as a negative at this point, but I can say the sheer thickness and weight of this parang could be a plus or a minus, depending on the task at hand... it's surprisingly thick and heavy for it's size.Lastly, before you purchase this, be sure you understand that this is a tool, not a collector's item (although it does look cool). It's made of relatively soft carbon steel so that it "gives" instead of breaking, which harder, more brittle, steels do. It's meant to be used and abused, not hung on a wall. Don't get me wrong- the steel quality is great, perfect for its task IMHO. But I wouldn't hesitate to do some choppin' with it!

The cable I got is genuine Skiva for sure, and it works great!It's long enough to plug into just about anything, and it's made of really thick, high-quality cable that seems to take a good amount of abuse. Both adapters are very securely attached, and the lightening charger works with my iPhone with no issues.Don't know what else to say about it really, it's a charging cable. It's been working great for me for the last month or so.

This charger works great! Not much I can really say about it to be honest with you, I've been using it for several weeks now. It stays in my 12V outlet pretty well in my truck, and all of the Skiva stuff that I've tried works perfectly with my iPhone. The cable is quality, and thick enough to stand up to reasonable abuse. Both connectors are securely attached, I've never had any issues with it, and it gets dogged around in quite a bit.All at a pretty good price as well! What's not to like? Recommended

Ok, this is one of those things where several factors need to be considered before you make your purchase. I'll try to be as detailed as I can, this hydra has many heads!The Packaging:This truly is "a light in a box." A very small box. The reason that this product is fairly inexpensive, I think, is in large part because it is you the consumer that puts it together! It's packaged quite well, and when you open it you get a base, instructions, a bag of wire-nuts and screws, a taped up cylinder of mother-of-pearl(?) discs, and a bag with 10.2 billion tiny slip rings (think miniature key rings).The Instructions:I'm calling the slip of paper that comes with this lamp "assembly instructions", but I think it's value is much higher as "entertainment." The diagram doesn't match the base in any meaningful way, and there is no mention of wire colors or proper grounding. They do an adequate job of conveying what you're shooting for in terms of linking together the disks, but really that's about it. Where these instructions really shine however, is in their copious usage of translated Chinese ("Chinglish"), which frankly will have you belly-laughing and is worth the price of the lamp in and of themselves. I would quote some, but I don't want to spoil your fun.My point here is that if you know how to install a ceiling lamp, you'll do just fine... it's simple enough, three wires: white, black, and copper (ground). If this is your first time hanging a lamp though, just be sure you get your instructions ANYWHERE(!) but here.Assembly:If you're a bit older, like me, and need reading glasses from time to time, grab them. You're gonna need them. And cancel that doctor's appointment because you're not going anywhere for at least an hour or two. To their credit, they give you plenty of extra discs and rings, so if you mess it up and break/bend something, no worries. But saying that linking all the rings together into the discs is tedious is the understatement of the year.One major bone of contention I have with these sorts of things (not just this lamp in particular) is that once you link it all together, you can't really move it too much, because every time you set it down something falls off and needs to be reattached. That's life in the big city I suppose...Installation:Piece of cake. If you have an existing standard ceiling receptacle, it fits perfectly. Be aware though, it only takes a single 40-watt small bulb, so it's not exactly gonna be a day at the beach in that room if this is the only light.Use:Here is where this ceiling lamp really comes into its own. After all of the nonsense associated with assembling it and keeping it together while I hung it, I have to admit it's a pretty darn cool lamp. I put in my daughter's room, and when only this lamp is on it bathes the entire room in soft purple light and projects a neat pattern on the ceiling. Very mellow, it softens the room up nicely. Again though, if this is your ceiling lamp of choice, make sure the room has other lighting options because it doesn't put out a lot of light.Well, that's about it. Personally I like it a lot, but it's not for everyone.

A muddler is not exactly one of those things most people are going to use every day. Well, at least I'm not. But I've used this one a couple times, and I can say that it's well made, ergonomic, and is great at it's job... crushing mint leaves.It also feels solid in your hands, and look pretty snazzy too.Great tool.

This is a great brush... it's long enough to really get into larger grills, solidly made, and the stainless steel components seem to be of a high quality (as grill brushes go). It's the same style as most of these sorts of brushes, but at this price it seems to be a better deal than say a comparable one you would buy at Wal-Mart.I've used it a few times now and it's none the worse for wear, I expect to have it for awhile, unless of course my daughter walks away with it!Good stuff, recommended.

This is as close to perfect as it gets.- The packaging is tough, but easy to open.- The instructions are clear, and installation is smooth.- Everything you need is in the packaging.- It looks good on the phone and is doesn't affect the quality of calls or pictures, and using the touch-screen is as easy as ever.- It stays put.Plus, being tempered glass, it's crystal-clear while still offering quality protection.Good stuff! The only complaint I have, and believe me it is a very, VERY small one, is that the tab attached to the adhesive backing on the glass came off without pulling the backing with it. Maybe it's supposed to do that, not really sure. That being said, though, it was still a piece of cake to get the backing off so I'm just nit-picking.I wouldn't think twice about buying this, iPhones cost too much.

While most of the time we as humans dream of getting our hands on really awesome, expensive stuff, as I've gotten older I've begun to realize that most of the time it's the little conveniences that make day-to-day life easier.And who doesn't need more flashlights?Both of the products that come in this set are exactly what you expect them to be. These flashlights are the more or less the same as the ones you've seen for $3-$5 in many places, and the keychain lights/bottle openers are the sort of thing you might see for a few bucks in a liquor store. They're both well made, seem to be durable, and function well. Plus you have enough of the key chains to give them away to everyone with a beer in their hand!At this price point, these are awesome. You probably could resell them for more. Heck the batteries alone would cost as much as this!

As I've stated in other reviews of "device armor", I find that with these sorts of things you have to be a bit philosophical when evaluating them.This case, at this price point, is awesome as a general piece of protection for your iPad if you're just looking to protect from the general knocks and bumps of use around the house, or the kids, maybe general travel. Especially cool is the way the corners grab fabrics that you lay it on - if you throw it on the edge of the bad, it stays put.As mentioned in other reviews, the screen protector isn't very useful; this thing is more for the armor than anything else. So the screen is going to be wide-open and exposed (not so unusual). I guess the point is that is if what you need is complete protection for your device, this isn't the one. But if you're more concerned with bumps and drops, this product does a great job!

For the money, I'm very pleased with these 30-pin cables. All three of them seem to work great, and they're built durably enough to stand-up to what I would consider normal wear and tear. They're also long enough to not get jerked around whenever I move my main device.The colors are also nice too, they match my daughter's case for her iPhone, which I suppose makes them very cool in her eyes.I'm always happy to see decent value priced cables, the OEM cables (for everything) cost too much...

You know, back in 2007 when I first refinanced my brand new $90,000 house for $250,000, and then $400,000, I was a little concerned that my granite-lined nursury didn't have enough accoutrements to fostor the sort of genius that my offspring will have. I had already signed my two-year old up for lacrosse, softball, baseball, swimming, and tackle football (she's big for her age), and I figured that having a nice place to live and do yoga with her mother was not only warrented, but practically her birthright. Standing in front of Home Depot at 6am every day and bargaining for cash jobs is hard work; we're entitled to have a few of the finer things that life has to offer.So after I got my wife and I matching BMW X3 SUV's with the refi money, I decided that the next worthy thing on the list is something that would brighten up my daughter's life, not to mention her room! I searched for many hours for the perfect trinket to light up her eyes (because I understand the value of money), and I believe I found it in this great product, which I purchased, sight unseen, simply by adding it to my cart and charging it. I could have used the cash I had on hand I suppose, but part of being wealthy is managing your debt, and my 22% APR Capital One card seemed like a prudent move.At any rate, when it arrived at my door it was stunning, with all the diamonds and stuff. It occured to me that at two years old, my daughter might be getting towards the end of her pacifier days, but I don't really pay too much attention to that sort of thing. I'm usually drunk on Miller High Life by the time I get home every day, can you blame me? I gave it to her anyway, and I have to say that for the next 40 minutes my little princess was enraptured... success!A little bit later I noticed that her fascination with it had ended, and her eyes were now transfixed on a piece of cat poop that had somehow been dragged up from the basement and into the living room. Her moment was over.So I took the pacifier and placed it in a conspicuous place in her room, next to her crib, under some Pottery Barn track lighting. It matches our changing table carved from mammoth ivory perfectly, which is new also, but that's another review. It now sits proudly on display in her room, 3-carats of shining glory, unless we happen to be using it as a doorstop (which is more often than not anymore).If you've arrived, you need to tell the world, and this outstanding product is the perfect way to do so!!! Even though things haven't been quite as good for the last few years, once those house appraisels get back up there we should be just fine.

I do a lot of of fishing, mostly fly-fishing, and fishing for stripers, blues, and seatrout in the Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic coast with conventional tackle. I tend to buy gear that's on the bottom-rung of what I would consider to be "serious" fishing equipment, meaning stuff that can take a lot of abuse, but still needs to be cared for properly to really get the return on investment.This reel falls squarely into that category.I was looking for something to pair with a fairly nice 11' surf rod that I have, and did a lot of research before finally deciding on the Spheros. The only other reel that was in the running was a Penn (the model escapes me), but after cruising 3 or 4 forums I had read many complaints that the gears in the Penn were cheap and stripped far more easily than they "should." One thing was for sure though, everyone loves the more expensive Shimano surf reels, pretty much without exception. I pullled the trigger and made the buy.What I like:It seems to be very rugged and is put together well.The 10000 sized reel fits my medium-heavy surf rod perfectly. Although it's heavier than a fly rod and reel (so is a chipmunk!), it's very balanced and a good pairing.It holds a lot of line. I chose 16-pound test mono instead of 20-pound mono or braid. I'm not sure how much is on there, but it's a lot to say the least, maybe 280-300 yards or so.It has a sealed drag and cleans up easy, which is the name of the game in the salt.The spool and bail are very well balanced... retrieving line is a piece of cake even after your arms start to get tired from casting all day.It's servicable, and as far as I can tell parts are easy to get.It lays and throws line very well, I can get a pretty good cast off with a bait rig and 2-4oz sinkers.What I don't like:I really can't think of anything I don't like about this reel, especially at this price point. The problems that I have I think are more a result of my technique(!) and not anything to do with the reel.So far the largest thing I've landed from the beach with this reel was a cow-nosed ray that weighed perhaps 25-30 pounds. It made several runs and really did a great job of testing the drag, which worked flawlessly. I was able to tire and beach the ray, remove the hook, and release it unharmed. Anyone that's hooked into one of these can tell you that they can trash a low-end reel before you even realize what's on the hook!I've also used it for whiting, and was pleasantly surprised and how well this larger reel handled smaller fish. Croakers and spot (of course) also showed up.I would buy another of these without a second thought.

This is one serious thermometer. I've been using it in my workshop as well as around the house... anything really that needs an accurate temperature is a breeze for this puppy, on pretty much any scale that normal humans use on a routine basis. I've stuck it into a roast. I took my daughters temperature with it. I've used it to test the accuracy of other thermometers around the house.I think chemists and others that work with tight temperature tolerances will find this item very useful. For me, it's got way too much going on for most of my uses. I feel like my tasks bore this thermometer to tears, as if it yearns for a real challenge that I am unable to provide...Seriously, as thermometers go, this is tops. Heck, it's got a phone number for support.

I'm not 100% sure what I think of this guide. I like that it's a bit old-school in its layout, and I like that it covers some species of fungus that other guides don't, which for me is the reason I've bought so many of these types of books.I guess two things rub me the wrong way a little: the color plates are inserted together in the center of the book, which is fairly typical for this sort of book (black-and-white, paperback-style for the text and copy, while the plates are more expensive glossy color), but I find that cramming so many illustrations on each color plate makes for a confusing search, and I also feel like at this point in time they really should use proper photographs in these guidebooks. Because when identifying mushrooms, as the old phrase goes, the devil is often in the details, and paintings are great for a lot of things but details ain't one of them. Honestly if you have even a modest amount of experience foraging for mushrooms the chances of you mistakely eating something dangerous is slim anyway, but having an artist's version of a particular mushroom as opposed to a photograph of the real thing isn't helping much.In other words, I wouldn't want a beginner to use this.The other thing that confuses me is this: As an owner of a pretty good stack of mushroom guides (and an experienced forager), I can tell you that there are always discrepencies between the guides over the degree of edibility of some species of mushrooms. Usually though the discrepency is small, maybe one guide says something is edible, while another says edible but it gives a lot of people a headache or something similar. I found myself with this guide really taken aback by what I thought was WAY too much caution with some species... let me be clear also that this is my opinion. And mixing that degree of caution with the ambiguity of a painted color plate just sort of confused me.Besides those two things though, there is plenty of useful information in here. Which, when you're hunting for mushrooms, you can never have enough of.

I LOVE this MP3 player.It's fairly tough, the OS is intuitive, and it's easy to load on both Windows and LINUX systems (simple settings change). It also hold a pretty good chunk of music, a ton if you use the micro-SD slot.I'm very tech-savvy, but I'm also in my 40's and the idea of keeping my life on a smartphone has zero appeal. I like that I can put my music(or whatever) on here and just go, and I don't have to worry about losing a $xxx smartphone if it falls off me and onto a rock while I'm out running around!And on the subject, the actual "clip" on the Clip is far more than enough to keep this feather-weight device attached to anything. You could close a bag of chips with this puppy...Other than that it supports all the usual suspects, i.e. playlists, sorting, shuffle, etc... the interface is very clean and easy to read. I've been using mine pretty much continuously for maybe 4 months now; it's none the worse for wear.Good stuff!

I use this cable for connecting to my portable stereo, as well as hooking into my truck's stereo system.This is a fairly robust, tough cable that works really well. The stepped-down connectors allow it to fit into devices with tight tolerances, and the signal quality seems to be great, to me at least. It also stays plugged in, even if your devices are flying all over the place.What else can I say, it's a great cable.
So far this battery has been great, especially for the price. Holds a charge as well at the OEM battery, I haven't had a single issue - just a phone that's got plenty of juice!

For whatever reason, I've always been a bit skeptical of these types of chargers. Don't really know why to be honest with you. I can tell you one thing though... that has changed.The charger itself is perhaps 6" long by maybe 2.5" wide. It's fairly blocky/dense, and weighs quite a bit for its size.When you turn it on, the LCD screen tells you how much juice is left, and hitting the power again fires up the worlds longest-lasting LED flashlight. There are two USB-ports on top, near the LED bulb.I fully charged the unit while I was at work, and while it did take a bit of time to charge it didn't really matter, because it's a background sort of thing. I've charged a couple MP3 players (one was dead) and mine and my wife's phones several times, and it still has something like 74% of its juice left!This thing really is handy when you just want to charge something, but don't want to boot up your PC or whatever.It really works great, highly recommended!

I'm one of those guys that's never quite sure how well cooked my grilled foods are, so I always end up cutting a piece of something up to see for myself. This thermometer is quick, accurate, and priced right. It's nice to be able to know when something is at the right stage of cooking without guessing or destroying it!Nothing bad to say really, it's well constructed, does exactly what its supposed to, and does it well.Recommended for sure.

I've only had a chance to use it once, but it really does produce awesome-looking cookies!I'm having trouble coming up with anything to add to the other reviews, which are spot-on. Well made, durable, functions great!

Ice cream scoops are weird. It seems like all of them have something about them that falls short of perfection. I think the issue is that  some scoops work great with really hard ice cream, some with softer ice cream, and still other work better with ice cream that has tons of chunks of various things mixed in.This is a really great scoop for ice cream on the softer side. It's very solidly constructed and the handle scoop-release works like a charm. If I had to find a fault in it I would say that the spread-handle design makes it a little tricky to really bear down on the hard stuff and coax a scoop out. It can be done of course, just not as easily as say an old-fashioned scoop with no moving parts.That being said you could always leave it in hot water for a minute for a little extra help.For me, I like softer ice cream, and this scoop is golden for what I need it for. And it's actually quite sturdy despite the moving parts.

I like this grinder a lot... it's very solid, and as the other reviewers have said it produces a very consistent grind for that perfect cup of java.What really appeals to me is the cost-benefit analysis. I camp as often as I can, and we always bring really good freshly roasted coffee beans with us. Usually we end up also bringing someone's high-end grinder also. This grinder is not only tough as nails and gives a really great grind, it's also inexpensive enough that if got dropped on a rock and cracked up I wouldn't lose any sleep over it, I would just purchase another (which we can't say for the other one we usually bring).Well made, and it feels solid in your hands, I like it.

This thing is pretty cool. It comes with hardware to mount it to the frame of your bike (or whatever), and it's far more solid in construction than I thought it was going to be. This is not something you're going to want to use for day-to-day inflation, and filling up like a beach toy or something could take a long, long time, but if you need something to reliably fill a bike tire (or something similar, a football maybe) it will do in a pinch for sure.You know, other than that it just sort of does what any pump of this type does... just on a somewhat smaller scale. It's well designed, small enough to stay out of your way, and looks pretty cool also.

I "get" Rob Zombie's films, I just don't usually care for them. His films are deeply rooted in the dark psychological horror films of the 70's, where the future is bleak and good guys usually don't win... I've got to be in the mood for that sort of thing, and usually I'm not.I have to admit though that for "Lords of Salem" everything I saw and read was SO all over the place that I had to sit down and decide for myself exactly what this thing is. And I think overall, while it does have its problems, I have to admit that I liked it. My wife hated it--but I thought it was entertaining, and it stuck with me more than a lot of other "better" films. I love Gothic horror, and I crave novelty. This film has its share of both.It really does have a "Rosemary's Baby" sort of feel to it, but with one major issue: I really have to agree with a lot of these other reviews that Sheri Moon Zombie, at 43, is getting more than a bit long in the tooth for these sorts of roles. She's just too old, heck, it happens to all of us. In "Rosemary's Baby", I felt real empathy for the young and victimized Mia Farrow, attempting to make sense of what was happening around her. In "Lords", however, Sheri Zombie is really hard to feel anything for at all... I found myself thinking for most of the film that she looked and acted like an ate-up (and selfish) old junkie, so when she went out and finally copped some heroin, I just didn't care.BTW, people in NA, those who take it seriously at least, don't spend the rest of their time drunk. Call it a faux-pas, you just don't do that.With that being said, the only other issue I had was the bad CGI of everything melting at the end, during the whacked-out "concert" montage. To the film's credit, it doesn't use any [noticable] CG effects up until this point; it's very old-school in it's approach, which I like a lot... so when those effects were stuck in the end, it felt cheap, like a music video or something.My complaints are minor. The way I look at it, if I put on a film and that film keeps me interested until the end, then that right there is worth the price of admission. And this film did just that. The story, while somewhat cliché, kept me engaged. And I like that.

Recently my husband and I decided to get a divorce, and my goal is to make this process as painless and easy as possible for our kids. However, good intentions can often quickly go by the wayside when emotions are involved and so I bought "101 Things Not To Do In A Divorce" as a way to help me ensure that I do everything possible to make a successful and easy divorce. What I liked about Amy J Hutchinson's book is that it is down-to-earth and inviting, making you feel ready to take the step necessary for an amicable divorce. It really is just common sense tips and advice, but in this modern day of busy lives and emotionally charged relationships common sense doesn't always take a front seat. The book is smart, practical, straightforward and easy to read... helping to establish a solid foundation for you as you go through a divorce. Overall, this turned out to be a great choice for my future divorce plans and I'd definitely recommend it to others who are contemplating or going through a divorce and want to avoid a messy one.

For years now I have been interested in traveling by train around North America and seeing the sights, but until recently that hasn't been in the cards. However, when everything fell into place I started planning the trip and ran across "The Ultimate North America Train Travel Guide" which proved to be a great addition to the planning process. The guide offers readers a chance to get in depth information about all the train stations to be found (and which ones are a great tourist stop) to various national parks and tourist destinations nearby that could prove to be a wonderful choice in a stop on the itinerary. The author manages to keep the book casual and down-to-earth, including interesting bits of information that just made me want to get to the actual train vacation and not just the planning process. Overall, this was a smart buy that helped me make sure my family's train vacation around North America will be truly exceptional.

This was recently recommended to me and I have to say that "So Shall My Word Be" turned out to be a wonderfully uplifting and enlightening read that allowed me to delve deeper into the meaning, need and promise of prayer in an intriguing way. Sonya M. Barge delves into God, His promise, His Word and the connection that prayer creates... allowing us to live a more devoted and connection walk with God. The well-written book is insightful and thoughtful, providing a down-to-earth look at God's Word that managed to bring a great deal of forethought and wisdom to my understanding of prayer. I found the book to be well worth the read, making for a truly enlightening afternoon filled with prayer and a deeper, more fulfilling conversation with the Lord.

I have to say that when I first was recommended "The Plan" I wasn't sure if it was my cup of tea or not, but all too quickly I found myself swept up in Cindy's plan to seek revenge on the man she believed killed her sister.
